column2: LESSER--Saal D. (1924 - 2006). Died at peace of Alzheimer 's Disease on June 13, 2006. He was ever the adoring husband of Deborah (Silverman), doting father of Marc and Elizabeth Lesser, Robin and Chris Cordima, and Nina and Todd Insler and proud grandfather of Danielle, Madeleine, Matthew, Gabriel and Ethan. He served as Director of the Encampment for Citizenship, District Director of the Office of Economic Opportunity under Sargent Shriver and as the Executive Director the N.Y. State Division of Human Rights. Through his consulting firms , Saal Lesser Associates and EEO Compliance Services, he was a respected advisor and tireless champion of equal rights. He served as President of the YM-YWHA of Southern Westchester and as Civil Service Commissioner of the City of Mount Vernon. He was an honored athlete and a true friend. Contributions in his memory would be appreciated by The Southern Poverty Law Center or by Jansen Hospice, Tuckahoe, N.Y. His family and friends will gather to remember him on Sunday, June 18, 2006 at noon at Riverside Chapel 21W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, N. Y.

A chart in Business Day on Wednesday with an article about the clash between the Chandler and McCormick families over the future of the Tribune Company misstated the relationship between Harry Chandler and Gen. Harrison Gray Otis, who bought part-ownership of The Los Angeles Times in 1882. Mr. Chandler is a son-in-law of Mr. Otis, not a son. The role of Col. Robert R. McCormick at The Chicago Tribune was also misstated. Mr. McCormick inherited his interest in The Tribune; he was not a founder.
SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Malvin dear, remembering ouranniversary. You are, and always will be, a wonderful influence in my life. Love you always, Audrey

Is indie rock going spiritual? Last year's sensation, Arcade Fire, built an entire album around the idea of the funeral: the regret, the loss, the mystery and the life-goes-on. Now Band of Horses, a new group from Seattle that has a shimmering, guitar-drenched debut album, ''Everything All the Time'' (Sub Pop), also heads to the undertaker's for some rock 'n' roll salvation. The focal point of the record, the song ''The Funeral'' -- which, the band has said in interviews, is as much about death as it is about the dread of birthdays -- both soars and sulks, led along by sheets of electric guitars by Benjamin Bridwell (above, left) and Mat Brooke (right) that begin as teardrops and rise to majestic heights. ''At every occasion I'll be ready for the funeral,'' Mr. Bridwell sings in a voice high and thin, an acceptance that sounds both glum and joyous. The band makes a sweep through New York-area clubs this weekend, with Mt. Egypt and the Can't See as opening acts. (Tonight at 8, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, 212-533-2111; sold out. Tomorrow at 9:30 p.m., Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., 201-798-0406; sold out. Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Warsaw, 261 Driggs Avenue, at Eckford Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, 718-387-0505; $13 and $15.) BEN SISARIO

An article on Wednesday about the prison release of Abu Bakar Bashir, a militant Islamic Indonesian cleric, referred incorrectly to a senior Qaeda operative, Omar al-Faruq, who did not testify at Mr. Bashir's trials in 2003 and in early 2005 because the Bush administration would not allow Indonesian authorities to interview him. Mr. Faruq was transferred from C.I.A. custody to American military custody and then escaped from detention in Bagram, Afghanistan, in July 2005. He is not in C.I.A. custody.
To the Editor: You rate the quality of the different domestic spying bills currently being discussed as if the outcome really mattered.
STANGER--Hannah. On June 14. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Jacalyn and Cary. Loving grandmother of Rebecca, Henry and Rivka.

Months before arresting 17 suspects in an alleged terrorism plot this month, agents of the Canadian Security Intelligence Service warned some of the suspects' parents that their sons were adopting ''extremist ideology,'' The Globe and Mail reported. The accused, mostly in their late teens and early 20's, face charges of participating in a plot to attack Canadian landmarks and behead the prime minister. The approach taken by the agents to speak to the suspects' parents was in line with a strategy to scare off the accused by not hiding the fact that they were being monitored. ''C.S.I.S. officers had approached some parents to let them know that C.S.I.S. suspected their children were becoming adherents to an extremist ideology,'' a spokeswoman for the service, Barb Campion, told the newspaper. CHRISTOPHER MASON (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''A Leap of Faith, Off a Cliff'' (editorial, June 15):

The funeral mass will be at Our Lady of Czestochowa Church, Jersey City, on Saturday, June 17, 2006 at 10:30AM. Visiting will be at St. Peter's Prep Chapel, 144 Grand Street, Jersey City, NJ Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

STREETER--Frank S.The Board of Directors and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend, Frank Streeter, a wonderful and caring man who was deeply committed to community service and to better health care for all New Yorkers. He served as Vice Chairman of the Fund and was an active member of the Fund's Board since 1989. His dedication, enthusiasm, generosity, wise counsel, and gentlemanly ways will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife Nancy and his children, and to the Streeter family. Howard Smith, Chairman James R. Tallon Jr., President $(6$)STREETER--Frank S. The members of the Council of the Grolier Club are deeply saddened by the loss of Frank S. Streeter, a member since 1970, councilor from 1974 to 1997, and President of the Club from 1982 to 1986. We will sorely miss the friendship, guidance, and sage advice of this extraordinary bookman, and our condolences go to his wife Nancy, his family, and his many friends in the world of books. $(6$)STREETER--Frank S. 88, on June 12, 2006, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Nancy Angell Streeter. Devoted father of Ellen S. Rhodes (Craig), Ruth Streeter (John), and Meg Streeter Lauck (Dan). Cherished grandfather of nine, great grandfather of five. Memorial Service Tuesday June 20th at 4 P.M. at Saint James' Church, Madison Ave at 71st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to NY Presbyterian Hospital, Box 123, 525 E 68 St, NYC 10021.

IT takes a certain determination to visit the island of Vinalhaven, Me. Once you've made it to Rockland, halfway up the Maine coast along slow, winding Route 1, you're still a 75-minute ferry ride away. The ferry fits only 16 cars, and reservations are limited, so it's not unusual for motorists on a busy summer day to wait in line for two or even three of the six daily ferries to depart before securing a place on board. Once you're on the island, though, you are immediately aware of its natural beauty. It's a place of rocky shorelines, dense forests of pine and spruce, swooping sea birds and quiet, secluded coves.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Congress Debates Setting Deadline to Leave Iraq The House and the Senate engaged in angry, intensely partisan debate over the war in Iraq as Republicans sought to rally support for the Bush administration's policies and exploit Democratic divisions in an election year shadowed by unease over the war. A1 American military officers released a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi as the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia after Mr. Zarqawi was killed in an airstrike last week. A1 Nations Urge Talks in Somalia The United States joined five other countries in calling for negotiations between Somalia's government in exile and the Islamists who have seized control in Mogadishu and swaths of southern Somalia. A6 Afghan Bus Bomb Kills Eight A bomb exploded on a bus taking workers to the United States military air base at Kandahar in Afghanistan, killing 8 people and wounding at least 16 others, officials said. A10 Britain Offers Taylor a Prison Britain said that the former Liberian president, Charles Taylor, may serve his sentence in a British prison if he is convicted at his coming war crimes trial in The Hague. A14 U.N. Extends Hariri Probe As the United Nations Security Council voted to extend the investigation into the assassination of Rafik Hariri, Syrian officials expressed a sense that Syria was no longer in imminent danger of being charged with the crime. A6 NATIONAL A18-28 Election Year Focus Shifts To Suburbs vs. Exurbs In searching for any advantage in this year's hard-fought Congressional elections, the two parties are fighting with increased intensity in the suburbs and exurbs. A24 Limits to Improper Entry Rule The Supreme Court ruled that evidence found by police officers who enter a home to execute a search warrant without first following the requirement to ''knock and announce'' can be used at trial despite that constitutional violation. A28 Catholics to Reword Prayers Roman Catholic bishops voted to change the wording of many of the prayers and blessings that Catholics have recited at daily Mass for more than 35 years. A18 Conjoined Twins Separated Ten-month-old conjoined twins became two for the first time when doctors in Los Angeles made the final incision in a long and complicated operation to separate them. A21 Miami Schools Ban Cuba Book A children's book about Cuba will be removed from Miami-Dade County school libraries because a parent said it contains deceptive information and paints an idealistic picture of life in Cuba. A24 SCIENCE/HEALTH New Bird Fossils Uncovered Scientists have dug up fossils of a bird that lived 110 million years ago and looked remarkably like a small modern-day waterfowl. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Scarcer Housing in City For Middle-Income Families The number of apartments in New York City considered affordable to hundreds of thousands of moderate-income households plunged by nearly a fifth from 2002 to 2005, according to a report by researchers at New York University. A1 City Help for Day Laborers A panel is examining whether New York City should subsidize job centers for day laborers, most of whom are immigrants, to give them links to prospective employers and curb wage and workplace abuses. B1 New Front in Wiretap Battle The New Jersey attorney general has issued subpoenas to five telephone companies to decide whether they violated the state's laws by providing records to the National Security Agency. Experts say it is the first legal challenge by a state to the agency's efforts to compile calling records to track terrorist activities. B1 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-8 Miami Evens Finals The Heat defeated Dallas 98-74 in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals. Dwyane Wade scored 36 points for Miami to even the series 2-2, in the best-of-seven final. D3 OBITUARIES C11 Craig Morris An archaeologist who helped transform modern knowledge of the Inca civilization, he was 66. C11 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Bill Gates Charts New Role Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years, and he will shift his energies to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. A1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: The don't-bother-to-knock rule; islands apart; young, bored and heading for Parliament; politics begins at home. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E35 TV Listings E27 Weather B8

Arrangement Lehmann Maupin 540 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through July 14 Christian Hellmich, an accomplished young painter who lives in Cologne, Germany, works under the influence of the Leipzig School's curiously dour revival of Modernist representational painting. In drab colors on canvases measuring about 7 feet by 13 feet, Mr. Hellmich paints sharp-edged, well-composed pictures of empty modern architectural situations: a spacious train station; the entry to an apartment building below a wall of decorative tiles; industrial ventilators on a rooftop; the vertiginous view from the top of a high escalator down to a shadowy, subterranean hallway.

The Philadelphia City Council voted to ban smoking in most city bars and restaurants. The ban, which would take effect in January, would exempt some businesses, like neighborhood taverns that sell little food. The measure still needs the approval of Mayor John F. Street, but a Street spokesman said he did not know whether the mayor would sign it. Numerous city and state governments have already restricted smoking. GARY GATELY (NYT)

La Paix du Cul Marianne Boesky Gallery 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through July 1 The German artist Martin Eder makes large, splashy, semisurrealistic paintings bringing together images of scantily clad women from pornographic magazines and much enlarged kittens; sometimes the women have grotesquely misplaced limbs. Mr. Eder paints in a slick, Expressionistic manner that is a kind of stylistic equivalent of his kitschy, creepy imagery.

To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof is correct that over time, simple distributions of food and shelter won't help desperate communities in developing nations. Instead, the humanitarian aid groups that most effectively help victims of wars and natural disasters also hand out seeds and tools and provide training in advanced methods of farming, earning livelihoods and maintaining hygiene and water systems that together enable communities to become proudly self-sufficient. Cathy Skoula Executive Director Action Against Hunger New York, June 13, 2006

SIMMONS--Daniel, Sr.The Foundation for Ethnic Understanding mourns the passing of the beloved father of our esteemed chairman, Russell Simmons. Russell's tireless advocacy in strengthening race relations and promoting tolerance and understanding is an enduring testament to his father of blessed memory. Our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier,Pres. Tonio Burgos, V.P. Ken Sunshine, Secy. Lawrence Kopp, Exec. Dir.

Early music sometimes seems to make a political statement as much as an artistic one, particularly in New York, where the general view among aficionados is that we need more of it. Boston, by contrast, is an early-music bastion. And halfway between the two, in more ways than one, the Connecticut Early Music Festival, based at and around Connecticut College in New London, has an air of the homemade but honorable, with a respectably wide range of small and noteworthy concerts. This year's offerings (the festival runs through June 25) include the Renaissance ensemble Piffaro, playing music from Spanish and Portuguese cathedrals, and an evening of Bach cantatas and ''Brandenburg'' concertos to conclude the proceedings. (Above, a performance from last year's festival.) A highlight this weekend is a performance by the New York Baroque Dance Company, a group devoted to performing reconstructions of 18th-century dances; it appears on Sunday with the ensemble Concert Royal in ''Mozart and the Dance,'' a program that includes the only ballet Mozart wrote (''Les Petits Riens''), as well as a ballet suite from the opera ''Idomeneo.'' Even more unusual, in the early-music world, is a concert tomorrow that pairs it with early film: the eclectic Baroque/folk group Hesperus has devised a live soundtrack, with lute, viol, recorder and voice, to accompany the 1922 silent ''Robin Hood,'' with Douglas Fairbanks. (Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Sunday at 6 p.m., Evans Hall, Connecticut College, 860-444-2419; $20 general admission; $26 reserved seating.) ANNE MIDGETTE

The information box with the Havens column last Friday about the second-home market in Pawling, N.Y., gave incomplete driving directions to Pawling from New York City. Drivers leaving the city on Interstate 87 north should take the Saw Mill River Parkway to I-684. Stay north on it as it turns into Route 22; after about 12 miles, turn left onto East Main Street, which leads to the Village of Pawling.

In the call and response of these N.B.A. finals, the Miami Heat seized the moment away from the Dallas Mavericks with the aplomb of a Dwyane Wade drive and the determination of the 7-foot giant Shaquille O'Neal rising from a flagrant foul. The Heat players and their coach, Pat Riley, not only absorbed the Mavericks' first two blows in the series, they responded with a roar, routing the Mavericks, 98-74, to tie the N.B.A. finals at two games apiece.
To the Editor: It is important to recognize the developmental benefits of aid.

GREER--Linda.The Board of Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Health System (MJHS), mourn the loss of Linda Greer, beloved wife of our highly-regarded colleague and past honoree Leonard. We extend our deepest condolences to Leonard and his family. May you be consoled amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Lefkowitz, Chairman, Board of Directors, MJHS Eli S. Feldman, President and CEO, MJHS

The Center for Book Arts 28 West 27th Street, third floor, Chelsea Through June 24 The Center for Book Arts deserves a lot more attention than it gets. It's a combination of atelier, education workshop and conservation laboratory, with a small exhibition space. Its current group show, ''No More Drama: The Saga Continues,'' fulfills two fundamental goals of the center: it introduces new artists and stretches the definition of book over several media.

To the Editor: Your article about travel in the West, ''A New Look at the Old West'' (June 9), is incorrect in at least one particular. You'll find that very few historians endorse the opinion that Custer ever crossed the Little Bighorn or that he retreated. The battalion that crossed was led by Major Marcus Reno and he did indeed retreat, first to a stand of timber, and then across the river to the bluffs beyond. Custer led his battalion along the line of bluffs overlooking the river and, as far as can be determined, made only a feint toward the river at Medicine Tail Coulee. This was done with only a company or two of his five-company battalion. He then proceeded northward along the river before taking positions on Battle Ridge, at the northern end of which, on Last Stand Hill, the famous last stand was made. There is no proof that at any point in his own advance Custer was forced to retreat.

In a class-action lawsuit, the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused the Baltimore Police Department of encouraging arrests without probable cause to increase arrest numbers. The suit, filed in Baltimore Circuit Court, asserts that of more than 76,000 people arrested in the city last year, more than 25,000 were released without being charged. In a statement, Ralph S. Tyler, the city solicitor, said the plaintiffs would fail to ''prove their wild allegation that the police department has a policy of making arrests without probable cause.'' GARY GATELY (NYT)

RUSH--Montgomery. Montgomery was born March 2, 1969 to Patricia Adams and Geoffery Donald in WA. He lived life to its fullest until June 12 2006. He lived in NY, for many years, where he was truly at home. Recently he moved back to Seattle to be close to family and friends here. He lived a very full life in a very short time. Memorial service at Beck'S Funeral Home, Edmonds, WA. Tues., June 20 at 4PM. Visitation will be June 17 thru June 20.
FRANK--Shirley, 92, formerly of Kearny, NJ, on June 15, 2006. Survived by loving children Laurie Krotman, Meri Apfel, and Russell, and seven grandchildren.

To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof can carry his arguments about the effectiveness (or lack thereof) of United States foreign assistance an important step further by acknowledging the structural changes over the past 25 years in how nongovernmental organizations operate.

STARK--Stephen Henry,a financial consultant who managed the New York office of L.F. Rothschild & Co. and later held a number of other senior positions in the financial services industry, including, most recently, Senior Vice President at RBC Dain Rauscher, died on June 14, 2006 in New York City. He was 72. A Yale graduate and 50-year member of the New York Athletic Club, Mr. Stark's passion for his work and dedication to his clients remained constant during his nearly five decades in the industry. He continued to be actively engaged in his profession at the time of his death. Mr. Stark's professional success was mirrored in his personal life, where his grateful, loving family and many friends basked in his warm smile, sharp humor and generous nature. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Joan, his three children, Anthony (and wife Debbie), Sanford (and wife Miriam), and Victoria (and husband Richard), and grandchildren Gigi, Anthony, Alessandra, Angelica, Ella, Stephen, Josephine, Ryan and Sarah. He will be sorely missed but not forgotten by everyone who knew and loved him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The DOE Fund, 232 East 84th Street, New York, New York 10028 (212-628-5207). Services will be private.

WHO -- Gary Coard, 65, retired owner of a hardware store in Port Townsend, and his wife, Jean, 64, head of administration for an architectural firm WHAT -- Krogen 42-foot trawler WHERE -- Port Townsend, Wash. Gary: Ever since I was a child I dreamed of sailing around the world. I knew that I'd have to live frugally and retire early to make that dream come true. My goal was to retire at 50. I waited until 51.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about an agreement between Delphi Corporation, the auto parts supplier, and the United Auto Workers to extend a buyout program referred imprecisely to the role of General Motors. (The error was repeated in a front-page article on Monday.) While G.M. will pay the full cost of the first 13,000 buyouts that were offered, it will split the cost with Delphi for an additional 10,000 buyouts.

Hampton Island Preserve WHAT --Private residential development and club on a barrier island. WHERE -- Off the coast of Georgia about 45 minutes south of Savannah by car. AMENITIES -- A Davis Love III golf course and an equestrian center, among others. PRICES -- Home sites from $600,000 to more than $3 million; nonresident club membership is $250,000 plus $17,500 in yearly dues, which also apply to residents. STATUS -- The golf course's first nine holes will open in October, with the other nine to follow in summer 2007. All home sites and amenities will be available by 2008. DEVELOPER -- Hampton Island Preservation. CONTACT -- 912-880-8888 or www.hamptonisland.com. DETAILS -- This 4,000-acre island, with lakes and tracts of pines, live oaks and water oaks, was bought in 2003 to be developed as a private club and second-home community. There will be 163 lots, ranging from one acre to just over 100 acres, where buyers can build their own houses, and there will be 17 guesthouses for nonresident club members (a total of 393 memberships are available). The equestrian center will take advantage of the island's more than 900 fenced acres. Other amenities include a wine program run by Rob Mondavi, an organic farm, four spas and a hunting lodge. Freshwater fishing will be available, as will deep-sea fishing, with two amphibious planes shuttling members to a 31-foot sport fishing boat. A bridge links the island to the mainland, but the planes will also provide transportation. The Residence Club At PGA West WHAT -- Residential development at a golf destination. WHERE -- La Quinta, Calif. AMENITIES -- Five nearby golf courses, three private putting greens and a clubhouse. PRICES -- Starting at $259,000 for a one-ninth deeded share in a three-bedroom villa. STATUS -- The first villa was built last summer, and the rest -- a total of 32 -- are expected to be completed by the end of 2007. DEVELOPER -- Nadador. CONTACT -- 888-650-9200 or www.residenceclubpgawest.com. DETAILS -- This development is 25 miles southeast of Palm Springs and near five courses at both the PGA West club, which has been host to tournaments including the Skins Game, and the La Quinta Resort and Club, with courses designed by Pete Dye. The development itself features three 6,000-square-foot putting greens, and fractional-share owners will be offered discounts and privileges at the neighboring courses. The residences are all furnished 3,300-square-foot three-bedroom villas with jetted plunge pools. A clubhouse, to be completed in summer 2007, will have a pool and a fitness area with massage services. Owners can book up to 21 days a year in advance, with no limit to the time they may spend at the club, depending on availability. NICK KAYE Breaking Ground is a weekly look at projects, planned or under construction, that include weekend or vacation homes.

MYERSON--Raymond. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on June 12 of Raymond Myerson, beloved father of our friend and partner Toby S. Myerson. We express our deepest sympathies to Toby and to all other members of the family.

A light earthquake struck about 25 miles south of San Jose, shaking the much of Bay Area awake but causing no injuries or reported damage. The earthquake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 4.7, hit at 5:24 a.m. near San Martin, the United States Geological Survey said. The quake, on the Calaveras fault at a shallow depth of two miles, was felt in San Francisco, about 70 miles to the north. JESSE McKINLEY (NYT)

CHANGE AT MICROSOFT Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates announced that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years. He will shift his energies to running the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Mr. Gates said the transition would begin immediately, with his role as chief software architect taken over by Ray Ozzie, above, one of three chief technical officers. [Page A1.] STOCKS RISE Share prices turned up sharply in a broad rally that was fed by tame inflation remarks from Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke and that signaled a return of volatility to the market. [C1.] AIRLINES TO RAISE FARES Most of the nation's large airlines, emboldened by falling operational costs and soaring demand, said they would raise prices for many last-minute ticket purchases. [C1.] IN EUROPE, CHIEFS' PAY SOARS Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives. [A1.] TOUGH TRADE ASSIGNMENT Not many new cabinet members take office with a deadline of six weeks or so to succeed or fail. But that was what Susan C. Schwab faced as she was sworn in as the United States trade representative. [C1.] PHONE COMPANIES SUBPOENAED The New Jersey attorney general has issued subpoenas to five telephone companies to decide whether they violated the state's consumer protection laws by providing records to the National Security Agency. [B1.] TWO LABOR MOVEMENTS The nation's private sector is divided into two very different labor movements. The first consists of manufacturing unions, which are on the defensive and on the decline. The second is made up of unions for the expanding service sector, which are upbeat and on the prowl for hundreds of thousands of new members. [C1.] BATTLE FOR PORT COMPANY A heated battle to buy Associated British Ports, which controls 21 ports in Britain, is pitting Goldman Sachs against Macquarie Bank of Australia. [C7.] OIL WEALTH AND CHOLERA As Angola experiences an oil boom that is giving it more money than it can spend, the government appears powerless to contain a cholera epidemic. [A1.] EMI SETTLES RADIO PLAY CASE The EMI Group, the music giant, agreed to pay $3.75 million to resolve accusations of paying radio programmers to play specific songs, becoming the last of four major companies to reach a settlement as part of an investigation by the New York attorney general. [C3.] BEAR STEARNS PROFIT SOARS Second-quarter profit at Bear Stearns rose 81 percent, beating estimates, as strong trading results lifted its fixed-income business. Its shares rose nearly 6 percent. [C5.] OLD ADVERTISING MEETS NEW JWT, the oldest ad agency in the country, has purchased all the ad space on The Huffington Post home page for one week, starting tomorrow. [C5.] ENERGY GROUP DRAWS INTEREST More nations are eager to join the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, which groups China, Russia and four of their central Asian neighbors. The interest reflects the expanding power and assertiveness of its two largest members and their influence in the energy industry. [A12.] SUPPORT FOR TRIBUNE CHIEF Independent directors of the Tribune Company threw their support behind the company's embattled chief executive, criticizing a call by the company's second-largest shareholder to break up Tribune. A letter from the directors was delivered the day after trusts controlled by the Chandler family criticized a plan to buy back stock and sell some assets. [C3.] DEMOLITION DETRACTORS In a backlash against the trend of wealthy buyers' tearing down houses and replacing them with outsize second homes, communities are enacting stricter guidelines for home renovations and demolitions. [F1.] 30,000 G.M. BUYOUTS EXPECTED It appears that at least 30,000 union members at General Motors will opt for incentives to leave or retire. [C3.] ONLINE THE NEXT BEST THING DVD sales are expected to grow just 2 percent this year, a far cry from the double-digit growth the movie industry enjoyed just two years ago. A report is at nytimes.com/yourmoney. DEBT, THE AMERICAN WAY Americans moralize about debt, then they borrow. A report can be found at nytimes.com/magazine. AUDIO: ONE IMMIGRANT'S STORY As illegal immigrants have increased in numbers, so have the ranks of those who want to swindle them. A report is at nytimes.com/yourmoney. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE ONLY EXECUTIVE of the HealthSouth Corporation convicted by jurors in a $2.7 billion accounting fraud was sentenced to eight years in federal prison. Lawyers for Hannibal Crumpler, a former vice president and division controller, said they might appeal because of the harshness of the penalty. (AP) THE USG CORPORATION, a maker of gypsum wallboard, received court approval for a plan to emerge from bankruptcy by paying as much as $3.95 billion to resolve asbestos liability claims. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE H. J. HEINZ COMPANY said it was planning a vigorous campaign against attempts by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz to get the company to raise its profit. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

GUTTENBERG--Adele. The Board of Directors and staff of the JCC on the Palisades are greatly saddened by the passing of Adele Guttenberg, a beloved friend and supporter, who was devoted to helping those faced with physical challenges. Adele and her husband Bill established the Chuck Guttenberg Center for the Physically Challenged at the JCC, which provides invaluable programs and services for the entire community. Kind and generous, Adele always provided for the less fortunate and those in need. Our deepest condolences go to her dear husband Bill and the extended family. May her memory be for a blessing. Daniel Rubin, President Avi A. Lewinson, Exec. Dir.

House Democrats voted on Thursday night to strip a Louisiana congressman of a key committee position as they tried to avoid any taint of scandal in a year when they want to ride accusations of Republican corruption to election victories. The congressman, William J. Jefferson, is the subject of a federal bribery investigation and has insisted he has done nothing wrong. He has rebuffed efforts to get him to step aside voluntarily.

BARKER--Chrissie Head of communications for JWT in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, passed away Friday, June 9, after a brave battle against cancer. Over more than a decade at JWT, Chrissie worked passionately and tirelessly to ensure that the agency, its leadership and its work were portrayed in positive light. A former editor of ''Campaign'', the British trade magazine, and a columnist for the ''London Evening Standard'', Chrissie was highly respected and enormously networked within the industry. Her huge circle of friends from all over the world will miss her warmth, her sense of humor, her loyalty, and her joie de vivre. Full of curiosity, pluck and opinons, Chrissie's main passion was her love for her husband, Mike Townsin, and her children, Luke and Georgie. Like them, we'll miss her tremendously.

The Collection of the Sigmund Freud Museum, Vienna Austrian Cultural Forum 11 East 52nd Street, Manhattan Through July 8 After giving a work in 1989 to the Sigmund Freud Museum, Vienna, the Conceptual artist Joseph Kosuth, heavily influenced by Freud, the psychoanalyst, invited other artists to do likewise. Today the museum owns 13 works by 13 Freud-influenced Conceptualists of varying stripes, adding another dimension to the museum that is Freud's former apartment and consulting room at Berggasse 19.

ARCHER--Edward C. Died with his family at his side after a one-year battle with mesothelioma, in his home in Newtown, CT. on June 13, 2006. Born in Brookfield, CT. on December 19, 1940, he was the only son of Percy and Ida Archer. Orphaned at an early age, he was raised in Bethel, CT. by his aunt and uncle, Marie and Charles Meyers, and their four daughters, Jeanne Banks, Marian Meyers, Eleanor Hunt and Evelyn Meyers. He attended Immanuel Lutheran Grammar School and graduated from Bethel High School in the class of 1958. He received a Congressional appointment to the U.S. Naval Academy, in Annapolis, MD. He graduated in June of 1962 as a member of the 20th Company. Following his career at Annapolis he was assigned to the USS Witek out of Groton, CT. He served during the Cuban Missile Crisis and completed one tour in Vietnam in the Commander Destroyer Division 202. He was awarded the Navy Commendation Medal with Combat ''V'' and was honorably discharged with the rank of Lieutenant in May, 1967. He began his career at IBM in 1967 as a marketing representative in Hartford, CT. After holding a number of management positions during his 27-year career at IBM, he retired in August, 1994 as Vice President, Healthcare and Insurance Industries, ISSC. In June of 1989, he graduated from the Yale Executive Management Program School of Organization and Management. He was a longstanding member of the American Management Association and a member of the National Association of Corporate Directors where he was a Corporate Governance Faculty member. In 1994 he joined Pearl Meyer and Partners, Inc., an executive compensation consulting firm in New York City as Managing Director where he remained until his illness prohibited him from continuing his work. He cared deeply about all people, his family, his faith and his country. Always active in the church, he was a weekly reader during mass, frequent church volunteer and was elected head of the Parish Advisory Council at St. Mary's in Ridgefield, CT. He was a founding member of the Emmaus community in Ridgefield, CT, which is a religious retreat serving hundreds of teens in the community. He took great pride in his contribution to St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City, NY while serving as lector for Cardinal John O'Connor during the televised mass. He was most recently a devoted member and lector for the Church of St. Mary in Bethel, CT. He took very seriously his role as a mentor to high school students in New York City, a role in which he took great pride. His deepest love was for his wife of 42 years, Maureen Reynolds Archer (Bethel, CT), a friend and companion from the age of nine. He is further survived by his adoring daughters and their husbands, Jennifer and Kenneth Papa (Madison, CT) and Suzanne and David Croke (Simsbury, CT) and seven grandchildren, Matthew, Brendhan, and Bridget Kolf and Olivia Papa (Madison, CT), and Charles, Carolyn and Edward Croke (Simsbury, CT). Calling hours will be held from 3-7 PM on Sunday, June 18 at Bethel Funeral Home, Bethel, CT. A celebration mass will be held on Monday, June 19, 2006 at 11:00 AM at the Church of St. Mary, Bethel, CT, with burial at St. Mary's Cemetery, with military honors. Memorials may be made to Western Connecticut Regional Hospice, 405 Main Street, Danbury, CT 06810.

Wishy Washy Bellwether 134 10th Avenue, Chelsea Through June 24 The Clayton Brothers, Rob (born in 1963) and Christian (born in 1967), have received much attention for their entertaining, densely worked collaborative paintings mixing influences from graffiti and skateboard culture, underground comics, tattoo art, folk art and old-time circus banners. The paintings are packed to bursting with narrative action, graphic improvisation and echoes of artists like Barry McGee, Chris Johannson, Lari Pittman and R. Crumb. But the Claytons themselves are more clever recyclers of familiar styles than wildly original visionaries.

DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. (Carolyn Rubin), Director of Development and Public Affairs at The Rogosin Institute, died on June 14, 2006. Dr. Diehl embodied the spirit of The Rogosin Institute, where she directed the fundraising and public affairs office for 20 years. A caring and ceaselessly energetic individual, Dr. Diehl found great joy in extending warmth and concern to the patients and families that The Institute served. Dr. Diehl earned an undergraduate degree from Cornell University in 1946. She received her medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1950 with the distinction of being the first woman to rank at the top of the graduating class. She completed an internship at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis and residency training at The New York Hospital. Following her medical training, Dr. Diehl directed the Nursing Health Service at The New York Hospital for more than 20 years. She worked as an internist at the Hypertension Center/Physician Practice Plan with Dr. John Laragh before joining The Rogosin Institute in 1983. Dr. Diehl is survived by husband, Albert L. Rubin, M.D., mother, Estelle Diehl, son, Marc Rubin, M.D., daughter-in-law, Jennifer, brother, John Diehl and grandchildren, Sara, Matthew and Bryan. Funeral services are private. Family will receive friends on Sunday, June 18 from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Marc Rubin at 179 Hillside Avenue, Englewood, New Jersey. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorial donations be made to the Dr. Carolyn Diehl Patient Care Fund at The Rogosin Institute, C/O The Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, New York, New York 10021. $(6$)DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Medical College of Cornell University mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Carolyn Diehl, director of development and public affairs for The Rogosin Institute. She was the first woman to be top-ranked in her graduating class at Weill Cornell Medical College (then Cornell University Medical College), where she met her beloved husband, Dr. Albert L. Rubin. Affiliated throughout her career with the Medical Center, she was attending physician at the Hospital and faculty member at the Medical College from 1952 until 1981, and continued as an important institutional liaison thereafter. Compassionate and committed to the service of patients and medical research, she will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Diehl & Rubin families. Dr. Herbert Pardes President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

Court Allows Evidence Despite Rule Violation The United States Supreme Court upheld the use at trial of evidence found by police officers who execute home search warrants without first following the constitutional requirement to ''knock and announce.'' The 5-to-4 decision left uncertain the value of the knock-and-announce rule, which dates to 13th-century England. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote in the majority opinion that people subjected to an improper police entry were free to go to court and bring a civil rights suit against the police. But Justice Stephen G. Breyer, writing for the dissenters, said the court's ruling ''weakens, perhaps destroys, much of the practical value'' of the knock-and-announce protection. The decision followed a reargument less than a month ago, with the newest justice, Samuel A. Alito Jr., left, evidently casting the decisive vote. They're here, they're queer and they're celebrating life in the South Bronx and dance in general in this program of choreography by and for men. Presented tomorrow at 8 p.m. at the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, the event is part of ''Out Like That at BAAD!,'' an annual event during gay pride month. Arthur Aviles (above), one of eight featured choreographers on tomorrow's program, saw great possibilities in the South Bronx in 1999, when he began work on BAAD!, a center that he envisioned as a grass-roots locus for the arts and a home for gay artists and audiences. Life for gay people in the South Bronx was often not easy. The festival's title comes from a comment by a closeted gay man to the irrepressible Mr. Aviles that he was ''not out like that.'' Have things changed in the neighborhood? Mr. Aviles talks of being greeted with a kiss by a gay male friend on the street the other day, something that would not have happened five years ago. ''I guess I can speak for myself by saying that I feel protected by the macho men that I know in the area,'' he added. ''I honestly feel that the greeting the auto glass guys give to us every morning is warm.'' And is it now safe for boys to dance? Latino men have no problem with the salsa, he said, where they lead. ''Pointing one's feet could be looked at as suspect,'' he said. ''Suspect of what, you might ask? Well, maybe the answer lies in why we ask the question.'' (The Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, 841 Barretto Street, 718-842-5223 or www.BronxAcademyofArtsandDance.org; $15.) JENNIFER DUNNING

Michael Jordan, who had been trying to own an N.B.A. team since he retired, settled for a co-ownership position yesterday with the Charlotte Bobcats, joining Robert L. Johnson, the majority owner. But Jordan, a close friend of Johnson's, will take a more active role in the franchise. He will become the Bobcats' managing owner in charge of all basketball operations and personnel matters, Johnson announced. Jordan held the same type of position with the Washington Wizards from 2000 until 2003, when he was fired.

MCGUIRE--Brian James, 36. Of Greenwich died on June 12, as the result of a car accident. He was married to Marcie Leisenring McGuire and had two sons, Kevin, 7, and Jason, 3. A Managing Director and U.S. Head of Deutsche Bank AG's Structured Capital Markets Group, Brian was a leader in the structured finance field and managed a team of financial professionals in Deutsche Bank's New York office. Brian was a C.P.A. and a 1992 graduate of the University of Michigan, where he earned a B.B.A. and M.A. in accounting. Previously, Brian worked at Arthur Andersen in New York. In addition to his wife and children Brian is survived by his parents, Frank and Barbara McGuire of Howell, Michigan; a brother, Noel McGuire, his parents-in-law, Jim and Kay Leisenring of Ridgefield, Connecticut, and his grandmother, Ginny Jeter, of Clifton, Tennessee. Brian was also the loving uncle of three nephews. Brian's father-inlaw is a member of the International Accounting Standards Board and formerly the Vice Chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 18 at 1:00 P.M. at the Tomes Higgins House, 216 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Brian J. McGuire Memorial Scholarship Fund at the Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, 701 Tappan Street, Ann Arbor, MI. 48109. $(6$)MCGUIRE--Brian James, 36 The global community of Deutsche Bank mourns the sudden and tragic passing of Brian McGuire, a longtime friend and colleague. Brian was loyal, kind and generous, an admirable leader who will be greatly missed by the many people he touched. One of the most knowledgeable figures in his industry, Brian will be remembered for his extraordinary intelligence and unfaltering dedication to the people around him, but most of all for his warm personality and deep heart. Simply put, he was one of the nicest people you would ever want to know. We extend our deepest sympathies to Brian's wife Marcie, sons Kevin and Jason and to the entire McGuire and Leisenring families.

Thirteen people who say they were abused by Roman Catholic priests several years ago have filed a federal racketeering lawsuit against the Archdiocese of Philadelphia. The plaintiffs accused the archdiocese; Cardinal Anthony Bevilacqua, the archbishop from 1988 to 2003; his predecessor; and his successor of covering up the abuse. C. Clark Hodgson Jr., a lawyer for the archdiocese, said he had not seen the lawsuit and had no comment. Stewart J. Eisenberg, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, said he hoped to circumvent the statute of limitations by arguing that a cover-up continues, even if the abuse does not.

With the start this week of a $190 million earth-moving project aimed at reversing centuries of silting, the medieval abbey of Mont-St.-Michel, a jewel in France's architectural crown, will become an island once again. After Paris, Mont-St.-Michel, built 1,300 years ago on a craggy rock off the northwestern Normandy coast, is France's main tourist attraction, but the encroaching spread of surrounding mud flats has spoiled the island-like character of the Benedictine abbey, now cut off from the mainland only at very high tides.

The Millennium Challenge Corporation, an American aid agency that provides large grants to well-governed poor countries, suspended Gambia's eligibility, citing a sharp deterioration in press freedom, political rights and anti-corruption efforts. As elections near, the government has barred opposition parties from holding public gatherings and has arrested opposition leaders, according to Freedom House, a research group the aid agency relies on for country evaluations.

Vittorio Emanuele, 69, the last crown prince of Italy and the head of the House of Savoy, which ruled from 1861 to 1946, was arrested in the northern city of Lecco as part of an investigation into corruption and prostitution, the Italian news agencies ANSA and AGI and the state broadcaster RAI reported. The reports said investigators suspected him of having contacts with the Sicilian Mafia and of helping procure prostitutes for clients of a casino in Campione d'Italia, an Italian enclave situated in Switzerland. Vittorio Emanuele's father, Umberto II, was Italy's last king, serving after World War II for just a month until Italians voted to end the monarchy. Because Umberto's father, King Vittorio Emanuele III, had cooperated with Mussolini, Italy passed a law banning all male members of the Savoy family from Italy. It remained in force until 2002, when Vittorio Emanuele returned.

The Security Council unanimously voted to authorize the transfer of Charles Taylor, the former Liberian warlord turned president, from Sierra Leone to the International Criminal Court at The Hague to stand trial. He faces 11 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity in connection with Sierra Leone's civil war, in which 50,000 people were killed and thousands more were maimed. The Council action followed by a day a pledge by Britain to imprison him if he is found guilty, a decision that met a Dutch demand that he not remain in the Netherlands after his trial.

At the world championships in Verona, Italy, the two major team events began on Tuesday. The 173 teams that entered the Rosenblum Cup were divided into 16 sections, with four to qualify from each group for yesterday's round of 64. Only 39 women's teams entered the McConnell Cup, so the conditions of contest were amended. From four sections, 16 teams qualified, beginning knockout matches today. There were no major surprises in the qualifying stage, with all the fancied teams making it into the knockout stage. The diagramed deal was one of the most exciting from the round-robin matches in the Rosenblum. (After picking up this 1-6-0-6, on the next board South had 3-5-0-5, and that was followed immediately with 2-5-0-6 -- a distinct dearth of diamonds.) And this was the most bizarre sequence of calls and plays.

An article in Business Day on June 9 about stock options granted in June 2004 to three executives of Cyberonics misstated the value of the vested portion of the options. Based on the difference between the price at which the options were granted and the closing share price on June 8, the 38 percent of the options granted to the chief executive, Robert P. Cummins, that had already vested would have been worth $228,570 that day, not $601,500. The 38 percent vested value of the grants to the other two executives would have been $15,238 each, not $40,100. (In all three cases, the higher figure would have been the value of their entire grants, including the shares not yet vested.)

In 1970, the saxophonist Sam Rivers and his wife, Beatrice, opened Studio Rivbea in a loft on Bond Street in Lower Manhattan. Mr. Rivers was already an accomplished musician at the time he had toured with Miles Davis, made albums for Blue Note and taught at Wesleyan so this act of self-determination had more than a casual resonance. For nearly a decade, Studio Rivbea served the city's avant-garde jazz community as a performance space committed to an ethos of independence. The same principles, and much the same aesthetic, govern the Vision Festival, an annual summit of experimental music, art and dance being held this week at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts on the Lower East Side. Founded in 1996 by Patricia Nicholson Parker, a dancer whose husband, the bassist William Parker, is a Studio Rivbea alumnus, the Vision Festival has evolved into an impressively vibrant and well-organized affair. Fittingly, this year's edition bears a dedication to Mr. Rivers. Wednesday's program was billed as "Lifetime Recognition: Sam Rivers Day."

Despite the dwindling ratings for ''Game Show Marathon,'' the rest of CBS's tried-and-true Thursday lineup delivered the network a victory among total viewers. Reruns of ''CSI'' (11.1 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (10.4 million) compensated for ''Marathon,'' which brought in an audience of 6.8 million. But CBS placed third for the night among 18-to-49-year-olds, since younger adults preferred the N.B.A. finals on ABC and, second to that, Britney Spears's gum-chewing appearance on a special edition of NBC's ''Dateline.'' Basketball was broadcast live on ABC, and therefore its ratings were preliminary, but the overnight numbers showed that it drew a larger audience than Game 4 of last year's finals. NBC, which was third among viewers, showed repeats of ''My Name Is Earl'' (5.5 million) and ''The Office'' (5.1 million), ''Dateline'' (8.9 million) and the second episode of ''Windfall'' (7.8 million), the network's new scripted series. The lottery drama fell slightly from its premiere last Thursday, but beat ''Without a Trace'' at 10 p.m. in the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

LESSER--Saal D.(1924 - 2006). Died at peace of Alzheimer 's Disease on June 13, 2006. He was ever the adoring husband of Deborah (Silverman), doting father of Marc and Elizabeth Lesser, Robin and Chris Cordima, and Nina and Todd Insler and proud grandfather of Danielle, Madeleine, Matthew, Gabriel and Ethan. He served as Director of the Encampment for Citizenship, District Director of the Office of Economic Opportunity under Sargent Shriver and as the Executive Director the N.Y. State Division of Human Rights. Through his consulting firms , Saal Lesser Associates and EEO Compliance Services, he was a respected advisor and tireless champion of equal rights. He served as President of the YM-YWHA of Southern Westchester and as Civil Service Commissioner of the City of Mount Vernon. He was an honored athlete and a true friend. Contributions in his memory would be appreciated by The Southern Poverty Law Center or by Jansen Hospice, Tuckahoe, N.Y. His family and friends will gather to remember him on Sunday, June 18, 2006 at noon at Riverside Chapel 21W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, N. Y.

DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. (Carolyn Rubin), Director of Development and Public Affairs at The Rogosin Institute, died on June 14, 2006. Dr. Diehl embodied the spirit of The Rogosin Institute, where she directed the fundraising and public affairs office for 20 years. A caring and ceaselessly energetic individual, Dr. Diehl found great joy in extending warmth and concern to the patients and families that The Institute served. Dr. Diehl earned an undergraduate degree from Cornell University in 1946. She received her medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1950 with the distinction of being the first woman to rank at the top of the graduating class. She completed an internship at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis and residency training at The New York Hospital. Following her medical training, Dr. Diehl directed the Nursing Health Service at The New York Hospital for more than 20 years. She worked as an internist at the Hypertension Center/Physician Practice Plan with Dr. John Laragh before joining The Rogosin Institute in 1983. Dr. Diehl is survived by husband, Albert L. Rubin, M.D., mother, Estelle Diehl, son, Marc Rubin, M.D., daughter-in-law, Jennifer, brother, John Diehl and grandchildren, Sara, Matthew and Bryan. Funeral services are private. Family will receive friends on Sunday, June 18 from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Marc Rubin at 179 Hillside Avenue, Englewood, New Jersey. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorial donations be made to the Dr. Carolyn Diehl Patient Care Fund at The Rogosin Institute, C/O The Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, New York, New York 10021. $(6$)DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. The Board of Directors, Medical Staff and employees of The Rogosin Institute mourn the loss of Dr. Carolyn Diehl, our colleague and mentor. Carolyn, as she wished to be called by all, was an extraordinary woman. Her kindness, compassion and dedication to The Institute and its patients inspired us all. We extend our condolences to her adored husband, Dr. Albert Rubin, Director of The Institute, and to both the Diehl and Rubin families. We are grateful to have known Carolyn, and she will always be missed.

MONTI--Tita. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Tita Monti. Mrs. Monti, 85, a resident of Sands Point, NY, for more than 45 years, was an extraordinary woman with a generous heart and determination who revolutionized cancer care on Long Island. Just a few days after the 1972 death of her 16-year-old son Don Monti from myeloblastic leukemia, Tita and her husband, Joseph, founded the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation. Over the past 34 years, it has raised more than $30 million for cancer research, education, fellowship and patient care. ''The idea was to bring the best of care to patients suffering from this dread disease,'' she said in a 1996 interview. ''That means top quality medical care as well as compassion. Our division is like a family, even though it has grown so big. From nothing, tremendous things have happened.'' In 1972, North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, NY, was a community hospital. With the Montis' support and leadership, its cancer programs grew by leaps and bounds. As the hospital grew, the Montis' support grew as well - in fact a pavilion, the Division of Oncology/Hematology, a research laboratory and the adult bone marrow transplant unit are all named in Don's honor. The Montis underwrote all administrative costs of the Foundation. Mrs. Monti was by no means a figurehead on the Foundation's letterhead. For nearly three decades, she came to her office at the hospital five days a week, overseeing all details of the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation, both great and small. Her door was always open and patients often stopped by. Particularly close to Mrs. Monti's heart was the annual cancer Survivors' Day, which routinely attracts more than 2,000 attendees annually to celebrate life. Mrs. Monti was born Tita Scandalis in Pelham, NY, the daughter of Greek immigrants. She began playing piano as a child and performed at Carnegie Hall at the age of 11. Her singing voice matured and she became a dramatic soprano. She gave up piano to study and coach voice at the Juilliard School of Music. There, she met and married Joseph Monti, a tenor. Mrs. Monti taught school for a decade and then raised three children, Caroline, Don and Richard. Mrs. Monti was a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, a benefactor of Long Island University's Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, a member of the International Executive Board of Boys Town and Girls Town of Italy, and a member of the Board of Directors at LaSalle Center. During her lifetime, Mrs. Monti was recognized by many organizations for her outstanding contributions, including the Eleanor Roosevelt Community Service Award from New York State and the 1998 Ellis Island Medal of Honor Award. She also received a Doctorate of Humane Letters in recognition of her contributions to cancer care research, education and philanthropy. Mrs. Monti is survived by her husband of 62 years, Joseph, children Caroline Monti Saladino and Richard Monti, son-in-law Arthur Saladino, 10 grandchildren, six great grandchildren and sisters Bess Hatsis and Joan Tegtmeier. Visitation Fairchilds Funeral Home 1570 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, NY 11030 516-627-2001. Saturday, June 17 and Sunday June 18 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass at St. Mary's R.C. Church 1300 Northern Blvd. Manhasset, NY 11030 Monday, June 19 at 10:00 a.m. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to: The Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory 1 Bungtown Road Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724 $(6$)MONTI--Tita. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System is deeply saddened by the passing of Tita Monti, a legendary figure at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset who turned a family tragedy into a vision of hope and inspiration for thousands of cancer patients across Long Island. After the 1972 death of their 16year-old son, Don, from leukemia, Tita and her husband, Joseph, founded the Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation. Over the past 34 years, it has raised more than $30 million for cancer research, education, fellowship and patient care. With the Montis' support, North Shore University Hospital built a 10story pavilion and named its Division of Oncology/Hematology, a research laboratory and adult bone marrow transplant unit in Don's honor. Tita's memory will endure in the countless lives she touched with her kindness, commitment and dedication. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband Joe; son Richard; daughter Caroline Monti Saladino and the entire Monti family. Michael Dowling President and CEO Saul Katz Chairman North Shore-LIJ Health System $(6$)MONTI--Tita. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the loss of Tita Monti. Tita and her husband Joe, along with their family, have been longtime supporters of Long Island University and Tilles Center. Their generosity and commitment to education and the arts know no bounds. Our thoughts are with Joe, Richard, Caroline, Arthur and the entire family during this difficult time. Edward Travaglianti, Chairman of Long Island University Board of Trustees Dr. David J. Steinberg, Pres., Long IslandUniversity John R. Bransfield, Jr., COO Chairman Dr. Elliott Sroka, Executive Director, Tilles Center for the Performing Arts

The European plan would also pay ''emergency allowances,'' but not salaries, to some nurses, doctors and others in health care.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Public Broadcasting Service's hiring of an executive from KQED Public Broadcasting in San Francisco to fill the new post of chief content officer referred incorrectly to the stations KQED operates. It runs one PBS television station in Northern California and is part of a consortium that owns and operates two others and runs two National Public radio stations there. It does not operate all the PBS and NPR stations in Northern California.

ZUCKER--Dr. William. Died at his home in Philadelphia of renal failure on May 13, 2006. He was 88 years old. Dr. William Zucker was the Meshulam Riklis Professor Emeritus of Creative Management at the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, and the founder and director of the Wharton Real Estate Center. Previously, he was the President of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Economic Development Corp., 1964-1973; VP, Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, 1959-64; and, Secretary, Commerce and Industry Association of New York, 1944-59. Born in Bridgeport, CT, on July 21, 1917, he received his A.B from Johns Hopkins in 1938; his A.M. from Harvard in 1940, and his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1951. Dr. Zucker is survived by his wife, Kathlyn Saltman Zucker, and children: Peter Zucker; Alison Broadbent; Jeremy Zucker, David Zucker; and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Cathedral Village, 600 E. Cathedral Rd., Philadelphia, PA 19128, on Saturday, June 24th, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Habitat for Humanity-Philadelphia, 1829 N. 19th Street, Phila., PA 19121

TISCHFELD--Gerald. The entire AHRC Nassau family mourns the passing of our dear friend and business associate Gerald Tischfeld. We will miss this wonderful man whom we've worked so closely with all these years. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Tischfeld family. Michael Mascari, Executive Director, AHRC Tom Rosicki, President, AHRC Board of Directors Board of Directors, AHRC Nassau

To the Editor: Re ''In Diabetes, One More Burden for the Mentally Ill'' (front page, June 12): Walk into many psychiatric clinics and you may find a harmful holdover from the 1950's. No, not the cigarette machine, but the soda machine.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Pentagon Finds Abuse In Old Iraq Interrogations American Special Operations troops employed a set of harsh, unauthorized interrogation techniques against detainees in Iraq during a four-month period in early 2004, long after approval for their use was rescinded, according to a Pentagon inquiry. A1 The House approved a resolution promising ''completion of the mission'' in Iraq, in a vote reflecting partisan divisions over the war. A7 Two G.I.'s were missing and one was killed after they came under attack at a traffic point southwest of Baghdad, an area with one of the most extensive strongholds of Al Qaeda in Iraq, the military said. A7 Iran Scrutinizing Incentive Plan Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, said his country was ''carefully considering'' an international proposal to resolve the dispute over its uranium enrichment program. A5 No Verdict in China Trial The closed trial of a researcher for The New York Times accused of disclosing state secrets and fraud ended in Beijing but a verdict may not come for a month. A3 North Korea Works on Missile North Korea appears to have stepped up preparations to test an intercontinental ballistic missile, perhaps as early as this weekend, American officials said. A8 Rebels to Join Nepalese State Maoist rebels agreed to join Nepal's new government under an accord that obliges both politicians and rebels to give up key pillars of power, in a statement issued by the Maoist leader and the interim prime minister after a meeting. A5 Palestinian Aid Plan Gains Favor The Bush administration said it would go along with a European proposal to transfer funds through the World Bank to pay stipends to poor Palestinians, some of whom had previously drawn salaries from the Palestinian government. A4 NATIONAL A9-11 As Oil Rises in Markets, Rigs Rise in Mississippi The high price of oil, hovering around $70 a barrel, has brought a nearly dormant Mississippi petroleum industry roaring to life. Wells abandoned long ago by the major oil companies are being reopened by independent operators. A9 U.S. Still Far From Prepared States and cities in hurricane zones generally have better plans to deal with disaster than do other regions, but the nation's overall level of preparedness is still far from sufficient, a new report by the Department of Homeland Security says. A10 A Memorial for Columbine Construction of a long-delayed and scaled-down memorial to the victims of the Columbine High School shootings began with a ground-breaking ceremony and a speech by former President Bill Clinton commemorating the incident. A10 Report on Death of Journalist Firefighters, ambulance technicians, police officers and the staff at a Washington hospital committed ''multiple individual failures'' in responding to the ultimately fatal beating of a journalist last January, an official inquiry concluded. A9 Democrats Unveil Platform Democratic leaders in Congress announced the platform they hope to use to regain the majority in November, including promises to raise the minimum wage, make college tuition tax deductible, negotiate lower drug prices for the prescription plan passed last year, and eliminate subsidies for oil and gas companies. A11 Constitutional Showdown A showdown between Congress and the Bush administration moved into federal court, as a judge peppered lawyers about the legal and historic significance of the F.B.I.'s search for evidence of bribery at the legislative offices of Representative William J. Jefferson, Democrat of Louisiana. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 After Years in the Hudson, The Intrepid to Get Repairs The Intrepid, a World War II-era aircraft carrier that has served as a military museum and has been docked on the West Side of Manhattan for almost 25 years, will be dragged down the Hudson River to a dry dock sometime in the next several months to be patched up and repainted, its owners have told some government officials. A1 Charges in Cliffside Suicide Victor K. Han, whose stepped out of the family minivan before his wife drove it off a cliff in Bear Mountain State Park, killing herself, has been charged with promoting a suicide attempt, the police said. B1 Drop in 5th Graders' Scores More than 8,900 New York City fifth graders are in danger of being left back as a result of failing scores on annual reading and math tests, city education officials said, a sharp contrast with last year's results. B1 Religion Journal B5 ARTS B7-17 Dan Rather Exiting CBS Having stepped down as anchor of the ''CBS Evening News'' last year, Dan Rather's contract with CBS, and ''60 Minutes,'' is not scheduled to expire until late November. But he said he and the network were close to an agreement that would end his tenure early, and that he was seriously considering other opportunities. A1 Ancient Tomb Unveiled Hoping for leniency in a coming trial, an accused tomb robber led Italian officials two weeks ago to a startling discovery on a sun-scorched hilltop less than 13 miles north of Rome: the oldest Etruscan burial chamber ever found. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Restrictions at Wikipedia Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia that ''anyone can edit,'' is not the experiment in freewheeling, collective creativity that it might seem to be. In response to well-publicized reports that certain articles are being vandalized, administrators are now protecting some entries. A1 Microsoft Faces Challenges Microsoft stands astride the computing world much as I.B.M. once did, but now its task is to avoid repeating I.B.M.'s mistakes. Microsoft's revenues have never been higher, but it has yet to profit from the array of businesses that it has entered beyond those it has already dominated. C1 G.E.'s New Appliances As a result of its commanding position in the major appliance market, General Electric has a new line of products aimed at customers far more concerned with gadgets and style than utilitarian function. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: A problem that can't be ignored; where did the good investments go?; keeping the faith with AmeriCorps; the art of the deal. Columns: John Tierney. Bridge B11 Crossword B16 Obituaries C10 TV Listings B17 Weather B18

The Security Council unanimously voted to authorize the transfer of Charles Taylor, the former Liberian warlord turned president, from Sierra Leone to the International Criminal Court at The Hague to stand trial. He faces 11 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity in connection with Sierra Leone's civil war, in which 50,000 people were killed and thousands more were maimed. The Council action followed by a day a pledge by Britain to imprison him if he is found guilty, a decision that met a Dutch demand that he not remain in the Netherlands after his trial. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

SPANBOCK--Jane. We are saddened by her passing and wish to offer our condolences to her mother Lynne, brother Richard and nieces Emily, Bari and nephew Alex. Her sense of humor filled with wit, her compassion for others and her infectious smile lighting up a room are the memories we shall always remember. Rest in peace dear Jane. Barbara, Jon and Cathy, Jodi and David, Jimmy and Jill

PERLMAN--Al B., former Chief Moderator Stop-Smoking Programs for American Cancer Society's NYC and Queens Divisions, died June 5. Conducted clinics for nearly 100 firms in Metro area; helping thousands quit smoking and saving their lives. Former smoker and lung cancer survivor, Mr. Perlman was also a writer, primarily for non-profit organizations. Noted creator of super-complex logic puzzles appearing in prominent magazines. World War II vet. Graduate of George Washington University. Survived by nephews Jonathan Perlman, Steve Perlman, Paul Isenstadt. His wife, the former Rhoda Seltin, died in 1998.

MORRIS--Joseph. Long Island resident and Palm Beach snowbird. Father, husband, attorney, judge, Republican, Bayshore Jewish Center President, Cold Spring Valley Tennis Club founder, Union College and NYU Law School graduate. He loved tennis, bridge, his sons Jeff and Bob, wife Ethel now deceased, and sister Sylvia. He liked everyone he met and always kept a song in his heart along with a package of Sweet & Low in his wallet.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the release of lawmakers' financial disclosure statements misstated the location where Representative John Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, won $2,700 from slot machines. RUBIN--Carolyn Diehl. Her passion and her grace were an inspiration to all who knew her. Sylvan League

GUTTENBERG -- Adele Basch. Of Tenafly, New Jersey on June 15, 2006. In 1978, she with four other parents of developmentally - disabled children formed Spectrum for the Living , as an organization to provide housing, educationand adult training for the multiple-handicapped, developmentally disabled adults. Spectrum built it's first building in Closter, N.J. in 1982, a 48 bed barrier free Intermediate Care Facility with individual rooms for each resident. Today, Spectrum serves over 600 clients in three counties, operating 29 sites for the ICF's Group Homes, supervised apartments and adult training centers. She successfully lobbied the State of New Jersey to provide housing and educational opportunities for the developmentally - disabled. She also, successfully lobbied the Bergen County Board of Freeholders to provide education and training for teenagers and young adults. In 1994, Adele was honored by the Bergen County Business and Professional Women's Organization for her work with the physically-disabled and developmentally-disabled. As a result, she was cited in the Congressional Record by both Senator Frank Lautenberg and Congresswoman Marge Roukema. Congresswoman Roukema was quoted '' Mr. Speaker, I have first hand the results of Adele Guttenberg's efforts. The Spectrum for Living, an organization which Adele co-founded, provides housing, day care, work shops and quality of life opportunities for 250 clients. It is clearly a effective source of dignity and hope for the people it serves''. She and her Husband William, are major benefactors of Spectrum for Living, The Chuck Guttenberg Center for the Phyically Disabled at the JCC of the Palisades, and New Jersey Institute of Technology, chiefly for causes to assist the disabled. Each year, perpetually, they fund a four year scholarship to a disabled student at NJIT. Adele was member of Womens ORT and The National Council of Jewish Women. Survived by her Devoted Husband William, Brother Sheldon Basch and also survived by nieces and nephews. Predeceased by her two children Frances and Chuck Guttenberg. Services Sunday 9:30AM ''Gutterman and Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Contributions may be made to, The Chuck Guttenberg Center for the Phyically Disabled C/O JCC of the Palisdes, Tenafly, N.J. or Spectrum for Living, River Vale, New Jersey, would be appreciated.

10 P.M. (Sundance) PRIDE DOUBLE FEATURE -- The Sundance Channel celebrates Gay Pride month with a weekly series of double features. Tonight's lineup starts with the television premiere of ''Nowhere,'' (1997) by the writer and director Gregg Araki (''Mysterious Skin''), which looks at a day in the life of a wide (and wild) assortment of Los Angeles teenagers. Mr. Araki once called the film ''a 'Beverly Hills 90210' episode on acid.'' Next up, at 11:30 p.m., is Duncan Roy's 2002 autobiographical drama, ''AKA.'' Dean Page (Matthew Leitch, above left, with Bill Nighy) is a working-class teenager who becomes a con man mingling with a mostly gay rich set in Paris. 8 P.M. (Hallmark) BLACKBEARD -- (2006) The notorious rogue who terrorized the seas of the early 18th century comes to life in this swashbuckling made-for-TV adventure. Angus MacFadyen, right (''The Divine Secrets of the Ya Ya Sisterhood''), right is the bloodthirsty pirate, known as much for his violence as his appetite for women - he apparently had at least a dozen wives. 8 P.M. (ABC) LADY AND THE TRAMP -- (1955) In this Disney classic of hand-drawn animation, a privileged cocker spaniel - named Lady, of course -- falls for the streetwise mutt Tramp. Peggy Lee provided the voices of four characters in the film. 9 P.M. (CSPAN2) AFTER WORDS -- Andrew Kohut, the president of the Pew Research Center, discusses his new book ''America Against the World," and suggests that Americans' go-it-alone attitude has contributed to an increase in anti- Americanism around the globe. Brooks Jackson conducts the interview. 10 P.M. (CMT) IN THE MOMENT -- Hank Williams Jr. has been performing since he was only 8 years old - which makes you wonder if he ever does anything else. Well, he does! In ''Hank Jr.'s Guide to the Great Outdoors,'' he takes the rising country star Joe Nichols to Paris, Tenn., for a turkey hunt and introduces Lee Ann Womack to the joys of deep-sea fishing in Apalachicola, Fla. STEVEN McELROY

We're not ones to knock the competition, and we've always admired the feature writing at The Wall Street Journal, but the article in Friday's Journal titled "Kissinger's Guide to Watching the World Cup" comes across as hopelessly antique. The premise of the article: well-known soccer fan Henry Kissinger is a good person to guide Americans through the mysteries of that most foreign pastime. Or, as the article puts it: "With the TV at his Park Avenue office in New York tuned to the Switzerland-France match, Dr. Kissinger offers a tutorial on the fine points of soccer, a game Americans are notorious for failing to grasp."

Alberto Contador won the eighth stage of the Tour de Suisse, and his fellow Spaniard Koldo Gil Perez retained the overall lead. Contador traveled the 103-mile course, starting and ending in Ambri, Switzerland, in 4 hours 19 minutes 3 seconds.

The United States yacht Pirates of the Caribbean won the ninth and final leg of the Volvo Ocean Race yesterday in Goteborg, Sweden. The Dutch entry ABN Amro One took overall honors for the around-the-world regatta. The Dutch yacht, skippered by Mike Sanderson, was last in the six-yacht fleet in the ninth leg but won the 36,000-mile race with a total of 96 points.

Roger Federer moved into the final of the Gerry Weber Open with a 6-4, 6-7 (4), 6-3 victory over Tommy Haas in Halle, Germany. Federer moved a victory from equaling Bjorn Borg's grass-court record of 41 victories from 1976 to 1981.
