''DADA,'' heralded as the first museum exhibition in the United States to focus exclusively on this influential avant-garde art movement, opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday, its last stop on a tour that began in Paris and included the National Gallery in Washington. The show's more than 400 works -- collage, montage, painting, film, photography, sound recordings -- were made from 1916 to 1924, as a response to World War I and the emerging glorification of machine culture. They reflect the many forms of Dada, including Zurich's experiments in radical abstraction, New York's readymades and machine portraits, Berlin's political montages, Cologne's hallucinatory dream imagery and Paris's critiques of painterly traditions. Among the nearly 50 artists represented are HANS ARP, KURT SCHWITTERS, MARCEL DUCHAMP, GEORGE GROSZ, MAX ERNST, MAN RAY and HANNAH H√ñCH. Through Sept. 11. (212) 708-9400. MoMA's sister organization in Long Island City, Queens, the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, is about to unveil the winning project of the seventh annual MoMA/P.S. 1 Young Architects Program: it's an installation called ''BEATFUSE!,'' designed by the OBRA firm and opening on Thursday in P.S. 1's courtyard. Created by PABLO CASTRO and JENNIFER LEE, the design features seven curved, interconnected shells made of plywood and polypropylene mesh. Wooden tidal pools, water misters and a frigidarium -- using foil bubble insulation and ice -- will offer relief from the heat -- a blessing on Saturdays, when the courtyard is the site of the ''Warm Up'' summer dance parties. On view into September, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, (718) 784-2084. The COLONNA ALTARPIECE, painted by Raphael for a Perugino convent, was dismantled in 1663, its pieces scattered among several owners, including Queen Christina of Sweden, the Colonna family in Rome and the kings of Naples and the Two Sicilies. In 1901 the main panel and lunette were acquired by J. Pierpont Morgan for the startling sum of two million francs. Newspapers called it the most important painting to cross the Atlantic. Since 1916 it has been at the Met. An exhibition opening on Tuesday will reunite these pieces with the predella, the small narrative paintings that run along the bottom of the altarpiece. It will also display a group of Raphael's drawings and paintings produced around the time he painted the altarpiece. Through Sept. 3. (212) 535-7710.

UNTERMAN--Ruth. On June 13, 2006. We mourn the loss of Ruth Unterman of La Jolla, CA, beloved mother of our partner Lee Unterman. Our deepest condolences to the entire Unterman family. The Partners and Staff Kurzman Karelson & Frank, LLP

WITH fireworks season approaching, piping-plover madness is in full feather in this privileged playground. The federally endangered species, a mild-mannered shore bird whose progeny resemble powder puffs on stilts, is again holding the town hostage. Fishermen can't get access to their favorite inlets, at least not by vehicle. This indignity provoked one frustrated member of the town board to break the lock -- the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is NOT amused -- on the metal gate that closes off Sammy's Beach to a public accustomed to fishing there.

Think back several Wall Street scandals ago, to the mutual fund market-timing affair. After New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, uncovered dodgy practices in the industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission in 2004 sued three companies that advised Pimco's stock funds, accusing them of letting a hedge fund make $4 billion in improper trades in and out of its portfolios. The three companies named in that suit -- PEA Capital, PA Fund Management and PA Distributors, all owned by Allianz, which also owns Pimco itself -- settled the case a few months later, paying $50 million but neither admitting nor denying fault. Two executives named in the suit, however, pledged to fight.

Graveside services will be held on Monday June 19th at 1pm at Old Montefiore Cemetery in St Albans, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity in Richard's memory. McGRAW--Donald C., Jr, 81. Of Gulf Stream, Florida, passed away on June 11, 2006 after a long illness with heart disease and complications due to a stroke. He was married to Dorothea McGraw and is survived by three sons, Donald III ''Josh'', of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., Robert L.W., of Sheffield, MA, David W. of Osterville, MA., and thirteen grandchildren. Don was predeceased by a son, Peter S., of San Rafael, CA., and a wife of fifty years, Anne Williams McGraw of Osterville, MA. He was a WW II Navy veteran and was with McGraw-Hill Inc. for many years. Mr. McGraw started Nautical Quarterly and owned Soundings Publications. Funeral services are private and in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Mystic Seaport, The Museum of America and the Sea, 75 Greenmanville. Avenue, Mystic, CT. 06355

SHORTLY after he took command of the Continental Army in 1775, at the onset of the Revolutionary War, George Washington ordered the construction of a military camp and storage yard south of the Fishkill Creek, on a 70-acre parcel that now spans both sides of Route 9, near Interstate 84, in the Town of Fishkill. The Fishkill Supply Depot, as the camp came to be known, was the main provider of artillery and food for up to 4,000 troops stationed there to keep the British from moving past New York City and capturing the Hudson Valley, the town's historian, Willa Skinner, said. Despite its significance, the depot and its role in the war have faded into obscurity, while most of the land where it once stood has been developed.

The rumble of off-road vehicles -- and the vandalism, like litter and graffiti, that officials blame on the vehicles' users -- has long been a problem at Shoreham Beach, one of 12 town beaches in Brookhaven. But illegal off-road traffic cut utility lines to the beach in late May, forcing the town to delay its official opening at least until mid-July. The beach usually opens Memorial Day Weekend. All-terrain vehicles created deep trenches on town property, severing cables that provide electricity and telephone service to the park and making it impossible to staff the beach with a lifeguard, said Brian Pratt, the town parks commissioner. He said repairs would cost the town more than $40,000 and would take about a month to complete.

I happen to live in Atlanta, a city that offers multiple sources for organic food, including a Whole Foods and a Saturday market where I can purchase produce from nearby small-scale farms. I pay a premium for beautiful produce, and I want to support local farmers. My daughter lives just an hour east of Atlanta, on a much lower income. Yet she desires the same healthful options. Wal-Mart may be her only reasonably-priced source of organic food. It's fine for Michael Pollan to alert organic food consumers to the global consequences of Wal-Mart's entering the organic market. But I would dearly love to hear his strategy for bringing affordable organic food to average Americans who live outside major cities. Paula Refi Atlanta

To the Editor: I travel quite often for business between Los Angeles and New York, so reading Amy Gunderson's ''Food to Go; Long Flight? You Don't Need to Go Hungry'' (Practical Traveler, May 28) hit home. There aren't a lot of options out there for those of us who travel all the time, unless you like McDonald's cheeseburgers, that is. As Ms. Gunderson points out, several hotels are picking up the slack, which is great for guests who stay at them.

Jay Leno Finally some good news for the White House. Today, federal prosecutors told Karl Rove he will not be charged in the C.I.A. leak case. This is the best news for the White House since oil hit $70 a barrel. I'm sure you know, there's a big storm named Alberto heading toward Florida. See, even the hurricanes are getting smarter. They know a Hispanic hurricane has a better chance of getting into the United States.

BERNS - Sabine. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft President

COME September, a Jewish day school will be moving into its own home in Greenwich. That will probably not surprise the residents of Greenwich, who have long been accustomed to a splashy mix of faiths in town. But it is worth recording as another small milestone in America's advancing tolerance. Greenwich, one of the nation's most patrician towns, was a place where by many accounts Jews were not always made to feel welcome as late as the 1950's. While Greenwich has long had synagogues, a day school is a more emphatic statement of Jewish arrival, because a school will perpetuate the teaching of Judaism for generations.
To the Editor: ''Short Circuits,'' by Tim Mount (Op-Ed, June 11), asserts that deregulation is unsuccessful in achieving both lower electricity prices and higher prices to attract investment.

To the Editor: George Saperstein (''How to Support Your Local Farmer,'' Op-Ed, June 11) has pinned the future of Connecticut agriculture on raising and killing animals for food. There's evidently no irony in saving farms by developing premium products for the consumers whose homes and S.U.V.'s sit atop what was recently prime farmland or natural habitat. Dr. Saperstein received almost $1 million from the Department of Agriculture to sell the idea of guilt-free meat. Playing on people's concerns about animals' living conditions has created a niche market for higher-priced meat, milk and eggs, but it also forestalls broader ethical considerations. Giving animals more space while alive cannot compensate for their lack of freedom and untimely deaths -- in taxpayer-financed slaughterhouses, if Dr. Saperstein got his way.

To the Editor: In her review of Bill Buford's ''Heat'' (May 28), Julia Reed refers to the Mississippi Delta disparaginglyas ''a place where Italian red sauce is invariably referred to as 'spaghetti gravy.' '' Indeed, ''gravy,'' a more accurate translation than ''sauce'' of the Italian ''salsa,'' is the word of choice of Italian-Americans everywhere in the United States for pasta sauces, most typically, but not exclusively, tomato-meat sauce, known widely as ''Sunday gravy.'' Judith Bergoffen New York
To the Editor: Re ''The Philharmonic's Double Challenge'' [June 11]:

Hillary Dawn Ross, a daughter of Carol and Sander B. Ross of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel Roger Posternak, a son of Barbara and Michael Posternak of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the Jumeirah Essex House in New York. The bride and bridegroom have known each other since kindergarten in Armonk, and both are to begin studying for M.B.A. degrees this summer, she in August at Columbia and he in July at New York University.

Route 5 in Wallingford is a truly ugly stretch of commercial road, the value of which until now has largely relied on being able to test drive some of the sexiest cars in America. There are a number of car dealerships within a few miles of one another, and it is certainly not an area where one would expect to find great food. But camouflaged behind the unremarkable exterior of an equally unremarkable building is the Taqueria Mexico, where you can get a terrific nosh at gratifying prices while deciding just how badly you want that M3 convertible.

SHORTLY after he took command of the Continental Army in 1775, at the onset of the Revolutionary War, George Washington ordered the construction of a military camp and storage yard south of the Fishkill Creek, on a 70-acre parcel that now spans both sides of Route 9, near Interstate 84, in the Town of Fishkill. The Fishkill Supply Depot, as the camp came to be known, was the main provider of artillery and food for up to 4,000 troops stationed there to keep the British from moving past New York City and capturing the Hudson Valley, the town's historian, Willa Skinner, said. AT 1 p.m. last Wednesday, the staff of the Sagamore Hill National Historic Site finally achieved closure after 16 years of uncertainty. In a brief ceremony outside the brick and timber house where Theodore Roosevelt lived from 1885 to 1919, Mark J. Mershon, assistant director in charge of the F.B.I.'s New York office, handed over a small steel pistol to Amy Verone, chief of cultural resources at Sagamore Hill. The pistol, which was stolen in 1990 from the site, is believed to be the one that Roosevelt, then a colonel, carried in his historic charge up Kettle Hill in Cuba in 1898 as leader of the Rough Riders volunteer cavalry regiment in the Spanish-American War.

INGRAHAM--David Jr. Died suddenly on June 13, 2006, at home in Laurel Hollow, NY, at the age of 62. He was a graduate of Boston University and Columbia University Business School and a former Vice President of Smith Barney and partner at Lafer Amster & Co. He is survived by his mother Laura Jennings Ingraham of Hanover, NH, sister Alice I. Davies, Weston, MA, brothers Frederic B. Ingraham, Laurel Hollow, John W. Ingraham, Tulsa, OK, seven nieces and nephews, and many friends.

8 P.M. (Cinemax) THE MOON AND THE SON: AN IMAGINED CONVERSATION -- When the filmmaker John Canemaker interviewed his elderly father shortly before his death in 1995, he discovered a mass of contradictions: a man born in America but raised in poverty in Italy; a devout Catholic long associated with organized crime; a war hero convicted of arson; a go-getter unable to meet his dreams; a devoted father and husband whose rage decimated his family. In this Academy Award-winning animated short, Mr. Canemaker draws upon memory, fact and conjecture to create an imaginary conversation (by way of the voices of Eli Wallach and John Turturro) with his father and lay the ghost to rest. 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) AFTER THE ATTACK -- How do you stay alive -- not mention regain your dignity -- after, say, a mama grizzly decides to turn you into her mid-afternoon snack? This new series talks with outdoorsmen and women who discuss their close encounters of the worst kind. 8 P.M. (NBC) TREASURE HUNTERS -- In the midst of producing ''The Da Vinci Code,'' Brian Grazer, apparently working overtime, helped mastermind this new reality series in which 10 teams travel to historic locations around the world and decipher codes and puzzles, each with a clue leading them closer to a grand prize. What, exactly, that prize is, the people at NBC aren't saying. 8 P.M. (A&E) TOUCH THE TOP OF THE WORLD -- Born with a genetic disorder, Erik Weihenmayer was only 13 when he lost his vision. But that didn't keep him earthbound. This made-for-television drama starring Peter Facinelli (right) recreates the ascent of Mr. Weihenmayer, a high-altitude climber, to the top of Mount Everest in 2001, when he became the first blind man to do so. 10 P.M. (USA) THE DEAD ZONE -- In this Season 5 opener, Miranda, convinced that marrying Stillson will save Johnny's life, heads toward the altar. Johnny, convinced that marrying Stillson places Miranda in grave danger, races to stop her. But who will cross the finish line first? 10 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES -- Who's your daddy? Tanya (Zoe Lucker) asks Amber (Laila Rouass, left, with Ms. Lucker) to be the godmother of baby Troy, whose Greek-themed christening party is about to sink with the force of a thousand ships. 10 P.M. (HBO) ENTOURAGE -- It's always something. Ari and Eric try to keep Vince in the dark when rolling blackouts in the Los Angeles area threaten to submerge the box-office totals for ''Aquaman.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

PROVIDENCE ESTATES. Cottage Gate. The Village Grande. The parade of names goes on and on as you drive around western Monmouth County, N.J. Nearly every subdivision announces its presence with a rustic wooden or stone sign. The ritualistic naming of planned communities is nothing new -- anyone living in a Levittown knows that. But as hundreds of subdivisions bloom each year in the New York metropolitan region and across the nation, many of the seemingly most desirable names have been taken. So who is coming up with new ones? And is there a point?
To the Editor: Re ''A Changing Mass for U.S. Catholics'' (news article, June 16): Why is it necessary to change the spoken English of the Mass just to satisfy some Latin purists in the Vatican?

The release of ''NACHO LIBRE'' on Friday may not make big Hollywood stars out of its collaborators, JACK BLACK and MIKE WHITE. But if there's any justice in the world -- and if years of snot-and-poo jokes haven't deadened our collective funny bone -- this comedy about a Mexican monk who yearns to be a wrestler should make their reputation as two of our finest weapons of mass-comedy disquisition. The careers of these Southern California natives -- Mr. Black plays the tights-wearing monk and together they wrote the screenplay -- have been slow to boil. Mr. Black cut his teeth performing with the Los Angeles ensemble the Actors' Gang, making his feature-film debut as a wild-eyed conservative in Tim Robbins's satire ''Bob Roberts.'' In the years since, Mr. Black has employed those wild eyes to considerable comic effect in films like ''High Fidelity'' and ''The School of Rock,'' though not until now have his gifts as an actor, not just as a funnyman and stooge, been so blissfully evident. Mr. White, who wrote ''School of Rock'' for Mr. Black, once said of his rowdy friend, ''I think there's a sweetness to him that he's not able to show.'' There's more than a little sweet and sour to Mr. White, whose writing credits include both television (''Dawson's Creek,'' ''Freaks and Geeks'') and film (''Chuck & Buck,'' ''The Good Girl''). Like Mr. Black, a performer who happily lets his inner brat out to play and sometimes to rampage, Mr. White understands that there is both comedy and pathos in the divide between childhood and adulthood, and that what doesn't make you weep will surely make you laugh.

THE recently opened Connecticut Post 14 Cinema de Lux in Milford is giving moviegoers a new twist: top-shelf service that they cannot get at home. The theater, owned by National Amusements, is the first in the state to offer luxury service, the company says. For an extra $2 to $3 a ticket, customers enter separate auditoriums, called Director's Halls, where they are escorted to leather rockers that have been reserved for them, watch live performances before the movie and can order food from their seats.

A FORMER executive with Goldman Sachs and J. P. Morgan Chase paid $5.8 million this month for two adjoining apartments at 1 Main Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn. The two units, with a combined 4,790 square feet, have views of the East River and Manhattan. The buyers were Mino Capossela, the former executive, and his wife, Maura McDonnell. The building, a converted cardboard box factory between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, was the first in the area that the developer David Walentas converted to condominiums, about eight years ago. Since then the neighborhood has been completely transformed, with a binge of residential construction.

To the Sports Editor: Commissioner Bud Selig's open letter to baseball fans addressing the spread of performance-enhancing drugs among players is an outrage (''Selig Admits Baseball's 'Problems,' '' June 16). It asserts that the office of commissioner was created nearly 86 years ago to ensure the integrity of America's pastime.
PERLSTEIN--Harvey L. Daddy dear, our 46th Father's Day without you makes us so sad. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen and Suzanne

WOLF--Alfred C. Of McLean, VA and Wellfleet, MA. died June 9 at Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, MA of complications following a hip fracture. He was 94. He devoted his life to public service and to the welfare of his family, who mourn him deeply, including his wife of sixty years, the former Agnes Strauss, their four children: Sally, John, Steven and Andrew, and their four grandchildren: Alex, Tyler, Katie and Sage. Memorial services are pending. Donations may be made to the Class of 1934 Scholarship Fund, Harvard College Fund, 124 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, MA. 02138.
An entry on May 7 about the soccer documentary ''Once in a Lifetime'' in a list of coming summer films misstated the year the New York Cosmos were founded. It was 1971, not 1977.

Laura Heffernan Hogan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Hogan of Litchfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Anthony Trani III, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Trani Jr. of Brooklyn. The Rev. Robert F. Tucker performed the ceremony at St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Trani, 27, and Mr. Trani, 28, met at the College of the Holy Cross, from which they graduated, he magna cum laude. The bride is a staff assistant at Harvard Business School in Boston, where the bridegroom received an M.B.A. this month.

Ilissa Beth Weisblack, a daughter of Robin and Abraham Weisblack of Melville, N.Y., was married last evening to Robert Eric Zimmerman, a son of Marcia G. Zimmerman of Wynnewood, Pa., and the late Harris S. Zimmerman. Rabbi Ronald N. Brown officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York. Mrs. Zimmerman, 34, is the manager of Sweats Appeal, a Plainview, N.Y., clothing store owned by her father. She graduated from Ohio State.
To the Editor: Re ''If Train Riders Don't Mind Their Manners, a Commuter Group Will'' (June 11):

THE COAST OF AKRON, by Adrienne Miller. (Picador, $14.) This first novel, by a former literary editor of Esquire, is a tale of an eccentric family's meltdown. Lowell Haven is a charismatic self-portraitist who lives in a 65-room Tudor mansion in Akron, Ohio. When Lowell demands that his lover, Fergus, give a party in honor of his prot√©g√©, Fergus devises a guest list that includes Lowell's estranged ex-wife (who may be the true creator of his work), their promiscuous daughter and a dogged reporter determined to find out why Lowell mysteriously stopped painting five years earlier. ''When Miller lights the narrative fuse, her readers wait for the fireworks with heart-pounding giddiness,'' Elissa Schappell wrote in the Book Review.

Landing Lights Park in Jackson Heights, Queens, could be the city's least serene park. It is a patchwork of nine grassy lots southwest of La Guardia Airport, strung along a flight path, that provides the swath of clear land for jets required by aviation regulations. For those who live in the 90 houses around the park, life can be as unsettling as it was for Alvy Singer, the character in the Woody Allen movie ''Annie Hall'' who grew up beneath a Coney Island roller coaster. When air traffic is at its busiest, houses near the park are shaken every three minutes or so by the passing of a jet. Windows rattle and conversations turn into shouting matches. At such times, there is no such thing as a quiet walk in the park.

I WANT to be a good father, really I do. I try to make the right decisions. I try to be wise and nurturing, firm when I need to be. But after guiding four children through their toddler years, through school and now college, I am still a wimp when it comes to discipline. I can't help it. I hate to see them cry.

Beethoven: Symphonies Nos. 2, 6 London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Bernard Haitink. LSO Live 0082; CD. FRIENDS of the Beethoven symphonies tend to choose up sides: odd numbers here, even numbers over there. There does seem to be a difference in mood and character between the Second, Fourth, Sixth and Eighth Symphonies as opposed to the Third, Fifth, Seventh and Ninth, but it would probably take a team of musicologists and forensic psychiatrists to sort it all out.

IN the fall of 1992, a woman was in her apartment on West 16th Street in New York City when her boyfriend walked in with a gun pointed at him. The gunman had pistol-whipped him in the vestibule and taken his keys. Once in the apartment, he forced the woman to go around collecting money and jewelry. Forcing her boyfriend to watch, the gunman then raped her twice.

I WANT to be a good father, really I do. I try to make the right decisions. I try to be wise and nurturing, firm when I need to be. But after guiding four children through their toddler years, through school and now college, I am still a wimp when it comes to discipline. I can't help it. I hate to see them cry.

Because of an editing error, an article on June 4 about Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador, the former mayor of Mexico City, who is running for his country's presidency, referred erroneously to Mexico's oil and gas resources. They were nationalized in 1938; they are not now part of the private sector.

ANYBODY who didn't know better would think that there had been an accident or a grave illness in the family. How else to account for the steady stream of teddy bears, candy and cards that appear on the doorstep of the Jonas family? The unlikeliest explanation is the correct one: inside are three teen-age heartthrobs.

To the Editor: In ''Nice; Going Straight To the Source for Proven√ßal Cuisine'' (Choice Tables, June 4) I savored Mark Bittman's short list of some of the city's wonderful dining choices. I would add to the minimalist's list both a ''maxi'' and a ''mini.'' For the ''maxi,'' I would suggest a restaurant called Chantecler at the Hotel Negresco, which has one Michelin star. For lunch, it offers ''Le Menu Plaisir'' with unlimited wine for about $70; dishes like carpaccio de gambas, p√¢t√© press√©e with c√®pes, saumon mi-doux au feu de bois, and quince tarte with Granny Smith ice cream represent some of the choices. Our meal included unlimited white wine (C√¥tes de Provence) and red wine of the Vaucluse region.

PERLMAN--Al B., former Chief Moderator Stop-Smoking Programs for American Cancer Society's NYC and Queens Divisions, died June 5. Conducted clinics for nearly 100 firms in Metro area; helping thousands quit smoking and saving their lives. Former smoker and lung cancer survivor, Mr. Perlman was also a writer, primarily for non-profit organizations. Noted creator of super-complex logic puzzles appearing in prominent magazines. World War II vet. Graduate of George Washington University. Survived by nephews Jonathan Perlman, Steve Perlman, Paul Isenstadt. His wife, the former Rhoda Seltin, died in 1998.

DAVIDSON--Harlan ''Harley'' Lee Davidson, Jr. 47, died June 14, 2006, in Manhattan after a long illness. He is survived by a sister, Francesca ''Spain'' Cerutti, a half brother, Frank ''Reid'' Cerutti, a stepmother, Angela ''Bee'' Davidson, a half brother Andrew ''Plucky'' Davidson, a sister-in-law, Linda ''Kit'' Gaio-Davidson, a nephew, Will Franklin Davidson, a half sister, Claudia ''P.G.'' Siler, and a brother-in-law, Steve Siler. He was preceded in death by his loving mother and father, Anita ''Toni'' Cerutti and Harlan ''Big Guy'' Lee Davidson, Sr., his Aunt Doris Cerutti, and his beloved Dalmatians, Bos (the smart and very large) and Doc (the sweet and handsome, not so much a thinker). A friend to all dogs, Harley worked for many years as a professional dog walker and sitter at his company, Dog's Buddy. In his later years, he founded the Canadian Canine Cheese Council (CCCC), the first oversight committee for small, artisanal cheese crafters from Canada's finest dairy kennels. He was magnificently intelligent -- widely read in history, all branches of science, and fluent in four languages--yet he suffered fools gladly, always willing to buy someone a drink and listen with interest to their troubles. He was truly funny and generous to a fault, emptying his pockets for friends or complete strangers without hesitation. He liked to play cards, hearts and poker among his favorite games, bet the ponies, and could never resist a bowling alley. He also liked to fly-fish in Montana with his father and younger brother--to watch him cast a fly-rod was to know grace--but, like most things in life, even fishing failed to hold his interest for long, and he was apt to be found on the bank of the river, his fly-rod leaning against a shrub, his nose in a book. He was a loving brother, and while we could not save him, we would not have traded him for anyone else and will remember him affectionately all the days of our lives. In lieu of flowers or cards, please memorialize Harlan, by making a dog's day.

AT 1 p.m. last Wednesday, the staff of the Sagamore Hill National Historic Site finally achieved closure after 16 years of uncertainty. In a brief ceremony outside the brick and timber house where Theodore Roosevelt lived from 1885 to 1919, Mark J. Mershon, assistant director in charge of the F.B.I.'s New York office, handed over a small steel pistol to Amy Verone, chief of cultural resources at Sagamore Hill. The pistol, which was stolen in 1990 from the site, is believed to be the one that Roosevelt, then a colonel, carried in his historic charge up Kettle Hill in Cuba in 1898 as leader of the Rough Riders volunteer cavalry regiment in the Spanish-American War.

Denis Leary wears many hats. He is the star, writer and executive producer of the hit FX network drama ''Rescue Me,'' in which he plays an embittered New York City firefighter. He is also a comedian, a fervent hockey player and a philanthropist: his Leary Firefighters Foundation is raising money for rescue boats for the firehouses of New Orleans. But Mr. Leary has two less-known titles: speed shopper and down-to-earth dad.

To the Editor: Developers' plans to overcrowd Park West Village (''Ready or Not, a Neighborhood Gets a Makeover,'' June 11), to divide our diverse community into separate and unequal parts, have sparked a Boston Tea Party on the Upper West Side. Renters and condo owners from Central Park West to Riverside Drive are gearing up for a summer of protests against accelerated overdevelopment. Middle-class and working families must be able to establish and keep their homes in Manhattan.

To the Editor: Opponents of the landmark designation of the Fieldston enclave in the Bronx (''A Leafy, Scenic Enclave, and Now a Landmark,'' May 28) assert that there are two dozen styles of architecture there, and the works of six dozen architects. They seem to find that proof that the area was inaptly designated a historic district.

To the Editor: In Seth Sherwood's ''Is Qatar the Next Dubai?'' (June 4), the author describes the Muslim call to prayer, recited five times a day, as an ''incantation.'' This implies magic and superstition and is thus a very direct insult to the religion of Islam. Perhaps the word he was searching for was ''invocation.'' Robert B. Betts Al Kurah, Lebanon
To the Editor: New York was defined by people who came here hoping to make it. What will happen when the only people who can afford to come here are those who have already made it?

THE recently opened Connecticut Post 14 Cinema de Lux in Milford is giving moviegoers a new twist: top-shelf service that they cannot get at home. The theater, owned by National Amusements, is the first in the state to offer luxury service, the company says. For an extra $2 to $3 a ticket, customers enter separate auditoriums, called Director's Halls, where they are escorted to leather rockers that have been reserved for them, watch live performances before the movie and can order food from their seats.

Can You Turn a Flight Into A B.Y.O.B. Affair? Now that some airlines (especially United States carriers) are charging for drinks in economy, my wife suggests that on our next flight we take our own wine and sandwiches. Is this permitted? -- Brian Lewis, Stallikon, Switzerland While there is no formal recommendation by the International Air Transport Association against consuming your own alcoholic beverages on an aircraft, you may fall foul of national legislation and specific airline rules, according to William Gaillard, chief spokesman for the association in Geneva. Understandably, airlines want to monitor the consumption of alcohol onboard flights for reasons of safety and security.

RAPP--Morris (Morty). Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Alan and Susie Rapp, Bruce & Marie Ascher, Debra and Keith Waldman, Melinda and Mitch Greenberg. Loving grandfather of Eve-Lynn, Jake, Ava, Matthew, Jason, Diana, Daniel, Samantha, Gabrielle, Jade and Melissa. He was greatly loved and will be sorely missed. Services were held on Friday, June 16.

For New York voters who want to make informed decisions in November, this is an important week. The state legislative session is scheduled to end on Thursday, and there is an enormous agenda of unfinished business. As usual in Albany, everything is a tangled mess, with critical legislation lying boxed up in committee, or sitting in two completely different versions in the Assembly and Senate. A handful of powerful leaders, however, have the power to unwind just about anything if they care to do so.

To the Editor: Re ''Poland's Bigoted Government'' (editorial, June 11): You mention President Lech Kaczynski's strong condemnation of anti-Semitism in the incident involving me on the Sabbath afternoon of May 27. Not only the president spoke out against this incident.

To the Editor: My daughter (age 20) and I cannot thank you enough for the Streetscapes article highlighting the Croton Dam (''A Place to Savor the Torrents of Spring,'' May 21). We drove up there and it was magnificent. The setting, the dam, the rushing water, the park and thankfully the wonderful weather made for a wonderful day. It amazed us that such a beautiful site exists so close to our home and we had no knowledge of it. Dr. Harold Biller Queens

Mozart: 'Serenate Notturne,' 'Eine Kleine Nachtmusik,' 'Ein Musikalischer Spass' Le Concert des Nations, conducted by Jordi Savall. AliaVox AV 9846; CD. WAIT, can I still add to my list of favorite Mozart CD's? This is a delight, and not just for the works listed on the cover. Tucked inside is a superb recording of Mozart's ''Musical Joke,'' and a similar effervescent humor enlivens everything here.

To the Editor: Re ''When a Risqu√© Online Persona Undermines a Chance for a Job'' (front page, June 11): Certainly each individual is responsible for his or her own level of self-disclosure on the Internet. But it would well serve the companies that take the time to investigate their job applicants' online presence to remember that while each individual is unique, each name is not.

General managers, team presidents and other senior executives for the Knicks, the Liberty and the Rangers keep two offices: one at Madison Square Garden and the other at the Madison Square Garden Training Center in Greenburgh. In 2004, Madison Square Garden applied for permission to build a heliport on the grounds of the training center, to ferry officials back and forth quickly. Now the Greenburgh Town Board will meet on Tuesday to review a recommendation of the Town Planning Board to approve the heliport. The Town Board will then vote on it at a later date.
An Op-Ed last week, about electricity deregulation, misspelled the location of a major hydroelectric plant in New York. It is Massena, not Messina.

THE family farm is not dead in these parts. But it has been revised, perhaps by a well-to-do New Yorker or a land-rich Yankee. Nowadays, when you drive country roads, you are likely to spot strange and beautiful breeds, exotic livestock that exist, in some cases, as much for show as for consumption. Llamas and alpacas, which look like miniature camels, crane their necks over split-rail fencing and chew their cuds thoughtfully. Cream-white sheep grazing on brilliant verdured hillsides seem to have stepped out of a scene from Thomas Hardy -- and they have! -- since they are Cotswold sheep, imported from exclusive breeding stock in England. Gaudy peacocks and heirloom chickens race into the road, testing your brakes and patience.

KING--Judith Ann. Beloved wife of Frederick L. King, loving mother of Michele Denise King and Katiti King. Cherished grandmother of Schuylar Frederique and Tristan Thomas Lacey. A celebration of her life will be held at a later date.

Wheeler III, Anne Harrison Buchanan and Elizabeth Cromwell L'Hommedieu. Also survived by seven grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be at St. Johns Church, 61 Broad St, Elizabeth, on Friday, June 23, 2006, at 1:30 PM. Contributions in her memory to Jefferson Park Day Care Center, 485 Madison Ave., Elizabeth, NJ 07201; or Family Children's Service, 16 Jefferson Ave., Elizabeth, NJ 07201; or Visiting Nurse Service, 354 Union Ave., Elizabeth, NJ, 07208, will be appreciated.

His face was in their hands, if not on their minds. Luke Donald is the 11th-ranked player in the world, a rare 20-something holding his own against golf's best. As fans at the United States Open at Winged Foot Golf Club followed Tiger Woods (30), cheered Phil Mickelson (36), contemplated Colin Montgomerie (who will turn 43 on Friday) and tried to recall Steve Stricker (39), they held a glossy brochure with the day's pairings and a course map that contained a full-page bank advertisement featuring Donald.

THE big spring ritual at our place just happened: the removal of the swimming pool cover. The exact date of this ceremony is determined by the pool guys, who cast runes to determine when, in exchange for a hefty financial tribute, they will deign to drop by and perform juju on the pipes, mutter incantations over the filter motor, and otherwise awaken the machinery whose continued function is the difference between a pool and a concrete-bottomed fen. But before this can happen, we have to remove the cover, a leaf-collecting tarp under which the pool hibernates all fall and winter, and top up the water level. We know that the time to do this is approaching when the weather, which had been giving hints of spring, suddenly turns cold and gray and dumps shower loads of new rainfall onto the cover, making it sag even more and adding extra broth to the slurry of leaf mold already fermenting there. Getting this gunk out is an extremely nasty job, and I try to leave it for my wife.

CLEARED The News -- The special prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak case decided not to bring charges against Karl Rove. Behind the News -- Last fall, it seemed that an indictment on perjury charges was imminent for Mr. Rove, the president's senior adviser, as part of the leak investigation. The decision not to charge him eliminates a major distraction for the White House and allows Mr. Rove to focus on the midterm elections. But a cloud hangs over the executive branch: I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff and the only person charged in the investigation, is expected to go on trial on perjury and obstruction of justice charges in January. Mr. Cheney may be called to testify. PLEADED The News -- Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island pleaded guilty to driving under the influence of prescription drugs. Behind the News -- Mr. Kennedy, 38, the son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was sentenced to court-ordered drug treatment and probation in connection with a late-night car crash last month near the Capitol. After the accident he denied he had been drinking, announced he was addicted to prescription painkillers and checked into the Mayo Clinic for a month of treatment. For Mr. Kennedy, it was the latest in a long line of revelations of personal troubles; the effect on his standing among the voters of his home state is yet to be seen. APPEALED The News -- The Supreme Court made it easier for death-row inmates to challenge states on the issue of lethal injection. Behind the News -- The justices ruled in the case of Clarence E. Hill, above, a Florida inmate who had been scheduled for execution last January for the killing of a police officer. The court said Mr. Hill could challenge Florida's method of lethal injection under the Civil Rights Act of 1871, an appeals route with few obstacles. Death penalty opponents have questioned whether the drugs used eliminate pain. If not, they say, it is a cruel and unusual punishment. In their ruling, the justices gave no indication of where they stand on the issue. FREED The News -- Abu Bakar Bashir, an Islamic cleric linked to the bombings of two nightclubs in Bali three years ago, was released from an Indonesian prison. Behind the News -- American officials said they were disappointed in the release of Mr. Bashir, whom they consider to be an important operative for Al Qaeda. Mr. Bashir had served a little over a year of a 30-month sentence after being convicted of conspiracy in connection with the bombings, which killed 202 people. The judges in the case said Mr. Bashir knew the perpetrators and may have encouraged them. But as he returned to his hometown there were signs his influence may be waning: the crowd that welcomed him was far smaller than expected. SUED The News -- KFC was sued by a nutrition advocacy group seeking to have it stop using partially hydrogenated oils in its fried chicken and other foods. Behind the News -- The lawsuit by the Center for Science in the Public Interest came after the group had unsuccessfully petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to require warning signs in restaurants regarding use of the oils, a major source of trans fats, which nutritionists consider unhealthy. KFC said the suit was frivolous and that the company took health issues seriously. It said it was reviewing the use of alternative oils, but that maintaining the flavor of the original Colonel Sanders fried chicken recipe was important.

ZUCKER--Dr. William. Died at his home in Philadelphia of renal failure on May 13, 2006. He was 88 years old. Dr. William Zucker was the Meshulam Riklis Professor Emeritus of Creative Management at the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, and the founder and director of the Wharton Real Estate Center. Previously, he was the President of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Economic Development Corp., 1964-1973; VP, Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, 1959-64; and, Secretary, Commerce and Industry Association of New York, 1944-59. Born in Bridgeport, CT, on July 21, 1917, he received his A.B from Johns Hopkins in 1938; his A.M. from Harvard in 1940, and his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1951. Dr. Zucker is survived by his wife, Kathlyn Saltman Zucker, and children: Peter Zucker; Alison Broadbent; Jeremy Zucker, David Zucker; and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Cathedral Village, 600 E. Cathedral Rd., Philadelphia, PA 19128, on Saturday, June 24th, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Habitat for Humanity-Philadelphia, 1829 N. 19th Street, Phila., PA 19121.

Dr. Michele Ann Karron, a daughter of Barbara and David Karron of Encino, Calif., and Joshua Samuel Belkind, the son of Rachel and Myron Belkind of Washington, were married last evening in Los Angeles. Rabbi Eli Herscher officiated at the Hotel Bel-Air, and Cantor Nathan Lam took part in the ceremony. The bride, 31, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a small-animal veterinarian at VCA Petville Animal Hospital in Venice, Calif. She graduated from the University of Chicago and received her doctorate in veterinary medicine from Oklahoma State University.

The state's top education official was hired last week as superintendent of the Greenwich School District, a position she said would allow her to see some of the direct effects of her policies. Betty J. Sternberg, the commissioner of the State Department of Education, was unanimously voted into the post on Tuesday by the Greenwich Board of Education. She will begin her new job on Aug. 14.
DUNN -- Irving, M.D. We grieve this wonderful man, so loved by Renee and his beloved children Roark, Darin and Jenny/Ryan, and their families. Our thoughts are with you. Eisenberg Family

The distinctly Iberian flavor of Ferry Street, in Newark's Ironbound district, extends beyond the restaurants to the neighborhood's best-known food emporium, A & J Seabra's. Outwardly a medium-sized plain-vanilla supermarket, Seabra's is the place to stock up on Portuguese and Brazilian provisions you won't find anyplace else. The butcher shop, bakery and deli in the back is where serious shoppers congregate.

An article and headline on May 21 about films, plays and other works about the killings of women in Ju√°rez, Mexico since 1993, misstated the number of victims who have been raped and strangled, with signs of ritual murder. According to Mexican law enforcement officials, it is about 90, not 400. (Estimates vary, but 400 is the approximate number of women killed in all kinds of cases in Ju√°rez in that time.)

THE circumstances of President Bush's second visit to Iraq could be seen as a measure of progress for the country. His first trip, in 2003, began and ended under cover of darkness and was confined to a military base at the Baghdad airport. Last week, Air Force One landed in the afternoon, and Mr. Bush traveled by helicopter over insurgent strongholds to the safety of the Green Zone in the city center. Still, the visit was a secret even to the Iraqi Prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, until shortly before Mr. Bush's arrival. Both of his trips lasted only a few hours.

WHEN leaders of the Sri Venkateswara Hindu temple in Bridgewater gathered last month for another public hearing on their proposal for a larger cultural center, they felt confident that the township's Zoning Board of Adjustment would approve a variance for it at long last. Two previous series of contentious hearings had ended in ''no'' votes. The first led the temple to take the township to court. At the second, the board approved requests for an expansion of the temple itself and construction of homes for priests, but not for the cultural center.

THE family farm is not dead in these parts. But it has been revised, perhaps by a well-to-do New Yorker or a land-rich Yankee. Nowadays, when you drive country roads, you are likely to spot strange and beautiful breeds, exotic livestock that exist, in some cases, as much for show as for consumption. Llamas and alpacas, which look like miniature camels, crane their necks over split-rail fencing and chew their cuds thoughtfully. Cream-white sheep grazing on brilliant verdured hillsides seem to have stepped out of a scene from Thomas Hardy -- and they have! -- since they are Cotswold sheep, imported from exclusive breeding stock in England. Gaudy peacocks and heirloom chickens race into the road, testing your brakes and patience.

A NEW exhibition at the Sterling Memorial Library at Yale University details the life of Anne Morrow Lindbergh, the aviator, author and wife of Charles A. Lindbergh, in letters, photographs and books. The show, which opened last week, marks the first time Yale's collection of Mrs. Lindbergh's papers has been displayed. The exhibition also marks another milestone: If she were still alive, Mrs. Lindbergh, who died in 2001, would have turned 100 on June 22. Mrs. Lindbergh and her husband gave their letters and other historical materials to Yale, said Judith A. Schiff, the chief research archivist at the Yale University Library and the show's curator. The items in the one-room show on Mrs. Lindbergh, which runs through Sept. 8, were culled from more than 300 boxes of materials, Ms. Schiff said.

STARK--Stephen Henry ,a financial consultant who managed the New York office of L.F. Rothschild & Co. and later held a number of other senior positions in the financial services industry, including, most recently, Senior Vice President at RBC Dain Rauscher, died on June 14, 2006 in New York City. He was 72. A Yale graduate and 50-year member of the New York Athletic Club, Mr. Stark's passion for his work and dedication to his clients remained constant during his nearly five decades in the industry. He continued to be actively engaged in his profession at the time of his death. Mr. Stark's professional success was mirrored in his personal life, where his grateful, loving family and many friends basked in his warm smile, sharp humor and generous nature. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Joan, his three children, Anthony (and wife Debbie), Sanford (and wife Miriam), and Victoria (and husband Richard), and grandchildren Gigi, Anthony, Alessandra, Angelica, Ella, Stephen, Josephine, Ryan and Sarah. He will be sorely missed but not forgotten by everyone who knew and loved him. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The DOE Fund, 232 East 84th Street, New York, New York 10028 (212-628-5207). Services will be private.
GERSON--John June 16, 1923--June 20, 1997 Missing you every day. Edie

To the Editor: Jay Jennings begins his review of my book, ''Horsemen of the Esophagus: Competitive Eating and the Big Fat American Dream'' (May 28), by noting that my surname sounds ''like pasta'' -- a cheap ethnic joke that I'm surprised got past a phalanx of editors at the nation's paper of record. Jennings even hits the joke twice, referring to my book as the one that's written ''by the pasta.'' If Colson Whitehead had written a book about Southern cuisine, would you have let Jennings write that his name reminds him of a bowl of chitlins? Apart from being snide, the review doesn't begin to cover the bases. My book -- which was excerpted in The Atlantic Monthly -- is paired with another about eating contests that was written with very different intentions, even if both books did feature pictures of hot dogs on the cover. The problem with pairing the two books is that the generalizations that follow are baffling. Jennings knocks both of us for ''mostly'' avoiding questions of ''nationalism, racism, psychology and physiology'' because we don't have the requisite ''chops.'' I won't speak for the other book, but the middle third of ''Horsemen'' begins with a four-page interview with a prominent psychologist from the University of Pennsylvania and goes on, over the next hundred pages, to discuss the nationalistic overtones and class implications of a specific eating contest in Philadelphia. I also have an entire chapter on the physiology of eaters, featuring interviews with top gastroenterologists at Stanford University, Thomas Jefferson University and the Cleveland Clinic. The chapter is 20 pages long. It should have been pretty hard for Jennings to miss. My book centers on people who eat hot dogs for a living, but that doesn't mean it needs to be reviewed in the spirit of an especially boorish drive-time D.J. In assigning the review to a writer more interested in making smug jokes than engaging what I actually wrote, it appears that The Times was judging the book by its cover. Jason Fagone Philadelphia

Cards and stationery by Set Editions make letter writers look witty before they've written a single word, thanks to spare design and wry captions. The company, which is in Brooklyn, sells an elegant collection of paper, made mostly from recycled materials, that includes handmade letterpress and offset cards, foil-stamped cardboard invitations and a case of 25 little calling cards embossed with the simple directive ''Stop Talking.'' Both men and women will appreciate cards decorated with diagrams of knots, a pictorial history of guitars, lists of the seven wonders of the world, poker terms or the phonetic alphabet.

I WANT to be a good father, really I do. I try to make the right decisions. I try to be wise and nurturing, firm when I need to be. But after guiding four children through their toddler years, through school and now college, I am still a wimp when it comes to discipline. I can't help it. I hate to see them cry.

Summer is in the air, so it's probably only appropriate that many coming dance events concern heat and light. KIMBERLY BARTOSIK's ''HOME IN THE NEON HEAT'' involves both. A collaboration between Ms. Bartosik, a former Merce Cunningham dancer, and the lighting designer RODERICK MURRAY, the production divides space with light so that the audience beholds a fractured landscape filled with brief, physically intense and emotionally hot movements evoking a divided society and a world broken by war. Thursday through next Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, at Second Avenue, East Village, (212) 674-8194 or www.danspaceproject.org; $15. STEPHAN KOPLOWITZ, a choreographer known for productions in unusual spaces, is staging ''REVEALED'' inside a room-size walk-in camera obscura on the outdoor plaza of the World Financial Center. A camera obscura is a darkened chamber with an aperture through which light enters to form an image on the opposite wall. The device has fascinated artists and scientists for centuries. Mr. Koplowitz hopes his piece for 10 dancers will challenge viewers' perspectives on place and scale. Thursday through next Sunday at noon, World Financial Center, 220 Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505 or www.worldfinancialcenter.com. THE PASCAL RIOULT DANCE THEATER makes Mozart swing in Mr. Rioult's new ''IF BY CHANCE,'' to JACQUES LOUSSIER's reinterpretation of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23, which introduces jazz rhythms and improvisation into this classic of the keyboard repertory. The program also includes Mr. Rioult's version of Ravel's ''Bolero,'' in which, as the music boils with intensity, dancers suddenly freeze their motions. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Wednesday at 7 p.m., Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or www.joyce.org; $38. The Metropolitan Opera House will sizzle with passion on Thursday night when JULIO BOCCA retires from AMERICAN BALLET THEATER in a performance of ''Manon.'' Mr. Bocca, a dazzling technician and a compelling dancing actor, plays for his final role Des Grieux, who falls fatally in love with the ballet's title character (ALESSANDRA FERRI). At 8 p.m., Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000 or www.abt.org; $23 to $95.

The Your Home column last Sunday, about restrictions on displaying the American flag in co-op, condominium and rental apartment buildings, referred incorrectly to New York State's regulation of such decisions. The state does indeed address the issue under its Real Property Law, which prohibits condominium boards from restricting displays of the flag in areas under the exclusive control of unit owners, provided the flag is no larger than 4 feet by 6 feet; the law does not regulate rules on the flag in co-ops or rental apartment buildings.

BUSH--Irving T. Esq., 95, a veteran of World War II, died in his sleep Sunday AM in NYC. He suffered from Alzheimer's disease. During WWII, he served heroically in the Philippine Islands. An attorney at the time, having graduated 1st in his class from NYU Law School, and a graduate of Union, he then served on the Island of Japan during its reconstruction under General MacArthur, assisting in drafting the law of Bankruptcy and setting up Japan's Government. After his service, Irving returned to NYC to practice law, specializing in Labor Law & Real Estate. He invested heavily in NY West Village real estate. Nephew of Irving T. Bush, the President of the NY Bush Terminal Co.. He is survived by his wife, Virginia Casey Bush of Greenwich Village, NYC, his sister Barbara Bush Denson of Hebron, OH, and his brother Capt. James Ter Bush, USN (Ret) of Naples FL. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Cabrini Hospital, Att: Mary Cook, 227E 19th St. New York, New York 10013.

''I do not mind borrowing a spatula or spoon,'' says Eric Ripert, the chef at Le Bernardin. ''I will never borrow a knife.'' And thus was born the chef's case: a necessity for today's mobile cook. Some are elegant, like Alain Ducasse's handmade leather Goyard bag; others are utilitarian, like the toolbox belonging to Jacky Pluton, the chef at Pluton's in Chicago.

Suzue Kondou, 32, right, a data entry clerk from Fukuoka City, Japan, with her friend, Emiko Katahira, also 32 and from Fukuoka City. ''Kyoto was absolutely a different world. There are a lot of old buildings and many people walking in kimonos. I enjoy seeing old things and hearing about the old days. The history seems very close to people in Kyoto. In the costume, I felt like being a completely different person. People watched and aimed their cameras at us. First I regretted, then, gradually started enjoying being watched. I was totally a different person for three hours.'' As told to Makiko Inoue

To the Editor: As chairman of the National Academy of Sciences committee that wrote the report ''Alternatives to the Indian Point Energy Center for Meeting New York Electric Power Needs,'' the subject of your June 11 editorial ''The Indian Point Report,'' I must correct the impression some of your readers are likely to infer from the editorial.

PROVIDENCE ESTATES. Cottage Gate. The Village Grande. The parade of names goes on and on as you drive around western Monmouth County, N.J. Nearly every subdivision announces its presence with a rustic wooden or stone sign. The ritualistic naming of planned communities is nothing new -- anyone living in a Levittown knows that. But as hundreds of subdivisions bloom each year in the New York metropolitan region and across the nation, many of the seemingly most desirable names have been taken. So who is coming up with new ones? And is there a point?

Baseball has always been one of the least theatrical sports. Though there are occasional heart-stopping moments, in general the game's staging is static, with most of the players sitting or standing still for long periods; the action starts and stops; and compared with, say, basketball or soccer, the ensemble acting (otherwise known as teamwork) is minimal. Even one of the game's great achievements, a no-hitter, celebrates the pitcher's ability to send the batter offstage without doing much. Yet whether it's the metaphorical potential, the cultural status or the off-field drama, baseball has long been a theatrical favorite, from ''Damn Yankees'' to Richard Greenberg's ''Take Me Out.'' On Saturday seven writers will present their takes on the sport at the SEVENTH INNING STRETCH festival, an evening of 10-minute plays about baseball held by the Mile Square Theater in Hoboken, N.J. A baseball series makes sense for this town, which claims to be the site of the first officially recorded baseball game in 1846. (For the record the New York Base Ball Club defeated the Knickerbockers 23-1.) And Mile Square, a nonprofit theater founded by CHRIS O'CONNOR in 2002, has managed to line up some well-known veterans like CRAIG WRIGHT and EDUARDO MACHADO to share their new work along with a few rookies. Since pigging out with a beer and hot dog during the performance is frowned upon, you might want to attend a 6:30 preshow reception at the library at Stevens Institute of Technology. Just save the Cracker Jack for after the show. DeBaun Auditorium, Fifth and Hudson Streets, (201) 216-8937; $15 to $25, $50 with reception.

William Safire's discussion of ''fur ball'' (On Language, June 4), while instructive, neglected mention of the most common usage of this term, i.e., a cat's grooming residue that decorates my carpet from time to time. If Safire prefers to conduct original research on this matter, I have a kitten in need of a good home. David Gillmore Houston

To the Editor: In ''The Next Thing in Tolls?'' (June 11), Alain L. Kornhauser, a Princeton professor of too many titles to fit here, says it best: ''We can't build enough roads. And yet people expect to be able to use them whenever they want.'' Those darn people! Heaven forbid they should use the roads they paid for with their taxes.

Judith Anne Singleton and Nicholas Joseph Ehrmann were married last evening by the Rev. W. Edward Harris, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at the Indiana State House in Indianapolis. Mrs. Ehrmann, 28, is known as Annie. She was until last week a senior consultant in New York at Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm, where she helped design strategic simulations for corporate clients. In August she is to become a project manager at the Arkin Group, a risk-consulting and business-intelligence firm in New York. She graduated from Georgetown and received a master's degree in international affairs from Columbia.
An Op-Ed last week, about electricity deregulation, misspelled the location of a major hydroelectric plant in New York. It is Massena, not Messina.

The formal part of the classical music season ended -- just moments ago, it seems -- and the festivals are under way. At CARAMOOR the violinist JOSHUA BELL is the opening-night draw. He performs the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto -- a work suited to his sweet tone and shapely approach to phrasing -- with the ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S, led by PETER OUNDJIAN. The program includes the Overture to ''Pope Joan,'' a 1998 work by JOHN MUSTO, the festival's composer in residence, and the Beethoven Eighth Symphony. Saturday at 8:30 p.m., Katonah, N.Y., (914) 232-1252; $40 to $92.50. If a single work isn't enough Beethoven for you, the annual FRIENDS OF THE ARTS BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL on Sunday at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, N.Y., should offer ample satisfaction, and perhaps some frustration as well. Between noon and 4:30 p.m., for example, you might find yourself shuttling between Coe Hall, where EDWARD ARRON, the cellist, and JEEWON PARK, the pianist, play all of Beethoven's Cello Sonatas, and the Horticultural Center, where members of the Knights Ensemble begin an afternoon of chamber works with the ''Ghost'' Trio and the Quintet for Piano and Winds. The seven-hour festival includes an orchestral concert, at 5, in which the pianist JEROME ROSE will be the soloist in the Concerto No. 3, and the KNIGHTS ENSEMBLE, led by ERIC JACOBSEN, plays the Fourth Symphony. (516) 922-0061; $40 for the full day, $25 for the orchestral concert. The CONNECTICUT EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL, under way since the beginning of the month, offers several inviting programs this week, including a performance of Spanish and Portuguese works by the vibrant young wind ensemble PIFFARO. Saturday at 8 p.m., Evans Hall, Connecticut College, New London, (860) 444-2419; $20 and $26.

BERGER--Ronald. You were my big brother, my rock, my protector. You lived your life with honor and integrity. You were so handsome and strong and yet so modest and humble. I could not have been more proud to be your sister. Dad lived on through your grace, dignity and humor. I will miss and love you all the days of my life. Love, Janey $(6$)BERGER--Ronald. We are saddened to have lost our Uncle Ronny. No finer gentleman has ever lived. We will miss your grace, your warmth, your humor, and most of all, your love. We love you. The Konigsberg and Levy Families

Amy Danielle Vassalotti, the daughter of Christine M. Vassalotti and Michael J. Vassalotti of Haddon Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Jonathan Alexander Malen, the son of Mary Lee Malen and David L. Malen of Maple Glen, Pa. The Rev. Marguerite Sexton, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Union League of Philadelphia. Mrs. Malen, 28, is an academic performance specialist at the Oakland Unified School District in Oakland, Calif. She graduated from Princeton and received a master's degree in public policy from the University of California, Berkeley. The bride was in the Teach for America Corps and taught chemistry from 2000 to 2002 at Eastern Senior High School in Washington.

A picture caption on the table of contents of the Magazine today misstates the given name of an anti-smoking advocate. He is Matthew Myers, not Michael. The caption also refers imprecisely to the title of a tobacco-industry executive, Steve Parrish. He is a senior vice president of the Altria Group, not simply a spokesman for Philip Morris USA, one of its subsidiaries.

SHAPIRO--Jerry. 76, died on June 16, 2006 of complications from emphysema. He was a lifelong New Yorker and resident of Port Washington and Amagansett. In the 1970s he was President of the Hertz Corporation. In the 1980s he was President of Carl Ally Inc Advertising. Most recently he owned and operated several businesses headquartered in Port Washington. Throughout his life he was a superb chef delighting his friends and family with wonderful dinners. He loved the beach, fishing and sailing. He was devoted to Ayla, his new grandchild, his wife June, his daughter Kit and her husband Serdar Demirdelen. Services will be private. Donations may be made to the Emphysema Foundation, Claycomo, MO, in Jerry's name. $(6$)SHAPIRO--Jerry. We mourn the passing of our good friend Jerry Shapiro who will be sorely missed. We send our condolences to the Shapiro family.Richard Bernhard, Robert Bernhard, Howard Olian, Jerry Shore, Dan Simon

A SNAZZY new outdoor grill is being promoted this year. It has spacious ceramic countertops, a sink with running water, a refrigerator, rotisserie, six burners and a grill. I've heard that men are lining up to buy them; the luckiest will get theirs this weekend. It sounds like a kitchen to me.

LEWIN--Harry M. Lawyer and restaurateur. Resident of Palm Beach, FL. Born January 10th, 1920. Died June 16th, 2006. Son of the late Arthur and Sadie Lewin, he was the beloved and devoted husband of Estelle for 64 wonderful years. Adored father of Linda and David Taub and Blylee Gardiner and David Bernstein. Cherished grandfather of Andrew and Suzanne, Marc and Sandy, Josh and Lisa, great-grandfather of Jake, Chloe, Trevor, Camille and Asher. Brother of Norman and the late Richard. A graduate of NYU Law School, Captain the U.S. Air Force, Office of the Judge Advocate General. He became one of New York's most successful restaurateurs. He also served as Vice President of Leasing at Damart Enterprises for 30 years. Funeral services will be held at 1 PM on Monday, June 19th, at Gutterman's, Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY $(6$)LEWIN--Harry M. of Palm Beach, FL & Montauk, NY. Son of Arthur and Sadie Lewin. Devoted husband of Estelle Lewin. Loving father of Linda and husband David Taub, Marc & Sandy Taub and Joshua & Lisa Taub. Loving great grandfather of Jake, Trevor, Chloe, Camille & Asher Michael. Survived by his brother Norman of Phoenix, AZ. Died on June 16th 2006.A lawyer by training and practice, he was vice president of Damart Enterprises for the last 30 years. For most of his working career, he was a highly successful restaurateur as the owner of several New York ''landmark'' restaurants including The Old Homestead, The Pressbox, Manny Wolfs Chop House, Shines, The Assembly, and The Double Dolphin. He was associated for many years with Palm Bay Imports, a well known U.S. wine and spirits importer. He continued his active business career throughout his entire life. He treasured his close family ties and was a source of inspiration for his children, grandchildren and great grandchildren who in turn loved him deeply. He will be greatly missed by all. The funeral will be held on Monday, June 19th at 1:00 at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

TO what extent is William Kentridge, the South African illustrator, filmmaker and theater set designer, a political artist? At first glance his printmaking, the subject of a touring survey at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers, suggests something out of a Sergei Eisenstein epic: withering black and white imagery of the poor and downtrodden, satirical attacks on bourgeois society. But since Mr. Kentridge's international art world debut in 1997, at the Documenta X survey in Kassel, Germany, he has become one of the darlings of cravat-wearing collectors, curators and art world kingpins. Now 51, he exhibits with the choosy Marian Goodman Gallery in Manhattan, and his animated films have swiftly earned a place in museum collections.

To the Editor: Re ''The Road Back'' series (news articles, June 9, 12 and 14): As I listened to Dan Barry's online narrative and saw the photos of Highway 90, I couldn't escape the still-raw emotions that even after nine months lie just below the surface of my daily life.

VAN BUREN--James Martin II. Died at the age of 79, this past Monday, June 12, 2006, from natural causes at St. Vincents Hospital. He was preceded in death by his wife Margaret Ellen in 1999, and son Edward (Ted) in 1993. He is survived by a son Martin (Matt), daughter Katrina Van Buren Claghorne, son-in-law Edward, two grandsons, Justus and Edward, and other extended family members. After serving in the Navy and traveling extensively in Europe, he joined Time Life Corp. and its internationally influential Look Magazine division, spending a number of years on assignments in London and Tokyo among other countries overseas. Afterwards in Manhattan, he was involved in establishing the first financial printing division for R. R. Donnelly & Sons and Scott Printing Corporation where he remained for over 25 years, and finally with Command Financial Press. The great loves in his life beyond his family were Colgate University where he graduated in 1950, the Holland Society in NYC where he served in various leadership positions for over two decades, Kane Lodge No. 454, Free and Accepted Masons, and the traditional Martin Van Buren/ Rooseveltian/Democratic Party politics of Greenwich Village and upstate New York. Being a collateral descendant of President Martin Van Buren, Jim was an active supporter of the Martin Van Buren Museum in Kinderhook, NY. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, June 20, at 12:45 PM, at Grace Church, 10th Street and Broadway, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to either the Kane Lodge Foundation or the Grace Church memorial fund. $(6$)VAN BUREN--James Martin II. Kane Lodge #

Dr. Lauren Christine Harshman, the daughter of Dorothy Harshman and Thomas Harshman of Allentown, Pa., was married yesterday morning to Brian Hawks Stark, the son of Barbara Stark and Dr. James Stark of Suffolk, Va. The Rev. Dr. Robert Henderson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at St. Clements Castle in Portland, Conn. The bride and bridegroom graduated from Cornell, where they met.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Woman Breaks Pin Barrier by Making the Pro Tour'' (June 15): The reason Kelly Kulick wants to play in the Professional Bowlers Association Tour, just as Michelle Wie wants to compete on the PGA Tour, is money. Both professional tours have their female counterparts, but the prize money is different. The reason is that more people are drawn to the men's tours, which translates into more prize money.

To the Editor: In your June 4 editorial ''People Get Ready,'' you mentioned my homeland security report and the defensive reply by Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive. Missing from the editorial is what happened next.

Assuming an immigrant has committed crimes against humanity in his or her native country and extradition exposes this person to a significant risk of torture or death, the humane course of action is clear: a trial based on international justice with punishment to be served in the new home country or any country that abides by international rules of law and is willing to accept the convicted criminal. To return Kelbessa Negewo to Ethiopia would be criminal. Jerry Frankel Plano, Tex.

I WANT to be a good father, really I do. I try to make the right decisions. I try to be wise and nurturing, firm when I need to be. But after guiding four children through their toddler years, through school and now college, I am still a wimp when it comes to discipline. I can't help it. I hate to see them cry.

THE family farm is not dead in these parts. But it has been revised, perhaps by a well-to-do New Yorker or a land-rich Yankee. Nowadays, when you drive country roads, you are likely to spot strange and beautiful breeds, exotic livestock that exist, in some cases, as much for show as for consumption. Llamas and alpacas, which look like miniature camels, crane their necks over split-rail fencing and chew their cuds thoughtfully. Cream-white sheep grazing on brilliant verdured hillsides seem to have stepped out of a scene from Thomas Hardy -- and they have! -- since they are Cotswold sheep, imported from exclusive breeding stock in England. Gaudy peacocks and heirloom chickens race into the road, testing your brakes and patience.

Just in time for summer camp season, Boo! shampoo and spray conditioner by So Cozy promise to scare away lice and ticks. Designed for children and made of natural ingredients like tea tree oil, lavender and rosemary, the new products ($12 each at www.cozyscutsforkids.com) offer parents a way to keep the varmints out of their children's hair without harsh chemicals. But Dr. David Colbert, a New York City dermatologist, said, ''While a lot of the ingredients in these products could potentially ward off insects, this is a prophylactic measure, not a treatment.''

PORETSKY - Ruvim. Died yesterday, June 17, in New York. Born October 28, 1910, in Bobruisk, Belarus. He was a prominent engineer who, among many other important projects, participated in the design of Sputnik--the first man - made object launched into space. His life was deeply connected to the fate of his beloved city, Leningrad, in which he lived for over four decades. His heroic behavior during the historic 900 day siege of Leningrad was recognized by a medal, ''For the Defense of Leningrad,'' awarded to him at the end of World War II. He immigrated to the United States in 1979. He is survived by two sons and their spouses, Dimitry Poretsky and Anne Schroeder of Laguna Beach, CA, and Dr. Leonid Poretsky and Tony DiCarlo of Manhattan. Funeral service Monday, June 19, 11:30 am, at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, Madison Ave. at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Dr. Nina Poretsky and Ruvim Poretsky Memorial Fund, Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism, Beth Israel Medical Center, 317 East 17th St., 7th Flr., New York, NY 10003, Attention: Leonid Poretsky, M.D.

THE big spring ritual at our place just happened: the removal of the swimming pool cover. The exact date of this ceremony is determined by the pool guys, who cast runes to determine when, in exchange for a hefty financial tribute, they will deign to drop by and perform juju on the pipes, mutter incantations over the filter motor, and otherwise awaken the machinery whose continued function is the difference between a pool and a concrete-bottomed fen. But before this can happen, we have to remove the cover, a leaf-collecting tarp under which the pool hibernates all fall and winter, and top up the water level. We know that the time to do this is approaching when the weather, which had been giving hints of spring, suddenly turns cold and gray and dumps shower loads of new rainfall onto the cover, making it sag even more and adding extra broth to the slurry of leaf mold already fermenting there. Getting this gunk out is an extremely nasty job, and I try to leave it for my wife.

An article last Sunday about commercial development at Park West Village, a housing complex on the Upper West Side, referred erroneously to the occupation of Paul Bunten, a resident who criticized some of the changes planned for the neighborhood. He is not a decorator.

To the Sports Editor: Bernie Williams may be one of the great Yankees, but there is one area in which his behavior is less than great (''Around the Yankees, 2,000 Is Becoming a Significant Number,'' June 13).

For New York voters who want to make informed decisions in November, this is an important week. The state legislative session is scheduled to end on Thursday, and there is an enormous agenda of unfinished business. As usual in Albany, everything is a tangled mess, with critical legislation lying boxed up in committee, or sitting in two completely different versions in the Assembly and Senate. A handful of powerful leaders, however, have the power to unwind just about anything if they care to do so.

The sad spectacle of children bearing gift baskets to ingratiate themselves with casting directors was only one of the disturbing elements of Hollywood Elementary (June 4). The fractured families, thousands of largely wasted dollars and bizarre parent-child lifestyle described made for riveting reading. The story left me wondering who's the boss when the ''dreams'' of a prepubescent child can so control and divide her family? What of the siblings left behind, who may also have a dream: to live in a two-parent family in which they receive an equal amount of attention and share in the family fortune? B.A. Boyle Blairstown, N.J.

Beethoven: Piano Sonatas Nos. 30-32 Mitsuko Uchida, pianist. Philips B0006379-02; CD. THE grouping of Beethoven's last three piano sonatas makes more sense to concert programmers and record-company executives than it does to the inquiring ear. The opus numbers (109, 110, 111) are all in a row. And together the pieces fill a recital nicely or fit comfortably onto a single CD, as they do with Mitsuko Uchida's new release on the Philips label. Yet each piece is so different from the others, and each is such a tremendous earful of music in itself, that it may thrive more fully given space and isolation.

WITH the recent climb in housing prices, more buyers than ever have been faced with a dilemma: swallow a monstrous monthly payment and risk financial ruin, or settle for a less desirable, more affordable home. But bankers say homeowners need not face that choice as long as they are prepared for the possibility of spending their retirements paying off their mortgages.

The National Organization for Women has been handing out ''Women of Power and Influence'' awards for almost two decades, singling out women who are leaders in business, law and sports. The winner this year is Kathryn Ryan Booth, a senior managing director at Bear Stearns. Ms. Booth, known to her friends as Kay, is director of the firm's 400-member global equity research department. She will receive the award Wednesday at the Helmsley Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan.

Sooner or later, even bad boys grow up. Anthony Baratta, who is famous -- or infamous -- for the wildly colored, pattern-on-pattern, object-stuffed apartments he designed for himself in Greenwich Village and Miami Beach, has a brand-new pad. And here, in a 1,600-square-foot apartment in a renovated industrial building in Chelsea, he has toned things down. Way down. Of course, there are still the Classical statues (although not nearly as many), clashing patterns and confident juxtapositions of Victorian and modern furniture for which Baratta and his design partner, William Diamond, are so well known. But where there was once heat, there is now cool. The out-every-night provocateur has traded in his hot pink Gucci shirts and black calf's-hair coats for a more domesticated existence -- and for camel's hair, flannel and tweed. That goes for the upholstery too.
