BANHAM--Judith A. The Sunshine Group mourns the loss of a dearly loved and highly respected member of our family, Judith A. Banham. A founding member of The Sunshine Group, Judy's lead ership, wisdom and creativity, over 16 years, inspired and guided the development of properties that re-shaped the New York City skyline. An es teemed colleague, she will be remembered for her optimism, wit, intelligence and kindness. She touched each of us, as our mentor, friend, and trusted advisor. Judy will be deeply missed and remain in our hearts forever. The Sunshine Group

The upstairs galleries of the Beaux-Arts-style wing of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, completed in the early 20th century, have never been so appropriately adorned as they are now, with the paintings that make up ''American Splendor: Hudson River School Masterworks'' -- a glorious, robust assemblage of 120 works by artists from a movement that defined 19th-century American landscape art. Those who follow American art will find few surprises here, but will be rewarded with excellent examples of every major artist's work, all drawn from the Wadsworth's permanent collection. For others less well versed, the show offers a superb overview of the movement. Probably the simplest indication of the originality and importance of the Hudson River School artists is the extent to which they changed the way we see the American landscape. Threatening visions of an untamed wilderness filled 18th- and early-19th-century landscape art, but the Hudson River School painted a more benign country --ripe for exploration and settlement.

Evidently, $1 million does not go as far as it used to, at least in San Francisco. In its latest proxy statement, the McKesson Corporation said it had paid more than $150,000 in ''housing assistance payments'' -- words normally associated with subsidized-rent programs for the poor -- to three senior executives last year.

To the Editor: Your May 28 editorial ''A Hit or an Error?'' suggests that Gov. Jon Corzine ''take a hard look'' at the plans for a minor league ballpark in Bergen County. I invite him to do that -- just as the Bergen Cliff Hawks did with a comprehensive feasibility study. He'll find what we did: that Bergen County is hungry for affordable family entertainment. You also express concern about committing ''scarce public money'' to this project. But the public won't build the ballpark at Xanadu. The owners of Xanadu will build it as they promised when they sought to persuade the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority that Xanadu was more than just an oversize mall.

O'NEILL--Kathryn. A memorial service to be held 10:30AM, Monday June 26, St. James Church, 71st St. & Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers the family requests contributions to St. James Church or the Alzheimer's Association.

Low-key charm was the style of dress at the annual benefit of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden last Monday, with the occasional spectacular hat or the nostalgia of a rose wrist corsage. The 400 guests obviously preferred that the roses speak loudest, and the 500 new roses planted after the severe winterkill of 2004 were in full bloom. New also was the fully restored pavilion, top left, and the president, Scot D. Medbury, above, with Elizabeth Scholtz, a former director. The evening raised $370,000.

To the Editor: Although I was correctly quoted in ''Why It's Right to Test,'' by Peter Staley (Op-Ed, June 4), in speaking with the advocates I collaborated with on the H.I.V. testing program, I realize now that I misspoke.

Katherine Taylor Goodson, the daughter of Terry Decker Goodson of East Hampton, N.Y., and Peter David Goodson of Monterey, Calif., was married last evening to John Stuart Pavelski, the son of Marlene Sarton Pavelski and Patrick Michael Pavelski of Ho Ho Kus, N.J. The Rev. Darwin L. Price, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton. Mrs. Pavelski, 28, is a marketing manager at Real Simple, the magazine. She graduated summa cum laude from Princeton and received an M.B.A degree from Harvard.

To the Editor: It's good to see the remembrance of the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire in Katharine Weber's depiction of her family history (''The Fire That Time,'' June 4). Current residents of the Lower East Side are moved by the chalk notices written each year, on the anniversary of the fire, noting the names and ages of the victims on the sidewalk in front of their erstwhile homes.

THE recently opened Connecticut Post 14 Cinema de Lux in Milford is giving moviegoers a new twist: top-shelf service that they cannot get at home. The theater, owned by National Amusements, is the first in the state to offer luxury service, the company says. For an extra $2 to $3 a ticket, customers enter separate auditoriums, called Director's Halls, where they are escorted to leather rockers that have been reserved for them, watch live performances before the movie and can order food from their seats.

To the Editor: Re ''The Ascent of a Woman'' (June 11): Ooh, a pink leather handbag with a presidential seal. Where can I buy one? But first tell me why an otherwise thoughtful article on prospects for a woman for President was in Sunday Styles at all. That placement trivializes the topic, and Hillary Rodham Clinton's potential candidacy. Susan B. Hansen Professor of Political Science University of Pittsburgh Pittsburgh

O'BRIEN--Thomas Arthur. Passed on May 8, 2006 at 74. Raised in Washington Heights, Manhattan. He lived with outstanding style, spirit, class and always rose to the occasion. He is greatly loved and missed.

I enjoyed Wendy McClure's True-Life Tale (June 4) that chronicled the less-than-enthusiastic reception Brian Eno's ''Thursday Afternoon'' received in Rossi's, ''an amiable dive bar.'' I am concerned, however, that readers unfamiliar with Eno's work might accept the reaction of the bar's patrons as informed and legitimate criticism. In that setting, Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations would have evoked a similar response. '' Thursday Afternoon'' is an organically complex work best experienced through a quality sound-reproduction system, in an environment without intrusive noise that would obscure the myriad intricate details suspended through the recording's dynamic range. McClure's ''Ting . . . ting. . .ting . . .'' characterization of the piece, while not inappropriate in context, is analogous to reducing Beethoven's Fifth Symphony to ''da-da-da-DUM''; there's really quite a lot lost in the process. I hope your readers will not leave the denizens of Rossi's with the last word on this quietly sublime music. Randy Walters Bristol, R.I.

While Jim Henson, the mastermind behind the Muppets, died in 1990 at age 53, his legacy lives on. Lisa Henson, the co-chief executive (with her brother Brian Henson) of the Jim Henson Company, has paired the family business with 4Kids Entertainment to develop merchandise using their father's pre-Muppet designs. ''We love the vibe, if you will, of this artwork and how it can be applied to clothing, educational toys and games,'' she said.

DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. (Carolyn Rubin), Director of Development and Public Affairs at The Rogosin Institute, died on June 14, 2006. Dr. Diehl embodied the spirit of The Rogosin Institute, where she directed the fundraising and public affairs office for 20 years. A caring and ceaselessly energetic individual, Dr. Diehl found great joy in extending warmth and concern to the patients and families that The Institute served. Dr. Diehl earned an undergraduate degree from Cornell University in 1946. She received her medical degree from Cornell University Medical College in 1950 with the distinction of being the first woman to rank at the top of the graduating class. She completed an internship at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis and residency training at The New York Hospital. Following her medical training, Dr. Diehl directed the Nursing Health Service at The New York Hospital for more than 20 years. She worked as an internist at the Hypertension Center/Physician Practice Plan with Dr. John Laragh before joining The Rogosin Institute in 1983. Dr. Diehl is survived by husband, Albert L. Rubin, M.D., mother, Estelle Diehl, son, Marc Rubin, M.D., daughter-in-law, Jennifer, brother, John Diehl and grandchildren, Sara, Matthew and Bryan. Funeral services are private. Family will receive friends on Sunday, June 18 from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Marc Rubin at 179 Hillside Avenue, Englewood, New Jersey. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorial donations be made to the Dr. Carolyn Diehl Patient Care Fund at The Rogosin Institute, C/O The Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, New York, New York 10021. $(6$)DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. The Board of Directors, Medical Staff and employees of The Rogosin Institute mourn the loss of Dr. Carolyn Diehl, our colleague and mentor. Carolyn, as she wished to be called by all, was an extraordinary woman. Her kindness, compassion and dedication to The Institute and its patients inspired us all. We extend our condolences to her adored husband, Dr. Albert Rubin, Director of The Institute, and to both the Diehl and Rubin families. We are grateful to have known Carolyn, and she will always be missed. $(6$)DIEHL--Carolyn. Our hearfelt condolences to Carolyn's husband Dr. Albert Rubin, her family and colleagues at Rogosin Institute. She was a dear friend of our founder Henry J. Leir and all of us at the Foundations. Leir Charitable Foundations $(6$)DIEHL--Carolyn, M.D. The Dreyfus Health Foundation, a division of the Rogosin Institute, is greatly saddened by Carolyn's passing. She was an extraordinary person who enriched the lives of all around her. We will greatly miss her and extend our deepest sympathy to her family.

To the Editor: What a pleasure to see John Ford get a fair shake from A. O. Scott. It's worth noting that on the cover, that iconic shot of John Wayne holding one arm in the other, from the closing scene of the film, was a nod to a great western star of the 1910's and 20's, Harry Carey. That was his trademark pose, and he was Ford's first great collaborator. Wayne at that very moment was facing Carey's widow, Olive, who played Mrs. Jorgensen in the film. Loren Schoenberg Bronx

The column also inaccurately described a detail of the hotel's interior design. Old toilet tank brackets are not part of the d√©cor.
To the Editor: Let's have more From David Orr. Timothy Ferris San Francisco

There is a lot going on in Atlanta in December 1939. The long-awaited movie ''Gone With the Wind'' is having its premiere, which means, as Lala Levy points out, that ''Clark Gable is less than five miles from this house this very second.'' Ballyhoo is right around the corner. That's a gala end-of-the-year celebration attended by German Jews, not ''the other kind,'' as several characters refer to Jews from Russia or Eastern Europe. And of course it's Christmas. There is a prettily decorated tree in the living room, and Boo Levy says it's fine, except for the star on top, which, for a Jewish household, may be a little too direct a reference to Jesus' birth. Never mind that Lala is singing ''Noel'' as the play begins. There are stories in the newspaper about the trouble in Europe (''This Hitler business in Poland -- ain't gonna turn out good,'' says the one member of the household who seems to read a newspaper). But that unpleasantness will be studiously ignored by most of the characters in ''The Last Night of Ballyhoo,'' the Schoolhouse Theater's final offering of the season.

The United States Department of Homeland Security has expressed concern about the coverage of the new siren system that Entergy Nuclear Northeast is installing across four counties for its Indian Point nuclear power plant. Concluding a brief review of a preliminary design report submitted by Entergy, a Homeland Security official said this month that the network ''will not provide complete coverage'' of the 10-mile emergency zone surrounding the two reactors in Buchanan.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Pulse column last Sunday about swim shorts by Boden referred incorrectly to the geometric fish and blue wave swirl designs on the shorts. Each is a distinct design; they are not part of the same pattern.

THE family farm is not dead in these parts. But it has been revised, perhaps by a well-to-do New Yorker or a land-rich Yankee. Nowadays, when you drive country roads, you are likely to spot strange and beautiful breeds, exotic livestock that exist, in some cases, as much for show as for consumption. Llamas and alpacas, which look like miniature camels, crane their necks over split-rail fencing and chew their cuds thoughtfully. Cream-white sheep grazing on brilliant verdured hillsides seem to have stepped out of a scene from Thomas Hardy -- and they have! -- since they are Cotswold sheep, imported from exclusive breeding stock in England. Gaudy peacocks and heirloom chickens race into the road, testing your brakes and patience.
SMITH--Philip. Five years. Always with us. We love and miss you. Michael and Jeffrey

What's a fence between good neighbors? To the United States government in considering Mexico, it's sophisticated but pretty straightforward: the plans may incorporate so much high technology that the fence is more virtual than real, but in the end it is an imposing barrier, intended to repel, not attract. To architects and designers, such a fence poses a different challenge, but one they often face in their line of work: making the unwelcome welcoming. William L. Hamilton, a reporter for The New York Times, asked a handful of designers to devise a fence for the border. Their disparate visions are depicted on Page 14.

THE morning constitutional that Jerry Stabile likes to take while his wife is at 8:30 Mass at St. Henry's used to take him straight down Broadway, the central artery in his hometown, Bayonne. Lately, though, it has taken him to a place he hasn't been since he was a boy. ''Right there,'' he said, gesturing toward the finger of tidal water that separates the new river walk along the edge of Constable Hook from the abandoned military base on the next peninsula to the north. ''There was the hulk of a ship sunk in the mud, a steel hulk, and we used to swim off of it.''

If he had not chosen Frankie Valli to entertain some Merrill Lynch stockbrokers back in the 1970's, Joseph J. Grano Jr. would not have been on stage at Radio City Music Hall at the Tony Awards last week. Mr. Grano, a longtime executive on Wall Street, helped to finance ''Jersey Boys,'' a Broadway show about Mr. Valli and the Four Seasons, which won the Tony for best musical.

To the Editor: In their letters to the editor of the Book Review, James Walling (April 30) and Morris Dickstein (May 7) are right to enter their qualifications about my review of Frederick Brown's biography of Flaubert (April 16), but I think a demonstrable case can still be made for Flaubert as a founder of the modern novel -- and, as I added in my review, of many kinds of modern narrative. Our indebtedness, whether we like it or not, extends to, among other things: the fetishizing of visual detail; the inverted relation between background and foreground detail (or habitual and dynamic detail); the sacralization of art; the privileging of the music of style over the recalcitrance of ''unmusical'' subject matter (Flaubert's famous desire to write a book about nothing); the agonizing over aesthetic labor -- all this looks pretty new, and different in many ways from Balzac's great achievements and solutions, not least because these new Flaubertian anxieties cannot be solutions. You might say that Flaubert founds realism and simultaneously destroys it, by making it so aesthetic: fiction is real and artificial at once. And I could have added two other elements of modernity: the refinement of ''free indirect style''; and the relative plotlessness of Flaubert's novels. All this is why different writers -- realists, modernists and postmodernists -- from Stephen Crane to Ian McEwan, from Kafka to Nabokov to Robbe-Grillet, all owe so much to Flaubert, and have been so keen to lay claim to different novels of his. I don't at all disagree with Dickstein's caveat that Flaubert's obsession with form, rhythm and ''the sentence'' inaugurates a potentially sterile aestheticism; I once wrote an essay, ''Half Against Flaubert,'' in which I said exactly that. I also agree that there are wonderfully messy writers like Dreiser and Hardy who, by Flaubertian standards, are beyond the aesthetic pale, and shouldn't be. My claim for Flaubert's primacy wasn't evaluative but factual: personally, I'm of two minds, or two hearts, about Flaubert. Henry James's devoted recoil from Flaubert's aestheticism (the devotion of an aesthete, the recoil of a moralist) seems the right response. James Wood Cambridge, Mass.

Sibongile Morowa Boyd, the daughter of Joan Grant-Boyd and Thomas L. Boyd of Brooklyn, is to be married this afternoon to Pernell Scott Brice III, the son of Lonzella and Mr. Brice Jr. of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. Peter W. D. Bramble, the rector of the Church of St. Mark (Episcopal) in Brooklyn, performed the ceremony there. The bride (whose given name is pronounced see-bone-GHEE-lay), 29, is a bank examiner at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in Manhattan. She is also pursuing a career as a coloratura soprano. She graduated cum laude from Harvard.

To the Editor: A reader would not know from ''It Takes a Village to Cause a (Rent) War'' (June 4) that the board of directors is democratically elected by all of the families at Rochdale Village in Jamaica, Queens. It is the board that truly represents Rochdale's 23,000 residents, so it is doubtful that all, or even most, of them are protesting the increase in charges.

Insurance companies often promote safety. Recently, Allstate ranked the safety of drivers in nearly 200 American cities. Rankings were based on the average number of years drivers went without an accident, no matter where they drove (the national average is 10 years). Data were based on the company's property damage claims from January 2003 to December 2004 and exclude cities in Massachusetts, where Allstate does not operate. Andrew Rice's ''The Long Interrogation'' (June 4) is a vivid reminder that some of us have paid for our freedom in ways that are almost too terrifying to believe. And that this freedom is worth protecting in any way possible. Corey DuBrowa Lake Oswego, Ore.

WHEN leaders of the Sri Venkateswara Hindu temple in Bridgewater gathered last month for another public hearing on their proposal for a larger cultural center, they felt confident that the township's Zoning Board of Adjustment would approve a variance for it at long last. Two previous series of contentious hearings had ended in ''no'' votes. The first led the temple to take the township to court. At the second, the board approved requests for an expansion of the temple itself and construction of homes for priests, but not for the cultural center.

For more than a year, Vladimir Kramnik of Russia has been a prisoner of his severe arthritis, and his game has suffered accordingly. But all of a sudden he came to life in the Olympiad in Turin, Italy, and showed what he could do. His overall score was 6 1/2-2 1/2, but that doesn't tell the whole story, because as Russia's top player, he could be paired only with the first-board players of the other top teams, so he had to come by his wins by toppling his strongest rivals. He was phenomenal.

VERNER--Jules Leonard. Of Boca Raton, died on Thursday, June 15, 2006, having just celebrated his 84th birthday. He put up a terrific fight and had been a cancer survivor for 12 years. Known to dear friends and family as Lenny, he is survived by his wife of 60 marvelous years, Irene, as well as their children Daniel and Meryle Verner, June and Aaron Speisman, Andrew and Anne Verner, grandchildren Joshua, Melissa, Jennifer, Adam, and his brother Lloyd. Lenny was a soldier in WWII and fought at the Battle of the Bulge. Although he was wounded twice in the head and leg, he continued to serve. Lenny was a graduate of NYU, and began his career as a CPA for a private accounting firm in Paterson, NJ. For his strong business acumen and ethics he was hired away by Calumet Manufacturing, a plastics company, to become their Executive vice President. He later became CFO of Quarex, a company he personally took public on the NASDAQ. Lenny's life in New Jersey was rich and full with so many cousins that were really dear friends. Ten years ago Lenny retired with Irene to Boca Raton where he greatly enjoyed golf, tennis, the beach club, bridge, poker, watching the stock market, opera, theater, restaurants, movies and world travel, always surrounded by his many wonderful friends and loving children. His greatest satisfaction was all the times shared with his beloved wife, his extended family and his friends who were so very dear to him. Funeral services and burial will be held (today), Sunday, June 18, 2006. For more info contact Rubin Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, FL, 561-496-3000.

There is a plethora of Father's Day programming on Sunday, but most of it isn't Oscar-winning. At 8 p.m. CINEMAX will present JOHN CANEMAKER's half-hour film ''THE MOON AND THE SON: AN IMAGINED CONVERSATION,'' which won the Academy Award for best animated short earlier this year. It's not so much a tribute to Mr. Canemaker's Italian-American father, who died in 1995, as it is a psychodrama, an effort to work out a troubled father-son relationship posthumously. The animated figures include Nazis, 1950's policemen, Mafiosi here and abroad and a few cute sheep. ELI WALLACH and JOHN TURTURRO do the voices. NBC, wondering how it could imitate Fox's √ºberhit series, ''American Idol,'' but change it just enough to give it another title, has come up with ''AMERICA'S GOT TALENT,'' which has its two-hour premiere on Wednesday night at 9. The difference is that aspiring dancers, comedians and other performers -- not just singers -- will compete. But where are they going with this casting? The host is REGIS PHILBIN. The judges are DAVID HASSELHOFF, the singer BRANDY and, presumably in the Simon Cowell role, PIERS MORGAN, a British newspaper editor and television host. Sometimes the PBS series ''HISTORY DETECTIVES'' does rattle on a little too much about its subjects. Do we really need to know the entire history of the cowboy profession while experts track down the truth behind a Chisholm Trail historical marker in a small Texas town? But in general, these investigations are highly satisfying emotionally. The fourth-season premiere (Monday at 9 p.m.) also looks into the history of a Houdini poster (the owner ends up with a program from that particular show) and a 45-star American flag that may have draped the coffin of President William McKinley after his assassination in 1901. That search ends up at a grave, but not McKinley's.

THE big spring ritual at our place just happened: the removal of the swimming pool cover. The exact date of this ceremony is determined by the pool guys, who cast runes to determine when, in exchange for a hefty financial tribute, they will deign to drop by and perform juju on the pipes, mutter incantations over the filter motor, and otherwise awaken the machinery whose continued function is the difference between a pool and a concrete-bottomed fen. But before this can happen, we have to remove the cover, a leaf-collecting tarp under which the pool hibernates all fall and winter, and top up the water level. We know that the time to do this is approaching when the weather, which had been giving hints of spring, suddenly turns cold and gray and dumps shower loads of new rainfall onto the cover, making it sag even more and adding extra broth to the slurry of leaf mold already fermenting there. Getting this gunk out is an extremely nasty job, and I try to leave it for my wife.

POUNDS--Richard, project manager in historic preservation field, 48. Richard Pounds, who died on June 3rd, in NYC was a project manager and architectural consultant. His projects included the Washington Square Arch, the Manhattan Appellate Court House, the Main Post Office, Grand Central Station, City Hall and the West Point Military Academy. His paper on Guastavino Acoustical Tile was published in the Association of Preservation Technology Bulletin. He received a bachelors degree from Columbia University in art history with a concentration in architectural history. He later earned his masters degree in historic preservation from Columbia. Born in Montclair, N.J., he lived in Greenwich Village and is survived by Bette, his wife of 17 years; sons Jordan and Jason; his mother Therese Pounds, sisters Mary Sisler and Virginia Pounds, brothers Donald, Thomas, James, Michael, John, and his beloved dog, Sammie.
To the Editor: Re '' 'Searchers': How the West Was Begun'' [June 11]:

Weeks This On Week List FICTION 1 10 THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Anchor, $14.95 and $7.99; Broadway special illustrated edition, $22.95.) This week pop royalty descends on New York. On Friday and Saturday night FAITH HILL and TIM MCGRAW -- the first couple of country music -- arrive at Madison Square Garden for the Soul2Soul II tour. As the DIXIE CHICKS have proved, it's not always easy for pop stars to keep their country fans happy. But Ms. Hill and Mr. McGraw, who have also been critical of President Bush, have managed to do it. Ms. Hill's 2005 album, ''Fireflies'' (Warner Brothers Nashville), is a gently down-home album from an A-list star; it's more likable than believable, which is precisely what matters. Mr. McGraw knows his way around a big, sentimental ballad (he proved it again with his blockbuster 2004 single, ''Live Like You Were Dying''), but his current hit is something of a surprise: a cover of ''When the Stars Go Blue'' by the alt-country divo Ryan Adams. At these two concerts, expect great fun: memorable sets, costume changes, cellphones-in-the-air duets. At 8 p.m.; Friday sold out quickly, but tickets for Saturday may still be available. (212) 307-7171; $50 to $100. (As it happens, Mr. Adams is to appear at the Beacon Theater this Friday night, alongside ROBERT PLANT, YO LA TENGO and others; it's a benefit for the ailing ARTHUR LEE, from LOVE.) A pair of R&B pioneers are also coming to town, although separately. ARETHA FRANKLIN is to play the Apollo Theater on Tuesday and Wednesday. At 8 p.m., 253 West 125th Street, Harlem, (212) 307-7171; $77 to $177. And on Thursday SMOKEY ROBINSON is to play the Isaac Stern Auditorium at Carnegie Hall, as part of the JVC Jazz Festival. At 8 p.m., (212) 247-7800; $35 to $85.

SHORTLY after he took command of the Continental Army in 1775, at the onset of the Revolutionary War, George Washington ordered the construction of a military camp and storage yard south of the Fishkill Creek, on a 70-acre parcel that now spans both sides of Route 9, near Interstate 84, in the Town of Fishkill. The Fishkill Supply Depot, as the camp came to be known, was the main provider of artillery and food for up to 4,000 troops stationed there to keep the British from moving past New York City and capturing the Hudson Valley, the town's historian, Willa Skinner, said. Despite its significance, the depot and its role in the war have faded into obscurity, while most of the land where it once stood has been developed.

The demand for craft-brewed beer has been fermenting for years, but few microbrewers have emerged in Westchester. Now Captain Lawrence Brewing Company, a new outfit in Pleasantville, is filling the void. Captain Lawrence, which opened earlier this year, offers complimentary tastings and tours on Fridays (4 to 7 p.m.) and Saturdays (noon to 6 p.m.). Most of the company's customers are restaurants buying wholesale, including Crabtree's Kittle House in Chappaqua, the Flying Pig in Mount Kisco and Sonora in Port Chester. But Scott Vaccaro, owner and brewer, is building a growing retail business out of his weekend tastings.

U.S. Feared Al Qaeda Plot on Subways, Officials Say Two former counterterrorism officials said the United States was concerned in 2003 that Al Qaeda was planning a cyanide attack on New York's subways. Their account seemed to confirm details in a new book. PAGE 25 Chechen Reported Killed Russian special forces killed the leader of Chechnya's separatists, officials said, dealing a blow to a movement that appears to be seriously weakened. PAGE 6 Updike's Other America In John Updike's latest novel, ''Terrorist,'' imagined views of the country converge as a New Jersey high school boy, half-Irish and half-Egyptian, becomes intoxicated with Islam after the 9/11 attacks. A review by Robert Stone. BOOK REVIEW 2 Missing U.S. Soldiers Are Sought in Iraq American soldiers began a search for two of their comrades who were apparently captured by insurgents in Iraq after an ambush in the chaotic area south of Baghdad. The search came on a day of widespread attacks across the capital, in which 38 Iraqis were killed. PAGE 10 U.S. Endures to Tie Italy The United States had two players ejected but earned a 1-1 draw with Italy in the World Cup. To have a shot at advancing, the Americans must defeat Ghana, which beat the Czech Republic, 2-0, in the biggest upset of the tournament. SPORTSSUNDAY

A Film entry today in the Week Ahead report on Page 6 of Arts & Leisure misstated the writers who collaborated with Mike White on the script for ''Nacho Libre.'' They are Jared Hess and Jerusha Hess, not Jack Black.
SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Daddy Dear, our 14th Father's Day without you. We love and miss you. Irik and Jaar-mel

When State Senator Stephen M. Sweeney first proposed cutting the salaries and benefits of state workers by 15 percent, union leaders called him a hypocrite. After all, they said, Mr. Sweeney -- a union leader himself -- collects $49,000 in public funds for his Senate salary and $17,000 as a Gloucester County freeholder, in addition to his pay from Iron Workers Local 399. So, last week Mr. Sweeney introduced a bill to cut the salaries of state legislators by 15 percent.
MANLEY--John M. April 4, 1919--June 18, 1999 Can it be that you left us seven years ago today. You always have and always will occupy a very special place in my heart. Carla

Marion Judith Goldstein, a daughter of Paula Goldstein and Alan Goldstein of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Ezra Feldman, a son of Dr. Judith Feldman and Henry Feldman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Lauren Grabelle Herrmann officiated at Club Getaway, a sports resort in Kent, Conn. Mrs. Feldman, 28, has completed first-year studies for a doctorate in education at Columbia. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and has a master's degree in educational communication and technology from New York University.

Susan Blatt Schwab and Charles Carnahan Goetsch were married yesterday at the bridegroom's vacation home on High Island in Branford, Conn. Judge Socrates Mihalakos of the Connecticut Appellate Court in Hartford officiated. Mrs. Goetsch, 54, was until last year the owner of Book Haven, an academic bookstore in New Haven. She graduated cum laude from Princeton and received a Master of Fine Arts degree in dramaturgy and dramatic criticism from Yale.

To the Sports Editor: Ben Roethlisberger is a large man, but I would bet that the driver of the car that hit him did not see him in the road (''Roethlisberger Sustains Facial Injuries in a Motorcycle Wreck,'' June 13). When, as a practicing orthopedic surgeon, I tended to injured cyclists, I often heard, ''The car just pulled right out in front of me.''

MERRILL - Philip. Cornell University mourns the loss of devoted alumnus, Philip Merrill, a champion of education who created the Merrill Presidential Scholars Program at the university, whereby exceptional Cornell seniors recognize the high school and Cornell teachers who inspired them. He also provided generous scholarships to financially needy students. Mr. Merrill recently funded Cornell University's Merrill Family Sailing Center on Cayuga Lake in Ithaca, NY, which, when it is built, will commemorate his love of sailing and Cornell. A member of the Class of 1955 as well as a renowned international statesman, adviser to U.S. and Cornell presidents, publisher with a commitment to public service, distinguished banker, and civic minded entrepreneur, Phil Merrill brought experience, distinction and vision to his roles as Cornell trustee, presidential councillor, and member of University Council. His entrepreneurial spirit helped guide the Johnson Graduate School of Management Advisory Council. Cornell University expresses its sincere condolences to his wife Eleanor, his son Douglas, his two daughters Cathy and Nancy, and four grandsons. Peter Meinig, Chair of the Board of Trustees Hunter R. Rawlings III, President Cornell University

FLYNN--James Morgan Jr. 62, of Montauk, NY, and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on June 14, 2006. Jim was born in Boston, MA, and graduated from Boston Latin School and St. Michael's College in Vermont. He is survived by his wife Valerie Kelly; his son James Morgan Flynn III, his sister Marilyn, brothers Richard, Charles and Thomas, their wives, and nine nieces and nephews. Please make donations in Jim's name to Renal Transplant Fund, Dept. of Surgery, Columbia University/NY Presbyterian Hospital, 630 West 168th St. NY, NY 10032; attn Mark Hardy, M.D.

Michael Pollan (The Way We Live Now, June 4) gets it right when he writes that organic agriculture's future production will be outsourced to countries where it is cheaper to grow crops without chemical inputs. The reason growing organic crops is cheaper in other countries is the availability of workers at cheap wages to pull weeds by hand out of crop fields. Pollan suggests that tens of thousands of organic corn acres would be required to meet the needs of a world thirsty for corn syrup. He's wrong there. Tens of millions of acres would be required. A vast expansion in organic acreage will sentence millions of low-paid workers around the world to a life of drudgery pulling weeds so that Americans can sip an organic drink. Seventy years ago, almost a quarter of the U.S. population lived on farms and millions of people hoed weeds all summer. Thanks to herbicides like atrazine, those days are long gone. In the U.S., chemical herbicides do the work of 30 million laborers. Without a vast infusion of migrant workers and a significant lowering of the wage rate, growing crops with organic methods has a very limited future in the U.S. Leonard Gianessi Director, Crop Protection Research Institute CropLife Foundation Washington

IN the fall of 1992, a woman was in her apartment on West 16th Street in New York City when her boyfriend walked in with a gun pointed at him. The gunman had pistol-whipped him in the vestibule and taken his keys. Once in the apartment, he forced the woman to go around collecting money and jewelry. Forcing her boyfriend to watch, the gunman then raped her twice.

An article last Sunday about the chances of women being elected president of the United States misspelled the surname of a prominent political family in India that included a female head of state. They are the Gandhis, not the Ghandis.

A few days after the Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester announced that it was shutting a summer program for hundreds of children from low-income families, Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County executive, announced on Thursday that the county would give $100,000 to the program in an effort to save it. The camp, operated out of the Community Opportunity Center in Tarrytown, is one of the few programs in affluent Westchester that caters to low-income families. But since its opening in 2002, the camp has accumulated a deficit of about $400,000, and earlier this year, unable to cope with a rent increase, the camp was asked by the center to leave by the end of this month.

IT was a small gesture, worth little or nothing in dollars and cents. A legally married gay couple still has to pay $150 for a family pass to a Westchester County pool, exactly what two unattached straight adults pay. But they qualify as a family -- and that is another milestone for gay residents of Westchester. A county shaped around the needs of families declared this month that gay people married in Massachusetts or one of a handful of countries, like Canada and the Netherlands, that accept gay vows are a family too, at least for the humdrum purposes of using the county's parks or shelters.

To the Editor: Gail Collins, in ''A Letter From the Editor'' (editorial, June 4), offered a number of opinions. I disagree with her ''pre-existing opinion'' on the No Child Left Behind Act. Yes, additional financing would be helpful for this act, but that alone does not resolve its serious flaws.
DOBRER--Jean. June 18, 1954--August 19, 2000. Jeannie, we miss you so much. Love, Nina, Mom & Dad

To the Editor: In his review of Phillip Lopate's anthology ''American Movie Critics'' (June 4), Clive James, wanting to demonstrate to critics how to ''take down'' a film they don't like, pans ''Munich.'' He accuses the film's writers of not knowing ''half enough about politics.'' No instances of our semi-ignorance are provided; not one line of the script is cited. Instead, a single scene is mentioned: a meeting of Golda Meir's ''cabinet'' -- it obviously wasn't a cabinet meeting, but never mind -- which, James writes, ''went for nothing.'' And that's it. I know film critics everywhere will profit from James's instruction. He may even enlighten the many who wrote admiringly of ''Munich,'' including the three film critics of The New York Times. I, having been taken down, will run for cover in a moment, but first I would like to respond to James's devastating analysis. I do so know more than half enough! And, furthermore, that scene went for something! Since ''Munich'' isn't mentioned in the anthology, his attack isn't merely vague, it's utterly gratuitous. After using up an awful lot of paper and ink sharing his opinions of real film critics, James exposes himself as the sort of writer who slags the people behind the art because he can't summon the substance or wit to articulate his unhappiness with the art itself -- or, I suspect, in the case of ''Munich,'' with the politics he feels the art expresses. That's the difference between a critic and a crank. Tony Kushner New York

To the Editor: Haven't you heard of lagniappe, the word meaning ''something extra'' or ''an unexpected gift''? When the Tulane commencement features two former presidents and then Ellen DeGeneres appears at the end, that's lagniappe.

BERK -- Irving A. Passed away June 16, after a short illness. He died peacefully at home surrounded by some of his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, as well as his beloved companion of eight years, Judy, and her daughter Sandy. He was in excellent health for 100 years, going to work six days a week until three weeks ago. Although the Berk Trade School, the Berk Plumbing Company, and the Berk Management Company were his passions for the last 66 years, he always had time for family and rarely missed a family function. We will all miss him dearly. He was married for 54 years to Ann until her demise. His daughter Bascia predeceased him. He is survived by Bascia's four children, Julian, Allan, Joyce and Ronald, his son Joel and his two children, Michelle and Kevin, and his son Harvey and his three children, Diana, Haley and Daniel. His eight great-grandchildren are Sara, Stephanie, Melissa, Lindsey, Courtney, Brian, Alexa and Charles. Services will be held Sunday at 11:30 AM, at the Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel located at 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, followed by the interment at New Montefiore Cemetery.

To the Editor: Re ''Skyline for Sale'' [June 4]: Is Nicolai Ouroussoff surprised that commercial architecture actually looks commercial? And as for the shock of famous architects designing banal buildings, has Mr. Ouroussoff visited many art museums lately?

MAYOR-ELECT Cory Booker held a broom over his head on Tuesday night and the image said it all: a clean sweep. All six of his candidates for the Municipal Council won in last week's runoff, ensuring that he will have an ally in each of the council seats when he takes office on July 1. But there is a catch: ''It's called accountability,'' said Ross K. Baker, a political science professor at Rutgers University.

The craze for vintage concert T-shirts has taken the next sartorial step. Eve Chrust, the designer behind eve*lynn, has refashioned the rock T-shirt by fusing old favorites like a worn-in Grateful Dead, Kiss or Pantera shirt with a supersoft jersey knit skirt, creating handmade one-of-a-kind dresses that graze the calves. Ms. Chrust also uses repurposed T's and sweatshirts to make halter tops, strapless dresses and tanks; $219 to $334 at Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Mass., (413) 528-9455. Her designs have been snatched up by celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow, who apparently find them the perfect weekend uniform. AMANDA M. TRIMBLE

PROVIDENCE ESTATES. Cottage Gate. The Village Grande. The parade of names goes on and on as you drive around western Monmouth County, N.J. Nearly every subdivision announces its presence with a rustic wooden or stone sign. The ritualistic naming of planned communities is nothing new -- anyone living in a Levittown knows that. But as hundreds of subdivisions bloom each year in the New York metropolitan region and across the nation, many of the seemingly most desirable names have been taken. So who is coming up with new ones? And is there a point?

THE big spring ritual at our place just happened: the removal of the swimming pool cover. The exact date of this ceremony is determined by the pool guys, who cast runes to determine when, in exchange for a hefty financial tribute, they will deign to drop by and perform juju on the pipes, mutter incantations over the filter motor, and otherwise awaken the machinery whose continued function is the difference between a pool and a concrete-bottomed fen. But before this can happen, we have to remove the cover, a leaf-collecting tarp under which the pool hibernates all fall and winter, and top up the water level. We know that the time to do this is approaching when the weather, which had been giving hints of spring, suddenly turns cold and gray and dumps shower loads of new rainfall onto the cover, making it sag even more and adding extra broth to the slurry of leaf mold already fermenting there. Getting this gunk out is an extremely nasty job, and I try to leave it for my wife.

Tomorrow's final Group B matches will decide whether Sweden or Trinidad & Tobago will join England in advancing to the next round. Sweden will go through unless they lose to England (for the first time since 1968) and could still win the group by winning that match. The Soca Warriors have to hammer already-eliminated Paraguay and hope England beat Sweden by enough that they make it through on goal difference. Considering the hair-pulling and all, it's really the least they could do.

Fresh from announcing its industry-jolting joint venture agreement with Nokia, Germany's Siemens said Monday it is already deep into negotiating the sale of its enterprise networking business unit as well. The unit, which builds telecommunications systems for businesses, could be of interest to France's Alcatel or Avaya of the United States, or it might be a tempting target for private equity firms, Reuters reported.

Ergo, its stock should rise on Monday's news, as investors anticipate a takeover premium somewhere down the line.

Patriotic optimism was the only thing that kept Ghanaian fans upbeat about the chances of their national team, the Black Stars, to overcome the highly rated Czech Republic. From that first minute on Saturday, when they were leading the Czech 1-0, the celebrations had already begun back home. The last time some Ghanaians remembered celebrating like this was 14 years ago when the Black Stars reached the final of the 1992 African Nations Cup after beating Nigeria in the semi-final (they lost to Ivory Coast in the final). Others compared it to their memory of the declaration of independence by Dr. Kwame Nkrumah in 1957.

NetRatings "could be re-consolidated within Nielsen before long, at a nice premium to the present share price," columnist Michael Santoli writes in this week's edition of Barron's. The Web audience-measurement outfit, an offshoot of Nielsen Media, is 62 percent owned by VNU Media, which was recently acquired by a group of private equity investors. Mr. Santoli sees the possibility that VNU's new owners will decide to sop up the publicly traded piece of NetRatings at a nice premium to their current price.
The Carolina Hurricanes won the Stanley Cup by defeating the Edmonton Oilers 3-1 in Game Seven.

Did former Virginia Gov. Mark Warner, who is expected to run for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008 (if he isn't already running for it), "win" the YearlyKos convention? Garance Franke-Ruta, a senior editor at The American Prospect, says that Warner's performance at YearlyKos is being overstated. "Though Warner's speech, his standard stump, earned him coverage in influential papers such as The Washington Post and The New York Times, it flopped with the politically sophisticated Kossaks," she writes. "His decision to use the Kos conference to increase his name I.D. and online profile was a shrewd political move for a little-known candidate, yet his politics, in the end, proved too centrist for many of the bloggers at the conference."
Tribune Company said on Monday that it plans to sell a television station, WCWN-TV in Albany, N.Y., to closely held Freedom Communications Inc. for $17 million.

An oil and gas producer, Stone Energy, said on Monday that a $1.4 billion takeover offer from Energy Partners was "superior" to its previous agreement to be bought by Plains Exploration & Production. The decision gives Plains Exploration until Friday to decide if it will make a counterbid.

Alberto-Culver said Monday it would split off its beauty-supply distribution business, Sally Beauty, with buyout firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice taking a 47.5 percent stake in the spun-off entity. The transaction comes a few months after Alberto-Culver's attempt to sell the unit to the Regis Corporation for $2.78 billion fell apart.

A man was beaten to death after an altercation early yesterday at a party to celebrate a christening, the police said. A group of men were asked to leave the New Grand Buffet restaurant in Long Island City after a dispute about 3 a.m., the police said. A short time later, one man who had left the restaurant returned bleeding from the mouth and neck, the police said. The man, Mercelo Chimbarazo, 22, of East Stroudsburg, Pa., was pronounced dead at Elmhurst Hospital Center. The police said that Mr. Chimbarazo had been beaten with fists.

Two Democratic state senators, Jeffrey D. Klein of the Bronx and Westchester County and Diane J. Savino of Staten Island and Brooklyn, joined Sonia Ossorio, president of the New York City chapter of the National Organization for Women, at a news conference yesterday to urge the state to repeal the five-year statute of limitations for criminal prosecutions in rape cases. They said that New York was one of only five states with a deadline of five years or less, that DNA technology had made it possible to positively identify suspects in long-dormant cases, and that the limit provided little incentive for the authorities to devote resources to old rape cases. The Senate passed the repeal on Feb. 14 and the Assembly on May 15. The board of New Jersey Transit is scheduled to discuss a plan today to open direct train service between Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan and Atlantic City. The Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, which provides investment funds for economic development, would pay $4.5 million over three years to lease trains for the service, said its executive director, Tom Carver.

The driver of a bus carrying Special Olympics athletes was killed in an accident Sunday while fixing the vehicle on the side of the New York State Thruway, the state police said. The driver, Ephraim Williams, 42, of the Bronx, was pronounced dead at the scene by the Orange County coroner, D. Kevin Quigley. Shortly before 11 a.m., two buses pulled onto the shoulder of the Thruway near Exit 16 at Harriman, 45 miles north of New York City. Mr. Williams was behind the first bus working on a mechanical problem when a 24-foot box truck drifted onto the shoulder and struck the second bus, the police said, pushing it into the first one and crushing Mr. Williams. Six passengers were treated for minor injuries.

A man was killed and his nephew was wounded in a shooting early yesterday at a Harlem restaurant, the police said. The man, Modesto Medel, was standing inside the Crown Fried Chicken restaurant at 136th Street and Broadway about 3:45 a.m. when two people entered and opened fire, the police said. Relatives said the police told them that a videotape appeared to show the gunmen firing at Mr. Medel and accidentally hitting Mr. Perea.

SMITH--Marion J. E. In her 102nd year, on June 17, 2006, of Roslyn Heights, NY. Beloved sister of Helen Emmerich and aunt and great-aunt to many. Lifelong member and past president of the Soroptimist International Club of New York. Marion also founded and served as president for 35 years of Marioness, Inc., of New York, a company she established in the Depression years.

BERMAN--Dr. William. At the age of 91. Dentist 47 years, formerly of Westbury, NY. Loving husband to Lillian, father to Janet and Phyllis, grandfather to Alexis, fatherin-law to Al and Michael. WWII Captain and only ''painless dentist in New Guinea'' and JFK. Selfless service to the community and his patients: Chancellor Commander Knights of Pythias, cancer care, volunteer dentist for cerebral palsy and handicapped children at LIJ Hospital, teen dentist Westbury High School and Sun City Center Emergency Squad. Services Tuesday, 1 pm, from Gutterman's Inc, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

Keane ''Under the Iron Sea'' (Island) Pity Tom Chaplin of Keane. That seems to be what he's campaigning for on ''Under the Iron Sea,'' the band's second full-length album. ''I give much more than I'd ever ask for,'' he informs a lover in one song, making a show of his martyrdom. ''You must think I'm a fool,'' he complains in another, ''so prosaic and awkward and all.'' And as for something called ''Broken Toy,'' well, you can probably guess who the toy is and who broke it.

SHAPIRO--Jerry. 76, died on June 16, 2006 of complications from emphysema. He was a lifelong New Yorker and resident of Port Washington and Amagansett. In the 1970s he was President of the Hertz Corporation. In the 1980s he was President of Carl Ally Inc Advertising. Most recently he owned and operated several businesses headquartered in Port Washington. Throughout his life he was a superb chef delighting his friends and family with wonderful dinners. He loved the beach, fishing and sailing. He was devoted to Ayla, his new grandchild, his wife June, his daughter Kit and her husband Serdar Demirdelen. Services will be private. Donations may be made to the Emphysema Foundation, Claycomo, MO, in Jerry's name. $(6$)SHAPIRO--Jerry. We mourn the passing of our good friend Jerry Shapiro who will be sorely missed. We send our condolences to the Shapiro family.Richard Bernhard, Robert Bernhard, Howard Olian, Jerry Shore, Dan Simon

Nelly Furtado ''Loose'' (Geffen) ''I always said, if we hooked it up -- it's so crazy, because with your beats with, like, an emotional vocal? Dope, y'know?'' This is how Nelly Furtado explains her partnership with Timbaland, one of hip-hop's greatest-ever producers. This snippet of studio banter appears near the end of the album they made together, ''Loose.'' She sounds pretty clueless, this Canadian pop star; when Timbaland responds, ''That's what I was saying,'' it's hard to tell whether he's merely humoring her.

BROWN --David Ingalls, 55, of West Hartford, died June 14th, 2006 in an airplane accident in Charlottesville, VA. Born in Cleveland, OH, he earned his BA from Trinity College, CT, in 1973 and MBA from the University of Michigan in 1984. Brown had a distinguished career in land preservation development, most recently at Qroe Farm Corp. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, June 21, at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford at 2:30 pm.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 North Korean Military Closer to Missile Test North Korea appears to have completed fueling a long-range ballistic missile, American officials said. One official said satellite photographs suggested that booster rockets had been loaded onto a launching pad and fuel tanks fitted to a missile at a site in North Korea's remote east coast. Such a move would greatly increase the probability that the North will go ahead with its first test firing in eight years. A1 Environmental Danger in Iraq Iraqi officials say that in a desperate move to dispose of millions of barrels of an oil refinery byproduct called black oil, the government pumped it into open mountain valleys and leaky reservoirs next to the Tigris River and set it on fire. The resulting huge black bogs are threatening the river and the precious groundwater in the region. A1 American forces have intensified their search for two soldiers missing and reportedly held captive by insurgents, widening their pursuit to areas beyond the restive town of Yusifiya, where the missing servicemen were attacked, and drawing troops from at least three brigade combat teams. A10 U.S. and China Court Hanoi Vietnam's leaders have made plain they want the United States on their side for equilibrium against China. The government, though an ideological ally of Beijing, is fearful of an expanding Chinese sphere of influence and of being reduced to an economic appendage by its northern neighbor. A3 Somalia's Battle Over Culture Islamic miliatiamen in Somalia, flush from an earlier military victory that caught Washington and the world by surprise, have begun waging smaller battles -- cultural, not military ones -- in and around Somalia's shellshocked capital. A11 Catalonia Approves Self-Rule Voters in Spain's northeastern region of Catalonia approved a sweeping overhaul of its constitutional relationship with the central government, endorsing a plan granting the region broad new powers of self-government. Murtha, left, the Pennsylvania Democrat and Vietnam War veteran pushing for a quick withdrawal of American troops from Iraq, mocked Karl Rove, the president's senior adviser, for championing the war while ''sitting in his air-conditioned office on his big, fat backside.'' A17 NATIONAL A12-16 Episcopal Church Names Woman as Top Bishop The Episcopal Church elected the Bishop Katharine Jefferts Schori of Nevada as its new presiding bishop, making her the first woman to serve as a primate in the history of the 77-million-member worldwide Anglican Communion. A1 Company Ties Not Noted A retired Coast Guard commander told lawmakers and reporters that domestic ports were vulnerable and offered a system that scans every container. But a fact remained in the background: From 2003 until 2005, he was a paid consultant to the company that manufactured the system. A1 Push for White House Change In his first three months as White House chief of staff, Joshua B. Bolten has brought new people to critical jobs, worked to repair frayed relationships with Republicans on Capitol Hill and tried to ensure that the White House takes advantage of its breaks. A15 I.R.S. Checks Hospitals The Internal Revenue Service has begun a wide-ranging investigation of nonprofit hospitals to determine whether they are flouting standards for tax-exempt status, whether they deny care to people without insurance and whether they provide significant amounts of charity care. A15 A.C.L.U. Warned on Speech A lawyer in the New York state attorney general's office informally warned the American Civil Liberties Union that his office had concerns about proposed standards that would limit the group's board members from speaking publicly about policies and internal operations, three board members said. A13 Illegal Workers in Mainstream In contrast to the typical image of an illegal immigrant -- paid in cash, working under the table for small-scale labor contractors -- a majority now work for mainstream companies, and are hired and paid like any other American worker. A1 A Sinking Island For natural and manufactured reasons, 30 square miles of Louisiana wetlands vanish every year into the Gulf. The residents of Isle de Jean Charles are worried, partly because wetlands and barrier islands act as hurricane buffers to a vulnerable mainland. A12 Concerns on Plane Blast Federal investigators say they are deeply concerned about an engine break-up that nearly destroyed a Boeing 767 on the ground in Los Angeles because the failure may indicate a recurrence of a problem they thought they had eliminated in 2003. A13 Giving Increased Last Year Charitable giving increased last year, propelled by a series of huge natural disasters at home and abroad, according to an annual report on philanthropy. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Researchers at Library Survive in Age of Internet A small band of researchers at the New York Public Library has been tackling questions from anyone, of any age, from anywhere for years. Today, despite the Internet, the ten employees of what is known as the telephone reference service are still at it and can answer questions in under five minutes. B1 Barbecuing by the Highway Dozens of New Yorkers with a tolerance for honking horns and emergency sirens gathered on the grassy areas between the highway and the East River for a Father's Day barbecue because finding a spot for a cookout can be difficult for many city residents who do not have a yard. B1 Violent Weekend in Brooklyn It was an unusually violent weekend in Central Brooklyn, with 10 people shot or slashed in five unrelated incidents that started shortly after midnight and ended just before daybreak. All of the victims are expected to recover. B3 SPORTSMONDAY D1-10 Ogilvy Wins U.S. Open Australia's Geoff Ogilvy won the United States Open at Winged Foot with a final-round two-over-par 72 to finish at five-over-par 285. Phil Mickelson, who only needed to par the 18th hole to win his third consecutive major championship, walked off with a double bogey -- his first in 72 holes. D1 Heat Take Control of Finals Dwyane Wade scored 43 points as Miami defeated Dallas 101-100 in overtime of Game 5 of the NBA finals. Miami leads 3-2 in the best-of-seven series. Lauder for $135 million, the highest sum ever paid for a painting. Hot Chip ''The Warning'' (DFA/Astralwerks) Hot Chip emerged in 2004 with a weirdly inventive sound (comatose electro-soul) and a weirdly irritating persona (nerdy tragic clowns). This British quintet's debut, ''Coming On Strong,'' was an oddball mix of sad lyrics, mournful atmospherics, Casio keyboards and ironic gangsta posturing. In the rap sendup ''Playboy,'' the vocalist Joe Goddard boasted of ''blazin' Yo La Tengo'' in a Peugeot decked out with 20-inch tire rims. The funky white-boy shtick often overshadowed the band's ability to plunder elements from disparate sources -- Prince, Devo, Aphex Twin, Beck, indie rock -- and fuse them in a surprisingly fresh new way.

9 P.M. (Lifetime) A GIRL LIKE ME: THE GWEN ARAUJO STORY -- In this Lifetime original movie, J.D. Pardo (''American Dreams'') plays Eddie Araujo, the Newark, Calif., teenager who defied his family'straditional Latino heritage when he began to dress and act like a girl, eventually changing his name to Gwen. Though Gwen's mother, Sylvia Guerrero (Mercedes Ruehl, above), learned to accept her child, others were not so tolerant; Gwen was brutally murdered in 2002. The film, based on real events, was directed by the Oscar nominee Agnieszka Holland (''Europa Europa''). 6 P.M. (TCM) SOMEBODY UP THERE LIKES ME -- (1956) Paul Newman is the boxer Rocky Graziano, who rose from reform school delinquent to the middleweight champion of the world when he defeated Tony Zale in 1947. This film also helped to launch the film careers of Steve McQueen, George C. Scott and Robert Loggia, all of whom had uncredited roles. 7 P.M. (ABC Family) SPRING BREAK SHARK ATTACK -- (2005) Since school's out for the summer, what better way to kick off beach season than with this goofy gorefest? Sharks terrorize vacationing college students in Florida, during spring break of course. Will the sexy coed Danielle (Shannon Lucio, of ''The O.C.'') become fish bait? 9 P.M. (Sundance) THE LADY IN QUESTION IS CHARLES BUSCH -- (2005) Here's another television premiere pegged to Gay Pride month. This documentary recounts the ''drag to riches'' tale of Charles Busch - from stagestruck teenager to genderbending comic diva - in a profile that chronicles his early success with the hugely popular ''Vampire Lesbians of Sodom'' and continues through his more recent experiences on Broadway with ''Taboo'' and ''The Tale of the Allergist's Wife.'' 9 P.M. (13) HISTORY DETECTIVES -- Season four kicks off with the team of historical experts walking along the Chisholm Trail, where more than six million cattle were herded after the Civil War, providing needed food to the East and giving birth to the legend of the American cowboy. Also tonight, a mysterious Harry Houdini poster and a flag that may have once draped the casket of President William McKinley. 10 P.M. (ABC) HOW TO GET THE GUY -- The women dine blindfolded with a different date for each course, but will choose one to actually see during dessert. 10 P.M. (13) FREE SPEECH -- Jim Lehrer conducts an indepth interview with Ben Bradlee, the former executive editor of The Washington Post, about the current state of journalism. Issues include anonymous sources and the general decline in public opinion toward the news media. STEVEN McELROY

NESTL√â SET TO BUY JENNY CRAIG -- Nestl√©, the Swiss food company, is planning to announce today that it has agreed to acquire Jenny Craig, the weight-loss company, for about $600 million. [Page C1.] QUESTIONS ON OPTIONS -- A case involving Micrel, a semiconductor company, raises questions about how companies that were pushing the envelope of accounting and tax practice were able to get the blessings of auditors and lawyers. [C1.] GAME MAKERS' STOCKS SINK -- Video game companies have been taking a beating in the stock market, reflecting a realization that the game industry will recover considerably more slowly than expected from the transition to a new generation of consoles, the Xbox 360 from Microsoft, the Sony PlayStation 3 and the Nintendo Wii. [C1.] TRIBUNE STRATEGY FALTERS -- Recent financial troubles at the Tribune Company show that its ''synergy'' strategy -- sharing broadcast and print content -- is not working out as planned. [C1.] DOWLOADABLE EXERCISE -- More personal trainers are packaging their services in audio or video files that can be downloaded to an iPod or P.D.A. for a quick trip to the gym. For example, Kimberly Fowler, left, who owns the YAS Yoga and Spinning Studio in Venice, Calif., uploaded a 53-minute workout video to iAmplify.com, the first of what she said would be a video series that could be viewed online or on devices like iPods. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C5.] REPORTERS TOLD TO LEAVE -- Last Wednesday, after spending four days reporting from the United States Naval Base at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, three newspaper reporters and a photographer were ordered off the island by the Pentagon. But it is not clear why they were banished. [C3.] BEYOND TOYS FOR PLAYSKOOL -- In a foray into the infant care market, Playskool's owner, Hasbro, will introduce a line of Playskool diapers, baby wipes and sippy cups. [C1.] TRYING IT, AGAIN -- The comedian Kathy Griffin is appearing in a remake of one of Madison Avenue's most popular commercials, the humorous 1971 spot for Alka-Seltzer known as ''Try it, you'll like it.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C8.] ONLINE CHINA'S DARK CLOUDS -- David Barboza discusses how China's coal industry is creating an environmental and health care crisis in a video report at nytimes.com/business. LITTLE LEAGUE'S LAST DAY -- Harry Hurt III, the writer of Executive Pursuits, reports on the last day of Little League at nytimes.com/business. THE CLASSICS -- Previous columns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/pages/timesselect.

SUMMERTIME is not so easy for people living with certain autoimmune diseases. The sun, heat and even air-conditioning can intensify symptoms and cause problems that linger for months, if not years. For doctors who manage those diseases, primarily lupus, scleroderma and Raynaud's phenomenon, the challenges of educating their patients about sun avoidance become greater, too.

NEWMAN--Fred, age 82, of Roslyn Heights, NY, passed away June 16, 2006. Attorney with Salamon, Gruber, Newman, Blaymore & Strenger, P.C. Fred is survived by his loving wife Claire of 59 years, his devoted children Ellen Deffes and Douglas Newman, two cherished grandchildren, Adrien and Jennifer, and loving sister Libby Solomon. Funeral services will be held at noon, Monday, June 19, at Gutterman's 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY.

THE comedian Kathy Griffin is perhaps best known for her self-mocking reality series ''My Life on the D-List.'' Now, an advertiser is promoting her to the A-list -- but as she might be quick to point out, the ''A'' stands for that most prestigious and glamorous of brands, Alka-Seltzer. Ms. Griffin appears in a remake of one of Madison Avenue's most popular commercials, a humorous 1971 spot for Alka-Seltzer known as ''Try it, you'll like it.'' The re-created commercial is to begin running today on television as well as on the brand's Web site (alka-seltzer.com), where it will be accompanied by features like a ''blooper reel'' of outtakes. Try It; You Liked It Once, and Alka-Seltzer Hopes You Do Again
''I will bend over backwards to build good relations with those who don't agree with me.'' KATHARINE JEFFERTS SCHORI, the new head of the Episcopal Church. [A15]

Dr. Morton M. Kligerman, who in the 1950's was an early advocate for using radiation and other experimental methods for treating cancer, died on June 7 in Philadelphia. He was 88. The cause was complications of esophageal cancer, his family said.

DWORETSKY--Ephraim D. Beloved husband of 55 years to Martha (ZL). Loving father of Harold and Laura, Eli and Rena, Ray (ZL) and Aliza, adored grandfather and great grandfather. Professor of accounting at LIU, QCC, and ORT College. $(6$)DWORETSKY -- Ephraim. Our community had been blessed and enhanced by Professor Dworetsky's visits. Professor Dworetsky was a man of intellect, humor, humility, humanity and showed the proper path of Jewish Orthodoxy in the modern world. In short, not only was he a professor of accounting but he was a teacher of life and Jewish piety. May G-d comfort his mourners, who include all of Israel, among the mourners of Zion. The Young Israel of New Rochelle Community

If reality television has taught anything, it is that many Americans are eager to become the next American Idol, Top Model or Apprentice. Do some of them also dream of being a published comic-book creator? That is certainly the hope of Scott Mitchell Rosenberg, chairman of Platinum Studios, a company with interests in comics, film and more. ''I've had a long history of being willing to look at unpublished writers and artists,'' Mr. Rosenberg said. One of the company's biggest hits, ''Men in Black'' (which inspired the megasuccessful Will Smith films), was rejected by scores of publishers before Mr. Rosenberg said yes. Visitors to www.comicbookchallenge.com can submit their artwork or story ideas through July 5. A team at Platinum, which is open to concepts beyond superheroes (one project in development, ''Cowboys & Aliens,'' left, mixes genres), will choose 50 finalists, who will present their work to judges on July 20 in San Diego. The top three will pitch their ideas on ''Streetside San Diego,'' on KNSD, the NBC television affiliate in San Diego. Votes cast online from July 21 to 24 will decide the winner. ''We feel that's important because the American public knows what they want to buy, and there's nothing better than asking to find out,'' Mr. Rosenberg said. The winner's work will have its premiere at a 2007 comic-book event. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

OLSHANSKY--Joan Rosmarin. Resident of Great Barrington, MA, formerly of New Rochelle and Manhattan, on June 16, 2006, surrounded by family. Survived by her husband of 54 years, Mark Olshansky, her children Neil and Karen Olshansky, Stephen Olshansky and Miranda and Jeff Levin, her granddaughter Hannah Olshansky and her sister Maxine Shapiro. Funeral services will be held at Finnerty and Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main St, Great Barrington, MA, noon on Tuesday, June 20, 2006.

An article on Friday about the Office of General Counsel to the House of Representatives referred incorrectly to a request that the office file a memorandum in Federal District Court supporting Representative William J. Jefferson's lawsuit against the Department of Justice. The counsel's office was asked to file the memorandum by all five members of a bipartisan legal advisory group, consisting of the three ranking House Republicans and the two ranking Democrats. The request was not solely from the Republican leadership.

WHILE joggers, weightlifters, recreational softball players and other fitness enthusiasts will surely be delighted to hear that exercise science now sees lactic acid as a force of good and not evil, the fact remains that people are sore. What can be done about it? While lactic acid can cause a burning sensation during hard exercise (because it is, as the name suggests, acidic) recent research has confirmed that the real culprits for the so-called delayed muscle soreness that comes one to three days after a big game or heavy workout are microscopic tears and trauma to the muscles and inflammation.

MORRIS--Florence. Passed away peacefully, Friday, June 16, at home, just short of her 92nd birthday. Devoted widow of J. Lincoln Morris (Pud), dear sister of Richard Carlton, sister-in-law of Blossom Carlton, caring aunt of Joyce and Howard Jaffe, Ralph and Susie Carlton, Ken Carlton and Karen and Allan Wood. A longtime resident of Sutton Place and La Coquille at Westhampton Beach, LI. Florence traveled the world but loved New York, where she was a consummate theater goer, bridge player, sometime golfer and tennis player. A vibrant woman who virtually walked through life via the sidewalks of the city and the wonderful beaches of Westhampton shore. Life was an endless panorama of sights and sounds. It was a full life with few regrets--perhaps the envy of all who knew her. The family wishes to express their gratitude to caregivers Audrey Felix and Andrea Fletcher for their dedication to Florence these past years and to the end. Service Tuesday, 11:30 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

GRAEV--Abraham(Al). passed away on June 15, 2006, at the age of 91 after a short illness. He was born in New York City on February 19, 1915, where he attended Stuyvesant High School and the Engineering School of New York University. He sang in the Children's Chorus of the New York Metropolitan Opera. He spent most of his professional career with the Eclipse-Pioneer Division of the Bendix Corporation, where he worked on a number of classified aeronautical and aerospace projects. He finished his professional career with Diagnostic Retrieval Systems. Mr. Graev is survived by his wife, the former Beatrice Ruthman, his two sons Lawrence and Bruce and their loving wives, Lorna and Nancy, and his four grandchildren, Adam, Nicole, Alyson and Stephanie. He was a wonderful and loving father and grandfather and we will all miss him. Donations can be made to the Beatrice and Abraham Graev Scholarship Fund at Cornell University, 139 East Seneca Street, Suite 400, Ithaca, NY 14850-4353.
To the Editor: Re ''Study Finds Huge Fraud in the Wake of Hurricanes'' (news article, June 14):

DREIER--Sidney, 90. Beloved husband of Mildred for 60 years. Extremely loving father of Francine (Burtt), Marc, Mitchel (Nancy). Cherished grandfather of Julie, David, Spencer, Jackie, Katie and Benjamin. Born in Otynia, Poland in 1915, and educated in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, to be a physician, he arrived in America in 1939, a captain in the Polish army, to represent his country at the World's Fair. WWII intervened and he remained in America, forging a career as an independent motion picture executive, becoming known and respected throughout the industry. Services will be held on Monday, June 18 at 2:15, Star of David Chapel, 7701 Bailey Road, Tamarac, Florida. Shiva will be observed at home in Boca Raton, Monday following the services, and Tuesday from 2-8 PM, and at his son, Marc's home at 150 East 57th Street, NYC, Wednesday, 6-9PM and Thursday 2-8PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486.

The Chrysler 300, the Ford Five Hundred and other full-size sedans without side air bags failed recent side-impact crash tests, according to test results released yesterday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The results showed that a driver's risk of serious or fatal head injuries declined significantly when the same vehicles were tested with the optional air bags.

Devoted father of Robert, John, Kathleen MacLennan, Mary Pat Metcalf, Peg Smith, Sheila Jemella, Jean Cooksey and Maureen Roslak. Dear brother of Charles O'Connor and Mary Therese Geraci and the late Kathleen O'Connor. Loving stepfather of Sheila Collier, Kevin Hendricks and Maureen Godfrey. In lieu of flowers contributions to the St. Joseph's New Church Fund, POB 719, Croton Falls, NY 10519 or to the charity of your choice.

LEWIN--Harry M. of Palm Beach, FL, and Montauk, NY. Son of Arthur and Sadie Lewin. Devoted husband of Estelle Lewin. Loving father of Linda and husband David Taub, Marc & Sandy Taub and Joshua & Lisa Taub. Loving great-grandfather of Jake, Trevor, Chloe, Camille & Asher Michael. Survived by his brother Norman of Phoenix, AZ. Died on June 16th 2006. A lawyer by training and practice, he was vice president of Damart Enterprises for the last 30 years. For most of his working career, he was a highly successful restaurateur as the owner of several New York ''landmark'' restaurants including The Old Homestead, The Pressbox, Manny Wolfs Chop House, Shines, The Assembly, and The Double Dolphin. He was associated for many years with Palm Bay Imports, a well known U.S. wine and spirits importer. He continued his active business career throughout his entire life. He treasured his close family ties and was a source of inspiration for his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren who in turn loved him deeply. He will be greatly missed by all. The funeral will be held on Monday, June 19th at 1:00 at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

DUNN -- Irving, M.D. We grieve this wonderful man, so loved by Renee and his beloved children Roark, Darin and Jenny/Ryan, and their families. Our thoughts are with you. Eisenberg Family

Boy Falsely Accused at 7 Is Accused Again at 15 In 1998, 7-year-old Romarr Gipson and an 8-year-old friend were charged with killing a little girl in Chicago. But after a month, the authorities said an adult was the real killer, and Romarr eventually got a $2 million settlement in a false-arrest lawsuit. Now 15, he is back in court, facing charges in the shooting of two men at a gas station. PAGE A12 Culture Battles in Somalia Flush from a military victory this month that caught Washington and the world by surprise, Islamic militiamen have begun waging smaller battles -- cultural, not military ones -- in and around Somalia's shellshocked capital. PAGE A11 U.S. and China Court Hanoi The United States and China are competing for the allegiance of Vietnam, a growing capitalist power. Vietnam wants the United States on its side as a counterweight to an increasingly influential China. PAGE A3 Warning for A.C.L.U. Board The New York attorney general's office warned that it had concerns about a plan to limit public speech by members of the A.C.L.U. board, board members say. PAGE A13 Sinking Island in Louisiana An island that is home to the Biloxi-Chitimacha tribe is sinking into the bayou, but the government has decided that it is not worth $100 million to save it. PAGE A12 Klimt Portrait Sells for a Record $135 Million The cosmetics magnate Ronald S. Lauder purchased Gustav Klimt's 1907 ''Adele Bloch-Bauer I,'' for his Neue Galerie in New York. Looted by the Nazis, it had been restored to the subject's heirs in January. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Stock Options Under Inquiry A Silicon Valley recruiting strategy in the 1990's was to value hefty stock options at the lowest price within 30 days of a hiring date. As an unintended consequence, many companies are accused of accounting irregularities. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 A Toy Maker Branches Out With traditional toy sales flagging, Hasbro's Playskool line is introducing a line of diapers, baby wipes and sippy cups, competing with Procter & Gamble and Kimberly-Clark. CASTLE -Cyril. Passed away on June 15th. Born in London, 1922, he will be dearly missed by his beloved wife, Betty, of 61 years, his children Michael and Gary, his daughters-inlaw Susan and Lori and his grandchildren Daniel, Alexis, Rebecca, Gregory and Jamie.

GRIBETZ -- Allen R., 59, passed away suddenly on June 17, 2006, highly respectied physician specializing in pulmonary disease, survived by his wife of 27 years, Jessica Schacter Gribetz, their daughters, Julie, Nina, Anna and Kate, mother, Florence Gribetz, and brothers, Kenneth and Michael Gribetz. Funeral services June 19, 9:30 am, at Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 East 85th St. $(6$)GRIBETZ--Allen. Dr. Carol Rosenbaum and Dr. Louis Depalo mourn the passing of Dr. Allen Gribetz, our colleague, friend and mentor. Allen's good cheer and steadfastness will be a loss to us all.
