Since the Mavericks arrived in Miami for the N.B.A. finals, all they seemed to do well was fold their tents and watch Dwyane Wade go. First, the Mavericks collapsed under Wade in the final 6 minutes 34 seconds of Game 3, losing a 13-point advantage and the chance to jump to a 3-0 series lead. Then, after the Heat pounded the Mavericks in Game 4, Dallas Coach Avery Johnson packed their belongings and sent the team to seclusion in Fort Lauderdale.

ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators, a forecast of economic activity, is expected to fall 0.5 percent for May, a sharper decline than the 0.1 percent drop in April. (Thursday.) ANY CLUES? -- The Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank president, Jack Guynn, is to speak about the economic outlook of the United States, in Naples, Fla., a week before the next two-day meeting of the interest-rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee. (Monday.) MEASURING REAL ESTATE -- Housing starts for May are expected to be 1.87 million, up from 1.85 million in April. (Tuesday.) DURABLE GOODS -- Orders for durable goods are expected to be 0.5 percent higher for May, a sharp improvement over April, when such orders dropped by 4.8 percent compared with the previous month. (Friday.) WHERE THE FOOD IS -- Kroger, the biggest grocery store chain in the United States, will release its quarterly earnings report on Tuesday, and hold its annual shareholders' meeting on Thursday. OVERNIGHT -- Investors who attach importance to the fortunes of delivery services as economic indicators will be paying close attention when FedEx, the No. 2 courier after U.P.S., reports its quarterly earnings. Morgan Stanley will issue its earnings report the same day. (Wednesday.) MORE REPORTS -- Rite Aid, the drugstore chain, above, expects to report profit for its latest quarter of 3 cents a share, compared with a nickel a share in the same period a year ago. Oracle, the software maker, is scheduled to report earnings on the same day. (Thursday.)

WHILE joggers, weightlifters, recreational softball players and other fitness enthusiasts will surely be delighted to hear that exercise science now sees lactic acid as a force of good and not evil, the fact remains that people are sore. What can be done about it? While lactic acid can cause a burning sensation during hard exercise (because it is, as the name suggests, acidic) recent research has confirmed that the real culprits for the so-called delayed muscle soreness that comes one to three days after a big game or heavy workout are microscopic tears and trauma to the muscles and inflammation.
GLADSTONE--Irving. Another year , Irving--nothing changes--I miss you all the time. Bertha

'Cars' Roars On The G-rated ''Cars'' (Buena Vista), right, rolled past the $100 million milestone in its second week in release as it gathered an estimated $31.1 million in weekend grosses to retain its top ranking at North American box offices. Finishing second to the animated auto film was the new comedy ''Nacho Libre'' (Paramount), starring Jack Black as a Mexican luchadore, or masked wrestler. It took in $27.5 million, according to the estimates of the box-office tracking company Exhibitor Relations. Next came ''The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift'' (Universal), with $24.1 million, and ''The Lake House'' (Warner Brothers), with $13.6 million. Rounding out the top five was the Jennifer Aniston-Vince Vaughn vehicle ''The Break-Up'' (Universal), with $9.5 million, a 53 percent decline from the previous week, which nonetheless left it with a three-week total of $91.9 million. Maybe No Baby in Namibia The budding status of Namibia as maternity ward to the stars was looking less fruitful yesterday after a tourism official said he might have been duped into believing that Britney Spears, below, was considering traveling there to give birth to her second child, The Associated Press reported. The official, Leon Jooste, deputy environment and tourism minister, said he made his announcement after receiving a telephone call last Monday from the United States. But he said the connection was so bad that he never got a name or contact information. After The Associated Press reported his saying there was ''a definite possibility'' that Ms. Spears might go to Namibia, it received an e-mail message from a press representative, Leslie Sloane Zelnik, saying, ''Not true.'' Mr. Jooste said he would investigate. Angelina Jolie, seeking privacy, gave birth to her daughter by Brad Pitt in Namibia in May. Auction Is Unsettling To French Academics French academics are keeping a wary eye on an auction tomorrow of a valuable private collection of manuscripts, fearing that some might go abroad, Agence France-Presse reported. In particular they are concerned about two Stendhal manuscripts: 570 pages of his journal and a corrected version of his 1839 novel ''The Charterhouse of Parma,'' reworked, according to the author's notes, ''following the advice of Mr. Balzac.'' The works, to be sold by the Drouot auction house in Paris, come from the collection of Pierre Ber√®s, 93, who decided last year to sell 177 manuscripts and rare editions, collected during the last 80 years and valued at $7.5 million. They include manuscripts by Balzac, Proust and Rimbaud, and a copy of Flaubert's ''Madame Bovary'' dedicated to Alexandre Dumas. Turkish TV Boots Piglet Piglet may have a pal in Winnie-the-Pooh, but he has no friend in the state-owned Turkish television network TRT, Agence France-Presse reported, citing accounts in the Turkish press. The network, an arm of the government, has banned the Walt Disney cartoon ''Winnie the Pooh'' because Piglet, below with Pooh, is a pig; Muslims regard pigs as unclean, and Islam prohibits the consumption of pork. TRT officials were not immediately available for comment, but ''Winnie the Pooh'' has been seen on other television channels in Turkey, and the videos are readily available in stores. Employees of TRT have recently complained of increasing government intervention in TRT policy, and Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Justice and Development Party are under fire for seeking to raise the profile of Islam in predominantly Muslim but strictly secular Turkey. Footnotes Four weeks have been added to the run of the well-received ''Spring Awakening'' at the Atlantic Theater Company. The final production of the company's 20th season and the first musical in its history, ''Spring Awakening,'' with music by Duncan Sheik, below, and book and lyrics by Steven Sater, will continue through Aug. 6. The annual ''Spirit of Django Reinhardt'' concert will have a new home this summer. Usually at Alice Tully Hall, it will take place in the Rose Theater at Frederick P. Rose Hall, the home of Jazz at Lincoln Center, on Aug. 1 at 8 p.m. The lineup of virtuosic Gypsy jazz guitarists includes Dorado Schmitt, his son Samson and, for the first time, his cousin Tchavolo Schmitt. Other performers include the violinist Florin Niculescu, the accordionist Ludovic Beier, the pianist Peter Beets and the saxophonist Joel Frahm. The Peccadillo Theater Company, which specializes in producing American theater classics like ''Counsellor at Law'' and ''The Shanghai Gesture,'' plans to revive the 1937 door-slamming farce ''Room Service,'' made into a Marx Brothers vehicle a year later. The new production of that comedy by John Murray and Allen Boretz, about a scheming theatrical producer holed up in a Times Square hotel with 19 starving actors while trying to rehearse and find a backer for his show, will open on July 10 at the Bank Street Theater in the West Village. Dan Wackerman will direct, and David Edwards, who played Max Bialystock in the national tour of ''The Producers,'' will portray the producer.

1 -- A Time to Make Friends POLITICAL CONTROVERSY SWIRLS around Iran's presence in the tournament, but then an Iran fan writes to the Times blog: ''World Cup would have been a great opportunity for us ordinary Iranians to remind the world of our humanity. We are a lonely people: oppressed by our own regime at home and dehumanized by the media abroad. How fitting would it be if we could use this chance to overcome this loneliness, even if for a short time. Alas that it is not going to happen. ... Or maybe I shall hope for a more understanding world for just a short while? It is still a joy to be part of all this.'' Others write in to express their support. ''You're part of this world,'' one writes. ''We love you. Right now, enjoy the goals in Germany. God bless you.'' So we are reminded that the World Cup is not about politics or ugly nationalism; it is about joy and fun and communion. As the tournament slogan says, this is a time to make friends. 2 -- The Battle Of Kaiserslautern THE UNITED STATES PLAYERS, facing elimination, fight like lions against Italy before a crowd whose American supporters are louder than Italy's. Perhaps they fight a little too hard -- two American players are red-carded, along with one from Italy. But they battle to a 1-1 draw and earn the respect of fans around the world. As the Scottish comedian Billy Connolly pointed out that night in New York, in England or Scotland the players would perform a lap of honor if they earned a 1-1 tie with Italy. ''Actually, in Scotland, we perform a lap of honor when we lose,'' he said. 3 -- The Grief and Joy Of Oswaldo S√°nchez MEXICO GOALKEEPER Oswaldo S√°nchez's father died of a heart attack three days before the opening match against Iran. He flew back to Guadalajara, where he spent 24 hours to mourn with his family, then went back to Germany with family members and was fantastic in a 3-1 victory. 4 -- The Pride Of Mother Africa THE FIVE AFRICAN NATIONS in the tournament -- four of them debutants -- started slowly. Then Tunisia scored an injury-time goal to tie Saudi Arabia, 2-2. Then Angola's 36-year-old unemployed goalkeeper Jo√£o Ricardo almost single-handedly stopped Mexico in a 0-0 draw. And then, Ghana put on a virtuoso performance against a Czech Republic team that a few days before had looked unbeatable. 5 -- The Goal of 24 Touches AT ONE POINT DURING the match between Argentina and Serbia and Montenegro, Univision's color commentator Jos√© Lu√≠s Chilavert claimed that Argentina was passing to the beat of a tango. He sang along, and it seemed true. The Argentines won by 6-0, and the second goal, by Esteban Cambiasso, was preceded by an incredible 24 straight passes. The end sequence: Sor√≠n to Saviola, to Riquelme, back to Saviola, across to Cambiasso, to Crespo, backheel to Cambiasso. Goal -- one of the most beautiful in World Cup history. 6 -- Ecuador in the City AS ECUADOR logged two entirely surprising victories to advance to the second round, the team's bright yellow shirts seemed to be everywhere in the streets of Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan. One of us has one, wore it and walked around Brooklyn. Immediately, a shout from a passer-by: ''Ecuador!'' A well-dressed old man, sitting on a stoop: ''They win again today, no?'' Yes, sir, they did. 7 -- Brave Soca Warriors FIRST THERE WAS SHAKA HISLOP versus Sweden. Hislop, a journeyman goalkeeper, stopped everything Sweden had for outmatched Trinidad and Tobago. Then there was little T&T's performance against mighty England, holding out for 80 minutes until finally falling to what now seems to have been a tainted goal. ''SOCA WARRIORS!!!'' one woman from Trinidad wrote on the Times blog. ''You've made your T&T people very proud! Keep playing your hearts out!'' 8 -- Peter Crouch AFTER STRUGGLING EARLY against Trinidad and Tobago, Crouch remembered why big men are on the field, heading a pinpoint cross from David Beckham to give a flagging England its first goal ina 2-0 victory -- even if he had to pull on the dreadlocks of T&T defender Brent Sancho to do it. 9 -- Germany Gets the Party Started GERMANY 4, COSTA RICA 2: The hosts win an entertaining opening match, which offers the promise of a great tournament ahead with six goals, as many as the openers of the last four World Cups combined. 10 -- America's Embrace FLYING FROM SAN FRANCISCO at lunchtime on opening day, one of us tried to catch a few minutes of the Ecuador-Poland match. We belong to a generation that has had to beg barkeeps to change the TV channel to soccer. But we're in luck: The terminal's one restaurant is showing the game. A crowd of businessmen, commuters and maintenance crews are all glued to the screen. There's no eat-your-greens moralizing about the virtues of the world'sbiggest sporting event -- just Americans watching and enjoying it.
KADUSHIN--Sylvia. 1913-2005. Never forgotten, always loved, constantly and sadly missed. Al , Goldie and Raphael

FIELDS - Eleanor. Passed away on June 17, 2006, at the age of 92. Ellie was a woman of great vitality, intelligence and accomplishment. She was a guiding force in many worthy causes, travelled the world, and was adored by her family and friends. Survived by brother Joel Williams, son Jack and daughter-in-law Marilyn; grandchildren, Jonathan Fields and Lauren and Larry Talve, Douglas Nelson and Victoria and Jose Gordo; great-grandmother to Lindsay, Ashley, Zack, Veronica and Victor. Graveside services at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Tuesday, 2 pm. Family will receive friends at the home of Jack and Marilyn Fields, Tuesday and Wednesday, 4-8 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Presbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68 St, NYC 10021.

With the loss of its postseason basketball broadcasts, TNT ceded prime time's No. 1 cable slot back to USA Network in the second week of June. According to Nielsen estimates, USA programming occupied the week's top four among total viewers. Its two hours of ''WWE Monday Night Raw'' (5.4 million, then 4.5 million) ranked first and second, followed by the season premiere of ''The 4400'' (4.2 million) on June 11. In fourth place was the second hour of ''WWE vs. ECW: Head to Head'' (4.2 million). (The revived Extreme Championship Wrestling brand is Sci Fi Channel's new show, but its corporate sibling USA gave it a boost before the channel's larger audience.) The rest of the week's Top 10 on cable were Nickelodeon broadcasts, and that children's channel was No. 1 in the total day, as always. KATE AURTHUR
IGNATOW--Archie. Memories and thoughts of you, especially on your birthday. Love, Gene and three Generations

Six Organs of Admittance ''The Sun Awakens'' (Drag City) For a band working on a little budget -- it comes down to one musician, Ben Chasny, with various helpers -- Six Organs of Admittance creates a gigantic mood.

INGRAHAM--David Jr. Died suddenly on June 13, 2006, at home in Laurel Hollow, NY, at the age of 62. He was a graduate of Boston University and Columbia University Business School and a former Vice President of Smith Barney and partner at Lafer Amster & Co. He is survived by his mother Laura Jennings Ingraham of Hanover, NH, sister Alice I. Davies, Weston, MA, brothers Frederic B. Ingraham, Laurel Hollow, John W. Ingraham, Tulsa, OK, seven nieces and nephews, and many friends.
To the Editor: Re ''Worse Than Nothing'' (editorial, June 14):

Yesterday, I claimed that a major reason large evolutionary changes often don't happen is that competition from the creatures around you stops you from changing. In other words, in environments that are already rich in different species, natural selection often prevents large changes. My piece of evidence for this was a claim that, when you take other organisms away - when you reduce competition for food, or space - evolution explodes. Today, I want to examine the truth of these claims more closely.
George Vecsey and Roger Cohen reveal the teams they would most like to run in this tournament -- and which ones they wouldn't touch.
Affordable Montenegro will not be around much longer. Unlike Croatia, this country is small, and the future of its beautiful beaches and wild hills seems to include only luxury travelers.
To underscore his new property tax plan, Eliot Spitzer has a new 30-second commercial that starts running tonight. Watch it here.

Breaking days of silence over the fate of its its Printemps department-store chain, French retail and luxury-goods group PPR said Tuesday that it was in "exclusive talks" to sell the business for 1.075 billion euro ($1.35 billion). The would-be buyer is a partnership between Deutsche Bank's real estate investment arm and Italy's Borletti family, PPR said.

A month ago, Merrill Lynch executives suggested the firm was in the market for a mortgage lender. Now the securities firm says it is hunting for acquisitions and joint ventures overseas. Citing comments from Merrill Lynch vice chairman Robert McCann at a presentation on Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that European private-client businesses -- those that cater to wealthy investors -- are looking particularly attractive:
Click "more" for play by play of the match, LIVE as it happened at the Fritz-Walter-Stadion in Kaiserslautern. Jeff Z. Klein describes the action.
Peter Kalikow may be staying on at the MTA for a while longer.
For live updates of Duncan Irving's commentary of England-Sweden from Cologne, press "more"
Technology deals and cross-border transactions are expected to make a strong showing in the back half of 2006, according to a recent poll of 1,200 deal-making professionals and corporate executives.
So call us softies, but it seemed pretty difficult not to smile at Willie Brodsky.

Bank of America has hired an investment banker from Citigroup for its financial institutions group. J. Kenneth McPhail will join Bank of America in July as head of North American depository institutions, the firm said. He will be a managing director based in New York. At Citigroup, Mr. McPhail had been head of North American banks within its financial institutions group.

Viewed over the long run, the recently announced joint venture between telecommunications giants Nokia and Siemens is winning praise from many observers. But two analysts on Tuesday cut their ratings on Nokia's stock, citing concerns about the short run.
Dwyane Wade and the Miami Heat again found answers when the Dallas Mavericks couldn't, pulling out a victory and the N.B.A. championship.

Savanna Energy Services, a Canadian oilfield-services company, agreed to buy Western Lakota Energy Services for 626.9 million Canadian dollars ($561.1 million) to add rigs that can drill for deeper oil and natural-gas deposits. Western Lakota's stockholders will receive 0.64 share of Savanna for each of their shares, the Calgary-based companies said on Tuesday. Savanna's shareholders will own 51.5 percent of the combined company.

The New York Stock Exchange's head of regulation, Richard Ketchum, said Monday he was concerned about potentially improper short-selling practices surrounding stock offerings, Reuters reported. The issue relates to secondary offerings, rather than initial public offerings, where there is already traded stock to sell short.
Emmis Communications's board of directors said Monday it had brought in legal and financial counsel to advise the company on a management buyout offer.

Andrew Sullivan has dubbed the backlash against the blogosphere the "bloglash," and he says it "is now in full swing." (In February, the bloglash was merely "gaining traction.") Slate's John Dickerson predicted last week, "We are probably just under five months away from a wave of coverage positing that bloggers weren't that powerful after all." Perhaps he meant five days?

There are 173 companies that offer online video services, according to Business 2.0 magazine. Of those, 85 host videos and allow users to share them. In April, three of them got $30 million in venture financing.

As European governments make noises about imposing stiff regulations on hedge funds, the industry is talking more about regulating itself, according to Bill Barnhart, a columnist with the Chicago Tribune.
Germany routs Ecuador to win its group and face Sweden.

As part of what it called its "ongoing efforts to enhance shareowner value," Rockwell Automation said Monday it had hired Sagent Advisors to sell its Dodge mechanical and Reliance Electric motors and motor-repair services businesses.

The Senate Democrats have offered an amendment designed to move the ball forward on Iraq and clarify their position on this contentious issue. Hillary Clinton is an original co-sponsor of the legislation, and according to Congressional sources familiar with the process, she played an active behind-the-scenes role in crafting it.
Now that she has the Conservative Party endorsement firmly in hand, Jeanine F. Pirro is tacking back to the center.

The Federal Communications Commission has approved the merger of Intelsat and PanAmSat Holding, removing one of the final hurdles to the deal, which will create the world's largest satellite operator. The two companies, which announced their $3.2 billion merger in August 2005, said Tuesday they expect to complete the transaction on July 3.
The private equity firm Texas Pacific Group is prepared to finance a bid for AOL Germany by the Internet service provider freenet, a newspaper reported.
Clever hackers have figured out a way to switch between programs by swatting the side of a computer screen.

There may be trouble ahead in the private equity business, according to some European leaders of the industry. Thanks to the "permissive environment," recent deals have included record levels of debt, Ronald Cohen, founder of Apax Founders, tells The Financial Times. A correction is coming, according to Jon Moulton, head of Alchemy.
Follow Germany-Ecuador with Victor Mather here.
The outgoing Goldman Sachs chief executive Hank Paulson last week got a subpoena from Richard Grasso's legal team to testify in his civil trial, according to CNBC's Charles Gasparino.
Fidelity International is to split its 6 billion pound Special Situations Fund into one fund focusing on UK stocks, and another called the Global Special Situations Fund.
Click "more" for play-by-play of the match, LIVE as it happened at the Niedersachsenstadion in Hanover. Jeff Z. Klein describes the action.
Surely there's no tighter twosome in Washington than Chuck Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Surely.

Otis Spunkmeyer Holdings, which sells frozen cookie dough and other baked goods, filed a preliminary prospectus to raise as much as $230 million in an initial public offering. The company is controlled by affiliates of private equity firm Code Hennessy & Simmons. Merrill Lynch and J.P. Morgan Chase are serving as underwriters.
Sinopec, the Chinese oil company, has signed an agreement to buy a mid-sized oil unit, Udmurtneft, from the Russian oil company, TNK-BP, marking China's first foray into Russian oil.
More than eight months after Pakistan's worst-ever earthquake, families in Muzaffarabad still swelter in tents.
Scenes from this year's benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

The media group Tribune said late Monday that it had secured commitments for a total of $2.25 billion in loans to provide funds for a proposed repurchase of the company's shares. The agreements, which include a $750 million revolving facility and a $1.5 billion term loan, come from a group including Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and J.P. Morgan Chase, Tribune said in a regulatory filing.
A man's quest to retrieve a friend's lost cellphone ended with a teen's arrest in Queens and her humiliation on the Internet.
Three former natural gas energy traders pleaded guilty to price manipulation charges Monday, authorities said.

The head of Japan's central bank apologized Tuesday for an investment scandal that triggered calls for his resignation and said the bank had set up a committee to review investment rules for its officials.

Conrad Black's $20 million bail bond should be modified or revoked, federal prosecutors said, claiming the former Hollinger International chairman had not been honest about the value of assets securing his freedom.

The Apollo Group, a for-profit education company whose schools include the University of Phoenix, said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the United States attorney's office for the Southern District of New York, related to stock option grants.
The Supreme Court agreed to consider a bid by Michigan to regulate Wachovia's mortgage-lending business in a case that may open banks to new oversight across the country.

A Federal Reserve governor, Mark W. Olson, was named yesterday as the chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, which regulates accounting firms and has come under fire from companies complaining that the costs of regulation have grown too high.
Telecom and media mergers would have an easier time winning government approval under legislation unveiled Monday by staffers for Senate Commerce Committee Chairman Ted Stevens.

Executives at the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company held an emergency meeting Monday to discuss their stumbling Airbus subsidiary, as an investigation about a stock sale by one of them continued.
June 19 - Business columnist Joe Sharkey recommends making a parking reservation before you head to the airport this summer. (Produced by Emily B. Hager)
June 20 - The Times's Cornelia Dean highlights the rising sea level, a reality that threatens to erode many beaches. Producer: Adam B. Ellick

A Boston buyout shop, Heritage Partners, is selling the vacuum and commercial cleaning products maker Castle Rock Industries to Alfred K√§rcher, a German cleaning products company, LBO Wire reported. The deal is expected to close in the next few days.

Brambles is drawing up the final list of potential buyers for its British waste-management business after selling its Australian operations to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for 702 million pounds ($1.29 billion).
JH Partners said Monday it closed its second institutional fund, totaling $350 million.

NeoPhotonics, an optical networking component supplier, accepted a $50 million Series 3 round and picked up two venture-backed optical component start-ups, LightConnect and OpTun, for a combination of cash and stock.
Vaperma has raised $6.2 million to build the first demonstration units of its filtration technology, which is designed to reduce the processing costs of ethanol production.

A wave of cellphone start-ups, hoping to attract users to television, music and other premium services, are floundering as they fight over a thin slice of the U.S. market, according to a report from The Wall Street Journal.

Greentown China Holdings became the fourth Chinese property developer in short succession on Monday to seek a public listing when it started pre-marketing of a share offer of between $300 million and $400 million.

China's largest homegrown maker of wind-power generators, Goldwind Science and Technology, is pursuing a listing in the United States to bankroll an expansion aimed at driving an eight-fold increase in sales to 4 billion yuan ($500 million) by 2008.

Intelsat, the satellite provider to the United States military, cut the size of its planned sale of junk bonds on Tuesday by $600 million, to $2.9 billion, in a reflection of waning investor demand for high-yield, high-risk debt.

Lloyds TSB, Britain's fifth largest bank, said it had agreed with its pension scheme trustees to provide funds for its 1.5 billion pound ($2.8 billion) actuarial deficit over the next six years. The bank will also make extra voluntary contributions and expects the larger accounting deficit to be fully eliminated within 10 years.

The Supreme Court has asked the Office of the Solicitor General to weigh in on an antitrust class action suit that threatens the widespread reliance on syndicates to underwrite initial public offerings. The request indicates that the justices seek a unified federal position on a case that has split two key government agencies.

Sandy Weill, the former high-flying Citigroup chairman who was renowned for his love of private jets, has pledged to give away his estimated $1.4 billion personal fortune as part of a "deal with God."

The times they are a changin' at Goldman Sachs. The deputy secretary of state, Robert B. Zoellick, said Monday that he would be leaving his post as the State Department's second in command, as expected, to join the Wall Street investment house as a managing director.
Publicly traded EMC has acquired the venture-backed ProActivity Software Solutions in another deal that signals consolidation in the market for business process management software.
Aegon, the Dutch-listed insurance group rumored to be interested in Prudential, has agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in a Mexican insurer.
The King County Journal and nine other local newspapers have been put up for sale because their publisher said it lacks the resources to help them flourish.

General Electric agreed on Tuesday to pay $390 million to buy a Swedish life sciences company that makes machines used in biomedical and drug discovery. G.E. said it bid 3.22 billion kronor ($438 million), or 330 kronor a share, for the company, Biacore International.
Federated Department Stores is planning to end a financing agreement used to pay for its $17 billion acquisition of May last August, and will resume its stock repurchase program.
A magazine publisher, Emap is to return 285 million pounds ($524 million) to shareholders after agreeing on Tuesday to sell its French business to an Italian media group, Mondadori.

In a sign that American deal makers see more Canadian takeovers coming, a United States investment bank, Greenhill, rolled north on Monday by snapping up Toronto-based Beaufort Partners, an advisory firm run by veterans of Morgan Stanley and the Goldman Sachs Group.
The European Commission began an in-depth inquiry into the French government's plan to merge Suez and Gaz de France, giving regulators four months to scrutinize the controversial deal.

Mediaset, the broadcaster owned by the former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi, said it was interested in buying Big Brother production company Endemol. Endemol, a Dutch company owned by Telefonica of Spain has said it is considering offloading the production house.
Deutsche B√∂rse made some structural changes yesterday to its proposed bid to merge with Euronext, but fell short of analysts' expectations of sweetened financial terms.

Roman Abramovich, Russia's richest person, has agreed to buy about 41 percent of Evraz Group, Russia's largest steelmaker by volume, from its two biggest shareholders, in a deal estimated to be worth $3.2 billion. Mr. Abramovich will acquire the stake through investment boutique Millhouse.

The Steelmaker Arcelor has been summoned to appear before a Luxembourg court on Thursday as part of a lawsuit filed by a French shareholder defense group, ADAM, which seeks to postpone the June 30 general meeting on the planned merger with Severstal, and change the voting procedures.

The Hong Kong phone company PCCW said Tuesday it had received a bid for its telecommunications and media assets, with newspapers reporting that the potential buyer, Australia's Macquarie Bank, has put up 40 billion Hong Kong dollars ($5.2 billion) for the possible deal.

A federal judge sentenced a former stock picker, Anthony Elgindy, to 11 years and 3 months in prison for using inside information to make short sales and extort money from companies he had criticized in an online newsletter. Mr. Elgindy, 38, was convicted last year in federal court on 11 counts of racketeering conspiracy, securities fraud, wire fraud and extortion.

The private equity firm Carlyle Group has raised nearly $2 billion for buyouts in Japan and is set to close the fund shortly, underscoring investors' growing appetite for the asset class, industry sources told Reuters on Tuesday. This would be the biggest buyout fund ever destined for investment in the country, topping a $1.2 billion fund raised by Carlyle's United States peer Ripplewood in 1999.
Nortel Networks and Motorola. Nortel and Huawei. Motorola and Huawei. Juniper Networks and Nortel.
Fears that France would lose a rare Stendhal manuscript were allayed when the collector who had offered it for sale donated it to the nation.

The dismal performance of Vonage's initial public offering could make it seem as if 2006 has been a lousy year for new stocks. But there have been some winners. Many will remember the sizzling debut of Chipotle Mexican Grill, the McDonald's spinoff that went public at $22 per share in late January and recently closed at $60.98. But several smaller, lower-profile I.P.O.'s have also done well: Fortunet and Calumet Specialty Products, for example.
England finally got a result against Sweden it can live with. A tie was enough for the English to win Group B at the World Cup.
For first-time homeowners, the question of when to refinance, and how, can be particularly vexing.
The World Trade Center memorial and museum tries to solve security problems, placate disaffected family members and, most of all, bring the project close to the $500 million budget cap.

Tomorrow's final group C match between Holland and Argentina is in some ways meaningless, since both teams, having won twice, have already survived the Group of Death and are through to the round of 16. Perhaps the only slight advantage at stake is that the winner of the group would almost certainly not cross Brazil's path until the final on July 9 in Berlin. Then again, since the runner-up is shunted to the opposite side of the draw, and Brazil has not looked invincible so far, this match could also be a preview of the final itself. But rather than looking forward, let's look back for a moment. Since all three of the previous meetings between these two countries in the World Cup have been extraordinary in one way or another, it's impossible for fans of the game not to be reminded of them.
The Miami Heat won its first N.B.A. championship with a victory over the Dallas Mavericks in Game 6 in Dallas.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Good morning, soccer fans! Starting today, Tuesday, and continuing through Friday, we will experience along with you the World Cup's Four Days of Constant Peril, the unspeakable climax of group play. On each one of these days, two pairs of simultaneous matches will be played -- and we'll narrate the action for you in every one, live! At 10 a.m. New York time, and then again at 3 p.m., your brave Times play-by-play men will maintain a blog entry for both games, and you can keep those up on your screen to stay abreast of the ebb and flow and interplay between the games as they unfold.
If you are considering borrowing money against the equity in your house, it is important to compare two distinctly different types of credit ‚Äî loans and equity lines of credit.
Republican leaders said they would hold hearings this summer around the nation on the politically volatile subject before trying to compromise with the Senate.
A former White House official was convicted on four of five felony counts of lying and obstruction in charges tied to Jack Abramoff.
In an effort to salvage a deal, Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov changed the terms under which he would buy a big stake in the steel giant Arcelor.
Christopher McCarthy plans to finish the tour of New York that came to a violent end last week aboard a subway train.
Lewis, whose repeated attacks on people nearly sent his owner to jail, was sentenced by a judge today.
Charles Taylor will be tried by a United Nations-backed tribunal for crimes against humanity and on war crimes charges.
The announcement came five months before his contract as a correspondent on "60 Minutes" was due to expire.
The move, which comes amid growing management turmoil at EADS, could set the stage for a possible clash with the German government.
They were killed by an Israeli aircraft that had fired on a car suspected of carrying militants who had launched attacks against Israel.
Dominique de Villepin lost control when the Socialist Party leader berated the government for its handling of the crisis at Europe's leading aerospace company.
A hearing by the National Transportation Safety Board revealed previously unknown safety problems on Southwest Airlines Flight 1248.
The new design tries to solve security problems  and bring the project closer to the $500 million budget cap.
President Vladimir V. Putin named Justice Minister Yuri Chaika as his candidate for chief prosecutor Monday, an announcement covered on the front page of all leading newspapers.
The mayor of Connecticut's largest city says he abused cocaine and alcohol since becoming mayor in April 2003.
Construction of new homes rose in May, but the figures were still below last year's brisk pace.
The U.S. plans to run DNA tests on the remains of the two Americans, suggesting that they  had been wounded or mutilated beyond recognition.
The World Anti-Doping Agency on Monday rebutted accusations that it had acted unethically in connection with drug testing from the 1999 Tour de France.
On their third try, the Hurricanes finally beat the Oilers, squeaking out a 3-1 victory in Game 7 Monday night to win the Stanley Cup.
Two members of the Army were killed when their vehicle hit a roadside bomb in the Pech River Valley, the Department of Defense said.
Warner Music in Deal With China Unicom.
Moody's Investors Service, the financial rating agency, signed a letter of intent to occupy 15 floors in the 52-story tower, according to two real estate executives.
Randy Johnson threw seven strong innings, but the Yankees stranded 11 runners on base and went quietly in the ninth.
Bronson Arroyo pitched like a vintage El Duque, changing his rhythms and varying his arm angles, and the Mets could not compete.
By Bloomberg News.
Nelson Cabezas's van is labeled with diagrams about the Kabbalah, the ancient mystical movement often studied by Hasidic Jews.
A former agent who blew the whistle on failings in the investigation of Zacarias Moussaoui was criticized for her own actions in the case.
No one is quite sure when New York City children began celebrating spring by dancing in schoolyards. The rite has been around, it seems, for as long as the public school system itself.
Marty Siegel has visited nearly 2,000 7-Elevens in 23 states and 3 Canadian provinces.
The European Commission began an in-depth inquiry into the French government's plan to merge Suez and Gaz de France.
The developer hired to expand Penn Station also has a plan to move the New York arena and build five towers.
Dwayne Palmer told his girlfriend he was going to kill her, according to her neighbors and relatives. A few days later, Mr. Palmer tried to make good on his threat, the police say.
The governor's office pulled back on a nomination to the state Workers' Compensation Board after criticism of its timing.
Ernie Fletcher's approval ratings have dropped below 30 percent after he was accused in a patronage scandal.
Wal-Mart has transformed the sedate rural community of Bentonville, Ark., into a teeming mini-metropolis.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice warned North Korea again on Monday to refrain from testing a long-range ballistic missile.
Togo fluttered out of World Cup contention yesterday after one of the most tempestuous journeys in the tournament's history.
The progression of Australian Geoff Ogilvy to the realm of major champion has been forecast by many golfers in recent years.
By Reuters.
By Bloomberg News.

In 10 seconds on Sunday night, the N.B.A. finals bounced between two truths, the ones that Coach Pat Riley once coined as winning and misery. Riley's Heat has a 3-2 series edge heading into tonight's game in Dallas.
The Supreme Court's fractured decision on the Clean Water Act is likely to lead to new regulatory battles and a push for new legislation.
The teams took a step toward marketing stadium naming rights Monday by tapping the Wasserman Media Group to sell them.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey tried to bolster support for a sales tax increase, but yielded on a proposal to tax hospital beds.
Three casinos will finance weekend train service to and from New York City's Pennsylvania Station in a bid to win new customers.
How a Frenchman turned the tables on anti-Americana.

An article on June 11 about the end of a Hamas cease-fire with Israel referred incorrectly to the money that Israel is withholding from the Palestinians. The money, about $50 million, is made up of taxes and duties that Israel collects for the Palestinians; it is not financial aid.
Johnny Estrada drove in the go-ahead run with a single in the 11th as the visiting Diamondbacks rallied to defeat the Pirates, 5-4.
The popularity of free laser eye surgery in the armed forces is transforming career choices.
On the day before he was to depart for a meeting with European allies in Vienna, President Bush issued a stiff warning to Iran.
Federal authorities generally deport illegal immigrants who are violent felons, but those who commit lesser crimes are often overlooked.
Apple Computer has been talking with executives at all the major studios about adding movies to its popular iTunes music store by the fall.
Deena Kastor, the U.S. women's marathon record-holder, has committed to running the New York City Marathon on Nov. 5.
Pro Football.

Vonage said that it was being sued over the underlying technology that allows voice calls to be delivered over the Internet.
If North Korea tests a long-range missile, it will be thoroughly bad for North Korea, for its region and for just about everyone else.
Seizures of methamphetamine labs dropped by more than 30 percent last year, the Bush administration said.
Saddam Hussein reacted dismissively as the prosecutor demanded that he and three associates be given the death penalty for the persecution of a mainly Shiite town.
As Nokia and Siemens announced plans to merge, the big unanswered question was not if, but when, the remaining telecommunications giants would team up.
Former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Roger W. Ferguson Jr., is joining the global reinsurance company Swiss Re.

An electrical fire on the Upper East Side yesterday caused a power failure that lasted hours and affected a dozen buildings near East 81st Street and Park Avenue, a Con Edison spokesman said. The fire, which took place beneath a manhole near the intersection and was caused by aging cables, began about 4 p.m. Workers spent several hours trying to replace the burnt wiring. In all, eight buildings on East 81st Street and four on Park Avenue were affected, including Public School 6. Power was restored to most of the buildings by midnight.

A drifter has been indicted on charges of attempted murder, assault and attempted robbery in the stabbing of a tourist from Texas on a subway train and three other people last week, Robert Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, said yesterday. The suspect, Kenny Alexis, 20, is a Haitian immigrant who had been living in Boston on a student visa, prosecutors said. He faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted of attempted murder.

A jury in State Supreme Court has found Mount Sinai Hospital and one of its neurosurgeons, Dr. Isabelle Germano, responsible for problems suffered by a Putnam County woman after surgery to drain fluid from her brain, and has awarded her $8.5 million in damages. The patient, Karine Aquilino, 37, has had difficulty with language, walking and balance since a routine operation for congenital hydrocephaly in August 2000, said her lawyer, Thomas A. Moore. In its verdict on Thursday, the jury agreed that she had been injured by improper follow-up care. Marcia Horowitz, a spokeswoman for Mount Sinai, said the hospital stood by its doctor.

A helicopter operator plans to offer Connecticut residents an expensive way to commute to Lower Manhattan. Starting next Monday, U.S. Helicopter will run one of its eight-passenger Sikorsky helicopters on a 20-minute flight between Bridgeport and the Downtown Manhattan Heliport once each weekday morning and evening. Flights will leave Bridgeport at 6:25 a.m. and head back there at 7 p.m. The fare will be $195 each way.

A woman who jumped off the Victory Bridge on Friday, clutching her 1-year-old daughter, died early Sunday, the authorities said yesterday. The woman, Jerlisa Contreras, 24, had been in critical condition at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick since the fall. An autopsy revealed that her baby, Alyssa Scott, was killed by beating and asphyxiation before the plunge into the Raritan River, prosecutors said. Nicholas Sewitch, an assistant Middlesex County prosecutor, said investigators believed that Ms. Contreras killed the child before jumping from the bridge.

A New Jersey-based developer is buying the last remaining parcel in the Times Square redevelopment district to build an office tower, real estate executives said. The developer, SJP Properties, signed a contract this month to pay more than $260 million for the land at the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue. The property is owned by Howard and Edward Millstein.

Marty Markowitz, the borough president, had two stents inserted in his arteries over the weekend after he felt some discomfort and checked himself into a hospital, his office said yesterday. He is expected to leave Maimonides Medical Center today, his office said.

A Long Island farmer was found crushed to death in a giant soil screener yesterday morning, the Suffolk County police said. A worker at the Liere family farm in Yaphank found that the machine's conveyor belt had pulled the farmer, Alan R. Liere, 26, under a 35-foot rotating steel drum, said Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick, the commander of the homicide squad. The police theorized that Mr. Liere had been trying to clear a jam in the machine, which is as big as a railroad car and screens out rocks and debris from topsoil.

A bill requiring the Administration for Children's Services to regularly report to the City Council on key indicators was among three pieces of legislation signed into law yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The mayor also signed into law a measure establishing a trust fund to pay for retired city workers' health benefits, and a bill temporarily easing a requirement that the Department of Correction use buses that run on alternative fuels.

The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, announced yesterday the appointment of Rodney S. Capel, formerly the executive director of the State Democratic Committee, as a deputy chief of staff, overseeing the Council's member services division and its state and federal legislative efforts. Mr. Capel, 34, will be paid $145,000. He replaces Kevin Wardally, who left to join the lobbying firm of Bill Lynch, a former deputy mayor.

Three men were shot yesterday afternoon in an apartment building in the Castle Hill neighborhood, the police said. A man wearing a white T-shirt was in the ninth-floor hallway of the building, at 635 Castle Hill Avenue, talking to the three about 5 p.m., neighbors said, when the three turned to go into an apartment. The man opened fire, shooting an 18-year-old in the leg, a 23-year-old in the side and a 21-year-old in the abdomen, the police said. The first two were in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center last night. The 21-year-old was in surgery there. All three live in the building where the shooting occurred. Neighbors said they thought the shooting was the result of a fight that had started earlier in the day. The police said they had a suspect in the case but had not arrested him as of late last night.
Delmon Young was suspended for 50 games after throwing a bat that hit an umpire during a Class AAA International League game.

Almost 1,000 pages of documents from the two students responsible for the Columbine High School shootings will be released, the Jefferson County sheriff said. The journals and other papers were seized from the homes and cars of the students, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, who killed themselves on April 20, 1999, after shooting to death 12 fellow students and a teacher. The documents will not include video and audio tapes made by the killers. In the filing, Sheriff Ted Mink called the documents

After a downpour flooded houses and stranded hundreds of motorists in Houston, residents and officials warily prepared for more rain, and Gov. Rick Perry sent National Guard troops and state equipment. The effects were most severe in the southeastern section of the metropolitan region, where Harris County emergency officials reported 10.7 inches of rain. Some 500 emergency calls were received, mostly from residents asking to be rescued from flooded vehicles, Mayor Bill White of Houston said. No deaths were reported.

The divine Trinity, Father, Son and Holy Spirit, could also be known as Mother, Child and Womb or Rock, Redeemer and Friend at some Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) services after action by the church's national assembly. Delegates to the meeting voted to receive a policy paper on gender-inclusive language for the Trinity, a step short of approving it. That means that church officials can propose experimental liturgies with alternative phrasings, but that congregations will not be required to use them.

The state's secretary of state has certified that enough signatures were collected to send a law banning nearly all abortions to a vote in November. Abortion rights advocates filed petitions with more than 38,000 signatures last month. They needed 16,728 signatures to send the measure to a vote. The ban was signed into law in March and will not go into effect on July 1, as planned.

Union officials with the Capitol police, angry that a federal grand jury refused to indict Representative Cynthia A. McKinney, Democrat of Georgia, on charges of assaulting an officer, said they wanted the House ethics committee to review Ms. McKinney's actions.

President Kurmanbek Bakiyev, left, barred government officials from taking a summer vacation as a punishment for not doing a good job. Most officials in former Soviet states like Kyrgyzstan take up to a month off in July or August. But since Mr. Bakiyev came to power last year after a popular uprising, the country has been plagued by violence and crime.

John R. Bolton, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, questioned the need cited by Secretary General Kofi Annan last week to return peacekeepers to East Timor, where an Australian-led multinational force has ended violence that killed more than 30 people. Mr. Bolton said the current conflict was internal and unrelated to the tiny nation's struggle for independence from Indonesia that had been the basis of an earlier United Nations presence.

A court agreed to try 56 mayors in the Kurdish southeast over a letter they sent to Denmark's prime minister, Anders Fogh Rasmussen. The state prosecutor has charged the mayors with helping Kurdish rebels when they urged Mr. Rasmussen not to close the Danish-based Kurdish satellite broadcaster ROJ TV. If convicted, they face up to 10 years in prison. Turkey accuses ROJ of being a mouthpiece of the outlawed Kurdistan Workers Party.

Zambia said it had begun revoking the refugee status it granted 6,000 Rwandans who fled genocidal wars in that nation in the mid-1990's and is urging 10,000 more war refugees from Congo to leave its northern regions and return home. Many Rwandans, Congolese and Angolans have effectively resettled after long years as refugees in Zambia and have long resisted returning to their homelands despite assurances that they would be safe. Some have clashed with native Zambians over food and land, and the government says international donors do not offset its cost of caring for the refugees.

The police arrested three teenage boys they say took turns raping a 17-year-old girl in Offenburg while filming the attack on a cellphone and sending the images to friends. It was the latest in a series of attacks in which German youths are accused of using cellphones to film sexual assaults. This month, prosecutors in Goslar opened an investigation against four youths after the rape of a 14-year-old boy was filmed and posted on the Internet, and last month four teenage boys were detained on suspicion of gang-raping a 16-year-old girl in a Berlin park and filming the act with their phones.

African honeybees stung a 73-year-old man to death after a traditional ceremony to remove their hive from a home in Eastern Cape Province went awry. The man, Victor Nyembezi, was among 100 residents of Mgomanzi who were trying to get the bees to leave the homestead, in part by serving home-brewed beer in an effort to enlist ancestral spirits in their campaign. When the bees attacked instead, Mr. Nyembezi was too slow to escape and was killed by the swarm. MALLONN--Hubert R. ''Bob'', 75, of Morehead City, North Carolina died on Friday, June 2, 2006 at Pitt Memorial Hospital in Greenville, NC. Mr. Mallonn was a veteran and served in the U.S. Army Infantry. He was the Night Shift Executive Foreman of the Composing Room here at the New York Times. He was with the New York Times for 36 years. He is survived by his wife, Evelyn Mallonn, children: Patricia Gajda of Waldorf, MD, Robert Mallonn of Long Island, NY, Brian Mallonn of Florida, Marilyn Feirer of Alpharetta, Georgia and a sister Dita Ansorge of Germany. Also surviving are six grandchildren: Jennifer, Kristin, Janine, Kyler, Michael and Brenna. $(6$)MALLONN -- Hubert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Hubert Mallonnn, associated with The Times since April, 1958 until retiring in June 1994.

A report in the What's Online column in Business Day on Saturday, about the dismissal of two investigative reporters at Time magazine, misspelled the surname of one reporter. He is Donald Barlett, not Bartlett.

KIELY--Francis G., Jr., 77, died Monday, June 19, 2006, at Moses Ludington Hospital, Ticonderoga. Born November 18, 1928, in Brooklyn, he was the son of the late Frances G. & Mary (Fitzsimmons) Kiely. Mr. Kiely served during World War II as a paratrooper in the United Stares Army. He was a retired pressman with the New York Times after 40 years of service. Mr. Kiely was a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars and he enjoyed crossword puzzles, horse racing and fishing. Mr. Kiely vacationed in Adirondack for 15 years and moved with his wife permanently 6 years ago from Floral Park. He will be remembered as a loving husband, father and grandfather. Mr. Kiely was predeceased by two brothers, James and John Kiely, and one sister, Gloria LaVelle. Survivors include his wife of 54 years, Joan Christmann Kiely of Adirondack whom he married December 19, 1951; one son, Matthew Kiely of Adirondack; four daughters, Patricia (Robert) Smith of Floral Park, Karen (Robert) Tooher of Guilderland, Jean (Edward) Luna of Dix HIlls, and Ellen (Thomas) Eckl of Rotterdam; also 12 grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 A.M. Friday, June 23, at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church, Schroon Lake, with the Rev. William G. Muench officiating. Interment will be at the Adirondack Cemetery, Adirondack. Relatives and friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Thursday, June 23, at Barton-McDermott Funeral Hoem, 9 Pine St., Chestertown.

Stendhal Work Saved for France Fears that France would lose a rare Stendhal manuscript, right, were allayed yesterday when the 93-year-old collector who had offered it for sale donated it to the nation, Agence France-Presse reported. The Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres hailed the gift by Pierre Ber√®s as a ''generous gesture'' that helped to ''bring to the national collection an essential piece of 19th-century literary history.'' He was referring to a version of ''The Charterhouse of Parma,'' substantially reworked by Stendhal, as he noted in the draft, ''following the advice of Mr. Balzac.'' Works by Balzac, Proust and Rimbaud from the Ber√®s collection are among the manuscripts and rare books valued at $7.5 million that are to be offered today at the Drouot auction house in Paris. Honors for Murray Louis The choreographer Murray Louis, below, was awarded the 2006 Samuel H. Scripps/American Dance Festival Award in ceremonies on Sunday night at Duke University, the site of the festival. The citation read, in part, ''In addition to his own success as an artist blessed with an uncanny musicality, he has encouraged generations of future dancers and won the hearts of audiences worldwide.'' Mr. Louis, 79, received the $35,000 prize from the choreographer and performer Doug Varone, whom he has known for more than 25 years. He is the 25th recipient of the award, created in 1981 to honor choreographers who have made indelible contributions to modern dance. Previous recipients include Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Bill T. Jones, Garth Fagan, Twyla Tharp and Trisha Brown. Kidman and Urban to Wed Get ready for Kidman and Keith. The actress Nicole Kidman, below, and the country singer Keith Urban arrived in Australia yesterday and promptly announced plans to marry, The Associated Press reported. ''We are very happy to be back in Australia,'' they said in a joint statement. ''We have come home to celebrate our wedding with our family and friends.'' The news media in Australia have speculated that Ms. Kidman, who turns 39 today, and Mr. Urban, 38, will be married on Sunday at a Roman Catholic church in a northern Sydney suburb near her old high school. Another Brangelina Baby A month after the birth of their first child, Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt are planning to adopt another, Reuters reported. ''Next we'll adopt,'' Ms. Jolie told CNN in an interview for the program ''Anderson Cooper 360,'' to be broadcast today. But she said she didn't know what country the child would come from or its sex. ''It's, you know, another boy, another girl, which country, which race would fit best with the kids,'' she said. Before the birth of Shiloh Nouvel Jolie-Pitt on May 27 in Namibia, Ms. Jolie had adopted a daughter, Zahara, now about 15 months old, from Ethiopia, and a son, Maddox, 4, from Cambodia. Meanwhile, Jennifer Aniston was telling a British newspaper that she would love Mr. Pitt forever, Agence France-Presse reported. After a seven-year relationship, including five years of marriage, they were divorced last year after he and Ms. Jolie made ''Mr. and Mrs. Smith'' together. Ms. Aniston, now linked with Vince Vaughn, her co-star in ''The Break-Up,'' told The News of the World, ''I will love Brad for the rest of my life, and I hope that someday we will be able to be friends again.'' 'Syriana' Suit Rejected A French screenwriter has lost the plagiarism lawsuit she brought in Paris against the makers of ''Syriana,'' Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The writer, Stephanie Vergniault, 37, who had sought $2.5 million in damages pending an expert appraisal, was ordered to pay $4,400 in court costs to Warner Brothers and the Section Eight production company owned by Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney, who won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his performance in the film. The French court said it found no proof that the companies had copied her script, ''Oversight,'' which touched on themes and incidents found in ''Syriana,'' a 2005 geopolitical thriller about politics and oil. The makers of ''Syriana'' said it was based on an autobiography by Robert Baer, a former C.I.A. officer, and that filming was well under way when Ms. Vergniault's screenplay received a United States copyright. Footnotes Michael Cerveris, below, John Cullum, Christine Ebersole, Sutton Foster, Shuler Hensley, Jane Krakowski and the cast of ''Jersey Boys'' will be among the performers in ''Broadway Under the Stars,'' the salute to the city's outdoor summer concert season scheduled for Monday night at 8 on the Great Lawn in Central park. The Rolling Stones have canceled another summer tour concert date as a result of scheduling conflicts arising from the head injury Keith Richards suffered in a fall this spring in Fiji, Agence France-Presse reported. In a statement yesterday, the German tour promoter Peter Rieger said a Frankfurt concert scheduled for July 14 had been dropped. The Stones guitarist Ron Wood, 59, who has long battled drinking problems, is being treated for alcohol dependency in London, the BBC reported, but the band said he would definitely rejoin it when it continues its world tour in Milan on July 11. Some 20,000 free concerts, recitals and other musical events expected to draw 10 million people are scheduled across France tomorrow in the F√™te de la Musique, Agence France-Presse reported.

MORRIS--Florence. Passed away peacefully, Friday, June 16, at home, just short of her 92nd birthday. Devoted widow of J. Lincoln Morris (Pud), dear sister of Richard Carlton, sister-in-law of Blossom Carlton, caring aunt of Joyce and Howard Jaffe, Ralph and Susie Carlton, Ken Carlton and Karen and Allan Wood. A longtime resident of Sutton Place and La Coquille at Westhampton Beach, LI. Florence traveled the world but loved New York, where she was a consummate theater goer, bridge player, sometime golfer and tennis player. A vibrant woman who virtually walked through life via the sidewalks of the city and the wonderful beaches of Westhampton shore. Life was an endless panorama of sights and sounds. It was a full life with few regrets--perhaps the envy of all who knew her. The family wishes to express their gratitude to caregivers Audrey Felix and Andrea Fletcher for their dedication to Florence these past years and to the end. Service Tuesday, 11:30 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. $(6$)MORRIS--Florence. The residents and Board of La Coquille of Westhampton Beach deeply mourn the passing of our fellow longtime resident Florence Morris.

With her political opposition in New York in disarray, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has embarked on a fund-raising sprint on behalf of fellow Democrats in Ohio and Pennsylvania, potentially allowing her to collect favors in two important presidential battleground states. Mrs. Clinton, a possible candidate for president in 2008, is planning to head to Ohio this week to hold a fund-raiser for Representative Sherrod Brown, who is trying to unseat Senator Mike DeWine, a prime target of the national Democratic Party.

KABAT--Herbert, 89, a 37 years resident of Bay Harbor Islands, FL, passed away on June 18th, 2006. Born in Cambridge, MA on June 24, 1916, he moved to Brooklyn, N.Y. as a child where his love for the Dodgers was formed. He first arrived in Miami Beach in 1943 for basic training in the U.S. Army Air Corp. where he would rise to the rank of 2nd lieutenant in the 505th Bomber Group, earning seven battle stars in the Pacific theatre. Following WW II he took the knowledge of radios and communications that he learned in the service into the field of Consumer Electronics where he would become a pioneer in the industry. In 1957 as President of Delmonico International, he became the first to import Sony radios into the United States. Subsequently Delmonico would open the U.S. market to compact refrigerators from Ignis of Italy as well as stereos and televisions from the Victor Company of Japan (JVC). Televisions from Sanyo and Gold Star would follow while he was President of Olympic International in the 1970's. He is survived by Hortense, his loving wife of 59 years; children Lawrence, Harry and Caryn; grandchildren Rebecca and Steven and sister Debra Zion. Services will be held Tuesday, 12:00 noon, at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 20955 Biscayne Blvd, Aventura, FL 33180. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to either Vitas Hospice Charitable Fund, 3700 Executive Way, Miramar, FL 33025 or The Macular Degeneration Foundation, c/o Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, 900 NW 17th Street, Miami, FL 33125.

MURRAY -- James J. Of Bronxville, New York and Londonderry, Vermont. Passed away peacefully on June 18, 2006 at age 67, following a long and heroic battle with cancer. Loving husband, father, and son. Graduate of Bishop Loughlin High School Class of 1957, Manhattan College Class of 1961, and Fordham Law School Class of 1964. An accomplished attorney who practiced in New York for over 40 years, his varied career included positions at Legal Aid, a Wall Street firm, and, ultimately, a smaller practice where he applied his skills to what fulfilled him most; advocating for the laborer and the vulnerable individual. Jim was a man of formidable intellect and legal acumen, but his chief legacy to his family and to those who knew him is a model of inexhaustible selflessness, unshakable devotion to family and friends, humility, and Christian manhood. Words are an inadequate medium for expressing the magnitude of his loss to his family and to the scores he touched throughout his life. Though he left us too soon, we are immeasurably richer for having been a part of his life. He lives on in all of us. Jim is survived by his wife of 34 years, Mary Jane Riordan Murray, his children John, Elizabeth, and James, his mother, Belinda Murray, his brother Peter and his wife, and many beloved friends and relatives. Wake Wednesday, June 21 at McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, New York from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Thursday, June 22 at the Church of St. Joseph, Bronxville, New York, at 11 A.M.

That Youthful Glow Q. What causes the ''bloom of youth,'' that infusion of red in the cheeks, in children and teenagers? A. The reason for rosy cheeks in children is not as clear as the reasons underlying the general glow of their healthy skin, but some informed conjectures can be made, according to Dr. Lyuba Konopasek, associate professor of pediatrics at Weill Medical College of Cornell University. In children under 2, skin and the layers of tissue under it are thinner, she said, so blood vessels may be easier to see. Until adolescence, faces have fewer wrinkles and invisible pores, with both related to the fact that there is less sun damage, she added.
ZORN--Iris Segal. 6/20/98.''Not a day goes by'' ''Not a day'' Love ,Joe

African honeybees stung a 73-year-old man to death after a traditional ceremony to remove their hive from a home in Eastern Cape Province went awry. The man, Victor Nyembezi, was among 100 residents of Mgomanzi who were trying to get the bees to leave the homestead, in part by serving home-brewed beer in an effort to enlist ancestral spirits in their campaign. When the bees attacked instead, Mr. Nyembezi was too slow to escape and was killed by the swarm. A bee expert, Prof. Randall Hepburn of Rhodes University, told the South African Press Association that the instructions for traditional bee-removal ceremonies were simple: ''Don't do it,'' he said. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

HOLLAND--Marie Dolores Ianni. Born in New York, NY in 1939, passed peacefully from this life at the Holland Farm in Amenia, NY on June 17 after a brief, but intense struggle with cancer. Known within her community--and far beyond--for her tireless energy, community service, and great sense of style, she was active on many committees: the hamlet of Amenias Master Plan, CIPC, New York Relief, Amenia's street tree and flower planting, Cornell Cooperative Extension Dutchess County, Amenia's Business Womens Club, and the Sharon Garden Club. Her immense contributions will be greatly missed. Recently Dolores was named Amenia's Citizen of tHe Year 2006. Dolores (the name she preferred after being amongst so many other Maries in Catholic school in the Bronx) gave to all who knew her stories and impressions that will last forever. After retiring from her work at the Metropolitan Transit Authority in New York City, she and her beloved husband, Larry, moved from NYCs Upper West Side to Amenia full time in 1996. Their farm, the EastWest Bamboo Farm and Garden, is much sought after for garden tours and was included in The Garden Conservancy listing in 2004. In addition to her community work, Dolores was an active member of the New York Master Gardeners, The Mad Gardeners, the American Bamboo Society, and the Conifer Society. Her world travels, often for international bamboo conferences, included Europe, Japan, Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Borneo,Thailand, Viet Nam, Laos, China, India, Sikkim and Nepal. Her library, home and garden are scattered with significant artifacts documenting her travels, often with close friends. In the 60s, 70s and 80s, Dolores was fascinated by ancient history and archeology, and was a founding member of the Westchester Chapter of the Archeological Institute of America. She traveled during those years to remote areas of Egypt, Morocco, Greece, Spain, Portugal, Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Peru, Ecuador, and Mexico. Her professional life at this time was as varied as it was impressive. She worked for the prestigious law firm of Sherman and Sterling, the New York State Atomic and Space Development Authority, and held a position on the Wang Advisory Board. Amid all of this, throughout her exciting life, was a passion for theatre, dance, Asian film, museums, red sports cars, Chinese custard and cannolis. Before moving to the country, Dolores was an active member of the Indoor Gardening Society in Manhattan and became very proficient at growing a wide variety of houseplants, especially succulents and bonsai gardens. With just a few years in the country air, she created a wonderful garden, collecting conifers, bamboo and many unusual trees.Her gardens speak for themselves, but anyone who was lucky enough for a guided tour learned something. Dolores attended mass at the Church of Immaculate Conception in Amenia. Loved by so many, Dolores leaves those who loved her mosther witty, charming husband of 28 years, Larry Dana Holland; her loving son Anthony Poveromo and his wife, Anne-Marie and their precious baby Emily Anne ofHartsdale, NY; her stepsons Kevin Holland of Elkhart, Indiana, and Larry Holland Jr. of Middleboro, Massachusetts, and her siblings Basil Ianni of Hartsdale, NY, and Lydia Narcissi of Lakewood, NJ, and their respective spouses, Joanne and Ron. Friends may call at the Hufcut Funeral Home, 3159 Route 22, Dover Plains, NY on Thursday, June 22, 2006 from 4 to 8 p.m. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Friday, June 23, 2006 at 1:00 P.M. at Church of the Immaculate Conception, Route 22, Amenia, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society Reade Place, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

John R. Bolton, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, questioned the need cited by Secretary General Kofi Annan last week to return peacekeepers to East Timor, where an Australian-led multinational force has ended violence that killed more than 30 people. Mr. Bolton said the current conflict was internal and unrelated to the tiny nation's struggle for independence from Indonesia that had been the basis of an earlier United Nations presence. ''This has the look of disagreements among politicians with rival security forces,'' he said. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

As many as 80 percent of older women who are surveyed about mammograms tell interviewers that they have the cancer screening at least once every two years. But a new study suggests that the real numbers may be much lower.

To the Editor: Re ''Seeds for a Geo-Green Party'' (column, June 16): Thomas L. Friedman is right when he proposes a gasoline tax with a portion of the proceeds going to finance energy research. Congress should create an Energy Manhattan Project to explore a variety of alternative-energy sources.

On Oct. 8, 1918, Cpl. Alvin Cullum York and 16 other American doughboys stumbled upon more than a dozen German soldiers having breakfast in a boggy hollow here. The ensuing firefight ended with the surrender of 132 Germans and won Corporal York a promotion to sergeant, the Medal of Honor and a place in America's pantheon of war heroes.
Ross--Arthur.''Artie you do not depart from us ''. Love, B & D

In the cliquish, cutthroat high school that is the Bush administration, the Central Intelligence Agency casts itself as Carrie, the disparaged and bullied outsider. And like that ill-used heroine of Brian De Palma's 1976 horror movie, the C.I.A. wants revenge, not by telekinetic power, but through public television. ''The Dark Side,'' a ''Frontline'' documentary on PBS tonight, chronicles Vice President Dick Cheney's campaign to wrest control of the intelligence community and hype the case for invading Iraq. It's a hair-raising tale of political infighting, but it has been told many times, particularly by ''Frontline,'' which has produced several similar documentaries about the ill-prepared rush to war.

An article on Sunday about the difficulties Mexico faces in policing its southern border referred imprecisely to a southern state where Mexico has immigration agents. Yucat√°n is near the border but not on it.

BRASWELL--Joseph, died on Friday, June 16 at his home in Pensacola, Florida. Born in Alabama, Mr. Braswell attended the Birmingham Southern College and Parsons School of Design. He soon emerged as a leading designer of residential and commercial interiors. His work extended from Park Avenue to Saudi Arabia and his projects included luxury homes, royal palaces, airplanes, ships, restaurants and department stores, including Bergdorf Goodman and Bonwit Teller. Mr. Braswell's work was a favorite among some of the 20th century's most powerful personalities, including many leaders in industry, finance and media. He was inducted into the Interior Design Magazine Hall of Fame in 1986. Mr. Braswell believed if design was good, it made people whom it served, better people. He will be remembered by his many friends, family and clients for his talent, kindness, luminous intelligence and gracious character.

President Vladimir V. Putin appointed his justice minister to serve as Russia's new prosecutor general. The appointment shed little new light on what Kremlin officials and analysts have described as a new campaign against corruption. The minister, Yuri Y. Chaika, replaces Vladimir V. Ustinov, who was dismissed earlier this month, officials said, amid a wave of arrests and dismissals involving corruption. Mr. Putin, however, announced over the weekend that he had ''no complaints'' against Mr. Ustinov and that he would appoint him to another position in the future. Within hours of Mr. Chaika's appointment, the upper house of Parliament gave preliminary approval to the choice. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

An article on June 2 about East River islands that have become home to great numbers of migratory seabirds referred incorrectly to a former resident of one island, North Brother, who lived in housing set up for veterans returning from World War II. The veteran, Evan Hunter, wrote the screenplay for the Hitchcock film ''The Birds,'' not the short story on which it was based (that was written by Daphne du Maurier.) The article also misstated the name of the organization that provides tours of the islands. It is New York City Audubon, not the Audubon Society of New York.

KETELS--Antoinette (nee Staaterman) 88, of Washington, D.C., formerly of Montvale, NJ and Berkeley Township, NJ, died Thursday, June 15th at The National Lutheran Home in Rockville, Maryland. Mrs. Ketels, the daughter of Frederick Staaterman and Frieda Schoene Staaterman, was born in New York City. She grew up there and in Demarest and Cresskill, NJ. Her husband of 50 years, Henry Conrad Ketels, died in 1986. She was also predeceased by her son, Peter Conrad Ketels, in 1958 and her brother, Henry Staaterman who died in 1990. Her identical twin sister, Marion Staaterman, died in childhood. While beginning her family, Mrs. Ketels worked with her husband in their delicatessen businesses in New York City and later in Northvale, NJ. In 1950, Mrs. Ketels and her family moved to Montvale, where she was an active member of the community for 31 years. She was one of the original organizers of the Montvale Little League Women's Auxiliary. A member of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Montvale and the Order of the Eastern Star, she was also active in the Montvale PTA/PTO. Before retiring with her husband to Berkeley Township, NJ in 1981 she enjoyed working as an Aid in the Montvale School System. she moved to the Washington, D.C. area in 1996 and in 2002 took up residence at The National Lutheran Home in Rockville, Maryland. Mrs. Ketels is survived by her daughter, Marion Ketels Ellis of Seattle, Washington, and her two sons, John Paul Ketels of Washington, D.C. and James Edward Ketels of Ocean Township, NJ. She is additionally survived by five grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. There will be visitation at the Robert Spearing Funeral Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ from 7:00 to 9:00 PM on Wednesday, June 21st. A funeral service 11:30 AM Thursday, June 22nd, 2006 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Montvale. Interment in George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ at 1:00 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to The National Lutheran Home, 9701 Veirs Drive, Rockville, MD 20850. A memorial service will be held at The National Lutheran Home.

To the Editor: Re ''Free and Easy Riders'' (column, June 17): John Tierney's suggestions about giving motorcyclists an economic incentive to make the rational choice to wear a helmet has merit, but there will always be a sizable number of people, if not a majority, who will make bonehead decisions -- like using a four-ton S.U.V. for personal urban transportation, or smoking and so forth.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about Ronald S. Lauder's purchase of Gustav Klimt's ''Adele Bloch-Bauer I'' for $135 million, the most ever paid for a painting, misspelled the name of the Nazi commander who occupied a summer palace near Prague owned by the Bloch-Bauer family. He was Reinhard Heydrich, not Reinhardt Hedrick. Also because of an editing error, the article misspelled a word in the title of another Klimt painting owned by the Bloch-Bauer family. It is ''Houses in Unterach on Lake Atter,'' not Utterach.
