McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM Friday. Service at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, June 24 at 2 PM.

The One Percent Doctrine Deep Inside America's Pursuit of Its Enemies Since 9/11 By Ron Suskind 367 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27. The title of Ron Suskind's riveting new book, ''The One Percent Doctrine,'' refers to an operating principle that he says Vice President Dick Cheney articulated shortly after 9/11: in Mr. Suskind's words, ''if there was even a 1 percent chance of terrorists getting a weapon of mass destruction -- and there has been a small probability of such an occurrence for some time -- the United States must now act as if it were a certainty.'' He quotes Mr. Cheney saying that it's not about ''our analysis,'' it's about ''our response,'' and argues that this conviction effectively sidelines the traditional policymaking process of analysis and debate, making suspicion, not evidence, the new threshold for action.

Zambia said it had begun revoking the refugee status it granted 6,000 Rwandans who fled genocidal wars in that nation in the mid-1990's and is urging 10,000 more war refugees from Congo to leave its northern regions and return home. Many Rwandans, Congolese and Angolans have effectively resettled after long years as refugees in Zambia and have long resisted returning to their homelands despite assurances that they would be safe. Some have clashed with native Zambians over food and land, and the government says international donors do not offset its cost of caring for the refugees. MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

Fears that France would lose a rareStendhal manuscript were allayedyesterday when the 93-year-old collectorwho had offered it for sale donated it to thenation, Agence France-Presse reported.The Culture Minister Renaud Donnedieu deVabres hailed the gift by Pierre Ber√®s as a"generous gesture" that helped to "bring tothe national collection an essential piece of19th-century literary history." He was referringto a version of "The Charterhouse ofParma," substantially reworked by Stendhal,as he noted in the draft, "following the advice of Mr. Balzac." Works byBalzac, Proust and Rimbaud from the Ber√®s collection are among the manuscriptsand rare books valued at $7.5 million that are to be offered today at theDrouot auction house in Paris.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the problems facing the video game industry misstated a figure from a report by Soleil-Hudson Square Research on analysts' financial forecasts for the industry. The report estimated a 60 percent cut in 2006 in the industry's total earnings, not its revenues.

Almost 1,000 pages of documents from the two students responsible for the Columbine High School shootings will be released, the Jefferson County sheriff said. The journals and other papers were seized from the homes and cars of the students, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, who killed themselves on April 20, 1999, after shooting to death 12 fellow students and a teacher. The documents will not include video and audio tapes made by the killers. In the filing, Sheriff Ted Mink called the documents ''largely irrelevant and innocuous, consisting mostly of school work.'' KATIE KELLEY (NYT)

CHANGE AT HOME -- Executives from major cities have transformed Bentonville, Ark., Wal-Mart's hometown, into a mini-metropolis populated by Hindus, Muslims and Jews. The Jewish families in Benton County have become increasingly vocal proponents of religious neutrality in the county. [Page A1.] OFFICIAL TO JOIN GOLDMAN -- Deputy Secretary of State Robert B. Zoellick, below, is leaving the State Department to join Goldman Sachs as a managing director. Mr. Zoellick's departure from the administration, in which he also was United States trade representative, has been widely expected. [A3.] THINKING GLOBAL -- When Goldman Sachs lost Henry M. Paulson Jr. to the Treasury, the firm ceded a nonpareil globe-trotting client man. Its board is moving quickly to fill the void by naming Robert B. Zoellick as a vice chairman. Market Place. [C1.] RUNNING ON COAL -- Europe likes to think of itself as a place that has moved beyond its sooty industrial past. But with oil prices soaring and worries rising about the reliability of gas from Russia, Europe must depend heavily on that industrial-age relic, coal. [A1.] WHO'S NEXT? -- As Nokia and Siemens announced plans to merge their telecommunications equipment businesses, the unanswered question was not if, but when, the remaining giants would team up. [C1.] BURGERS IN FRANCE -- Denis Hennequin, president of McDonald's Europe, is the engineer of the restaurant chain's success in France. His skill lies in selling something quintessentially American to a people who purport to be against American culture. [C1.] SAKS REVIVES PETITE SECTION -- Scolded by short women across the country, Saks Fifth Avenue said it would re-establish its petite women's clothing department, which it had quietly dropped several months ago. [C1.] ENERGY LEGISLATION -- Since Hurricanes Katrina and Rita shut down refineries in the Gulf region last summer, accelerating the increase of gasoline costs, House members have introduced 267 energy-related bills and senators have introduced 210, a Congressional analysis says. [A11.] IRAQ CONTRACT CANCELED -- The Army Corps of Engineers said it had canceled a $99.1 million contract with Parsons, one of the largest companies working in Iraq, to build a prison north of Baghdad. [A9.] PLANS FOR THE GARDEN -- Steven Roth, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, is quietly circulating a $7 billion plan for the district surrounding Madison Square Garden that includes moving the arena to what would be its fifth home. [A1.] INTERNET PHONE SUIT -- Vonage, the Internet telephone start-up, said it was being sued by Verizon Communications in a dispute over the underlying technology that allows voice calls to be delivered over the Internet. [C7.] CITIGROUP RETHINKS BRAND Citigroup senior managers have been meeting to review the company's brand, an effort that may spell the end of the ubiquitous red umbrella logo. Citigroup retained the umbrella, brand symbol of the Travelers Group, when it shed its insurance companies. Advertising. [C7.] ACCOUNTING BOARD APPOINTMENT -- A Federal Reserve governor, Mark W. Olson, was named chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, which regulates accounting firms. [C3.] ARCELOR DELAYS VOTE -- The steel giant Arcelor said that it would put off a crucial vote related to its 13 billion euro ($16.7 billion) deal with the Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov, raising questions about whether the deal was unraveling. [C3.] ARREST IN TAX CASE -- The owner of a machine tool maker was arrested at his California home and charged with orchestrating a tax fraud that cost the government nearly $20 million. [C3.] ONLINE ONE IMMIGRANT'S STORY -- As illegal immigrants in the United States have increased in numbers, so have the ranks of those who want to swindle them. A report can be found at nytimes.com/business. CHINA'S DARK CLOUDS -- In a video, David Barboza of The Times discusses how China's coal industry is creating an environmental and health care crisis. A report can be found at nytimes.com/business. IN THE IMPALA, A G.M. TALE -- The Chevy Impala shows how much progress General Motors has made and, how far behind it continues to fall. FRANC--Helen M. Died peacefully on June 14 at the age of 98. Worked for the Museum of Modern Art as an Editorial Assistant until her reitrement in 1972. Published extensively in the art world, and is best known for ''An Invitation to See'' which is still used as a guide to the works of MOMA. She had numerous philanthropic interests and volunteered her time to further human rights and the welfare of children. She is survived by her nieces, Anne Morgan, and Marie Ruth Willcox and their children and grandchildren.

Science Times received an extraordinary outpouring of letters -- more than 100, pro and con -- over last week's article ''Breast-Feed or Else,'' about the public health campaign to promote breast-feeding and discourage formula and bottles. A sampling follows; others are online at nytimes.com/science. To the Editor: As a breast-feeding mother, I appreciated your thoughtful, important article ''Breast-Feed or Else'' (June 13). It is important to add that the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breast-feeding not only for six months, but exclusively for six months, and for as long thereafter as mutually desired by mother and child. Further, studies indicate that the composition of the breast milk becomes better over time, contrary to the popular belief that after six months it offers little benefit. Cammie Kim Lin New York To the Editor: When my son was born, I was intent on breast-feeding, regardless of the difficulties. But even with the help of my pediatrician and a lactation consultant, we needed to supplement with formula.

An article in The Arts on April 13 about Barney Rosset, the publisher who brought Samuel Beckett's work to the United States, misstated the terms of his deal to publish ''Waiting for Godot.'' Grove Press, which Mr. Rosset owned, agreed to a contract with Les √âditions de Minuit, Beckett's French publisher, that called for a $200 advance -- not $150 -- for ''Godot'' (and $400 advances for the novels ''Molloy'' and ''Malone Dies''). The deal also included a 7.5 percent royalty for the first 3,000 copies of ''Godot'' that were sold and 10 percent thereafter (along with an additional 2.5 percent for the translation). The royalty was not 2.5 percent. The article also included a quotation from Mr. Rosset in which he said that Les √âditions de Minuit had said that Grove Press could not publish ''Waiting for Godot.'' According to Georges Borchardt, a literary agent who negotiated the contract, Minuit was delighted to make the deal. This correction was delayed by a reporting lapse.

Smoking is known to cause early aging of the skin. It is also known, of course, to cause lung disease. Now a study finds that smokers with a lot of wrinkles are far more likely to have lung damage than are smokers with less-lined faces. The study, which appears online in the journal Thorax, found that heavily wrinkled smokers were five times as likely as other smokers to have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The findings ''raise the question, 'Is it possible to predict the presence of C.O.P.D. in smokers from their facial appearance?' '' the authors write. The study was led by Dr. Bipen Patel, a British researcher.

4:30 P.M. (TCM) THE HEIRESS -- (1949). Olivia de Havilland is Catherine Sloper, whose domineering father (Ralph Richardson) tries to keep her away from the object of her affection, Morris Townsend (Montgomery Clift). William James's novel ''Washington Square'' was the inspiration for this film, and also for a play version that has had three runs on Broadway in the past 60 years. In other words -- if you haven't seen it, you can't say you didn't have the chance. An added incentive: Ms. De Havilland (above) won an Oscar for best actress for the role. 7 P.M. (Lifetime) THE MARY KAY LETOURNEAU STORY: ALL AMERICAN GIRL -- (2000). Now starring on the other side of the tracks is Penelope Ann Miller (''Carlito's Way'') as the infamous Seattle schoolteacher who had an affair with one of her sixth grade students, became pregnant, and was jailed on a charge of statutory rape in 1997. She and her student, Vili Fualaau (Omar Anguiano), could not keep away from each other, however, and they had a second child in 1998. Might be time for a sequel, though: the two were married last year. 8 P.M. (NBC) FEAR FACTOR -- The trial of the reality stars continues as contestants face more scary challenges, including rescuing their partners from a burning houseboat and other icky stunts involving insects and worms -- par for the course on this show. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING -- The 12 finalists (above) have been chosen, and now must live together, of course. They're moving on to the good ship Queen Mary, permanently moored in Long Beach, Calif. Tonight they will compete against one another in a heckle challenge, and two will have to go home. Listen for cries of ''Comic overboard!'' 10 P.M. (CNN) ANDERSON COOPER 360degrees -- Mr. Cooper spends an hour with Angelina Jolie in her first interview since giving birth to a daughter at a private clinic in Namibia on May 27. Ms. Jolie, a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, talks about giving birth and about her passion for refugee relief. 10 P.M. (BRAVO) QUEER EYE -- The Fab Five continue in their attempt to clean up Las Vegas as they make over Ed Miller, a professional poker player turned author, whose grooming (and sloppy apartment) need some work. Mr. Miller (above) recently wrote a book with his fellow poker authority Dave Slansky and needs some image polishing before hitting the book signings. With some help from the team, he should look like a million bucks: so, his followers hope, should his pile of chips. STEVEN McELROY

NBC has signaled its intention to order another edition of ''The Apprentice'' for next season, the show's star, Donald Trump, said yesterday. Mr. Trump said NBC executives had called to inform him that they were renewing the show for a seventh cycle. NBC had no comment. There have been questions about the continuation of ''The Apprentice'' beyond the version that NBC had announced for January, the sixth edition, to be set in Los Angeles instead of New York. But Mr. Trump said yesterday that strong ratings for this spring's finale had led NBC to step up discussions about continuing the franchise. The seventh edition of the series would also be set outside New York, Mr. Trump said, probably in either Miami or Las Vegas. ''The Apprentice'' will be off NBC's schedule this fall, returning Sunday nights in January after the network concludes its coverage of the N.F.L. Mr. Trump said in a telephone interview that he believed that the break would help, especially because the series was overexposed last season when NBC added a version starring Martha Stewart, which fared poorly. Mr. Trump has blamed Ms. Stewart's version for some of the falloff in ratings for his own show. ''They had us on three times last year, including the Martha fiasco,'' he said yesterday, ''so I think the break will help.'' BILL CARTER

An obituary on June 10 about Kemoko Sano, a choreographer and director, misstated his estimated age. Mr. Sano, who was not sure of his birth date, was believed to have been in his mid-60's, not his mid-70's.

Deputy Secretary of State Robert B. Zoellick said Monday that he would be leaving his post as the State Department's second in command, as expected, to join the Wall Street investment house Goldman Sachs Group Inc. as a managing director. Bush administration officials said the search was now on to find a replacement for Mr. Zoellick, a six-year administration veteran who spent his first four years as the United States trade representative.

A retired dentist, veteran of WWII and Bronze Star recipient. A man among men. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10 AM, Assumption Church, Westport, CT.

Three American soldiers suspected of killing three detainees in Iraq and then threatening a soldier with death if he reported the shootings have been charged with premeditated murder and obstructing justice, Army officials said Monday. The accused soldiers, two enlisted men and a noncommissioned officer, also face charges of attempted murder, conspiracy and threatening in connection with the deaths of the three detainees on May 9, the Army's documents showed.

An obituary on Thursday about the sculptor Luis Jimenez referred incorrectly to the execution of the Aztec emperor Cuauht√©moc, whose burning by Spanish conquistadores was the subject of one of Mr. Jimenez's sculptures. He died later by hanging; he was not burned to death. (His feet were burned to force him to reveal where gold was hidden.)

ABC's broadcast of Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals delivered a ratings victory for the network on Sunday. Nielsen's preliminary estimates for the live event indicated that the ratings for the Miami Heat's overtime defeat of the Dallas Mavericks were up slightly from last year's equivalent game. CBS placed second among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49, with a steadily performing night of repeats: ''60 Minutes'' (9.05 million), ''Cold Case'' (8.24 million) and the Mel Gibson movie ''What Women Want'' (9.45 million). NBC's prime time led off with a spillover of the United States Open golf tournament, which took first place between 7 and 7:30 p.m. Later, the two-hour debut of ''Treasure Hunters'' brought in an average of 6.91 million viewers. At 10 p.m. NBC broadcast a rerun of its new series ''Windfall,'' which drew a mere 3.89 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

ROSSMAN--Ilse. Age 89, died on June 18, 2006 after a long illness. Born in Mannheim, Germany and emigrating to New York in 1938, she lived a life of profound dignity and dedication. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Karl Rossman, and her adored brother, Hans Wirth. She will be remembered by her sisters-in-law Lucy Kahn and Rena Wirth, her nephew Barry Kahn and his wife Sandy, her nieces Judy Florsheim and her husband Steve, and Barbie Stanczak and her husband Bob. She is also survived by many great nephews and nieces. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Tuesday June 20 at 1:00 PM.

DREIER--Sidney, 90. Beloved husband of Mildred for 60 years. Extremely loving father of Francine (Burtt), Marc, Mitchel (Nancy). Cherished grandfather of Julie, David, Spencer, Jackie, Katie and Benjamin. Born in Otynia, Poland in 1915, and educated in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia, to be a physician, he arrived in America in 1939, a captain in the Polish army, to represent his country at the World's Fair. WWII intervened and he remained in America, forging a career as an independent motion picture executive, becoming known and respected throughout the industry. Services will be held on Monday, June 18 at 2:15, Star of David Chapel, 7701 Bailey Road, Tamarac, Florida. Shiva will be observed at home in Boca Raton, Monday following the services, and Tuesday from 2-8 PM, and at his son, Marc's home at 150 East 57th Street, NYC, Wednesday, 6-9PM and Thursday 2-8PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, FL 33486.

On German television Diego Armando Maradona can be seen in the stadiums smoking the Cuban cigars sent to him by his friend Fidel Castro. But he's not wearing the T-shirt he wore to the anti-Bush summit he attended last November, after being invited by Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez. The shirt has the face of United States President George W. Bush, with the words "war criminal" printed above and below it. Now, Maradona prefers the Argentinean national team shirt, which covers up the Che Guevara tattoo he has on his left arm, as he cheers on his fantastic team in the German stadiums, shouting and dancing in the stands. His fellow countrymen, who revere him as a God, reward him with chants of "Oh-ay, oh-ay, oh-ay, oh-ay, Die-gooo, Die-gooo." This can be heard in any German stadium where Argentina plays.

John Mack got a financial pat on the back from investors on Wednesday, as better-than-expected financial results sent shares of Morgan Stanley up as much as 5 percent. The quarterly figures showed Morgan Stanley's net income more than doubling to $1.96 billion in the second quarter as revenue hit record levels. The results came as Mr. Mack celebrated his one-year anniversary as the firm's chief executive.

There are victories that taste like defeat, and defeats that taste like victory. Mexico's 2-1 loss to Portugal today tastes like defeat. Our team played badly. They failed to score a penalty, they were imprecise, nervous, even foolish. In spite of all that, we made it, barely, (in part, thanks to Iran) to the next round, where we will play the Netherlands or Argentina.

The markets' recent volatility does not seem to be keeping hedge fund heavyweights from paying enormous sums for New York City real estate. The New York Observer reports that Glenn Dubin, a co-founder and managing partner of $8-billion-plus hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management, has signed a contract to buy Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' former apartment on New York's Fifth Avenue for $32 million. He is acquiring the storied property from billionaire David Koch, who bought it in 1995 for a mere $9.5 million. Mr. Koch told the Observer that he "gutted the apartment and redid everything."

Is Madison Dearborn betting on bad times to come? Corporate Financing Week reports that the Chicago-based private equity firm is bidding for AlixPartners, a turnaround advisory firm whose bankrupt clients have included Kmart, Worldcom and Parmalat USA. The newsletter, from the publisher of Institutional Investor magazine, did not name its source for the report, and a spokesman for AlixPartners declined to comment for the story.

Despite Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi's claim of being a reformer, outsider and foe of special interests, critics say his own record smacks of "pay to play" political fundraising.

Far from being vultures who do not care what gets destroyed in their single-minded pursuit of profits, private equity firms, rather, see their role as "empowering business leaders as they seek to make change," wrote Marek Gumienny, managing director of Candover, in what amounted to an industry apologia published Tuesday by the Web site of BBC News. Coming one day before The Financial Times warned about the dangers of private equity on its editorial pages, Mr. Gumienny's commentary underscores the growing attention, good and bad, these kinds of investment pools are getting.

When it comes to energy company Mirant, it seems Pirate Capital can't stop dispensing advice. In a letter to Mirant's board of directors filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, the activist hedge fund, which owns a 1.6 percent stake in Mirant, called for the company to implement a share buyback program and sell its international and "domestic noncore" assets. It also repeated its not-so-subtle message that a sale of the entire company might be the best strategy in the end.

It took third place last year, but Goldman Sachs Asset Management has jumped to the top of the heap in Alpha magazine's latest Hedge Fund 100 list, which ranks funds by assets. A tidy $21 billion under management was enough to put Goldman Sachs' hedge fund arm in the No. 1 spot. D.E. Shaw moved from No. 7 to No. 3 on the list, with $19.9 billion in assets, according to Alpha.
Henry Schein, a supplier of dental and medical products, said on Wednesday it would acquire three companies from the closely held Darby Group Companies for about $51.5 million in cash.
The Dutch telecoms group KPN will merge its international wholesale voice business with iBasis and pay $55 million for a majority stake in the combined company, the two companies said on Wednesday.
Shares in takeover target Arcelor were suspended on Wednesday while directors of the steel group held a board meeting in Luxembourg, pending a statement from the company.

Cowen Group, which is being spun off from France's Societe Generale, has revealed that it is the latest investment bank to try "unbundling," TheStreet.com reported. Unbundling involves the decoupling of research and trading services, which have historically been sold together -- an arrangement that has recently drawn criticism over potential conflicts of interest.

After serving in the House of Representatives for four years from 2001 to 2005 but losing a close Senate race in 2004 to Tom Coburn, Oklahoma lawyer Brad Carson may have suspended his political career, but he's turning into an impressive pundit. (The New Republic's Jason Zengerle says Carson has "a bit of Bulworth about him.")

An oil refiner, Delek US Holdings, said on Wednesday it had agreed to acquire the refining assets and marketing business of the Pride Companies of Abilene, Tex., and its affiliates for about $54.4 million in cash.
Sanpaolo IMI has appointed Citigroup as its adviser to study possible alliances, the Italian bank's director general, Pietro Modiano, said on Wednesday.

The Federal Communications Commission will try again on Wednesday to revamp media ownership restrictions and possibly clear the way for more consolidation in the industry. Reuters reports that the F.C.C. on Wednesday is expected to ask for public comment on what its five commissioners should do with current restrictions that bar a company from owning a newspaper and a radio or television station in the same market. Several companies, including Tribune and Media General, have pressed the agency to lift the ban.

France's Areva Group has held talks to acquire Candu, the commercial reactor business of Canada's federally owned Atomic Energy Canada, according to a report in the Toronto Star. The state-owned Areva is the world's largest nuclear company.

A group of financial-services companies including Goldman Sachs have agreed to invest a total of $20 million for a minority stake in CHX Holdings, which operates the Chicago Stock Exchange, CHX said Wednesday. The investors also include Bank of America, Bear Stearns and E*Trade Financial.

Here's something to bookmark: the brackets and schedule for the knockout stage, here on FIFA's Web site, now starting to be filled in as the groups conclude. After a fairly predictable last set of games yesterday, are there any surprises in store for us today? While everyone's talking about the Argentina vs. Holland exhibition match in the afternoon (both coaches are resting players for the next round, not seeming to care who wins), keep in mind that Mexico could still, in theory, get knocked out this morning, if they lose to Portugal and Angola manages to beat (up on) Iran. We'll have all the action for you in both games, relayed via the Web as it happens, starting at 10 a.m. New York time.
Parisian minds are creating shiny industrial designs, extraordinary everyday objects, viewing rooms, new applications for vinyl and cultivating new talent.

My review of Lexar's PowerToGo software, which lets you install Windows programs onto a flash drive, prompted many responses from readers.

Morgan Stanley said its net income more than doubled in the fiscal second quarter, as the securities firm completed its first full year under the leadership of chief executive John Mack. The company's net income in the three months ended May 31 was $1.96 billion, compared with $928 million a year earlier. Income was up 25 percent from the fiscal first quarter.
"Love," Cirque du Soleil's ambitious fantasy tribute to the band, offers classic Beatles tunes in extraordinarily crisp sound.
General Motors extended a $5.6 billion credit line set to expire in 2008 after agreeing to put up collateral to protect the lenders from nonpayment.

There are more millionaires in the world than people in New York City, but they're increasingly likely to live in Seoul, Mumbai or Dubai rather than the Big Apple, according to a new survey of the planet's rich.
Media conglomerate Time Warner said Tuesday it was looking into whether company funds were used by its chief financial officer for gifts he allegedly gave an accused prostitution ringleader.
Renewed hopes that British magazines and books retailer WH Smith could be a takeover target led to heavy volumes in the shares which rose 12.75 pence to 460.75 pence a share.
Crow House, in Rockland County, was designed and built  in the 1920's by Henry Varnum Poor, for many decades one of the country's most famous painters and potters.
Former Enron President Jeffrey Skilling has asked a judge to overturn a jury's verdict that found him guilty of 19 counts in the collapse of the energy company.
The New York Stock Exchange, which has already sued 23 specialists for illegal floor trading, is investigating improper activities by other market makers between 1999 and 2003.
Dutch group Philips Electronics said on Wednesday it will float or sell its semiconductors business by the end of the year, keeping only a minority stake.
Microsoft said Martin Taylor, a vice president appointed in March to revamp marketing for the MSN Web sites and Windows Live services, has left the company.

A company controlled by Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chairman and chief executive of the American International Group, sued A.I.G. yesterday, seeking access to documents it said might show mishandling of a $1.64 billion legal settlement.
Upping the ante in a potential bidding war for Onyx Software, rebuffed suitor CDC on Tuesday said it would offer up to $96 million for the customer relationship software maker.

Privately held pipeline company SemGroup on Tuesday bowed out of a protracted bidding war for oil products marketer TransMontaigne, leaving Morgan Stanley's offer valuing the company at $634 million as the last one standing.
MicroMed Cardiovascular said this week it recently raised $15.4 million, and that it plans to add 12 people to its staff of 30 in the next six months.

The latest company in the ethanol fuel scramble debuted in a makeover yesterday with a hefty 14 percent price jump -- but until last spring it had been just a Zen pottery commune in the Rocky Mountains.

SK Telecom, South Korea's largest mobile-phone operator, plans to buy as much as $1 billion of bonds convertible into a 6.7 percent stake in China Unicom to tap the world's biggest wireless market by subscribers.
Citigroup was approached by more than 30 banks last month, three times the number it was seeking, as it lined up lenders to finance Kohlberg Kravis Roberts's first leveraged buyout in India.

It's hard to imagine Goldman Sachs or Merrill Lynch investing in a company that grows marijuana or scalps concert tickets. Yet the two firms, along with such houses as Morgan Stanley, J.P. Morgan and Fidelity, have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in shares of online casinos, even though those companies may be breaking United States laws.

The Korea Exchange Bank has sold a 5.2 percent stake in Hyundai Engineering and Construction in a block trade. The deal precedes the sale of a majority stake by the company's creditors that could be started as early as this week.

After a spate of consolidations in the customer relationship management sector in which both Siebel and PeopleSoft were snapped up by Oracle, there will be no letup in merger activity, according to analysts at Gartner.
Barneys and Isetan are winding down a long and sometimes anguished relationship.

Petro-Canada is extending its $113 million hostile bid for Canada Southern Petroleum until July 5 but hasn't increased the price, even in the face of a friendly $146-million bid by Canadian Oil Sands Trust.

In an effort to bolster its presence in the online multiplayer video game business, Electronics Arts said after Tuesday's closing bell that it had agreed to acquire Mythic Entertainment for an undisclosed sum.

As Macquarie Bank confirmed it has held talks to buy assets of Richard Li's PCCW, Hong Kong's biggest phone company, a report that another suitor may emerge from the woodwork heightened the possibility of a bidding war.

Within hours of the announcement that a joint venture of BP in Russia would sell several oil fields to Sinopec of China, Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled energy company, said it would exercise an option to buy 51 percent of Sinopec's newly acquired assets, leaving the Chinese with a minority stake.

Following reports Tuesday that Pfizer and Schering-Plough were mulling bids for Sepacro, industry analysts said the two drug giants could easily snap up the smaller drugmaker, but said risks to its two products would limit any potential gains.
It seems that Deutsche Borse can't please anyone.
After rebuffing a revised offer from Deutsche Borse, Euronext moved on plans to make a buy of its own. But its German rival may try to spoil the party.

The Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov changed the terms Tuesday under which he would buy a big stake in the European steel giant Arcelor, in an effort to salvage a deal that is facing increasing opposition from shareholders.

The crisis at EADS, the majority-owner of Airbus, deepened yesterday when the French government indicated over the heads of its German partner it wanted to seize more control of the pan-European aerospace and defence group.
Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, agreed to buy Berliner Bank for 680.5 million euros ($856.2 million) to gain more customers in a home market dominated by state-owned lenders.

The auction of Univision, the nation's largest Spanish-language media company, was sent into disarray last night as two bidders, including a consortium of investors led by the Mexican television giant Grupo Televisa -- the group tipped to win the contest -- missed the deadline to submit an offer.

Once again, the social-networking Web site Facebook is drawing gasps and snorts for its supposedly bubbly valuation. The site, founded in 2004 by a Harvard student, has grown to include millions of users -- mostly in college and high school -- and has become a sort of proxy for the renewed excitement about certain kinds of Internet startups.

The two blogs that I started behind the Great Firewall of China seem to have been taken down. In my Tuesday column I wrote about how easily I had started them and used them to post counterrevolutionary comments. As soon as I posted the links, the two blogs got lots of traffic and began to be quoted by other Chinese blogs and linked to them.

If you find yourself in Mogadishu sometime over the next couple of weeks and want to watch the World Cup while you're there, you'd be well advised to pick your spots. Some of the Islamist militias that recently wrested control of the city from other Somalian warlords aren't particularly fond of the world's most popular sports event, as the Times's Marc Lacey reported in Monday's paper.

The names, addresses and Social Security numbers of about 500 people were mistakenly distributed to unemployment recipients because of a mail-processing mistake, the State Labor Department said yesterday. The department said a mail-stuffing machine inserted more than one unemployment insurance form into envelopes. The machine processed about 9,500 forms from May 31 to June 7, and about 498 were mistakenly sent to the wrong people, the department said. Letters will be sent to all potentially affected individuals alerting them about the security breach, the department said.
Dwyane Wade starred again with 36 points and 10 rebounds to beat the Mavericks for the 4th game in a row.

DALLAS, June 29 (AP) — Southwest Airlines said Tuesday that it would test assigning seats to travelers, in a comparison with its longtime first-come-first-served seating system. Passengers will be assigned seats on about 200 flights from San Diego for several weeks beginning July 10, the airline said.
Striker Miroslav Klose scored twice in the first half  as an increasingly impressive German team defeated Ecuador to finish undefeated in the first round of World Cup.
Next week, MySpace, the popular online hangout, will make it harder for strangers to send messages to younger teenagers.
England won its group and avoided a showdown with Germany in the next round. Sweden advanced, too, but must meet the feared Germans on their home turf on Saturday.

Four teenage patients were injured yesterday during an attempted escape from Holliswood Hospital in Queens, the police said. Four girls, all 16 or 17, climbed out a third-story window using sheets tied together, the police said, and managed to get within eight feet of the ground before falling. One suffered a broken leg and the others suffered cuts and bruises, according to the police.

City officials formally reopened the Crotona Park Tennis House in the south-central Bronx yesterday after a $1.6 million renovation that included electrical and ventilation upgrades, bathroom enlargements and a new meeting room. The building will be a rest area for tennis and baseball players and will also provide space for parks officials and community groups.

A 21-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 15-year-old boy from his neighborhood, the police said yesterday. The burned body of Earl Mabry, of Loring Place, was discovered on the roof of 1125 University Avenue early Monday morning. The boy had been shot and stabbed. After a canvas of the neighborhood, the police arrested Markel Nance of University Avenue. The police said the two knew each other from the neighborhood, but the motive for the killing was unclear.

More than 50 examples of intrusive advertising signs have been found in a photo contest by the Municipal Art Society, a civic organization, and Curbed, a real estate blog. Entrants were invited to submit pictures of the city's

A restaurateur and his wife, a real estate agent, were found dead in their home late Monday in what prosecutors believe was a murder-suicide. The Monmouth County prosecutor, Luis Valentin, said the bodies of Joseph Importuna, 38, the owner of a small pizza restaurant in Jackson, and his wife, Vincenza, were discovered about 10:30 p.m. by a relative with whom Mr. Importuna left his two young children earlier in the day. Mr. Importuna and his wife had each been killed by a single shot to the chest, and investigators said preliminary indications were that the shots came from a 9-millimeter handgun registered to Mr. Importuna and found at the scene.

A Brooklyn teenager was convicted of murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for taking part in a robbery that caused the death of a 15-year-old in East Flatbush last summer. The defendant, Darran Samuel, 17, was convicted of second-degree murder and robbery for the July 2 attack on Christopher Rose, said Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Prosecutors said that Mr. Samuel and three other young men demanded an iPod that one of Mr. Rose's friends was carrying. In the resulting struggle, prosecutors said, Mr. Rose was fatally stabbed. One man, Quaison Fraser, 18, has pleaded guilty to gang assault, prosecutors said, and two other defendants are awaiting trial. Mr. Samuel faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life, prosecutors said.

The president of Alfred State College, whose leadership was the focus of a rare three-month investigation by state education officials last year, has resigned, college officials said yesterday. The president, Uma G. Gupta, left, will leave on June 30, the officials said. In February, after complaints by staff members, a report by a team of officials from the State University of New York urged Dr. Gupta to change her management style. Dr. Gupta said at the time that she had made tough and unpopular decisions but had led the campus with integrity. She has accepted another position within the state university system aimed at increasing the number of female and minority students in mathematics and science. She declined to comment on her resignation, said a spokeswoman, Colleen A. Brade.

A federal magistrate has ordered a Washington Township school district to pay the legal fees of a high school student who fought his 2001 suspension for wearing a shirt that made fun of rednecks. Magistrate Judge Tonianne J. Bongiovanni of Federal District Court determined that the Warren Hills Regional School District was responsible for $574,245 in legal fees incurred by the family of the student, Thomas Sypniewski Jr., now 23. The school district suspended Mr. Sypniewski, then a senior, for three days for wearing the shirt, which officials claimed violated the school's anti-harassment policy.
G.M.'s debt rating was cut further into junk status Tuesday after the company announced a plan to refinance $5.6 billion in loans.

A Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) national assembly voted to create some leeway for gay clergy members and lay officers to serve local congregations.

Joe Sakic, the Avalanche captain, signed a one-year deal yesterday to stay in Colorado. Sakic, who has played all 17 seasons with the Avalanche franchise, will turn 37 next month. He said that he thought a one-year contract extension was fair to both sides, but that he hoped to play at least two more seasons. Financial terms were not disclosed. Sakic ranks 11th on the N.H.L.'s career list in points (1,489), 15th in assists (915) and 17th in goals (574). He has more overtime playoff goals (seven) than anyone. Only Steve Yzerman has a longer tenure with the same team (22 seasons), and only five players have scored more points with one organization (Wayne Gretzky, Mario Lemieux, Gordie Howe, Ray Bourque and Yzerman).

The final round of the United States Open on NBC generated a 4.7 rating Sunday, the lowest since 1991, when the tournament was won by Payne Stewart. The round, in which Geoff Ogilvy won after Phil Mickelson double-bogeyed the 18th hole, was viewed by an average of seven million people, down from eight million last year. The weekend average rating of a 4.0 (with an average of 5.7 million viewers) was off 17 percent from a 4.8 (6.7 million viewers) last year.

Five Florida spring training sites are eligible to receive $15 million each over the next 30 years under a bill signed yesterday by Gov. Jeb Bush. The bill also provides the Orlando Magic with $60 million to refurbish its arena. Six baseball teams will be able to apply for the money, which would be split into $500,000 annual payments to help keep Arizona's Cactus League from raiding the Florida Grapefruit League. Baltimore, Cincinnati, Cleveland, the Mets, Pittsburgh and Tampa Bay are covered in the bill.

Alain Vigneault, a former coach of the Montreal Canadiens, was hired yesterday as coach of the Vancouver Canucks, who promoted him from their minor league affiliate. He replaced Marc Crawford, who was fired in April after the Canucks missed the playoffs for the first time in five seasons. Crawford has since been hired as coach of the Los Angeles Kings. Vigneault, 45, coached the Canadiens for more than three seasons (1997-2001) and spent last season behind the bench of the Manitoba Moose of the American Hockey League. He led the Moose to their first 100-point season and the second round of the playoffs. Vigneault was 109-113-39-5 in Montreal. After a strong 1999-2000 season, the Canadiens started the next season 5-8-6-1, and Vigneault was fired after 20 games.

Big waves generated by a storm 2,000 miles away battered Central America's Pacific Coast, wrecking at least 20 houses in Nicaragua and a small hotel in Guatemala, civil defense officials said. There were no reports of fatalities. Authorities ordered 200 people evacuated in Nicaragua as reports of high tides came in from Mexico and several Central American countries. Swells up to 12 feet high hit beaches from the Gal√°pagos Islands to Acapulco. Beaches were closed as far south as northern Chile. Officials said the event was not a tsunami.

The police arrested at least 45 people in what they said was a operation aimed at thwarting an all-out Mafia war of succession after the capture of Bernardo Provenzano, the boss of all bosses of the Sicilian Mafia, in April. They said that the suspects, including the heads of 13 Mafia families in Sicily, made up the support network that had allowed Mr. Provenzano to remain on the run for 43 years and that the sweep came after wiretaps pointed to a possible Mafia war of succession.
In an effort to salvage a deal, Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov changed the terms under which he would buy a stake in the steel giant Arcelor.

Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China pledged to forge closer ties with Angola, the focal point of a seven-nation African tour aimed at cementing Beijing's links to the oil-rich continent. Australian hospitals are bracing for a baby boom next month as pregnant women try to delay births to take advantage of a new welfare payment, researchers said. Beginning July 1, a baby bonus paid to the parents for every newborn will increase by $740, to $3,000. Economists said that after the baby bonus was introduced in 2004, about 700 births were delayed by a week to take advantage of the payment.

A French court found Bob Denard, left, France's best-known mercenary, guilty of mounting a coup in the Comoro Islands off southeast Africa in 1995 and gave him a five-year suspended sentence. Twenty-six accomplices drew lesser sentences. The coup was ended after two weeks when the mercenaries surrendered to the French Army and freed the president they had taken hostage. Mr. Denard, 77, who was born Gilbert Bourgeaud before he gave himself the rank of colonel and a new name, was excused from testifying because doctors said he had Alzheimer's disease. He is said to be the model for the lead character in Frederick Forsyth's 1974 novel
The announcement came 44 years after Dan Rather started at CBS and five months before his "60 Minutes" contract was due to expire.

One week after a knife blade pierced his heart, Christopher McCarthy left St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center yesterday morning with plans to return someday and finish the tour of New York that came to a violent end aboard a subway train.

The Sweet Cherry, the waterfront strip club that for nearly a decade bedeviled the police, prosecutors, politicians and neighborhood groups who wanted it shuttered, has closed — permanently, officials say — as part of a broad and unusual plea agreement, lawyers involved in the deal said yesterday.
The graduates of Millennium High School in Lower Manhattan celebrated not just themselves, but also the school that grew out of the rubble of Sept. 11.

The headline with an article on Monday about proposals under consideration by the board of the American Civil Liberties Union to limit internal critics from speaking publicly against the organization's policies and internal operations misstated the intended target. It would be the organization's board members, not all A.C.L.U. members.
In West Chelsea, a commercial condominium that will let galleries buy their space could help keep them from getting priced out.

Simple syrup, indispensable to bartenders, is usually nothing more than equal parts sugar and water, heated until the sugar dissolves. Depaz, a plantation on the Caribbean island of Martinique that makes fine rum from cane juice, has introduced a syrup made of freshly pressed sugar cane juice diluted with filtered water, something you cannot make at home. It is an amber color, like the rum, and it has a clean, slightly honeyed flavor. You can use it to sweeten iced tea, and in baking, too.

POPPING open a bottle of prosecco has none of the ceremony associated with Champagne. Prosecco is not a special-occasion quaff; it's a refresher, especially on a warm summer afternoon or evening. It does offer the almost giddy delight that can be derived from sipping a sparkling wine, but its relatively low alcohol content keeps the giddiness in check. Prosecco is the wine of choice for making a Bellini, either with white peach pur√©e or in some other fruited version. In Scotland, I had a Highland Bellini, deliciously punched up with a shot of Scotch. But prosecco does more than just contribute to a cocktail.

Suzan-Lori Parks's curious writing idea -- writing a play a day for a year -- has started its own curious producing idea. In presenting Ms. Parks's play cycle, ''365 Days/365 Plays,'' the Public Theater is mounting a widespread collaboration with more than 600 theaters nationwide. The theaters involved -- in Atlanta, Denver, Los Angeles, the Carolinas and other places -- will present the premiere of the cycle as it unfolds from Nov. 13, 2006, to Nov. 12, 2007. In New York the plays will be performed by 52 theaters around the city selected by the Public, Ms. Parks, right, and the producer, Bonnie Metzgar. Each theater will put on a week's worth of the plays. At the end of each month, the theaters will be invited to put on a free performance of their share of the cycle at the Public Theater. The ''365 Days/365 Plays'' project will be accepting applications online from New York theaters. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

FINSTON--Beth Waters. Cooney/Waters Group mourns the loss of our cofounder, Beth Waters. Beth was remarkable for her intelligence, conviction and sheer force of will. She refused to believe there was a problem that could not be solved, never saw a challenge she declined to take on. She found paths through thorny dilemmas, hope in situations others sought to abandon. Highly demanding and great fun, as partner, colleague and friend, she will be deeply grieved and grievously missed. Lenore Cooney, Chairman $(6$)FINSTON--Beth Waters. Died June 19, 2006. Resident of Morristown, NJ. Widow of Mark Finston. Mother of Wendelyn Waters, M.D. and Rebecca Daley, grandmother of Aseema Daley, Lona and Lilah Sniderman and Paige Freund, mother-in-law of Erik Freund. Beth was born in Newark, New Jersey, and graduated from Syracuse University. A reporter for publications including the Philadelphia Bulletin, Boston Magazine and the Boston Herald in the early years of her career, Beth was a Senior Managing Director of Ogilvy Public Relations before cofounding Cooney/Waters Group, a health care public relations and public affairs company in New York City. Beth's passion was advocacy for vaccines to prevent and treat diseases in the industrialized world and in developing countries. She was indefatigable in her work, traveling the world to lend her intensity and expertise to her client sanofi pasteur, governmental committees and non-governmental organizations, advancing immunization against polio, HIV/ AIDS, avian influenza meningococcal disease. Beth was a wise counselor, a creative problem-solver, and a relentless optimist. She was a founding member of the advisory board of the Vaccine Education Center of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and a member of the HIV Vaccine Communications Steering Group of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 22 at 1 p.m. at Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, 973-422-0600. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broadway Cares/ Equity Fights AIDS, Planned Parenthood USA or American Jewish World Service.

Wild shrimp from the Gulf of Mexico, sold fresh, have a firm texture and a mild, clean flavor when quickly boiled in salted water. They are $19.99 a pound (16 to 20 shrimp, with heads) at Wild Edibles, in Grand Central Market and at 535 Third Avenue (35th Street), where $2 of the price is donated to shrimpers recovering from last year's hurricanes. At the Lobster Place, in Chelsea Market and at 252 Bleecker Street (Cornelia Street), they are $8.95 with heads. Fairway has them for $6.99, without heads.

A front-page headline on Saturday about the online reference work Wikipedia referred imprecisely to its ''anyone can edit'' guidelines, which have always restricted changes in a small percentage of articles. While Wikipedia has indeed added a category of articles that are ''semi-protected'' from editing, it has not ''revised'' its policy or otherwise put additional restrictions on editing; it says the change is intended to reduce the number of entries on which editing is banned altogether.

Dr. Gribetz, a preferred pulmonary consultant, joined Mount Sinai in 1971 and gained the highest praises from his colleagues for his intelligence, enthusiasm, diligence, generosity, and exemplary relations with patients, and staff. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his family and friends. Peter W. May Chairman of the Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, M.D. President, CEO and Dean

Higher gasoline prices increased Canada's inflation rate to 2.8 percent in May from 2.4 percent a month earlier, Statistics Canada reported. More surprising to economists, however, was a rise in the country's core inflation rate -- a measure that excludes volatile costs like energy -- to 2 percent from 1.6 percent in April. Most economists had expected that rate to increase to 1.7 percent. The rise in core inflation, combined with solid job growth in May, has again fueled speculation that the Bank of Canada will increase lending rates. IAN AUSTEN (NYT)

An article in The Arts yesterday about the world bridge championships in Verona, Italy, referred incorrectly to the Senior Teams competition schedule. The competition ended on Monday; it did not continue yesterday. It was won by the team of Shalom Zeligman of Israel, Aleksander Jezioro, Julian Klukowski, Victor Melman and Jerzey Zaremba, all of Poland; and Victor Markowicz. The article also misidentified Mr. Markowicz's country. While he is Polish, he has lived in the United States in recent years.

The World Cup match had hit a lull. Neither Argentina nor Serbia and Montenegro was able to penetrate the other's territory, and the crowd at Scorpio, an outdoor bar in the seaside Montenegrin town of Kotor, had started to discuss other subjects: real estate, girls, local hip-hop. I was beginning to understand why Americans are not big soccer fans. Then, out of nowhere, the ball skipped into the air and a player flew after it, one Adidas-clad foot extended. Goal! The applause echoed off the white stone walls of this medieval town, wedged between a fortress-crowned mountain and a pristine fjordlike bay. For a moment, I was shocked. The dozen Montenegrin guys drinking 1.50-euro Nik beers at Scorpio were cheering not for their home team but for their apparent opponents, Argentina.

MILLER -- Robert Douglas. June 21, 1970 -June 21, 1996. ''His life was gentle: and the elements So mix'd in him, that NATURE might stand up, And say to all the world, 'This was a man!''' With loving memory, Mom, Dad and Rachel

INTERNATIONAL A3-9 2 Bodies Found in Iraq Were Brutalized, U.S. Says The American military said that searchers had found the remains of what appeared to be the two American soldiers captured by insurgents last week during an ambush south of the capital, and a senior Iraqi defense official said the two men had been ''brutally tortured.'' A1 As the Senate prepares for a bitter debate about whether to begin pulling troops from Iraq, Senator John Kerry insists on setting a date for all American combat troops to be withdrawn, frustrating some Senate Democrats who say in interviews that his new stand may complicate their hopes of taking back a majority in Congress in 2006. A4 North Korea Defiant on Pledge North Korea said it was not bound by its own moratorium on long-range missile tests, as tension over Pyongyang's missile intentions continued to mount. It is contributing to a suicide rate that officials describe as close to triple what it was before Hurricane Katrina struck. A1 Conviction in Lobby Case A former White House aide, David H. The Security Council extended its political mission by two months and asked Secretary General Kofi Annan to plan for a ''strengthened presence'' of the United Nations there in light of recent violence that killed 30 people. The United States voted for the resolution despite a statement by its ambassador, John R. Bolton, questioning the need for returning peacekeepers. WARREN HOGE (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''When School Turns Into the Land of 1,000 Dances'' (news article, June 20): New York City is to be lauded for continuing the tradition of spring dance festivals for children. What a great way for kids to exercise, interact with friends and get a feel for music and dance, all at the same time.

A headline on Monday about proposals under consideration by the board of the American Civil Liberties Union to limit internal critics from speaking publicly against the organization's policies and internal operations misstated the intended target. It would be the organization's board members, not all A.C.L.U. members.

DEBT RATINGS CUT Two major rating agencies cut General Motors' debt rating further into junk status after the automaker announced a plan to improve its liquidity by refinancing $5.6 billion in loans. The airline wants to know if assigning seats will slow the unloading of arriving planes and the boarding of passengers for the next flight. The store is to open in the fall. WE sounded the call and you responded: the Dining section received hundreds of submissions in response to a notice on May 31 soliciting readers' recipes for the summer cocktail of 2006. The recipes came from across the country: our runners-up were submitted by a chef in Florida (the Gingino) and a food purveyor in Texas (L'Alhambra). Other entries were from as far afield as Kingston, Ontario and Berlin. The winning cocktail, the Cuke, was submitted by Adam Frank, a gallery director at the Hosfelt Gallery in New York. In addition to the bragging rights, Mr. Frank will receive a modest selection of books on cocktails as his prize.

SYLVESTER--Albert R. On June 12, 2006, Albert Sylvester died after a long illness. Born in 1926, he was a beloved husband, father, and decorated World War II veteran. He was 80years old. Services will be at Saint Phillips Episcopal Church in Brooklyn: 718-778-8700, on June 21st and 22nd.

CLARK--Hays. The Trustees, Life Trustees, Physicians and Staff of New York-Presbyterian Hospital and the Overseers, Faculty and Staff of Weill Medical College of Cornell University are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Hays Clark. Mr. Clark was elected Governor of The Society of the New York Hospital in 1971, Life Governor in 1988 and Life Trustee of New York-Presbyterian Hospital in 1998. He enthusiastically championed and generously supported the shared missions of the Hospital and Medical College. Involved in numerous areas of governance, including clinical, finance and operations, he also endowed a professorship in pathology in honor of David D. Thompson, M.D. Energetic and dedicated, Mr. Clark will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife, Rosamund Seidel Clark, and his brother James Clark, a Hospital Life Trustee. Our deepest condolences are extended to the entire Clark family. John J. Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Herbert Pardes President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Dr. Antonio M. Gotto Jr. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

Along Front Street from Peck Slip to Beekman Street, in the former Fulton Fish Market area, renovated buildings are shedding the brown paper on their doors as food shops and restaurants emerge. Among the pioneers is Barbarini Alimentari at No. 225, which is owned by the restaurateurs Claudio Marini and Stefano Barbagallo. In this grocery and cafe there is a counter for ordering light Italian food, like a sandwich of speck with taleggio cheese and fris√©e or an open-face vitello tonnato ($6 to $9); salads ($7); and plates of pasta ($9 to $12). Shelves are starting to be stocked with imported rice, pasta, coffee, olive oil and condiments. Refrigerated cases hold cheeses, including buffalo mozzarella; excellent jars of anchovies ($13.95 for 8.4 ounces); and chubby mini mortadellas ($12.95).

CONNOR--Sidney. On June 17, 2006, age 79, after a long illness. Loving husband of Marjorie, devoted father of Bradley, Nancy and Joseph, grandfather of Liora & David Connor, Danielle & Michelle Long, brother of the late Robert Connor and Sylvia Goldberg. Former Special Agent, Intelligence and Criminal Investigation Division, U.S. Treasury Dept., and private forensic accountant.

McDOWELL--Alan Stewart. A Jackson, WY resident, died peacefully at his home in Wayzata, MN with his family on June 16, 2006 after a battle with prostate cancer. Born on June 27, 1938 in Binghamton, NY, he was the son of the late W. Wallace McDowell and Louise Smith McDowell. He spent his formative years in Ardsley-on-Hudson, NY and graduated valedictorian from the Hackley School in Tarrytown, NY in 1956. He was a 1960 cum laude graduate of Princeton University and earned an MBA from The Harvard Business School in 1963. While at Princeton, Alan was a member of Cottage Club and studied in the Woodrow Wilson School. He rowed crew and competed in the Henley Regatta in July of 1959.After Harvard, Alan spent several years at the New York investment bank, Allen & Company. In 1967, he married Susan Snyder of Wayzata, MN. In 1975, he moved to Wayzata to start a new career as an entrepreneur in the fast food industry. His major success came with building Pizza Ventures into the biggest franchisee of Godfather's Pizza. Pizza Ventures went public and was ultimately sold to the parent company in 1984. After selling Pizza Ventures, Alan enjoyed continuing success as a business leader through the roles of private investor and director of several public and private corporations, including The Foothill Group, Chart House, Buffets, Diamond Brands, and AGCO. He was also a dedicated and accomplished golfer who devoted considerable time and effort toward mastering the game. Over the years he was fortunate enough to play golf at many of the world's greatest venues and to share those experiences with his many close friends. In addition, he was a member of Woodhill Country Club and Spring Hill Club in Wayzata; Teton Pines in Jackson, WY; The Valley Club in Montecito, CA; and The Stock Farm in Missoula, MT. He was also a member of The United States Seniors' Golf Association. Alan loved America and was a passionate devotee of the principles of liberty and free-markets. As a great friend and mentor to many young people, he enjoyed helping them achieve their own version of the American Dream. Friends and family alike will remember Alan for his intellectual integrity, his enthusiastic support, and his great generosity. Alan is survived by his wife, Susan, and two children, Whitney Weed McDowell of Bozeman, MT and Jeffrey Morrison McDowell and wife Carrie of Austin, TX, and two grandchildren, Daisy Louise McDowell and Callie Morrison McDowell. His older brother, W. Wallace McDowell, Jr. and wife Anne, of Greenwich, CT also survive him. A memorial service will be held on Thursday 4:30pm at the Woodhill Country Club, 200 Woodhill Road, Wayzata. In lieu of flowers the family prefers that memorial donations be made to a charity of the donor's choice. For information: David Lee Funeral Home, Wayzata, MN 952473-5577

A report in the National Briefing column on Thursday about financing for Amtrak incompletely described a House vote. The vote, 406 to 22, came on an appropriations bill that included money for the Transportation Department as a whole; the vote was not just for Amtrak.

LAMB--Bill. The Trustees, Staff and Volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation (EBC) lament the passing of Bill Lamb, one of the founding members of EBC's flagship station, Thirteen/WNET. A member of the team that brought Thirteen/WNET to life in 1962, Bill also oversaw the creation of some of public televisions most outstanding offerings, including: ''Nature,'' ''Great Performances,'' ''American Playhouse,'' ''The Brain'' and ''Heritage: Civilization and the Jews.'' We join his companion, Marcie Setlow, and his family in mourning the loss of a dear friend and colleague. Steven Rattner Chairman William F. Baker President

Impressionist and Modern artworks sold for a total of $163.6 million at Sotheby's in London on Monday night, the highest amount for any auction held in London. The star of the show, consigned from an otherwise unidentified American collection, was a portrait, above, painted by Amedeo Modigliani in 1919, a year before his death. The portrait, said to represent Jeanne H√©buterne, the artist's companion, sold for $30 million, the second-highest price ever paid at auction for a Modigliani. The seller bought the painting at its last auction appearance, at Sotheby's New York in May 1997, for $8.7 million, a figure that seems timid in retrospect, although widely deemed high at the time. SOUREN MELIKIAN (IHT)

WEXLER--George, 81, a wellknown painter of Hudson Valley landscapes, died on June 17 after a long illness. He had been associated with Fischbach Gallery in New York City for almost 20 years. His paintings are represented in many museums as well as public and private collections. Most recently, his works were selected by the State Department's ''Art in Embassies'' program for display at U.S. embassies worldwide. He was a Professor Emeritus from the State University at New Paltz, where he taught painting and drawing for 30 years. Previous to that, he was a Professor at Michigan State University for seven years. Mr. Wexler lived in Sarasota, FL after leaving New paltz, NY in 2004. He is survived by his wife, the Sculptor Thyra Davidson, and three sons: Andrew, of Glenville, NY, James, of Junction City, KA, and Daniel, of Milwaukee, WI. Also four grandchildren. Mr. Wexler was a veteran of WWII. Memorial donations may be made to DAV Chapter 3, 2445 Fruitville Rd., Sarasota, FL 34237

The National Basketball Association fined Mark Cuban $250,000 on Tuesday for what the league called ''several acts of misconduct'' after the Dallas Mavericks' loss to Miami in Game 5 of the finals. Upset by what he said were officiating mistakes in Dallas's 101-100 overtime defeat Sunday, Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Mavericks, went onto the court after the game and used profanity in berating the referee Joe DeRosa. Cuban stared down Commissioner David Stern while leaving the court and uttered profanities while criticizing some questions from reporters in two separate tirades in the Mavericks' locker room.

To the Editor: Your assertion (''Phony Deficit Hawks,'' editorial, June 18) that pay-go budget rules are the answer to federal deficits is a page from the liberal playbook -- a way to put forth a solution that also happens to be irrelevant to the issue at hand. Pay-go does not reduce the deficit, nor does it have any effect on the national debt.

GUEDALIA--Judah. Those privileged to worship under his steady eye, dignified demeanor and commanding presence, will forever revere his memory as the guardian of the Minhagim; the rituals of which Shearith Israel, forever remains the American guardian par excellance of our English and Dutch forebears. May his light be perpetuated by our presence. Alvin Deutsch, Hon. Parnas

Faced with the demolition of public housing projects used as hideouts and a crackdown by city police, Chicago street gangs are increasingly setting up shop in the suburbs, according to a report by the Chicago Crime Commission. The report also found that Chicago-area gangs were engaging in more white-collar crime and increasingly working with instead of against each other to make more money. The report profiles 56 of the more than 70 gangs that have a total of more than 70,000 members in the Chicago area. It includes photographs of gang leaders, drawings of gang graffiti and maps of gang territory. GRETCHEN RUETHLING (NYT)

A front-page article on Sunday about members of the Bush administration who are now working for companies that sell domestic security products misstated the elected office once held by Asa Hutchinson, a former under secretary of Homeland Security, in some copies. He was a congressman from Arkansas. (It was his older brother Tim who served as a senator for one term.)

On a lazy, hazy Monday night for the networks, Fox and CBS divided what spoils there were. Fox rebroadcast a ''Hell's Kitchen'' at 8 p.m. and then showed a new episode at 9 p.m., which brought in an estimated 7.39 million viewers and the night's highest 18-to-49 rating. The draw in that demographic was enough to give Fox an overall win. CBS's schedule of repeats was No. 1 among total viewers. Its rerun of ''CSI: Miami'' (11.1 million) at 10 p.m. was Monday's most-watched show. During that hour, ABC's dating reality series ''How to Get the Guy'' continued to tank in its second week, delivering only 3.8 million viewers. NBC broadcast Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals. The preliminary estimates for the live event indicated it put NBC in third place for the night, and that the Carolina Hurricanes' victory was the highest-rated game of these low-rated N.H.L. finals. KATE AURTHUR

The Public Lives column on Friday, about Courtney Sale Ross, the founder of a New York City charter school that is the subject of a lawsuit, referred incorrectly to the New Explorations Into Science, Technology and Math school, which currently occupies the Columbia Street building to which the Ross school is assigned. NEST, as it is known, is a public school, not a charter school.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday the creation of the South Bronx Initiative, a group with officials from seven city agencies charged with ''articulating a vision for the future of the South Bronx'' and making plans to realize that vision. The initiative will be led by Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, and will be loosely modeled on an earlier plan to guide the development of the Hunts Point peninsula. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

Loving father of Gerry and the late Roland, grandfather of Scott, Robb, and Matthew and great grandfather of Tabatha, Holliss, Ronald and Marilla. THE best bar snack I've had in New York lately was the fried hominy at Cookshop in the meatpacking district. It was an easy order the first time around, because I'm a huge fan of all forms of dried corn. I especially like the flavor of hominy (also called posole), in which corn is treated with slaked lime, or calcium hydroxide. The resulting product is used to make tortillas and grits, and if you think about their unusual flavor you can recognize why hominy has always been so popular.

The trial of a security official accused of human rights abuses during the military dictatorship of the 1970's, the first such legal proceeding since the Supreme Court overturned a pair of amnesty laws last year, has begun in La Plata, the capital of Buenos Aires Province. Miguel Etchecolatz, the former chief of investigations of the provincial police, faces charges of illegal arrest, torture and murder in eight cases. He was found guilty of kidnapping political prisoners in a 1986 trial and sentenced to 23 years in prison, but that verdict was later vacated because of the amnesty provision, which granted immunity from prosecution to officials who were following their superiors' orders. LARRY ROHTER (NYT)

JUST as a margarita is often an introduction to tequila, for most Americans the first taste of cacha√ßa, the national spirit of Brazil, is likely to be in a caipirinha, a cocktail made by muddling lime wedges with sugar, then adding cacha√ßa and ice. ''Americans might know the caipirinha but until recently they probably did not know what spirit it was made with,'' said Matti Anttila, a New York investment banker turned cacha√ßa entrepreneur.

The Department of Health and Human Services has placed a $165 million order for 20,000 doses of a new anthrax drug that it hopes to put in a biodefense stockpile starting in 2009. The drug, Abthrax, made by Human Genome Sciences of Rockville, Md., neutralizes the deadly toxin that anthrax bacteria produce, which accounted for the majority of deaths in the 2001 anthrax attacks, said Dr. Gerald Parker, acting assistant secretary for public health emergency preparedness. ERIC LIPTON (NYT)

Laurence Shames, a writer known for such crime novels as "The NakedDetective" and "Welcome to Paradise," would not confirm or deny yesterdaya report in Daily Variety that he is also the author of "Bad Twin," a novel publishedunder the name of Gary Troup, a character from ABC's hit drama series"Lost." "Gary Troup wrote the book," Mr. Shames said in a telephone interviewfrom his home in Southern California. "It is interesting how closelyhis prose style resembles mine. He sets a lot of the story in places I've been."Mr. Shames, who has written eight novels, all set in the Florida Keys, also notedthat the town where he lives "bears a striking resemblance" to a little towncalled Luna in "Bad Twin." The real author of the book has been a source ofspeculation for weeks among fans of "Lost," which is set on a mysterious Pacificisland where bad things keep happening. Mr. Shames said that he hadnever talked with anyone at Daily Variety but that the article about his "outing"had sparked speculative e-mail messages comparing his style toTroup's. And just for the record, Mr. Shames calls "Bad Twin" an "excellent"book that "everyone should read."
CHAKEJIAN--Mary. A dear, gentle aunt who lived among us for 98 blessed years...and made the best potato salad! Louise Yacoobian Garofalo

9 P.M. (USA) AFI LIFETIME ACHIEVEMENT AWARD: A TRIBUTE TO SEAN CONNERY -- ''Bond. James Bond.'' Uttered in that silken voice, those words left more than a few viewers shaken and stirred. In this special, taped on June 8 at the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles, some of Sir Sean's (above) envious peers pay homage to the actor who has gotten his way with more brazen beauties than any other, at least onscreen. Harrison Ford, no slouch in the seduction department, bestows the honors. 8 P.M. (CBS) BIG BROTHER 7: ALL-STARS -- Historically, democracy has been riddled with subterfuge, deception and treason. Which may be why the producers of ''Big Brother'' opted to let viewers vote for the series's next 12 houseguests from hell in this hour-long casting special for the new season, which begins July 6 at 8 p.m. 8 P.M. (13) DANCE IN AMERICA: BEYOND THE STEPS: ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER -- Past, present, future: that concept is at the heart of the Ailey's mission statement, which means performing in the here while looking ahead to what the ensemble hopes to achieve and keeping a legacy alive. This ''Great Performances'' documentary follows the company as it travels to Russia for the first time in 20 years, moves into its new headquarters in Manhattan, and creates ''Love Stories'' (above, with, from left, Clifton Brown, Matthew Rushing and Dwana Adiaha Smallwood), a three-part ballet choreographed by the Ailey's artistic director, Judith Jamison (whose segment, she said, references the past), the hip-hop innovator Rennie Harris (the present) and the modern dance trailblazer Robert Battle (the future). 9 P.M. (13) A LION IN THE HOUSE -- Every year in the United States, some 12,500 children hear the diagnosis that leaves most adults quaking: ''You have cancer.'' This ''Independent Lens'' documentary follows five young patients and their families at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center and asks the tough questions: How do you decide to stop medical intervention when treatment fails? And how do you put your lives back together when it succeeds? 9 P.M. (NBC) AMERICA'S GOT TALENT -- In varying degrees, of course, as will be made brutally apparent in the latest in Simon Cowell's anything-for-fame series. An array of singers, dancers, comedians and promising ''unique acts'' will pour their hearts out for a chance at $1 million, with the final two contestants chosen, one each, by viewers and a panel of celebrity judges. If ''American Idol'' had Paula Abdul, Randy Jackson and Mr. Cowell, this time around it's the singer Brandy, the actor David Hasselhoff and Piers Morgan, a somewhat scurrilous British media personality. Standing in for the dentally enhanced Ryan Secrest: the toothsome Regis Philbin (above). KATHRYN SHATTUCK

An article on April 5 about the date 04/05/06 -- a once-in-a-century alignment -- referred erroneously, in discussing other dates of numerical interest, to calculations by the evolutionary biologist Stephen Jay Gould in his 1997 book ''Questioning the Millennium: A Rationalist's Guide to a Precisely Arbitrary Countdown.'' Mr. Gould, in analyzing a theory that Jesus was actually born in 4 B.C. and that the world would end 2,000 years after Jesus's birth, concluded that the 2,000-year mark would arrive in 1997 -- not 1996. (There was no year zero.) A reader reported the error at the time, but his e-mail was misdirected at The Times.

A television highlight entry yesterday about the movie ''The Heiress,'' on TCM, misidentified the author of the novel ''Washington Square,'' the film's inspiration. It was Henry James, not his older brother, William.

But thundering waterfalls would still cascade into the pools, at the bottom of two voids marking where the twin towers stood. PAGE B1 Conviction in Lobbying Case David H.
