A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on Friday about the Museum of Modern Art's acquisition of three films by the South African artist William Kentridge misstated the number of trustees who gave the films to the museum. It was four, not three. Marie-Jos√©e Kravis, the museum's president, made the gift along with Kathy Fuld, Agnes Gund and David Rockefeller Sr.

BBC Drops 'Top of the Pops' Forty-two years after the Rolling Stones, below in 1964, sang ''I Wanna Be Your Man'' on the first broadcast, ''Top of the Pops'' is being canceled by the BBC. ''The time has come to bring the show to its natural conclusion,'' said Jana Bennett, the BBC's director of television. A BBC statement said that the weekly program, which features a countdown through the pop chart to the No. 1 single of the week, could no longer compete with 24-hour music channels. In its heyday in the 1970's, the show attracted audiences of 15 million, but by 2002 the number had dropped to 2 million. When ''Top of the Pops'' first went on the air it was scheduled for six episodes, but soon proved so popular that it was given a weekly slot. The final broadcast is scheduled for July 30. Judge Delays Retrial Of Notorious B.I.G. Lawsuit A federal judge has postponed a retrial of the wrongful death suit brought by the family of the rapper Notorious B.I.G. against the city of Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. United States District Judge Florence-Marie Cooper delayed the trial by three months, to Jan. 16, to give the family more time to seek information from the defense. Notorious B.I.G., right, whose real name was Christopher Wallace, was shot and killed on March 9, 1997, after a party at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles. The homicide has never been solved. The rapper's family contends that rogue police officers were involved in the slaying. The judge declared a mistrial and ordered payment by the city of $1.1 million in legal fees and other expenses to the family after finding that a police detective had concealed statements by a jailhouse informant that linked the killing to two former officers. Perry Sanders, a lawyer representing the family, is seeking information from 27 city employees that he says had contact with the statements. Jerry Lewis on the Mend Jerry Lewis, below, has returned to work, preparing for his annual Labor Day telethon for muscular dystrophy as he recovers from heart surgery and pneumonia aboard his boat in San Diego, The Associated Press reported. His longtime manager, Claudia Marghilano, said Mr. Lewis, 80, was released from a hospital on Saturday after a stent was placed in an artery after he had a heart attack on June 11. She also said that he was taking antibiotics for the pneumonia, associated with pulmonary fibrosis, a lung ailment that has afflicted him since 2000. ''He's doing just great now,'' Ms. Marghilano said. Footnotes The first annual Tony Randall Grant, a $100,000 award given to a New York-area nonprofit theater company for the production of a classic play, an adaptation of a classic or a work inspired by the classics, is to be awarded today to the New York Theater Workshop for production of Martha Clarke's ''Pirandello Project,'' scheduled to open in October. Lincoln Center Theater announced more of the cast for its production of Tom Stoppard's epic trilogy, ''The Coast of Utopia.'' Billy Crudup, as the 19th-century Russian literary critic Vissarion Belinsky, will be joining Ethan Hawke, Brian F. O'Byrne and Josh Hamilton as the intellectuals at the heart of the play. Richard Easton, Jennifer Ehle, Martha Plimpton and David Harbour will show up in multiple roles. Martin Short's improbable version of his life, ''Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me,'' has found a home on Broadway. It is to open in previews at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater on July 29. The opening date is Aug. 17.

AMERICAN chefs love to brag about their intimate relationships with food producers, but the chef Ana Sortun of Oleana restaurant, in Cambridge, Mass., went all out and married a farmer. She and Chris Kurth live on his family's farm in Sudbury, outside Boston, where they work together to reconcile the stubborn New England growing season with the restaurant's need for Mediterranean produce.

To the Editor: In ''A Problem That Can't Be Ignored'' (editorial, June 17), you make the proposal that as a precondition for peace in the Middle East, Hamas needs to renounce terrorism, acknowledge Israel's existence as a sovereign nation and abide by formal agreements previously signed by lawful Palestinian negotiators.

Last Tuesday's Science Times article on the U.S. government's public awareness campaign to promote breast-feeding left me feeling queasy. Not because I question the superior benefits for babies and mothers of breast- over bottle-feeding. Nor because, to anticipate the criticism normally lobbed at those who challenge the tenor of today's pro-breast dogma, I am in some way in the pocket of the formula industry or indifferent to children's health needs, or ignorant of the decades of research - detailed throughout the Times story - suggesting that breast-feeding may help ward off ailments ranging from ear infections to cancer.

Remember how in 1992 people used to say we were entering an enchanted world in which the Internet and television would be as one? That sounded exciting. But then one and another America-transforming event happened - O.J., the failure of Pets.com - and somehow the master screens kept stubbornly not converging.

Wachovia said Thursday it would sell its mortgage servicing unit to Barclays for $469 million. Barclays' acquisition of the division, HomeEq Servicing, will strengthen its mortgage securitization business in the United States.

Many onlookers have scratched their heads over the dealings of the media billionaire Sumner Redstone with Midway Games. Mr. Redstone, who controls both Viacom and CBS, quickly accumulated 89 percent of the video game maker's shares on the open market -- fueling hopes that a full takeover was coming -- and then abruptly stopped buying late last year. He shifted his Midway holdings around through some complex transactions involving his movie company, National Amusements, and a separate entity controlled by his daughter. In the months since then, Midway's stock has tanked.

As recently as April, some analysts thought Google might be interested in buying Baidu.com, the undisputed leader of Internet search in China. But Google has apparently done just the opposite. Regulatory filings show that the United States-based company has recently sold its entire stake in Baidu, which amounted to about 2 percent of Baidu's equity. Google's comments on the transaction only reinforced the notion that it does not plan to buy its way into the Chinese market.

Just two days before Morgan Stanley's announcement on Wednesday that quarterly profits had more than doubled, Reuters published a somewhat dour article explaining that it will probably take some time before the Wall Street giant can right itself.

The New Republic's Jason Zengerle, writing on his magazine's The Plank blog, uncovers an e-mail from Markos Moulitsas Zuniga, the proprietor of DailyKos, that may help explain things.

A former ambassador and deputy national security adviser under President Bush was hired on behalf of a Dubai state-owned firm to lobby the committee that approves foreign investments in the United States, PoliticalMoneyLine reported Thursday. Robert Blackwill, now president of the lobbying firm Barbour Griffith & Rogers, registered on behalf of Dubai International Capital as of March 25, but the registration document was made public only recently.

The Securities and Exchange Commission may take action against several hedge funds for giving preferential treatment to certain investors, according to two recent reports. At issue are so-called "side letters," or agreements with particular investors that include terms not given to other investors. Up to half of all hedge funds offer such side agreements, according to one estimate.
In an 86-13 vote, the Senate turned back a proposal that would require the administration to withdraw all combat troops from Iraq by July 1, 2007, with redeployments beginning this year.
Like a dipsomaniac at an open bar, Wine.com has gone back for yet more venture financing. This time it has collected $12 million from Baker Capital, it said in a press release on Thursday.

It may be a huge hit with the youngsters, but social-networking phenomenon MySpace "is so irrelevant to the financial performance" of owner News Corporation that "it doesn't even merit describing," Henry Blodget wrote Thursday in his Internet Outsider blog. MySpace's financial insignificance leaves Mr. Blodget wondering why the media giant spent $580 million to acquire MySpace's parent, Intermix Media, six months ago.

Green Mountain Power on Thursday said it had agreed to be acquired by Vermont-based Northern New England Energy, a unit of Gaz Metro Limited Partnership, for about $187 million. Green Mountain shareholders will receive $35 a share under terms of the deal.

A few days ago, the richest man in the world, Bill Gates, announced that he'd be stepping down from daily Microsoft activities in order to devote himself to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Through this foundation, Mr. Gates has said that he intends to give away 95 percent of his wealth. The foundation's primary interests are education, poverty and global health--saving the lives of the millions who die of preventable diseases, mostly in poor countries.

Dresdner Bank, the banking arm of Allianz AG, will cut 2,480 jobs, or almost 9 percent of its workforce, to reign in costs that exceed rivals. Along the way, Dresdner is revamping its investment banking unit which has struggled to compete against its Wall Street rivals.

The stock market is seesawing, housing is looking winded, and interest rates are climbing. So how can Wall Street's biggest investment banks - Morgan Stanley, Lehman Brothers, Goldman Sachs, and Bear Stearns - be posting their biggest gains in recent memory? More important, how long can the good times roll for them?
Apollo Management-controlled Hexion Specialty Chemicals suspended its already once-delayed initial public offering yesterday, citing "adverse market conditions."

NEC, one of the largest Japanese electronics conglomerates, said Wednesday that it was in talks to sell part of its European personal computer operations, which would lead to its withdrawal from the home-use PC market in that region.
Goldman Sachs Asset Management has started a $200 million offshore Chinese equity fund that will invest exclusively in China's domestic A-share market, the fund manager said on Thursday.

Nothing on wheels more personifies Italian style than the Vespa scooter, whose carefree spirit was immortalized by Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck circling Rome's piazzas in the 1953 film "Roman Holiday."

Three British bankers wanted in the United States on Enron-related fraud charges have a week to appeal to the European Court of Human Rights against their extradition, their lawyer said.

Harvard is still waiting for the software billionaire Larry Ellison to make good on a $115 million pledge, a year after he announced what would have been the largest single contribution in the university's history.

British Airways, Europe's third-largest airline, said on Thursday that it and other carriers were being investigated by competition authorities in both the United States and Britain over ticket prices and fuel surcharges.

Two groups of private-equity firms submitted formal bids for the arts-and-crafts retailer Michaels Stores Wednesday night, coming close to $40 a share, or roughly $5 billion, The New York Post said.
RGB Networks, which sells a switch used for video processing and bandwidth management, has closed a $20 million Series C round, resulting in a valuation of $110 million.

Intel Capital has increased its stake in a mobile WiMax equipment vendor, Navini Networks, a key supplier for the burgeoning wireless standard that could one day dramaticaly expand the use of Intel chips for wireless data and voice services.

IMG Artists, a major classical music management company, is in talks with the talent agency giant International Creative Management to acquire its classical music division, The New York Times reported.

The Bank of Cyprus made a 3.78 billion-euro ($4.8 billion) bid for Emporiki Bank of Greece, topping a bid from Credit Agricole for control of the bank, the sixth-biggest lender in Greece.

The chairman of the board of Yukos on Wednesday offered an unusually frank - and glum - assessment of the future of his oil company, comparing its prospects to those of Europe the day before the start of World War II.

At roughly the same time Wednesday that my Chinese blogs were causing consternation in Beijing, the two main Chinese search engines went offline. John Wiener, Boulder, Colo. : Judging a policy, or indeed an administration, as successful or failed may implicitly presume that there is some common basis for such a valuation. Throwing good money after bad, for example, may seem like a very good idea if you are the receiver of the money. Its value in accomplishing any given stated purpose may be quite irrelevant if the receiver has successfully invested in control of the thrower. Any reason to throw more money may suffice. And, the objective valuation may have no particular interest to those describing the game if they are convinced of higher ends that justify the means, or just enjoying the fruits of their success in description, however fictional or factional. A Flushing man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to two and a half to five years in prison for fatally striking a restaurant worker with his car last October, prosecutors said. The driver, Joung Il Cho, 38, pleaded guilty on May 1 to vehicular manslaughter for killing the worker, Angel Quizhpi, 24, who was riding his bicycle on Northern Boulevard when he was struck on Oct. 29, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that after the accident, the driver was found to have a blood alcohol content of 0.195 percent, more than twice the legal limit of .08 percent.

Two Depression-era recreation centers ‚Äî the Orchard Beach bathhouse and promenade in the Bronx, and the Astoria Park pool and play center in Queens ‚Äî have been designated landmarks by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Orchard Beach's 200,000-square-foot bathhouse and wide promenade, once called the Riviera of New York City, were built between 1933 and 1937 under Parks Commissioner Robert Moses. The Astoria Pool, the city's largest, has an Art Deco pavilion and was the site of the United States Olympic swimming trials in 1936 and 1964.

Ruling in favor of a 9-year-old boy who was severely injured in a 2001 traffic accident, a state appellate panel has found that schools are responsible for ensuring that young students are not dismissed without proper supervision. In its ruling on Tuesday, a panel of the Appellate Division of State Superior Court said found that school districts schools had a responsibility to protect children from foreseeable risks. The boy was hit by a car after being released from school.

Councilman Joel Rivera, left, the chairman of the City Council Health Committee, said yesterday that he would introduce a zoning change to limit the number of fast-food restaurants in low-income areas and increase the number of farmers' markets as a way to combat obesity. Mr. Rivera, of the Bronx, spoke during a committee hearing.

A tractor-trailer accident on the New Jersey Turnpike caused extensive traffic delays for several hours starting at 6 p.m. yesterday. Vehicles were backed up for more than three miles in both directions near Exit 8, the state police said.

Three workers were injured yesterday when the eight-car subway train they were traveling on slammed into a protective block in a Canarsie train yard, according to New York City Transit. There were no passengers aboard. The subway operator, who apparently suffered a seizure, was trying to park the train at 11:48 a.m. after its exterior was washed at the yard, said James Anyansi, a transit spokesman. The operator and the two other employees on board were taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center for treatment of unspecified injuries, Mr. Anyansi said.

The son of an admitted embezzler at the center of the Roslyn schools scandal was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation for buying $83,000 worth of merchandise for his personal use with a school district credit card given to him by his mother.

Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's office has sued a national debt-collection company, charging it with abusive practices, officials said. The lawsuit, filed on Tuesday in State Supreme Court, named the company, JBC & Associates; its successor companies, JBC Legal Group and Boyajian Law Offices; and their operator, Jack Boyajian of New Jersey. Joel Galante, director of business development for Boyajian Law Offices in Rutherford, N.J., said he had not seen the suit and declined to comment.

A 21-year-old man was shot yesterday afternoon at Troy Avenue and Sterling Place in the Weeksville section, the police said. The man was shot once in the chest about 3:35 p.m., the police said. They said the man, who was found near the vehicle on the street, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead at 5:15 p.m.

Rail service between Newark and Pennsylvania Station was temporarily suspended yesterday morning because of power problems along the Northeast Corridor, the third time in a month that Amtrak has suffered electrical failures. Cliff Black, an Amtrak spokesman, said there was a brief power fluctuation at 8:05 a.m. in the New York City area. He said trains were stopped but were allowed to move again by 8:33 a.m. Yesterday's power problems came less than a month after a power failure caused widespread disruption of rail service between Washington and Boston.

A nurse working at the Suffolk County jail was arrested on Tuesday and charged with passing cigarettes and matches to an inmate, the Sheriff's Department said yesterday. The nurse, Erin Clancy, 31, of East Patchogue, was charged with two misdemeanors, promoting prison contraband and criminal possession of stolen property, Sheriff Vincent DeMarco said. Investigators found her carrying a bag of pills that they said they suspected had been stolen from the jail's pharmacy, the sheriff said. Employed by the county health department, Ms. Clancy had worked at the jail six years. She was released and is scheduled to be arraigned next Wednesday.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the city could join state officials in opposing a lawsuit aimed at blocking plans for a 1.3-mile-long park along the Brooklyn waterfront. Lawyers for the Brooklyn Bridge Park Defense Fund, a neighborhood volunteer group that filed the lawsuit in May, argued that the city was irrelevant to the lawsuit and was joining it largely to create extra work for them. The group opposes the plan in part because it calls for luxury housing to help subsidize the cost, and seeks to reinstate an earlier plan that does not include the housing. City and state officials support the existing plan.
In New York City, between 1970 and 2000, the share of neighborhoods classified as middle-income neighborhoods declined to 30 percent from 42 percent.
A vote was canceled after some House Republicans said the civil rights measure unfairly singled out Southern states.
A bidding war has broken out over some assets of PCCW, one of Hong Kong's biggest telecommunications and media companies.
Executives from Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips indicated that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies.

Track and field's new generation of star athletes, who are trying to resuscitate the reputation of their sport after years of battering by drug scandals, are blood-tested regularly, at major competitions and at random.
The graduates of the Children's Learning Center at the Helen Keller Services for the Blind face challenges that would overwhelm most children their age.

An article on Tuesday about new research into the precise location of a World War I firefight in which Sgt. Alvin Cullum York captured 132 Germans misstated the make and model of the bolt-action rifle that historians say he used. It was an Enfield Model 1917, not a Lee-Enfield Model 17.
The Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts dropped out of a consortium of investors planning to bid in the auction for Univision.
Through the first five months of 2006, publishers brought out 338 new magazines, compared with 395 for the period a year ago.

As a candidate for governor, Thomas R. Suozzi is running as a reformer, a political outsider and a foe of special interests. But critics say his own record as Nassau County executive smacks of "pay to play" campaign fund-raising.
In reporters questions, President Bush faced reminders of how far the U.S. has fallen in the estimation of most Europeans.

Senator Arlen Specter, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said his hearings would explore the need for temporary guest workers.
Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles reached a compromise with legislative leaders and teachers unions that would give him some authority without the outright control he had sought.
The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida is challenging a decision by the Miami-Dade School Board to remove a book about Cuba from school libraries.
The San Diego theater said that Des McAnuff will not be renewing his contract after it expires next April.
The Falun Gong follower who heckled Hu Jintao at a White House ceremony has reached a deal with prosecutors under which all charges against her will be dropped.

Angel Maturino Resendiz, a Mexican national suspected in as many as 15 murders, is competent to be executed Tuesday, a judge decided. Mr. Resendiz, 46, was sentenced to death for the 1998 killing of a Houston doctor, Claudia Benton. Defense lawyers presented psychiatric testimony that Mr. Resendiz is a schizophrenic who believes he will return to life after his execution. But the judge, William T. Harmon of State District Court, held that Mr. Resendiz met the standard of sanity the United States Supreme Court requires for the death penalty to be carried out. The authorities have linked Mr. Resendiz to homicides in Texas, California, Illinois, Kentucky, Georgia and Florida. He came to be known as the
The provision would have given the governor of Massachusetts veto power over a proposed wind-power installation.
The FedEx Corporation reported a 27 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings and raised its profit forecast for the year.

Hollywood Park will replace its dirt main track with a synthetic surface in July, making it the first California track to do so. The state's other major thoroughbred tracks face a deadline of Dec. 31, 2007, by the California Horse Racing Board to install synthetic surfaces.

Oscar De La Hoya said yesterday he would not fight this year but hinted strongly that he would fight one last time next May against the unbeaten Floyd Mayweather Jr. De La Hoya had to make some decision on his future plans because a proposed Sept. 16 date loomed for a fight against Mayweather that could be the richest nonheavyweight fight in history.

A proposal to move the swimming finals at the 2008 Beijing Olympics from the evening to morning hours to accommodate television viewers in the United States is meeting resistance from coaches and broadcasters in other parts of the world. The International Olympic Committee executive board is expected to discuss the request by NBC today, but a final decision is likely to be put off until later this year. The move would showcase swimming for eight nights in prime time in the United States but at less desirable times in Europe, Asia and Australia.

Jenny Haigh, the Northwestern women's coach, resigned yesterday after her team was recently reprimanded for hazing. Northwestern reinstated its women's program earlier this month after suspending it May 15, the day photographs of the hazing incident appeared on a Web site. Several players are on disciplinary probation, and the team is required to perform community service. Some players will also be suspended from regular-season games next season, Athletic Director Mark Murphy said.

The N.H.L. board of governors approved the sale of the St. Louis Blues yesterday to a group headed by Dave Checketts, the former president of Madison Square Garden. The deal, reached March 24, transferred ownership of the Blues ‚Äî which had the league's worst record this season ‚Äî and the Savvis Center from Bill and Nancy Laurie to Checketts and his Sports Capital Partners and Towerbrook Capital Partners.
A proposal to add to the safety margin for runway stopping distances is setting up a conflict between concerns about safety and reliability, experts said.

To the Editor: As a four-mile-a-day, early-morning walker for over 20 years, I'd like to add one benefit to those mentioned in ''Sidewalks Are for Walking'' (Health special section, June 19). Beginning each day in such a healthful manner, which to me is both exhilarating and contemplative, ensures that no matter how complicated, troubled or even lazy the rest of the day may be, I can be proud of that hour.

The consistent use of condoms protects against human papillomavirus, a cause of warts and cervical and other female cancers, researchers are reporting today. In the study, which independent experts said was the most conclusive to examine the role of condoms in preventing infection with the virus, women whose male partners used condoms every time they had sexual intercourse had less than half the rate of infection as did women whose partners used condoms less than 5 percent of the time.

A report in the Personal Shopper column last Thursday about ideas to freshen up a kitchen included an incorrect price listed on Target's Web site for a wood kitchen cart with a stainless steel top. It is $279.99, not $79.99.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 104.62 points to 11,079.46. To the Editor: Re ''By Demand, Saks Revives Petite Dept.'' (Business Day, June 20):

The Miami Heat's N.B.A. championship victory on Tuesday brought ABC a win, too. The game's ratings easily beat the other networks' in Nielsen's estimates. The overnight numbers showed that the broadcast improved on last year's Game 6. ABC's telecasts of the finals last week made the network No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, while CBS ranked first among total viewers for the third week in a row. The second week of ''The Closer'' continued to post strong ratings for TNT on Monday night. The episode, in which Frances Sternhagen appeared as the mother of Kyra Sedgwick's character, drew 6.11 million viewers. Following ''The Closer,'' ''Saved'' (3.52 million) lost a significant portion of that audience. Also on Monday night, Lifetime's movie ''A Girl Like Me: The Gwen Araujo Story'' attracted 5.1 million viewers, making it the second most-watched cable movie of the year. (A&E's ''Flight 93'' brought in 5.9 million viewers.) KATE AURTHUR

A map yesterday showing population changes in some American cities from July 1, 2004, to July 1, 2005, included erroneous information from the Census Bureau on St. Louis. Its population grew 0.5 percent for the period; it did not fall 1.8 percent.

An article on Monday about the shootings or stabbings of 10 people in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the increase in violent incidents involving gunfire so far this year, over the same period in 2005, in the 67th Precinct, which includes East Flatbush. The rate is about 45 percent higher, not double.

The University of Chicago has acquiredthe remaining professional papers of SaulBellow from his estate. "The acquisition,which will be combined with the university'sexisting Bellow archive, is in accordancewith Bellow's own wishes and bringshis professional papers to one location," theuniversity said in a statement. Bellow, a winnerof the Nobel and Pulitzer prizes who diedin 2005, was a member of the university'sfaculty for more than 30 years and the author of novels like "Herzog," "Humboldt'sGift" and "The Adventures of Augie March."

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 3rd Lawyer for Hussein Seized and Shot to Death Saddam Hussein's trial for crimes against humanity was struck by new violence when a senior lawyer on his defense team was abducted, beaten and shot to death. Two other Hussein lawyers were killed earlier. A1 More than three years after it cast the votes setting the nation on the course to war, the Senate began the first extended debate on whether to end it. A12 The emerging Republican embrace of the war reflects the success of a White House effort to bring a skittish party on board. A1 An average of one civilian every day was killed by coalition forces in 2005 at checkpoints, roadblocks or alongside convoys, according to the American military's statistics. A13 President Bush, in Vienna, issued an impassioned defense of his Iraq policy amid pointed reminders of how far the United States has fallen in the eyes of many Europeans. A14 Airstrike Kills Another Gazan A Palestinian woman was killed and 13 people were wounded in Gaza after two Israeli missiles veered off target. A3 Ukraine Nears Parliament Deal Ukraine's quarrelling political parties announced an agreement to form a new parliamentary coalition that would generally support the pro-Western policies of President Viktor A. Yushchenko. A3 Mexican Strike Expands What started as a Mexican teachers' strike five weeks ago could affect the presidential election on July 2. A6 Iran to Delay Response on Plan The Iranian president said it would take more than a month before Iran responded to a proposal to resolve the dispute over its uranium-enrichment program. A14 NATIONAL A16-23 Detention Center Shootout Leaves 2 Dead in Florida A federal agent was killed and a prison officer wounded in a shootout with a guard about to be arrested in connection with a sex ring at a federal prison in Florida. The guard also died in the gun battle. A1 Renewal of Voting Act Canceled House Republican leaders abruptly canceled a planned vote to renew the landmark Voting Rights Act after a rebellion by lawmakers who say the civil rights measure unfairly singles out Southern states and unnecessarily requires ballots to be printed in foreign languages. A23 Presbyterians Won't Divest The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted to back off from a decision it made to pursue divestment from companies that profit from Israel's continuing involvement in the Palestinian territories. A18 FEMA Suspends Evictions The Federal Emergency Management Agency has suspended the eviction of 3,000 families who are living in government trailers in Mississippi. A16 Drug Raids in Chicago Hundreds of law enforcement officials carried out raids in a public housing project in Chicago, taking aim at what they described as a sophisticated drug ring that may be responsible for some of the 70 overdose deaths in the city and its suburbs. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Condoms Block Harmful Virus The consistent use of condoms protects against human papillomavirus, a cause of warts and cervical and other female cancers, researchers report. A20 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 Pastor Defends Husband Charged in Wife's Suicide A Sunday school teacher from Staten Island who killed herself in a plunge from a cliff had talked to her husband about suicide, the family's pastor said. But the husband, who is charged with assisting a suicide, took her comments as emotional outbursts rather than literal warnings, the pastor said. B1 A Small Group in the Middle New York has a smaller share of middle-income families than any other major metropolitan area in the nation, and like residents of most American cities and suburbs, they live in a dwindling number of middle-income neighborhoods, according to a new analysis of census figures. Argentina, the group winner on goal differential, will play Mexico in the second round. E1 OBITUARIES C16 Evelyn Dubrow Organized labor's most prominent lobbyist at the time of its greatest power in her four decades with the nation's largest apparel union, she was 95. COHEN--Albert. Loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend, will be missed by all who knew him. His charm and sense of humor will live on long after him. Services at East End Temple, 245 East 17 St, NY, NY, on Friday, June 23,11 AM.

MAZZARULLI--Pasquale V. (Pat), age 66 of Sante Fe, NM and Palm Desert, CA died June 20, 2006. He was born June 21, 1939 to Frank Mazzarulli and Rose Puma Mazzarulli in New York City. He married Marilyn Meola on June 18, 1983 in Rye, NY. Pat founded the oil brokerage company PVM Oil Associates in NY in 1971. PVM was dedicated to servicing the international crude oil and products trading markets and quickly gained a world wide reputation for market knowledge, integrity and extensive contacts. Through his leadership PVM expanded over the years to include offices in London, Vienna, Singapore (formerly Tokyo), and Houston in the U.S. PVM is now considered one of the world's largest independent over the counter brokers of oil instruments. After retiring from active brokerage in 1996, he remained active as a consultant advising a prestigious client base including senior oil company executives, national oil companies, government agencies and commodity exchanges. Pat leaves an extensive legacy as one of the original patriarchs of the oil trading business and will be forever revered for his business acumen, engaging demeanor and generosity to his countless proteges still active as oil brokers and traders. He is survived by his wife Marilyn Mazzarulli of Sante Fe, NM and Palm Desert, CA, sons Steven Mazzarulli of Ithaca, NY, Paul Mazzarulli of Wilton, CT; stepsons James Derrico of Monroe, CT, Edward Derrico of Long Beach, CA, Richard Derrico of Whitehouse Station, NJ; nine grandchildren, his twin sister Josephine Denicola of The Bronx, NY and his sister Rosalie Fontana of Lewiston, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: The Pat Mazzarulli Music Scholarship Fund, Cardinal Hayes High School, 650 Grand Concourse, Bronx, NY 10451. Tel: 718-292-6100. Make checks payable to: ''Cardinal Hayes High School'' and put ''Pat Mazzarulli Music Scholarship Fund'' in note section.

Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin apologized for accusing the Socialist Party leader of cowardice during an outburst in the National Assembly on Tuesday. ''If some words personally injured you, I regret them and I take them back,'' Mr. de Villepin told lawmakers during a question-and-answer session in the Assembly, as Fran√ßois Hollande, the Socialist leader, looked on. Mr. de Villepin added, ''You will understand, Mr. Hollande, that I have not been spared from personal attacks, from calumny and from lies.'' During Tuesday's session, Mr. Hollande accused the government of irresponsibility in its handling of the crisis involving the delay in deliveries of the newest super-jumbo plane by Airbus and possible insider trading by the French co-chief executive officer of its parent company, EADS, the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company. The accusation prompted Mr. de Villepin's angry outburst. ELAINE SCIOLINO (NYT)

An article on Saturday about a fire that killed four people at a Portuguese social club in Fall River, Mass., misspelled the surname of the owner of a nearby hair salon, who described the community's shock. She is Tina Rebelo, not Revelo.

8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) BILLYWILDER SPEAKS -- And boy, does he have a lot to say. In 1988, Wilder (right) -- director, writer and producer sublime -- agreed to be interviewed by a German film crew on the condition that his revelations not be disclosed until after his death. This 90-minute special, edited down from a longer television series, celebrates Wilder√ïs 100th birthday (he died in 2002) with snippets from films including ''Double Indemnity,'' ''Sabrina'' and ''Sunset Boulevard'' and nuggets about leading ladies like Audrey Hepburn, Gloria Swanson and Marilyn Monroe. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Lance Bass and Kathy Najimy try to fill in the blanks of questions posed by six celebrity panelists in ''Match Game,'' the latest installment in this competition series. Gene Rayburn was the host and Richard Dawson, Brett Somers and Charles Nelson Reilly the panelists in the 1970's, when the show, rife with double entendres and more than a hint of suggestiveness, became the most popular daytime program ever. This time around Adam Corolla, Adrianne Curry, George Foreman, Kathy Griffin, Bruce Vilanch and Betty White will provide the touch of raunch, with Ricki Lake overseeing the mayhem. 9 P.M. (13) A LION IN THE HOUSE -- Part 2 of this ''Independent Lens'' documentary, filmed over six years at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, looks at some of the obstacles facing five children with cancer and their families: the emotional and economic impact of experimental treatments, disparities among diagnoses and the difference between giving up and letting go. 9 P.M. (Sundance) HOUSE OF BOATENG -- Move over, Bravo. The Sundance Channel is posed to push ''Queer Eye'' and ''Project Runway'' off the catwalk with this new reality series following the British designer Ozwald Boateng (above), creative director of Givenchy, to America as he prepares to sink or swim. 9 P.M. (BBC America) WATERLOO ROAD -- What happens when the faculty at a troubled English high school is more out-of-control than the students? This series, that's what. In this new episode, a teacher announces she is pregnant, while another sets up a date with the principal. 11:35 (NBC) THE TONIGHT SHOW WITH JAY LENO -- Look, up in the sky! It's a bird! No, it's the plane flying in Kevin Spacey to promote his star turn in ''Superman Returns'' as Lex Luthor, a performance he says was inspired by Enron's deposed prince of darkness, Kenneth Lay. Taylor Hicks, who rose from Southern shlub to People magazine's hottest bachelor in the blink of an ''Idol,'' is the musical guest. 11:35 (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Shhh. Is that another Oscar nomination we hear in Meryl Streep's (right) future? Tonight she talks with Mr. Letterman about Vogue-ing for the camera in ''The Devil Wears Prada.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

An article on Tuesday about new research into the precise location of a World War I firefight in which Sgt. Alvin Cullum York captured 132 Germans misstated the make and model of the bolt-action rifle that historians say he used. It was an Enfield Model 1917, not a Lee-Enfield Model 17.

''I never know what to expect when I turn on one of my lights for the first time,'' said Christophe C√¥me, 41, a French artist who makes sculptural light fixtures out of massive pieces of industrial glass, some of which weigh more than 100 pounds. Often the tools used to cut the glass create striations, he said, or dust stirred up during the polishing and melting processes affects the opacity of the glass, changing the quality of the light. Mr. C√¥me, above, began by working in cast bronze but switched to iron and glass in 1995 after he became fascinated by their mutability. He has had an avid European following since the fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld showed Mr. C√¥me's lighting and his equally distinctive rusted iron furniture at the Lagerfeld Gallery in Paris last year. In mid-June his work attracted significant international attention at the Design Miami/Basel fair in Switzerland.

A report in the World Briefing column on Saturday about a French engineering project to remove centuries of silt from the waters around the Mont-St.-Michel abbey and restore its island character misstated its location. It is off the southwestern coast of Normandy, not the northwestern coast.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about plans by Nestl√©, the Swiss food giant, to acquire Jenny Craig, the weight-loss company, misidentified the maker of the candy bar KitKat. It is the Hershey Company, not Nestl√©.

Editors at The New England Journal of Medicine say they are investigating a letter about avian flu that its Chinese authors apparently tried to withdraw before publication. The letter, signed by eight Beijing scientists, reports that the country's first avian flu case appeared in 2003 -- two years before the Chinese government admitted having any cases -- and that it was misdiagnosed as SARS.

Busta Rhymes has been a hip-hop star since the mid-1990's, but until this week he has never reached No. 1 on the Billboard 200. His new album, ''The Big Bang'' (Aftermath/Interscope), below, sold 209,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving it a fairly easy ride to the top. The Dixie Chicks' ''Taking the Long Way'' (Columbia) held at No. 2 with 130,000 sales, and AFI's ''Decemberunderground'' (Interscope), last week's top seller, fell to No. 3 with 104,000. The hard rock band Three Days Grace reached No. 5 with ''One-X'' (Jive/Zomba), which sold 78,000 copies in its first week of release. Down the chart, the quirky hip-hop duo Gnarls Barkley has made a slow but steady rise since the release of ''St. Elsewhere'' (Atlantic) in May. Last week the album climbed three spots to No. 11; this week it holds there, with 63,000 sales. Andrea Bocelli's ''Amore'' (Decca) jumped 13 spots to No. 12, an rise that Billboard ascribed to Father's Day shopping. Taylor Hicks, the latest ''American Idol'' winner, has a No. 1 single. ''Do I Make You Proud'' sold 228,000 copies in its first week, including 38,000 downloads; it had little radio airplay, though its sales are enough to put it at the top of the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart, to be announced today, the magazine said. (The Hot 100 chart is compiled by a combination of sales and airplay, while the Billboard 200 album chart counts only sales.) BEN SISARIO

SINGER--Rabbi Philip Harris, 83. Our beacon of Torah was taken to illuminate the heavens on June 20th, 2006. He served the Avenue ''O'' Jewish Center, Brooklyn, NY for over 50 years. President Vaad Ha'rabonim of Flatbush, Executive Vice President Igud Ha'rabonim, Executive Chairman-Friends of Yeshivat Shaalvim. Re nowned orator of Yiddish radio. He is mourned by his beloved wife Celia, his children: Rena Bakst (Yitzchak), Karen Avrech (Robert), Naomi Weissler (Steven), David (Elana), eleven grandchildren and one great grandchild.

REILLY--Donald, 72, husband of Kathleen Collins Reilly, died from cancer on June 18, 2006, in Norwalk, CT. A prolific cartoonist and cover artist for ''The New Yorker'' since the early 1960's, Donald was also a contributor to publications as diverse as ''MAD'' magazine and ''The Harvard Business Review,'' among them ''Look,'' ''Colliers,'' ''Playboy,'' and ''The Saturday Review.'' As a teenager, Donald got his start at what would become a sideline for most of his life, playing jazz trumpet, trombone, and flugelhorn. Born November 11, 1933, in Scranton, PA, Donald grew up principally in Allentown, PA, and was the son of the late Helen and William F. Reilly. He graduated from Muhlenberg College in 1955 and from the Art School at Cooper Union in 1963. Donald's survivors, in addition to his wife, are his children, Patricia, Brian, and Michael, as well as Kathleen's children, Robert, John, and Maura Williams, and their spouses. Donald is also survived by his sister, Helene Fagan. His sister Jane Gallo predeceased him. Donald leaves eight grandchildren: Hanna, Liza, Michael, Henry, Maggie, John, Michael, and Daniel. Family and friends will meet on Saturday, June 24, at 4 PM at the Williams residence, 223 Chestnut Hill Road, Wilton, CT. For information: Harding Funeral Home in Westport, CT, Memorial contributions may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 4 Chase Metrotech Center, 7th Floor East, Lockbox 5193, Brooklyn, New York 11245.

Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the possibility that Citigroup might drop the red umbrella symbol it acquired with the Travelers Group, misstated the title of Ajay Banga, who leads the brand-management committee. He is head of Citigroup's international consumer business, not its consumer business over all. The column also omitted words from a quotation in a memo by the chief executive, Charles O. Prince, who expressed concern that Citigroup had not coordinated its approach to brand management, when he wrote, ''This clearly isn't a thoughtful approach to dealing with one of our most important assets.'' -- not ''our most important asset.''

Three years ago, Lo√Øc Bigot, 45, above, made what some would consider a questionable decision -- he gave up a practice in international law to indulge his passion for design, opening a product and furniture showroom called ToolsGalerie in the Marais district in Paris. His gamble paid off, though: The gallery is now widely known for discovering young talent, as well as commissioning work by established designers like Chris Kabel, whose Mesh Chair, above, was produced in a limited edition of 20 and sells for around $4,200. Mr. Kabel also designed the Platinum Money Vase, inset, made of platinized porcelain, which sells for about $1,000. ToolsGalerie is located at 119 rue Vieille du Temple, 011-33-1-42-77-35-80.

United States (0-1-1) vs. Ghana (1-1-0) Jere Longman breaks down a few matchups to watch in today's game. The U.S. must win in order to advance to the second round. 1) Claudio Reyna U.S. VS. Michael Essien GHANA One of the primary matchups could be in defensive midfield, where Claudio Reyna, the American captain, and Michael Essien of Ghana will both play. Pablo Mastroeni is out with a red card for the U.S. And John O'Brien has played little. Bruce Arena said O'Brien was not comfortable in the last week. He has suffered chronic groin, hamstring and Achilles tendon injuries, which apparently have flared up. O'Brien will likely play in Mastroeni's place, but it will be up to Reyna to organize the American midfield. Essien, who plays for Chelsea, can play attacking midfield or defensive midfield and is a fierce tackler. 2) U.S. VS. Ghana's Goalkeeper Brian McBride, Landon Donovan and perhaps Eddie Johnson against Richard Kingson, Ghana's goalkeeper. The United States has created no goals of its own in the first two games. Its only score came when Italy put the ball into its own net. The Americans have officially put only one shot on goal. They must win this game to advance, so the offense will have to come alive. 3) Red Card Replacements Eddie Pope is out with a red card in the central American defense. Perhaps Jimmy Conrad will replace him. Striker Asamoah Gyan is also out for Ghana with a red card, but the Ghanaians have potent scorers in forward Matthew Amoah and central midfielder Stephen Appiah.

Just off the Champs-√âlys√©es, design enthusiasts can lunch in a new restaurant designed by the French architect Jean-Michel Wilmotte in the 19th-century mansion he renovated in 2002 for Artcurial, an art-book publisher and auction house. Completed last month, the space is furnished with tables and chairs by Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, the French furniture designers, and oversize domed lamps by the German lighting designer Ingo Maurer. Visitors may also peruse the items for sale in Artcurial's viewing rooms -- 6,500 square feet of art, furniture, photography and jewelry. (Next Wednesday, many items will be black, as the auction house will hold a thematic auction -- the ''Black'' design sale.) Artcurial is at 7 Rond-Point des Champs-√âlys√©es, 011-33-1-42-99-20-20, artcurial.com.

University of Chicago Gets More Bellow Papers The University of Chicago has acquired the remaining professional papers of Saul Bellow, right, from his estate. ''The acquisition, which will be combined with the university's existing Bellow archive, is in accordance with Bellow's own wishes and brings his professional papers to one location,'' the university said in a statement. Bellow, a winner of the Nobel and Pulitzer prizes who died in 2005, was a member of the university's faculty for more than 30 years and the author of novels like ''Herzog,'' ''Humboldt's Gift'' and ''The Adventures of Augie March.'' Arctic Monkeys Bassist Quits Andy Nicholson, right, the Arctic Monkeys bassist who pulled out of that indie rock band's North American tour last month, has left the band for good, the BBC reported. ''We are sad to tell everyone that Andy is no longer with the band,'' said an announcement from the other three members on the band's Web site, www.arcticmonkeys.com. Mr. Nicholson's departure in May, days before the band was to start a 17-date tour of the United States and Canada, was attributed to ''fatigue following an intensive period of touring.'' Nick O'Malley, who will continue with the group for the rest of the summer, took his place. Farewell to Billy Preston Joe Cocker sang and Little Richard reminisced as hundreds of friends and relatives gathered in Inglewood, Calif., for the funeral of the prolific songwriter and keyboardist Billy Preston, sometimes known as the fifth Beatle, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Preston, who played with the Beatles, was 59 when he died on June 6. ''He made that piano walk and talk,'' said Little Richard, who discovered Mr. Preston, who was then in high school, took him on tour in the early 1960's and introduced him to the Beatles and the Rolling Stones. Mr. Cocker drew shouts and thunderous applause when he sang ''You Are So Beautiful,'' written by Mr. Preston. Mourners also heard letters written by Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton and others who toured and recorded with Mr. Preston. Literary Auction Sets Marks Records were toppled in Paris, where organizers said an auction of rare French manuscripts had taken in over $17.5 million, more than double the estimate, Agence France-Presse reported. Gathered over 80 years by Pierre Ber√®s, 93, the collection included a volume of 16th-century bird drawings by the painter Gourdelle, which fetched $1.76 million, a record for a book sold in France. The auction, at Drouot, also set a world record for a first edition of French literature when a first edition of Arthur Rimbaud's ''Season in Hell,'' dedicated to his lover and fellow poet Paul Verlaine, sold for $643,146. Six sections of a diary by Stendhal, the author of ''The Red and the Black'' and ''The Charterhouse of Parma,'' were to be auctioned, but the French government intervened, using its pre-emptive right and paying $1 million for the 570 pages. They will join 16,000 pages displayed at a museum dedicated to Stendhal. Rediscovered Schiele Landscape Brings Millions A monumental Egon Schiele painting, believed missing or destroyed for more than 60 years, has been sold at Christie's in London for $21.5 million, the BBC reported. The 1914 masterpiece, ''Wilted Sunflowers (Autumn Sun II),'' right, a homage to van Gogh's ''Sunflowers,'' surfaced last year when an anonymous collector sought appraisal. When the collector learned that the Nazis had confiscated the painting in 1938 from Karl Gr√ºnwald, an Austrian industrialist and antiques dealer, he asked Christie's to return it to the heirs, who put it up for auction. It had been expected to bring $7 million to $10.6 million. Jazz Honors Sonny Rollins, below, took top honors at the 10th annual Jazz Awards, The Associated Press reported, as he was named musician of the year and tenor saxophonist of the year. Mr. Rollins, 75, returned to the front ranks of jazz with his first live recording in nearly 20 years, the Grammy-winning ''Without a Song: The 9/11 Concert.'' In ceremonies at B. B. King's Blues Club on 42nd Street on Monday, more than 400 members of the Jazz Journalists Association worldwide gave top album honors to ''Thelonious Monk Quartet With John Coltrane at Carnegie Hall'' (Blue Note). Roy Haynes, 81, was given the award for lifetime achievement in jazz, and the conga player Ray Barretto, who died at 76 in February, was chosen percussionist of the year. Footnote Erica Cornejo, a soloist with American Ballet Theater, will join Boston Ballet as a principal dancer for the 2006-7 season. Ms. Cornejo is married to Carlos Molina, a Boston Ballet principal dancer.

LIGHTING designers are having fun with materials this season, although there are still pieces out there for the less bold. The newest hanging pendants and chandeliers come in familiar materials, like spun aluminum and glass, and more surprising ones, like wool felt, goose feathers and crystals dipped in rubber. This last example might sound outr√©, but unexpected combinations of materials are not new to Tobias Wong, the Brooklyn designer responsible for it; he also makes a bed cover in black bulletproof fabric. 1. The L-LX hanging pendant, designed by Jaime Salm of Philadelphia, is made of powder-coated spun aluminum. The two-piece fixture is 14 inches tall and 19 inches in diameter at the bottom of the ring. It takes bulbs of up to 120 watts. Because the cone-shaped pendant can be used with or without the bottom ring, and because both pieces come in a choice of white, black or silver, there are many color combinations available. The pendant alone is $139; with a ring it is $195. The ring alone is $64. From (215) 925-9359. 2. Delight is a hanging shade made of wool felt, aflutter with three-dimensional hand-cut butterflies. Designed by Nahoko Koyama, the British-made shade is 10 1/2 inches high and 9 inches in diameter. The fixture takes a compact 20-watt fluorescent bulb, the equivalent of a 75-watt incandescent one; it is $105 from 2jane.com or (813) 832-5263. 3. Tobias Wong has taken a 12-bulb crystal chandelier and dipped it in white industrial rubber to create a more modern fixture. The rubber can be peeled off when the owner wants a more traditional look. The 24-inch-high chandelier is $4,900 from citizen-citizen.com or (415) 695-7748. 4. Lyra, a lacquered aluminum shade, can be raised or lowered for overall illumination or more concentrated light; $19.99 at Ikea stores only, ikea.com or (877) 345-4532 for store locations and availability. A fixed, unmovable version is $9.99. 5. Pearl is a hand-blown glass fixture designed by Ragna Berlin, a Swedish designer working in New York. Each is slightly different, but all are about 18 inches high and 12 inches wide. The fixture takes up to a 100-watt bulb and is $1,100; for store locations, ameico.com or (888) 350-8765. 6. Veneziano is an opaline Murano glass chandelier with six arms. It is $5,400 at Ruby Beets, 25 Washington Street (Main Street), Sag Harbor, N.Y., or (631) 899-3275. The chandelier can also be ordered with 8 or 12 arms. 7. Pluma Cubic is a globe made of goose feathers, 35 inches in diameter. Designed and made by Heike Buchfelder in Germany, the large, whimsical fixture is $3,990 at mossonline.com or (866) 888-6677.

To the Editor: So much of New York City has been defined by the people who came here with hopes of making it. What will happen when the only people who can afford to come here are those who have already made it?

DUBROW--Evelyn (''Evy''). A passionate and beloved defender of workers' causes, died June 20, 2006 in Washington DC. The members and directors of the 21st Century ILGWU Heritage Fund are deeply saddened by Evy's passing. Evy Dubrow was the labor movement's most wellknown and tenacious lobbyist on Capital Hill for over sixty years. She was the Legislative Director and a Vice President of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union(ILGWU), and then of UNITE! She was a forceful voice for higher minimum wage, safer workplaces, universal health care, for civil rights, women's rights, children's rights and immigrants' rights, and against industrial homework and unfair trade laws. She was an inspiration and a mentor to generations of union activists. She truly embodied the values of the labor movement and ofthe ILGWU. Evy received numerous awards for her distinguished career, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1999. Jay Mazur, President, Ted Bernstein, Vice President, Irwin Solomon, Secretary of the 21st Century ILGWU Heritage Fund.

MOSHER--James W. Lawyer, 65 died May 31, 2006 in Manhattan. His practice was in the theater and music industry. Prior to forming his own firm, he had been a partner in Zissu, Stein, Bergman, Couture and Mosher. A memorial is planed for June 23, 2006 at the Princeton Club in New York, 15 West 43rd Street at 5PM. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to The ACLU. $(6$)MOSHER--James. The Board of Directors of 186 Riverside Corp. is saddened by the loss of our colleague and neighbor, James Mosher. Jim worked tirelessly with us and we will miss his good nature and wise counsel. We extend our deepest sympathies to his friends and family.

GLOBUS--Dr. Rudo, PhD, age 82, died on June 14, 2006. He is survived by his loving wife Marie & his devoted children Andrew, Daniel, Jennifer, Amy and Susan. He was a great inspiration to all who had the privilege to know him. He will live on in the hearts and memories of his patients, friends, and family. The Globus Family

The French design duo Catherine L√©vy, below left, and Sigol√®ne Pr√©bois -- better known as Ts√© & Ts√© -- have been creating poetic interpretations of everyday objects to international acclaim since they joined forces nearly 16 years ago. Now Mc & Co, a new store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, carries a selection of their work, including lighting and decorative objects. The Vase of the Seven Nights, below, a group of seven black glass vases of varying sizes and shapes, which sells for $195, ''allows you to create an arrangement of flowers as well as vases,'' Ms. L√©vy said. Mc & Co is at 57 North Sixth Street, (718) 388-3551.

The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida filed a federal lawsuit challenging a decision by the Miami-Dade School Board to remove a children's book about Cuba from its elementary school libraries. The board voted last week to ban the book, ''Vamos a Cuba,'' and its English version, ''A Visit to Cuba,'' after a parent objected to it, saying it contained misleading information about the island and painted a rosy picture of life there. But civil liberties union leaders called the ban a violation of the First Amendment, saying schools are responsible for providing students information with different viewpoints. TERRY AGUAYO (NYT)

Records were toppled in Paris,where organizers said an auction ofrare French manuscripts had takenin over $17.5 million, more than doublethe estimate, Agence France-Presse reported. Gathered over 80years by Pierre Ber√®s, 93, the collectionincluded a volume of 16th-centurybird drawings by the painterGourdelle, which fetched $1.76 million,a record for a book sold inFrance. The auction, at Drouot, alsoset a world record for a first editionof French literature when a first editionof Arthur Rimbaud's "Season inHell," dedicated to his lover and fellowpoet Paul Verlaine, sold for$643,146. Six sections of a diary byStendhal, the author of "The Red andthe Black" and "The Charterhouse ofParma," were to be auctioned, butthe French government intervened,using its pre-emptive right and paying$1 million for the 570 pages. They will join 16,000 pages displayed at amuseum dedicated to Stendhal.

''Vynil, an Alternative to Wallpaper'' is the debut collection of a Paris-based company called Domestic, formed last year by three friends: Christine Montard, 36, below left; St√©phane Arriuberg√©, 33, center; and Massimiliano Iorio, 36. The adhesive vinyl cutouts, which can be applied to windows and walls, were created by 19 artists and designers with experience in furniture, textile and graphic design. Hybrid Pink, below, four flowers and six stems by the French designers Antoine+Manuel, costs about $85 plus shipping. Pam, a geometric pattern by the French collective Trafik, sells for $35 at the MoMA Design Store (momastore.org), and the entire collection is available online at domestic.fr.

Two Web sites linked to Chechnya's separatists announced that Doku Umarov, a veteran commander from the republic's two wars with Russian federal forces, had replaced the movement's previous leader, Abdul Khalim Saidullayev, who was killed in a raid by Russian forces on Saturday. Mr. Umarov, 42, has been one of the most prominent commanders, accused by the Russians of a series of attacks and terrorist acts in and near the republic. He is a close ally of the movement's most notorious leader, Shamil Basayev. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

More than three years after it cast the votes setting the nation on the course to the war in Iraq, the Senate on Wednesday began the first extended debate on whether the time had come to end that war. With polls showing that Americans believe the war is going badly but are ambivalent about how to respond, both Democrats and Republicans worry about how it will affect elections in November. They staked out starkly different visions in the debate. Democrats insisted that the war had cost too much and that the United States must begin pulling troops out, while Republicans equated any withdrawal with retreat.

The nation's largest telephone company, AT&T, has revised its privacy policy for its television and Internet customers, clarifying that the personal information it collects is owned by the company and may be shared in response to court orders and other legal processes. ''While your account information may be personal to you, these records constitute business records that are owned by AT&T,'' the statement said. ''As such, AT&T may disclose such records to protect its legitimate business interests, safeguard others, or respond to legal process.''

KEEPING growing children geared up can be a pricey predicament, requiring parents to buy new athletic equipment frequently or to choose oversize items. Many customers buy the biggest bike possible for their child, hoping to eke out a second season, said Jon Minor, the bicycle products manager for Trek Bikes of Waterloo, Wis. ''But that can be dangerous and cause children to struggle getting on and off, or fall.'' To ease this quandary, Trek, like a handful other athletic companies, has developed products that grow with children. Though gear that easily expands is popular among pennywise parents, the equipment makes up a small part of the market, retailers say. ''The growth feature has been around for over five years, but unfortunately only a few manufacturers are utilizing it,'' said David Hill, the owner of Kid's Sportsworld, a 14-year-old sporting goods chain in St. Louis that caters exclusively to the 10-and-under crowd.

Lang Lang, meet Yo-Yo. IMG Artists, a major classical music management company, is in talks with the talent agency giant International Creative Management to acquire its classical music division, a person close to the negotiations said Wednesday.
Military prosecutors charged eight American servicemen with murder and other crimes in the death of an Iraqi civilian. Page A13.

CENTER--Thelma. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our long time member, Thelma Center. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Nina Koppelman, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

A film entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on June 2 about a Stanley Kubrick retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image, which continues through July 9, misstated the number of feature films Kubrick made. It is 13, not 12. (His first, ''Fear and Desire,'' has rarely been screened since its original release in 1953.)

Senate and House leaders have agreed to remove an addition to the Coast Guard spending bill that would have effectively killed a wind-power installation proposed for Nantucket Sound, south of Cape Cod. The provision would have given the governor ''of the adjacent state,'' Massachusetts, veto power over any such installation. The governor, Mitt Romney, a Republican, opposes the plan. The wind installation, proposed by Cape Wind Associates, a private concern, would occupy 24 square miles between Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket. It would have 130 turbines; each, with its blades, would rise 420 feet above the water. CORNELIA DEAN (NYT)

FINSTON--Beth Waters. Cooney/Waters Group mourns the loss of our cofounder, Beth Waters. Beth was remarkable for her intelligence, conviction and sheer force of will. She refused to believe there was a problem that could not be solved, never saw a challenge she declined to take on. She found paths through thorny dilemmas, hope in situations others sought to abandon. Highly demanding and great fun, as partner, colleague and friend, she will be deeply grieved and grievously missed. Lenore Cooney, Chairman $(6$)FINSTON--Beth Waters. Died June 19, 2006. Resident of Morristown, NJ. Widow of Mark Finston. Mother of Wendelyn Waters, M.D. and Rebecca Daley, grandmother of Aseema Daley, Lona and Lilah Sniderman and Paige Freund, mother-in-law of Erik Freund. Beth was born in Newark, New Jersey, and graduated from Syracuse University. A reporter for publications including the Philadelphia Bulletin, Boston Magazine and the Boston Herald in the early years of her career, Beth was a Senior Managing Director of Ogilvy Public Relations before cofounding Cooney/Waters Group, a health care public relations and public affairs company in New York City. Beth's passion was advocacy for vaccines to prevent and treat diseases in the industrialized world and in developing countries. She was indefatigable in her work, traveling the world to lend her intensity and expertise to her client sanofi pasteur, governmental committees and non-governmental organizations, advancing immunization against polio, HIV/ AIDS, avian influenza meningococcal disease. Beth was a wise counselor, a creative problem-solver, and a relentless optimist. She was a founding member of the advisory board of the Vaccine Education Center of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and a member of the HIV Vaccine Communications Steering Group of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 22 at 1 p.m. at Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, 973-422-0600. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Broadway Cares/ Equity Fights AIDS, Planned Parenthood USA or American Jewish World Service.

PONCZ--Ruth Herling, 87, Holocaust survivor, real estate entrepreneur, formerly of NYC, Resided in West Palm Beach. Feisty mother of Dr. Mortimer (Sarah) and Dr. Louis (Rita); loving grandmother of Dr. Ariella (Tal) Golomb, Elisa, LiXiang, Joel and Gabrielle. Predeceased by husband Elo and granddaughter Esther.

EPSTEIN--Barbara. The New York Review of Books mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague Barbara Epstein on June 16, from cancer. Barbara, co-founder and co-editor of The New York Review, was at her desk working on the paper, as she had for the past 43 years, as recently as two weeks ago. She was born Barbara Zimmerman in Boston, and educated at Radcliffe College. In 1952, Barbara championed the publication of The Diary of Anne Frank in the US. Before co-founding The New York Review, she was an editor at Partisan Review. Along with Jason Epstein, Robert Silvers, Robert Lowell, and Elizabeth Hardwick, Barbara founded The New York Review of Books during the long news blackout of the New York publishing strike in 1963. With Barbara and Robert Silvers as editors, this small group of friends created a new kind of magazine--one in which the most brilliant minds they could find would discuss current politics, books, art, and culture in depth. The first issue included pieces by Elizabeth Hardwick, Mary McCarthy, W.H. Auden, Robert Penn Warren, Norman Mailer, and Gore Vidal. Barbara Epstein, as coeditor of The New York Review, was equally fierce as a protector of the rights and causes she believed in and as a champion and mentor for younger writers. She worked long and tirelessly on articles that exposed injustice and that presented new talent to readers. She had a particular love for the arts, and that love infused much of the work published by the Review. Memorial donations in Barbara's name may be made to the following organizations that work on behalf of AIDS orphans in sub-Saharan Africa and a variety of justice, health, and human rights issues: CAFOD (www.cafod.org.uk), the Firelight Foundation (www.firelightfoundation.org), FXB USA (www.fxb.org), or Save Africa's Children (www.saveafricaschildren.com).

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about the election of Bishop Katharine Jefferts Schori of Nevada as presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church referred incorrectly in some copies to the name of the school where she received a master's of divinity. It is Church Divinity School of the Pacific, not the School of the Pacific.

''These agents were out just trying to do their jobs. They were trying to make arrests in a very controlled situation, and it just didn't come down as planned.'' MICHAEL FOLMAR of the F.B.I., on a shootout that left a federal agent dead at a prison in Florida. [A22]

Senator Arlen Specter, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said he would hold his own summer sessions on immigration policy. His move came after House Republicans said Tuesday that they would delay negotiations on immigration legislation pending a new round of hearings. Mr. Specter said his first hearing on July 5 would be held in Pennsylvania, the state he represents, and would explore the need for temporary guest workers in agriculture and other industries. ''I'm doing it to develop a broader, factual, evidentiary record on the need for the comprehensive bill, which is challenged by quite a number of House members,'' Mr. Specter said. CARL HULSE (NYT)

TAFT--Mary Jane, 76. On June 24 at 2:30PM, a memorial service honoring the life of Mary Jane Taft will take place at Dwight Hall Chapel, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut. Following the service there will be a reception in the Dwight Hall Library. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, memorials be sent to the Cherokee County Humane Society, P.O. Box 2299, Woodstock, GA 30188. For more information call 301-580-1481. Sosebee Funeral Home, Canton, GA

The Tamil Tiger rebels have told the Sri Lanka Monitoring Mission, set up to facilitate a 2002 cease-fire and comprised of members of the Nordic countries, that they want the 37 monitors from Denmark, Finland and Sweden excluded because those countries belong to the European Union, which last month listed the rebels as terrorists, a mission spokesman said. ''It's a blow to the peace process,'' said the spokesman, Thorfinnur Omarsson. A loss of the Danes, Finns and Swedes would leave the mission with just 20 monitors from Iceland and Norway as escalating violence moves Sri Lanka close to a full-scale war. SHIMALI SENANAYAKE (NYT)

BURLINGHAM--Adair M., 72. A Cambridge chef and writer, died Tuesday, June 13, of complications from Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP), a rare neurologicaldisease. Born in New Orleans, she graduated from the Baldwin School in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania and entered Radcliffe College at 16, graduating in 1954 with honors. As a young wife and mother in Massachusetts she taught second grade at Buckingham School in Cambridge, started a catering business in Chestnut Hill, drove a taxi and eventually became a chef at the Peasant Stock restaurant in Somerville, where she worked for 14 years, winning many culinary awards without ever following a recipe. She would rather cook for forty than for four, and always welcomed surprise dinner guests. She experimented with all foods and enjoyed everything (except lasagna) gnawable bones, sweet breads, okra, jambalaya, salad with poached eggs with Tabasco on all. She wrote poetry and short stories, hosted Shakespeare readings, studied Italian, Chinese and James Joyce, spent many summers at the Sewanee Writing Program in Tennessee and participated in various writing groups, including most recently her Food Writing Group. Upon retirement, she became a freelance grandmother, traveling in her Marimekko dresses to the homes of each of her eighteen newborn grandchildren as they appeared, where, according to one grandchild, she made ''the best bacon.'' She loved going to the movies with grandchildren, friends or even alone. She loved Bach, the Mendelssohn Octet, James Taylor, the Sunday New York Times crossword puzzle and family games of Scrabble. She was known for her funky clothes, her original turn of phrase, her amiable kookiness and her great heart. She bravely survived esophageal cancer, which is nearly always fatal, and for many years afterwards her surgeon would proudly introduce her to his Harvard Medical School classes as ''Exhibit A.'' Called ''Dearie'' by all who knew and loved her, she leaves her husband, Charles Burlingham, Jr of Cambridge, five daughters, Barbara (and John) McGrath of Windham, CT, Mary Meley of West Hartford, CT, Susan (and Doug) Frank of Kennebunk, ME, Eliza (and Michael) Anderson of Lincoln, MA and Alice (and Roger) Wille of Lake Park, FL; her stepdaughter and stepson Robin Burlingham (and Pan An-Yi) of Ithaca, NY and Nicholas (and Camille) Burlingham of Stonington, CT; and eighteen grandchildren: Michael, Mary Adair and Frances McGrath; Margaret and Elizabeth Meley; Sarah, David, Chloe and Louis Frank; Sam, Charlie, James and Ian Anderson; Heidi Thorpe; Julian and Aidan Pan; and Caroline and Colin Burlingham. Services will be held at Memorial Church in Harvard Yard, Cambridge on July 8, 2006 at 2:00 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Society for PSP at www.psp.org. Further information available at www.keefefuneralhome.com

The young man with an assault rifle, a convicted killer, stood beneath a statue in the central square of the Uzbek city of Andijon. He had been freed from prison in an armed raid the night before. It was May 13, 2005. The man, Daniyor Akbarov, addressed a growing crowd of unarmed civilians, telling them he was part of a group of 100 to 150 armed men that had already lost 20 or 30 members in a night of fighting. He said that they were trying to change Uzbekistan, one of the world's most repressive nations.
Well then you need a cool name. Like Pele, Garrincha, Zico, Falcao, Bebeto, Ronaldo or Ronaldinho. Or, well, Fred.

Those of you whose teams were eliminated, before you go away, we wonder if you could help us out with something. Also those of you whose teams are still in it, and everyone else too. Here's the thing.

Whether or not you consider a fireplace a desirable amenity, it doesn't do much good if it doesn't work. The two-floor apartment in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, rented by Eric Johnston and Claudia DeMairo has three non-working fireplaces, which consume valuable wall space. There was little they could do with the bedroom fireplace, so they put the dog bed there. Here's Claudia with Milo. -- JOYCE COHEN
George Vecsey looks ahead to the first game of the second-round matches: Germany-Sweden.

Diner's Journal is taking a diet, going on a break. Consider it a kind of anticipatory observance of our nation's imminent birthday. Call it a vacation. The latter would be more accurate. And it's a vacation that's not geared toward the consumption and contemplation of food, so bringing a laptop and filing dispatches seems ill-advised. It would also be a downer. Plus the laptop's sort of heavy and I'm trying to travel light.

So take a look at Revver, the greedy twin of YouTube. A video-sharing site, Revver is not a Montessori collectivized information-should-be-free venture. Instead, it's videos embedded with ads. If a video gets a lot of looks, the producer gets that ad money, but he has to split it with the Revver house. It all seems so easy. Revver seems very pro-artist, and its site even offers a course in online filmmaking that's quicker and more motivating than Robert McKee.

There is nothing like a huge premium to get Wall Street's attention. Anadarko Petroleum's announcement on Friday that it would buy two energy companies for a total of $21.1 billion -- at premiums of 40 percent, in the case of Kerr-McGee, and 49 percent, for Western Gas Resources -- sent shares of other energy-related companies soaring. Anadarko's offers seemed to confirm the notion that oil- and gas companies are sorely undervalued after a recent selloff in the sector. The perceived value gap will drive even more acquisitions, or so the theory goes.

Shares of Univision crept higher on Friday after Grupo Televisa and its fellow bidders -- or what remains of them -- submitted an offer for the Spanish-language broadcasting company. The takeover bid may have been tardy, missing Univision's supposedly final deadline of Tuesday by a long shot, but it was reportedly greater than the one previously lodged (pre-deadline) by a rival consortium including media entrepreneur Haim Saban. That earlier bid was said to value Univision at $11 billion.

For updates of Duncan Irving's live coverage of France-Togo from Cologne, hit the refresh button on your browser bar, or click "more."

The mere suggestion of a union between Microsoft and Yahoo -- a potential combination that has been reported upon, praised, derided, refuted and generally tossed around for months -- was enough to lift Yahoo's shares as much as 3 percent on Friday. The speculation resurfaced because of a research note from a Merrill Lynch analyst that said a "possible acquisition of Yahoo! would be a strategic positive" for Microsoft. Specifically, such a deal would help advance Microsoft's strategy on the Web, an area in which the software behemoth is something of an underdog.

JibJab Media, known for the jerky, animated political satires that probably landed in your e-mail inbox a few years back, has secured its first round of venture financing from Polaris Venture Partners, PaidContent.org reported Friday.

German politicians and labor leaders are not happy with the continuing efforts by Deutcshe Borse, the country's stock exchange in Frankfurt, to beat NYSE Group's offer for Euronext, The Economist reports. Most irksome for them is Deutsche Borse's proposal, outlined in its latest offer for the pan-European exchange, to abandon Frankfurt's Xetra automated trading system in favor of Euronext's NSC system.

Morgan Stanley said Friday that its board of directors has elected Charles E. Phillips Jr., president of Oracle, as its newest director. Mr. Phillips currently also serves on the boards of both Oracle and Viacom.
Has anyone else noticed that Dick Cheney appears to be coaching fractious Togo?
The first phase of the World Cup is finally complete. With Switzerland's 2-0 defeat of South Korea, the final slots were filled in the Round of 16.

The push to regulate hedge funds was dealt a major setback on Friday when a federal appeals court threw out a rule that forced thousands of United States-based funds to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The former 10-term California congressman and the only Democrat in President Bush's Cabinet is stepping down next month.
The much-anticipated Parallels, which lets you run Windows on any Intel-based Macintosh, has finally exited beta-land.

This much is known about the nascent bidding war for PCCW. Several bidders have entered the fray to snap up Hong Kong's largest fixed-phone-line company, and China Netcom, the company's second-largest shareholder, presents a formidable obstacle to any deal.
