Not unexpectedly, the joint scoop by The New York Times and The Los Angeles Times that "counterterrorism officials have gained access to financial records from a vast international database and examined banking transactions involving thousands of Americans and others in the United States," has become the buzz of the blogosphere.

Even as private equity firms continue to enjoy "heady times," the business is beset by a number of threats, The Economist suggests in its latest issue. There is "a growing sense among fund managers that the bountiful era is drawing to a close."
The Border Patrol Academy is striving to train enough cadets to fulfill the president's plan to add 6,000 agents by 2008's end.

Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group plans to sell a third of its investment banking and brokerage business to outside investors, a move that could be a prelude to an eventual separate stock listing for the broker-dealer affiliate, The Washington Post reported. Shares of Friedman Billings, whose other main business is investing in mortgage-backed securities, jumped more than 14 percent on Friday after the transaction was announced, giving the entire company a market capitalization of nearly $2 billion.

Despite the best efforts of apparent plant Zeljko Kalac in the Australian goal, Croatia of course came up short of the win they needed to advance yesterday. Nowhere was the loss felt more keenly than in the tiny Croatian enclave in Astoria, also known as Cafe Bar Scorpio, which was again packed with more than 200 hundred fanatic supporters of the Vatreni, living and dying with every touch of the ball. Here, in two phone-cam video clips, is a taste of both the joy and the pain that the World Cup is delivering in massive doses to real fans around the planet this month.
HealthTronics said on Friday it was selling a specialty vehicle unit to the Oshkosh Truck Corporation for $140 million.

Energy Partners said Friday it has finalized its offer to buy the Stone Energy Corporation for $1.4 billion to expand its exploration and production capacity in the Gulf of Mexico.

The 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver this week denied a request to withhold 220,000 pages of documents from shareholders in a civil securities fraud lawsuit against Qwest Communications International.

As the finance minister Thierry Breton of France met Thursday with the German co-chairman of EADS, Manfred Bischoff, the question of the future of No√´l Forgeard, the French co-chief executive of EADS, was left unanswered.

Trian Group, the activist investor team looking to shake up the board of H.J. Heinz, on Thursday filed a preliminary proxy with regulators calling for widespread cost cutting, an increased share buyback and a higher dividend payout.

The founder and former chief executive of Homestore, an online real estate listings company, was found guilty Thursday of insider trading, lying to company accountants and federal regulators, and conspiring in a scheme to defraud investors by inflating revenue.

Scientific-Atlanta and two executives paid Adelphia Communications $43 million disguised as marketing allowances in 2000 and 2001 to help the cable operator falsely meet Wall Street earnings expectations, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday.

Anadarko Petroleum on Friday unveiled a pair of multibillion-dollar deals, adding to what has already been a very active period for big mergers and acquisitions in the energy sector. The company said it had agreed to buy Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources in two separate all-cash transactions for a total of $21.1 billion in cash. It will also assume debt estimated at $2.2 billion.

One of the nation's most prominent hedge funds, Pequot Capital Management, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for possible insider trading, The New York Times reported Friday.
Yoshiaki Murakami, the fund manager whose clients included the governor of the Bank of Japan, Toshihiko Fukui, was indicted on Friday for insider trading, prosecutors said.
Parlux Fragrances has raised doubts about part of a takeover offer from its chairman and chief executive officer.

While Roman Abramovich buys yachts and Premiership football teams, his former partner and fellow Russian billionaire, Oleg Deripaska, is making a bid for something slightly less glamorous - the British van.

New York private equity firms Kelso and MSD Capital plan to invest $230 million or more in US Electrical Systems, a new acquisitions platform for electrical equipment distributors, reports The Daily Deal.
Paul Allen's real-estate company, Vulcan, has announced further expansion into South Lake Union's Cascade neighborhood with the purchase of a two-acre full block previously owned by Pemco Insurance.

Less than six months after emerging from bankruptcy, the diet supplements maker Atkins Nutritionals is on the auction block again and its owners have hired Blackstone Group to sell the company, according to The Daily Deal. Estimates say the company could fetch about $150 million.

Carlyle Group's NT$47.6 billion ($1.5 billion) offer to buy controlling stakes in Taiwan's Eastern Multimedia and affiliated cable networks has been halted by a government request for more information, a regulatory official said.
A software developer, Autotask, has landed $6 million in venture capital, the company announced Tuesday.
Americans are looking for all sorts of new ways to power their cars and trucks, from ethanol to biodiesel to hydrogen.

Solar energy company Nanosolar said Wednesday that it plans to build the world's largest solar cell factory in the Bay Area. The Palo Alto-based company said it raised more than $75 million in new funding, bringing its total cash raised to more than $100 million, including government funding.

Interested in reaching further out around the globe and sign another major partnership, LignUp, provider of enterprise voice over Internet protocol platform, closed a $9.8 million Series B funding round, VentureWire reported.
Info Edge India, the Indian company behind jobs site Naukri.com, may be the first venture-backed Internet start-up to go public on the Bombay Stock Exchange.

Techwell on Wednesday raised $21 million in an initial public offering hoping to cash in on soaring demand for high-definition television sets, surveillance cameras and video gadgets for cars. The company, only the sixth Silicon Valley company to go public this year, sold about 2.5 million shares under the symbol TWLL on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

PSA International priced a $1 billion bond offering Friday that effectively completes the $4.4 billion financing for the 20 percent acquisition of Hutchison Ports and pays down the outstanding $1.8 billion bridge loan.

As private equity companies eagerly await the return of optimal market conditions which would allow them to file an I.P.O. and secure the holy grail of money management, permanent capital, they will not be alone.

Bruce Wasserstein, the legendary Wall Street banker and head of Lazard, will soon be able to reclaim his name from Allianz, the German insurance giant that became the ultimate owner of the firm he founded with Joe Perella.
Keith Ince has been appointed executive vice chairman and acting head of asset management for Credit Suisse in Australia while the firm looks for a new person to head the division permanently.
Playboy Enterprises has headed deeper into hardcore adult entertainment with a deal to buy Club Jenna, a business founded by porn star Jenna Jameson, for an undisclosed sum.
A shoe trade entrepreneur based in southeast London is to bank about 135 million pounds ($246 million) in cash and shares after selling his business to the Iceland-listed Mosaic fashion group.

Shares of Six Flags dropped nearly a fifth of their value in after-hours trading Thursday after the theme-park company said that it was looking to shed six properties as part of its initiative to sell off non-core assets.
CDC Software, which is making a last-minute bid to buy Onyx Software, said it is "deeply troubled" by the fees that will go to Onyx's preferred suitor, M2M Holdings.

The Justice Department has cleared McClatchy to buy Knight Ridder, after McClatchy agreed to sign a guarantee that it will sell the St. Paul Pioneer Press, according to people familiar with the process.

Exelon and Public Service Enterprise Group have agreed to sell six power plants in Pennsylvania and New Jersey to complete Exelon's $16.6 billion takeover of the New Jersey utility, the Justice Department said Thursday in approving the deal.

The Russians have arrived. Gazprom, the world's biggest supplier of natural gas, on Friday entered the British gas supply market by snapping up a Leeds-based commercial gas business for an undisclosed sum.
The new hostess gowns can be worn beside the pool or curled up on the sofa with a tall drink. It's going to be a long summer.

Macquarie Bank, Australia's biggest securities firm, agreed to buy Stagecoach Group's London bus operation for 263.5 million pounds ($482 million) to expand in Britain. Stagecoach shares rose as much as 6.5 percent.

Houston Exploration, resisting Jana Partners' takeover pressure, said Thursday it will take its time evaluating the hedge fund's unsolicited buyout offer, despite Jana's signal that a prompt commitment to open its books could net shareholders a fatter dowry.

Shares of Baidu.com, China's most-used Internet search engine, fell as much as 6.8 percent after Google said it sold its 2.6 percent stake in the Beijing-based company to develop its own business in the nation.
Mittal Steel, the world's biggest steelmaker, said it is moving closer to an agreement with Arcelor on an unsolicited takeover offer last valued at 23.96 billion euros ($30.15 billion).
A group of investment firms is considering joining the bidding war for PCCW, Hong Kong's largest fixed-line company, according to The South China Morning Post.

Despite speculation that the new Lord & Taylor owners NRDC Equity Partners would convert the Manhattan flagship store into loft-style condominiums, the company said it would remain a department store after all. Furthermore, much of the entire chain is to be left in place, preserving, for now at least, one more venerable retail name in an industry that has a knack for erasing them.

A group of investors led by the Mexican entertainment giant Grupo Televisa inched closer late Thursday to bidding $11.2 billion for Univision Communications, the largest Spanish-language media company in the United States, according to the Los Angeles Times.

In the latest twist in the battle for Associated British Ports Holdings, the British ports operator said on Friday it had accepted a revised takeover bid from a consortium led by Goldman Sachs Group valuing the company at 2.8 billion pounds ($5.17 billion).

Bidding began late Thursday on eBay for the chance to break bread (or, more likely, a fat Porterhouse steak) with billionaire investing guru Warren Buffett. The highest offer, as of 7 a.m. E.D.T. on Friday was $455,100. (You can check for the latest bid here.) That was already well above the $351,100 that was last year's winning offer for what is being described as a "power lunch" with Mr. Buffett.

The reasons for the Americans' 2-1 loss to Ghana Thursday and their three-and-out elimination from the World Cup are obvious enough: an inability to attack creatively (witness the dozens of hopeful long balls hoofed uselessly right to the Ghanaian defense); a poor tactical set-up (a 4-5-1 when it had already been proven that the Americans cannot score with a lone striker); a lack of highly skilled players (the Yanks have no field player who comes close to matching Essien, Appiah, Rosicky, Nedved, Del Piero or Gattuso); and poor preparation that depended on excessive secrecy and that somehow left the players psychologically overwhelmed. The blame spreads around evenly among the players, the coach and the federation -- though it does seem as if the man most responsible for the missteps in preparation and tactics, Bruce Arena, bears the biggest share of that blame.

Kimi Raikkonen may or may not have signed a contract with Ferrari already, as that many-months-old rumor goes. But words he said during the press conference in Montreal today in preparation for Sunday's Canadian Grand Prix, certainly make it clearer than ever that he hasn't decided where he will drive next year.

LONDON, Friday, June 23 (Reuters) — A consortium led by Goldman Sachs has apparently beat out Macquarie Bank of Australia in an auction for Associated British Ports after raising its cash offer on Friday to £2.795 billion, or $5.14 billion.

Legislation that would impose stricter requirements on the use of eminent domain was approved yesterday by the General Assembly over objections from some Republicans that the bill did little to protect homeowners. Legislators have been under pressure to revise the state's redevelopment law since a United States Supreme Court ruling last June 23 that allowed local officials in Connecticut to take a residential neighborhood by eminent domain to turn over to a developer. A pastor has been charged with sexually assaulting an 11-year-old girl in his church, the police said. The pastor, Modesto Reyes, 52, was arrested Wednesday at his Hartford home and charged with four counts each of first-degree sexual assault, second-degree sexual assault and risk of injury to a minor, the police said. Mr. Reyes is accused of raping the girl, who became pregnant, several times inside Iglesia de Dios Cristo te Llama, where he is the pastor, the police said.

A 2-year-old Lindenwood girl died yesterday after her mother found her unconscious in a swimming pool at their house, the police said. The girl, Jolie Annecco, was briefly revived by doctors at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center before she was pronounced dead about 11:15 a.m., a hospital spokeswoman said. A neighbor on Whitelaw Street who is a retired firefighter also tried to save the girl, the police said.

A manager who stole credit card numbers from diners at a Connecticut restaurant was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 3 years and 10 months in prison. The defendant, Victor Kalaba, 41, of Yonkers, was also ordered to repay $200,000 to his victims. His brother Robert Kalaba, 39, whom prosecutors described as the leader of the credit card scheme, was sentenced to 5 years and 10 months in prison. The brothers pleaded guilty in February. Prosecutors said they used the credit card numbers to make counterfeit cards.

A 15-month-old North Brunswick boy was on life support after he fell into his family's pool yesterday, the police said. The boy, who was being watched by his grandmother, fell into the backyard pool shortly before 4:45 p.m. He was unconscious when he was lifted from the pool and was taken to Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, where he was listed in critical but stable condition.

A 25-year-old White Plains man was killed in a barbershop on Wednesday night when a gunman walked in and opened fire, hitting the man point blank in his chest and abdomen, the police said yesterday. The man, Coray Kidd, was shot while relaxing in a chair about 7:30 p.m. at Tha Basement barbershop at 100 West First Street. He had just gotten a haircut and was chatting with other customers, the police said.

A former member of Mensa, the organization for people with high I.Q.'s, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to one to three years in prison for welfare fraud, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Finkelstein, 58, of the Bronx, was convicted in February, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said evidence showed that Mr. Finkelstein forced a girlfriend, whom he had met through Mensa, to allow him to use her apartment address to improperly receive city housing benefits.

A kitten infected with rabies was found last week in a vacant lot near the southern end of Staten Island, the city health department said yesterday. It was the first rabid cat identified in the city since 2002 and is suspected to have contracted the disease from a rabid raccoon, two of which have been found in the same area in the last two months, officials said. The kitten, which was tested after its death, was one of three found in a diaper box on Seguine Avenue in Prince's Bay on June 11. Of the two other kittens, one died, presumably of rabies, but was not tested, and the other will be euthanized because it was exposed to the rabies virus, said Sara Markt, a department spokeswoman. A dozen people who had contact with the kittens were treated to prevent rabies; the health department is trying to identify anyone else who might have touched the cats. There has not been a human case of rabies in the city in more than 50 years.

A map dealer who catered to rich collectors admitted in federal court to having stolen 97 antique maps from universities and libraries.
Harry Kewell scored from close range to give Australia a 2-2 tie with Croatia and send the Aussies into the second round alongside the defending champion Brazil from Group F.

Members of Somalia's transitional government signed a series of accords with the Islamists who recently took over the capital, Mogadishu, in an attempt to ease tensions in the country. The two sides, meeting in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, agreed to recognize each other and work toward peace.

Villagers and rescue teams searched for survivors on Sulawesi Island, hit by floods and landslides, as the number of dead climbed to 178, officials said. More than 135 other people were missing, with many feared to have been swept out to sea. The flash floods and landslides were set off by incessant rain since Monday.

Pope Benedict XVI looked to his inner circle and picked Cardinal Tarcisio Bertone of Genoa, Italy, to be the Vatican's new secretary of state, in effect, the pope's prime minister. He is will replace another Italian, Cardinal Angelo Sodana, 78, whom John Paul II appointed to the post ‚Äî the second most important in the Vatican after the pope ‚Äî 15 years ago. Cardinal Bertone, 71, served as secretary of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith when it was led by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, now Pope Benedict XVI. The Vatican also announced that Cardinal Edmund Szoka, 78, who led the Archdiocese of Detroit from 1981 to 1990, was retiring as governor of Vatican City, a post he has held since 1997. He will be replaced by Archbishop Giovanni Lajolo, 71, the Vatican's foreign minister. No replacement for Archbishop Lajolo was announced.

President Xanana Gusm√£o, widely revered for his role in helping East Timor achieve independence from Indonesia, threatened to resign after Prime Minister Mari Alkatiri refused to step down, prompting thousands of protesters to spill into the streets as the country faced a deepening political crisis. Many East Timorese say Mr. Alkatiri's decision to fire 600 disgruntled soldiers in March was to blame for recent street battles and gang warfare that left at least 30 people dead.

NATO's chiefs flew into Cape Verde for the alliance's first exercises in Africa, a show of force involving 7,800 troops backed with fighter planes and a flotilla of warships. The operation is intended to test a new NATO response force, which the alliance is struggling to declare fully operational by October as the 25,000-strong spearhead of a modernized military pact focusing on managing threats and crises around the world.

Syria's foreign minister said the time was not right to open an embassy in Lebanon, despite recent Lebanese and United Nations pleas that Syria establish formal diplomatic ties and mark out a common border.

The United Nations Security Council recommended to the General Assembly that Montenegro be admitted as the 192nd member of the United Nations. The Assembly is expected to approve membership next week. Montenegro formally declared independence from its union with Serbia on June 3, after a referendum. Under the union's Constitution, Serbia inherited membership in the United Nations.
An Amtrak official told a State Senate committee that he couldn't explain why there had been four power failures in the past month on the Northeast rail corridor.

Ben Curtis shot a nine-under-par 62, a career best, in the first round of the Booz Allen Classic yesterday in Potomac, Md. He was one shot off the course record at T.P.C. at Avenel, which looked especially inviting after last week's brutal challenge in the United States Open at Winged Foot.

The Toronto Raptors named Maurizio Gherardini, general manager of the Italian club Benetton Treviso, as vice president and assistant general manager yesterday. The appointment of Gherardini is a strong indication that the Raptors may select Andrea Bargnani, a center for Benetton Treviso, with the No. 1 overall pick in Wednesday's N.B.A. draft.
Michael Jordan went to work for the Charlotte Bobcats yesterday, overseeing a predraft workout as part owner of the team.

Bill Elliott will stand by as a possible replacement for the driver Scott Riggs of Evernham Motorsports this weekend at Infineon Raceway in Statesville, N.C., after Riggs sustained cuts to both feet while unloading a jet ski in an oyster bed.

Three cities made the cut yesterday as the International Olympic Committee trimmed the field for the 2014 Winter Olympics. Salzburg, Austria; Pyeongchang, South Korea; and Sochi, Russia were selected as finalists by the I.O.C.'s executive board.

TRENTON, June 22 — Of all the questions surrounding Gov. Jon S. Corzine's $31 billion budget, one of the hardest to answer is this: Will the New Jersey State House be half empty or half full?.

A Democratic National Committee panel considering changes to the presidential primary calendar voted to allow two other states to join Iowa and New Hampshire in voting early in 2008. If the full national committee adopts the recommendation, one state will be allowed to hold a caucus between Iowa's caucus and the New Hampshire primary, and a second will hold a primary shortly after the New Hampshire contest. Ten states and the District of Columbia have applied to fill the two slots. The panel, the Rules and Bylaws Committee, will select the two states next month.

A federal courthouse in Chicago was locked down for more than three hours while the authorities searched for a man who was scheduled to appear in court but fled after he learned of a warrant for his arrest. The man, Larnell Rogers, 38, was caught later a few miles from the courthouse. Officers searched floor-by-floor but failed to find Mr. Rogers before reopening the building around 2 p.m. Mr. Rogers was accused of lying to federal agents about the shooting death of an informant.

Two small moons of Pluto, formerly known as S/2005 P1 and S/2005 P2, now have the names Hydra and Nix. In May 2005, astronomers discovered the two moons, each probably less than 100 miles wide, using the Hubble Space Telescope. In Greek mythology, Pluto is the god of the underworld, so the discoverers proposed as names for the moons Hydra, the serpent with nine heads, and Nyx, the goddess of darkness. The International Astronomical Union in Paris, which governs astronomical nomenclature, changed Nyx to Nix because an asteroid had already been named Nyx.
Douglas M. Duncan, left, the Montgomery County executive, said he pulled out of the Maryland governor's race because he was suffering from clinical depression.

Jurors in the corruption trial of former Gov. Donald Siegelman and three others said they were deadlocked, but the judge told them to keep trying to reach a verdict. On their sixth day of deliberations, jurors sent a note to Judge Mark Fuller of Federal District Court saying they could not reach a unanimous verdict in the 34-count case against Mr. Siegelman, Richard Scrushy, the former HealthSouth chief executive, and two former members of Mr. Siegelman's cabinet. Mr. Siegelman's lawyers asked Judge Fuller to declare a mistrial, but he declined. He gave jurors instructions designed to encourage them to reach agreement.

State Comptroller Carole Keeton Strayhorn and the author-musician Kinky Friedman were certified as independent candidates for governor by the Texas secretary of state. Ms. Strayhorn chose to run as an independent to avoid the expense of a challenge to Gov. Rick Perry, a fellow Republican whom she has sharply criticized and who is seeking a second four-year term. Mr. Friedman's only previous political campaign was in 1984, when he ran unsuccessfully for justice of the peace in Kerr County as a Republican. Former Representative Chris Bell of Houston is the Democratic nominee. A fifth candidate, James Werner, is running as a Libertarian.
A campaign for Svedka, a Swedish vodka, is serving as inspiration for a series of articles to appear online and in a book.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 22 — The prosecution's final witness in the court-martial of a cadet at the United States Coast Guard Academy accused him on Thursday of coercing her into performing sex acts out of fear he would reveal a secret she had told him.
The latest casualties came during military operations against insurgents across eastern and southern Afghanistan.
Demand for stocks fell as a report from the Conference Board showed that the Index of Leading Economic Indicators had slipped 0.6 percent in May.
The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel held informal and inconclusive talks on Thursday.
Thousands of acres of land in northern China are sinking because of the ravages of underground coal mining.
Gulf Coast communities that lost public libraries will get up to 22 bookmobiles or temporary library buildings under a grant from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
Someone set fire to seven American flags in a Brooklyn neighborhood yesterday, stoking outrage in a place where flags are displayed outside homes all year long.

NEWARK, June 22 — The claims were frightening, the plans ambitious and the response swift: a partial lockdown of four New Jersey prisons after guards discovered a letter written by an inmate prison officials say is a leader of the Bloods, a violent street gang.
Lawmakers voted to water down a draft law that could force Apple to make its iPod music player and iTunes online store compatible with rivals' offerings.

Andrew M. Cuomo, left, a leading Democratic candidate for state attorney general, was endorsed yesterday by the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the large police union. Patrick J. Lynch, the union's president, praised Mr. Cuomo as a candidate with a ''record of results.'' Mr. Lynch said Mr. Cuomo offered ''the integrity and the commitment to stand up for law enforcement.'' Mr. Cuomo, a housing secretary in the Clinton administration, is expected to face three other candidates in the Democratic primary. JONATHAN P. HICKS (NYT)

Communities along the Gulf Coast that lost public libraries in the hurricanes last year will get up to 22 bookmobiles or temporary library buildings under a $12.2 million grant from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation that was announced yesterday. In addition, up to eight libraries will receive $5 million for repairs and reconstruction from the Bush-Clinton Katrina Fund, which was founded by two former presidents, George Bush and Bill Clinton, to help the Gulf of Mexico region recover. The libraries will be chosen by the Americans for Libraries Council, a nonprofit group that is administering the rebuilding grant.

An article in Business Day on June 14 about plans by the oil company BP to spend $500 million over 10 years on biofuels research misstated the total amount committed to an energy research program at Stanford, whose contributors include Exxon Mobil. It was $225 million; $100 million was Exxon's contribution. The article also referred incorrectly to the scope of the research at Stanford. It includes a portfolio of technologies aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions; it is not limited to hydrogen fuel cells or trapping carbon emissions.

An article in Business Day on Monday about the new $50 gold coin, known as the American Buffalo, carried erroneous information from the United States Mint about the dealer markup for the coins. It is 5 percent to 7.5 percent, not 12 percent.

Tom was a stock analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, and loved calling New York home for the last 20 years. He is survived by his mother, Nena Bradham of Memphis, one sister and two brothers. The family requests any memorials be sent to : Adventa Hospice, 1355 Lynnfield Rd., Suite B187, Memphis, TN. 38119.

A $500 million deal by India's largest private airline, Jet Airways, to take over a rival, Air Sahara, appeared to fall through late Wednesday after the sale agreement expired, a victim of the country's inflated stock valuations. Jet Airways backed out of the deal after investors pounded its stock down by 40 percent since January over the price paid. The acquisition of Air Sahara, owned by the family-run Sahara Group, would have made Jet Airways the country's biggest airline, with more than half the market share in India. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

He will be greatly missed by wife Chanie, sons Dr. Eric and David and their wives Betsy and Kate; grandchildren Nina, Josh, Sofi and Corinne. Services Friday, June 23, 9:30AM,at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue corner 91 St. $(6$)GROSSMAN--William I., M.D. The New York Psychoanalytic Society and Institute mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Dr. William I. Grossman. One of our most distinguished members, a brilliant teacher, an internationally recognized scholar and theoretician in psychoanalysis, whose important contributions to psychoanalytic literature will endure. A valued member of our society and institute, he will be sorely missed. Our condolences to his wife, Chanie, sons Eric and David, and their families. Paul Rosenbaum, MD President Philip Herschenfeld, MD Dean

Kapalua Bay WHAT -- Oceanfront residential development adjoining a resort on one of Hawaii's most popular islands. WHERE -- Maui. AMENITIES -- Golf courses, a beach club and a full-service spa. PRICES -- Full-ownership residences start at $3.9 million; fractional-ownership properties from about $300,000. STATUS -- Expected to open by late 2008. DEVELOPERS -- Maui Land & Pineapple Company and the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company. CONTACT -- 800-281-9440 or www.ritzcarltonlife.com. DETAILS -- On Maui's western end, this 24-acre development surrounded by pineapple fields will fill the space held since 1978 by the Kapalua Bay Hotel, which is now being razed. Residential options include 84 full-ownership, three-bedroom properties, 28 of which will be bought by the Exclusive Resorts vacation club for its members' use, and 62 two- and three-bedroom Ritz-Carlton Club fractional-ownership properties sold in one-twelfth shares (fractional owners of the Ritz-Carlton Club properties can book 21 days a year in advance, with more time granted depending on availability). The development will adjoin the Ritz-Carlton, Kapalua resort, which features three golf courses and three beaches. A beach club, a pool and a restaurant with a bar will be built for the private use of club members and residence owners. Terranea Resort WHAT -- Hotel and residential development near Los Angeles. WHERE -- Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. AMENITIES -- Swimming pools, beach cabanas, a full-service spa and a golf academy. PRICES -- Two- to three-bedroom units start at about $2 million. STATUS -- Planned to open in winter 2008. DEVELOPER -- Lowe Destination Development. CONTACT -- 866-366-7474 or www.terranea.com. DETAILS -- This development will overlook the Pacific Ocean from bluffs at the tip of the Palos Verdes Peninsula, 30 miles south of downtown Los Angeles. It will include a 400-room hotel and 82 residences with 1,850 to 2,800 square feet of indoor space. Owners will be allowed to spend only 60 or 90 days a year, depending on the type of residence, at their properties, which will be part of a rental program. There will be three swimming pools, private cabanas on a secluded beach, restaurants and a 25,000-square-foot full-service spa and fitness center. The development will also feature a golf academy and trails along its bluffs. NICK KAYE Breaking Ground is a weekly look at projects, planned or under construction, that include weekend or vacation homes.

For the first time in more than a century, the government introduced legislation to raise the legal age of sexual consent, to 16 from 14. Under an exemption in the bill, youths 14 and 15 could continue to have a legal sexual partner who is up to five years older. ''Adults who sexually prey upon young people are the targets of these reforms, not consenting teenagers,'' the justice minister, Vic Toews, said. CHRISTOPHER MASON (NYT)

GRIBETZ--Alan, MD. We are grieved beyond words at the untimely death of Dr. Gribetz. He was not only a distinguished doctor, but a Mensch. He was an angel incarnate. Israel Friedman In the name of Bojaner Chassidim $(6$)GRIBETZ--Allen, M.D., the Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine of the Mount Sinai Medical Center notes with great sorrow the untimely death of Dr. Allen Gribetz. Dr. Gribetz was a skilled, compassionate physician who was a valued supporter of our teaching and patient care programs. He was the first Fellow to graduate from the modern Pulmonary Division Program and one of the best. His quiet excellence was a mark of the joy he experienced in his work and the love of his wife, Jessica, and their four daughters. We are all in mourning.

Soccer fans around the world are focused on the FIFA World Cup tournament in Germany this month. If history holds, merger and acquisition activity will take a back seat to the action on the field. But the winning country can look forward to an increase in deals after the final whistle blows.

Four American soldiers were killed and one was wounded in a battle with Taliban insurgents on Wednesday in the far northeastern region of Afghanistan, the American military said Thursday. The latest casualties came during military operations against insurgents across eastern and southern Afghanistan, and as the fugitive second in command of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahiri, called on Afghans to rise up against the foreign forces.

Legislation that would impose stricter requirements on the use of eminent domain was approved yesterday by the General Assembly over objections from some Republicans that the bill did little to protect homeowners. Legislators have been under pressure to revise the state's redevelopment law since a United States Supreme Court ruling last June 23 that allowed local officials in Connecticut to take a residential neighborhood by eminent domain to turn over to a developer. The Assembly bill narrows the criteria for declaring an area ''in need of redevelopment'' and requires more public hearings on development proposals and better notice to property owners. It also improves compensation for people who are forced to sell. A Senate committee plans hearings on the issue later this summer. LAURA MANSNERUS (NYT)

BECKER--Norma. Teacher, civil rights activist, and peace organizer, died June 17, aged 76. A founder of the Fifth Avenue Viet Nam Peace Parade Committee, which drew tens of thousands to protest the Viet Nam War, a founder of Mobilization for Survival , and Chair of the War Resisters League 1977--1983, she was crucial to the anti-war movement. The War Resisters League and the A.J. Muste Memorial Institute mourn her passing and condole with her family.

B1 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-6 Knicks Fire Larry Brown Larry Brown was cast as a savior when he came home to coach the Knicks last July. In the months that followed, he came to be viewed instead as an enigma, an agitator, a failure and, finally, a pariah. By the time the Knicks fired Brown -- just 331 days after hiring him -- the franchise's image had been transformed, too: from merely dysfunctional to comically inept. D1 U.S. Exits With a Whimper Stung by a borderline penalty kick awarded late in the first half, the United States exited from the World Cup with a 2-1 defeat to Ghana. Disputed officiating aside, the United States did not prove that it deserved to advance beyond group play. The familiar qualities of hard work and grit and determination were present, but the proficiency of soccer was deeply lacking. D1 OBITUARIES B7 Louis B. Sohn A professor of international law who helped draft parts of the United Nations Charter in 1945 and was a leader in subsequent efforts to turn the U.N. into a true world government, he was 92. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Hedge Fund Investigated One of the nation's most prominent hedge funds, Pequot Capital Management, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for possible insider trading, according to government officials who have been briefed on the case. A1 Lord & Taylor Stays on Fifth After fevered speculation that whoever bought Lord & Taylor would sell off its flagship Manhattan building, the new owners said that the Fifth Avenue store would continue to operate and that much of the chain would stay in place. C1 Merck Loses Drug Patent Merck's cholesterol-lowering drug, Zocor, loses its United States patent today -- a blow to both Merck and to Pfizer, whose rival drug, Lipitor, is the most popular cholesterol medicine. Now, insurers want to convince doctors that cheap clones of Zocor will make full-priced Lipitor a luxury. C1 House Curtails Estate Tax The House voted to permanently abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth for all but a sliver of the nation's wealthiest families. The vote sets the stage for a decisive vote in the Senate next week. To the Editor: Re ''American Muslim Clerics Seek a Modern Middle Ground'' (front page, June 18): Kudos for profiling two influential Muslim leaders who have a palpable influence in the mainstream American Muslim community. After reading frequent articles describing the hopeless endeavors of pariahs trying to effect change in the broader Islamic community, it's refreshing to read about people whose thought actually matters among the majority of Muslims in America. The truth is that those who will dictate the future of Islam in America and the world are those who speak within the tradition, admonishing Muslims to emulate the noble character of their prophet, not those who place themselves outside that tradition and show only contempt for the vast majority of Muslims. Bisher Tarabishy Brooklyn, Ohio, June 18, 2006 To the Editor: It is encouraging to read that there are American Muslim clerics seeking ways to mesh their faith with our society's modernity. But it is troubling that one of those clerics said that he hoped that America would become an Islamic country ruled by Islamic law. There is nothing wrong with wanting to spread understanding of Islam in America. The better we understand all religions, the better our pluralistic society will be. Religion flourishes in America because we have no imposed religion, as the founding fathers designed. Imam Zaid Shakir's hope for an America ruled by Islamic law is fundamentally un-American. Our hope is that he is an aberration and that moderate Muslim voices will prevail. Abraham H. Foxman National Director Anti-Defamation League New York, June 19, 2006 To the Editor: Imam Zaid Shakir's call for his fellow Muslims to mobilize to help those in need -- especially in war-torn Congo -- is laudable. But by asking, ''Where are the Muslim Doctors Without Borders?'' and urging people to ''form it,'' he unwittingly gives a false impression about the nature of Doctors Without Borders and the humanitarian action we practice. Humanitarian assistance is characterized precisely by the fact that it is provided solely on the basis of need, without a religious, political or economic agenda of any kind. In fact, this impartiality is crucial for our international and local aid workers, who come from a wide variety of backgrounds, in delivering medical aid to people in crisis around the world. Nicolas de Torrente Executive Director Doctors Without Borders New York, June 21, 2006

A front-page article on Tuesday about the growth and influence of the Jewish community and other religious faiths in Bentonville, Ark., because of the expansion of Wal-Mart's headquarters there, referred imprecisely to the name of one Christian denomination with several churches in the area. It is the Assemblies of God, not Assembly of God. The article also, misstated the location of the IHOP restaurant where free copies of the book ''The Truth About Mary Magdalene'' are available. It is in Rogers, Ark., not Bentonville.

GOTTLIEB - Blanche. The partners and staff of Labaton Sucharow & Rudoff LLP express their deepest sympathy to their partner, Louis Gottlieb, on the passing of his mother, Blanche, and we extend our sincerest condolences to his granddaughter and daughter-in-law. Labaton Sucharow & Rudoff LLP

For much of his career, Gonzalo Rubalcaba has been the quintessential Cuban piano monster, blessed (and sometimes cursed) with ferocious technique and the audacity to indulge it. But a noticeably gentler and more introspective tone has crept into his musical persona in recent years. Probably the most dramatic evidence of the shift is a pair of courtly albums by the bassist Charlie Haden -- ''Nocturne'' and ''Land of the Sun,'' both on Verve -- for which Mr. Rubalcaba, above, not only played piano but also wrote most of the arrangements. (For a handy contrast, put those albums in a CD changer alongside ''The Montr√©al Tapes,'' a Verve release that documents Mr. Rubalcaba's breakout performance with Mr. Haden in 1989, and ''Discovery: Live at Montreux,'' Mr. Rubalcaba's own Blue Note Records debut, recorded the following year with the same personnel.) Mr. Rubalcaba's recent Blue Note albums suggest that restraint has tempered his proficiency without clouding or diluting it. ''Paseo,'' released in 2004, is a tour de force of Afro-Cuban fusion remarkable for its unassuming self-assurance. ''Solo,'' issued earlier this year, might be an even more considerable accomplishment: it's Mr. Rubalcaba's first solo piano recording on a major label, and rather than staking a claim, he wisely casts a spell. The same sort of magic will most likely transpire during his solo performances at the Jazz Standard next Tuesday and Wednesday; for the rest of the week, he'll lead a promising trio with Matt Brewer on bass and Jeff (Tain) Watts on drums. (Tuesday through July 2 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, 212-576-2232; cover, $25; $30 next Friday and Saturday.) NATE CHINEN

DANIEL--Ruth, passed away on June 22, 2006, in Sarasota, Fl at age 83. Ruth was known for fierce determination and tenaciousness in all aspects of her life. Following Hitler's 1933 boycott of Jewish MDs, Dr. Bruno Feilchenfeld and his family made aliyah from Berlin to Tel-Aviv, then a Jewish outpost in British Palestine. Ruth's nursing experience with Jewish and Arab children imbued her with a lifetime commitment to enrich the lives of underprivileged children. Ruth, husband Gerry, and their 2 children immigrated to NYC in 1949, settling in Mamaroneck, NY. In the late 1950s, she played an important role at Gerard Daniel & Co., the premier importer and manufacturer of filtration wire mesh. In the early 1990's, Ruth and Gerry moved to Longboat Key, Florida and became active real estate developers in Manatee County, Fl. They also maintain a home in Chevy Chase, Md. Ruth was passionate about a number of causes and became Life President of the New Rochelle Day Nursery; active on the Bds of Family Services of Westchester, Chair of Jewish Conciliation Board of NY Jewish Federation, Treas & VP for the World Union for Progress Judaism and the Helen R. Payne Day Nursery Program in Sarasota, Fl. Ruth served on the boards of the Sarasota Jewish Federation, American Jewish Committee, Sarasota Jewish Housing Council, and the Tel-Aviv Museum of Art. Ruth maintained her love of Tel-Aviv, and with her husband of 65 years built the first Reform synagogue and community Center in Tel-Aviv, Beit Daniel in 1991. It operates 12 preschools throughout Tel-Aviv and Yaffa. Ruth & Gerry are now completing Mishkenot Daniel, a community center and youth hostel and in TelAviv Yafo, with Tel-Aviv City and Israel Youth Hostels Assoc. Ruth is survived by husband, Gerard, son Dr. Ralph Daniel, daughter Miriam Daniel, Esq.; brother Kurt Feilchenfeld, 4 grandsons,2 granddaughters, and 2 greatgranddaughters. Funeral services will be held at Adas Israel Congregation, 2850 Quebec St, NW, Washington,DC on Sunday, June 25, 2006 at 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to ''Children First'', 1723 N. Orange Ave, Sarasota, Fl. 34234, or ''Friends of Beit Daniel'', 4108 Leland Street, Chevy Chase, Md. 20815.

To the Editor: Concerning your Havens article on Pawling, N.Y. (''Billionaires Welcome, Helicopters and All,'' June 9): We live in North Salem, N.Y., a bucolic community just south of Pawling, so I found Debra West's exploration very illuminating. Our family moved there to enjoy our own little ''outdoor paradise'' and also a bit of peaceful solitude. Unfortunately, we appear to be in the flight path of some of the helicopters that the Pawling billionaires find necessary to commute to work. Although Beth Coursen, the Pawling town supervisor, says, ''We do a great job protecting all of our environmental features,'' the town should be aware that they allow their residents to pollute their neighbors' environment with a particularly noxious type of toxin -- noise pollution. Michael Gitlitz North Salem, N.Y.

The Senate on Thursday roundly rejected two Democratic proposals to begin pulling troops out of Iraq, as Republicans and Democrats staked out starkly different positions heading into Congressional elections this fall. The more far-reaching measure, calling for all United States combat troops to be withdrawn within a year, failed 86 to 13, with no Republican supporters.

Celebrities are, by definition, bigger than life, and that is how the commercial photographer Martin Schoeller portrays them in his king-size, extraordinarily lucid photographs. You would not call Mr. Schoeller's pictures flattering, at least not conventionally so. He borrows from the photorealist painter Chuck Close the close-up, mug-shot-like approach, which drains faces of expressive animation and turns them into awesome landscapes of bulges, folds, cracks, pits, craters and stubble. Unlike Mr. Close, whose subjects are usually people he knows personally, Mr. Schoeller portrays famous people like Brad Pitt, Angelina Jolie and Jack Nicholson. (His pictures frequently appear in The New Yorker.) There are some portraits of the nonfamous, including members of an African tribe and a United States soldier who sustained facial injuries in Iraq, but they are not irresistibly captivating the way the celebrity pictures are. There is something magically gripping about how these beings who exist in our collective imagination like pagan gods are so vividly, physically embodied, stripped of the protective veneer of publicity yet untainted by the salaciousness of the paparazzi shot. You can't help thinking, ''So that is what Mickey Rourke (or Donald H. Rumsfeld or Cindy Sherman) really looks like.'' Yet despite the remorselessly clinical scrutiny, they retain their superhuman auras, which may say as much about us as it does about them. If you have ever suspected the fabulous actor Christopher Walken (above) of being from another planet, Mr. Schoeller's eerie portrait clinches it. (Hasted Hunt, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, 212-627-0006; through Sept. 1.) KEN JOHNSON

The Navigator's Quarters Must Not be Disturbed Guild & Greyshkul 28 Wooster Street, SoHo Through July 1 In his New York gallery debut, Halsey Rodman joins a line of myth-prone, multimedia sculptors that reaches back, in recent memory at least, to Matthew Barney and the early work of the underappreciated Katie Schimert. Hallmarks include an inscrutable narrative and a mute, questing hero.

Painter of Modern Life, Part II: The Mature Years James Graham & Sons 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, Manhattan Through June 30 This second part of an exhibition of the paintings of Guy Pene du Bois (1884-1958) -- Part I, dealing with the first half of his career, appeared here in 2004 -- may be one part too many.

Petites Anatomies, Petites Images Ubu Gallery 416 East 59th Street, Manhattan Through July 28 Drawings, Photographs and Prints Miguel Abreu Gallery 36 Orchard Street, near Hester Street, Lower East Side Through July 2 Hans Bellmer (1902-75), the girl-crazed German Surrealist, is not exactly an unknown quantity, but these two exhibitions expand one's sense of him, if not always in nice ways. The Ubu exhibition takes you deep into Bellmer's working method in the late 1930's, when he was most involved with photography. Its 76 vintage prints and contact images, many exhibited for the first time, mostly feature Bellmer's signature female dolls, which he constructed so that their exaggerated limbs, torsos, heads and so forth could be detached and rearranged. Mixed with household items (a caned chair, bedspreads, pillows, a carpet beater), they appeared in the small books he produced in 1935 and 1949, hand-tipped onto the pages and often hand-colored.

Diner's Guide presents excerpts from recent restaurant reviews. Degustation Jewel Bako One of the many progeny of Jewel Bako, Degustation is actually contiguous to it, a 16-seat, U-shaped counter wrapping around an open kitchen. The intimate arrangement works, primarily because most of the modestly portioned dishes, which use Spanish new-wave flourishes and recall tapas, are terrific. Open since 2001, Jewel Bako itself still has an impressive array of sushi and sashimi, some of it very fine. But a crowded field of competitors has raised the sushi bar.

The United Nations Security Council recommended to the General Assembly that Montenegro be admitted as the 192nd member of the United Nations. The Assembly is expected to approve membership next week. Montenegro formally declared independence from its union with Serbia on June 3, after a referendum. Under the union's Constitution, Serbia inherited membership in the United Nations. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER (NYT)

Douglas M. Duncan, left, the Montgomery County executive, said he pulled out of the Maryland governor's race because he was suffering from clinical depression. ''It is the right decision for me, my family and for the Democratic Party,'' Mr. Duncan, 50, said. His withdrawal leaves Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore as the only major Democratic candidate seeking to unseat Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., a Republican, who is running for a second term. Polls showed that Mr. Duncan trailed Mr. O'Malley and Mr. Ehrlich. Mr. Duncan said that he was taking medication to treat his depression. GARY GATELY (NYT)

ANGLISANO--Suzanne (nee Fridman), born Paris, France, Oct. 21, 1932, died suddenly June 15, 2006. Loving mother of Allen, Laura (Noah), Felicia (Ken); proud grandmother of Craig, Phillip, Paul, Danielle, Doron, Simone and Alex; great-grandmother of Isahai; devoted sister of Charles and Barbara Fridman; loving aunt of Russell (Amy), Michele (Steve), Lara (Gavin); and great aunt. As a young child Suzanne survived the Holocaust and she continued to have a difficult life. We pray she has found peace.
To the Editor: Re ''Putting Millions Where Her Heart Is, in Schools'' (Public Lives, June 16):

''America's Got Talent'' got off to a strong start on Wednesday, giving NBC a victory for the night. The Simon Cowell-produced show, with Regis Philbin, above, as its host, drew 12.1 million viewers between 9 p.m. and 11. In the earlier prime-time hour, NBC broadcast a rerun of ''Dateline'' (6.4 million), which nearly dragged its overall ratings out of the No. 1 slot, as Fox finished a close second. Its competing talent show, ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' also from the ''American Idol'' family tree, brought in 8.9 million viewers and a strong sampling from the 18-to-49 demographic. On CBS, the ''Big Brother: All Stars'' casting special led off the night. Twenty former housemates from the ''No Exit''-like reality show's six previous seasons are competing for 12 slots in the new house; an audience of 6.1 million cared. KATE AURTHUR

PARIS does funny things to people. Imagine, for example, crawling off an airplane, making your way across the city with a bad case of jet lag and waking up the next day to find that you are the new owner of some stranger's apartment in the 17th Arrondissement. That would be where, exactly? And how much did it cost again?

The long lives that some former cannibals enjoy before succumbing to a brain-wasting disease suggest that many more humans will eventually die of mad cow disease, scientists said yesterday. But several experts in such illnesses, called prion diseases -- which are blamed for killing New Guinea cannibals and British eaters of infected beef -- disagreed with that frightening implication of the study, which is to be published today in The Lancet, a British medical journal.

MOSHER--James W. Lawyer, 65, died May 31, 2006 in Manhattan. His practice was in the theater and music industry. Prior to forming his own firm, he had been a partner in Zissu, Stein, Bergman, Couture and Mosher. A memorial is planned for June 23, 2006 at the Princeton Club in New York, 15 West 43rd Street at 5:00 PM. Memorial gifts in his name may be made to the ACLU.

HANSEN--William P. Born August 9, 1940 died on June 9, 2006. He was an editor and writer for American Heritage, Random House and Chelsea House. After graduating from University of Wisconsin he studied at NYU and started his literary career. His works covered a wide range of topics from drugs to shells, world leaders and even comic books. His reference works on American politics and history are tomes for the ages. His wit, incredible sense of humor, playfulness, curiosity and powerful mind were a gift to all who knew and worked with him. He will be missed forever by his wife Janet and his daughter Nadja who found in him the most patient and loving of soulmates.

Mr. Amargo is best known as a smoldering young Spanish flamenco star who has gazed out of movie screens and the covers of countless glossy magazines. But underneath that sexy, ebullient exterior lies the soul of an artist in love not only with dance but also with the theater. Those loves combine in Mr. Amargo's ''Poeta en Nueva York,'' an award-winning multimedia production inspired by the writing of Federico Garc√≠a Lorca, that will be presented tonight at City Center. Performed by Mr. Amargo's 30-member troupe of dancers and musicians, this ''flamenco musical,'' as he calls it, will also feature performances by guest stars who include the ballet wunderkind Rasta Thomas, recently in the Richard Move-Mikhail Baryshnikov production of ''The Show,'' and Spanish actors and actresses in filmed readings of the Garc√≠a Lorca poems. Described by El Pa√≠s, Spain's leading newspaper, as one of the most promising flamenco talents to have developed in years, Mr. Amargo, above performing ''Poeta,'' is greeted like a rock star in Europe. But New York has seen a lot of flamenco in recent years. What is different about this? ''It's not different, my company,'' he said. ''What's different is my feeling, my intuition about flamenco. People in Spain say it's eclectic. I like everything. But my power is my sexy flamenco feeling. My elegance. Sometimes flamenco is very savage.'' Mr. Amargo was trained in flamenco by Mariquilla and Maite Gal√°n. He was inspired to begin training and classical Spanish dance at the Royal Conservatory of Madrid at 9, after seeing Antonio Banderas in ''Carmen.'' ''I don't like dance for dance,'' he said. ''If I liked that, I would go to the street or my father's house. For me the story is important. Movement is dance.'' (City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, 212-581-1212 or www.nycitycenter.org.) JENNIFER DUNNING

To the Editor: Re ''No More Teachers, Lots of Books,'' by Sara Bennett and Nancy Kalish (Op-Ed, June 19): As a high school history teacher for nearly 35 years, I know that hard work, discipline and practice are keys to high achievement, whether in the arts, athletics or academics. A reasonable amount of summer homework keeps the mind sharp. There's a reason children are told that ''practice makes perfect'': a daily regimen of practice lays the foundation for a bravura performance, regardless of discipline. Writers write every day, and musicians practice every day. Michael Jordan was the first to arrive for basketball practice and the last to leave the gym. He didn't take the summer off. Marvin Pollock Brooklyn, June 20, 2006 The writer is director of studies at the Berkeley Carroll School. To the Editor: Even beyond the questionable practice of overloading kids with schoolwork on their vacations, Sara Bennett and Nancy Kalish claim that ''there's serious doubt about whether homework has any benefit at all.'' As a former high school English teacher, I would like to thank all those math, science, social studies and foreign-language teachers who canceled their homework, leaving my students time to read Shakespeare and Dickens and to write the occasional essay, personal narrative, story, poem and play. Based on my own eight years in the classroom, I see no way to teach reading and writing except by reading and writing, two rather time-consuming activities. With respect to homework and learning, as Lear says to Cordelia, ''Nothing will come of nothing.'' Craig Hanoch Highland Park, N.J., June 19, 2006 To the Editor: Though I agree with Sara Bennett and Nancy Kalish that an overload of homework is unnecessarily taxing to children, not all summer homework is evil. My daughter's middle school assigns summer homework so that the children can start right in discussing a novel on the first day of school rather than have to wait a week or two for them to read it after school starts. The provocative questions the kids were asked to consider over the summer were among the best assignments that my daughter has ever been given. So, a moderate, well-crafted summer assignment seems like a wise approach. Jennifer Prost Montclair, N.J., June 19, 2006 To the Editor: Sara Bennett and Nancy Kalish lament the ever-increasing barrage of summer schoolwork being assigned to children but do not mention what drives this trend. It is precisely the ''months of freedom stretching out ahead,'' an anachronism from the days when children were needed on farms. At no other time in their lives will Americans enjoy such long vacations. Indeed, as adults they will find their vacations among the shortest in the industrialized world. Ms. Bennett and Ms. Kalish question whether students' skills can be so fragile that they will slip without summer work. Who knows? But what has been proved definitively is that skills learned in school slip significantly during the summer break. And ask any athlete or musician what happens when he or she goes without practicing for three months. All of which points to an obvious answer: Shorten the summer break! Extend the winter and spring breaks, and make them all what children really need: weeks, not months, of unencumbered freedom. Suzy Maroon Washington, June 19, 2006 To the Editor: Kids are working hard over the summer whether they realize it or not -- perfecting the undervalued art of relaxation and cultivating an imagination that is desperately needed in our ever-changing world. Some homework is reasonable (I first encountered some of my favorite books as summer-reading homework), but the response assignments can wax to absurdity, and elementary school math packets still haunt my dreams. Moderation is essential and creativity even more so. Kids are inventive by nature: give them options and artistic liberty, and they will develop in ways that are vital to life, even if you can't measure them on the SAT. Julia Collins Stratford, Conn., June 19, 2006 To the Editor: I'm embarrassed to say there was a time we thought that homework was one of the most important parts of our two young sons' school day. Now that one is in middle school and the other is in high school, we realize just how wrong we were. It's so obvious to us today that this in fact was the part of the day they should have been having fun just being kids. We've been only lucky in that they've done well academically in spite of the amount of homework they had, and not because of it. It's all too sad. Ellen Schleifer Brooklyn, June 19, 2006 To the Editor: I would like to counter the argument against ''vacation homework.'' First, American students spend a relatively shorter time in the classroom than their global counterparts. Second, during the school year, students are involved in a myriad of extracurricular activities, limiting their opportunity for reading great works of literature. Finally, a comment that I frequently hear in the fall from my English students goes roughly like this: ''If you hadn't assigned 'Anna Karenina,' I would have never read it. And I loved it.'' Elizabeth P. Ueland Philadelphia, June 19, 2006

Pope Benedict XVI looked to his inner circle and picked Cardinal Tarcisio Bertone of Genoa, Italy, to be the Vatican's new secretary of state, in effect, the pope's prime minister. He is will replace another Italian, Cardinal Angelo Sodana, 78, whom John Paul II appointed to the post -- the second most important in the Vatican after the pope -- 15 years ago. Cardinal Bertone, 71, served as secretary of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith when it was led by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, now Pope Benedict XVI. The Vatican also announced that Cardinal Edmund Szoka, 78, who led the Archdiocese of Detroit from 1981 to 1990, was retiring as governor of Vatican City, a post he has held since 1997. He will be replaced by Archbishop Giovanni Lajolo, 71, the Vatican's foreign minister. No replacement for Archbishop Lajolo was announced. PETER KIEFER (NYT)

FEILER - LEHRMAN - Regina. Tel Aviv University and its American Council deeply mourns the passing of Regina Feiler-Lehrman, mother of Jack Feiler, member of the TAUAC Board of Directors. Our sincere condolences to Jack and his family. Prof. Itamar Rabinovich, President, TAU Robert M. Schrayer, National Chairman, TAUAC Sam Witkin, President, TAUAC $(6$)FEILER--Regina. Jack, your friends and colleagues at Palisade Capital are saddened by the passing of your loving mother, Regina Feiler. We had grown very fond of her over the years and always admired her strength and fortitude--a woman so full of life. It was a pleasure and a privilege to know her. We truly believe that all the love and affection showered upon her by you and your devoted family sustained her through these last trying years and made them more enjoyable despite her illness. She led an extraordinary life having survived the challenges of the Holocaust and will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. We extend our deepest sympathies to you and your family. Martin Berman, Steve Berman, and Dennison Veru

Tilton Gallery 8 East 76th Street, Manhattan Through June 30 Kustera Tilton Gallery 520 West 21st Street, Chelsea Through July 14 New art in China changes, if anything, faster than new art in New York. The scene is spread out over several cities. Stars pop up every two minutes. As in New York, a lot of the work is tasty but thin. The only possible way to keep track of it is through large gallery group shows like the 34-artist extravaganza titled ''Jiang Hu'' at two Tilton outlets.

WHO -- Tom Cucciniello, 48, from Paterson, N.J., owner of a linen service, shown with his wife, Margaret, 48, a stay-at-home mother WHAT -- 4-bedroom house WHERE -- Ferrisburg, Vt. My wife and I vacationed for many years in Westport, N.Y., on Lake Champlain. We grew to love the area but we never thought frontage on the Vermont side was in our price range. One day, a few years ago, we rode by this place. I could barely see the house, the property was so overgrown, but I did see the 400 feet of frontage on the lake. My wife told me I was crazy and to go sleep it off. I contacted the owner and it turns out he was ready to sell. I thought, ''When am I ever going to find this kind of frontage again?''

REILLY--Donald, 72, husband of Kathleen Collins Reilly, died from cancer on June 18, 2006, in Norwalk, CT. A prolific cartoonist and cover artist for ''The New Yorker'' since the early 1960's, Donald was also a contributor to publications as diverse as ''MAD'' magazine and ''The Harvard Business Review,'' among them ''Look,'' ''Colliers,'' ''Playboy,'' and ''The Saturday Review.'' As a teenager, Donald got his start at what would become a sideline for most of his life, playing jazz trumpet, trombone, and flugelhorn. Born November 11, 1933, in Scranton, PA, Donald grew up principally in Allentown, PA, and was the son of the late Helen and William F. Reilly. He graduated from Muhlenberg College in 1955 and from the Art School at Cooper Union in 1963. Donald's survivors, in addition to his wife, are his children, Patricia, Brian, and Michael, as well as Kathleen's children, Robert, John, and Maura Williams, and their spouses. Donald is also survived by his sister, Helene Fagan. His sister Jane Gallo predeceased him. Donald leaves eight grandchildren: Hanna, Liza, Michael, Henry, Maggie, John, Michael, and Daniel. Family and friends will meet on Saturday, June 24, at 4 PM at the Williams residence, 223 Chestnut Hill Road, Wilton, CT. For information: Harding Funeral Home in Westport, CT, Memorial contributions may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, 4 Chase Metrotech Center, 7th Floor East, Lockbox 5193, Brooklyn, New York 11245.
HIRSCH--Ruthe. June 23, 2004. Dearest Ruthe, beloved grandmother, mom, wife and sister. Forever in our hearts. Love, Your Family

BANKING DATA EXAMINED -- Under a secret Bush administration program begun weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, counterterrorism officials have gained access to financial records from a vast international database and examined banking transactions involving thousands of Americans and others in the United States, according to government and industry officials. [Page A1.] FUND INVESTIGATION -- One of the nation's most prominent hedge funds, Pequot Capital Management, is under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for possible insider trading, according to officials. The S.E.C. declined to confirm or deny that it was investigating Pequot. [A1.] BIAS SUIT RULING FAVORS WORKERS -- In a 9-to-0 ruling, the Supreme Court substantially enhanced legal protection against retaliation for employees who complain about discrimination or harassment on the job. [A22.] JUSTICES DROP PATENT CASE -- The Supreme Court backed away from ruling on a closely watched case that could have set boundaries on what discoveries and inventions can be patented. The court dismissed the case, which effectively upheld the medical diagnostic testing patent at issue. [C3.] ZOCOR PATENT -- Today, Merck's cholesterol-lowering drug Zocor loses its United States patent protection. The change will cost Merck billions of dollars a year, but it could be nearly as damaging to Pfizer, whose rival drug, Lipitor, is the world's most popular medicine. [C1.] LORD & TAYLOR DEAL -- A team of real estate and private equity investors said they would buy the 48-store Lord & Taylor department store chain from Federated Department Stores for $1.2 billion in cash. [C1.] NOVELL OUSTS OFFICERS -- The software company Novell ousted its chief executive, Jack L. Messman, and chief financial officer, Joseph S. Tibbetts Jr., in the latest effort to reverse lackluster performance and a sagging share price. Mr. Messman and Mr. Tibbetts led the company as it shifted its focus from networking software to the Linux operating system and related services. [C2.] INTEREST WORRIES DEPRESS STOCKS -- Stocks fell as investors bet that the Federal Reserve would keep raising interest rates even as economic growth shows signs of slowing. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 60.35 points to end at 11,019.11. [C9.] LEADING INDICATORS SLIP -- The Index of Leading Economic Indicators slipped 0.6 percent in May to 137.9, the Conference Board said, suggesting that the nation's economy is likely to cool in the coming months. [C9.] COAL'S COST -- A coal mining boom is devastating large swaths of north China, where some of the nation's richest coal deposits lie. [C1.] THE CLAUSE -- Tucked into the Coast Guard budget bill is language that would allow Nabors Industries, a big oil drilling company, access to offshore supply business open only to American companies. Nabors moved its tax headquarters to Bermuda and its legal headquarters to Barbados to avoid American taxes. [C1.] ESTATE TAX VOTE -- The House voted 269 to 156 to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth permanently for all but a sliver of the nation's wealthiest families. The action sets the stage for a decisive vote in the Senate next week. [C3.] OPTIMISM ABOUT A TRADE DEAL -- A month after he warned that the five-year negotiations for a global trade agreement were in the ''red zone,'' the head of the World Trade Organization, Pascal Lamy, left, said he had grown considerably more optimistic about the odds of a deal. [C4.] CHRYSLER MAY REVIVE DISCOUNTS -- The Chrysler Group said it was considering bringing back its employee discount program of last summer to clear out a backlog of cars and trucks on showroom lots. The program offers consumers the same deals that employees receive. [C3.] FED BANK PRESIDENT TO RETIRE -- Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, said that he would retire on Oct. 1. His decision creates a third vacancy on the Federal Open Market Committee, which sets interest rates. [C3.] AIRLINE PRICE-FIXING INQUIRY -- British and United States agencies are investigating a possible conspiracy to illegally fix the amounts of fuel surcharges imposed on passengers on long-distance flights to and from Britain. [C3.] UKRAINE MAY REVIEW GAS DEAL -- Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who is poised to return as Ukraine's prime minister, vowed to review a disputed deal with Russia on natural gas imports, setting the stage for a new confrontation that could disrupt her country's economy and threaten supplies of Russian gas to Europe. [A5.] SCRAMBLE FOR ASSETS -- The bidding war surrounding PCCW, Hong Kong's largest telecommunications company, is taking on a new twist. Everyone seems to want the major telecom assets of PCCW, though not the company itself. [C5.] LAYOFFS AT INSURER -- Allianz, the insurance giant, announced it would lay off 7,480 employees, about 4 percent of its worldwide work force, as part of an overhaul aimed at raising profitability. Almost all of the layoffs will be in Germany. [C5.] ONLINE THE HOME AUCTION -- As sellers seek more control in today's real estate market, they may decide to put their houses under the gavel. A report is at www.nytimes.com/realestate. MAKING A RUN FOR IT -- Over all, people who jog are less likely to have a heart attack over time than if they had not been joggers. A report by Jane Brody can be found at nytimes.com/health. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A daily report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.

The New York cityscapes in this enchanting exhibition date from 1947 to 1995.

CLARK--Hays. The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Hays Clark, our longtime Governor, friend, supporter and a true champion for children. Hays Clark was quite simply the greatest philanthropist in Boys & Girls Clubs of America's century-long history. He was a humanitarian without peer, a man of great vision and deep compassion. Hays expected nothing in return for his generosity, except results that would benefit the young people for whom he cared so deeply. Across four decades, Hays Clark had a profound impact on the Boys & Girls Club Movement, creating a powerful legacy that will last for generations. We are gratified that everyone who walks into our beautiful Hays & Ros Clark National Headquarters Building in Atlanta for many years to come will learn about Hays, a giant of a man whose like will not be seen again soon. A recipient of the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America for his passionate commitment to America's youth, Hays' contributions to our mission of service will never be forgotten. We will miss him greatly. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Anne Szostak, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President

Salander-O'Reilly 20 East 79th Street, Manhattan Through today It's summer-group-show time again. While temperatures are up and curators can play, galleries are making offbeat choices of artists and themes. Salander-O'Reilly jumps in early with ''Mid-Life Crisis,'' distinctive for uniting some of the city's better-known youngish talent with some of Mannerist Italy's lesser known (to nonspecialists at least) religious sculptors.

''Audiences now don't really know who the composer is,'' John Musto said. ''The composer is somebody who stands up in the audience for a bow at the end of a piece and gets pointed at. Or the person who gives you a preconcert lecture. And I've done that, and it's fine. But to have a composer as a musician onstage, saying, 'I made this piece, and this is how it goes,' and interact with an audience onstage -- that's what I wanted to do.'' Mr. Musto, 52, is being presented as exactly this kind of performing composer at this year's Caramoor festival, in Katonah, N.Y., where he is composer in residence for the 2005-6 season. The festival opens tomorrow with a concert that includes a piece by Mr. Musto: the overture to ''Pope Joan'' (1998), an unfinished project he calls ''the opera that never was.'' But the main event arrives on July 15: the world premiere of his Piano Concerto No. 1, with Mr. Musto himself as soloist.

GLOBUS--Dr. Rudo, PhD, age 82, died on June 14, 2006. He is survived by his loving wife Marie & his devoted children Andrew, Daniel, Jennifer, Amy and Susan. He was a great inspiration to all who had the privilege to know him. He will live on in the hearts and memories of his patients, friends, and family. The Globus Family

SMOKE--Esther, on June 19. An active cooperator, poet and a model of graceful aging whose love of Three Arrows Cooperative Society was reflected in her energy and interest in all aspects of our collective life. She will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathy goes to her family.

State Comptroller Carole Keeton Strayhorn and the author-musician Kinky Friedman were certified as independent candidates for governor by the Texas secretary of state. Ms. Strayhorn chose to run as an independent to avoid the expense of a challenge to Gov. Rick Perry, a fellow Republican whom she has sharply criticized and who is seeking a second four-year term. Mr. Friedman's only previous political campaign was in 1984, when he ran unsuccessfully for justice of the peace in Kerr County as a Republican. Former Representative Chris Bell of Houston is the Democratic nominee. A fifth candidate, James Werner, is running as a Libertarian. STEVE BARNES (NYT)

To the Editor: In ''The Golden Revolving Door'' (editorial, June 20), you say that the Department of Homeland Security has succeeded in ''creating a giant, expensive crop of government-trained consultants and lobbyists'' and that ''the worst effect of this kind of take-the-money-and-run mentality is on the people left behind.''

An information box with an article on June 9 about a driving tour along Interstate 90 in Wyoming and Montana gave an incorrect telephone number for the Buffalo Jump Steakhouse in Beulah, Wyo. It is 307-643-7173.

Protection for Workers In Discrimination Cases The Supreme Court substantially enhanced legal protection against retaliation for employees who complain about discrimination or harassment on the job. The 9-to-0 decision adopted a broadly worded and employee-friendly definition of the type of retaliation that is prohibited by the basic federal law against discrimination in employment. PAGE A22 Strategist Linked to Lobbyist A Senate report documented more than $5.3 million in payments to Ralph Reed, the former Christian Coalition director and a Republican Party strategist, from an influence-peddling operation run by the lobbyist Jack Abramoff. PAGE A22 Quest for Weapons in Iraq The United States government abandoned the search for unconventional weapons in Iraq long ago. But a collection of Americans, mostly on the political right, are still pushing for the search. PAGE A20 A Few Little Things in Albany Legislators took a break from bickering over issues like taxes and Medicaid by agreeing on a new official state insect: the pink spotted ladybug. They didn't stop there, also agreeing on an official state reptile and saltwater fish. PAGE B1 U.S. Soccer Team Leaves World Cup Empty-Handed Brian McBride (20), Oguchi Onyewu (22) and Clint Dempsey of the United States after a missed scoring opportunity against Ghana yesterday. The United States, needing a victory to advance to the second round, lost by 2-1. PAGE D1 A Deletion Error Pages of a government brief were electronically blacked out to protect what prosecutors said was sensitive material about an investigation into steroid use in baseball, but they can be viewed by using a word processing program. PAGE A18 Luck Be a Novel Tonight To the roster of musicians and magicians now appearing at casinos from Las Vegas to Connecticut, add your favorite author. PAGE A16 Map Dealer Admits Theft A prominent map dealer admitted to having stolen 97 antique maps worth more than $3 million from more than a half-dozen universities and libraries over the last seven and a half years. PAGE B1 Perforated Shells Offer Evidence of Early Adornment A 100,000-year-old shell, shown from four angles, from the Skhul rock shelter in Israel is among three found with holes for stringing that suggest that people wore jewelry 25,000 years earlier than had been thought. PAGE A6 Knicks Fire Larry Brown In a long-expected move, the team lets its coach go, and it may try to avoid paying the more than $40 million owed him. Isiah Thomas, the Knicks' president, will now also be the coach. SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D1
GRUDER--Scott. On your birthday. Love you and miss you. Love, Mother

A universal remote control lives up to its name in ''Click,'' the new movie directed by Frank Coraci. It stars Adam Sandler, right, Kate Beckinsale as his wife and Christopher Walken as a housewares salesman who understands that what today's harried white-collar family man really needs is to be able to hopscotch through time. Manohla Dargis's review, Page 12.

An article on Wednesday about the challenges Bishop Katharine Jefferts Schori faces in leading the Episcopal Church referred incorrectly to the ordination of women within the Anglican communion and a picture caption misstated the distinction she holds. Thirteen, not most, of the 38 provinces of the communion do not ordain women as priests. Bishop Jefferts Schori is the first woman to be elected as the church's presiding bishop, not as its first bishop.

COLE--Mark Allen. Died Sunday, June 18, 2006. Mark was a licensed Real Estate Broker in Connecticut and New York, for 25 years with Vincent and Whittemore of Bedford Village, NY.
