Details of the week's free performances and exhibitions can be found at jacobspillow.org. Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, 358 George Carter Road, Becket, Mass., (413) 243-0745. (Rockwell) STEPHEN KOPLOWITZ (Today through Sunday) ''Revealed'' seeks to alter perspectives of place, site and scale with the aid of 10 dancers and the optical device known as the camera obscura. At noon, World Financial Center, 220 Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505 or worldfinancialcenter.com; free. (Anderson) * LA MAMA MOVES! (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) This ambitious festival includes four different programs this weekend, in two of La MaMa's honeycombed little theaters. ''Children of Ur'' (tonight) features work by nine individuals and groups, among them Karinne Keithley, David Neumann and Nicky Paraiso. ''Duets'' (tomorrow) showcases dance by five duos, and ''Dancing Divas'' (Sunday) lives up to its name with work by Pat Catterson, Ellen Fisher, Keely Garfield, Sally Gross, Deborah Jowitt, Jodi Melnick, Yvonne Meier and Vicky Shick. And ''Mavericks in Motion'' (Thursday) features dance by Jonah Bokaer, Monica Bill Barnes and Tami Stronach. Tonight at 10, tomorrow and Sunday at 5:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710; $10. (Dunning) MICHELA MARINO-LERMAN (Tonight and tomorrow night) Ms. Marino-Lerman, a 19-year-old ''Sesame Street'' alumna, and her company will examine existence, public life and education in tap dance. At 8, Dixon Place, 258 Bowery, between Houston and Prince Streets, Lower East Side, (212) 219-0736 or dixonplace.org; $12 or T.D.F.; $10 for students and 65+. (Dunning) * THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET (Tonight through Sunday) The closing weekend of the company's spring season, ending on Sunday afternoon with an all-Balanchine program of ''Symphony in C'' and ''Vienna Waltzes.'' All the programs will be conducted by Andrea Quinn, the departing music director. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, tomorrow at 2 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570 or nycballet.org; $30 to $86; student rush tickets at $12. (Rockwell) * NOCHE FLAMENCA WITH SOLEDAD BARRIO (Tonight through Sunday; Wednesday and Thursday) Ms. Barrio is a remarkable dancer, serious and impassioned, and the hit of this winter's Flamenco Gala at City Center. Her Spanish company, founded with her husband, Martin Santangelo, has settled into the intimate Theater 80 for this month and next, through July 30. Tonight and tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8; tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m.; Sunday at 5 p.m.; Theater 80, 80 St. Mark's Place, East Village, (212) 352-3101 or theatermania.com; $45. (Rockwell) OF MOVING COLORS (Tonight and tomorrow night) The company, based in Baton Rouge, La., will perform dances by Pavel Zustiak, Ashleigh Leite, Nick Erickson and the company director, Garland Goodwin Wilson. At 8, Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 279-4200 or dnadance.org; $17. (Dunning) OUT OF SPACE @ BRICSTUDIO (Tonight and tomorrow night) This occasional series, organized by Marya Wethers, is presented in collaboration with Danspace Project, which suggests a talent-scouting expedition might be in order. The new works on the program are by Ke√Øty Anjoure, Faye Driscoll, Will Rawls and Tamar-kali. At 8:30, BRICstudio, 57 Rockwell Place, second Floor, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 855-7882; $12; $10 for students. (Sulcas) * PASCAL RIOULT DANCE THEATER (Tonight through Sunday) Mr. Rioult, a former Martha Graham dancer, tends to give his larger-than-life themes and dances a Grahamesque heroism, this time in a program that includes ''If by Chance,'' a world premiere set to a score by Jacques Loussier, a French jazz composer, that reworks Mozart's Concerto No. 23. Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or joyce.org; $38. (Dunning) SITELINES 2006: DOUGLAS DUNN AND ELKE RINDFLEISCH (Today and Monday through Thursday) This free avant-garde arts festival, also produced by River to River, features Mr. Dunn and Ms. Rindfleisch in paired pieces. At 12:30 p.m., Elevated Acres, 55 Water Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 219-9401. (Dunning) Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Museums * American Folk Art Museum: 'WHITE ON WHITE (AND A LITTLE GRAY),' through Sept. 17. The importance of neo-Classicism to early American architecture, silver and fine furniture is not exactly news. This small, beautiful show follows its spread into more personal corners of visual culture: often exquisite, strikingly dimensional white-work bedcovers; luminously grisaille, sometimes wacky marble-dust drawings; and print-work embroidery mourning pictures. 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040. (Roberta Smith) * BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'SYMPHONIC POEM: THE ART OF AMINAH BRENDA LYNN ROBINSON,' through Aug. 13. This prodigious show, by an artist born and still living in Columbus, Ohio, celebrates her heritage in paintings, drawings, sculpture, stitchery, leather work and less classifiable forms of expression. Besides its sheer visual wizardry, using materials like leaves, twigs, bark, buttons and cast-off clothes, her art is compelling in that it ruminates on the history of black migration to and settlement in the United States, from early times to the present, in a garrulous, very personal way. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000. (Grace Glueck) COOPER-HEWITT NATIONAL DESIGN MUSEUM: 'FREDERIC CHURCH, WINSLOW HOMER AND THOMAS MORAN: TOURISM AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through Oct. 22. It turns out that the Cooper-Hewitt owns thousands of rarely seen paintings, prints and sketches by Church, Homer and Moran. Studies of the countryside, mostly, they revere unspoiled nature and record tourism, a booming industry in 19th-century America. Here they're combined with antique postcards, old Baedekers, stereoscopic photographs, playing cards with pictures of Yellowstone on them and souvenir platters, all to trace the nation's transformation from primeval wilderness to Catskills resort. The show is extremely entertaining. 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400. (Michael Kimmelman) * FRICK COLLECTION: 'VERONESE'S ALLEGORIES: VIRTUE, LOVE AND EXPLORATION IN RENAISSANCE VENICE,' through July 16. Paolo Veronese (1528-88), a superb colorist and one of the most suavely sensuous of Renaissance Venetian painters, used the age-old device of allegory to make abstract concepts visual, often by means of human or mythological figures. In this five-painting show, the first to include all of his large-scale allegories from American collections, high ideals mingle with earthy and sometimes erotic physicality, as in the painting ''Venus and Mars United by Love.'' 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700. (Glueck) SOLOMON R. GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'ZAHA HADID: THIRTY YEARS IN ARCHITECTURE,' through Oct. 25. This exhibition, Ms. Hadid's first major retrospective in the United States, gives New Yorkers a chance to see what they've been missing. The show, in the Guggenheim's rotunda, spirals through Ms. Hadid's career, from her early enchantment with Soviet Constructivism to the sensuous and fluid cityscapes of her more recent commissions. It illuminates her capacity for bridging different worlds: traditional perspective drawing and slick computer-generated imagery; the era of utopian manifestos and the ambiguous values of the information age. (212) 423-3500. (Nicolai Ouroussoff) * International Center of Photography: 'UNKNOWN WEEGEE,' through Aug. 27. From the 1930's through the 50's, Weegee -- real name, Arthur Fellig (1899-1968) -- was one of the best known news photographers in the country. He specialized in capturing the sensational side of urban life: crime, disaster, demimonde nightlife. Tirelessly invasive, he lived by night. For him, the city was a 24-hour emergency room, an amphetamine drip. This show of 95 pictures gives a good sense of his range and calls particular attention to his awareness of social problems related to class and race. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000. (Holland Cotter) * METropolitan museum of art: 'GIRODET: ROMANTIC REBEL,' through Aug. 27. Hugely famous in the early 19th century, Girodet dropped down the memory chute. His ''Ossian Receiving the Ghosts of French Heroes,'' painted for Napoleon, is one of the most deranged pictures in art history. It's so unhinged that it's almost lovable, which is otherwise the last word to come to mind for an artist who, in his uptight, smarty-pants mode, could be a bore. But give the show a shot. It's sometimes brilliant, and Girodet's strangeness and fairly repellent character make him at least fascinating to contemplate and heroic in his immoderation. (212) 535-7710.(Kimmelman) * Met: 'Treasures of Sacred Maya Kings,' through Sept. 10. ''Treasures of Sacred Maya Kings'' gets a huge gold A for truth in advertising. The treasures are plentiful, rare and splendid. A carved wood figure of kneeling shaman, arms extended, time-raked face entranced, is simply one of the greatest sculptures in the museum. And wait till you see the painted ceramic vessel known as the ''Dazzler Vase,'' with its red and green patterns like jade on fire, you'll understand its name. Much of the work has never traveled before; many objects have only recently come to light in Mexico, Guatemala and Honduras. They add up to an exhibition as a think-piece essay on how a culture saw itself in the world. (212) 535-7710. (Cotter) * Morgan Library and Museum: 'Masterworks from the Morgan,' through Sept. 10. Almost three years after closing to build an expansion, the Morgan is back and brilliant. What's new: Renzo Piano's splendid four-story glass-and-steel court, a sort of giant solarium with see-through elevators; two good-size second-floor galleries; and a neat little strongbox of an enclosure, called the Cube, for reliquaries and altar vessels, medieval objects made with so much silver and gold that they seem to give off heat. What's not new: almost everything in this exhibition, which fills every gallery with mini-exhibitions of master drawings and musical manuscripts, as well as illuminated gospels, devotional sculptures and historical and literary autograph manuscripts from the Bront√´s to Bob Dylan. 225 Madison Avenue, at East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 or www.themorgan.org. (Individual show closings can be checked by telephone or through the Web site.) (Cotter) Museum of Arts AND Design: 'THE EAMES LOUNGE CHAIR: AN ICON OF MODERN DESIGN,' through Sept. 3 Celebrating the 50th anniversary of a chair whose combination of declarative modernist structure and sheer creature comfort was both innovative and a bit alien, this exhibition is a successful design object in its own right. It pays homage with drawings, advertising ephemera, precursors, vintage television clips, a wonderful documentary and three versions of the chair itself, enshrined, exploded and useable. 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535. (Smith) MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: 'DADA,' through Sept. 11 This is pretty much Dada's official survey (an oxymoron), and it makes nearly all 450 or so objects in it look elegant. That hat rack looks awfully stylish now. It's good to be reacquainted with a generation of artists who had no market to speak of and for whom society's corruption and exhaustion seemed a golden opportunity to make themselves useful. Cynical and traumatized, the Dadaists were tireless young optimists at heart. They discovered a world full of wonders, and we are, on the whole, their beneficiaries. (212) 708-9400. (Kimmelman) New York Public Library: 'FRENCH BOOK ART/LIVRES D'ARTISTES: ARTISTS AND POETS IN DIALOGUE,' through Aug. 18. Organized with the Biblioth√®que Litt√©raire Jacques Doucet in Paris, this lavish exhibition surveys some of the experimental ferment brought on by the combination of free verse, visionary publishers and the high rate of talent among French artists and poets, especially in the early years of the 20th century. New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089. (Smith) NOGUCHI MUSEUM: 'BEST OF FRIENDS: BUCKMINSTER FULLER AND ISAMU NOGUCHI,' through Oct. 15. Great, lasting friendships are rare, but friendships that enlarge the spirit through ideas, ideals and new insights are in a class by themselves. Over a stretch of more than 50 years the sculptor Isamu Noguchi and the visionary designer R. Buckminster Fuller enjoyed such a friendship, which led to aesthetic and practical achievements that left their mark. The course of their varied collaborations is traced in this exhibition, which includes models, sculptures, drawings, photographs and films. 9-01 33rd Road, between Vernon Boulevard and 10th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 204-7088. (Glueck) * The Studio Museum In harlem: 'Energy/Experimentation: Black Artists and Abstraction, 1964-1980,' through July 2. During one of the most radical periods in 20th-century American politics, the Black Power era, a group of African-American artists was working in one of the most radical forms of 20th-century art: abstraction. This show is stylishly installed. (One gallery bursts with color, another has a cool platinum shimmer.) The 15 artists are intensely individualistic and part of an important history. 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500. (Cotter) Galleries: Uptown * WANGECHI MUTU: EXHUMING GLUTTONY: A LOVER'S REQUIEM In tandem with this artist's Chelsea debut, an over-the-top installation made with the British architect David Adjaye includes fur-trimmed wine bottles dripping wine, animal skins and an enormous raw wood table. Conflating morgue, tannery and banquet hall, it brings the excess and color of paintings on Mylar into real space, but its main message seems to be: I built this because I can. Salon 94, 12 East 94th Street, (646) 672-9212, through July 7. (Smith) Galleries: SoHo Philippe Decrauzat: 'Plate 28' A conceptually perplexing but visually striking installation by a young Swiss artist includes a black and white grid painted on the walls; a sculpture based on a Russian Constructivist design, and a grainy, flickering black-and-white film showing glimpses of ominous landscapes from ''The Twilight Zone.'' Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, at Broome Street, (212) 925-2035, through July 15. (Ken Johnson) Galleries: Chelsea * 'An Ongoing Low-Grade Mystery' Organized by the curator Bob Nickas, this excellent group show includes works in many different mediums and styles, related in that they are all predominantly red. Donald Judd, Sherrie Levine, Jim Drain, Wolfgang Tillmans and Dan Walsh are among more than 30 artists included. Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105, through June 23. (Johnson) Jackie Gendel: 'Portraits' With seemingly off-hand painterly verve, smudgy colors and a sweet sense of humor, Ms. Gendel creates smart and sensuous, semi-abstract riffs on Modernist portraiture. Jeff Bailey, 511 West 25th Street, (212) 989-0156, through July 1. (Johnson) * NEW VIDEO, NEW EUROPE A selection of 49 tapes by 40 artists from 16 Eastern European countries, several of which did not exist before the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1989, presents bits and pieces of another world. Revolution, landmines, economic hardship and disappearing ways of life alternate with wit and artistic originality. The whole forms an inadvertent documentary, but many of the parts are well worth attention. The Kitchen, 512 East 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, through June 30. (Smith) Last Chance * 'Artists Against the State: Perestroika Revisited' Satiric and subversive Pop and Conceptualist works by more than 50 artists working in the Soviet Union during the years leading up to the end of Communism. Ronald Feldman, 31 Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 226-3232, closes tomorrow. (Johnson) * Loretta Lux By means of subtle digital manipulations, Ms. Lux turns color photographs of children in empty rooms into hallucinatory portraits of angelic beings with slightly oversized heads; big, soulful eyes; and beautiful clothes. Yossi Milo, 525 West 25th Street, (212) 414-0370, closes tomorrow. (Johnson) * 'The Rest is Silence: James Lee Byars' New York only really started to wake up to James Lee Byars (1932-1997) when he died. This three-gallery survey has some early work but focuses on the large-scale sculptures of his later years. It is tempting to fit him into existing slots: performance art, Minimalism, Conceptualism, whatever. But his extravagance and his privacy combine to keep him outside the fold, as do his philosophical concerns: Big Ideas, or rather Big Questions, about perfection, death and eternity. Perry Rubenstein Gallery, 526 West 24th Street, (212) 627-8000; 534 West 24th Street and 527 West 23rd Street; Mary Boone Gallery, 541 West 24th Street and 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 752-2929); Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623. All close tomorrow.(Cotter)

An article on Tuesday about a deal to provide direct weekend train service from New York to Atlantic City misstated the cost of a one-way bus ticket for the same route. Greyhound and Academy, two bus lines that serve that route, charge about $25 one way, not about $30. (The round-trip fare is about $30.)

9 P.M. (13) BILL MOYERS ON FAITH AND REASON -- In a world where religion is poison to some and salvation to others, how do we live together? In this new seven-part series, Mr. Moyers poses this question to writers from around the world, starting tonight with Salman Rushdie (above) and continuing with Margaret Atwood, Mary Gordon, David Grossman, Anne Provoost and Richard Rodriguez, and examines whether the vision of religious tolerance is merely a utopian dream. 8 P.M. (Disney) LEROY AND STITCH -- In this direct-to-DVD animated sequel to ''Lilo and Stitch,'' Lilo gathers her friends from a galaxy far, far away to battle the dastardly Dr. Hamsterviel and Stitch's evil alien twin, Leroy. Dr. Jumba Jookiba's 625 ''experiments '' (Stich is No. 626) join in the fun. 8 P.M. (Flix) JULES AND JIM (1962). It's Paris in 1900 and Catherine (Jeanne Moreau) has just fallen in love with Jules (Oskar Werner), whose friend Jim (Henri Serre) loves her too. Now it's Germany after World War I, and Catherine decides she loves Jim in this charmingly circuitous romantic drama by Francois Truffaut. And no one seems to mind. 9 P.M. (CMT) GREATEST MOMENTS -- What becomes a legend most? In this episode, it's Johnny Cash, the highlights of whose life are counted down from Folsom Prison and the Grand Ole Opry to strumming the heartstrings with his wife June Carter Cash (above). 9 P.M. (Style) MODERN GIRL'S GUIDE TO LIFE -- The Modern Girls -- Jane Buckingham, Eva La Rue, Claudia Jordan and Jess Zaino -- explain how to fake it like a pro, but not necessarily where you're thinking. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR -- Just in time for the return of black to fashion prominence, Stacy London and Clinton Kelly sober up the wardrobe of Katie M., a New Yorker operating under the mistaken belief that brightly colored clothes complement her vibrant character. 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) STAND UP NATION WITH GREG GIRALDO -- Lewis Black, Carlos Mencia, Steve Byrne and Jimmy Carr prove just how funny they actually are in comedy routines, in case there were questions. 10 P.M. (CMT) UNSUNG STORIES -- When their marriage fell apart, Millard and Linda Fuller (left) rebuilt their family from the ground up. But the couple didn't stop at their own doorstep, helping instead underprivileged families around the country who needed homes of their own by creating Habitat for Humanity. In this new episode, the songwriters Jamie O'Neal, Tim Nichols and Shaye Smith tell the story of the couple whose organization has put roofs over the heads of thousands in their anthem ''Look What Love Built.'' KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Members of Somalia's transitional government signed a series of accords with the Islamists who recently took over the capital, Mogadishu, in an attempt to ease tensions in the country. The two sides, meeting in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, agreed to recognize each other and work toward peace. ''The parties have committed themselves to cease all verbal provocation and all military action,'' the secretary general of the Arab League, Amr Moussa, said at the signing ceremony, in the presence of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, The Associated Press reported. Somali's foreign minister, Abdullahi Sheikh Ismail, and Mohammed Ali Ibrahim, the delegation leader for the Islamists, embraced after the signing. MARC LACEY (NYT)

PARIS does funny things to people. Imagine, for example, crawling off an airplane, making your way across the city with a bad case of jet lag and waking up the next day to find that you are the new owner of some stranger's apartment in the 17th Arrondissement. That would be where, exactly? And how much did it cost again?

To the Editor: Re ''The End of Innocence'' (Op-Ed, June 16): David R. Dow seems to miss his information's most important implication. If his shocking figures are accurate that 6 to 8 out of every 100 people receiving capital verdicts are innocent, then the system is clearly setting too low a standard for reasonable doubt. Jurors must be more effectively taught the difference between the most reasonable assumption -- as much of the evidence provided allows -- and beyond a reasonable doubt; judges must also be more willing to interpose with directed verdicts, if a jury's verdict tangibly defies the standard. Only then will the number of wrong capital verdicts descend from the present horror of nearly one tenth to a percentage more normal for human margin of error. The legal system and profession can do great good with serious and expedient effort on this matter. (Rabbi) Bruce L. Cohen Bronx, June 16, 2006 To the Editor: David R. Dow says his opposition to the death penalty does not focus on the likelihood that some innocent people will be executed. But for many death penalty opponents this is a primary argument, and I would like to respond to it. Not executing murderers results in these murderers serving prison sentences, where some of them will assault, rape or kill other prisoners or guards. Some of these murderers will escape or be released and then assault, rape or kill people on the outside. We don't know the names of these would-be victims whom we save by executing murderers, but it is likely that they far outnumber the innocent people that we execute. David Schwinger Staten Island, June 16, 2006
ROSENBLATT--Melinda Lande. Of blessed memory 10 years without you. Forever in our hearts and thoughts. Mom ,Jane, Andre, Lief, Bob,Floozie

FEASTS for the eye sit inside the vaults of the newly rebuilt Morgan Library and Museum, which houses a vast collection of musical manuscripts and early printed editions. Now the library wants to lay out a banquet for the ear. Plans are shaky, like a newborn thoroughbred taking its first steps. But the library has disclosed a rich menu of performances for next season. And they will take place in its new Gilder Lehrman Hall, New York's latest small concert space.

An obituary on Wednesday about Charles H. Older, the judge at the trial of Charles Manson and his followers, misstated their original sentences. They were sentenced to death, not life in prison. (Their sentences were commuted in February 1972 when the death penalty was declared unconstitutional in California.)

This is moving day at the world bridge championships. The Open, Women's, Senior and Imp Pairs have entered their final stages. The Senior Pairs ends on Friday, the other three events on Saturday. Yesterday the World Computer-Bridge Championship concluded with an emphatic victory by Jack, from the Netherlands.

The United States was not one of the eight teams seeded in the first round of the World Cup, something that folks like Bruce Arena apparently never quite got over. Those silly FIFA rankings aside, it appears that the formula that took into account the pitiful U.S. performance in France in 1998 could again rear its ugly head four years hence when (if?) the U.S. qualifies for the 2010 World Cup in South Africa.

The BBC has posted an intriguing article about the expected surge in power demands in the U.K. on Sunday, when so many households will tune in to the England-Ecuador game. Only in Britain, however, can electricity-supply issues be expressed in terms of "halftime cuppas" and the "equivalent of 800,000 kettles being switched on."
Aaron Spelling created a number of hit series, from the vintage "Charlie's Angels" to "Beverly Hills 90210."
The Bloomberg administration's push to create more charter schools, a plan that was strongly backed by the governor, fell short.
The police yesterday identified a body that was found in a garbage bag on Thursday morning as that of a 16-year-old Brooklyn girl who was reported missing on Monday.
Joe Girardi brought his young and surprising Marlins to Yankee Stadium and lost his first game to his mentor, Joe Torre, with a sloppy performance by the Marlins, who nevertheless were tenacious.

David Wright broke open the game with a three-run homer in the third, and Xavier Nady and Paul Lo Duca added run-scoring hits as the Mets defeated the Blue Jays for their ninth consecutive road victory, a franchise record.
The two 100-meter champions at the United States track and field championships, Marion Jones and Justin Gatlin, trotted happily off the track, awash in cheers.
By The Associated Press.
Workers have found the body of a miner, one of 65 sealed underground since a methane gas explosion in northern Coahuila State in February.

Vittorio Emanuele, the 69-year-old son of Italy's last king, left his jail cell in the southern city of Potenza for house arrest after spending a week behind bars. Investigators say he had contacts with the Mafia and was involved in procuring prostitutes for clients of a casino in Campione d'Italia, an Italian enclave in Switzerland. He was expected to stay with his wife at their residence in Rome.
President Xanana Gusm√£o appeared to withdraw a threat to resign, but the prime minister, Mari Alkatiri, was reported to be about to quit.

Prime Minister Kazimierz Marcinkiewicz accepted the resignation of his finance minister, Zyta Gilowska, after a prosecutor asked a court to investigate whether she had covered up ties to the Communist-era secret police. Though past collaboration does not bring penalties for office holders, lying on so-called vetting statements meant to disclose any past cooperation requires a 10-year ban on any public service. Ms. Gilowska denied ever having lied. Ms. Gilowska, a liberal, was seen as a guarantor of fiscal responsibility in Mr. Marcinkiewicz's government, a coalition of social conservatives with two small Euro-skeptic parties.

Harriet, a Gal√°pagos land tortoise that held the Guinness World Record as the world's oldest living animal in captivity, died at Australia Zoo in southeast Queensland at the age of 176. DNA testing vouched for both her age and her birth in the Gal√°pagos Islands. Mistaken for a male tortoise and called Harry for more than a century, she produced no offspring.

Turkey's top court indefinitely suspended the corruption trial of former Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz on technical grounds, a move that amounts to the case being dropped. He immediately signaled that he would return to politics, telling fans outside the courthouse,

Kurt Busch took his first road course pole, turning a lap of 93.055 miles an hour at the Infineon Raceway in Sonoma, Calif. Busch, who has now qualified among the top six in five of six trips to Infineon Raceway, goes into Sunday's Dodge/Save Mart 350 in 12th place in the standings. Jamie McMurray grabbed the other front row position with a run of 92.948, followed by Kevin Harvick at 92.889, Ryan Newman at 92.812 and Boris Said at 92.663.

The Carolina Hurricanes have agreed to terms with veteran captain Rod Brind'Amour for a new five-year contract worth $18 million, keeping him with the franchise he led to the Stanley Cup. Oxygen devices recovered from the Darby Mine accident in Kentucky were not used to their full capacity, just as at the Sago Mine accident in West Virginia that killed 12 miners. Government documents, filed in a Washington court this week, show that oxygen-producing chemicals remained in the air packs used at the Kentucky mine, where five people were killed May 20. The same type of packs were used in both mines. Three of five miners killed at the Darby accident died of carbon monoxide poisoning, according to preliminary tests. Officials have said the miners were wearing their oxygen units. The Mine Safety and Health Administration maintains in the documents that the air packs

President Bush declared that the federal government could seize private property only for a public use like a hospital or a road. The president signed an executive order in response to a Supreme Court decision granting local governments broad power to bulldoze people's homes to make way for private development. It was the one-year anniversary of the Supreme Court decision in a case involving homeowners in New London, Conn. The opinion limited homeowners' rights, saying local governments could take private property for projects purely related to economic development.

An Atlanta jury convicted a 79-year-old woman of murder in the shooting of her 85-year-old former boyfriend, rejecting her plea of insanity. The judge sentenced the woman, Lena Driskell, to life in prison plus five years for the death of her former boyfriend, Herman Winslow. In closing arguments, Ms. Driskell's lawyers said her jealous delusions about Mr. Winslow and other women became the motive for shooting him to death after Mr. Winslow ended their 14-month relationship. But prosecutors argued that Ms. Driskell could not plead insanity because she had admitted that she knew she was wrong when she shot Mr. Winslow.

A wealthy former pawn shop owner from Reno who was sought in the stabbing death of his estranged wife and the shooting of the judge hearing their divorce case surrendered Thursday night in Mexico, ending a 10-day search, the authorities said. The man, Darren R. Mack, 45, was taken into custody at the United States Consulate in Puerto Vallarta. The police said Mr. Mack had fled to Puerto Vallarta after the June 12 killing of his wife, Charla Mack, 39, and the shooting of Judge Chuck Weller, 53, of Reno Family Court. Mr. Mack, who had no criminal record, was unarmed, the authorities said.

Personal data of 28,000 sailors and members of their families have been found on a civilian Web site, setting off a criminal investigation. The Navy said the information was in five documents and included people's names, birth dates and Social Security numbers. A Navy spokesman, Lt. Justin Cole, would not identify the site or its owner but said the information had been removed. He would not provide details of how the information had ended up on the site. Lieutenant Cole said there was no indication that the information had been used illegally, but people whose data had been posted were being contacted and encouraged to monitor their bank accounts and credit cards.

Two broadcast television networks have finished selling commercial time to advertisers before the start of the 2006-7 season. The Fox Broadcasting Company, part of the News Corporation, sold $1.8 billion to $1.9 billion in commercial time in what is known as the upfront market, so called because it takes place ahead of the fall season. Last year, in the upfront market before the 2005-6 season, Fox sold about $1.6 billion in commercial time. And the new CW network, which replaces the UPN and WB networks, sold about $650 million in commercial time. WB sold about $625 million in the upfront market last year, while UPN sold about $250 million. CW is owned by the CBS Corporation and Time Warner.

REISLEY--Rosalyn. Ronny died unexpectedly after a brief illness on June 22, 2006. Wife and best friend of Roland; loving mother of Robert; mother-in-law of Lynne and adoring grandmother of Alex and Danielle. She was a lifetime learner, a fabulous cook, a responsible citizen, an ardent craftsperson, a valued member of the Neuberger Museum Service Council and a Trustee and Secretary of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester. She was an original member of Usonia Homes and of the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy. For many years, she was a psychologist with the Bedford Central School System. A memorial gathering will be held on Tuesday June 27 at 12:15pm at the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, 108 Pines Bridge Rd, Ossining, NY. For directions call 914941-3544. Memorial donations may be sent to the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester or to the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy, 53 West Jackson Blvd, #

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, which infects a share of the world's population but rarely causes serious illness, referred incorrectly to the educational affiliation of Dr. Lloyd H. Kasper, who commented on the parasite. He is a professor at Dartmouth College, not Dartmouth University.

At the world bridge championships today, Americans won more gold medals. The Women's Pairs title was taken by Irina Levitina and Kerri Sanborn from the United States. (Levitina was a Russian chess champion, but has lived in the United States for many years.) They held off a spirited challenge by Honglin Wang and Wei Fei Wang from China. Third were Sabine Auken from Germany and Janice Seamon-Molson from the United States. This is the fourth world title for Levitina and the sixth for Sanborn.

A chart in the Street Scene page of Business Day yesterday with the Insider column, about hedge funds listings on foreign exchanges, mislabeled the scale reflecting estimated hedge fund assets. It is trillions of dollars, not millions.

Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta, who has served longer than anyone else now in the cabinet, announced Friday that he was resigning effective July 7. In a letter to President Bush dated Tuesday, Mr. Mineta, 74, did not give his reasons for leaving, other than to say simply that ''it is time for me to move on to other challenges.''
To the Editor: Re ''Afflicting the Afflicted'' (editorial, June 23):

To the Editor: Re ''Senate Rejects Calls to Begin Iraq Pullback'' (front page, June 23): I find it appalling that the Republicans, when faced with a serious debate about our policy in Iraq, simply retreat and continue to back the president with catchy slogans such as ''surrender is not a solution.''

With basketball out of the way, CBS easily won Thursday night among total viewers and tied with Fox in the 18-to-49 demographic. CBS's ''Gameshow Marathon,'' which featured Betty White, performed better than it has in recent weeks, drawing 7.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, and winning the 8 p.m. hour among 18-to-49-year-olds. It beat the premiere of ABC's ''Master of Champions'' (6.2 million), which took second place in the hour. CBS's ringer repeats, ''CSI'' (11.8 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (10.2 million), both won their slots among viewers. But Fox's results for ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (8.9 million) made it the top-rated show of the night among adults 18 to 49, and it lifted the network into a tie with CBS in that age group. On NBC, the third week of ''Windfall'' dropped precipitously in the ratings, bringing in 5.5 million viewers. On June 16 Disney Channel's movie ''Wendy Wu: Homecoming Warrior,'' in which a popular girl learns that she is a reincarnated Chinese warrior, drew 5.7 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about ''Artists Against the State: Perestroika Revisited,'' at the Ronald Feldman gallery in Soho, included an outdated closing date. It is July 28, not today.

SWISKAY--Hanan. Beloved husband of Judy. Devoted father of Dana and Charles Mollins, Jeffrey and Michael Swiskay. Cherished grandfather of Braeden Mass and Reed Mollins. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

Did China have a death from avian flu two years before it admitted having any human cases? The mystery deepened yesterday, and the possibility was raised that someone had tried to block publication of that event from a prestigious American medical journal.

An art review in Weekend yesterday about ''Raphael at the Metropolitan: The Colonna Altarpiece'' referred incorrectly to the work. It was one of Raphael's earliest altarpieces, not one of his last. The review also misidentified his birthplace in Italy. It was Urbino, not Perugia.

The Yankees' top prospect, starter Phil Hughes, took a no-hitter into the eighth inning for Class AA Trenton last night, with several scouts looking on. Hughes, who turns 20 today, allowed a double to the leadoff hitter in the eighth but finished the inning. He is 4-3 with a 3.18 earned run average in 10 starts for Trenton.

Germany, its team growing in stature by the day, powered into the quarter-finals of the World Cup with a 2-0 win over Sweden in a lopsided contest that was over almost before it began. Sweden played with 10 men for much of the match after the sending off of Teddy Lucic for two yellow cards, and missed a penalty early in the second half. The team never recovered from a devastating German start.

To the Editor: In ''Pentagon Study Describes Abuse by Special Units'' (front page, June 17), you report that Special Operations forces held three Iraqi detainees in cells that were ''four feet high, four feet long, and 20 inches wide'' for up to seven days. Such a cell makes it impossible for an adult detainee to either stand up straight or lie down.

To the Editor: Re ''Bank Data Sifted in Secret by U.S. to Block Terror'' (front page, June 23): The question is, What's more important, the Central Intelligence Agency's ability to track terrorist financing, or the ''public interest'' in these activities?
''Every girl I know has at least one story.'' BARBARA VENCEBI on sexual harassment in the New York subway. [A1]

GROSSMAN--William I., M.D.The Philoctetes Center for the Multidisciplinary Study of Imagination mourns the death of its Board Member, Dr. William I. Grossman. Psychoanalyst, scholar, and teacher, Bill's graceful brilliance and gentle presence lit the world for those who knew him. Freud wrote, ''The voice of the intellect is a soft one, but it does not rest til it has gained a hearing.'' Such was Bill's voice, and in the work he has left with us, it will ring out for a long time to come. We grieve with his wife Chanie, sons Eric and David, and all those who loved him. Edward Nersessian, M.D. Francis Levy, Co-Directors The Philoctetes Center

An obituary on Wednesday about the Hollywood director Vincent Sherman misstated the sequence of work on two films by his collaborators Philip and Julius Epstein. They were among the writers of the screenplay for ''Casablanca'' before they wrote the screenplay for Mr. Sherman's ''Mr. Skeffington,'' not after.

A front-page article yesterday about reports that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a major hedge fund, Pequot Capital Management, misstated the investment vehicle that has been involved in many of the 78 S.E.C. enforcement actions against all hedge funds from 2002 through 2005. It is Private Investments in Public Equity cases, not Public Investments in Private Equity.

Shopping at consignment or thrift stores can work for fashion connoisseurs who are as concerned with brand name and fit as they are with price. It is a gamble, however, for those in a rush to find a specific garment. Here are some tips on how to find the shops and what to look for once you're there: 3/5paragraf 4/5Search online with keywords like ''plus-size consignment'' or ''children's consignment'' or at the National Association of Resale and Thrift Shops (www.narts.org/shopping/).

A walking tours entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday misidentified the starting point of a Central Park tour tomorrow at 2 p.m. led by the Friends of the Parks. It is the Women's Gate at West 72nd Street and Central Park West, not the Pulitzer Fountain at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South. That is where the tour will end.

An article in Business Day on Tuesday about an announcement by researchers at I.B.M. and Georgia Tech about a new speed record for silicon-based semiconductors referred incorrectly to the chips used in cellphones. Some cellphones operate on a frequency of 2 gigahertz; that is not speed of their chips.

To the Editor: ''The Art of the Deal'' (editorial, June 17) says of ''Cathy's Book: If Found, Call (650) 266-8233,'' our upcoming novel for teenagers, that the book ''captures the weird coalescence of the shape-shifting culture adolescent girls live in, where the borders between advertising and literature, podcast and sitcom, novel and lipstick go unpatrolled'' -- as if it's a bad thing.

An article on June 16 about Morton Morrison, a 94-year-old driving instructor from Danbury, Conn., referred imprecisely to the school that he attended in 1929. At the time, it was the business school of City College in New York; it did not become the independent Baruch College until 1968.

A report in the Supreme Court Roundup on Tuesday about the settlement of Holocaust survivors' claims against Swiss banks imprecisely stated the proportion of the $1.25 billion settlement fund that is going to survivors in the United States. The settlement includes five subcategories, including one known as the ''looted assets class.'' The American survivors are receiving 4 percent of the $185 million earmarked for that category; these survivors, who constitute 14 percent to 19 percent of survivors worldwide, have received 28 percent -- not just 4 percent -- of the money distributed to all five settlement classes.

10 P.M. (Discovery Channel, DTimes) ADDICTED TO OIL: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN REPORTING -- The cry of ''Go Green!'' is ricocheting around the country as the war on terror takes a toll on the American economy, and global warming, conservation and energy alternatives become more important than ever to national security. In this hourlong special, Mr. Friedman (above), a columnist for The New York Times, riffs on petropolitics -- a phrase he coined to define the relationship between oil prices and oil-rich nations -- and discusses the political, strategic and economic impact of the country's reliance on fossil fuels while proposing solutions for beating the addiction. Forget the gasoline lines of the 1970's. ''This is not your parents' energy crisis,'' Mr. Friedman says. 8 A.M. (HBO Family) POSTMAN PAT -- Since 1981, British children have gone postal over Pat, a mail carrier in the make-believe hamlet of Greenfield in Yorkshire. In 2004, the series was retooled with stop-gap animation and multicultural story lines, and Pat was exported to the United States -- by FedEx, we're guessing. In these two new episodes, the warm-and-fuzzy Pat (above left, with his cat, Jess, in New York) paints a rainbow on the playground wall, complete with a pot of gold, and helps knight a brave child. 8 P.M. (Oxygen) BANSHEE -- Talk about lousy planning. In this made-for-television action drama, a tough girl (Taryn Manning) boosts the car of a serial killer -- and he's dead set on getting it back. 9 P.M. (Logo) THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM -- They are outcasts in either corner: the gay community doesn't want them and neither does the Republican party. This ''Real Momentum'' documentary looks at three gay Republicans fighting to gain acceptance, love and victory while sticking tight to their principles. 9 P.M. (Spike) THE ULTIMATE FIGHTER -- Prepare to be pounded in this three-hour season finale of the mixed martial arts reality series in which bitter competitors suffered the indignities of training and living together. Four matches will be shown in their entirety, live from the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, with the winners in the light heavyweight and middleweight rounds being crowned Ultimate Fighters and rewarded with six-figure U.F.C. contracts. Those who missed the pummeling up to this point can watch all of Season 3, starting at 9 a.m. this morning. 9 P.M. (Sci Fi) ANDROID APOCALYPSE -- A hard-working human (Scott Bairstow) loses his job in the last city on Earth to an android, and in a fit of rage kills another. Now he's sentenced to a prison deep in the wasteland, and only the android (Joseph Lawrence, above right, with Mr. Bairstow) he is shackled to can get him out. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about heart risks associated with jogging, overstated the frequency of heart attacks during marathons. While studies have found that marathon runners may be at increased risk of heart attack for 24 hours after racing, there is no evidence that heart attacks occur ''in the course of nearly every marathon.''

JAHODA--Maria C. Died June 16, 2006 at her home in NYC after a brief illness. Born in Vienna on November 13, 1922, she moved permanently to the U.S. in the early 1980's. Mirli was a font of joy and good will to many and she will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held in NYC at a later date.

After Florida's Miguel Cabrera intentionally swung during what was supposed to be an intentional walk, it looked on video replays as if an unintentional smile flashed across his face when he made contact and sent the ball into center field. Cabrera's unlikely base hit scored a run to break a 5-5 tie in the 10th inning Thursday night in Baltimore, and the Marlins added two more runs in an 8-5 victory, their 10th in 11 games.

WILLIAMS--Isabel Rae (nee Lory). Beloved wife of Harry Williams. Loving mother of Ronnie Williams and her partner Suzanne Arnopolin, Martin Williams and his wife Micheline, Terry Pesso and her husband Noah, and Ruth Williams. Devoted sister of Jerry Lory and the late Leona Post. Cherished grandmother of Natalie, Gregory, Erica, Rachel and Sarah. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews and their children. A member of Hadassah and the Jewish Community Center of West Hempstead. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the charity of your choice. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, RVC, NY. $(6$)WILLIAMS--Isabel. Thanks for being a dear friend for over 50 years. For Mexico, the most recent loss to Argentina, does not quite taste like a defeat - at least not of the kind we had against Portugal. Our team played with courage. Our defense was superb. We could have only been beaten by Maxi Rodr√≠guez scoring perhaps the best goal of the World Cup. And we were. Over the last three weeks we've met the fast-evolving fishes of African great lakes and evolutionary biologists who worry that humans are becoming like barnacles. More generally, I've talked about how genomes are constructed, what natural selection is (and whether it still affects us), why birds don't get pregnant, and what would happen if we crossed humans and chimpanzees. I've suggested experiments that could (in principle!) be done, and considered why questions can't always be answered. This week I want to wrap up with a collection of some of the other questions, within evolution and without, that are currently on my mind.

A. J. Allmendinger, the only driver from the United States in the Champ Car series, helped celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Grand Prix of Cleveland by setting a track record yesterday. Allmendinger won the pole for today's race with a lap of 56.283 seconds at 134.705 miles an hour. Jimmy Vasser had held the qualifying record, 56.417 seconds and 134.385 m.p.h., since 1998.

Fernando Alonso won his fifth consecutive Formula One pole yesterday, setting himself up for a strong run in the Canadian Grand Prix and a chance to widen his lead in the standings. Alonso, the defending series champion, has a 23-point lead over Michael Schumacher heading into today's race in Montreal. Schumacher qualified a distant fifth.

Ben Curtis moved closer to his first title since the 2003 British Open, shooting a four-under-par 67 yesterday to take a five-stroke lead after three rounds at the Booz Allen Classic in Potomac, Md. He was at 19-under 213, breaking the tournament record through 54 holes at the T.P.C. at Avenel.

Rich Rodriguez, who coached West Virginia to a victory in the Sugar Bowl against Georgia in January, received a three-year contract extension that will pay him at least $1 million a year. The contract, which runs through the 2012 season, includes an additional $100,000 a year in deferred compensation, which Rodriguez can collect in December 2011 if he remains head coach. Rodriguez led the Mountaineers to their third straight Big East title last season.

The public editor's June 18 column incorrectly indicated that Jayson Blair, the former Times reporter who brought scandal to the paper in 2003, didn't receive performance evaluations during his time on the metro desk during 2001-2. Mr. Blair was evaluated and an evaluation was specifically provided to the sports editor when the reporter was moved to the sports department. But no evaluations of Mr. Blair's work on the metro desk, then one of the few departments doing regular formal performance assessments, were reviewed by the editors involved when the reporter subsequently was deployed to the national desk.

THE sanctuary was dim, the twilight through the stained-glass window fading, and Hugh Davis -- five nights away from crossing the river with his choir for a big gospel competition in Manhattan -- was standing at the altar, looking for the right move. It was the kind of soft spring end-of-school-year evening that had lured many young people outside, where they clustered on corners and porches and crowded the basketball court down the block. But 30 of them were gathered inside Elmwood Presbyterian Church, singing a single rapid-fire chorus -- ''When I think about Jesus'' -- over and over, trying to find a stylish way to punctuate it with their bodies.

Allegations of racketeering, money laundering and wire fraud are one thing. But now federal prosecutors have hit Conrad M. Black where it hurts: they have disparaged his personal wealth. The United States Attorney's office in Chicago has asked a federal judge to modify or revoke Lord Black's $20 million bail bond because the asset backing the bond -- his home in Palm Beach, Fla. -- is not worth as much as he said it was. For one thing, prosecutors say, it has a Canadian tax lien against it. For another, they say, he has defaulted on the mortgage.

The top American commander in Iraq has drafted a plan that projects sharp reductions in the United States military presence there by the end of 2007, with the first cuts coming this September, American officials say. According to a classified briefing at the Pentagon this week by the commander, Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the number of American combat brigades in Iraq is projected to decrease to 5 or 6 from the current level of 14 by December 2007.

WARD POUND RIDGE RESERVATION, a 4,700-acre preserve in Cross River, is one of the finest places in the Northeast to find butterflies. Today, as in earlier times, a watchful visitor will be impressed by the luxuriant chaos of a busy meadow in mid-July when the number and variety of species of butterflies reach their peak. In this busy jumble, scores of butterflies can be observed jostling for position on dogbane and milkweed blossoms. Elegant, gliding monarchs and swallowtails will land to sip nectar alongside smaller, fast-darting skippers. In all, more than 80 butterfly species have been recorded at the reservation, including more than 65 percent of all the species that commonly reside in New York State.

To the Editor: As a two-year resident of the Myrtle Avenue area in Fort Greene, I can understand George Sarrinikolaou's concerns about contributing to the area's pronounced socioeconomic dichotomies (''The View From His Window,'' June 18). However, he need not resign himself to his bleak conclusion that his infant daughter will someday criticize his complicity in the neighborhood's gentrification.

On Nov. 29 and Feb. 28, the Op-Ed page published articles co-written by Stephen E. Flynn, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, on the need to scan shipping containers. An article last Monday in the news pages of The Times reported that Mr. Flynn had earlier been a paid consultant to Science Applications International Corporation, which manufactured a container-scanning system. The Times's Op-Ed contract compels contributors to disclose potential conflicts of interest, but not past ones. In this regard, Mr. Flynn did not violate the contract. However, had the editors known of Mr. Flynn's previous relationship with Science Applications International, they would have made that information available to readers.

REISLEY--Rosalyn. Ronny died unexpectedly after a brief illness on June 22, 2006. Wife and best friend of Roland; loving mother of Robert; mother-in-law of Lynne and adoring grandmother of Alex and Danielle. She was a lifetime learner, a fabulous cook, a responsible citizen, an ardent craftsperson, a valued member of the Neuberger Museum Service Council and a Trustee and Secretary of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester. She was an original member of Usonia Homes and of the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy. For many years, she was a psychologist with the Bedford Central School System. A memorial gathering will be held on Tuesday June 27 at 12:15pm at the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, 108 Pines Bridge Rd, Ossining, NY. For directions call 914941-3544. Memorial donations may be sent to the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester or to the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy, 53 West Jackson Blvd, #

I'm looking for a Web site where I can compare prices and schedules of low-cost airlines across Europe, like easyJet and Ryanair. Sites such as Expedia and Opodo are great, but only show conventional carriers. -- Steve Capper, Trausse, France Many readers are frustrated at being unable to find the schedules of no-frills, or low-cost, carriers on major online travel sites. There are basically three kinds of sites for planning itineraries and making reservations: those that display a choice of airlines and fares and allow you to book and pay with your card on that site; so-called comparison sites, which show options from airlines and other travel sites (not necessarily prices) and require you to click on a link to those sites to book; and sites run by specific airlines, which may give a wider choice of their schedules and fares than other sites.

To the Editor: I found Mr. Isherwood's article very interesting. It reminded me of an advertisement from the 1960's that contained the most honestly misleading copy I have ever seen in my 44 years in the theater business. There was a play called ''The Family Way,'' which, upon opening on Broadway, received probably the worst set of totally bad reviews I have ever seen. Next morning, the following small box advertisement for the play appeared: ''The Family Way. Critics Unanimous!'' Robert A. Freedman Manhattan The writer owns the Robert A. Freedman Dramatic Agency, which represents playwrights.

Germany powered into the quarterfinals of the World Cup on Saturday with a 2-0 victory against Sweden in a lopsided game. Sweden had only 10 men for most of the game after Teddy Lucic was sent off in the 35th minute after receiving his second yellow card. Sweden then missed a penalty kick early in the second half and never recovered.

Adena Malka Silberstein and Levi Isaac Pinsky are to be married today by Rabbi Adam S. Ferziger, a cousin of the bride, at the Sheraton Universal Hotel in Los Angeles. The bride, 25, completed first year studies for a doctorate in modern Jewish history at New York University last month. In 2004 and 2005 she was a fellow and an assistant to the executive director at the American Jewish Committee in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from Barnard. She is a daughter of Linda Silberstein and Dr. Sylvain Silberstein of Valley Village, Calif. Her father, an endocrinologist, is a partner in Internal Medicine Associates, a group practice in Van Nuys, Calif.

FIRST an elderly couple in a beige sedan crept by, fascinated by the strange contraption screwed to the hood of a gleaming red S.U.V. A few minutes later, a pair of fishermen in a battered pickup truck stopped, glaring at crew members huddled in the roadway over a snake's nest of cables. Even in June, the remote spot in Hampton Bays where Dune Road meets the Shinnecock Canal is just for locals. But on a recent morning it morphed into command central for ''Easy Driver,'' an Italian television program featuring beautiful people cruising beautiful places in flashy, expensive cars. The show spent four days taping on the South Fork before heading to the Catskills. ''You should have seen us last week in Manhattan,'' said Christina Emma, a producer. ''We had a Ferrari.''

BECKER--Norma. We former staff members of the 5th Ave Vietnam Peace Parade Committee mourn the death on June 17 of Norma Becker, unsung hero of the Anti-Vietnam War movement. Others spoke or wrote; Norma acted. She was the indispensable dynamo of American dissent.Alan Barnes, Robert Eberwein Laurie Sandow, Glenn Tepper Joshua Brown, Wendy Fisher

In this literary thriller, three narratives intersect around a rape-murder on the Upper West Side. UNCOMMON CARRIERS, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) Wal-Mart caused a stir recently when it announced it was going to push organic foods, but it is hardly alone in that marketing approach. Increasingly, hotels and resorts are featuring organic cuisine on their menus and in their guest programs. Rancho La Puerta in Tecate, Mexico (www.rancholapuerta.com), which has a six-acre organic farm that produces vegetables, herbs and fruit used by the spa's chefs and therapists, plans to open a cooking school next spring with a focus on natural foods.

ON occasion, running an alternative art space can be more than just hard work. Late last year, someone walked into City Without Walls in the depressed Lincoln Park area of Newark, picked up a hammer and attacked the director and the education coordinator. Neither man was seriously hurt, and the police later arrested a suspect, but the art institution closed immediately for a six-month renovation that included expanded security measures. A month ago, the gallery, which moved three years ago from its former home in the Gateway Center next to Newark Penn Station, quietly reopened with upgrades including surveillance cameras and a prominent security station at the entrance.

FANS of the work of Robert Havell Jr., the 19th-century Westchester County resident and artist best known as the engraver of John James Audubon's vaunted ''Birds of America'' series, were impressed with a recent lot of his work offered by Sotheby's in Manhattan. Nineteen paintings, prints, sketches and engravings were put up for bid on June 15; 17 sold, for a total of $665,000. But one work that Havell collectors would have been delighted to see was a mural that has been missing from Mr. Havell's Ossining home for almost 20 years. Its whereabouts has been a mystery ever since.

HOW does a company persuade its longtime chief executive to keep working in his golden years? Give him more gold, of course. Legg Mason, the money manager in Baltimore, gave its chief, Raymond A. Mason, 70, a pay package worth more than $35 million for the fiscal year that ended March 31. Mr. Mason, who has run Legg for 25 years, received $14.5 million in cash, and options that the company valued at $21.2 million.

England might as well get used to it. Apparently nothing will come easily. The World Cup is halfway over, and the British are still scuffling to find their way. There is little elegance in their game, only toil and exertion to provide an austere beauty and grim satisfaction. David Beckham scored, as perhaps only he can, on a wickedly curving free kick in the 60th minute today, giving England a 1-0 victory over Ecuador and a respite from a sluggish afternoon with the temperature climbing into the 90s'.

The DealBook column last Sunday, about Goldman Sachs hiring a lawyer to advise its clients on bankruptcy and restructuring, referred incorrectly to one group that is normally disqualified from restructuring work. It is creditors, not debtors.

A month after nine school budgets were shot down across Westchester and Putnam Counties, voters returned to the polls on Tuesday to approve seven of the budgets that had been defeated, rejecting only the two that were resubmitted without a single change. The seven budgets that passed contained minor deletions and revisions. Five of the budgets were in Westchester -- Eastchester, Tuckahoe, Pocantico Hills, North Salem and Mount Pleasant -- and two were in Putnam, in Brewster and Putnam Valley.

Starlee Kine says that she ''had no idea'' that she owed more than $64,000 in college and credit-card debt, which she is struggling to repay. Kine claims that her mother, now estranged, probably signed Kine's name on various loan applications, all without her knowledge or permission. If that's the case, Kine should promptly consult a lawyer. It is highly doubtful that she would be held legally responsible for debts incurred because someone else used her name, unless Kine in some way authorized or ratified the loans. Gregory Schwed New York

It is looking to be a long summer, as hemlines skim the grass and brush the tops of painted toes. The new hostess gowns have a casual, old-time Palm Beach glamour; wear them with ponytails and bare feet, beside the pool or curled up on the sofa with a tall drink. Here are some of the best ways to go on at length. 1. Diane Von Furstenberg's creamy chiffon camouflage print has mother-of-pearl disks adorning the spaghetti straps and a knotted tie-front ($425 at Saks Fifth Avenue stores). 2. Ella Moss's elegant color-block sheath in aqua, olive and sand has a stretchy halter top ($190 at Nordstrom stores). Necklace by Good Charma. 3. A fluttery, strapless botanical A-line by Morgane Le Fay is printed with every sort of flora and fauna ($820 at Morgane Le Fay in New York, 212-879-9700). 4. Tracy Feith's Le Shack jersey knit stunner has smocking at the waist and a breezy print of chocolate brown, aqua blue and gold leaves ($328 at www.anthropologie.com). 5. An article last Sunday about firms that advise institutional investors on corporate governance issues referred incorrectly to Warburg Pincus, which has an ownership stake in one of those firms, Institutional Shareholder Services. Warburg Pincus is a global private equity firm based in New York, not in Britain.

ZWIEBEL--Norman, 81, of Delray Beach FL passed on June 12, 2006. He is survived by his loving wife Wanda, sons Stanley (Louise), Michael (Jennifer), Harold (Phyllis), Richard (Judith), grandchildren Maddie, Alana, Mia, Benjamin, Samantha, Melissa (John), Timothy, Terrence and Kennon. Greatgrandsons Joseph and Thomas. He received his P.H.D in Chemistry from Princeton University. May this Brilliant and Extraordinary man. REST IN PEACE. I Love You Wanda!! Sinai Memorial ChapelS 561-865-1747

THE Fairfield Board of Education voted late last month to have the town's two high schools start their day 20 minutes later, beginning in the fall, part of a movement around the state to get teenagers more sleep. Greenwich P.T.A. members have been asking the school board to consider a delay, and board members in West Hartford have also been discussing later start times. Other schools have also looked into the issue, but have made no changes. Wilton became the first school district in the state to make the change when it delayed middle and high school starting times by almost an hour in 2003.

To the Editor: I have time to write this letter because a client just canceled her appointment. I would rather be with her, as I bill on an hourly basis, and no one is paying for my time as I write this. Self-employed professionals can always find something else to do with the free time created by a last-minute cancellation, but this ''gift'' of free time isn't a gift at all -- it's just free. And, in fact, it has the potential to create trickle-down cancellations: i.e., less income means fewer massages, movies and dinners out.

To the Editor: In ''New York's Crime Against Women'' (Op-Ed, June 18), Sonia Ossorio correctly observed that New York State's statute of limitations for prosecuting rape was nearly the shortest in the nation: only Florida, North Dakota and Utah had shorter time limits during which a rapist may be brought to justice.

June brides, right, shared the spotlight with Sweet 16 birthday girls, left and below, with their Cinderella white gowns, tiaras, magic wands, below, and color-coordinated entourages, above, including toddlers. In city gardens and parks, both groups gathered for photographs. It was often impossible to distinguish between the groups, except that the brides had veils, dresses with trains and a parasol to protect fair skin.

To the Editor: ''Connecticut's Energy Problem'' (editorial, June 11) is based on the premise that if Connecticut utilities owned and operated power plants again, consumers would be shielded from rising electricity rates. Frustration with rising electricity costs is understandable. But regardless of who owns and operates power plants, electricity rates closely follow the prices of natural gas and oil, which fuel the majority of the region's power plants. As long as fossil fuel remains the energy source of choice in New England, we can expect continued volatility in electricity prices.
DOEMLING--Mary JaneHoran. Died June 24, 2002. In loving memory. Son William Horan Doemling

YOU may not be able to discern my secret, because I am in disguise this summer, camouflaged by a college-age son living at home for a few months. But really, my husband and I are stealth parents, the ones lingering around the edges of suburban life, the ones who no longer fit into this child-centric universe. We are the empty nesters -- clich√©-ridden, childless, but hardly alone. Nationwide, there are about 70 million parents born between 1946 and 1964, and within the next 10 years or so, nearly all of our youngest children will graduate from high school and move on. In the New York metropolitan area, which includes Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Long Island, northern New Jersey and southern Connecticut, half of married-couple households no longer include children under the age of 18, according to the 2000 census data. Soon, we boomers will be one big child-free family, figuring out where and how to live without our little ones.

AS David Acker greets the class of aspiring emergency medical technicians on the first day of the summer session at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut, you're not exactly sure if he's welcoming them or trying to run them off. ''You get disrespected so much in this job,'' Mr. Acker said, leaning on a lectern in his blue paramedic's uniform at the hospital's Emergency Medical Services Institute. ''At least now it's good we have doctors riding with us in the field, so they can see what it's like when you're lying in the puke in the snowbank at 3 a.m. trying to intubate someone, or when you're bouncing down the highway, going 65 and trying to start an IV. I've been called every name in the book.''

To the Editor: Re ''Poland's Bigoted Government'' (editorial, June 11): Poland is a party to numerous international treaties and conventions that provide for strong safeguards of human rights and democratic standards. Therefore, it is with respect and gratitude that I read the June 18 letter from the chief rabbi of Poland, Michael Schudrich, in response to your editorial.

''A man's home is his castle'' goes the adage, which finds perhaps its most literal representation in the fanciful cottage of Wemmick, a London clerk in Charles Dickens's novel ''Great Expectations.'' Although Wemmick's home is tiny, he has modified it to resemble a Gothic fortress of sorts, complete with a plank drawbridge, a moat and a ''turret bedroom.'' While there is no evidence of a run on Dickens novels in area bookstores, much less a conscious emulation of Wemmick, turrets have been popping up with increasing frequency on upscale suburban homes around New York City.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Miller's Analysis Takes a Divot Out of Mickelson,'' (June 20): I'd like someone to explain to me the reason that the savaging of Phil Mickelson and others by NBC's Johnny Miller during the United States Open or any other tournament is acceptable behavior?

MARCHIONY--Lawrence, Jr. of Montclair, NJ on June 15. Larry served as VP of Creative Development for the Howard/Marlboro Group in New York City, co-foundedHidden Valley ski area in Vernon, NJ and was a founding member of the Montclair Ski Club. He was a grandson of Italo Marchiony, inventor of the ice cream cone. He is survived by sons David, Bill, John, his brother Bill, and his best friend, Susan Goodman. A memorial service is planned for 2 PM on Sunday, July 9, at the Montclair Art Museum. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Montclair Art Museum Art School Scholarship Fund.

WARD POUND RIDGE RESERVATION, a 4,700-acre preserve in Cross River, N.Y., is one of the finest places in the Northeast to find butterflies. Today, as in earlier times, a watchful visitor will be impressed by the luxuriant chaos of a busy meadow in mid-July when the number and variety of species of butterflies reach their peak. In this busy jumble, scores of butterflies can be observed jostling for position on dogbane and milkweed blossoms. Elegant, gliding monarchs and swallowtails will land to sip nectar alongside smaller, fast-darting skippers. In all, more than 80 butterfly species have been recorded at the reservation, including more than 65 percent of all the species that commonly reside in New York State.

HAIRSTON--Enid Carey. 1924-2006. Daughter of prominent lawyer and District Attorney Richard E. Carey and school teacher Homozelle W. Carey of NYC, passed on June 16. A Psychiatric Social Worker, Supervisor and Program Analyst in the Medicare and Medicaid Programs for the Department of Health and Human Services in Washington, D.C. She worked in the Mental Hygiene Clinic at Harlem Hospital, NYC, St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Washington, D.C., and supervised field placement services for Catholic, Virginia Commonwealth and Fordham Universities. Survivors are her husband William Hairston of 49 years, daughter Ann Marie Hairston, first cousins Edwin Peets, Ronald Wilson, Phyllis Prout and a host of in-laws, nephews, nieces, cousins and Hairston clan relatives all over America.

WITH sunglasses on and seatbelts fastened, David Hegna and his flight instructor, Margo Kay, prepared for takeoff in the Cessna 172 that Mr. Hegna was learning to fly at Solberg-Hunterdon Airport. After running through safety checks and pointing out a turkey standing in the grass nearby, he put the single-engine plane into the air. General aviation public-use airports like Solberg-Hunterdon often provide aspiring pilots like Mr. Hegna, of Wall, with the means to learn to fly. Most also offer aviation-related services, among them sales, storage, rentals, charters, maintenance and fueling. The State Department of Transportation remains committed to preserving the airports; 47 are still operating.

A picture caption with a report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday, about the Robin Hood Foundation gala at the Javits Convention Center on June 14, misidentified the bank represented by a group of men in kilts. It was the Royal Bank of Scotland, not the World Bank of Scotland.

FANS of the work of Robert Havell Jr., the 19th-century Westchester County resident and artist best known as the engraver of John James Audubon's vaunted ''Birds of America'' series, were impressed with a recent lot of his work offered by Sotheby's in Manhattan. Nineteen paintings, prints, sketches and engravings were put up for bid on June 15; 17 sold, for a total of $665,000. But one work that Havell collectors would have been delighted to see was a mural that has been missing from Mr. Havell's Ossining home for almost 20 years. Its whereabouts has been a mystery ever since.

CLIPBOARD in hand, Mike Thompson climbed the stoop of a well-kept, two-story home here and rang the bell. Ethel Corsale, a 79-year-old widow, answered and listened as Mr. Thompson, a 23-year-old organizer for the nonprofit Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, or Acorn, explained why she should support Gov. Jon S. Corzine's proposed sales tax increase. Mrs. Corsale agreed to write a note to her state legislators, dictated by Mr. Thompson, asking them to vote to increase the sales tax by 1 cent.

Dimitri Kyriakides, in the foreground, a 51-year-old accountant from Johannesburg, South Africa. ''I was born in Cyprus, but I left there when I was very young -- about 10. I felt that I should go and see if there was anything there that I could relate to. It's always good to go back to your birthplace. I had to go and try to establish some connection with my roots, and I think that was quite important for me at this stage in my life. Aphrodite was reputed to have been birthed from the sea at this very spot. And when you're in a place of beauty like this, you feel insignificant in the events of time. Time doesn't have any relation to what you're doing. I think it made me decide which direction I wanted to go in, and I'm following that in hot pursuit, as they say.'' As told to Austin Considine
