INTERNATIONAL 3-10 Military Plans for Iraq Cuts The top American commander in Iraq has drafted a plan that projects sharp reductions in the United States military presence there by the end of 2007, with the first cuts coming this September, according to American officials. 1 After an unusually violent week in Baghdad, three American soldiers were killed in combat, and a fourth died from injuries unrelated to fighting, the military said. The deaths bring the number of American soldiers killed in Iraq so far this month to 46. 4 As prosecutors prepare to try Saddam Hussein in Baghdad on charges of genocide against the Kurds, a group of experts who have studied chemical weapons use by Iraq against its Kurdish citizens are dusting off evidence in an effort to define the scope of the attacks. 4 Syria and Iran Strengthen Ties Washington may face a worrying phenomenon as it seeks to contain Iran and isolate Syria: the two governments, and their people, are tightening relations on several fronts as power in the region shifts away from the once dominant Sunnis to Shiites, led by Iran. 1 Educating Defectors in Korea Born and reared in one of the most isolated nations, North Korean defectors come to the South Korean government's resettlement centers for a crash course on life in South Korean society. About 6,900 North Koreans have graduated from the center since 1999. 3 Phone Tapping Faulted in Italy Italian authorities' use of phone tapping has long been an issue, and since 2001 the number of tapped phones has more than tripled, the Justice Ministry says. But more and more, legal scholars and worried politicians are objecting on principle, seeing a grave risk to a fair trial. 3 NATIONAL 12-22 Sidelining Immigration Plans House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert informed President Bush that Republicans were effectively sidelining -- and in the view of some congressional aides probably killing -- what has become Mr. Bush's signature domestic initiative of the year: an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws. 1 After promoting Medicare drug plans for three years, the Bush administration is having difficulty regulating these same plans to ensure they comply with federal standards for marketing, customer service and consumer protection. 17 Unifying Muslim Worship A small but determined band of North American Muslims, mostly younger women, has been challenging the practice of segregated worship, which is the norm in the United States and Canada. 14 14 Saudi Detainees Released Fourteen Saudi Arabians were released from the detention center at the American naval base at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, and transferred to their home country, the Pentagon said. About 450 detainees remain at the detention center, including 120 who are considered eligible for transfer or release. 16 Washington Screening for HIV Washington, D.C., is launching a campaign to screen every resident between the ages of 14 and 84 for HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Health officials say the effort, if successful, would be the most aggressive screening regimen undertaken in the history of the 25-year-old epidemic. 21 NEW YORK/REGION 25-30 Youth Soccer Faces Audit A youth soccer league in Fairfield, Conn., has grappled over the last two years with an Internal Revenue Service audit, which claims that the association failed to withhold taxes for a dozen paid coaches and scores of referees in 2003 and 2004. 25 Candidate's Past Revisited Thomas H. Kean Jr., the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, has accused his opponent, Senator Robert Menendez, of distorting his role in helping to bring down a corrupt political machine in Union City years ago. 25 OBITUARIES 31-32 Sir Peter Smithers A lawyer, politician, diplomat, and spy who saw his work as a distraction from his passion for growing gardens, he was 92. 31 Chess 30 Weather 20

KOSSOVER - Ruth. Passed away at home surrounded by her loved ones. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Steven and Andrew. Cherished grandmother of Noah, Lindsey, Jacqueline, Lauren and Jared. Former President of Julia Bernstein League of Free Nurses, former Board member of Parker Jewish Geriatrics at Long Island Jewish Hospital, former board member of North Shore League for Parent Education, and retired New York City school teacher. Services Sunday, 1 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

DUNWORTH -- Mary Violet Hegarty, 89, resident of Ocean Beach, NY and Cleveland Heights, OH died peacefully in her sleep on June 22, 2006 at her home on Fire Island. Born in NYC June 1, 1917 to Violet Gunigal Hegarty and Joseph Hegarty. Graduate of Hunter College. Widow of the Thomas Dunworth, to whom she was married for 65 years. Preceded in death by her sister Lily and son-in-law Thomas A. Frayne. Survived by Mary Violet (Thomas) Frayne, Thomas C. (Judith), Christopher (Beth), Joseph, Jane (Paul) DeDenus, Patrick and Gerald. Grandmother of Thomas D. (Susi) Frayne, Tara (Lars) Olesen, Nora Dunworth and Malachi Dunworth and Timothy DeDenus, and great-grandchildren Anders, Alexandra and Erik Olesen and Oscar Lux Frayne. She nurtured a great love for music, reading, and discussions of world affairs and religion in her family. She will be missed by her children and many friends. This would have been her 70th summer in Fire Island. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in her name to Our Lady of the Magnificat Catholic Church, Ocean Beach, NY 11770.

FIRST an elderly couple in a beige sedan crept by, fascinated by the strange contraption screwed to the hood of a gleaming red S.U.V. A few minutes later, a pair of fishermen in a battered pickup truck stopped, glaring at crew members huddled in the roadway over a snake's nest of cables. Even in June, the remote spot in Hampton Bays where Dune Road meets the Shinnecock Canal is just for locals. But on a recent morning it morphed into command central for ''Easy Driver,'' an Italian television program featuring beautiful people cruising beautiful places in flashy, expensive cars. The show spent four days taping on the South Fork before heading to the Catskills. ''You should have seen us last week in Manhattan,'' said Christina Emma, a producer. ''We had a Ferrari.''

To the Editor: In ''Where the Defining Lines Run Deep'' (June 4), Akiko Busch says of Robert Frost: '' 'Good fences make good neighbors,' the poet assured us more than 90 years ago.'' To the contrary, in ''Mending Wall'' Frost is deeply skeptical of that bit of folk wisdom, reflecting:

PALMER--Gloria Elhat. 78, of Shushan, NY, died peacefully at her home Wednesday, June 21, 2006 after a long, courageous battle with cancer. She was the loving wife of James Wesley Palmer, who died June 14, 2004. Born January 8, 1928 in Brooklyn NY, she was the daughter of Mary Adams and Thomas Joseph Elhat. She grew up in Brooklyn and was active with the Girl Scouts, which remained a life long interest. Gloria was also an avid and loyal Brooklyn Dodger fan, going to every baseball game she could at Ebbets Field. She graduated from Hamilton High School and Adelphi University in Garden City. She earned her Master of Arts degree in mathematical statistics from Columbia University. Gloria went to work for the Bell Telephone system on Broadway in NYC, where she was the first woman hired for their executive staff. She worked there for her entire career. Her job was to develop trends and forecasting in expenses and revenue and personal statistics. Late in her career she provided economic forecasts for Alan Greenspan. She was very active with the American Statistical Association. Gloria purchased her home in Shushan NY in 1977 and moved there when she retired. On April 30, 1994 she married her longtime friend, James Palmer and they enjoyed a wonderful life together caring for each other and traveling the world. Gloria was a communicant of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Cambridge where she served as a vestry member. She is survived by her niece, Gloria Zahkes of Norwich VT, a nephew, a niece and several cousins. A Memorial Service will take place on Saturday, July 8 at 11 A.M. at St. Luke's Episcopal Church. In accordance with her wishes, Gloria's body has been given to the Albany Medical College Anatomical Gifts Program. Memorial donations may be made to St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 4 St. Luke's Place, Cambridge, NY 12816 and directed to Gloria Elhat Palmer Foundation. For Gloria's online guestbook, please visit www.mcclellan funeralservice.com. For more information: McClellan Funeral Service, Salem NY, 518-854-3555.

JUST off Exit 70 of the Long Island Expressway on a nondescript swath of flatland, Kay Rosaire, arguably Suffolk County's most exotic summer resident, lives in a modest trailer tucked away on the perimeter of the Long Island Game Farm. She dresses the part: animal print shirt, lion-head ring, safari vest. Even her patio umbrella is leopard print. And she is not summering alone. Ms. Rosaire, 57, keeps cats on Long Island, the same type of kitty that took a tragic bite out of one-half of her more famous contemporaries, Siegfried and Roy, in Las Vegas awhile back. The type that took a 200-stitch bite out of her in 1991, a breach of trust that briefly caused her to rethink her career and rue the day her only child, Clayton, decided to follow in Mom's footsteps and train tigers (and lions and bears).

AS David Acker greets the class of aspiring emergency medical technicians on the first day of the summer session at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut, you're not exactly sure if he's welcoming them or trying to run them off. ''You get disrespected so much in this job,'' Mr. Acker said, leaning on a lectern in his blue paramedic's uniform at the hospital's Emergency Medical Services Institute. ''At least now it's good we have doctors riding with us in the field, so they can see what it's like when you're lying in the puke in the snowbank at 3 a.m. trying to intubate someone, or when you're bouncing down the highway, going 65 and trying to start an IV. I've been called every name in the book.''

Martina Carissa Hoppe and Matthew McManus Barnes were married yesterday at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen J. Fichter, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Anabel Taylor Chapel. Mrs. Barnes, 34, is a regional planner in New York for the United States Forest Service; she works on watershed planning projects in the Northeastern United States, identifying areas for protection. She graduated and received a master's degree in regional planning from Cornell.

SteelCloud builds computer-security systems for federal agencies. One can only hope its handiwork is as impenetrable as its disclosures to investors. The company said last week that its chairman and chief executive, Thomas P. Dunne, 63, had quit following an investigation by the board's audit committee into ''the attempted exercise of certain employee stock options'' that he owned.

GOLDBERG--Sheldon. Born August 28, 1930, died June 19, 2006. Native New Yorker, Sheldon died at his home in Southampton, NY after a long battle with cancer. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, he was an expert advisor of tax law and estates planning. Retired in 1998 from Edward Isaacs & Co., where he was managing tax partner. He is survived by his wife, Miriam, his sons Seth and Hal Goldberg. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloane-Kettering and Southampton Rose Society.

The following is a letter Bill Keller, the executive editor of The Times, has sent to readers who have written to him about The Times's publication of information about the government's examination of international banking records:

COHEN--Frances, a resident of Boca Raton for over 30 years died Thursday June 22, 2006 at the age of 89. Born Frances Dilbert, she was the wife of the late Solon Cohen and the mother of the late Roy Cohen. Frances is survived by her children, Laurie and Bruce Cohen and her grandchildren, Nicolas Solon and Sarah Frances Cohen, and her daughter-in-law, Lauren Cohen and son-in-law, Richard McArdle. Fran Cohen was well known for both her philanthropy and her active involvement in many South Florida organizations. She was on the board of directors of The Florence Fuller Child Development Centers for more than 20 years serving as President for five of those years. She was a long time benefactor of the Boca Raton Community Hospital. Fran rarely missed an interfaith service, and was on the board of trustees of Temple Beth El and supported the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County. In addition, Fran gave college scholarships to many local students, as well as being a patron to Lynn University's Excaliber Society and Caldwell Theatre. Fran Cohen was recognized for her kindness and generosity in the many awards she received through the years: A star on the Walk of Recognition honoring those individuals who have enriched the lives of the citizens of Boca Raton; Jewish Federation's Award of Merit; The National Exchange Club's Book of Golden Deeds; Boca Raton Junior League and 1st United Bank's Woman Volunteer of the year; Silver Medallion Brotherhood Award by The National Conference of Christians and Jews; Frances D. Cohen Day for civic achievement from the American Jewish Committee; JC Penney's Golden Rule Award; The State of Israel's Lion of Judah Award; Woman of Achievement Award by The Soroptimist International; Federation's Living People Award; South Florida Magazine's Woman of Distinction Award and Palm Beach County Sun-Sentinel Publisher's Award for community involvement. At Temple Beth El, the Atrium bears the name of Frances and Solon Cohen. Fran supervised the construction of the West Campus of the Florence Fuller Child Development Center and was there so much that the workers gave her a hard hat inscribed ''Crew Chief''. The office and after school building on the West Campus is named the Frances and Solon Cohen Annex. Also at Florence Fuller is an administration building on the East Campus named in memory of Fran's son, Roy Cohen. Fran's positive energy, presence, personality and insistent spirit have contributed much to our world. Her charity, leadership and heroism as well as her strength of character will be missed. She was truly a woman of valor. Services will be at Temple Beth EL 333 SW 4th Ave. Boca Raton, Fla. 33432 Sunday 2:30pm June 25, 2006. Donations in Fran's memory may be made to Florence Fuller Child Development Center, Boca Raton Community Hospital, Temple Beth El, the Federation of South Palm Beach County, or Pet Therapy of South Florida, 1355 West Palmetto Park Road #

For the design-conscious traveler, Wallpaper magazine-- the hip architecture and interior design glossy -- plans to roll out a series of illustrated pocket guides this fall. The 6 1/4-by-4 1/4-inch guides, published by Phaidon Press, are expanded versions of the magazine's Navigator page -- a pullout laminated map and miniguide on a featured destination -- which is being eliminated as of the September issue.

A DECADE ago my husband and I bought what our real-estate agent kindly called ''a rather unique parcel'' -- three overgrown acres with a crooked Cape Cod, a goat barn and a chicken coop. It sits atop a steep, winding private road in the western Connecticut woods in a seven-home enclave herein called the Hill. Soon after we moved in, the Hill's elder statesman, a 70-ish bachelor, introduced himself at the mailboxes. Saying that he ''knew the property,'' he bade us good luck with the kindly gravitas of a funeral director. ''I'm Franc,'' he went on, ''though I'm sure some people call me the neighborhood fusspot.''

Re ''Hillary and Bill: A Relationship Too Political to Be Ignored'' (June 4): I, too, think that the relationship between these two famous and influential politicians needs a keen eye if Hillary Clinton runs for president. Consider the money that former President Bill Clinton has taken in from countries for speaking fees, advice and his library, which could have a great influence on the decisions Senator Clinton would make as president regarding the same countries. It's a complicated web they have created, and it's not lost on the average voter.

A self-guided tour group pauses in a tram, gawking; people walk casually by, heads turned on their way to somewhere else; and a docent picks up stray pieces of rubbish that may detract from the site that seems to be stealing everyone's attention: Mark di Suvero's building-size, painted stainless-steel sculptures on the landscaped lawns and in the fields of the Storm King Art Center. Piece by piece, starting in 1976, 16 of them have been installed here to constitute a kind of partial, semipermanent retrospective of Mr. di Suvero's 40-year career. Situated in Mountainville, in New York's Hudson Valley, Storm King is a breathtaking setting for the display of outdoor sculpture. Its 500-acre property encompasses woods, a stream, several ponds, alfalfa fields, lawns and rolling hills. No outdoor sculpture park in the world that I know has such an attractive natural setting.

DULMAN--Dorothy, age 77, loving wife of the late Howard Dulman, mother of David and Laura Dulman, Abby and Barry Simon, Melissa and Troy Hangen, passed away June 23, 2006 in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Adored Nanny to Aaron, Rebecca, Annie, Michael, Spencer, Julie and Claudia. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, June 26, 10:30 AM. Lifelong New Yorker and part time Floridian, longtime member of Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, NY. An accomplished artist and sculptor, she enjoyed many trips overseas and especially loved Italy.

ON this week's cover, Luc Sante, the author of ''Low Life: Lures and Snares of Old New York,'' reviews Robert Greenfield's biography of Timothy Leary. When the Book Review first approached Sante about the assignment, he said he had always wanted to write something about Leary. Why? ''Because I'm interested in the 1960's,'' he explained in an e-mail message, ''and that time is now sufficiently distant that things are coming out, the location of the buried bodies, so to speak.'' Starting in 1968, Sante commuted from New Jersey to high school in Manhattan. ''Nearly every day I bought underground newspapers, from all over the country, at newsstands. They usually cost a quarter. I was a very critical under-age observer of the scene. As a kid of that time, I was checking everything out, including psychedelics, which fascinated me almost as much as they scared me.''

JAHODA--Maria C. Died June 16, 2006 at her home in NYC after a brief illness. Born in Vienna on November 13, 1922, she moved permanently to the U.S. in the early 1980's. Mirli was a font of joy and good will to many and she will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held in NYC at a later date.

A picture caption with a report in the Evening Hours column last Sunday, about the Northside Center for Child Development dinner on June 8, misspelled the surname of a guest. She is Camille O. Cosby, not Crosby.

Don't be fooled by the rather bland name Caribbean Cuisine. This 10-year-old spot in South Orange specializing in Trinidadian fare -- typically a blend of Spanish, Indian, Chinese and Creole elements -- has more character than a carnival stilt walker, and the flavors to back it up. Though many regulars order takeout, there are nine tables. Curried chicken (the friendly woman behind the counter will ask how hot you want it) arrives wrapped in warm, soft roti bread ($8). A mound of expertly seasoned okra rice with plump shrimp ($10.95), a lunch special, comes with fried plantains or cabbage salad.

If only because museum exhibitions of dog paintings are a rare occurrence, the show now at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich -- which for the last couple of years has been organizing intelligent and scholarly exhibitions -- should be given a chance by visitors, no matter how skeptical they may be. For ''Best in Show: Dogs in Art From the Renaissance to the Present,'' Robert Rosenblum, Peter Sutton and Edgar Peters Bowron, the curators, have brought together several dozen images of dogs from Europe and America created over the last 500 years. George Stubbs, Th√©odore G√©ricault and Thomas Gainsborough are on the checklist, as well as less likely figures like Giovanni Battista Tiepolo, Tracey Emin and Andy Warhol.

JACKSON--Ernest. On June 2. Husband of Linda Kovach. Father of Garrick Jackson of Maitland, FL, granddaughter Cheree Rumley Miawama, her daughter Zahra of Alpharetta, GA, great-grandson, Roman Francis of PA. A jazz memorial service will be held at St. Peter's Church, corner of 54th and Lexington, 7 PM, July 2, 2006.

A picture caption last Sunday with the continuation of the article about the Ring Road in Iceland incompletely described the scene shown. It was a warm pool near Lake Myvatn that is called Blue Lagoon. It was not the more famous Blue Lagoon, near Reykjavik, which was mentioned in the article.

FIRST an elderly couple in a beige sedan crept by, fascinated by the strange contraption screwed to the hood of a gleaming red S.U.V. A few minutes later, a pair of fishermen in a battered pickup truck stopped, glaring at crew members huddled in the roadway over a snake's nest of cables. Even in June, the remote spot in Hampton Bays where Dune Road meets the Shinnecock Canal is just for locals. But on a recent morning it morphed into command central for ''Easy Driver,'' an Italian television program featuring beautiful people cruising beautiful places in flashy, expensive cars. The show spent four days taping on the South Fork before heading to the Catskills. ''You should have seen us last week in Manhattan,'' said Christina Emma, a producer. ''We had a Ferrari.''

To the Editor: Re ''Our World Cup Edge,'' by David Brooks (column, June 22): While I certainly take no issue with touting academics over sports, I wonder whether Mr. Brooks wore rose-colored glasses to view the ''dynamic'' American university system.

COLE--Mark Allen. Died Sunday, June 18, 2006. Mark was a licensed Real Estate Broker in Connecticut and New York, for 25 years with Vincent and Whittemore of Bedford Village, NY. Born November 3, 1944, Mark is survived by devoted life partner of 28 years, Steven Carty; beloved sister Francine and her husband, Joseph Tumulo of Long Island, nephew Todd Schoen and his wife, Ginger, of Wrightsville Beach, North Carolina. A memorial service will be held Monday, June 26, 2006 at 11:30 AM at Conant Hall, Pound Ridge, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

To stand in the early morning before the curved glass counter at the Bedford Pastry Shop is to face the best possible sort of existential crisis. Prune danish or poppy-seed? Bear claw or brioche? A little bell rings as customers enter. They help themselves to coffee from silver thermoses, somehow manage to make a selection and walk out happy. For almost 10 years in this location, Michel Rossignol, baker and owner, has been whipping up a perfect blend of butter, sugar, flour and yeast, with waves of butter cream thrown in for good measure. His picturesque breakfast rings -- wreaths of leafy pastry filled with almond paste, or apricot or raspberry jam, or bursting with pecans, raisins or poppy seeds -- are favorites. Packed into a neat white box and tied with cotton string, they make welcome gifts ($7.50 to $8).

CHESKIN--Joel Richard. Died June 21, 2006. A tenured professor in mathematics at Marymount College, Tarrytown, he also taught at Mercy College, Manhattanville College and was in private practice tutoring mathematics. He was very much beloved and will be truly missed by his family. Survived by his parents Irving and Mildred (Estrin) Cheskin, daughters Jessica (Mark) Cheskin Wilson and Julie Cheskin, granddaughter Kira Wilson. Funeral service private. Contributions to the Actor's Fund.

Unlikely friendships can make good theater. A white Southern Jewish matron and her black chauffeur grow close in Alfred Uhry's ''Driving Miss Daisy.'' The New York writer Helene Hanff and her London bookseller develop something rich and meaningful without ever meeting in the epistolary ''84 Charing Cross Road.'' And in Joanna McClelland Glass's ''Trying,'' a crusty old liberal judge who knows he is not long for this world disdains, dislikes, is annoyed by and eventually cares deeply about his new 25-year-old secretary. The outstanding production of ''Trying'' now at TheaterWorks in Hartford features Michael McGuire, a Drama Desk award winner for ''That Championship Season,'' as Francis Biddle and Lena Kaminsky as his new employee, Sarah Schorr, the alter ego of Ms. Glass, who did, in fact, work for Biddle before his death in 1968.

To the Editor: The food issue (May 28)was most enjoyable. I especiallyliked reading Amanda Hesser's Cookbook Chronicle, wherein I found ''Saucepans and the Single Girl.'' I lived in New York City in the late 60's, and my roommate and I used that book all the time (except for the canned stuff -- my roommate came from Wisconsin so we didn't go the canned route too often. I do have to admit to Jell-O, however). Therecipes were really quite good, and we happily served many to ourselves and to guests. The No. 1 winner was the ''special salad,'' a forerunner of today's ubiquitous greens with protein and an egg dressing. I would immediately rush out and buy the reissue, but the 1965 copy is still on my cookbook shelf. Eugenie Sherer Norwalk, Conn.

GORELL--Frank. The family of The Curtis Institute of Music mourns the loss of its devoted friend Frank Gorell and extends deepest sympathy to his family. A recipient of Curtis's Alumni Award, he shared his profound commitment to young musicians through projects such as the young artists' series at the Raymond F. Kravis Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. He also served Curtis as an overseer and a trustee. His pride in his musical training and his unwavering dedication will long inspire us. Roberto Diaz, President H.F. (Gerry) Lenfest, Chairman The Curtis Institute of Music

WALTER HILL's ''BROKEN TRAIL'' (AMC, Sunday at 8 p.m.) bucks recent trends in the western genre: the cowboys aren't gay, and they don't curse. And yet this slow-paced, atmospheric mini-series manages to be arresting anyway; its expansive scenery and laconic screenplay are laced with an undercurrent of dread. THOMAS HADEN CHURCH, who looks gaunt after his puffy ''SIDEWAYS'' turn, and ROBERT DUVALL play two decent ranchers looking for a place of their own. Along the way they run into five Chinese women who have been sold into slavery and decide to help them. Which means Trouble with a capital T. (Part 2 is Monday at 8 p.m.) Look out, vampires; the corny ''BLADE'' trilogy has been adapted for television (Spike, Wednesday at 10 p.m.). KIRK JONES, also known as STICKY FINGAZ, will try to capture the impassive, cartoonish campiness WESLEY SNIPES brought to the movie role. Also of potential interest to comic fans this week is ''THE SCIENCE OF SUPERMAN'' (National Geographic Channel, Thursday at 9 p.m.). This tie-in with ''SUPERMAN RETURNS'' dissects all of Clark Kent's super powers in the comics, the movies and on television, and attempts to put them into a scientific context. While that's crazy, it's also embarrassingly pleasurable to hear physicists describe how Superman would have actually crushed Lois -- not saved her -- when he flew up to catch her as she fell from atop a building. (Because she would have reached terminal velocity.) The documentary ''BOFFO! TINSELTOWN'S BOMBS & BLOCKBUSTERS'' (HBO, Thursday at 9 p.m.) is a breezy examination of what makes a movie successful. The film's talking heads -- GEORGE CLOONEY, JODIE FOSTER, PETER GUBER and others -- say ''no one knows'' for 75 amusing minutes. BRIAN GRAZER offers one unintentional gem, when he admits that he has wished failure upon others, and then has to specify that he doesn't mean his friends. That's Hollywood.

THE Fairfield Board of Education voted late last month to have the town's two high schools start their day 20 minutes later, beginning in the fall, part of a movement around the state to get teenagers more sleep. Greenwich P.T.A. members have been asking the school board to consider a delay, and board members in West Hartford have also been discussing later start times. Other schools have also looked into the issue, but have made no changes. Wilton became the first school district in the state to make the change when it delayed middle and high school starting times by almost an hour in 2003.

FIALKOW--Dr. Morris N. 92, died peacefully on Friday. Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, father-in-law, brother-in-law and friend. An accomplished civil engineer for over 40 years, he served as chief of the design branch for the Army Corp of Engineers. A world traveler, bridge player and opera lover. He will be deeply missed. Burial on Sunday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

To the Editor: ''Perfect Vision, via Surgery, Is Helping and Hurting Navy'' (front page, June 20), in describing the laser eye surgery procedure known as photorefractive keratectomy, or PRK, states, ''Rather than slicing into the cornea covering, Navy doctors grind it away.'' The use of the verb ''grind'' connotes a process involving high abrasion and friction, with trauma to the surrounding tissue. Nothing could be further from the truth.

MIGUEL HERN√ÅNDEZ of Ossining is the only Hispanic mayor in New York State, though that distinction took effect early this month and will last only until year's end. Still, what a statement those seven months will be about how polychrome Cheever country has become. Most Americans still think of Westchester as white, and white bread, except when an urban anomaly like Yonkers conquers that stereotype. But the county, like the country, turns out to have lots of everything, even in its villages. In Ossining, Port Chester, and Sleepy Hollow, Hispanics are a major force.
SOMMER--Gregg,We miss you so much. You're always in our hearts. Happy Birthday! Mom & Dad

Taking a cue from Manhattan's Chelsea district, with its warehouses and garages reinvented as sleek showcases for contemporary art, two new East Hampton galleries have brought the same look to former industrial spaces on eastern Long Island. One is an adapted commercial unit in a complex that also houses carpentry and landscaping businesses; the other is a former automobile repair shop in Springs. The Fireplace Project, at 851 Springs-Fireplace Road, anchors a small commercial strip that includes a liquor store, a pizza restaurant and Hampton Auto Collision. The building, formerly Talmage's Garage, has been handsomely adapted as an exhibition space but retains much of its utilitarian character. The walls in the main gallery are clean white sheetrock, but the original overhead garage door, the knotty pine paneling in what was the office and the bare concrete floor have been preserved. Instead of car parts, the building now houses dusky landscape paintings by David Ryan, and Wayne White's eye-catching multicolored sculpture of welded lettering sits in the front yard.

For the White House, the Congressional picnic last week seemed like the perfect setting to mend strained relations with Republican allies on Capitol Hill: President Bush and his advisers eating taquitos and Mexican confetti rice on the lawn of the White House with Republican Congressional leaders. But moments before Mr. Bush was to welcome his guests, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert told the president that House Republicans were effectively sidelining -- and in the view of some Congressional aides probably killing -- what had become Mr. Bush's signature domestic initiative of the year: an overhaul of the nation's immigration laws.

GRUBER--Samuel. 1913-2006. We, the family of Samuel Gruber, will love and miss him forever. He was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He lived his life with humility and dignity. He was an underground fighter in Poland against Nazism and wrote the book, ''I Chose Life.'' Israel was his passion and he had many friends there. He leaves his wife Judith, sons Jack and Mark, three grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren.

THE Fairfield Board of Education voted late last month to have the town's two high schools start their day 20 minutes later, beginning in the fall, part of a movement around the state to get teenagers more sleep. Greenwich P.T.A. members have been asking the school board to consider a delay, and board members in West Hartford have also been discussing later start times. Other schools have also looked into the issue, but have made no changes. Wilton became the first school district in the state to make the change when it delayed middle and high school starting times by almost an hour in 2003.

FIRST an elderly couple in a beige sedan crept by, fascinated by the strange contraption screwed to the hood of a gleaming red S.U.V. A few minutes later, a pair of fishermen in a battered pickup truck stopped, glaring at crew members huddled in the roadway over a snake's nest of cables. Even in June, the remote spot in Hampton Bays where Dune Road meets the Shinnecock Canal is just for locals. But on a recent morning it morphed into command central for ''Easy Driver,'' an Italian television program featuring beautiful people cruising beautiful places in flashy, expensive cars. The show spent four days taping on the South Fork before heading to the Catskills. ''You should have seen us last week in Manhattan,'' said Christina Emma, a producer. ''We had a Ferrari.''

To the Editor: Elizabeth Marshall Thomas misses the point in her review of ''Kicked, Bitten, and Scratched,'' by Amy Sutherland (June 4), when she states that: ''Despite the beliefs of animal rights activists, many captive animals welcome their training. . . . Training gives them a life.'' Wild animals have a life -- it is in the wild. Keeping them in captivity, trained or otherwise, for human entertainment deprives them of that life. If species conservation is important (which it is), it should be done on huge reserves that simulate the natural environment, which means keeping animals away from people. It is hard to imagine that Thomas really believes that the trained animals she describes benefit in any way from their puppetlike existence, or that they are much better off than wild animals kept in zoos. Joann Stephan St. Louis

New York art rock is full of isms: primitivism, conceptualism, minimalism, eclecticism, stoicism and skepticism, along with some basic intransigence. TV ON THE RADIO, from Brooklyn, has given the nervous New York rock drone -- as handed down from the Velvet Underground via punk -- at least two twists of its own. Electronics, like mechanistic drum machines and pulsating sustained tones that can fill every cranny of a mix, can make songs sound both exhilarating and claustrophobic, while vocal harmonies hint at the sweetness of old doo-wop. The band hasn't released a full-length album since ''Desperate Youth, Blood Thirsty Babes'' in 2004, but a new one is in the works. Friday at 6:30 p.m., Celebrate Brooklyn, Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Park Slope, (718) 855-7882; $3 donation requested. THE LIARS are far less ingratiating. They're an austere and single-minded band whose songs can be little more than a slow drumbeat and a keening melody, sometimes jarred by some extra guitar noise. The band is an all-or-nothing proposition. Anyone who doesn't find them mesmerizing will find them pretentious and annoying. Monday at 8 p.m., Avalon, 662 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 807-7780; $15 in advance, $16 at the door. THE FIERY FURNACES are led by MATT and ELEANOR FRIEDBERGER, siblings originally from Chicago. Their songs delve into memories and visions, sometimes harking back to 1960's pop, sometimes with a frenetic drive that's like carnivalesque punk. Their latest album, ''Bitter Tea'' (Fat Possum), relies on keyboards, but their Web site promises a live show with songs rearranged around guitar. Thursday at 6 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111; $20.

TARNER--Stanley P. , 83. Of Meriden, CT. Formerly of Mount Washington, MA. Died June 10, he was the husband of Elizabeth Tarner. Mr. Tarner was bourn March 10th, 1923 in Piraeux, Greece. The son of the late Philip and Catherine (Papalazaros-Tarner). He served in the US Navy from 1942-1946. Mr. Tarner attended the Brooklyn Conservatory of music and Juilliard school in New York where he received a Rhodes scholarship to study at the University of Oxford in England. He later became a professional Jazz musician, playing drums, piano and percussion. In the 1950's he was a producer and director for ABC radio in New York. He was Agency music, TV an radio producer at J. Walter Thompson advertising in New York from 1961-1979 when he retired. He was a award winning jingle writer and received a ''Clio'' award for writing and producing the 1968 Ford Mustang commercial. Most importantly Stan has been acknowledged by his family and friends for being the most loving, decent and civil man this world has ever known. Besides his wife Mr. Tarner is survived by two sons; John Jetter and his wife Trish of Saint Petersburg, FL. And Brian Tarner and his wife Sherry of Mt. Kisco, NY. A daughter Elizabeth Abbatiello and her husband Martin of Cheshire, CT. A sister Mary Dowling and her husband Richard of New Fairfield, CT. seven grandchildren, one great grandchild and several nieces and nephews. Funeral services are private, Memorial contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society. PO BOX 1004 Meriden, CT 06450.

A DECADE ago my husband and I bought what our real-estate agent kindly called ''a rather unique parcel'' -- three overgrown acres with a crooked Cape Cod, a goat barn and a chicken coop. It sits atop a steep, winding private road in the western Connecticut woods in a seven-home enclave herein called the Hill. Soon after we moved in, the Hill's elder statesman, a 70-ish bachelor, introduced himself at the mailboxes. Saying that he ''knew the property,'' he bade us good luck with the kindly gravitas of a funeral director. ''I'm Franc,'' he went on, ''though I'm sure some people call me the neighborhood fusspot.''

Nassau County has moved into the state's recycling forefront by deciding to use re-refined motor oil in its public vehicles. Instead of buying virgin motor oil and hydraulic fluids, the county earlier this year started buying re-refined oil -- used oil that has been processed to remove contaminants and then blended with additives to produce motor oil or hydraulic oil. The county expects to save as much as $25,000 this year as a result.

Melissa Floren, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas C. Floren of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to David William Filippone, a son of Catherine E. Filippone of Paradise Valley, Ariz., and the late Charles A. Filippone. Betty M. Ralston, a deacon, officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Steamboat Springs, Colo. Mrs. Filippone, 32, graduated cum laude from Princeton and is a chartered financial analyst. She is a portfolio manager at DCF Capital, a Greenwich hedge fund of which her father is the managing partner. Her mother, Olivia R. Floren, is a Republican state representative whose district includes Greenwich, Stamford and Norwalk.

To the Editor: Your article on how some overly busy people are thrilled when plans are canceled so they can finally have some free time omitted the obvious solution to their hectic schedules. To avoid being booked for every possible spare moment, these people can simply schedule themselves some free time. It's not hard to enter ''Relax'' or ''Read'' or ''Sleep'' or ''Play'' into the calendar. And then when someone calls to schedule something for that time, they can truthfully say, ''I'm sorry, I already have something on my calendar.'' Shaun Breidbart Pelham, N.Y.

POST--Sheldon. 9/5/36-6/25/88. Founder, Chelsea Pines Inn. As we pause today for a moment to recall those we loved & lost in the still-raging battle against AIDS, think of Sheldon, an early leader in our community, a man who fought hard to do the right thing, no matter the cost. He would have been amazed to see where we are today, & should be very proud of the part he played. Please join my spouse Tom Klebba & me as we recall them all, especially Gary Olde, Peter Monette and Mark Fuschetti, whose lives & spirits will live on. ''Hard to see the light now. Just don't let it go. Things will come out right now. We can make it so'': Stephen Sondheim. Rest well, my love, & know that you & all the others have made it so. Jay Lesiger
O'BRIEN--Lois Levin.It has been ten years since we last saw your smile and heard your clear, practical words. We are still heartbroken, each in his own way. Rest in peace, beloved. Jack and Jeremiah

I found your articles on debt troubling. Why tell us what we already know: Spike Gillespie's being tormented by collection agencies or Walter Kirn's misguided beliefs regarding lenders or how Starlee Kine's identity was stolen by her mother? And then Rob Walker tells us, in the Consumed column, about how well Cash America treats its customers and about the ''financial solutions'' it provides, at 4 percent to 25 percent a month. My goodness, I almost want to buy its stock. Norman H. Perlmutter Morganville, N.J.

CLIPBOARD in hand, Mike Thompson climbed the stoop of a well-kept, two-story home here and rang the bell. Ethel Corsale, a 79-year-old widow, answered and listened as Mr. Thompson, a 23-year-old organizer for the nonprofit Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, or Acorn, explained why she should support Gov. Jon S. Corzine's proposed sales tax increase. Mrs. Corsale agreed to write a note to her state legislators, dictated by Mr. Thompson, asking them to vote to increase the sales tax by 1 cent.
HOLSTEIN - Robert. Died May 30. Beloved by his friends, Bob will be missed. Donations: Humane Society of New York, 212-752-4840.

BLINDING LIGHT, by Paul Theroux. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) In this Faustian allegory Slade Steadman, a rich and rather grumpy middle-aged writer with only one published work to his name, travels to Ecuador to drink a hallucinogenic brew he hopes will stimulate his creativity. Disappointed by the experience, he turns to another drug, expensive and rare (and fictional), that heightens both his powers of perception and his libido, but also leaves him with an unfortunate side effect: periodic blindness. Under the influence Steadman is reinvigorated, and satisfies his sexual fantasies while writing a novel of erotic exploration. But this forbidden knowledge comes at a price, and Steadman, like Dr. Faustus, rises high, then falls far and fast. In the Book Review Hari Kunzru called ''Blinding Light'' a ''bravura performance.''

''I'm what a lot of people call a pioneer in the quilting revival,'' Virginia Avery said, and to illustrate just how far she has come as a quilter, she walked into the living room of her 18th-century house in Port Chester and pointed to the wall. Hanging above the sofa was her first quilt, a 4-foot-by-4-foot traditional pattern called a Snail's Trail in red and white, which she made in the late 1960's.

WEIDENBACHER--Richard L. Jr., M.D., aged 76, a psychiatrist on the Forensic Psychiatry Service at Kings County Hospital since 1973, died suddenly on May 10, 2006. He was a graduate of Princeton and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. Dick, who was well known for his sharp intellect, elegant writing, and compassion for his patients, was involved in psychiatric evaluations for the courts for some of the area's highest profile criminal cases. He placed a premium on objectivity, loved to teach colleagues and students. Driven by his love of medicine he did residencies in pathology and surgery. He also studied Arabic, Japanese, Greek, comparative religions, and anthropology. After completing his residency in general psychiatry at Kings County Hospital in 1968, he joined the U. S. Navy Medical Corps as a psychiatrist attached to the First Marine Division in Da Nang. Upon his return he did a residency in child psychiatry at Columbia Presbyterian. Survivors include his sister, Lee Winborne and many nieces and nephews to whom he was very devoted. The family suggests donations in his memory to St. Andrew's Presbyterian College, 1700 Dogwood Mile, Laurinburg, NC 28352. A memorial gathering will take place at Kings County Hospital on June 28, 2006, 3 PM, at Kings County Hospital, G Building.

Kudos for a comprehensive issue on the increasingly trenchant topic of America's debt (June 11). I found Niall Ferguson's article ''Reasons to Worry'' of particular interest. His comparison of the national debt to an adjustable-rate mortgage made the problem uncomfortably real, since most of us with such mortgages are dreading the date our teaser rates change into real rates. One crucial point that could conceivably alter Ferguson's dire prediction that our creditors will desert us for others, leaving the United States no choice but to borrow at ''subprime'' rates, is the lack of viable alternative investments. Asthe size of our deficit and the size of our mortgage debtcontinue toskyrocket, it isincreasingly evident that the creditorsfeeding these gigantic mouths will have no choice but to continue. Maureen Bolton Cedar Rapids, Iowa I want to compliment you on your debt-focused issue. I thoroughly enjoyed reading every article on this timely (and yet disturbingly historic) topic. Justine Bateman Studio City, Calif.

To the Editor: I am a performer, not a critic, but because I had a following in Dallas, the promoters of a show there asked me to contribute a quote to help sell tickets for the singing-songwriting trio the Burns Sisters. I love the Burns Sisters: they are beautiful, have that harmony thing that only family members have, and happen to have big heads of gorgeous hair. So this is the quote I gave them: ''The Burns Sisters: great voices, great songs, great hair. I hate them!'' I don't know who made the mistake, but the newspaper ads and posters carried this quote instead: ''The Burns Sisters: I hate them!'' -- Christine Lavin. Fortunately the mistake drew more attention than the original ad would have, and they sold out. Whew! Christine Lavin Manhattan

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday on the minor league hockey team in Danbury misspelled the name of the team at one point. They are the Trashers, not the Thrashers. The error was repeated in the headline and caption.

Alyson Tischler and John Christian Eberhart were married last evening at the Cranwell Resort, Spa and Golf Club in Lenox, Mass. Donna Lippman, an interfaith minister, officiated. Ms. Tischler, 33, is keeping her name. She is a research director for health care in the Norwalk, Conn., office of Harris Interactive, a Rochester-based market research company. She graduated from Wesleyan University and received master's and doctoral degrees in English language and literature from the University of Michigan.

DANIEL--Ruth. The World Union for Progressive Judaism notes with profound sadness the passing of Ruth Daniel, our beloved friend and longtime leader, past vice president and treasurer. Her vision, passion and support were invaluable in contributing to the growth and strengthening of Progressive Judaism in Israel and Reform Jewish communities throughout the world. A native of Germany, Ruth escaped the Holocaust by moving to Tel Aviv, and always retained an abiding love for that city, even after moving to the U.S. With her husband Gerry, a past president of the World Union, she helped make possible the construction of Beit Daniel in Tel Aviv, Israel's largest Reform synagogue and community center. Her illness unfortunately prevented her from attending the June 18th dedication of Mishkenot Daniel, the Reform cultural and education center, youth hostel and synagogue in Tel Aviv-Jaffa, attended by the nation's leading government and religious dignitaries. She will be sorely missed but forever remembered for her love of, and commitment to, the dream of Progressive Judaism in the Jewish state. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her husband, children and grandchildren. Steven Bauman, Chairman Rabbi Uri Regev, President $(6$)DANIEL--Ruth. The Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledges with sorrow the passing of Ruth Daniel. A longstanding trustee and more recently honorary board member, Ruth served as chair of the agency's Jewish Conciliation Board. She was a very devoted supporter of JBFCS Volunteer Services. Our condolences to her husband Gerard and the entire family. John A Herrmann, President Alan B. Siskind, Executive V.P. & CEO Paul Levine, Associate Executive V.P.

LAURIN--Eleanor M. On June 21, 2006. Loving mother of Kristin and Gerald (Rachael). Dear friend of Geraldine, Maureen and Leah. Best friend to all and the strongest person we all have ever known and loved.

A man's home is his castle'' goes the adage, which finds perhaps its most literal representation in the fanciful cottage of Wemmick, a London clerk in Charles Dickens's novel ''Great Expectations.'' Although Wemmick's home is tiny, he has modified it to resemble a Gothic fortress of sorts, complete with a plank drawbridge, a moat and a ''turret bedroom.'' While there is no evidence of a run on Dickens novels in area bookstores, much less a conscious emulation of Wemmick, turrets have been popping up with increasing frequency on upscale suburban homes around New York City.

DARLING--George F., 70, of Providence RI and formerly of East 77th Street, New York City, died June 16. Mr. Darling was the vice president of Regatta Sport in New York City. He was a former member of the New York Athletic Club and the Broadway Theatre League. He leaves a sister, nieces and a nephew. The funeral and burial was in Providence, RI. Donations in his memory may be made to Hospice Outreach, 502 Bedford Street, Fall River, MA 02720.

Because of an editing error, a review on June 11 about ''The Good Fight,'' a book on American liberalism by Peter Beinart, gave an incorrect source for a quotation by Harry S. Truman that illustrated one of his foreign-policy principles. It was in a speech at the 1945 United Nations conference on international organization in San Francisco, not in his 1949 Inaugural Address, that he said, ''We all have to recognize -- no matter how great our strength -- that we must deny ourselves the license to do always as we please.
RIPPS--David.Missed every day and always remembered with love. Mommy, Daddy, Van, Leah and Emily

A DECADE ago my husband and I bought what our real-estate agent kindly called ''a rather unique parcel'' -- three overgrown acres with a crooked Cape Cod, a goat barn and a chicken coop. It sits atop a steep, winding private road in the western Connecticut woods in a seven-home enclave herein called the Hill. Soon after we moved in, the Hill's elder statesman, a 70-ish bachelor, introduced himself at the mailboxes. Saying that he ''knew the property,'' he bade us good luck with the kindly gravitas of a funeral director. ''I'm Franc,'' he went on, ''though I'm sure some people call me the neighborhood fusspot.''

Jon Gertner's description of the income-contingent, loan-repayment program in Australia and New Zealand, while fair, neglected to address the adverse consequences of the program -- well, for the government. Many students emigrate from Australia and New Zealand after graduation (often to Britain) because there is higher earning potential abroad and also to avoid repaying loans (since their income is no longer being taxed by their ''home'' governments). This being said, I believe that a similar program might reasonably work in the United States because American students are less apt (and have less opportunity) to move abroad. The devastating cost of higher education certainly makes it worth exploring! Christopher Petersen Chicago I was wondering why the cover of the Money issue referred to debt as ''America's scariest addiction.'' The articles by Jon Gertner, Alex Kotlowitz and Starlee Kine all show that borrowing is often a necessity, and that debt, like greatness, can be thrust upon us. Rahul Sharma New Brunswick, N.J.

A credit last Sunday for a picture of the art dealer David Zwirner with an article about artists leaving their longtime galleries misstated the surname of the photographer. She is Dana Lixenberg, not Luxenberg.

Re ''Preventing a Second Jayson Blair'' (June 18): During my career as a cell biologist, I have heard and read about countless cases of junior researchers fabricating data even at the most prestigious universities and medical schools. As with the Jayson Blair affair, many of these scandals were the result of inadequate or complete lack of supervision by senior staff.

With the summer driving season under way, thousands of people in Westchester County are feeling the sting of soaring prices at the pump. Those who rely on public transportation have mostly been immune, but in Mount Vernon at least, that is about to change. Starting on July 1, the cost of taking a cab in Mount Vernon will jump by at least 50 cents and could go as high as a dollar, depending on how far gasoline prices continue to climb. The Mount Vernon Taxi Commission asked for the surcharge earlier this year to help offset costs for taxi drivers after gasoline prices surpassed $3 a gallon. The City Council voted to approve the request on June 14.

Diane Farr, an actor in television and film, was married yesterday to Seung Yong Chung, an entertainment marketing executive. Barry G. Littman, a film executive who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Rainbow Tarns, a lodge in Mammoth Lakes, Calif. Five Buddhist monks also participated in the ceremony. Ms. Farr, 36, is keeping her name. She is a star of ''Numb3rs'' on CBS. She is also the author of ''The Girl Code: The Secret Language of Single Women'' (Little, Brown, 2001), and owns OtherAnnouncements.com, an online greeting card company. She graduated magna cum laude from the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

WARD POUND RIDGE RESERVATION, a 4,700-acre preserve in Cross River, N.Y., is one of the finest places in the Northeast to find butterflies. Today, as in earlier times, a watchful visitor will be impressed by the luxuriant chaos of a busy meadow in mid-July when the number and variety of species of butterflies reach their peak. In this busy jumble, scores of butterflies can be observed jostling for position on dogbane and milkweed blossoms. Elegant, gliding monarchs and swallowtails will land to sip nectar alongside smaller, fast-darting skippers. In all, more than 80 butterfly species have been recorded at the reservation, including more than 65 percent of all the species that commonly reside in New York State.

AS David Acker greets the class of aspiring emergency medical technicians on the first day of the summer session at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut, you're not exactly sure if he's welcoming them or trying to run them off. ''You get disrespected so much in this job,'' Mr. Acker said, leaning on a lectern in his blue paramedic's uniform at the hospital's Emergency Medical Services Institute. ''At least now it's good we have doctors riding with us in the field, so they can see what it's like when you're lying in the puke in the snowbank at 3 a.m. trying to intubate someone, or when you're bouncing down the highway, going 65 and trying to start an IV. I've been called every name in the book.''

On Nov. 29 and Feb. 28, the Op-Ed page published articles co-written by Stephen E. Flynn, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, on the need to scan shipping containers. An article last Monday in the news pages of The Times reported that Mr. Flynn had earlier been a paid consultant to Science Applications International Corporation, which manufactured a container-scanning system. The Times's Op-Ed contract compels contributors to disclose potential conflicts of interest, but not past ones. In this regard, Mr. Flynn did not violate the contract. However, had the editors known of Mr. Flynn's previous relationship with Science Applications International, they would have made that information available to readers.

In some circles it is not baseball or the end of school or the solstice that signals the start of summer, but an outdoor performance of ''A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM,'' preferably near a spot ''where oxlips and the nodding violet grows.'' O.K., so I can't really vouch for the oxlips or nodding violets, but there is no doubt that theaters outside New York City offer some luscious settings for their annual summer productions, Shakespearean or otherwise. This year you can spend a ''Midsummer Night'' at the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival in Garrison, N.Y., which is marking its 20th anniversary. Whatever the reviews, the backdrop -- sunset over the Hudson River -- is always spectacular. www.hvshakespeare.org, (845) 265-9575. You can stay in the area and try out a new production of ''CAMILLE'' at Bard College's SUMMERSCAPE. www.fishercenter.bard.edu, (845) 758-7900. Or try traveling east to Massachusetts and the Berkshires for more mountains and more theaters. At SHAKESPEARE & COMPANY in Lenox, bring a picnic and hang out at its Bankside Festival for a lecture, demonstration and short family-friendly performance before going in for ''HAMLET'' or ''ENCHANTED APRIL.'' www.shakespeare.org, (413) 637-1199. Maybe you'll get lucky and see a Broadway preview. The BARRINGTON STAGE COMPANY in Pittsfield, where the hit ''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee'' was created, is hoping magic strikes again with one of its MUSICAL THEATER LAB productions. www.barringtonstageco.org, (413) 236-8888. At the BERKSHIRE THEATER FESTIVAL in Stockbridge, last year's production of ''Souvenir'' ended up moving to Broadway. The play lost money, but its star, Judy Kaye, won a Tony nomination. This year STEPHEN TEMPERLEY, the playwright, and VIVIAN MATALON, the director, have teamed up again for a new political satire, ''THE PILGRIM PAPERS.'' www.berkshiretheatre.org, (413) 298-5576. It is the Tony-winning WILLIAMSTOWN THEATER where you're most likely to see boldface names on or behind the stage. At the swanky new theater complex, you can see classics like ''ANYTHING GOES'' (with SHARON LAWRENCE) and ''ROMEO AND JULIET'' as well as new works, including a play directed and written, with RICK ELICE, by the theater's artistic director, ROGER REES. wtfestival.org, (413) 597-3400.

To the Editor: My thanks to Bob Morris for bringing back a cherished memory (''To Dad, Anytime,'' June 18). I, too, was with my father during the last stages of an illness. He looked up from his hospital bed at me, my wife, my sister and my mother (the grandchildren were dropping by later) with a quizzical expression and asked, ''Why are all of you here so much?'' When I answered simply that we were all there because we loved him and wanted to be with him, he reacted with amazement and then cried with understanding. That was the best Father's Day each of us ever had. Bertram Perkel Wellfleet, Mass.

YOU may not be able to discern my secret, because I am in disguise this summer, camouflaged by a college-age son living at home for a few months. But really, my husband and I are stealth parents, the ones lingering around the edges of suburban life, the ones who no longer fit into this child-centric universe. We are the empty nesters -- clich√©-ridden, childless, but hardly alone. Nationwide, there are about 70 million parents born between 1946 and 1964, and within the next 10 years or so, nearly all of our youngest children will graduate from high school and move on. In the New York metropolitan area, which includes Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Long Island, northern New Jersey and southern Connecticut, half of married-couple households no longer include children under the age of 18, according to the 2000 census data. Soon, we boomers will be one big child-free family, figuring out where and how to live without our little ones.

HANSEN--William P. Born August 9, 1940 died on June 9, 2006. He was an editor and writer for American Heritage, Random House and Chelsea House. After graduating from University of Wisconsin he studied at NYU and started his literary career. His works covered a wide range of topics from drugs to shells, world leaders and even comic books. His reference works on American politics and history are tomes for the ages. His wit, incredible sense of humor, playfulness, curiosity and powerful mind were a gift to all who knew and worked with him. He will be missed forever by his wife Janet and his daughter Nadja who found in him the most patient and loving of soulmates.
PART 10

Jay Williams's return to the basketball court will be accompanied by an important memento. He says he plans to wear a No. 2 jersey, a change from his No. 22 and a reminder of his second chance -- in basketball, but most of all, in life.

Two new movies this week look at the complexities of life after 9/11 at home and abroad. ''THE ROAD TO GUANT√ÅNAMO'' is a thought-provoking documentary that reflects the complicated situation we are in. Directed by MICHAEL WINTERBOTTOM and MAT WHITECROSS, it details the incarceration of three British Muslims captured during combat in Afghanistan after 9/11 and sent to Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, where they claim to have been tortured. The prisoners, known as the Tipton Three, are portrayed as na√Øve or nefarious young men (you decide) who chose to place themselves in a war zone at an extremely inopportune moment in East-West history. As depicted in the film their treatment since being arrested is shocking, and edifying. If not fundamentalists before, the three men, who have since been released, certainly appear to have become fundamentalists during their incarceration. In New York at the Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets, Greenwich Village, (212) 995-2000, and the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway at 63rd Street, (212) 757-2280, as well as at theaters in Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington; it will open in two weeks in more cities. ''THE GREAT NEW WONDERFUL,'' set in New York a year after 9/11, is just the latest film to deal with the aftershocks of the attacks. Starring MAGGIE GYLLENHAAL, OLYMPIA DUKAKIS and TONY SHALHOUB, the movie follows the lives of five New Yorkers as they deal with the trauma. Here's an incongruous note: The drama is directed by DANNY LEINER, who directed the stoner comedies ''Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle'' and ''Dude, Where's My Car?'' In this new film he takes a stab at substance and emotion. Now playing in New York at the Angelika; AMC Empire 25, 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue, (212) 398-3939; and United Artists at 64th Street and Second Avenue, (212) 832-1670, and in Washington and Boston.

''A man's home is his castle'' goes the adage, which finds perhaps its most literal representation in the fanciful cottage of Wemmick, a London clerk in Charles Dickens's novel ''Great Expectations.'' Although Wemmick's home is tiny, he has modified it to resemble a Gothic fortress of sorts, complete with a plank drawbridge, a moat and a ''turret bedroom.'' While there is no evidence of a run on Dickens novels in area bookstores, much less a conscious emulation of Wemmick, turrets have been popping up with increasing frequency on upscale suburban homes around New York City.

JOHN from New Haven was posting comments on a political blog a few weeks ago when one of the site's regulars posted a comment of his own: ''Wow.'' He was reacting to John's last name, DeStefano, and his current position, mayor of New Haven. Without telling the administrator of the site, Mr. DeStefano, a Democrat, had decided to begin a dialogue about his campaign for governor. There was risk involved: Anyone can sign up and comment on the site (which has an off-color name), and there was no telling what kind of vitriol the mayor might inspire. In his attempt to join in an unpredictable forum, Mr. DeStefano seemed at first like someone's dad, trying to be cool.

To the Editor: Fred Bernstein's lack of ''nostalgia for Orchard Street,'' as noted in his review of the Blue Moon Hotel (Check In/Check Out, June 4) is reflected in his inaccuracies and obtuse comments, which demonstrate a lack of appreciation for the personal and family histories bound to the Lower East Side, and a lack of perspective regarding the preservation and design development of a neighborhood icon; thus, he was an inappropriate choice of critic for our hotel. I was trained as an artist and have created and orchestrated the preservation and design of the building, meshing the historical elements with contemporary materials. This project was neither plotted nor planned. My goal was to keep the process liquid as well as soulful. In a painterly approach, using a combination of inspiration and instinct, I created settings for the original details, as well as enhancing their innate properties, thus resulting in the soul of the building being preserved and glorified as well as useful and functional.

To the Editor: Your May 28 article ''In a Vulnerable Year for Republicans, Just How Vulnerable Is Sue Kelly?,'' about New York's 19th Congressional District, notes that Representative Sue W. Kelly ''has spent more than a decade carefully crafting an image as a moderate independent Republican.'' It would be more accurate to describe her as an entrenched Washington establishment corporatist.

GORELL--Frank. The family of The Curtis Institute of Music mourns the loss of its devoted friend Frank Gorell and extends deepest sympathy to his family. A recipient of Curtis's Alumni Award, he shared his profound commitment to young musicians through projects such as the young artists' series at the Raymond F. Kravis Center in West Palm Beach, FL. He also served Curtis as an overseer and a trustee. His pride in his musical training and his unwavering dedication will long inspire us. Roberto Diaz, President H.F. (Gerry) Lenfest Chairman The Curtis Institute of Music

The last thing New York's Legislature deserves right now is a pay raise. The lawmakers know they are somewhere near the bottom of any taxpayer's list of things to spend more money on. So they have devised ways of camouflaging pay increases so they will attract the least possible notice. This year, it is time for the voters to pay attention. The Legislature always likes to couple its pay increases with increases for the judiciary. This is totally unfair to the state's judges, who really do deserve a hefty raise.

To the Editor: In her Cookbook Chronicle, Amanda Hesser asks where ''older folks''-- i.e., adults --enjoy black cows/root beer floats: ''Where -- on 'Leave It to Beaver' ''? Where do adults enjoy root beer floats? Answer: all over, from the Hudson to the Sierras -- wherever it is possible to get genuine root beer, rather than that flavorless, characterless brown liquid passed off as root beer in New York. In fact, it is even occasionally possible to get a reasonable facsimile of root beer under the label of ''ginger beer'' at specialty food stores, and to make a passable black cow at home on a July afternoon. The fact is that the heartland is the only part of the United States that knows how to make a proper soda, sundae, shake, malt or split. Rosanne Klass New York

The paintings in ''AMERICANS IN PARIS, 1860-1900,'' on view at the MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS, BOSTON, may look quaint to the casual observer, but they are rooted in a time when Paris embodied the city as public spectacle: cosmopolitan, dynamic, radically new. American artists like Whistler, Sargent and Homer journeyed there to lose their provincial veneer with varying degrees of success. The exhibition includes parodies of Bohemian society like Thomas Hovenden's ''Self-Portrait of the Artist in His Studio'' (1875). His ragged shoes and disheveled clothing were displayed as badges of honor. But the show's highlights are paintings that depict the posturing of the city's fashion-conscious flaneurs: the dandies strolling through Sargent's ''In the Luxembourg Gardens'' (1879) or the portrait Whistler painted of his mistress, ''The White Girl'' (1862). Opens Sunday and runs through Sept. 24; (617) 267-9300 or mfa.org. Few architects have immersed themselves more fully in the art world than the Swiss team of Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. They have designed some of the world's most original museum spaces, from the bold postindustrial landscape of the Tate Modern in London to the fluid interiors of the recently completed de Young Museum in San Francisco. And their work, known for the often surreal quality of its surfaces, has drawn inspiration from artists as varied as Andy Warhol and Hans Richter. With ''HERZOG & DE MEURON, PERCEPTION RESTRAINED,'' part of the Artist's Choice series at the Museum of Modern Art, they get to try their hand at organizing a show. In the installation, scenes from old films will be projected onto the ceiling, and works from the Modern's collection will be embedded in small niches carved out of black walls. Runs through Sept. 25; (212) 708-9400 or moma.org. The Whitney Museum of American Art indulges in a bit of nostalgia with ''FULL HOUSE: VIEWS OF THE WHITNEY'S COLLECTION AT 75.'' In celebration of the museum's anniversary, the show will focus on flashpoints in 20th-century American art, from Abstract Expressionism to Minimalism to Pop Art. As an added bonus Alexander Calder's ''Circus'' (1926-31) will be reinstalled in the lobby for the first time since 1998. Thursday through Sept. 3; (800) 944-8639 or whitney.org.

AN expansive, gorgeous view of Central Park. A lifelong dream for me. Many years ago, while living in a 20th-floor apartment on East 79th Street, I would go out on our small terrace, look left and get a glimpse of a sliver of treetops. So the idea that I could have a magic-carpet view of The Park as I drank my coffee every morning was reason enough to propel me to 110 Central Park South, the new co-op (with condo bylaws) that's smack across from the southern tip of the park.

To the Editor: In ''New York's Crime Against Women'' (Op-Ed, June 18), Sonia Ossorio correctly observed that New York State's statute of limitations for prosecuting rape was nearly the shortest in the nation: only Florida, North Dakota and Utah had shorter time limits during which a rapist may be brought to justice.

Spike Gillespie's cavalier attitude, trivializing a serious subject, was unsettling. Maybe she should have worked harder to get a better job, so she could afford more things. Does she realize that I have to pay for her freedom, relief and quieter phones? Marvin Coopersmith Verona, N.J. Credit cards, in one form or another, have been around for some time, but until the last few decades they were given primarily to middle- and upper-income families. This was because state usury laws limited the interest that companies could charge, and the risk of nonpayment by lower-income families was greater than the return the companies could expect. But in its obscure Marquette decision, in 1978, the Supreme Court decided that credit-card companies, based in states without usury laws, could charge whatever they desired to customers in any states, a decision effectively rendering all state usury limitations useless. At this point, credit-card companies flooded the market. The rates they have charged on unpaid balances have risen dramatically. Frederic L. Pryor Swarthmore, Pa.

Attention President Bush: C.E.O.'s in Detroit are standing by for your call. Mr. Bush was supposed to have a meeting with senior auto industry executives in May, but it did not happen and has not been rescheduled. Rather than keep pestering the White House, Chrysler's chief executive, Thomas W. LaSorda, says Mr. Bush should just reach out when he's ready. ''My phone number is available,'' he said. ''I'm sure he could get me faster than we could get him.'' MICHELINE MAYNARD

To the Editor: Re: ''Pencil It In Under 'Not Happening''' (June 18). I have always been suspicious of all those very busy people. Finally an article that explains it to me. They fill their busy, busy days with appointments and dates that they would rather cancel or, more desirably, be canceled by someone else. Many of these people are successful executives! I don't see how this can translate into a successful life, but I guess I'll just blame cellphones and BlackBerries. Carol Rosen West Chester, Pa.

THIS is a war story, a redeeming one, a tale full of mirrors and echoes and acts very different from the deeds at Abu Ghraib or at Haditha. But it is also about the pull of an illustrious ancestor and how it can penetrate even the fog of war. Growing up as a Kennedy cannot be shrugged off. Neither can growing up a Kolff.

The problem Mattathias Schwartz writes about -- gambling addiction -- is a tragedy for those who suffer from it, but it's the addictive personality, not the game, that is the real culprit. If we're to ban online poker, should we ban online shopping to save shopaholics? Online stock trading to rescue day traders? What people do in their own time should be their own business. For most online-poker players, it's about entertainment. Carl Skutsch New York

BLOTNER--Norman David. Born December 16, 1918, in Beverly, MA. Resident of New Rochelle for 45 years. Died June 23, 2006. Harvard University, Class of 1940. Served in US Navy for five years during WWII, entering as ensign and achieved rank of lieutenant commander. Received a law degree from Harvard Law School, where he coached the Harvard lacrosse team. An All-American lacrosse player and avid athlete his entire life, he played tennis through 2005. After practicing law for six years, joined Lane Bryant as VP Real Estate, Legal Matters, and stayed until retirement. Predeceased by Helen Whitman and Ethel Schanzer. Survived by his loving companion Vera Rosen, of New Rochelle, and her children, and Lucy.

To the Editor: Cathleen Medwick, in her review of Jaime Manrique's ''Our Lives Are the Rivers'' (June 4), mistakenly defines the word criolla as meaning ''mixed-race.'' The dashing Manuela S√°enz, Sim√≥n Bolivar's famous lover, was indeed a criolla, but not because she was of mixed race. In colonial Latin America, criollos were the American-born descendants of the original Spanish settlers. Criollos were members of the land-holding or merchant classes and generally well-to-do. While some were certainly of mixed race, it is their ties to their Spanish families that define them as a group. It was this class, whose members increasingly saw their fate wedded to the growing societies in the New World, that rose in opposition to Spanish colonial rule in the early 19th century, eventually establishing the republics of the Spanish-speaking Americas. Medwick may have mistakenly assumed the word to be the equivalent of ''creole'' in English, one of whose many meanings is ''mixed-race.'' Ramiro E. Prudencio Miami

8 P.M. (AMC) BROKEN TRAIL -- A veteran cowboy and his estranged nephew save five Chinese girls from prostitution while running 500 horses from Oregon to Wyoming in 1897 in this two-part made-for-television movie. Sitting tall in the lead saddles: Robert Duvall, who lives in rural Virginia, and Thomas Haden Church (above left, with Mr. Duvall), who calls a Texas ranch home. 6 P.M. (MSNBC) DARFUR: CAUGHT IN THE CROSSFIRE -- Ann Curry, digital camera in hand, reports on the ethnic cleansing that has terrorized the Darfur region of Sudan and provides the images to back it up. 7 P.M. (CNBC) DLIFE: YOUR DIABETES LIFE -- This series on coping with diabetes begins a new season with a look at health care and insurance, and offers fast-food alternatives for when home cooking isn't an option. 8 P.M. (TNT) HALF LIGHT -- This comeback vehicle for Demi Moore, who plays a mystery writer trying to put her life back together after the death of her 5-year-old son, went straight to DVD. But fans say its setting -- an isolated fishing village in Scotland -- and its haunting story line are big screen worthy. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE -- Emeril Lagasse indulges in a little goodnatured competition with his friend and network rival Mario Batali. Their battleground: Italy, or at least its food, with which they demonstrate their own versions of dishes like linguine with red clam sauce, ragu Bolognese and duck scalloppine. 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) LET'S JUST PLAY: GO HEALTHY CHALLENGE -- This special checks in, for the second time, on four children committed to improving the diet and exercise habits not only of themselves but of their families, friends and communities. 9 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- For 12 seasons, James Lipton has leveled his sometimes odd questions at the best of the best, even though a few of them can only loosely be categorized as actors. (Elton John?) In this 200th episode, Mr. Lipton lobs a few at Dustin Hoffman (right), who seems to take them in stride. 10 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES -- Darius's fun and games come to an end when Katie, in revenge for being raped in Spain, kidnaps him. And Conrad and Tanya get engaged. For now. 10 P.M. (Showtime) HUFF -- The season is over, but the angst goes on -- at least in this episode, in which Huff answers Russell's call, Izzy visits Teddy, Byrd vents and Beth (Paget Brewster, left) tells Alec where they stand. And he's not going to like it. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

THE Fairfield Board of Education voted late last month to have the town's two high schools start their day 20 minutes later, beginning in the fall, part of a movement around the state to get teenagers more sleep. Greenwich P.T.A. members have been asking the school board to consider a delay, and board members in West Hartford have also been discussing later start times. Other schools have also looked into the issue, but have made no changes. Wilton became the first school district in the state to make the change when it delayed middle and high school starting times by almost an hour in 2003.

To the Sports Editor: Ben Roethlisberger was indeed breaking Pennsylvania law by riding his motorcycle without a helmet because he did not possess a valid license (''Roethlisberger Didn't Have License,'' June 20). But the legal helmet that many bikers wear would not have saved his face. Only motorcycle racers and Nervous Nellies like me wear hot, heavy and expensive full-face helmets. Richard Horwich East Hampton, N.Y. To the Sports Editor: There should be stiffer fines for drivers who create accidents when they are in a much larger vehicle than a motorcycle and endanger the lives of motorcycle riders. Whether or not the motorcycle riders choose to wear helmets is not the issue. Jacqueline Kazlas Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
