Beloved wife of Kenneth, devoted mother of Kathleen O'Malley and Terence Gallagher, proud grandmother of Thomas O'Malley and Michael O'Malley, loving sister of Anne Forlini, the late Alfred Mazzucci and the late Louise Mazzucci. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home: 36-46 Bell Blvd, Bayside, NY. Visiting Monday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday, 10 AM, Holy Family RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

KETCHAM--Laurie Camden. 51, of Jamestown, RI, died Sunday, June 18, of ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). She was the beloved daughter of the late James B. and Ira D. Ketcham. A longtime resident of Manhattan, Laurie was the President and owner of Laurie C. Ketcham, a photographer's representative until stricken with ALS. Laurie fought a courageous battle and was determined to help others with this fatal disease. Gifts in her memory can be made to the ALS Association of Rhode Island, 1637 Warwick Avenue, Warwick, RI 02889. She is survived by a brother, George Ketcham of Newport, RI; sisters: Susan K. Coffin of Manchester By the Sea, MA, and Brucie K. Donahue of Northfield, VT. In addition, she is survived by an uncle, William Tredwell Ketcham Jr. of New York and Lawrence, LI. A funeral service will be held at 11 am, on Thursday, June 29, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, 87 Narragansett Avenue, Jamestown, RI. A memorial celebration of her life will take place at a later date to be determined on Long Island.

HIGHER INTEREST? -- Wall Street's attention is focused on the Federal Open Market Committee, which is expected to raise the benchmark short-term interest rate, the federal funds rate, for the 17th consecutive time, to 5.25 percent. (Thursday.) TRADE TALKS -- Trade ministers are scheduled to meet in Geneva to try to revive stalled negotiations for a global trade agreement, known as the Doha Development Round. (Wednesday through Saturday.) STRIKE THREAT -- More than 10,000 employees of Asda, the British subsidiary of Wal-Mart Stores, are threatening to start a five-day strike over wages and working conditions. (Saturday.) HOUSING OUTLOOK -- A picture of the housing industry will develop this week, starting with a report for new-home sales in May. (Monday.) The report for sales of existing homes will follow. (Tuesday.) OTHER REPORTS -- The Conference Board is scheduled to issue its report on consumer confidence for June. (Tuesday.) The final reading for the gross domestic product in the first quarter will also be released. (Thursday.) And rounding out the week are reports for personal income and personal spending in May, and the University of Michigan's final report on consumer sentiment for June. (Friday.) EARNINGS -- A spate of companies are scheduled to announce quarterly profit reports this week, including Walgreen (Monday), Nike, above, (Tuesday), 3Com and ConAgra (Wednesday), and General Mills, Monsanto and Palm (Thursday).

A picture on Friday with an article about a map dealer's admission in federal and state courts in New Haven that he stole 97 antique maps worth more than $3 million from universities and libraries carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times.

To the Editor: As a second-grade mother, I couldn't agree more with ''No More Teachers, Lots of Books'' (Op-Ed, June 19). In addition to blaming some teachers, I also blame many of today's supercompetitive parents, who have made up this imaginary link between huge amounts of homework and getting into a better university. There is no evidence that I have uncovered to prove such nonsense.

Brad Mehldau Trio ''House on Hill'' (Nonesuch) Brad Mehldau and Ren√©e Fleming ''Love Sublime'' (Nonesuch) Last year the pianist Brad Mehldau replaced the longtime drummer in his trio, Jorge Rossy, with a much more loamy percussionist, Jeff Ballard. The results, as heard in performance by the new trio and on Mr. Mehldau's last Nonesuch album, were salutary, like drawing the curtains to let the daylight in. Still, Mr. Mehldau's original trio, with Mr. Rossy and the bassist Larry Grenadier, was a joy throughout its 10-year run. And it bowed out on a high note, with the exceptional standards album ''Anything Goes,'' in 2004.

Bonnie Fuller, the celebrity-magazine editor whose fate has been swinging in the wind along with the fortunes of her employer, American Media, has renewed her contract as editorial director for three years, she and company officials said. Ms. Fuller, who signed the new deal on Friday, is to receive the same $1.5 million annual base salary as in her current three-year contract, but she can earn more in bonuses over the next three years than she did in the previous three.

An article on Friday about an ethics camp in Santa Clara, Calif., where politicians and officials heard accounts of ethical lapses, described as chilling, misspelled the name of an author known for chilling fiction. He is Edgar Allan Poe, not Allen.

Meryl Streep's range as an actress is legendary. She has played passionate heroines in movies like ''Silkwood,'' cunning women in adventures like ''River Wild,'' and simmering lovers in romances like ''Out of Africa.'' Ms. Streep (above, right, with Anne Hathaway) takes on a new kind of alpha role in ''The Devil Wears Prada,'' a comedy about the fashion world. She plays a powerful magazine editor known for chewing up her assistants with all the compassion of a meat grinder. Still, she has never looked more stylish. SHELLY FREIERMAN

GILBERT --Marc K, 89, of Plantation, Florida, and previously of Hollywood and Tamarac, Florida, passed away on June 24, 2006. Marc was well known for both his philanthropy and his active involvement in many local, national and international organizations. Marc was a founder of the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, an Anti-Defamation League Honorary Life Member, and was just recently honored as a Trustee and founder of the American Friends of the Hebrew University. Marc was also an active member of the United Jewish Community of Broward County. Marc was predeceased by his wife Ann, his father Samuel, his mother Jenny, his brother Barney and his sister Anne. He is loved and remembered by his daughters Roni (Frank) Schaeman of Oakland, NJ and Tina (Gary) Silverstein of Plantation, Florida, as well as his grandchildren Michael (Jessica) Schaeman, Sharon (Gary) Dobel, Jeffrey (JoAnne) Silverstein, Francine (Yoram) Nisim, and Jody Silverstein. All ten great-grandchildren, David, Matthew, Shannon, Alison, Jack, Laura, Sydney, Sophie, Mollie and Jenny will lovingly remember their special ''Papa.'' Services will be held at Menorah Gardens at Griffin Road and US 27, Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on Monday, June 26 , at 11:30 am.

Tim O'Reagan ''Tim O'Reagan'' (Lost Highway) Tim O'Reagan is best known as the drummer for the Jayhawks, a solidly tuneful band that helped shape the sound of alternative country for two decades. (The band has been on indefinite hiatus since last year.) His self-titled debut as a singer-songwriter doesn't quite come out of left field -- he has a reputation in his native Minneapolis -- but it does lay new groundwork for a multidimensional solo career.

YANEK--Dona Julia Victoria Albota Sands. 87, passed after a heart attack in her sleep on June 22, 2006. Julia married the late Henry Charles Yanek on June 21, 1942. After a long career as a cosmotologist, she retired to San Luis Obispo (SLO). Burial will be at Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing at 2 o'clock on June 29, 2006. She is survived by her sister Mathilda, 96, of Florida, and her children John H.P.C. Yanek, O.S.B., O.B.L., D.D., Dean of Holy Rood, who will preside over the Funeral Mass in SLO on June 27, 2006, and Carol A.M.Y. Coch of Forest Hills, NY.

FINALLY, A STEEL DEAL -- Arcelor, the steel maker, has agreed to a takeover offer from Mittal Steel, ending a five-month tussle and creating a new global champion. [Page C1.] BIG-TICKET INTERNET -- With online advertising revenues growing quickly, sites devoted to big-ticket purchases -- particularly cars, real estate and travel -- are refining features and marketing strategies in the hopes that they can attract the growing number of consumers flocking to such sites for buying advice. Bob Brisco, above, the chief executive of Internet Brands, said the sites had become more specific and niche-oriented. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.] A NEW STRATEGY -- For years, advertisers seeking to reach gay and lesbian consumers concentrated their spending in the print media. But that limited media menu is starting to be broadened. TV, the Internet, radio and even movies are joining magazines and newspapers as places to pitch products to gay men and lesbians. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.] A SHIFT AT MICROSOFT -- Microsoft plans to offer a strategy on Monday describing how it intends to transform the telecommunications world in much the same way it changed the computing world in the 1980's. Its new approach centers on systems for the workplace that blend desktop computers with office and mobile phones, a combination known as ''unified communications.'' [C6.] PETS AND GAMES AT MTV -- MTV, a unit of Viacom, plans to introduce a cellphone-based version of its popular Neopets Web site tomorrow. The site, which MTV bought a year ago for $160 million, lets users adopt, feed and nurture their pets and do battle with cartoonish creatures including the catlike Aisha and the dragonlike Scorchio. [C2.] ACTIVITY, BUT FEW CUSTOMERS -- Despite WiFly's ubiquity in Taiwan -- with 4,100 hot spot access points reaching 90 percent of the population -- just 40,000 of Taipei's 2.6 million residents have agreed to pay for the service since January. That such a vast and reasonably priced wireless network has attracted so few users in an otherwise tech-hungry metropolis should give pause to civic leaders in Chicago, Philadelphia and dozens of other American cities. [C1.] A NEW RULE AT MSNBC -- Dan Abrams, an on-air anchor who will become the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC, acknowledged that he was still in the learning stages of his new job, his first management job in television. While steering away from suggestions that an overhaul of MSNBC is imminent, he did suggest that he would push right away for more breaking news coverage during the channel's daytime hours. [C1.]

HUSTON--Robert L. Of Scarborough, NY on June 23, 2006. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, Bob was a banker who loved golf, travel, friends and family. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Phelps Hospice, 701 N. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591, would be appreciated. Funeral Mass 10 am, Wednesday, June 28, at Transfiguration Church, Tarrytown, NY. Enjoy heaven, sweet prince.

Michael D. Eisner, the former chief of the Walt Disney Company, has acquired the producer of sports videos for infants and toddlers in a deal expected to be announced on Monday. The company, Team Baby Entertainment, makes DVD's that highlight college athletic teams while, at the same time, teaching children to count and spell. Mr. Eisner and Team Baby declined to say how much he paid for the company.

Six Flags, New York and Oklahoma City, selected Zimmerman Advertising, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group, to handle its creative account, which had been at Doner, Southfield, Mich. Spending was estimated at $75 million. The decision to leave Doner, which created the ''Mr. Six'' character, came after the investor Daniel M. Snyder took control of Six Flags. The L'Or√©al Paris division of L'Or√©al USA, New York, part of L'Or√©al, selected R/GA, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as its worldwide interactive agency of record. The duties had been handled by offices of Nurun, part of the Quebecor Group. Spending has not been determined.

Sara Tavares ''Balanc√™'' (Times Square) What's left of Portugal's former empire are scattered strongholds of the Portuguese language and a geography-defying musical kinship that binds a good part of Portuguese-speaking pop. Sara Tavares was born in Portugal to a family with roots in the Cape Verde islands off Senegal, and on her album ''Balanc√™,'' she presents Lisbon as a creolized city, a musical hub for Portugal, its former colonies and some of their neighbors in Africa and the Americas.

HIRSHFIELD - Susan, 60, passed away on Friday, June 23rd, in her Manhattan apartment. Susan spent two decades as an actress, during which she stared as Zenobia, in an Off-Broadway production of ''Ethan Frome.'' She later founded Quoi De Neuf, a fine jewelry business whose pieces grace many of the best dressed women of the world. A woman of impeccable taste, Susan loved all things beautiful. She was a tenacious tennis player, an avid reader, a beach loafer, and a devoted friend, mother and wife. Susan knew how to live life to the fullest and inspired those around her to do the same. Thoughout a courageously fought 16-year battle with cancer, Susan always pursued pleasure and never looked back. She is survived by her adoring husband Peter Hirshfield, her loving daughters, Lauren and Victoria, her beautiful mother Ellen Levy, and her devoted brother Charles Levy. A memorial service will be announced for September at a later time.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on June 16 about the extension of the run of ''The History Boys'' and other theater scheduling misspelled the surname of an actress who is to appear in ''A Spanish Play'' at the Classic Stage Company in the East Village in January. She is Linda Emond, not Edmond.

For the first time since winning a Tony Award in 1998 as the mother in Martin McDonagh's ''Beauty Queen of Leenane,'' the Irish actress Anna Manahan, below, will return to the New York stage when she appears in the local premiere of the solo show ''Sisters,'' opening on Sept. 12 at 59E59 Theaters. The play by Declan Hassett, the former arts editor of The Irish Examiner, was created specifically for the 81-year-old Ms. Manahan, who plays both Martha and Mary, two sisters whose lives have taken very different turns. The characters are based on the biblical sisters with the same names, traditionally seen as representative of spirituality (Mary) in contrast to action (Martha). First presented at the Everyman Theater in Cork, Ireland, ''Sisters'' played at last year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival and had its United States premiere at the Colorado Festival of World Theater last summer. STEVEN McELROY

Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis has completed agreements to be the exclusive sponsor in the beer category for the next six Super Bowls. The company, the exclusive beer sponsor for the Super Bowl since 1989, will announce today that it has made a deal with NBC for the games in 2009 and 2012.

Brazos Bookstore, Houston's premier literary marketplace and a mecca for touring authors since 1974, will keep its doors open after a threatened shutdown thanks to some unlikely saviors: a consortium of 14 loyal customers and private investors. The independent Brazos, an increasingly lonely and financially struggling holdout among bookselling chains, had been seeking a buyer since its founding owner, Karl Killian, was named program director of the Menil Collection in March. When no one could be found to meet the asking price of at least $275,000, Edward R. Allen III, an investment counselor and philanthropist long on the board of Asia Society Texas, assembled 13 other Brazos fans, including Sis Johnson, president of Inprint, a literary arts group, to purchase the store. Jane Moser, who owned a children's bookstore nearby, was hired as manager, and Mr. Killian's wife, Kathy, will stay on with the rest of the staff. The store, which draws large crowds for readings by popular authors like Molly Ivins, is holding an open house tomorrow evening to celebrate. RALPH BLUMENTHAL

8 P.M. (ABC Family) KYLE XY A teenage savant (Matt Dallas, left) with all the guile of a newborn, and no knowledge of where he's from, is found wandering through traffic and put in an institution. And then Nicole Trager (Marguerite McIntyre), his psychologist, brings him home, much like a new puppy, where her family is forced to deal with his emerging brilliance -- and the fact that he never sleeps. 8 P.M. (AMC) BROKEN TRAIL In Part 2 of this made-for-television western, Robert Duvall and Thomas Haden Church, as gnarled cowboy Print Ritter and his estranged nephew, Tom, continue their trek through mountain territory with five would be Chinese prostitutes in their charge. ''Sometimes you got to roll with what's thrown at you,'' Print says, and the scenery they're rolling through sure is nice. 9 P.M. (Fox) HELL'S KITCHEN Things -- among them Gordon Ramsay's temper -- are heating up as the two groups of wannabe chefs show slim-to-no food aptitude. Last week, the stoic Heather stuck it out despite a serious burn. This week, someone leaves, even without hospitalization. 9 P.M. (TNT) THE CLOSER Deputy Chief Brenda Johnson (Kyra Sedgwick) investigates the gang-related shooting of three youngsters, and finds that one of the victims isn√ït as blameless as he seems. Meanwhile, Brenda's mother, played by Frances Sternhagen, shows up in Los Angeles, making it difficult for her F.B.I. agent boyfriend (Jon Tenney) to move in. More doughnuts, please. 9 P.M. (BBC America) THE BEST MAN Peter (Toby Stephens) and Michael (Richard Coyle) share a best friendship and a dark past. And then Michael's new wife, Kate (Keeley Hawes, above, with Mr. Coyle, center, and Mr. Stephens), comes along in this two-part thriller. Can Kate survive? 10 P.M. (ABC) HOW TO GET THE GUY Apparently it takes communication, as the four women in this reality series find out when their coaches get them to ask as assortment of men outlandish questions about love, sex and relationships. And you know how men like to talk. 10 P.M. (13) HOW ART MADE THE WORLD Before Pamela Anderson, Anna Nicole Smith and Barbie, there was the Venus of Willendorf, a tiny statue created some 25,000 years ago of a woman with greatly exaggerated, um, features. In the first episode of this new five-part series chronicling the history of visual imagery and its impact on contemporary life, Nigel Spivey (above, holding the Venus of Willendorf), a Cambridge University lecturer, explains how her image made it impossible for humans to look at the female body in quite the same way. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The IAC/InterActiveCorp, which operates Web sites like citysearch.com, evite.com and match.com, will for the first time sell advertising for independent Web sites, beginning with The Huffington Post (huffingtonpost.com). The IAC Advertising Solutions unit of IAC will become the exclusive national sales force for The Huffington Post, which had handled ad sales internally. The goal is to sell ads for ''a very niche group of sites with more engaged users'' that attract from 1 million to 10 million unique visitors a month, said Mort Greenberg, vice president for media sales strategy and development at the unit.

FRIED--Elsie. June 25, 2006. Wife of Stanley. Mother of three daughters and their spouses. Sister of two sisters and their spouses. Also survived by nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Monday, 10:30 am, at Goldstein's Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks, 6410 North Broad St, Philadelphia, PA. Graveside services will be held Tuesday, 1 PM, at King David Memorial Park, Putnam Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to the National Alzheimer's Association.
To the Editor: Paul Krugman gives us another wake-up call in ''Class War Politics'' (column, June 19) and indirectly sends a stern message to the Democratic Party.
An article on Friday about President Bush's visit to Budapest misidentified the location for his speech. It was outdoors on Gellert Hill, not at Buda Castle on Castle Hill.

GAUDIANI--Vincent A. 86, of Indianapolis and NYC, deceased, June 23, 2006. West Point '43, RCA executive. Survived by his wife of 63 years, Vera Rossano Gaudiani. Children, Dr. Claire L., Dr. Vincent A., Dr. Linda M., Elissa A. and Michael Gaudiani, 13 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Memorial tribute at www.mem.com.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.26 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.57 percent.
To the Sports Editor: The United States soccer team is a victim of hype. First by FIFA, by ranking it fourth or fifth in the world. Really? This game is played for goals.

To the Editor: In Budapest, President Bush said, ''We resolve that when people stand up for their freedom, America will stand with them'' (''Bush Sees Iraq Echo in '56 Hungary Revolt,'' news article, June 23).

BLOTNER--Norman David. Born December 16, 1918, in Beverly, MA. Resident of New Rochelle for 45 years. Died June 23, 2006. Harvard University, Class of 1940. Served in US Navy for five years during WWII, entering as ensign and achieved rank of lieutenant commander. Received a law degree from Harvard Law School, where he coached the Harvard lacrosse team. An All-American lacrosse player and avid athlete his entire life, he played tennis through 2005. After practicing law for six years, joined Lane Bryant as VP Real Estate, Legal Matters, and stayed until retirement. Predeceased by Helen Whitman and Ethel Schanzer. Survived by his loving companion Vera Rosen, of New Rochelle, and her children, and Lucy.

Nicole Kidman, Keith Urban Wed Nicole Kidman, 39, the Oscar-winning actress, and Keith Urban, 38, the Grammy Award-winning country singer, were married yesterday in a traditional Roman Catholic ceremony in the clifftop Cardinal Cerretti Memorial Chapel overlooking the Pacific Ocean and Sydney Harbor in Australia, Reuters reported. The union was the second for Ms. Kidman, whose 10-year marriage to Tom Cruise ended in divorce in 2001, and the first for Mr. Urban. Ms. Kidman and Mr. Urban, right, both Australian although born elsewhere, met in January 2005 in Los Angeles at a dinner given in their honor by the Australian government. After the candlelight wedding ceremony, which ended with the pealing of church bells, Ms. Kidman, who had arrived in a cream-colored Rolls-Royce, and Mr. Urban, who had arrived in a four-wheel-drive vehicle, issued an official wedding picture and a statement that said, ''We just want to thank everyone in Australia and around the world who have sent us their warm wishes.'' Australian television reported that the actors Russell Crowe and Hugh Jackman were among the 230 guests, as were the actress Naomi Watts and the director Baz Luhrmann. Adam Sandler Rides High The new Adam Sandler comedy, ''Click'' (Sony), below, took in an estimated $40 million to claim the No. 1 ranking at North American box offices over the weekend, the tracking company Exhibitor Relations reported. After two weeks at the top, the animated ''Cars'' (Buena Vista) dropped to second place with $22.5 million, and the Jack Black wrestling comedy, ''Nacho Libre'' (Paramount), fell a notch to third place with $12.1 million, a decline of 57 percent. The newcomer ''Waist Deep'' (Focus/Rogue), starring Tyrese Gibson as an ex-convict out to avenge the kidnapping of his young son, took in $9.4 million, followed by ''The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift'' (Universal) with $9.2 million. In seventh place, after ''The Lake House'' (Warner Brothers), which took in $8.3 million, ''The Break-Up'' (Universal) sold an estimated $6.1 million worth of tickets, to bring its cumulative total to $103.7 million in its fourth week in release. The 10th-ranking ''Da Vinci Code'' (Sony) took in $4 million in its sixth week to total $205 million. ''X-Men: The Last Stand'' (Fox), in ninth place in its fifth week with $4.4 million, for a total of $224 million, is the only other summer film to break the $200 million barrier. Backstreet Boy Bows Out Kevin Richardson is bidding the Backstreet Boys bye-bye. As the Grammy Award-winning pop band prepared to start work on a new album, Mr. Richardson, below, announced on its Web site (backstreetboys.com): ''After 13 years of what can only be described as a dream come true, I have decided that it is time to leave the Backstreet Boys. It was a very tough decision but one that was necessary in order to move on with the next chapter of my life.'' The other members of the band -- Nick Carter, Howie Dorough, Brian Littrell and A. J. McLean -- said in a statement, ''We have no intention of replacing Kevin, and the door will always be open for him to return to the Backstreet Boys.''

KISSEL--Christine, June 1st, 1943-June 23rd, 2006. Painter, musician, potter. Beloved wife of Howard, daughter of Mary Jane Buck, sister of Margaret and Jim, aunt of Chris and Nicole. Donations: Philmont Public Library, Philmont, NY 12565.

BROWNE--Jean Mason, age 88, died on June 21, 2006, in Bellevue, Washington. Jean and her late husband, Robert Prall Browne, were longtime residents of Garden City, New York, as well as Marietta, Georgia. A descendent of both Pierre Van Cortlandt, the Van Cortlandt Manor, Croton - on - Hudson, New York, and George Mason, Gunston Hall, Lorton, Virginia, Jean's main interests in life were American history and American decorative arts. She will be remembered for her generous gifts of historic letters, documents, paintings, and decorative arts to the Van Cortlandt Manor House, which is a part of Historic Hudson Valley. She is survived by daughter Carolyn Mason Browne of Langhorne, PA, and also by three stepsons, James Stewart Browne, Alan Robert Browne, and Christopher Peter Browne, all of greater Atlanta. A private family service will be held in August in Cortlandt Manor, New York, at the Hillside Cemetery.

Paris Hilton ''Stars Are Blind'' (Warner Brothers) Last week this debut single from an aspiring pop star started showing up on radio-station playlists. The song, "Stars Are Blind," sounds a bit like No Doubt covering UB40's ''Kingston Town'': the music is light ska, the vocals are breathy, the double-entendre is absurd but somehow charming. (''If you show me real love, baby/I'll show you mine.'')

To the Sports Editor: Selena Roberts asks (''A Bad Seed Is to Blame for the Mess at the Garden,'' June 23): ''Does Charles F. Dolan lie awake at night counting his black sheep son?'' The answer is I really sleep very well.

A Pakistani television station broadcast an audiotape on Sunday that it said was the voice of the fugitive Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar. The voice on the tape issued a challenge to the Afghan government and foreign troops fighting insurgents in the country, contending they did not have the wisdom to solve the increasing unrest. Two foreign soldiers in the coalition fighting the insurgency in Kandahar Province in the south were killed Sunday.

BECKER--Eugene. August 2, 1929-June 25, 2006. Beloved husband of Rae, devoted father of Eve and Margot, proud Bapa of Leo Liebeskind, former assistant principal violist of the New York Philharmonic, master musician, mentor, friend and paradigm to his many students and professional colleagues. A man of passion and compassion who touched and moved the world he inhabited. Services Monday, June 26, 12:45 pm, Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

Okay, so let me respond to the points that readers made below about Chinese education. Here goes....

Here are some comments from the mailbag on today's column on China's education system. Martin Stein from nyc writes: "Maybe when the brightest from other countries cannot be imported here because their homelands have become more attractive to live in, we will start nurturing our own youth. We are like a baseball team winning with free agents imported from other teams, while failing to develop our own farm system. When the free agents dry up, or refuse to sign, they are left without any talent. That is what may happen to America."

"In Argentina there are forty million coaches." The saying is as old as it is popular - the only thing that changes about it over time is the number of coaches: as the population grows, there are more. The saying refers, of course, to soccer coaches - every Argentine believes himself to be one. Everyone knows which players should be in the starting line up and how Argentina should play when it faces Germany this Friday in Berlin, for a ticket to the quarter finals of this World Cup. But only one man will make those decisions: Jos√© Pekerman, the real coach of the Argentinian team. And he is a man walking a thin line between heaven and hell.

A bankruptcy judge said Tuesday he would allow cable company Adelphia Communications to sell itself to Time Warner Cableand Comcast for nearly $17 billion in cash and stock. Judge Robert Gerber of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York indicated Tuesday that he would sign an order approving the long-awaited sale later that day.

Renault and Michelin have been celebrating Sunday's victory at the Canadian Grand Prix a little more loudly than usual - but with good reason. It was the 100th victory for Michelin in Formula One, and lifts it to second position in that area, behind Goodyear, which has won nearly four times as many races. Bridgestone, is only about three behind Michelin, though.

The steel giant Arcelor may have unceremoniously dumped Russia's Severstal in favor of a $33.5 billion merger with Mittal Steel, but not all of Arcelor's investors are so ready to let go. AFX reported Tuesday that at least one significant Arcelor shareholder plans to vote in favor of Severstal's $16.6 billion offer at a shareholder meeting scheduled for Friday.

One day after Warren E. Buffett announced his unprecedented $30 billion donation to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, there comes another story of one of the world's richest men giving to charity. With a slight twist.

Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers are suing a subscription-based market-information Web site, claiming it pirated their equity research. The firms filed their copyright infringement lawsuit against the site, called TheFlyonthewall.com, on Monday in United States District Court in New York, several wire services reported.

My recent post asserting that wine should be more fun drew a raft of wonderful responses. Most interesting to me was a little set-to over white zinfandel. For the most part, attitudes on the part of connoisseurs toward white zinfandel range from appalled to aghast . But white zinfandel also drew some surprising defenses, and a few comments of real common sense, like Sommelier's.

The allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that Democratic ur-blogger Jerome Armstrong, an adviser to presumed presidential candidate Mark Warner, took money from a technology company to hype the company's stock on Internet bulletin boards have bolstered the suspicions in blogdom that Armstrong trades "on his reputation -- and his friendship with [Markos "Daily Kos"] Moulitsas and other bloggers at MyDD -- to further his political consulting business," in the words of Salon's Michael Scherer. The blogstorm on the subject has also damaged Warner's status in the increasingly visible "invisible primary" among aspiring Democratic presidential candidates. Hotline editor Chuck Todd dropped Warner from second to third place last week in his rankings (done jointly with Hotline associate editor Marc Ambinder) of the likely Democratic contenders.

Citizens Banking said on Tuesday it would buy Republic Bancorp for about $1.05 billion of stock and cash in a merger of two Michigan banks.
Industrial Alliance Insurance and Financial Services said on Tuesday it would buy a mutual fund brokerage firm, FundTrade, but did not disclose the terms of the deal.

Sara Lee on Tuesday said it had reached an agreement to sell its European meats business to Smithfield Foods for $575 million in cash and the assumption of $39 million in pension and other liabilities.
A judge denied a government request on Monday to revoke Conrad Black's $20 million bond, a move sought by prosecutors who claimed the former press baron had not fully disclosed his assets.

Shares of major orthopedics makers tumbled on Monday after four companies said they had received subpoenas from the Justice Department as part of a sectorwide investigation of possible antitrust violations.
With earnings growth lackluster and the share price stagnant, the directors of Kraft Food yesterday ousted the chief executive, Roger K. Deromedi, and named Irene B. Rosenfeld to succeed him.

Patterson-UTI Energy, an onshore oil and natural gas driller, said yesterday that federal regulators were investigating whether securities laws were violated in the embezzlement of $77.8 million by a former chief financial officer.

Proposed rules that would make it harder for national banking regulators to thwart foreign takeovers will be put to European Union ministers in the near future in a bid to end "brutal violations" of E.U. law, a top official said Monday.

The two main industrial shareholders of EADS, the parent company of Airbus, have agreed in principle to streamline the management structure -- potentially pushing out the embattled French co-chief executive, N√∂el Forgeard, a person close to both companies said Monday.

The Supreme Court announced Monday that it would consider a lawsuit that accuses the nation's largest telephone companies of violating federal antitrust law by conspiring to carve up local markets to preserve their monopolies.

European Commission authorities plan to recommend that Microsoft pay up to two million euros ($2.5 million) for every day it has failed to disclose information about its operating system to competitors, The International Herald Tribune reported.
Warren E. Buffett's decision to donate the bulk of his Berkshire Hathaway holdings will certainly transform the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. But will the move change Berkshire Hathaway, too?

The withdrawal of buyout firms from prominent deals, such as the defection of Carlyle, Blackstone and KKR from the Univision auction, reflects concerns not only about price, but also about the cost of financing these deals, says Breakingviews.
A month after Telmar Network Technology was acquired by Warburg Pincus, the telecom equipment maker has sealed its first add-on deal, acquiring Somera Communications for $4.60 a share in cash.

Pyxis Technology said Monday it raised $9.2 million in second round funding. Santa Clara-based Pyxis, a design-for-manufacturability routing company, said funding was led by Menlo Park-based Formative Ventures. Also participating were first round investors Austin Ventures of Austin, Tex., and CMEA Ventures of San Francisco.

TZero Technologies, a developer of ultra wideband chips used to wirelessly transmit video inside of households, has raised a $25.5 million Series B round of funding to help it start marketing and selling to equipment manufacturers.
The Dutch-Belgian financial services group Fortis said on Tuesday it would buy two North American power and gas trading companies for about 330 million euros ($415 million).

An organ regeneration company Tengion said that it had raised $50 million in Series B financing for its artificial bladder trials and manufacturing infrastructure. The company plans to do its manufacturing by itself, with no partner in the United States.

Casual-clothing retailer J. Crew Group leads a $1.3-billion wave of nine initial public offerings this week that may decide whether last week's 11 cancellations marked the start of a slump or just a hiccup for the busiest I.P.O. market since 2000.

A group working to create a Boston-based online community bank targeting African-Americans is changing the terms of its public offering to give it more time to meet federal requirements for the number of shareholders.

The Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that it had released Citigroup from an enforcement action taken two years ago for violating a law on deceptive lending practices.

Sweeping aside concerns about its controversial float, the Russian state oil firm Rosneft said Monday it would go ahead with its $11 billion initial public offering, potentially the fifth biggest in the world.

It was clear yesterday that the investment banks advising on the Mittal-Arcelor deal were in for a windfall. But Bloomberg News breaks down some of the actual figures, as well as supplying a sneak peak into the code names used by advisers for the companies.

After a tumultuous auction, Univision Communications, the nation's largest Spanish-language broadcaster, said early Tuesday it had accepted an offer to be acquired by a private equity consortium for $36.25 per share in cash. The transaction is valued at about $13.7 billion, including the assumption of $1.4 billion in debt, Univision said.

The Marvell Technology Group, a diversified maker of microchips, said on Tuesday that it would buy the Intel Corporation's communications and application processor business for $600 million plus the assumption of undisclosed liabilities.

The Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development is warning that Canada's effective ban on bank mergers could be hampering the country's productivity and is urging Ottawa to remove the political red tape that has been choking the industry's efforts to consolidate.

Shareholders of Knight Ridder, the nation's second-largest newspaper company, voted overwhelmingly Monday to sell the company to McClatchy. The vote completed a process that began a little over a year ago and ended the chain's 32-year existence amid expressions of sorrow and regret.

The NYSE Group's chief executive, John Thain, said Monday he expects to have the agreement to purchase Euronext in front of the shareholders of both companies for a vote in the autumn and the merger closing in early 2007.

A chance to dine with Warren Buffet will now cost the successful bidder more than half a million dollars, with the price tag for the annual charity lunch, this year to be held at New York steak house Smith & Wollensky, hitting $502,400 last night.
Houston Exploration roundly rejected an unsolicited bid for the company from the hedge fund Jana Partners, and the activist shareholder could not be happier.
Barr Pharmaceuticals agreed to buy Pliva, eastern Europe's biggest drugmaker, for $2.2 billion in cash, beating a bid from the Actavis Group of Iceland.

A slew of analysts Monday questioned Johnson & Johnson's $16.6 billion deal for Pfizer's consumer-products business, saying the health-care giant had overpaid.Merrill Lynch called the 16.6 billion deal "a bit of a surprise." At first blush, the price tag seems hefty at 4.3 times 2005 sales of $3.9 billion, said analyst Katherine Martinelli.

It could turn out to be a win-win situation for Xstrata, the Swiss-based mining company who's hopes to buy Falconbridge of Canada began to fade on Monday when the copper miner Phelps Dodge agreed to acquire Falconbridge and its rival Canadian nickel producer Inco in a $40 billion deal.
Mittal Steel shares fell Monday as the chairman, Lakshmi Mittal, and Arcelor split over the direction of the combined company after a 26.9 billion-euro ($33.7 billion) takeover.

Opposition from the Chinese government could prevent Hong Kong's PCCW from completing a deal with foreign bidders trying to acquire the company's telecom and media assets, according to media reports Tuesday.

Take-Two Interactive Software received grand jury subpoenas from the New York County district attorney requesting production of documents related to the video-game maker's "Hot Coffee" explicit-scene additions.
After two chapters CBS has folded "Tuesday Night Book Club," the reality show about the lives of members of a book club in Scottsdale, Ariz.
J. K. Rowling revealed that at least two characters will die in the seventh and final installment of her best-selling series.
General Electric agreed Monday to buy 186 nursing homes for $1.4 billion from Alpharetta, Ga.-based Formation Capital, the Associated Press reported.

"By all appearances, the irrevocable has happened," the Russian Foreign Ministry said Monday, announcing the death of four Russian diplomats who were taken hostage earlier this month in Iraq.

Israeli troops entered Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station tonight in an operation to rescue a soldier abducted by militants. Earlier, Palestinian political factions completed a draft agreement aimed at a national unity government. At right, Israeli soldiers preparing to cross into Gaza.

The British sprinter Dwain Chambers had his European 100-meter title erased yesterday along with his other results over the past year and a half because of his doping record. Chambers was barred for two years after testing positive for the steroid THG in November 2003.

Senator Robert Menendez and State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr. focused more on the issues in their second debate, clashing over the war in Iraq, taxes and immigration.

The Port Authority and the developer Larry A. Silverstein asked a New York court yesterday to bar seven insurers at ground zero from using the new rebuilding plan as an excuse to withhold more than $1.5 billion in payouts needed to rebuild office towers on the site.

In a last-ditch effort to influence talks between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council over a long-term strategy for handling the city's trash, hundreds of residents, advocates and elected officials crowded City Hall yesterday for a six-hour hearing that exposed tense divisions of race, class and geography.
Knicks owner James L. Dolan said new head coach Isiah Thomas has exactly one year to show "significant progress" or he will be fired.
Somalia's newly powerful Islamists said they would stone five rapists to death, in what some fear is part of a plan to install a severe religious authority.
Two veteran police detectives accused of taking bribes from a Chelsea street peddler last year were acquitted yesterday by a Manhattan jury, their lawyers said.

A front-page article on Friday about possible ways to reduce the risk of suffering from lethal injection misstated an effect of a fatal overdose of a barbiturate drug, sodium thiopental. The drug does not cause involuntary jerking movements before death even when used alone.

The completion of the Booz Allen Classic at Potomac, Md., and Ben Curtis's long-awaited first victory since the 2003 British Open was postponed for another day, setting up the PGA Tour's first Tuesday finish in 26 years. More rain was in the forecast.

After more than 50 years at downstate tracks, the Woodward Stakes will move north this summer to anchor the last weekend of racing at Saratoga Race Course. The six-week meeting at Saratoga usually peaks with the Travers Stakes, run on the last Saturday in August. New York racing officials hope the Woodward will carry the momentum ‚Äî and the fan support ‚Äî into Labor Day weekend. The race will be run Sept. 2.

The Astana team was asked to withdraw from the Tour de France in the wake of the doping scandal in Spain, organizers said yesterday. If the team, formerly called Liberty, refuses to withdraw, organizers will apply to the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Lausanne, Switzerland. Astana is under the spotlight after its manager, Manolo Saiz, was implicated in a scandal in which the police uncovered a network of blood doping in a series of raids. Alexander Vinokourov, who rides for Astana, is considered one of the top contenders for the Tour's overall title.
California suspended the senior quarterback Steve Levy indefinitely after his arrest on felony assault charges stemming from a bar fight.

European monitors said the suicide bombing  that killed the third-ranking officer in the Sri Lankan Army bore the hallmarks of the Tamil Tiger rebels.

The Denver Police Department identified Michael J. Ford, 22, as the man who killed one person and was then killed by the police in a shootout Sunday at a Safeway distribution center. Mr. Ford worked in the produce section at the center, said a police spokesman, Sonny Jackson. The police said they did not know what motivated the rampage. Five other people were wounded in the shootings, including a SWAT officer.

A federal appeals court has agreed to hear new arguments in a case involving an illegally taped telephone call leaked to reporters by Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit said all nine judges would hear Mr. McDermott's appeal. A three-judge panel ruled in March that McDermott violated federal law by turning over the recording of a 1996 call involving Newt Gingrich, who was House speaker then. The opinion upheld a ruling that Mr. McDermott violated the rights of John A. Boehner, who was heard on the call. Mr. Boehner, a Gingrich lieutenant at the time, is the House majority leader.

A federal judge has temporarily prevented the State of Georgia from forcing eight sex offenders from their homes Saturday ‚Äî the day a law that prohibits sex offenders from living within 1,000 feet of school bus stops goes into effect. According to a brief filed by the plaintiffs' lawyers, the provision would make nearly 9,000 sex offenders and their families homeless because there are virtually no housing arrangements that meet the law's requirements.

A former district attorney in the Panhandle who had hounded drug offenders into jail while barely hiding his own methamphetamine habit pleaded guilty to possession of a controlled substance and was sentenced to 18 years in state prison. The defendant, Richard J. Roach, 57, was already serving a five-year federal sentence on another conviction involving weapons possession. The terms will run concurrently.

Arif Mardin was one of the most successful and artistically significant behind-the-scenes figures in popular music in the last half-century.
Sophie Maslow was a choreographer who drew on the populist sympathies of Woody Guthrie, Carl Sandburg and Duke Ellington.
The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the federal government is required to control vehicle emissions of carbon dioxide.
Many in Gaza were not angry at Hamas for attacking an Israeli military post on Sunday, even if it almost guarantees a severe Israeli counterstrike.
Bruno, the brown bear who cut a bloody swath through the Alps on the German-Austrian border, finally met his end early Monday.

A defendant who has been wrongly forced to accept a different lawyer is entitled to have a conviction overturned, the Supreme Court ruled.
With earnings growth lackluster and the share price stagnant, the directors of Kraft Food ousted the chief executive, Roger K. Deromedi.
The resignation of Prime Minister Mari Alkatiri cleared the way for a resolution to the violence that has swept this small impoverished nation.

A court sentenced a Swedish citizen of Somali origin to four years in prison for forcing his 13-year-old daughter to be undergo genital cutting, the first such conviction since genital cutting ‚Äî also called female circumcision ‚Äî was banned by Sweden in 1982. Prosecutors said the man had had his daughter undergo the cutting during a visit to Mogadishu, the Somali capital, in January 2005. The Swedish law also prohibits children from being taken abroad for the procedure.
A Brooklyn filmmaker was the third cyclist since 2005 to be killed on West Houston Street in Greenwich Village.

Voters in a two-day nationwide referendum overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to change the Constitution and increase the powers of the prime minister and Italy's 20 regions. With nearly all the votes counted, results showed that 61.5 percent had opposed the plan, while 38.5 percent approved it. The outcome dealt a new blow to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, whose former center-right government had drafted the proposed changes, which the center-left government of the new prime minister, Romano Prodi, vociferously opposed.

An American soldier died of wounds received in fighting with insurgents on Sunday in eastern Kunar Province, the United States military reported. In another attack, a suicide bomber detonated his car behind an American military convoy not far from Bagram Air Base, near Kabul, killing himself and wounding Afghan boys playing near the road. No soldiers were hurt in the blast.

Prince Charles's private business interests earned him more than $25 million last year, an increase of around $1.3 million over the year before, according to figures released by his office to show greater openness in royal finances. The prince, heir to the British throne, disclosed his income tax bill for the first time, saying he paid more than $6 million in taxes, roughly the same as a year earlier. His income is based on rents and investment income from the Duchy of Cornwall, one of Britain's biggest and oldest private estates, created in 1337 by King Edward III. Charles was also said to have raised around $200 million for charities.
The vote completed a process that began a little over a year ago and ended the chain's 32-year existence amid expressions of sorrow and regret.

Voters in Mauritania, a mostly desert but newly oil-producing West African nation that has known only coups, have overwhelmingly approved a constitutional change that puts a limit of two five-year terms on future presidents and ensures that power will change hands at least every decade, the interior minister said, citing provisional results. The referendum was organized by a military junta that seized power last summer. It has promised to give up power and organize municipal and legislative polls in November and a presidential election in March.

The National People's Congress, China's Parliament, has scrapped a proposal that would criminalize abortions based on the sex of the fetus, the state media reported, despite a growing population imbalance between males and females. Newspapers said lawmakers were divided over criminalizing sex-selective abortions. The original amendment called for fines and prison terms of up to three years for aborting a fetus because of the sex for nonmedical reasons, the reports said. A three-decade-old policy limiting most couples to one child has made abortion a widely used method for controlling family size. As a result, and because of cultural preferences for sons, China faces a growing population imbalance, with many more boys than girls. The New China News Agency said there were now 119 boys born for every 100 girls, a larger gap than the government's previously published figure of 117 boys per 100 girls. Globally, the average ratio is about 105 boys to 100 girls.

An Egyptian court sentenced Ibrahim Eissa, the editor of Al Dustour, a independent weekly newspaper that has regularly been critical of President Hosni Mubarak, to a year in prison for defaming Mr. Mubarak. Mr. Eissa had published an article last year that reported on a lawsuit brought against Mr. Mubarak by an Egyptian who accused him of corruption.

Seven soldiers were killed and 20 wounded when a suicide bomber blew up his car at a checkpoint near the town of Miramshah, in the restive tribal region of North Waziristan. The attack was the third suicide attack in recent weeks in the region and came just as the government had brokered a cease-fire agreement from pro-Taliban militants in the adjoining district of South Waziristan in an effort to end the conflict.

A man charged with helping his wife commit suicide was released from a psychiatric hospital in Rockland County yesterday, his lawyer said. The man, Victor K. Han, 35, an architect, had been held for eight days of evaluation at Summit Park Hospital. The police say that on June 14, on a family trip to Bear Mountain State Park, Mr. Han got out of the family's van on a mountain road, leaving his wife, Hejin Han, and their two daughters inside. Moments later, Mrs. Han drove the van off the cliff. The children were not seriously hurt. Mr. Han has pleaded not guilty.

Richard A. Falkenrath, a former deputy homeland security adviser to President Bush, has been named the Police Department's senior counterterrorism official, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. Dr. Falkenrath, 37, will succeed Michael A. Sheehan, who left last month after three years in the post. Dr. Falkenrath served in the White House from January 2001 to May 2004. After Sept. 11, he was the senior director for policy and plans in the Office of Homeland Security and a special assistant to the president. He will start his new job on July 10, overseeing training and risk assessment and working with federal agents, among other things, Mr. Kelly said.

A 12-year-old boy was shot in the head about 6 p.m. yesterday and was pronounced dead at 6:30, the police said. Neighbors said that the boy who was shot was visiting a friend's home, where there was a gun collection, and the friend accidentally shot him. The police said the shooting occurred at a condominium on Cypress Lane in the Kingswood Station complex. They said that the grandmother, who owns the condominium, was at home when the shooting occurred.
The Department of Defense has identified 2,515 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg broke ground yesterday on the first housing development to be built under the city's recently expanded inclusionary zoning program, which allows developers to build at greater-than-usual density in return for making at least 20 percent of all new units available for people with low incomes. The development, at 164 Kent Avenue in Greenpoint, which was rezoned last year, will consist of a market-rate complex and a mid-rise building with 113 moderately priced apartments.

Despite running $45 million over its $799 million budget, the plan for a Fulton Street transit center linking a dozen Lower Manhattan subway lines will not be scaled back, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday. Work on the project, which requires the relocation of commercial tenants on the east side of Broadway between Fulton and John Streets, is to begin in September, with completion planned for June 2009, the authority said, adding that it had asked the Federal Transit Administration, which has dedicated $4.5 billion to rebuilding Lower Manhattan, to fill the gap.

A Manhattan Criminal Court judge yesterday gave the singer Boy George, left, until Aug. 28 to fulfill a community service sentence or face jail time. The singer, whose real name is George O'Dowd, pleaded guilty in March to third-degree false reporting of an incident for claiming that his Lower Manhattan apartment had been burglarized. When officers arrived, the authorities said, they found cocaine. Mr. O'Dowd agreed to perform five days of community service and enter a drug program in England, but has not yet performed the community service. Mr. O'Dowd's lawyer, Louis Freeman, said,

One man died and his brother was in critical condition yesterday after a fight on Sunday night that began in a room they shared and spilled into the street, the police said yesterday. Investigators are trying to determine the identities of the men, believed to be Guatemalan immigrants. Neighbors said the brothers, whom they knew as Jose and Tomas, worked as day laborers and had a history of drinking and fighting. Officers went to the brothers' apartment, on Sutphin Boulevard in South Jamaica , about 9:30 p.m. on Sunday and found both men with stab wounds in the head, back and chest.

Raoul Lionel Felder, the lawyer who represented former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in his divorce from Donna Hanover, has been elected chairman of the state commission that polices the ethics of New York judges, officials said yesterday. Mr. Felder takes over as head of the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct from Alan Pope, a Binghamton lawyer, who resigned last month in the face of a complaint against a judge that involved members of Mr. Pope's law firm. Mr. Felder was appointed to the commission in 2003 and will serve a renewable two-year term.
The lawsuit accuses the nation's largest telephone companies of conspiring to carve up local markets to preserve their monopolies.

General Motors said that Modernista in Boston would become the creative agency for its Cadillac division, effective Oct. 1.

New research shows that the two types of spiders that spin wheel-shaped webs have been doing it since the early Cretaceous period.

As a film about a country where two decades of violence have cost 60,000 lives, and where the practice of suicide bombing was perfected, "No More Tears Sister" is a bit too beautiful.
Des McAnuff, who directed the Tony-winning musical "Jersey Boys," has been named artistic director at the classical repertory theater in Ontario, Canada.

Susanne Mentzer, the mezzo-soprano, and Sharon Isbin, the guitarist, joined forces to close this season's Free for All series of free concerts at Town Hall.
James S. Tisch, the president and chief executive of the Loews Corporation, was named chairman of EBC's board at a late-afternoon special meeting on Monday.
The Mint Theater Company has unearthed a rare gem in its revival of this 1937 comedy by Rachel Crothers.
A new box set from Warner Home Video brings together six Clark Gable films, all but one from his prewar period of greatest fame.
NASA will try resuming regular space shuttle missions this week, hoping to finish construction of the International Space Station.
Two new books describe not just what Americans like to eat but also what we ought to eat.
Gordon S. Wood says the founding fathers helped unleash egalitarian forces that would put an end to the kind of elite leadership they represented.
Head lice are highly resistant to the active ingredient in many common head lice lotions and shampoos, a new study suggests.

The age at which a baby first tastes cereal may be significant in determining whether they develop wheat allergies, a new study suggests.
The number of premature births in the U.S. has risen 30 percent since 1981, but there are also additional ways to help small babies.
Drinking coffee is linked to a reduced risk for diabetes, a new study reports, and caffeine apparently has little to do with the effect.
Researchers found inspiration in a beetle to make a new water-trapping material.
When a patient finally took a trip she had  long dreamed about, a certain section of her brain might have perked up and given the all clear.
The notion that emotional distress can harm a developing fetus has been around for centuries.
What started as an informal race among growers to create a truly red iris has developed into a decades-long marathon.
An automated CPR machine approved by the F.D.A. produces worse outcomes than CPR performed manually, a randomized trial suggests.
In last week's column I suggested we hear more about readers' air-travel pet peeves. The response was impressive.
The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will use an enormous gift to try to find cures for AIDS and other fatal diseases.
Warren E. Buffett's decision to donate the bulk of his Berkshire Hathaway holdings will certainly transform the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. But will the move change Berkshire Hathaway, too?.
Republicans in the House who want to spend the summer studying immigration must consider the big picture: their jobs.
Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates agree that the capitalist system is not capable alone of addressing the root causes of poverty.
The 6-to-3 ruling suggests that efforts to limit the role of money in politics might face considerable resistance.
A special prosecutor said that revisions in the Rockefeller drug laws benefited major drug traffickers more than the low-level offenders they were supposed to help.
Scams, schemes and bureaucratic bungles after Hurricane Katrina have cost taxpayers up to $2 billion.
American commanders have ringed Ramadi with thousands of American and Iraqi troops and have begun to reclaim the city neighborhood by neighborhood.
Side by side near the United Nations compound were a demonstration against the Guant√°namo Bay detention center and a rally in favor of guns.
A good idea in education reform is "weighted student funding," in which a child receives financing that travels with him to the public school of his family's choice.
The fight against global warming has largely focused on reducing greenhouse gases. But what if ... ?
A small observational clinical trial suggests that pregnant women can undergo chemotherapy without threatening their babies.
Dr. Arata Kochi's manner may be abrasive, but even his critics say his record against tuberculosis was impressive.

While James L. Dolan might be more comfortable in a small group, he still owed it to fans to describe his anti-Brown case to a wider audience.
There can be no more excuses for Isiah Thomas and the players he acquired ‚Äî creating crippling salary-cap conditions ‚Äî and empowered.
The masters of soccer seem unable to straighten out the mixed messages of diving and mauling that are dragging soccer down in front of the whole world.
That many young Chinese in cities like Shanghai or Beijing get a better education than Americans do is a reality that should stir us to seek lessons from China.

Voters in a two-day nationwide referendum overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to change the Constitution and increase the powers of the prime minister and Italy's 20 regions. With nearly all the votes counted, results showed that 61.5 percent had opposed the plan, while 38.5 percent approved it. The outcome dealt a new blow to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, whose former center-right government had drafted the proposed changes, which the center-left government of the new prime minister, Romano Prodi, vociferously opposed. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO (IHT)

NBC has become the third broadcast television network to complete selling commercial time to advertisers before the start of the 2006-7 season. NBC, part of General Electric, sold about $1.9 billion in commercial time in what is called the upfront market, which takes place ahead of the fall season. Last year, in the upfront market before the 2005-6 season, NBC also sold about $1.9 billion.

STUART--Lyle. As members of the Board of Trustees and staff of The Albert Ellis Institute, we wish to extend our deepest sympathy to the family of Lyle Stuart on the occasion of his untimely passing. Lyle lived a long and full life, championing truth, justice and freedom of expression at every turn. He will be remembered by his many friends and admirers as a kind and caring man. In recent months, Lyle had given generously of his time to The Albert Ellis Institute, serving tirelessly as president of our board. We are greatful for his extraodinary leadership, highly principaled insight and strong support. We will miss him greatly. The Board of Trustees and staff Albert Ellis Institute
An obituary on Saturday about Dr. Heinz L. Ansbacher, an authority on the psychologist Alfred Adler, misstated the year Dr. Ansbacher's wife, Dr. Rowena Ansbacher, died. It was 1996, not 1994.

To the Editor: ''Next Victim of Warming: The Beaches'' (June 20) corroborates Al Gore's thesis in his film and book ''An Inconvenient Truth.'' When will enough people and politicians wake up? Edd Doerr Silver Spring, Md.

To the Editor: Your Side Effects columnist, James Gorman, says that ''if you are anything like me,'' you ''instinctively cheer for the natural mules'' over the cloned ones (''Belmont. Schmelmont. You Ought to See a Cloned Mule Run,'' June 13). Well, I'm not and I don't. I cheer for the cloned mules and for the triumph of human ingenuity. Felicia Nimue Ackerman Providence, R.I. The writer is a professor of philosophy at Brown University.

LaMarcus Aldridge remembers sitting across from Shaquille O'Neal, his idol and would-be mentor, at lunch one day and the first thing he noticed was that O'Neal's knees did not fit under the table. Three years ago, as a high school senior in Dallas, Aldridge and his mother, Georgia, accepted an invitation that came with a phone call when the Los Angeles Lakers were in town. Aldridge was in awe.

Amy Langford was utterly surprised when, at 42, she found out she was pregnant. Her joy dissipated a few weeks later, when she and her husband were told that a suspicious lump in her right breast was cancerous. ''The doctor came back and said he had 'not very good news,' '' recalled Amy's husband, Gregg. ''His second words were, 'Of course, this means you will have to terminate your pregnancy.' ''

Prince Charles's private business interests earned him more than $25 million last year, an increase of around $1.3 million over the year before, according to figures released by his office to show greater openness in royal finances. The prince, heir to the British throne, disclosed his income tax bill for the first time, saying he paid more than $6 million in taxes, roughly the same as a year earlier. His income is based on rents and investment income from the Duchy of Cornwall, one of Britain's biggest and oldest private estates, created in 1337 by King Edward III. Charles was also said to have raised around $200 million for charities. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

Nascar spilled into prime time on Sunday, which meant that Fox won the night among adults 18 to 49. After the race, repeats of Fox's animated comedies either won or tied their half-hour slots in that demographic. In Nielsen's estimates, a 9 p.m. ''Family Guy'' (6.61 million) was second only to the Nascar broadcast among 18-to-49-year-olds. In the total viewer category, CBS won easily. Its ''60 Minutes'' (9.25 million) was the most-watched show of the night, and a rerun of ''Cold Case'' (8.22 million) also brought in a large audience for a summer Sunday. ABC, which dominated Sundays during the regular season, placed third in the 18-to-49 demographic and fourth, behind NBC, among total viewers. Its repeats of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' at 8 p.m. (6.07 million) and ''Grey's Anatomy'' at 10 p.m. (6.61 million) fared well, but the ''Desperate Housewives'' rerun (4.51 million) sandwiched between them wiped out. KATE AURTHUR

To the Editor: Re ''Stephen Hawking Takes Beijing; Now, Will Science Follow?'' (June 20): I hope the Chinese Academy of Sciences has its American counterpart's recent report ''Revealing the Hidden Nature of Space and Time,'' which recommends building an international linear collider to explore high-energy electron-positron interactions.

DEMPSEY--Patricia A., died peacefully at her home in New York City on June 25, 2006 surrounded by her family. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Louis F. Dempsey. Devoted mother of Maryann Sedlack (Jeff) of Cheshire, Connecticut, Patsy Hammond (Bill) of Summit, New Jersey, Kathleen Malhame (George) of Manhasset, New York, Louis F. Dempsey (Maria) of Weston, Connecticut, and Thomas F. Dempsey (Melinda) of Bronxville, New York. Cherished grandmother of Will, Anne, Meg, Charlie, Mary, Katie, Jack, Luke, Mark, Colin, Hannah, and Maeve. Beloved daughter of the late Thomas J. Fox and the late Agnes Fox of New York, New York. She was predeceased by her sisters Kathryn Kade and Agnes McGoldrick and by her brother Thomas Fox. In addition to being a wonderful mother and wife, Pat was a Registered Nurse and trained at Adelphi College School of Nursing. As an RN during WWII, Pat crossed the Atlantic 20 times as a ship's nurse where she cared for Nazi concentration camp survivors. Pat was Secretary of the Board of the Catholic Guild for the Blind and was active in other Catholic organizations. The family will receive family and friends at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Home at 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York on June 27 from 3:00 to 5:00 PM and from 7:00 to 9:00 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said on June 28 at 10:00 AM at the Church of St. Mary, 1300 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York. Burial will be held at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Catholic Charities Community Services (Guild for the Blind) at 1011 First Avenue, New York, New York 10022, Attn: Therese Snyder.

Tick Patrol Q. Do ticks have any natural predators that might control them? A. There are several species, mainly other arthropods, that feed on ticks, but few of these predators have been extensively studied to see if they have a real impact on tick populations. Many anecdotal reports suggest that chickens and guinea fowl prey enthusiastically, if opportunistically, on local tick infestations, but there is no formal evidence that they are an effective means of control.

GROSSMAN--Dr. William. The members of the New Jersey Psychoanalytic Society mourn the abrupt and premature passing of our beloved colleague, Dr. William Grossman. It is hard to imagine our psychoanalytic lives without his remarkable presence. He was a brilliant thinker, a generous friend, a majestic man. Although gone, he will live on in all of us. Gisela Zerykier, M.D., President New Jersey Psychonanalytic Society

Seven soldiers were killed and 20 wounded when a suicide bomber blew up his car at a checkpoint near the town of Miramshah, in the restive tribal region of North Waziristan. The attack was the third suicide attack in recent weeks in the region and came just as the government had brokered a cease-fire agreement from pro-Taliban militants in the adjoining district of South Waziristan in an effort to end the conflict. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

NIVES--Ernest, 81, on June 25, 2006. Born Vienna, Austria. Husband of Fanny, father of David and Julie, grandfather of Marisa and Zoe, brother of Fred. As a Holocaust survivor, you carried forward your message by educating others; you earned the devotion and love of so many who admired you.

Larry Brown was fired because of a disastrous, deflating and, at times, comical Knicks season. If the franchise does not rebound soon, Isiah Thomas will be the next one to lose his job. Speaking publicly for the first time since firing Brown, team owner James L. Dolan said today that Thomas the team president and now the head coach has one season to show "significant progress."

To the Editor: Re ''Ground Zero Memorial, Revised but Not Improved'' (Critic's Notebook, Arts pages, June 22): I agree with Nicolai Ouroussoff's sharp criticism of the latest design plan for the ground zero memorial: to build this version would be a tragic mistake.
The Supreme Court will consider government regulation of vehicle carbon dioxide emissions. Page A14.

WEIL--Michael P. Friends and colleagues at the New York City Department of City Planning mourn the untimely passing of Mike Weil. A professional with the utmost integrity and honesty, Mike used his formidable planning, architecture and urban design skills to help shape the city he loved so dearly. As Director of Zoning and Urban Design for the last ten years, one of his greatest achievements was the master plan for the two-mile Greenpoint/ Williamsburg waterfront. All of us at City Planning will miss him greatly. He will be remembered for his candor, commitment, character, sense of humor, talent and creativity.

SHERMAN--Julia. 96. Dear wife of Bernard. Mother of Barbara Pohl and Paula Wagner. Grandmother and step grandmother of seven and great grandmother of seven. Sister of William E. Grubel of Sunrise, FL. Services private.

Survived by his wife, Elizabeth Jayne Skudder and by five children and eleven grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife of 32 years, Margaret Youmans Skudder. Visiting hours at Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave., Pelham, Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor on Wednesday, 10am. BILLIONS TO HELP FIGHT DISEASE -- Warren E. Buffett's $31 billion gift to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will help the foundation pursue its goal of curing the globe's 20 leading fatal diseases, Mr. Gates said, along with improving education. [A1.] SHARED VIEWS OF TWO BILLIONAIRES -- Bill Gates and Warren Buffett both have a disdain for inherited wealth and share the view that the capitalist system that has enriched them is not capable alone of addressing the root causes of poverty. [C1.] GAME MAKER IS SUBPOENAED -- The video game publisher Take-Two Interactive said that it had received a grand jury subpoena from the Manhattan district attorney's office, seeking information about a range of its business practices dating back to 2001 and its inclusion of sexually explicit material in one of its games. A company spokesman said the district attorney had not told Take-Two whether it or any of its executives or directors were the focus of the inquiry. [C1.] HEART DEVICES RECALLED -- Boston Scientific said that it was recalling 23,000 heart pacemakers and defibrillators and recommended that 27,000 patients who already have the devices in their chests consult their doctors. Market Place. [C1.] PART OF VIOXX PAPER RETRACTED -- The simmering controversy over data from the 2004 clinical trial that caused Merck to stop selling Vioxx bubbled up again, as the New England Journal of Medicine retracted part of a paper it had published about the trial. [C13.] FINDINGS ON FOOD AND DRUG LAW -- A 15-month inquiry by a top House Democrat has found that enforcement of food and drug laws declined sharply during the first five years of the Bush administration. [A15.] EMISSIONS CASE ACCEPTED -- The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the federal government is required to control vehicle emissions of carbon dioxide, the principal greenhouse gas that has been linked to global warming. [A14.] 35,000 TO LEAVE G.M. -- In an employee exodus that is one of the biggest ever, about 48,000 workers at General Motors and Delphi accepted early retirement or buyout offers. [C1.] ANTI-PORNOGRAPHY EFFORT -- In the face of government pressure, a group of Internet companies is undertaking an effort to help combat child pornography online. [C3.] SALES OF NEW HOMES INCREASE -- Sales of new homes rose in May, surprising economists who had been forecasting that housing would slow because of rising loan rates. [C3.] STEEL INDUSTRY AD CAMPAIGN -- The steel industry has inaugurated an advertising campaign to reposition itself as a vibrant and crucial part of the American economy. [C10.] JUSTICES TO HEAR PHONE CASE -- The Supreme Court said that it would consider a lawsuit that accuses the nation's largest telephone companies of violating federal antitrust law by conspiring to carve up local markets to preserve their monopolies. [C3.] CHANGE AT THE TOP AT KRAFT -- Amid lackluster earnings growth and a stagnant share price, the directors of Kraft Food ousted the chief executive, Roger K. Deromedi, left, who had been at Kraft for 28 years and its head since 2001. He will be succeeded by Irene B. Rosenfeld, who will become one of 12 women leading a Fortune 500 company. Analysts say that Kraft has lagged some rivals in introducing successful products. [C3.] NEWSPAPER DEAL APPROVED -- Shareholders of Knight Ridder, the newspaper company, voted overwhelmingly to sell the company to McClatchy. [C10.] MINING DEAL MAY NOT BE FINAL -- The $40 billion deal by the copper miner Phelps Dodge to acquire Inco and Falconbridge, two major nickel producers in Canada, could yet be upset by another bid, analysts say. [C11.] BIAS AGAINST RUSSIA SEEN -- The Russian oligarch Aleksei Mordashov lost the battle for the steel company Arcelor for one reason, Russian politicians say: Russophobia. [C11.]

For the first time in four years, General Motors is changing agencies of record on a principal brand. General Motors said yesterday that Modernista in Boston would become the creative agency for its Cadillac division, effective Oct. 1. The assignment had been handled by the Troy, Mich., office of Leo Burnett and predecessor agencies since 1936.

To the Editor: Re ''To Lower Risk on Jogging Trail, Get Off the Couch'' (Personal Health, June 20): If those who run regularly are less likely to have a heart attack, does that prove that running regularly is good for the heart? Or does it simply indicate that those with a strong heart and good health otherwise are more likely to enjoy running and do it more regularly?

An Egyptian court sentenced Ibrahim Eissa, the editor of Al Dustour, a independent weekly newspaper that has regularly been critical of President Hosni Mubarak, to a year in prison for defaming Mr. Mubarak. Mr. Eissa had published an article last year that reported on a lawsuit brought against Mr. Mubarak by an Egyptian who accused him of corruption. MONA EL-NAGGAR (NYT)

To the Editor: I was 18 when I was groped on the E train (''Women Have Seen It All on Subway, Unwillingly,'' front page, June 24). The shame of the assault that lasted barely a nanosecond has stayed with me for 34 years.

J. K. Rowling revealed yesterday that at leasttwo characters will die in the seventh and whatshe says will be the final installment of her best-sellingHarry Potter series. But she was carefulnot to say who. Ms. Rowling, right, has alreadysaid that the final chapter of the seventh book waswritten long ago. "The final chapter is hiddenaway, although it's now changed very slightly,"she said in an interview broadcast on Channel 4 inBritain. "One character got a reprieve, but I haveto say two die that I didn't intend to die." Whenasked to be more specific, she added: "No, I'm not going to commit myself,because I don't want the hate mail or anything else." She did say that she understoodan author's desire to kill off the main character of a successful series."I've never been tempted to kill him off before the end of Book 7," shesaid, referring to Harry, "because I always planned seven books, and that'swhere I want to go. I can completely understand, however, the mentality of anauthor who thinks, 'Well, I'm going to kill them off because that means therecan be no non-author-written sequels.' "

MURPHY--Julie. With heartfelt sorrow, Horace Mann School mourns the untimely passing of Julie Murphy '86, beloved daughter of John and Noreen Murphy, Executive Assistant to Head of School Dr. Thomas Kelly, and devoted and adored sister of Denise Regan '84, and Melissa Parento '90, Director of Development. Julie's kindness and generosity of spirit, her deep affection for Horace Mann, her selfless nurturing and outreach, her great sense of humor and her calm, boundless courage in dealing with life's vagaries will continue to inspire us. With universal charm Julie made everyone she met feel they were her friends for life. Julie earned the love, respect and admiration of all who knew her. May our wonderful memories of her be a source of consolation to us all. She will be deeply missed. Our sincere condolences, thoughts and love are with Julie's family and friends in this time of profound sadness and mourning. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly, Head of School Robert J. Katz '65 Chair, Board of Trustees $(6$)MURPHY--Julie, on June 26, 2006 at age 37. Cherished daughter of Noreen and John. Beloved sister of Denise Regan (her husband Finbar) and Melissa Parento (her husband Stephen). Loving aunt to Taylor, Shane and Jack.
