ATKIND--Russell Scott, on June 25, 2006, of Brooklyn. Beloved son of Marsha and David Atkind. Dear grandson of Leon Belle and Rose Atkind. Dear great nephew of Doris Atkind. A 1994 valedictorian graduate of Montclair High School, Russell graduated from Yale in 1998, where he served as Director of the Klezmer Band, glee club member and the Advisory Council as an alumni representative. He was head of the computer technology department of the upper school of the Packer Collegiate Institute of Brooklyn from 20012005 and most recently served as software designer for Wireless Generation of Brooklyn. Services were held June 26 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Funeral Home in Livingston, NJ. For Shiva information, call 973-422-0600.

An article in The Arts on June 19 about the purchase of ''Adele Bloch-Bauer I,'' a portrait by Gustav Klimt, for the Neue Galerie by Ronald S. Lauder misstated the context in which an Austrian journalist uncovered crucial documents about the work in 1998. The journalist, Hubertus Czernin, was conducting independent research in Austria when he found a will by Ms. Bloch-Bauer mentioning the portrait; he was not researching the case for The Boston Globe. (Austria turned over the painting this year to a niece of Ms. Bloch-Bauer, Maria Altmann of Los Angeles, who sold it to Mr. Lauder.)

To the Editor: Re ''A Threat That Belongs Behind Bars,'' by Eric Posner (Op-Ed, June 25): International law requires that prisoners of war be accorded the same procedural protections that American soldiers receive under the Uniform Code of Military Justice and that there be a competent tribunal to determine whether an individual is a prisoner of war.
MARDIN--Arif M. On June 25, 2006. The family will receive friends on Wednessay from 4 to 8 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Burial at a later date in Turkey.

OH YEAH? SEZ WHO? -- New York City is ranked the most polite of major world cities in a survey in the July issue of Reader's Digest. The magazine sent reporters to major cities in 35 countries to study public courtesy. After New York in the top five were Zurich, Toronto, Berlin and S√£o Paulo. The bottom five were Singapore, Seoul, Kuala Lumpur, Bucharest and Mumbai. FEWER EUROPEANS COMING -- European air passenger traffic to the United States was off more than 9 percent in the first quarter of this year, says Donald N. Martin & Company, citing Commerce Department data. No reasons were suggested for the downturn, after increases of 6.5 percent and 12.1 percent in 2005 and 2004, respectively. One possible benefit, the forecaster says, is that ''more seats may be available for Americans bound for Europe'' this summer, though trans-Atlantic fares are projected to remain high. U.S. SHARE OF WORLD TRAVEL OFF -- In a speech to the Foreign Policy Association last week J. W. Marriott Jr., chairman of Marriott International, noted that while the global travel industry has grown about 30 percent in the last decade, the United States' share of world travel has shrunk by as much as 9 percent. A major reason is that security procedures for obtaining visas abroad are increasingly tangled. The average wait in Brazil for an interview to obtain a visa to visit the United States is 55 days, he said. In 2000, about 737,000 Brazilians traveled to the United States. Last year, only 485,000 came, he said. MAXJET GROWS -- MaxJet, the discount all-business-class start-up that flies between Stansted Airport serving London and New York and Washington, acquired its third 767 aircraft. In May, the carrier reported a load factor -- the average number of seats occupied by paying customers -- of 72 percent on the New York-London route. Gary Rogliano, the chief executive, said MaxJet planned to acquire a fourth 767 and to announce a new domestic city flying to Stansted later this year. He declined to identify the city. ET CETERA -- Marriott Hotels and Renaissance Hotels are rolling out lobby computer stations to allow guests to check in for flights and print out their boarding passes. Ten hotels -- all properties of Marriott International -- now have the stations and 150 more will be equipped within two weeks, Marriott said. Virgin Air reported a 10.1 percent increase in business-class traffic for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, citing increasing demand for the new Upper Class Suite business-class product it introduced in late 2003 Underscoring rising fares, the Air Transport Association said that yields -- prices paid per mile flown -- for domestic airlines rose 11.9 percent in May compared with May 2005. JOE SHARKEY

A front-page article on Friday about possible ways to reduce the risk of suffering from lethal injection misstated an effect of a fatal overdose of a barbiturate drug, sodium thiopental. The drug does not cause involuntary jerking movements before death even when used alone. The article also misstated the amount of time that would have to pass in some states before death could be pronounced if a barbiturate alone was used. In states where death is determined by listening for a heartbeat, death could be pronounced in as little as 5 to 10 minutes after the injection, not 45 minutes. It could take up to 45 minutes only in states that use the cessation of electrical activity in the heart to determine death.

An article yesterday about the controversy over the construction of a dam in Laos that will provide the country a source of income misidentified the location of Thailand, which is expected to get some of the electricity produced as a result of the dam. It is to the west of Laos, not to the east.

DePINNA--Marcia Pincus. We acknowledge with sorrow the passing of Marcia DePinna, the beloved mother and grandmother of our dear friends. Our heartfelt sympathy to Jane, Stanley, Robyn and Margot and Geoffrey, Bernadette, Caryn and Gregory. Shelley, Steven, Elisabeth, and Andrew Holm

Waiting to expose a baby to cereal grains until after the age of 6 months may increase the risk that the infant will become allergic to wheat, a new study suggests. Researchers followed 1,612 children from birth until an average age of about 4 1/2. The prevalence of wheat allergy among the 958 children exposed to cereal grains before 6 months was 0.41 percent. But among the 654 who were not exposed to grains before that age, it was 1.8 percent, more than four times as high. Of the 16 children who developed the allergy, 12 had not received cereal grains until they were older than 6 months.

To the Editor: If John Tierney (''Kicking the Soccer Habit,'' column, June 24) and fellow Americans feel bored by the ''long scoreless stretches'' of soccer, it is because their sporting sensibilities have been molded by our industrialist obsession with productivity. The rhythm and progress of Americans' favorite sports are defined by instant, up-to-the-minute, quantifiable results that measure production: yards gained or lost, balls and strikes, points and rebounds.

KEILLOR--Ronald Woodhull, 82, of Essex, CT, died June 23, 2006 at Middlesex Hospital Hospice Unit in Middletown. He is survived by his loving wife Wilda (Heath) Keillor, his four children, Frederick M. Keillor of Martha's Vineyard, MA, Dana Davison (Keillor-Fitton) of Essex, CT, Jay D. Keillor of Monroe, CT, Ronald W. Keillor Jr. of Kerhonkson, NY, his son-in-law Geoffrey Fitton, 11 grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. He served honorably in the USGC during WWII and was the former Chief of the East Williston, NY Volunteer Fire Dept. Graveside services will be held at Wading River Cemetery, Wading River, L.I. on Wednesday, June 28, 2006 at 10 A.M. Memorial service to follow at 4 P.M. at the First Congregational Church, Methodist Hill, Essex, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to the First Congregational Church in Essex. For information contact Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home, Centerbrook, CT.

To the Editor: ''Video of Ill-Fated Uzbek Rising Offers Haunting, Complex View'' (front page, June 22) notes that the video of the events in Andijon, Uzbekistan, on May 13, 2005, even after heavy editing by the government to suit propaganda purposes, shows that a vast majority of protesters that day were unarmed. It is important to shed light on the protesters' grievances and goals, and equally important is the need for justice for the hundreds killed that day. Even given the presence of some armed people, the Uzbek government flouted its obligation under international law to desist from using disproportionate and certainly lethal force in policing the protest.

Pedro Mart√≠nez used to pitch for the Red Sox, and Willie Randolph used to coach for the Yankees, which meant that they often found themselves in the center of some rather intense moments. At times each said some unprintable words to the other. While the Mets were wooing him during the 2004 off-season, Mart√≠nez was curious whether his history with Randolph, selected as the Mets manager six weeks earlier, would diminish his chances of signing with them. Obviously, the answer was no, but Mart√≠nez made a point of speaking to General Manager Omar Minaya about it during the early stages of the courtship.

The David Carr column in Business Day on June 19 about political documentaries misstated the reason that an electric vehicle was removed from a display at the Smithsonian Institution on June 14, shortly before the release of the film ''Who Killed the Electric Car?'' It was taken out as part of the standard rotation of exhibits; it was not removed in anticipation of the documentary's release.

8 P.M. (BET) BET AWARDS '06 -- Bring on the scorecards, and hunker down for a long evening. Jamie Foxx, ever the Renaissance man, has earned five nominations -- including best male R&B artist and best male actor -- for these awards honoring achievements by African-Americans and other members of minorities in music, sports and entertainment. But it's Damon Wayans, as host of this ceremony broadcast live from Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, who pulls off the evening's big coup: he'll present the humanitarian award to Harry Belafonte and the lifetime achievement award to the inimitable Chaka Khan. The festivities begin at 6 when ''106 and Park'' points its cameras at fabulosity radiating from the red carpet. And at 11, in ''The Black Carpet Lounge: BET Awards Post Show,'' the winners -- and we're guessing that means you, Mr. Foxx (above, with Mary J. Blige, also a nominee) -- will speak. 7:30 P.M. (IFC) YO SOY BORICUA, PA'QUE TU LO SEPAS! In some sense, Puerto Ricans are neither here nor there. They are citizens of the United States but don't vote for the president. They travel without restriction between the island and the mainland, yet endure prejudice and economic oppression. So what makes them so darn proud? Inspired by the exuberance of the Puerto Rican Day Parade, the actress Rosie Perez, in her directorial debut, asks that question of members of the band Yerba Buena (above right) and others, while examining the complex history between the United States and its Caribbean commonwealth. 8 P.M. (Discovery Times) GUESTS OF THE AYATOLLAH -- It was the event that did in the Carter presidency, and yet just another bump along the gnarled road of relations between the United States and Iran. Parts 3 and 4 of this documentary based on Mark Bowden's book about the Iran hostage crisis examines President Jimmy Carter's authorization of an Army rescue mission and, at 9, negotiations as the 1980 presidential elections approached that led to the release of hostages only minutes after Ronald Reagan was sworn in. 9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING -- Rise and shine. The comics get a surprise earlybird wake-up call to exhibit their wares on Adam Carolla's radio show. Turns out two don't catch the worm. 9 P.M. (13) ZIMBABWE: SHADOWS AND LIES -- Whither Zimbabwe? Once a model of independence and economic success, the country has slid into a quagmire of poverty and terror as its 82-year-old president, Robert Mugabe (above), has metamorphosed from liberation hero to Africa's longest-standing dictator. In this ''Frontline/World'' documentary, Alexis Bloom and Cassandra Herrman pose as tourists to meet secretly with opposition leaders, dissidents and people merely struggling to survive a country plunged into darkness and deceit. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

An American soldier died of wounds received in fighting with insurgents on Sunday in eastern Kunar Province, the United States military reported. In another attack, a suicide bomber detonated his car behind an American military convoy not far from Bagram Air Base, near Kabul, killing himself and wounding Afghan boys playing near the road. No soldiers were hurt in the blast. CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''In Medicine, Acceptable Risk Is in the Eye of the Beholder'' (June 20): Dr. Peter A. Ubel's findings are consistent with what we know about people's willingness or unwillingness to make different types of errors. In a classic game-show puzzle, a contestant picks one of three doors; the host, who knows where the prize is, then opens another door to show no prize, and asks the contestant if he would like to switch his choice to the other closed door. Few switch, even though that would double the odds of winning.

The city's special prosecutor for narcotics criticized the revisions in the Rockefeller drug laws yesterday, saying they benefited major drug traffickers more than the low-level offenders they were supposed to help. A year and a half after the State Legislature revised the drug laws in an effort to reduce harsh prison sentences for low-level offenders, a study by the prosecutor, Bridget G. Brennan, examined 84 drug offenders prosecuted by her office who have asked for resentencing since the laws were changed in 2004. The offenders had been convicted of possessing or selling enough hard drugs to make them eligible for sentences of at least 15 years to life.

NACHT--Carl H., M.D. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center family acknowledges with profound sadness the untimely passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Carl H. Nacht, M.D., who earned the respect and admiration of all of us for his constant devotion to his patients and his profession. As Medical Director for West Care Medical Associates, SLR's multi site primary and specialty practice, Carl was principally responsible for the oversight of the medical care provided to thousands of New Yorkers. He also served as President of River to River Medical Associates, a multi site voluntary medical practice with which SLR also has enjoyed a longstanding relationship. Carl did his medical training at SLR, was very involved with the Hospital Center's Medical Board and its various committees and was an active participant in its teaching and training programs. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him and worked with him--but most especially by those who turned to him for help. To his beloved wife Mary Beth, daughter Zoe, son Asher, and all of his family and loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Board of Trustees Richard F. Daines, M.D. President and CEO Donna Mendes, M.D. President, Medical Board Michael Lesch, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Medicine $(6$)NACHT--Dr. Carl Henry. On June 25, 2006. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign has hired Peter Daou, one of the most prominent political bloggers in the nation, to help disseminate her message in a forum that has not always been that hospitable to her. The move underscores the degree to which bloggers -- the authors of Web logs, or blogs -- have begun to transform American politics. In many cases, candidates have even set up their own blogs, with staffers answering questions, presenting policy proposals and posting campaign literature and videos.

GERLI--John Emanuel, at the age of 96, died peacefully on June 20th at the Pavilion of the Osborn Retirement Center in Rye, NY. His large and extended family mourns his passing. He is survived by his brother David, his wife, Christine, his sons John Jr. and Alexander, his daughters Margaret, Eleanor and Diana, his grandchildren John III, Margaret, and Linda, and grandsons Bennett and Brooks, and Alexander Jr. and Carrington, and five great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his twin sisters, Diana and Muriel. John Gerli was born on October 16, 1909 in New York City. He attended the Allen Stevenson and Hotchkiss Schools, and graduated from Yale University, Class of 1932. He was an executive with E. Gerli & Co. and with Greef Fabric Company and co-owner of Palmer Marine Engine Company, located in Cos Cob, CT. In WWII he served as an Intelligence Officer with the U.S. Army's 66th Fighter Wing of the 8th Air Force. He was posted to a command position outside of Cambridge, England with a fighter plane group supporting bomber raids and reconnaissance flights. He was awarded the Distinguished Service Cross. He was very active in the community life of the Town of Greenwich, CT. He served as a member of the Greenwich Police Auxiliary Force. He served as a member of the Representative Town Meeting, representing District 11, for over fifty years, and he was honored in 2004 for his long and devoted service to that body. He was also a Trustee of the Northeast Greenwich Association. As an active and enthusiastic skier, till his 92nd year, he was a co-founder and a Vice President of the Mad River Glen Ski area in Vermont, where he maintained a residence and participated in a number of local groups. He was a member of the Amateur Ski Club of New York, the Round Hill Club, and the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, and Honorary Member of Ye Olde King's Highway Stamp Club of Darien, CT, and the Horseneck Club of Greenwich. Memorial Service to be held at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich on Wednesday, June 28th at 4PM. Memorial contributions may be made to: The Boys & Girls Club of Greenwich, or the Mad River Valley Community Fund.

The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said Tuesday that while North Korea showed clear signs of preparing a missile for a test launching, it remained uncertain whether it was fully fueled for an imminent firing. The chairman, Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican, spoke on Capitol Hill after committee members received a closed-door briefing from officials of the Missile Defense Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency and the defense secretary's office.

I have a clear memory of the moment I learned the word "taboo." I was 7 or 8, and I had just spent the day walking around a golf course with a great friend of my mother's (and later, of mine), a man called Tim, and his opponent, a woman called Nora. They had not played each other before. Nora, it transpired, was an excellent golfer. Tim was not. She trounced him. Worse, she didn't do it from what I learned were called the "ladies' tees." She didn't do it from the "gentlemen's tees." She did it from the hardest of all, the "tiger tees."

Stardoll.com, a Web site that lets young girls virtually dress up their favorite stars in the latest fashions, landed $6 million in venture financing from Sequoia Capital. The relatively diminutive funding round has enjoyed big-time news coverage over the past couple of days, with Forbes.com, CNET News.com and Red Herring Online (which focuses on technology-finance news) all publishing staff-written articles about it. The deal was first reported last week, before it was formally announced, in a short item by Om Malik on his GigaOm blog.

I'd planned to do a piece from China on the environment, but there was too much else to do. Still, it's a fascinating topic, and although most of the focus has been on how China's modernization will leave the entire globe filthy and under a rising sea, the fact is that Beijing has done more than many developing countries in addressing environmental concerns.

Christopher Hitchens, the hawkiest of Iraq hawks, offers four suggestions in his latest Slate column for how people opposed to the Iraq war "who don't want to be associated with Michael Moore, George Galloway, Ramsey Clark and the rest of the Zarqawi and Saddam apologists can make themselves plain." Unfortunately, he appears to believe that the only way for antiwar opponents to prove they are not acting in "bad faith" is to risk their lives by traveling to Iraq and serving as "human shields" against the insurgency - the "chickendove" inverse of the specious "chickenhawk" argument - but the column is typically provocative.

Six months after buying Hertz in a $14 billion leveraged buyout, Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, Carlyle Group and Merrill Lynch Private Equity are about to collect a $1 billion dividend, recouping almost half their original equity investment. The financing is expected to close Friday, June 30.

Mu Security, a player in the new security analyzer market, has raised an additional $10 million in a Series B funding round. Mu's second round of financing was led by Duff, Alderman & Goodrich Ventures and includes Series A investors Accel Partners and Benchmark Capital, bringing Mu Security's total funding since inception to $14 million.

A federal judge ruled yesterday that a tactic used by prosecutors to crack down on corporate misconduct violated the constitutional rights of employees, a decision that may change the way the government pursues white-collar cases.
Warren Buffett, the world's second-richest person, has no interest in stepping down as chairman and chief executive of the insurance and investment company Berkshire Hathaway, Reuters reported.
Time Warner said Tuesday no company funds were used by the chief financial officer, Wayne Pace, for gifts he allegedly made to an accused prostitution ringleader.
Eurotunnel has called on British and French regulators to investigate whether an alternative debt restructuring plan led by Deutsche Bank is misleading investors.
Nokia, the world's biggest cell phone maker, has sued two Chinese competitors in its first Chinese legal action alleging illegal product copying.
In a rare case of music retailer-turned-Internet pirate, the Virgin store chain in France said Tuesday that it had been found guilty of downloading and reselling a Madonna hit without permission.
Lawrence J. Ellison, chief executive of the Oracle Corporation and one of the world's wealthiest people, has decided not to donate $115 million to Harvard as he announced he would last year.

Federal securities regulators said Tuesday that Morgan Stanley had agreed to pay $10 million to settle claims that it had failed to maintain proper procedures to prevent the misuse of insider information.
A bank manager who embezzled 21 million pounds ($38 million) from his employer in Scotland's biggest single fraud case was jailed for 10 years on Tuesday.
The European Court of Human Rights refused on Tuesday to halt extradition proceedings against three British bankers wanted in the United States on fraud charges related to the Enron collapse.

The Chinese government disclosed $1.1 billion worth of fraud at one of the country's largest state-owned banks this week, underscoring the risks confronting foreign investors as they seek big stakes in China's precarious banking system.

EADS' co-chief executive, Noel Forgeard, faced a parliamentary grilling in his battle to survive a management crisis at the planemaker Airbus on Wednesday amid mounting signals its German shareholders want him to go.

According to a survey of hedge-fund managers in Asia conducted by the CFA Center for Financial Market Integrity, 77 percent of respondents support greater regulation by financial service authorities or securities regulators to protect investors, and 49 percent say regulation should apply to both retail and wholesale investors.

A former chief executive of Capital Bank, Jim Beck has turned to Greenville, N.C., to once again run a Raleigh bank. Mr. Beck and a partner, Steve Johnson of Atlanta, will buy Greenville-based Millennia Community Bank, rename it TrustAtlantic Financial, and move it to Raleigh. Founded in 2000, Millennia has total assets of about $30 million, 19 employees and two offices.
Six venture capital groups are racing to buy the Spanish company that owns the rights to MotoGP - motorcycling's answer to Formula One - which is up for sale with a price tag of 500 million euros.

The first share float on the Chinese stock exchanges since the end of a temporary moratorium on initial public share offerings by state-run firms is being investigated by the Chinese authorities because of suspicions of market-rigging.
Shares in Elpida Memory, Japan's largest maker of computer memory chips, slumped as much as 11 percent after the company said it would sell about 137 billion yen ($1.2 billion) of stock.
Rosneft, a Russian state-owned oil and gas company with assets estimated at more than $60 billion, is planning to raise $11.6 billion in an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

Shares of J. Crew Group surged nearly 28 percent in their first trading day, a gain that was all the more impressive considering that their offer price was well above previous estimates. After setting an expected range of $15 to $17 per share, underwriters led by Goldman Sachs and Bear Stearns priced J. Crew's initial public offering offering at $20, raising $376 million for the clothing company, excluding discounts and commissions. The stock closed Wednesday at $25.55 on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the company a total market capitalization of about $1.45 billion.
Bank of China drew $84.6 billion of bids for the nation's biggest domestic public offering, 52 times the stock on offer, underlining demand for share sales after the lifting of a yearlong ban.

J.P. Morgan has bolstered its Asian financials team, appointing Samuel Chen senior financial analyst. Mr. Chen will report directly to Sunil Garg, managing director of Asian financials research, and Frank Gong, head of China equity research. Mr. Chen will work in both Hong Kong and China.

In a surprise move Munesh Khanna announced yesterday his resignation as co-head of investment banking at Enam Financial Consultants. Khanna, who joined Enam from NM Rothschild, spent less then a year at the investment bank. Previously, he worked at Arthur Andersen, where he set up and headed the corporate finance practice in India.

Goldman Sachs chairman and President Bush's Treasury secretary nominee Henry M. Paulson Jr. treaded carefully at his confirmation hearing before the Senate Finance Committee on Tuesday. Mr. Paulson reiterated Mr. Bush's general views on the need for low taxes, budget restraint, increased American competitiveness and the use of persuasion rather than threats in dealing with China on economic issues.
Origin Energy, Australia's second-largest power retailer, abandoned plans to merge with its New Zealand unit, Contact Energy, citing a lack of support from shareholders.

Comcast has purchased thePlatform, a fast-growing Seattle startup whose software helps about 60 customers, including National Geographic, CNBC and The Wall Street Journal, distribute video and audio content over the Internet.
McClatchy closed on its acquisition of Knight Ridder Tuesday and will emerge as the nation's second-largest newspaper company measured by circulation.
China Life Insurance bought 12 percent of Citic Securities for 3.25 billion yuan ($406 million), the biggest brokerage acquisition by a Chinese insurer as the government relaxes investment barriers.

Univision's acceptance of a $12.3 billion bid from a group of private equity firms on Tuesday has provoked the ire of rival suitor Grupo Televisa which contends it has been deliberately shunned in favor of a lesser bid.
The Russian steel company Severstal is considering a bid for an Anglo-Dutch rival, Corus, just days after its merger attempt with Luxembourg's Arcelor was derailed, Reuters reported.
Shades by Oliver Peoples, Dior, Marc Jacobs, Cutler and Gross, Mykita's, and others.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has reportedly joined Macquarie's bid for the core assets of the Hong Kong telecom giant PCCW, and the Macquarie-News Corporation team has attracted one more member, according to .

Reliance Industries, a major Indian energy company, announced on Tuesday that it would expand into retailing with a $5.6 billion investment and a plan to add hundreds of thousands of employees in the next few years.

The Australian and Canadian investment funds that are the remaining members of the Macquarie consortium bidding for Associated British Ports are thought to have pulled out, raising the likelihood that the ports operator will fall to a rival group led by Goldman Sachs.
Water-based exercise, once practiced only by the 60-plus set, is coming out of retirement.

The standoff between EMI Group and Warner Music has flared into a two-way takeover battle, with each company rejecting bids from the other. Less than two months after EMI of London first unveiled its unsolicited $4.2 billion offer for New York-based Warner Music, EMI said Wednesday that Warner Music had proposed acquiring EMI -- once, for 315 pence per share, on June 14, and again, for 320 pence per share, on June 27. The second bid is valued at about $4.6 billion.
Harper Lee has written a letter for O, the Oprah Winfrey magazine, about how she became a reader as a child.
At the Nassau County Museum of Art, an exhibition tries to convey how women's fashion over the past two centuries has mirrored social and artistic change.
The U.S. futures industry regulator said today that BP tried to corner the propane market in February 2004.
Heavily armed, haute couture vampires confront a still deadly "Blade" in a new series premiering Tuesday on Spike TV.

Those who like their soccer announcers passionate and excitable rather than calm and measured will appreciate Huang Jianxiang, the commentator handling the play-by-play of the Italy-Australia match for China Central Television. According to News Guangdong, Huang "shouted himself hoarse," "shrieked in excitement" and generally "lost his cool" as Fabio Grosso earned a controversial 93rd-minute penalty that was converted by Francesco Totti to give Italy a 1-0 victory over Guus Hiddink's Socceroos.

As much as everyone makes fun of American TV coverage of the World Cup -- including Budweiser ads in the U.K. -- it is also true that the ratings for this World Cup are through the roof in the U.S., more than double those of 2002. That's largely because most of the games in 2002 were on at 5 a.m. or similar ungodly hours, while this year they are on at much more civil times in the morning and afternoon. Still, the numbers are remarkable, for both English-language and Spanish-language telecasts.
Gary Aguirre, who was investigating insider trading charges, testified today to a Senate panel.
A Texas woman flees homeland insecurity for a New York vision quest in this acute, resourceful and bracingly ambitious debut film.
"Rank" is as thorough an examination of the sport of bull riding as you could hope to squeeze into 90 taut, well-organized minutes.
Michael Kang's small, perfectly observed portrait of a Chinese-American boy  captures the glum desperation of inhabiting the biological limbo of early adolescence.
Fast and furious, "Who Killed the Electric Car?" is the sad tale of yet one more attempt by a heroic group of civic-minded souls to save the browning, warming planet.
Like many feature films based on small-screen, short-form comedy, "Strangers With Candy" feels more like a long, sloppy "very special" episode than a movie.
Though chardonnay is here to stay, the style of California chardonnay is very much worth discussing, even to the point of contentiousness.
Am√©lie Mauresmo, Venus Williams and Maria Sharapova trounced their opponents today, while high-profile men had to work harder to advance.

Control orders ‚Äî a form of house arrest without trial ‚Äî violate European human rights laws, a judge ruled today.
Thousands of people have been evacuated, and at least nine people have been killed, authorities said.
Egypt's chief Egyptologist had a theory that a 3,300-year-old tomb was the burial place of King Tut's mother, Queen Kiya.

The order reflected the deep shock and anger that has unfolded since the killing of five Russians in Iraq.
The ruling does not threaten Republican gains after redistricting, but some political lines must be redrawn to address the court's concerns.
Sedley Alley was only the second person executed in Tennessee since 1960.

President Vladimir V. Putin addressed his diplomatic corps on Tuesday, calling for Russia to play a more prominent role in world politics and aligning his country with Asian nations as he distanced himself from American policy.
Honda will spend $550 million to build the new assembly plant, the company's sixth factory in North America.
The architects were eager to avoid creating a fortress that overshadows the World Trade Center memorial.

The secretary of state said the Taliban forces that have mounted renewed attacks will eventually be defeated.
Israeli tanks hunkered down inside Gaza today and warplanes flew over the house of Syrian president Bashar Assad.
The bombing that set off waves of sectarian killing was allegedly the brainchild of an Iraqi member of Al Qaeda.
A Staten Island woman who the police said killed herself was mourned at a service, most intently by her husband, who wept uncontrollably.
Jeering tenants disrupted a meeting as officials approved rent increases for New York's rent-stabilized apartments.
Sheri Sam scored 17 points and Tammy Sutton-Brown added 14 as Charlotte beat the Liberty, 73-67, for its first road victory of the season.

Roger Hoit gave up playing tennis and turned to golf after graduating from Amherst. That decision finally paid off for the 46-year-old Hoit as he won the Ike Stroke Play Championship at the Fresh Meadow Club in Great Neck, N.Y. Hoit, who posted rounds of 75 and 74, finished at 218. Andrew Giuliani, the defending titlist and the first-round leader, and Joe Saladino wound up tied for second at 220. Hoit birdied the par-4 17th hole and followed with another par 4 that clinched his victory.
The Mets' youngest players played as if overwhelmed by the history of Fenway Park.

It is hard to imagine a reigning most valuable player more unloved than Alex Rodriguez. Every time he makes an out in a home game the Yankees are losing, Rodriguez is booed by the fans at Yankee Stadium.
The network will create an official NBC Channel on the popular video Web site to show clips from shows in its fall lineup.
Morgan To Pay $10 Million to Settle S.E.C. Claim.
Intel will sell the division to the Marvell Technology Group for $600 million, as it focuses on its main business of supplying chips for PC's and computer servers.
The announcement comes as analysts expect India to relax rules that block foreign investment, thereby allowing the entry of global players like Wal-Mart.

By The Associated Press.
Isiah Thomas got a new job, an ultimatum and a one-year lease on his office at 2 Penn Plaza — his career and the Knicks' fate now inextricably intertwined.
A 3-year-old Brooklyn girl died yesterday morning after a neighbor found her unconscious and bruised in her East New York apartment, the police said.
Two construction workers excavating the foundation for a warehouse in Brooklyn spent nearly an hour trapped beneath tons of debris.

With a handshake, a hug and four kisses, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, sealed an agreement yesterday on a $52.9 billion budget that sets aside more than $1 billion for health care costs, puts 1,200 more police officers on the street and adds money for libraries, summer jobs and prekindergarten classes.
After years of failed efforts to fight malaria, major donors are increasing financing and pushing for a new approach.

Decades before she became a candidate for the United States Senate, Kathleen Troia McFarland grew up in a home where she was beaten by her father's fists, whipped with belts and kicked as she curled on the floor.
Israel sent troops into Gaza and its planes attacked three bridges and a power station early Wednesday in an operation to rescue a soldier abducted by militants.
Oregon State, a university from a northern state with early-season bad weather, achieved a rare feat by winning the College World Series on Monday.

Experience prevailed as Andre Agassi beat Boris Pashanski of Serbia and Montenegro, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4, 6-3, even though it was not always pretty.

A front-page article on Monday about the abduction of an Israeli soldier by Palestinian militants referred incorrectly to the hostage. He is the fourth Israeli soldier abducted in the Arab-Israeli conflict since 1994, not the first. (Three Israeli soldiers were captured by Shiite Muslim guerrillas along the Israel-Lebanon border in 2000.).

France advanced to the quarterfinals with a victory in a match that restored some beauty to a tournament marred by anarchic grappling for the referee's attention.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 27 (AP) ‚Äî A military jury returned a split verdict on Tuesday against a Coast Guard Academy cadet, acquitting him of a rape charge but convicting him of several other crimes in the first court-martial of a student in the academy's 130-year history.

The N.H.L. salary cap was increased to $44 million, the league and players' association said.  The increase is about $5 million per team.

Mike Sullivan was fired after two seasons as coach of the Boston Bruins, the first major move by Peter Chiarelli, the new general manager.

Nassau County warned the residents of four communities yesterday to use bottled water after a possibly carcinogenic gasoline additive was discovered in their water system.

Dr. Hwang Woo Suk, who fabricated evidence that he had cloned human cells, will open a laboratory in Seoul next month to resume his cloning work, his lawyer said. Dr. Hwang, once hailed as a national hero, went on trial this month, charged with misusing millions of dollars given to him by the government and private donors. His lawyer, Lee Geon Haeng, said private contributors had provided the money to put Dr. Hwang and most of his old research team back into a laboratory.
In an interview on Indian television, Anton Balasingham, the chief negotiator for the Tamil Tiger guerrillas, said the group

Prosecutors recommended that the two leading political parties ‚Äî Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's Thai Rak Thai Party and the opposition Democrat Party ‚Äî be dissolved because of irregularities in national elections in April. The election, which was boycotted by the opposition, was annulled by the courts last month. The main charges grow directly from the Democrats' boycott, including a claim that it was illegal. Mr. Thaksin's party was charged with two violations, including a claim that it illegally financed fringe groups to contest the election to satisfy electoral rules.

A jury in Copenhagen convicted nine people, all family members or friends, of murder or accessory to murder in the killing of a 19-year-old woman. The woman was gunned down by her older brother last September, two days after her wedding, because her Pakistani family disapproved of her choice of a husband. The victim, Ghazala Khan, who was born in Denmark, was shot and killed outside a train station in Slagelse, west of Copenhagen. Besides her brother, the defendants included her father, three uncles, an aunt and two family friends. Sentencing is expected as early as today.

Joschka Fischer, the foreign minister under Chancellor Gerhard Schr√∂der, said he was giving up his seat in Parliament to become a visiting professor at Princeton University, teaching international crisis management in September, and join the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.

President Chen Shui-bian easily survived a recall motion brought by the opposition Nationalist Party over corruption allegations involving his family. Just 119 lawmakers in the 221-member legislature voted for the measure ‚Äî more than half but well below the two-thirds majority, or 148 votes, needed to pass the motion and put the recall question to the electorate in a referendum. Mr. Chen's Democratic Progressive Party boycotted the vote.

The police arrested two people under terrorism legislation in Bolton, outside of Manchester, in the latest in a series of antiterrorism raids ‚Äî some linked, some independent ‚Äî across England in the last few weeks. The two suspects, who have not been formally charged, were taken into custody in the aftermath of a search of eight properties in order to target
Closing out what could be the weakest first half of a year in its history, G.M. will offer zero percent financing over the Independence Day weekend.
Tour de France officials asked the team of a top contender to withdraw Monday, and Tuesday they cleared another contender, Jan Ullrich of Germany.
William A. Shurcliff went on to play an outspoken role in defeating plans for a supersonic passenger plane in the 1960's and the Star Wars antimissile defense system in the 80's.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (Reuters) — Sales of existing homes fell 1.2 percent in May as higher interest rates slowed buying activity, the National Association of Realtors said Tuesday.

The United States attorney in Brooklyn, Roslynn R. Mauskopf, has been selected to serve as a federal judge, according to several people briefed on the matter. The move will open up one of the most important law enforcement posts in New York City.

Rush Limbaugh, the radio talk show host, was detained for more than three hours on Monday at Palm Beach International Airport after Customs Bureau officials found Viagra apparently prescribed with another name in his bag, said Paul Miller, a spokesman for the Palm Beach County sheriff. Investigators tried to determine whether Mr. Limbaugh, 55, who was returning from a vacation, violated a deal with prosecutors in a prescription fraud case. His lawyer, Roy Black, said the prescription was written in the name of Mr. Limbaugh's doctor
EUROPE.

One of the three Duke University lacrosse players accused of rape appeared in court on a noise complaint and was convicted, even though a roommate had been acquitted of the same charge. The athlete, David Evans, a recent graduate, attended the session but did not testify. The charge against Mr. Evans stemmed from a party on Jan. 10, when a neighbor complained to the police after midnight. Judge Elaine Bushfan of Durham District Court ordered Mr. Evans to pay $110 in court costs and entered a judgment that means no conviction will appear on his record even though he was found guilty.
A jury found that makers of welding rods were not liable for the health problems of a former civilian worker at a Navy base.

A longstanding feud over house rules at a high-rise apartment building for the elderly in Baltimore led one resident to shoot and kill another, the police said. The shooting, on Monday, apparently occurred after a desk clerk, 66, refused to allow the granddaughter of a resident, 80, to board an elevator without a visitor's pass, the police said. The clerk, Thomas Batty, was shot once in the head as he sat behind the front desk. Clyde Lewis was charged with murder. Both lived on the 12th floor of the building.

A guard shot a man in the face at a hotel after they fought about who had served in the toughest branch of the military, the police in New Orleans said. The argument between the guard, Christopher Marlowe, 25, of Lufkin, Tex., and the other man, Erik R. Beelman, 30, of New Orleans, began at 7 a.m. in the Royal St. Charles Hotel lobby, the police said. Mr. Beelman was ending a visit to a hotel guest when he and Mr. Marlowe began a conversation that ended in an argument
A federal district judge refused to order the release of an affidavit that the F.B.I. had used to obtain a search warrant to dig for James R. Hoffa's remains at a horse farm.

A man was convicted of murder for assaulting a Providence detective and shooting him with his own gun last year at an interrogation. The man, Esteban Carpio, said he was mentally unstable when he killed the officer, Detective Sgt. James Allen, at the police headquarters. Mr. Carpio, who was questioned about a stabbing, jumped out the window after the shooting and was caught an hour later. Mr. Carpio, whose conviction warrants an automatic sentence of life in prison without parole, was also convicted of stabbing an elderly woman, the offense he was being questioned about. Sergeant Allen, 50, was a 27-year veteran of the department.

Former President Bill Clinton said he and Hillary Rodham Clinton opposed allowing another state to have a presidential caucus after Iowa and before the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Clinton said that he wanted to preserve the integrity of the election process and that his one-on-one campaigning had made him a better candidate and president.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld a lower court decision that overturned personnel rules at the Homeland Security Department, saying they failed to ensure employees' right to bargain collectively.
A rapist changed the course of their lives forever, destroying their sense of innocence and causing one of them to become anorexic, two women told a judge yesterday.

Federal financing for the city's annual summer youth employment program has been sharply reduced, forcing the city to shoulder an increasing burden of the program's costs, according to an analysis released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office. In 1999, federal funds made up 82 percent of the program's budget and city funds 14.5 percent; in 2005, the respective figures were 11.5 percent and 53.1 percent. This year's program starts next Wednesday and lasts for seven weeks. The employment program received 71,000 applications for summer jobs by the June 7 deadline. Under a budget deal that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council announced last night, the city's Department of Youth and Community Development will have a budget of roughly $51 million for the program, enough for about 41,000 jobs.

An unsuccessful bidder for a $1 billion franchise to build bus stop shelters, newsstands and public toilets on city sidewalks filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to overturn the contract, which was awarded to a Spanish company, Cemusa. Relatives of 1,100 victims who died in the World Trade Center attack but whose remains have never been found claim there is new evidence that hundreds of body parts remain mixed with debris in the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. The charge is part of an amended complaint filed yesterday in Federal District Court by the relatives. Their lawyer, Norman Siegel, said the claim is based on his interviews with a former supervisor at the site who would testify at a jury trial. A lawsuit aiming to force the city to search the debris was filed by the relatives in August.

The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation yesterday requiring the Environmental Protection Agency to study the effects of a half-century-old underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The Senate has said it will also approve the legislation, and President Bush is expected to sign it as part of a broader maritime bill. The bill was sponsored by Representatives Anthony D. Weiner and Nydia M. Vel√°zquez, both of whom represent parts of Brooklyn and Queens. Last week, New York environmental officials asked the state attorney general's office to investigate the spill.

BearingPoint, one of the world's largest management and technology consulting firms, signed a lease yesterday to move from Midtown to 3 World Financial Center downtown. The company said the new location would have space for 633 people, although far fewer would be there at any one time. In return, the city and state, which portrayed the deal as a victory in their campaign to lure companies to Lower Manhattan, gave BearingPoint a $2.4 million job creation grant and is expected to approve $700,000 in tax breaks and other incentives.

The chairman of the State Democratic Party called on the Federal Election Commission and the Justice Department yesterday to investigate allegations that Representative Vito J. Fossella Jr. violated campaign finance regulations. Mr. Fossella, left, is the only Republican member of Congress from New York City. In a statement, the chairman, Assemblyman Herman D. Robert Troy, the chief of the Jersey City police since November 2004, announced yesterday that he would retire from the force on Saturday. Chief Troy was appointed to run the department in the state's second-largest city by Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy shortly after he was elected. Chief Troy, 51, joined the police force 25 years ago. A spokesman for Mr. Healy said a replacement had not yet been named.

A delivery company owner was in extremely critical condition yesterday after being shot in the head in the driveway of his home in an exclusive neighborhood, the Nassau County police said. The victim, Jaikaran Singh, 54, was shot about 8:45 p.m. Monday, shortly after returning with his wife and two daughters to their home on Powerhouse Road, said Detective Lt. Dennis Farrell. Lieutenant Farrell said Mr. Singh's 11-year-old daughter alerted him that someone was opening their garage door, and when he went to investigate, he was shot. Mr. Singh was taken to North Shore University Hospital. A preliminary investigation found that nothing had been stolen, the police said.

The Hilton Corporation and the unions representing hotel workers agreed yesterday to extend their bargaining talks for 14 days to avoid a lockout or strike at the Waldorf-Astoria and Hilton New York on Saturday, when the current contract expires. The unions signed a six-year contract last week with the Hotel Association of New York City covering many of the city's best-known hotels and 23,000 workers. But sometimes bitter negotiations have continued between the unions and Hilton over what labor leaders say are the company's repeated failure to pay employees their full wages, and asbestos problems at the Waldorf. The latest announcement indicates that both sides are inching toward an agreement.

Relentless rain continued drenching the East Coast on Tuesday as the region braced for overnight downpours that prompted evacuations of homes and businesses, knocked out power to tens of thousands, shut down government office buildings and led to flash flood warnings from upstate New York to North Carolina. Heightening anxieties, the National Weather Service said a tropical storm forming near Cape Fear in North Carolina would bring more precipitation and heavy winds up the Atlantic coast to the lowlands of eastern Maryland and Northern Virginia, which in the past few days have been battered by storms and flooding.

In the head-to-head reality show clash on Monday, the screaming chef Gordon Ramsay, below, of ''Hell's Kitchen'' beat the racing puzzlers of ''Treasure Hunters.'' At 9 p.m., the two summer series competed directly, and Fox's ''Hell'' delivered 7.7 million viewers, in comparison to 5.8 million viewers for NBC's ''Treasure.'' The Fox cooking contest, in which the aspiring chefs seem incompetent, also scored the highest rating of the night in the 18-to-49 age group, giving the network a victory in that demographic for Monday. CBS was No. 1 among total viewers. The highlight of its night of repeats was ''CSI: Miami'' (10.6 million) at 10 p.m. It steamrolled NBC's ''Medium'' (5.7 million) and ABC's ''How to Get the Guy'' (3.2 million). In its third week, that dating reality series hit a ratings low. KATE AURTHUR

Some remaining barriers to the Arcelor-Mittal Steel merger came down as the Luxembourg government and Arcelor's largest shareholder pledged to back the deal. Luxembourg, once one of Mittal's staunchest critics, said it supported the 26 billion euro ($33 billion) deal and planned to sell some shares but remain a long-term shareholder with 2.7 percent of the company. Lakshmi Mittal, the founder of Mittal Steel, met with the Luxembourg prime minister and the minister of economy. ''I was very pleased to meet them, and found them very happy that this had turned into a friendly transaction,'' he said. An investor, Romain Zaleski, who has 7.8 percent of Arcelor, also said he would back the deal with Mittal. Arcelor's shareholders will vote on Friday on a separate deal with the Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov that was worked out before the Mittal deal and is expected to be annulled. HEATHER TIMMONS (NYT)
NACHT--Carl H, MD. A gentle healer who kept us whole. Kathy Jones Clyde Haberman Amanda Harris Drew Fetherston Mig Boyle Lydia del Carpio

The police arrested two people under terrorism legislation in Bolton, outside of Manchester, in the latest in a series of antiterrorism raids -- some linked, some independent -- across England in the last few weeks. The two suspects, who have not been formally charged, were taken into custody in the aftermath of a search of eight properties in order to target ''individuals suspected of possession of information that could be used for a terrorism purpose,'' a police spokesman said. The spokesman said the operation was not linked to other antiterrorism investigations in London and elsewhere. SARAH LYALL (NYT)

A proposed Constitutional amendment to allow Congress to prohibit desecration of the flag fell a single vote short of approval by the Senate on Tuesday, an excruciatingly close vote that left unresolved a long-running debate over whether the flag is a unique national symbol deserving of special legal standing. The 66-to-34 vote on the amendment was one vote short of the 67 required to send the amendment to the states for potential ratification as the 28th Amendment. It was the closest proponents of the initiative have come in four Senate votes since the Supreme Court first ruled in 1989 that flag burning was a protected form of free speech.

The French government's self-imposed deadline to resolve the situation at EADS passed with no resolution of who would take over as chairman in a restructuring. Adding to the uncertainty, EADS, formally the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, disclosed that French regulators had searched the company's offices in Paris as part of an inquiry into whether top managers, including the French co-chief executive, No√´l Forgeard, were privy to inside information when they sold shares in EADS in March. EADS is the French-German parent company of Airbus. NICOLA CLARK (IHT)

Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike in Woodbury.

8 P.M. (CBS) SHARK: MIND OF A DEMON WITH FABIEN COUSTEAU -- With the Cousteau blood running through his veins, it was perhaps inevitable that Fabien Cousteau, son of Jean-Michel and grandson of Jacques Yves, would heed the call of the ocean. But it was ''The Adventures of Tintin: Red Rackham's Treasure,'' whose cover has a submersible in the shape of a shark on it, that inspired his latest adventure. Mr. Cousteau went on to build the craft (above) and then to spend the next two years in it, swimming with the Great White off Isla Guadalupe, Mexico. The result is this hourlong special that Mr. Cousteau hopes will give one of nature's most maligned creatures a much-needed break. 8 P.M. (Fox) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Last week Aleksandra Wojda and Dmitry Chaplin lost their partners to clumsy maneuvers. In this two-hour episode, they're stuck with each other as the top 16 contestants try not to step on each other's toes. 8 P.M. (13) IN PERFORMANCE AT THE WHITE HOUSE: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM -- In 1955, Arthur Mitchell joined New York City Ballet and became the first African-American man to be made a permanent member of a major company. Inspired by the death of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Mitchell decided it was his turn to give others, especially children in Harlem, a chance to dance. Teaching in a remodeled garage, he helped to found Dance Theater of Harlem in 1969. This special honors the organization's legacy with performances by Harolyn Blackwell, the Rev. Al Green, Audra McDonald and LeAnn Rimes as well as some of the students (above) Dance Theater has taught to soar. 10 P.M. (AMC) HUSTLE -- Like a certain national hero, these London scammers steal from the city's hardened upper crust - but they don't give back. In this season premiere, the gang tries to con an obnoxious pub owner whose lug of a son aspires to be the next Eminem. If only he had a way with words. 10 P.M. (TV Land) MY FIRST TIME -- Whether good, bad or merely a yawn, it's almost always unforgettable if it's you there. This new series looks at how celebrities got their big breaks, starting with Henry Winkler and Katey Sagal, whose initial close encounters were with Mary Tyler Moore. 10 P.M. (Spike) BLADE: THE SERIES -- Half man, half vampire, all living nightmare. In this new series adapted from the movie trilogy starring the monosyllabic - at least in this role -Wesley Snipes, Kirk ''Sticky Fingaz'' Jones (above) plays it passive-aggressive as the Marvel Comics madman while opening up the lines of communication. Translation: he uses bigger words. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

A front-page article on Monday about the abduction of an Israeli soldier by Palestinian militants referred incorrectly to the hostage. He is the fourth Israeli soldier abducted in the Arab-Israeli conflict since 1994, not the first. (Three Israeli soldiers were captured by Shiite Muslim guerrillas along the Israel-Lebanon border in 2000.)

A federal judge in Los Angeles has unsealed three search warrants that investigators used to raid Anthony Pellicano's detective agency and seize evidence in the early stages of what has become a sprawling wiretapping and conspiracy case. The first warrant, on Nov. 19, 2002, covered records that could illuminate Mr. Pellicano's involvement in threats that summer against Anita Busch, a reporter for The Los Angeles Times, and Ned Zeman, a writer for Vanity Fair; both were working on articles about the actor Steven Seagal's possible ties to organized-crime figures. When investigators found explosives and firearms in a safe in Mr. Pellicano's office, they went back two days later with a warrant for more evidence of violations of explosives laws. A few days later, the warrants show, Ms. Busch told the F.B.I. that she had discovered, in repeated calls to the phone company about trouble on her lines, that her phones had been tapped for months, and that the phone company could not explain the taps. On Jan. 14, 2003, the F.B.I. returned to Mr. Pellicano's offices specifically combing through his files, computers and other equipment for all wiretapping evidence. DAVID M. HALBFINGER and ALLISON HOPE WEINER

SORIAN--Jack. 94, of New York City, NY. On June 26, 2006. Beloved uncle of Joseph, Janice A., David, Janice R., Estelle, Sidney, Stephen and Richard. Jack had been acting since 1945, and had been involved in theatre productions in Off-Broadway and Summer Stock. He was Alan King's understudy in the Broadway production of ''The Impossible Years.'' Throughout Jack's life he was dedicated and generous to his siblings--and all of their families. Jack served as a Medical Technician during WW II in the Army. Services 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 12 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

Harper Lee Writes Again Ever since Harper Lee's novel, ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' was published in 1960 and went on to sell 2.5 million copies in its first year and win the Pulitzer Prize, the author has led a low-profile life. Ms. Lee, now 80, has published virtually nothing of significance since then except a 1983 book review. But now she has written something for publication. It is a letter for O, the Oprah Winfrey magazine, about how she became a reader as a child in a rural, Depression-era Alabama town, The Associated Press reported. In the magazine's July ''special summer reading issue,'' Ms. Lee recalls becoming a reader before she entered first grade. Older sisters and a brother read to her; her mother read her a story a day; her father read her newspaper articles. ''Then, of course, it was Uncle Wiggily at bedtime,'' Ms. Lee writes of the popular old-time children's character, right. She notes that books were scarce in the 1930's in the town, Monroeville, where she still lives part time; and the scarcity of books in a town without movies and parks made them a special treasure. ''Now,'' she writes, ''75 years later in an abundant society where people have laptops, cellphones, iPods and minds like empty rooms, I still plod along with books.'' Axl Rose Arrested in Stockholm Axl Rose, below, the Guns N' Roses frontman, was arrested yesterday and accused of biting a security guard in the leg after a night of partying that followed a concert in the Globe Arena in Stockholm, The Associated Press reported. A police spokeswoman, Towe Hagg, said Mr. Rose, 44, had been held on suspicion of attacking and threatening the guard and damaging the Berns Hotel. ''He was deemed too intoxicated to be questioned right away,'' she said. The origin of the incident was unclear, but Swedish newspapers said the guard had tried to intervene when Mr. Rose began to argue with a woman in the hotel lobby. The Web site of the newspaper Aftonbladet (aftonbladet.se) quoted Fredrik Nylen, a police officer, as saying that Mr. Rose acted aggressively toward the police and had to be ''handcuffed and restrained.'' Officer Nylen said, ''He kept a high profile, so to speak.'' The penalty for violent conduct could be as high as four years in prison; conviction for a misdemeanor might bring six months in prison or a fine, Reuters reported. China Finances Theater In West Africa China is plowing $35 million into the construction of the biggest theater in West Africa, an 18,000-seat three-level structure with parking for 3,000 cars in Senegal, Reuters reported. The project was described by Pierre Goudiaby At√©pa, an architect and adviser to President Abdoulaye Wade. China also plans to build an arts museum in Senegal before the end of next year. The announcement comes as China seeks to strengthen political and economic ties in Africa as it pursues oil and raw materials for its fast-growing economy. After Mr. Wade visited China last week, China announced $20 million in debt relief for Senegal. Free Summer Parks Shows Theater and dance are being added this summer by the CityParks Foundation to a program of free performances that already includes the CityParks Concerts and the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival. In the theater program, five troupes, including Classical Theater of Harlem, Hip Hop Commedia and Liza Jessie Peterson, will offer 15 public performances in Von King, Maria Hernandez and Sunset Parks in Brooklyn and Marcus Garvey Park in Manhattan. (Above, Classical Theater of Harlem performing ''Medea'' in 2005.) The series begins on July 15, when Communicable Arts performs ''As You Like It'' in Maria Hernandez Park, and ends on Aug. 6 with a Creative Stages performance of ''Bricolage'' in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem. The dance season, featuring small and midsize companies, opens on July 29 in Jackie Robinson Park in Manhattan. The foundation's 17th season of concerts will offer 30 free performances in 10 parks in all 5 boroughs beginning on July 11, and the annual Charlie Parker Jazz Festival is scheduled for Aug. 26 at Marcus Garvey Park and Aug. 27 in Tompkins Square Park in the East Village. Information: CityParksFoundation.org. Footnotes Paul Meecham has resigned unexpectedly as executive director of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra, The Seattle Post-Intelligencer reported yesterday. ''I am leaving for personal reasons, and I am asking people to respect that,'' said Mr. Meecham, who assumed his post in 2004 under a contract that expires in December. New York will get a dose of the Grinch when ''Dr. Seuss' How The Grinch Stole Christmas! -- The Musical'' comes to Broadway in the fall. Playing 12 performances a week, the show, from Running Subway Productions (''Sinatra -- His Life, His Way,'' ''Peter Pan'' with Cathy Rigby, ''Bodies -- The Exhibition''), will begin previews at the Hilton Theater on Oct. 25 and open on Nov. 8, continuing through Jan. 7. The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts has announced the appointment of George Boziwick as chief of its music division, and of Michelle Potter as curator of its Jerome Robbins dance division. The appointment of Mr. Boziwick, most recently the curator of the American Music Collection of the music division, is effective immediately. Ms. Potter, the inaugural curator of dance at the National Library of Australia in Canberra, will begin in August.

Admit it. You buy blueberries all year because they are said to be good for you, splurge on raspberries in December and buy strawberries in early spring because you are tired of winter. But the real season for berries from local farms has started, and the Greenmarkets and nearby farm stands will be loaded with delicious berries until fall. This summer 10 new Greenmarkets will be open by July 14 in Manhattan. (A listing is at www.cenyc.org.) An encyclopedic approach is taken in ''Berries,'' by Roger Yepsen (W. W. Norton, $24.95), an elegant volume that has chapters on more than a dozen kinds, how and where they are grown and how to use them. The text is better than the recipes, which should be read with care. One for blueberry blintzes omits the necessary flour from the ingredients.

A music review on Monday about Herbie Hancock's concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday night misidentified the composer of ''Footprints,'' which Mr. Hancock played in a piano duet with Gonzalo Rubalcaba. He is Wayne Shorter, who also performed, not Mr. Hancock.

A listing of American military deaths yesterday included an erroneous given name from the Department of Defense for an Army staff sergeant. He is Alberto V. Sanchez, not Virrueta.

GOODMAN--Lorraine R., 78. Once of Brooklyn and Sleepy Hollow, NY and Cambridge, Massachusetts, died June 16 at her Bedford, MA home with her husband, William, her children, Jonas and Sara, and her niece, Laurie Miller, at her side. Mother, grandmother of Alex and Ben, sister of Blossom and Roz, teacher, retired Bolt, Baranek & Newman administrator, seasoned reading for the Blind and Dyslexic volunteer, devoted gardener, patient birder and good neighbor. Her unfailing intelligence and grand humane competence served all who knew her well. She was much loved.

An article last Wednesday about recipes submitted to the Dining section's summer cocktail contest misstated the residence of Carey Savona, the creator of one of the cocktails, the gingino. He lives in New York City, not Florida.

An article yesterday about the reburial of the remains of Sophia and Una Hawthorne, the wife and daughter of Nathaniel Hawthorne, misidentified the poet whose book Sophia gave to Nathaniel during their courtship. It was Wordsworth, not Wadsworth.

With his proposed overhaul of the nation's immigration laws now in legislative limbo, President Bush focused on another priority on Tuesday, to secure Congressional approval of a presidential line-item veto. Speaking to a conservative group here in the morning, Mr. Bush said he would use a line-item veto to eliminate spending on the pet projects called earmarks that lawmakers attach to spending bills.

Federal financing for the city's annual summer youth employment program has been sharply reduced, forcing the city to shoulder an increasing burden of the program's costs, according to an analysis released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office. In 1999, federal funds made up 82 percent of the program's budget and city funds 14.5 percent; in 2005, the respective figures were 11.5 percent and 53.1 percent. This year's program starts next Wednesday and lasts for seven weeks. The employment program received 71,000 applications for summer jobs by the June 7 deadline. Under a budget deal that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council announced last night, the city's Department of Youth and Community Development will have a budget of roughly $51 million for the program, enough for about 41,000 jobs. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)
MARDIN--Arif M. On June 25, 2006. The family will receive friends on Wednessay from 4 to 8 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Burial at a later date in Turkey.

FLORENCE--Leonard, Age 74, formerly of Chelsea, died on June 26th at his residence in Chestnut Hill. Mr. Florence the son of the late Myer and Fannie (Raisman) Florence, grew up in Chelsea, and graduated from Chelsea High School, and Boston University School of Business Administration. After serving in the US Army, Mr. Florence, known as ''Lenny'' began his career in the silver business working at Raimond Silver Mftg. of Malden. In 1963, Lenny left Raimond Silver and founded Leonard Silver Mftg. Co. Inc. Subsequently, he acquired Towle Manufacturing Company of Newburyport and remained with the Company until 1985. In 1986, Lenny founded Syratech Corporation, a manufacturer and importer of tabletop, gift ware and seasonal products. In 1992, Syratech Corporation became a publicly traded company on NASDAQ and subsequently moved to the New York Stock Exchange in 1993. In 1997, Syratech Corporation completed a transaction with the Thomas H. Lee Company in which Mr. Florence remained as Chairman of the Board until October 2003. Following, Mr. Florence established the Leonard Florence Group, a manufacturer and importer of giftware and premium products. Florence served as the Honorary Consulate General to Costa Rica. He also was a member of the Board of Directors of The Cardinal Cushing School and Training Center for Children of all Faiths in Hanover, Mass., The Board of Overseers of Tufts University School of Dental Medicine in Boston, The RACE TO ERASE Multiple Sclerosis Foundation in Los Angeles, The Jewish Theological Seminary of New York, The Beth Israel Hospital Board of Overseers in Boston, The American Committee for the Weizman Institute, Lifetime Hoan Corporation, The Fashion Institute of New York, The Commonwealth of Massachusetts Soldiers Home and Suffolk University in Boston. Mr. Florence also served on the Board of the Florence, Chafetz Hillel at Boston University, the Anti-Defamation League, the Cohen, Florence, Levine Estates for assisted living in Chelsea, the Florence Chafetz Special Care Building in Chelsea and the Or Chadash For Girls in Israel. Florence has received many awards and accolades from various associations throughout his long and established career. He has received nine (9) honorary doctorate degrees from the following institutions: Merrimack College, King's College, Stonehill College, Tufts University, Cardinal Stritch College, Boston University, Suffolk University, Johnson & Wales University, and Catholic University. In 1993, Florence received, by appointment of Pope John Paul II Supreme Pontiff, the order of St. Gregory The Great. The award is the highest honor given by the Catholic Church. It recognizes individuals who distinguish themselves for notable accomplishments on behalf of society --regardless of their religious beliefs. In 2000, His Holiness Pope John Paul II elevated Mr. Florence to a Commander of the Knights of St. Gregory, the highest honor given by the Catholic Church. Mr. Florence was a member of the Congregation of the Orange Street Synagogue of Chelsea, Congregation Mishkan Tefila of Chestnut Hill, and Temple Emanuel of Chelsea. He was the brother of Gertrude Bial and Delray Beach, Fl., Rosalie Cohen of Boston, David Florence of Boynton beach, FL., Dr. Lewis Florence of Houston, and the late Sylvia Sazinsky, Dr. Hyman Florence and Barry Florence. HALPERIN--Donald M. of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, 60, the youngest person ever to be elected to the NY State Senate at the age of 24, died June 26, 2006 at the Menorah Nursing Home and Hospital in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn after a valiant 22 month battle with cancer. Don Halperin was the beloved son of Gladys and the late Charles Halperin; devoted husband of Brenda; father of Jeremy and Rebecca and future-son-inlaw Joshua Burch; brother of Susan and Alan Gorman; and uncle of Sam Gorman. A graduate of Rutgers University and Brooklyn Law School, Don was a partner in the law firm of Kantor, Davidoff, Wolfe, Mandelker & Kass, PC. He represented the shorefront communities of Brooklyn in the NYS Senate for 23 years, with 13 years as the Ranking Democrat on Finance Committee. In 1993, former Governor Mario Cuomo named Don to the dual positions of Commissioner of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) and Housing ''Czar'', a cabinet level position. Don Halperin was the ultimate consensus builder, a skilled negotiator who had the uncanny ability to relate to all people, bringing the most diverse and opposing factions together to reach satisfying resolutions to thorny issues and debates. His sharp sense of humor and amazing wit earned him friends across the political spectrum. His work ethic and dedication to the people of New York earned him the respect of all his colleagues. As a result, Don Halperin had more bills signed into law than most members of the Minority Party in the Senate achieving a record 22 chapters in 1978. During his legislative career Don Halperin authored a law requiring braille and audio signals in elevators and was a leading advocate for child welfare and criminal justice. He authored the Rapid Transit Noise Code Act on elevated trains and subways. He was a pioneer in developing legislation to revamp the NYS Reverse Mortgage Law and wrote a law to provide grants to finance programs to reduce and prevent racial and cultural conflicts in schools. During his illness Don Halperin advocated and secured passage of significant affordable housing legislation, (Chapter 714 of the Laws of 2005) which provides more realistic evaluation and assessment rates on rental properties with restricted income issues. Funeral Services will be on Wednesday, June 28th, 2006 at 1PM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. The family will sit shiva at their home, 118 Hastings Street, Wednesday evening; Thursday and Friday afternoon after 1PM, Saturday evening and Sunday and Monday afternoon starting at 1PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions in Donald Halperin's name be made to: Shirley Applebaum Heart League; Menorah Nursing Home and Hospital; or the Lung Cancer Alliance. $(6$)HALPERIN--Donald M. The members, counsel and employees of Kantor, Davidoff, Wolfe, Mandelker & Kass, P.C. mourn the passing of our partner, friend and collegue, Donald M. Halperin. Don Halperin joined our firm in 1995 after a distinguised career in public service. He was the youngest person ever elected as a New York senator. He held that office for 23 years, rising to ranking member of that body's Higher Education, Insurance & Finance committees. In 1993 he was named Director of Housing for New York State and Commissioner of the Divison of Housing and Community Renewal. Don Halperin was beloved and trusted by both sides of the aisle in city and state government. His sunny disposition, incisive mind and fierce loyalty well served his constituents, while he held public office, and his many clients whom he served as a lobbyist once he left public office. Don Halperin graced our firm with his presence and will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to Brenda, Jeremy and Rebecca and his mother Gladys.

If flavors like black mission fig, strawberry darling or chocolate-cabernet are not unusual enough, how about the fact that they are made with goat's milk? Laloo's, a company in Petaluma, Calif., introduced ice creams in those flavors last year, but they were sold only in West Coast stores or online. Now they are also sold at Gourmet Garage and Whole Foods stores. Vanilla snowflake, delicately sweetened, is a classic flavor. Not so the intriguingly tangy ch√®vre chiffon made with goat cheese. Strawberry darling has a swirl of balsamic vinegar. The chocolate-cabernet will not be made again until grapes ripen in the fall, but until then Laloo's deep chocolate flavor is a suitably delectable stand-in. Pumpkin spice and molasses tipsycake would tempt me in cold weather.

MOSS--Dr. Melvin L. Former dean of Columbia University Medical Center's College of Dental Medicine, professor emeritus of anatomy and oral biology in the College of Physicians and Surgeons, and professor emeritus of dentistry, passed away on Sunday, June 25, 2006. Dean Moss' visionary leadership shaped the school we have today, and his death is a great loss to us all. Dean Moss was a 1946 graduate of Columbia's dental school, and received his PhD in anatomy, specializing in physical anthropology from Columbia in 1954. He joined the Columbia faculty in 1952, and was well known throughout the medical center as an outstanding teacher of human anatomy to generations of medical and dental students. A prolific researcher, Dean Moss' work on the theoretical basis of craniofacial growth and development received international recognition. His appointment in 1968 to lead the dental school initiated a period of renewal and new directions in the dental school. Under his leadership, the school received more resources for strengthening dental education through investment in facilities and faculty recruitment. Dean Moss also made significant changes to the curriculum, and oversaw the creation of several new divisions with the dental school. Our thoughts and prayers are extended to his wife and our colleague, Dr. Letty Moss-Salentijn, professor of dentistry and senior associate dean in the College of Dental Medicine, to his two sons, Noel and James, and to his granddaughter Kristina. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, June 28, 2006, at 11:15 A.M. at The Riverside, Amsterdam Avenue & 76th Street, NYC. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, Dr. Moss-Salentijn has requested that donations be made to The Melvin L. Moss Scholarship Fund, payable to Columbia University College of Dental Medicine, 630 West 168 St., New York, NY 10032. Ira B. Lamster, D.D.S., M.M.Sc. Dean, College of Dental Medicine Columbia University Medical Center

INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Israeli Troops Enter Gaza In Effort to Rescue Soldier Israel sent troops and tanks into Gaza, and Israeli planes attacked three bridges and a power station, in an effort to cut the territory in half and rescue a wounded Israeli soldier abducted by militants on Sunday, military officials said. A1 Rethinking African Malaria New financing and a fresh scrutiny of efforts in Africa to combat malaria are prompting donors to revamp years of failed efforts to stem the disease's toll. The disease kills 800,000 children a year even though inexpensive remedies are well known. A1 Iraqi Narrows Amnesty Offer Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq said publicly for the first time that attacks on American soldiers would not be pardoned under the rules of a new amnesty plan. A10 While some American officials have offered Algeria as a study in forming a plan to end Iraq's sectarian violence, interviews with journalists and Algerians suggest that, despite an amnesty program that ended the country's civil war, fighting still kills dozens of people a month.
