A3 North Korea Missile Uncertainty The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said that while North Korea showed signs of preparing a missile for a test launching, it remained unclear whether it is fully fueled for an imminent firing. A9 NATIONAL A14-19 Flag Burning Amendment Falls Short by One Vote A proposed constitutional amendment to prohibit desecration of the flag fell a single vote short of approval by the Senate, leaving unresolved a long-running debate over whether the flag is a unique national symbol deserving of special legal standing. A1 Anglicans Lay Out New Plans The Archbishop of Canterbury proposed a plan that could force the Episcopal Church in the United States either to renounce gay bishops and same-sex unions or give up full membership in the Communion. A14 Rain Swamps East Coast Rain continued drenching the East Coast as the region braced for overnight downpours that prompted the evacuation of homes and businesses and led to flash flood warnings from upstate New York to North Carolina. A17 Legend to Start Food Line Evoking his status as a three-time heavyweight boxing champion and American icon, Muhammad Ali plans to introduce reduced-calorie foods and beverages for young adults. A14 Blast Destroys Motel in Georgia A maintenance man remained unaccounted for after an explosion tore through a rural Georgia motel where he was working. Carmona said. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Child-Care Givers May Be Able to Bargain With State The State Legislature is poised to override Gov. George E. Pataki's veto and give 52,000 home child-care providers, now independent contractors, the right to organize and collectively bargain with the state for pay and benefits. The move could have a major impact on state finances in the long term. B1 Co-op Prices Could Go Public The prices paid for co-op apartments in New York City could be made public for the first time under a bill passed last week by the legislature in Albany. The bill proposes to lift the veil on what has long been a central secret of Manhattan real estate -- how much your neighbor paid for his apartment. Race officials asked the team of a top contender to withdraw Monday, and then cleared another contender, Jan Ullrich of Germany, after a Spanish newspaper linked him to the blood-doping inquiry. It came more than six months after ABC executives decided not to renew her contract, Barbara Walters, the show's co-executive producer, said in an interview. THOMSON--Dudley George. 74, of Sheldon, SC, died Sunday, June 25, 2006 at his Brays Island home. Services will be at a later date. Mr. Thomson was born August 31, 1931, in Flushing, NY, a son of Louise Magoon Thomson and John B. Thomson. He was a veteran of The United States Army, a member of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and Brays Island Plantation Club where he enjoyed golf and sport shooting. He was a stockbroker and manufacturing executive with Thomson Industries in Port Washington, NY. He was preceded in death by his wife, Jean Logue Thomson. Survivors include two sons, Keith Thomson of Groton, NY, Edward ''Ted'' Thomson of Jacksonville, FL; a daughter, Wendy Harrington of Huntington, NY; a brother, John B. Thomson of Sands Point, NY and seven grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to Beaufort Memorial Hospital Foundation, Post Office Box 2033, Beaufort, SC 29901. For more information: Copeland Funeral Home.

FOR many years, the seasons came and went with no particular urgency in my kitchen. Did I need basil? I could get basil. Ditto melons, potatoes, squash. New York is full of stores catering to off-season-produce junkies like me.

A Brooklyn charter school is embroiled in a dispute over whether two teachers were fired based on their performance, or because they were trying to organize teachers to press for better salaries and benefits. Nichole Byrne Lau, one of the teachers, said she was let go this month even though she received an evaluation in May saying that her students at the Williamsburg Charter High School were ''lucky to have you as their teacher.''

Mo Johnston yesterday became the first coach fired by the New York Red Bulls but joined a long list of coaches who have toiled without success for the Major League Soccer team that was once known as the MetroStars. Johnston, a Scotsman who took over when Bob Bradley was fired last October, was replaced on an interim basis by Richie Williams, who had been Johnston's assistant. Johnston was the eighth coach in the team's 11-year history of mediocrity.

To the Editor: Re ''The Road From My Lai,'' by Alex Vernon (Op-Ed, June 23): My father was drafted near the end of World War II. One day a soldier in his company snapped and shot a 12-year-old German girl for giggling. While I would uneasily concede that that young girl's life and that young man's soul were prices worth paying for the end of Nazism, I doubt that you will find a combat veteran of any war who didn't at least witness a crossed line at some point in his experience.

Ressler--Elizabeth S. Of Quogue, New York died on June 26 after a long battle with lung cancer. She was born in Englewood, New Jersey on April 2, 1920, the daughter of Helen and Oswald Kirkby. She grew up in Englewood and traveled extensively with her parents. She graduated from Warrenton Country Day School in Warrenton, Virginia and attended Briarcliff Junior College. On September 12, 1941, she married David B. Ressler with whom she had four sons. She was a leader in many community activities in Englewood. She and David moved to Quogue when he retired and she was active in and co-president of the Westhampton Garden Club. She is survived by her husband and sons David B. Jr., Harold K., Richard S. and Stewart K. Ressler. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations in her memory may be made to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978

To the Editor: ''At Ethics Camp, Not-So-Tall Tales From the Dark Side'' (news article, June 23), about the Ethics Camp at Santa Clara University, raised some speculations on any transgressions that the campers may have engaged in during their youth, from grammar school to college. These include cheating (in the classroom or on the playing field), swearing, snubbing, bullying, shoplifting, snooping or name-calling. It is also likely that one camper or more got grounded or spanked, or that a parent or teacher motivated them to behave better by bribery.

The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation yesterday requiring the Environmental Protection Agency to study the effects of a half-century-old underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The Senate has said it will also approve the legislation, and President Bush is expected to sign it as part of a broader maritime bill. The bill was sponsored by Representatives Anthony D. Weiner and Nydia M. Vel√°zquez, both of whom represent parts of Brooklyn and Queens. Last week, New York environmental officials asked the state attorney general's office to investigate the spill. NICHOLAS CONFESSORE (NYT)

CALIFORNIA chardonnay and salmon are not things I serve very often. Finding the two on nearly every menu is enough for me. But there are always exceptions to my bias. The first fresh Pacific king salmon of the season is worthy of attention. Unless the fish is grilled or served with some hearty seasoning or accompaniment, like tomatoes, that will demand a red wine, it is best with a rich chardonnay. I decided to prepare the salmon with an elegant sauce of creamed cucumbers.

The evidence is now ''indisputable'' that secondhand smoke is an ''alarming'' public health hazard, responsible for tens of thousands of premature deaths among nonsmokers each year, Surgeon General Richard H. Carmona said yesterday. Dr. Carmona warned that measures like no-smoking sections did not provide adequate protection, adding, ''Smoke-free environments are the only approach that protects nonsmokers from the dangers of secondhand smoke.''

Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice sought on Tuesday and Wednesday to prop up two troubled leaders whose success is crucial to the administration on two fronts: the fight against terrorism and relations with the Muslim world. Arriving in Islamabad, Pakistan, on Tuesday evening, Ms. Rice met with President Pervez Musharraf, whom she prodded, gently, to allow democratic elections. ''We've had a discussion about the role of continuing democratization,'' Ms. Rice said after the meeting. ''It's a good start to talk about a good and moderate Pakistan.''

Senator Pat Roberts, the chairman of the Senate intelligence committee, asked the director of national intelligence on Tuesday to assess any damage to American counterterrorism efforts caused by the disclosure of secret programs to monitor telephone calls and financial transactions. Mr. Roberts, Republican of Kansas, singled out The New York Times for an article last week that reported that the government was tracking money transfers handled by a banking consortium based in Belgium. The targeting of the financial data, which includes some Americans' transactions, was also reported Thursday by The Los Angeles Times and The Wall Street Journal.

NIVES--Ernest, 81, on June 25, 2006. Born Vienna, Austria. Husband of Fanny, father of David and Julie, grandfather of Marisa and Zoe, brother of Fred. As a Holocaust survivor, you carried forward your message by educating others; you earned the devotion and love of so many who admired you.

CARON--Diana Welwood, died unexpectedly on June 21st, 2006 at her home in Stuart, FL. Born in NY, Diana attended Ms. Hewitt's classes and Vassar College before moving to New Canaan with her young family. She was an active and engaged member of the community for over 30 years. Diana is survived by her loving daughter Sandra Oldershaw, devoted sons Peter John and Philip Caron, 5 grandchildren, her sister Helen Welwood-Gavales of NY & brother Phornton Marshall of Huntington, L.I. A family service was held in Stuart.

LINS--Marion Stewart, 88, wife of the late John P. Lins, died June 24, 2006 in Jennersville, PA. She is survived by her children, Louise Chinn Ducas, Andrew Lins, Susan Jackson, four grandchildren and her sisters, Kate Kuehn, and Joan Ruvane. She was a life-long resident of New York City, and a dedicated volunteer at many organizations in New York including St Luke's Hospital and The Ladies Christian Union. Memorial contributions may be made to Francis Vale Home For Smaller Animals, Upper Gulph Road and Radnor Road, Radnor, PA 19087.

THE secret to the green salsa served throughout Mexico and now much of the United States is the tomatillo, a relative of the tomato that is smaller and almost always eaten green. (It turns yellow as it ages.) Although you can substitute green tomatoes for tomatillos, which ought to make gardeners happy come fall, this substitution undersells the difference between the two, and the difference is notable.

Barbecue's many styles have a sense of place, notably Kansas City, Texas and Memphis. But not New York. Yet Lobel's, the Upper East Side butcher, has introduced what it calls barbecue beef and others might call Manhattan barbecue. It's not smoked or highly spiced, it's made in a pot on a stove, it's available ready to eat, and while it's delicious piled on a bun for a picnic, a platter of it would also draw raves at a terrace buffet. Because New Yorkers tend to prefer lean first-cut brisket to the richer and fattier second cut, Stanley Lobel has come up with this new item using the top section of the second cut. He pots the soft-textured meat and mixes it with Lobel's mild honey-based barbecue sauce. It fairly falls apart, sort of like pulled beef. Cooked, the beef is $24.98 a pound; uncooked, to simmer at home or braise with onions, it's $18.98 a pound. The sauce is $9.98 for a pint jar; 1096 Madison Avenue (82nd Street).

GOLDBERGER--Seymour. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club, record the passing of our esteemed member, Seymour Goldberger. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Selma, his sister and brother-in-law, Helen and Lawrence Doppelt, his son Marc Goldberger and the entire family.

The Hilton Corporation and the unions representing hotel workers agreed yesterday to extend their bargaining talks for 14 days to avoid a lockout or strike at the Waldorf-Astoria and Hilton New York on Saturday, when the current contract expires. The unions signed a six-year contract last week with the Hotel Association of New York City covering many of the city's best-known hotels and 23,000 workers. But sometimes bitter negotiations have continued between the unions and Hilton over what labor leaders say are the company's repeated failure to pay employees their full wages, and asbestos problems at the Waldorf. The latest announcement indicates that both sides are inching toward an agreement. CHARLES V. BAGLI (NYT)

CHEFS have played with purple rice, red rice and black rice, with farro and quinoa and almost every imaginable grain. But barley, one of the oldest cultivated grains, languishes in wintry soups and dense breads and porridge. When I asked five chefs for recipes with barley, only two had something to share. Besides having a wonderful texture and delightful nutty taste, barley also has proven health benefits. The federal government said last month that barley can reduce cholesterol levels, just like oats.

An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday about Trader Monthly magazine misstated the work history of Rich Blake, a senior editor at the magazine who heads the editors and writers that track traders. He is a former staff writer at Institutional Investor, not a former investor.

SILVER--Sadye, devoted wife of the late Morris Silver, loving mother of Carole and Ronald Korn, dedicated grandmother of Douglas and Betsy Korn, Karen and Brendan Herron, Steven and Alissa Korn, and adoring great grandmother of eight, passed away peacefully on June 27, 2006 in Boca Raton, FL. She was born Sadye Cymrot in New York on February 19, 1912. Sadye met Morris, her husband of over 60 years, when they worked together in a law office in Manhattan in the 1930's. Longtime residents of Jamaica Estates, the Silvers later lived in Miami Beach and Boca Raton. Sadye served as an officer of Hadassah for many years. She will be deeply missed but remembered with love for the wise counsel, insightful thinking, and unconditional love she provided to her family and friends. Memorial on Thursday in FL. Donations in her memory may be made to Youth Renewal Fund, 250 W. 57th St., Ste. 632, NY NY 10107 or to the Sadye Silver Fund, Jewish Endowment Foundation, 1160 Dickinson Street, Springfield, MA 01108.

To the Editor: Re ''Bush Condemns Report on Sifting of Bank Records'' (front page, June 27): President Bush calls the conduct of The New York Times and other newspapers ''disgraceful'' for revealing a secret program to track terrorists. I say it is the conduct of his administration that is disgraceful.

BECKER--Eugene. The Juilliard School mourns the death of Eugene Becker, member of the viola and chamber music faculty since 1987, and Pre-college faculty since 1975. A distinguished musician and dedicated teacher, Gene approached his teaching at Juilliard with passion and professional expertise. He will be greatly missed by his students and colleagues. We send our deepest condolences to his wife Rae & his entire family. Joseph W. Polisi, President Stephen Clapp, Dean
LEVY--Rena. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. Peter Neustadter, Parnas

LUERSSEN--Amy. The Trump family mourns the passing of our beloved Amy, a trusted and loyal friend and employee for over 65 years. A great lady we will never forget, she will surely be missed by all of us whose lives she touched. The Trump Family

A chart on Monday with the continuation of a front-page article about plans by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett to donate most of his fortune to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation omitted two of the largest philanthropic foundations. The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation has an endowment of $9 billion, and the Lilly Endowment $8.6 billion.
An article last Wednesday about cold drinks from around the world misidentified the brown sugar used in the fruit drinks called aguas frescas. It is piloncillo, not panela.

The Nets have three picks in tonight's draft and have big men at the top of their wish list. But with the 22nd, 23rd and 54th selections, it is doubtful that the likes of Cedric Simmons, Patrick O'Bryant, Hilton Armstrong or Saer Sene will still be available. Rod Thorn, the team president, said that the Nets had spoken with teams with picks in the top 15 but that they were not close to a trade.

THERE is an essential truth about cold cooked meat that's revealed in a brisket sandwich -- what I call the brisket code. It goes like this: Even unadorned by gravy, hot brisket can be succulent and flavorful, but the next day, when it's cold and you're thinking it should be perfect for a sandwich, it turns out that it's become a sad, bland bit of business. You have to slather on horseradish to bring it back to life. Otherwise you might as well be eating bologna. I keep the brisket code in mind whenever I cook meat the night before to serve cold or at room temperature the next day, which is pretty much my standard for summer soir√©es, picnics or potlucks. Since the flavors of something cold are usually less pronounced than when they were warm, and since flavors are always muted during storage anyway, the key is to start with more flavor: a blast of herbs, a rub or a marinade.

To the Editor: Re ''It Died for Us,'' by Frank Bruni (Critic's Notebook, Week in Review, June 25): There is no ethical difference between eating a dog, cat, chicken, pig or fish. If anything, eating your dogs or cats would be morally preferable, since they would have led a good life until you killed them.

An article in Business Day on Monday about plans by Microsoft to integrate desktop computers with office and mobile phones referred incorrectly to the software that will let users have e-mail read to them by telephone. It is the next version of Exchange, called Microsoft Exchange 2007 Unified Messaging, not an extension to Exchange called Communications Server.

KAPLAN--B. David, 86. Died peacefully at home in New York on June 26, 2006. The cause was heart failure. David was the fourth generation of his family to be born and raised in New York. His late father, Dr. Ira Kaplan, was a radiologist who took his wife and two small children with him when he went to study the effects of radium with Madame Curie in Germany; David spoke German and French before he spoke English. He was a graduate of The Taft School, Yale University and Harvard University. During WWII, he served as lst Lieutenant in the OSS and was parachuted behind enemy lines. When he returned to New York, he became a partner of Norman B. Norman's in the advertising agency they formed, Norman Craig & Kummel. For many years, he lived in London but returned to the United States in the 70's,retired and lived in Woodstock, VT. In 2005, in failing health, he moved permanently to NYC to live at the home of his former wife and life-long friend, Judith Woodfin, who survives him. David leaves his and Judy's son, Tom Kaplan, a daughter, Anne of London, seven grandchildren, four greatgrandchildren, and his sister, Roslyn Brecher. Another son, James, died many years ago. A gentle man and an erudite gentleman, he loved history, literature, music, art, travel and gardens. He was an indefatigable correspondent with friends all over the world. He leaves sweet memories. The burial will be private. Any donations in his name can be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice Care. $(6$)KAPLAN--B. David. The brokers and staff of Fox Residential Group acknowledge with sorrow the passing of David Kaplan, former husband and lifelong friend of our colleague, Judy Woodfin. David's life was an inspiration to Judy and their children and our love & thoughts are with them at this difficult time.

CHESKIN--Joel Richard. The members and Board of Directors of the Broadway Association mourn the passing of Joel Richard Cheskin, the son of Irving and Mildred Cheskin, our beloved friends and members of our Board. We extend our condolences to the family. The Board of Directors

Prosecutors recommended that the two leading political parties -- Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's Thai Rak Thai Party and the opposition Democrat Party -- be dissolved because of irregularities in national elections in April. The election, which was boycotted by the opposition, was annulled by the courts last month. The main charges grow directly from the Democrats' boycott, including a claim that it was illegal. Mr. Thaksin's party was charged with two violations, including a claim that it illegally financed fringe groups to contest the election to satisfy electoral rules. SETH MYDANS (IHT)

It's a clever idea, packaging four new ales based on Colonial-style brews with founding father tie-ins. Samuel Adams, the Boston company that has gone from microbrewing to big business, has introduced this four-pack, appropriately for the Fourth of July. Traditional Ginger Honey Ale, inspired by Thomas Jefferson's taste for homemade ginger beer, is a fine summer refresher. James Madison Dark Wheat Ale is surprisingly light-bodied, and also quenching, though somewhat one-dimensional.

DRETZIN--David. The Nation magazine mourns the loss of David ''Duff'' Dretzin, our long time labor lawyer and a remarkable, generous man. Duff was much more than an esteemed colleague, he was our friend. We will remember him always for his exceptional kindness, his many good works, and his wise counsel. Our sympathies to his wife Joanna, his daughters Rachel and Julie, his extended family and his many, many friends. We will miss you, Duff. The Nation

The protest was recorded by the writer, who can be heard leading the mourners in a chant -- "There is no God but God" -- until he is overcome with emotion.

A few minutes after 2 p.m. Eastern daylight saving time on Thursday, shares of Charlotte Russe got a sudden lift as trading volume spiked. There was no obvious news to explain the move, but we did notice one possible factor: That happens to be about the same time that regulatory filings revealed that SAC Capital, Steven Cohen's giant and secretive hedge fund, has taken a 5.6 percent stake in the trendy women's apparel company.

The market for well-connected financial consultants is apparently so hot that Merrill Lynch is asking certain employees to pledge their faithfulness to the company. Registered Rep magazine reports that the securities firm has asked a few of its "best producers" to fill out a questionnaire that asks if they are in talks to take another job and seeks a commitment to stay at the firm.

More than a year after tumbling into bankruptcy protection, the supermarket chain Winn-Dixie Stores has detailed its plan to climb back out again. Its proposed Chapter 11 reorganization, filed with the bankruptcy court on Thursday, would turn Winn-Dixie's new stock over to its suppliers and creditors and leave the company's existing shareholders with nothing. This revelation apparently came as a shock to some investors, because Winn-Dixie's thinly traded shares plunged 60 percent on Thursday to about 8 cents apiece.

Nearly everything in a bankruptcy case becomes part of the public record, and that includes the hourly rates charged by some of the nation's top lawyers. The Daily Report, a legal newspaper based in Georgia, has taken advantage of that fact by rounding up a sampling of the fees charged by lawyers in bankruptcies both inside and outside of the state.

Speculation that Kimco Realty is considering an acquisition of New Plan Excel Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust concentrated in shopping centers, has driven up shares of New Plan over the past two days. The stock was at $25.08 in midmorning trading on Thursday, up more than 5 percent from Wednesday's opening price.

Responding somewhat late to our earlier request for readers to submit their greatest all-time teams -- and having apparently misread the instructions to construct a team that could take on an all-time Brazilian XI -- German legend Franz Beckenbauer has just submitted his starting XI, or rather, the 10 players he'd like to have on the pitch alongside himself. Der Kaiser's team is posted over on the FIFA site, where it is called his "Adidas +10 Team," proving that even the age-old Greatest Team Ever discussion among fans is now in the process of being trademarked.

The nation's political reporters and analysts have begun to watch the comings and goings in Iowa and New Hampshire - and even South Carolina - to gauge the early line on Campaign 2008, but Mark Hemmingway predicts in the Weekly Standard that, from this distant vantage point, the critical battle for the Republican nomination will take place in Michigan. "In fact," Hemmingway writes, "as Republican insiders and political consultants break out the laminated maps and dry erase markers, it's becoming clear that the entire Republican nomination strategy may come to hinge on the battle in Michigan."

A digital security company, RSA Security said on Thursday it is in talks about a potential "strategic transaction" but did not give the names of any of the parties involved. The announcement came after a report in The New York Times that RSA was near a deal to sell itself to the acquisitive technology giant EMC or at least one other bidder.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's hedge-fund regulation program "has entered a state of limbo" in the wake of last week's Court of Appeals decision to vacate the so-called Hedge Fund Rule, according to a newsletter from the law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. The rule -- actually a set of rules and amendments -- effectively required fund managers to register as investment advisers.

Shutterfly, an online photo-sharing service funded partly by a co-founder of Netscape, Jim Clark, filed with regulators to raise as much as $92 million in an initial public offering. The preliminary prospectus did not indicate how many shares it would sell or at what price.

When Johnson & Johnson acquired Pfizer's consumer goods business, the market valued the price the company paid at $6 billion too much. In Phelps-Dodge's bid for Falconbridge and Inco the suitor valued future savings at $5.8 billion, a price the market did not buy into, sending the value tumbling. Mittal's acquisition of Arcelor has been more favorably received with the aggregate value of the two companies climbing by $25 billion since the bid was launched in January.

Genworth Financial of Richmond, Va., said on Thursday it has agreed to acquire AssetMark Investment Services, an investment adviser with more than $8 billion in assets under management, for $230 million. AssetMark is based in Pleasant Hill, Calif.

H.J. Heinz on Wednesday defended its results over the last four years and once again urged its shareholders to reject board candidates proposed by a dissident investor group led by the billionaire Nelson Peltz.

Four months after Portland defenseman Jordan Smith lost his left eye after he was hit by a puck, the American Hockey League yesterday became the second minor hockey league to require face protection for all players. The league's board of governors voted overwhelmingly to require protective visors, which are mandatory in the East Coast Hockey League. Face protection is also required for college players. Smith was hit in the eye by a deflected puck on Feb. 24 in a game against the Manchester Monarchs. The injury was so severe his eye had to be removed, and he now has a prosthesis.

The former pitcher Steve Howe had methamphetamine in his system when he was killed as his pickup truck drifted off a desert highway, a coroner's autopsy showed. Howe, 48, died of injuries sustained in the April 28 single-vehicle crash on Interstate 10 in Coachella, Calif., about 150 miles east of Los Angeles.

The state will change its lethal injection process to help prevent problems like last month's struggle to find a vein in a condemned man's arm, leading the man, Joseph L. Clark, left, to ask that officials find another way to kill him, according to a state report. Execution teams will make every effort to find two injection sites and will use a new method to make sure the veins stay open, the prisons director, Terry Collins, told Gov. Bob Taft, a Republican, in the report. The review was prompted by the execution of Mr. Clark, 57, which was delayed when staff members had problems finding a viable vein. The changes will be in place for Ohio's next execution, which is scheduled for July 12.

An Interior Department official who has been linked to the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff was charged in Federal District Court with filing a false financial disclosure report, a misdemeanor. The official, Roger G. Stillwell, handles the Northern Mariana Islands, a territory that hired Mr. Abramoff as a lobbyist. In interviews with The Washington Post last year, Mr. Stillwell said he had sent Mr. Abramoff copies of e-mail messages to his boss. He also told The Post that he accepted meals and tickets to Washington Redskins games from Mr. Abramoff. He said that was not wrong because at the time he was a contract employee of the Interior Department, not a federal employee.

Gov. Bill Owens called the legislature into special session for next week to talk about immigration. Earlier this month, the State Supreme Court struck down a proposed ballot initiative that would have barred illegal immigrants from receiving non-emergency state and local services, and on Monday the court declined to reconsider. Mr. Owens, a Republican, said the Democratic-controlled legislature should either fashion a new referendum similar to the one invalidated by the court and send it on to the voters, or pass legislation that would address the same issues.

Representative Chris Cannon, a five-term congressman, survived the toughest challenge of his political career Tuesday against a political newcomer who portrayed him as soft on illegal immigration. Mr. Cannon, left, defeated his opponent, John Jacob, a millionaire real estate developer, in the Republican primary by 56 percent to 44 percent.

The federal Department of Justice approved rules for issuing photo ID's to voters in Georgia, clearing the way for the state to decide whether to require them for the July 18 primary. The rules establish what kinds of documents must be presented to obtain the ID's, as well as where and when they will be distributed. Critics of the law, which mandates that all voters present a government-issued photo ID, are expected to seek an injunction to block it.

Nabors Industries, the big oil driller that wanted to be considered a Bermuda company for tax purposes but an American company for business purposes, may regret trying to be both.

A Nyack man pleaded guilty to robbery and other charges yesterday in Federal District Court in connection with a series of holdups in the Bronx and towns around New York City, prosecutors said. The defendant, Richard Regis, 33, was charged with the robbery and attempted robbery of banks, check-cashing stores and a credit union last year, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney for the Southern District. In a series of holdups between February and June 2005, Mr. Garcia said, Mr. Regis and his accomplices stole about $314,000.

A group opposed to the proposed Atlantic Yards project is seeking to appeal a recent appellate court ruling regarding the project's legal representation. The group, Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, and 15 co-plaintiffs sued the project's developer, Forest City Ratner Companies, and the state agency sponsoring the project, the Empire State Development Corporation, in January after the agency retained an environmental lawyer, David Paget, who had earlier advised the developer on the project. In May, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court struck down a lower court's ruling that Mr. Paget's involvement was a conflict of interest. Opponents hope to appeal that decision to the State Court of Appeals.

The probate judge overseeing the estate of Andrew M. Kissel appointed the uncle of Mr. Kissel's widow yesterday as executor in accordance with the dead man's will. Judge David Hopper essentially dismissed objections raised by lawyers for William Kissel, Andrew Kissel's father, saying the father was not named as an heir and lacked standing to bring a legal challenge. Andrew Kissel, who was found fatally stabbed on April 3, left behind a long line of creditors that include his former business partner, his lenders, title insurance companies and his wife, Hayley, who was in the midst of divorce proceedings when he died.

Investigators arrested three Brooklyn men yesterday and charged them with trying to bribe a city building inspector. The arrests of the men, David Safir, Gennadiy Bronsteyn and Arkadi Shapiro, came after Mr. Safir offered a building inspector $3,000 to revoke a stop-work order on construction at a Brooklyn property he owned, said Rose Gill Hearn, the city's investigation commissioner. The Department of Investigation, which worked on the case with the Department of Buildings, said Mr. Safir then referred the inspector to Mr. Bronsteyn and Mr. Shapiro. The two men later offered the inspector $10,000 to erase citations for violations on a pair of adjoining properties they owned, investigators said.

Three Queens fortunetellers were arrested on Tuesday after they tried to charge undercover investigators for services including exorcism and rekindling a past romantic relationship, the authorities said. The fortunetellers, who operated out of apartments or storefronts on 30th Avenue in Astoria, face charges including fortunetelling, which is illegal unless patrons are told that such services are for entertainment purposes. One of the fortunetellers, Sabrina Martell, 42, told a female investigator that her problems stretched back to something her mother had eaten while pregnant, prosecutors said. Ms. Martell charged the investigator $1,100 for those and other services, prosecutors said. The other women arrested were identified as Dorothy Miller, 53, and Rose Miller, 73. They are not related.

A Long Island utility worker died after being electrocuted yesterday afternoon in Nassau County, the police said. The worker, Joseph Ingenito, 55, an employee of KeySpan Energy Corporation who lived in Malverne, had been working on a malfunctioning transformer on Lido Boulevard in Point Lookout, in the town of Hempstead. Mr. Ingenito, who the police say had climbed into a manhole to investigate a blown fuse, was electrocuted around 2:30 p.m. He was taken to Long Beach Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead.

A lawyer representing a woman charged with murdering her 7-year-old daughter is seeking to seal court records and prohibit lawyers from discussing the case publicly, court records show. The woman, Nixzaliz Santiago, is accused of participating in a pattern of violent abuse that ended with the death of the girl, Nixzmary Brown, in the family apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant in January. Ms. Santiago's boyfriend, Cesar Rodriguez, is also charged with murder. Both have pleaded not guilty. Ms. Santiago's lawyer, Robert W. Abrams, has filed papers seeking the order of silence, which prosecutors have opposed.

Spurred by recent cases in which club bouncers were arrested in connection with the deaths of patrons, the City Council held hearings yesterday on proposed legislation that would penalize club owners who hire unlicensed security guards or who fail to keep licensing paperwork on the premises. The measure would allow the Police Department and the Department of Consumer Affairs to close clubs or bars that violate such regulations. Bar owners testifying at the hearing said they welcomed stricter licensing for door personnel but asked that the new regulations apply only to those involved in security. The bill was prompted by three recent incidents involving security guards, including the murder last February of Imette St. Guillen, a college student. Darryl Littlejohn, a bouncer who worked at the SoHo bar that Ms. St. Guillen visited, has been charged with her murder. He has pleaded not guilty.

Montenegro became a member state of the United Nations by acclamation of the General Assembly, less than a month after the end of its 88-year union with Serbia. A short while later, the Montenegrin flag ‚Äî a gold double eagle on a red field ‚Äî was raised alongside the flags of the 191 other member nations.

The father of a 19-year-old woman shot to death two days after her wedding last September because her Pakistani family disapproved of her choice of a husband was sentenced to life imprisonment as the mastermind of the killing. The woman's older brother, who had admitted pulling the trigger, was handed a 16-year term. Two uncles who helped the father were also sentenced to 16 years. Another uncle and an aunt were given 14 years, and three family friends who helped track the newlyweds were sentenced to terms ranging from 8 to 10 years. The trial, which began in May, had been widely followed in the Danish news media. At least nine other honor killings are known to have taken place in Denmark since the late 1980's.

Parliament's lower house gave preliminary approval to amendments that would expand the definition of extremism, a measure critics say is so broadly worded that it could allow the authorities to quash political and public protests. Joseph Kony, the leader of a rebel group that has kidnapped thousands of children to reinforce its ranks, told a British journalist that he was finally ready to reach a peace accord with the Ugandan government he has fought for the last two decades. Mr. Kony, who heads the Lord's Resistance Army and is wanted on war crimes charges by the International Criminal Court, denied committing the many atrocities attributed to him and his movement. His followers attribute mystical powers to Mr. Kony, and he told The Times of London in an interview that spirits speak to him.

Tamil Tiger boats hiding among fishing vessels off the island's northwest coast attacked two navy craft, killing five sailors in a 45-minute battle, officials said. A navy spokesman said 12 rebels were killed and two of their boats destroyed in retaliatory airstrikes. A Tiger spokesman said just one rebel died.

A judge sentenced a businessman, David Mugo Kiragu, to 30 years in prison for drug trafficking but acquitted six other defendants for lack of evidence in one of Africa's biggest drug seizures, 1.1 tons of cocaine. Mr. Kiragu is the brother of the main suspect in the case, George Kiragu, who is awaiting extradition from the Netherlands. The drugs were seized in 2004. Kenyan law enforcement authorities have been criticized for bungling the investigation of the case.

An article on May 31 about the re-election campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton overstated the cost of her 2000 race. She raised $30.2 million and spent $29.9 million; the campaign did not cost $41.8 million. (The Federal Election Commission lists the $41.8 million in its records because $11.6 million of the $30.2 million was counted twice when it was transferred from one of Mrs. Clinton's fund-raising committees to another. Under law, both committees had to report that they handled the money, even though the duplicated $11.6 million incorrectly increased the $30.2 million total to $41.8 million. Final accounting records by the F.E.C. reflect the accurate figure of $30.2 million.).
Russia has unveiled details of a plan to reorganize the country's myriad nuclear power plants, agencies, institutes and departments into a single state company.

In this grave, beautiful novel by Philippe Claudel, a village policeman writes out his sorrow-laden journal of the plague years.
The company for women is making room for a few sharp men.

Her store, which opened in April, is an airy ballroom of a place, the walls painted bright coral pink and embellished with gold scrolls that put me in mind of the beautiful abstract work of the painter Philip Taaffe.

DANIELI--Francesa. Mother, sister, daughter, friend, wife, and artist...we all lost a beautiful woman on the the evening of June 27. Francesca has shown remarkable grace, strength & dignity, having first faced cancer 22 years ago when diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma; then with breast cancer eight years ago; followed by metastatic disease diagnosed nearly two years ago. Having lived her life with such grace, dignity and wit, Francesca spent her last weeks in character at a hospice and wanted all of her friends and family to know that she believes that she led a very fortunate life. Having received national recognition for her work as a photographer and videographer, Francesca has published her body of work in Gamma Knife by Nazraeli Press in 2005. Her video project ''One Nice Thing'' was an official selection at 3 film festivals. Her work is held in the collections of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, TX and the Getty Museum. Francesca completed Masters Degrees at both the Columbia Business School and the Maryland Institute College of Art and received her BFA from the Virginia Commonwealth University. Francesca is survived by her three daughters, Anna, Lee and Isabel Gensler; her husband, Gary Gensler, all of Brooklandville, MD; her father, Francesco Costagliola of Alexandria, VA; and her three sisters, Marisa Costagliola of Columbia, MD, Antonia Burns of Cambridge, MD, and Rose Rubin of Falls Church, VA. Funeral services will be held at her home in Brooklandville, MD, Thursday, June 29, at 1:30 pm. Francesca wanted to thank everyone for their expression of support over many years and asked that in lieu of sending flowers or food please send contributions to: Hopewell Cancer Support; PO Box 755; Brooklandville, MD 21022 (410)-832-2719).

The headline on a report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about contract talks between New York City hotel workers' unions and the Hilton Corporation referred incorrectly to their negotiations. The two sides agreed to extend their talks for 14 days; they have not reached a settlement.

CARON--Diana Welwood died unexpectedly on June 21st, 2006 at her home in Stuart, FL. Born in NY, Diana attended Ms. Hewitt's classes and Vassar College before moving to New Canaan with her young family. She was an active and engaged member of the community for over 30 years. Diana is survived by her loving daughter Sandra Oldershaw, devoted sons Peter John and Philip Caron, 5 grandchildren, her sister Helen Welwood-Gavales of NY and brother Thornton Marshall of Huntington, L.I. A family service was held in Stuart.

Andrea Bargnani donned a red Toronto Raptors hat and walked onto the stage at the Theater at Madison Square Garden for the first close-up of his new life. Hailing from Italy, a soccer-crazy country known more for importing rather than exporting basketball talent, the 7-foot Bargnani last night became the first European chosen with the top selection in the N.B.A. draft.

A front-page article on Sunday about the development of ethanol plants gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of the chief economist at the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, who is concerned about how the production of the biofuel could affect corn supplies. It is Gregg Doud, not Dowd. Because of an editing error, the article referred imprecisely to plants in Fulton, N.Y., and Savannah, Ga., in some copies. They are in the planning stages; they are not yet operating.

LUERSSEN--Amy. The Trump family mourns the passing of our beloved Amy, a trusted and loyal friend and employee for over 65 years. A great lady we will never forget, she will surely be missed by all of us whose lives she touched. The Trump Family

No√´l Forgeard, the co-chief executive of EADS, dismissed a French lawmaker's suggestion that he quit his post, even as the group's largest German shareholder stepped up the pressure for a quick solution to the company's management crisis. Marylise Lebranchu, a Socialist lawmaker and former justice minister, asked Mr. Forgeard at a French parliamentary hearing whether he had considered resigning in the interest of the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the corporate parent of Airbus. Mr. Forgeard refused to quit, according to several members of Parliament who attended the hearing behind closed doors. Support for Mr. Forgeard among EADS shareholders and within the French government appears to be eroding. NICOLA CLARK (IHT)

The new Parallel Lines collection of vinyl wallcoverings from KnollTextiles ''explores the boundary between the hand-crafted and digital,'' according to Paul Lewis, a partner in Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis Architects, the New York-based firm responsible for the designs. The architects, who are known for experimenting with patterns and surfaces in projects like the Tides restaurant and Fluff Bakery in Manhattan, used hand-drawn pencil lines that were digitally scanned and manipulated. The Perimeter pattern, below, features overlapping boxes outlined in dashes and dots ($16 a yard); Vector and Margin, the collection's two other designs, are embellished with seemingly random combinations of vertical and horizontal lines that gradate from light to heavy ($15 a yard). Available through KnollTextiles, (866) 565-5858, knolltextiles.com.

GOOGLE PAYMENT SERVICE Google is introducing a service that will let users make purchases from online stores using payment and shipping information they keep on file with Google. [Page C1.] ACCUSATIONS AGAINST BP Federal regulators charged that BP manipulated the price of propane two years ago by cornering the market through its dominant position, pushing up heating costs for millions at the peak of winter demand. [C1.] MUSICAL BIDDING WAR Years of jockeying to combine two of the world's biggest music companies, the EMI Group and the Warner Music Group, has escalated with the two now bidding to take over one another. EMI said yesterday that it had raised its recent bid for Warner Music to $31 a share, or about $4.6 billion. Warner then turned the tables and extended an offer for EMI of roughly $4.6 billion, to be financed mainly by debt. EMI dismissed the bid as ''wholly unacceptable.'' [C1.] SUMMER OF CAR DEALS American car shoppers have learned that summer is the season of big discounts, and this year is shaping up no differently, with some discounts amounting to savings of 20 percent or more. [C1.] HEDGE FUND TESTIMONY A former investigator for the Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress on Wednesday how senior S.E.C. officials gave in to what he described as political pressure and stopped his investigation of suspected insider trading by a prominent hedge fund. [C3.] AD FORECAST LOWERED A leading forecaster of advertising spending has again lowered his estimate for growth in the United States in 2006. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C13.] NEW CHAIRMAN AT DISNEY The Walt Disney Company announced that John E. Pepper Jr., a former Procter & Gamble chief executive who joined Disney's board early this year, had been appointed non-executive chairman. [C13.] STOCKS ADVANCE The Dow Jones industrial average gained 48.82 points to finish at 10,973.56. The Standard & Poor's 500 added 6.80 points to end at 1,246. The Nasdaq advanced 11.59 points to close at 2,111.84. [C15.] INSURANCE WOES IN FLORIDA Many Florida residents are scouring for homeowners' insurance after two ferocious hurricane seasons and struggling to pay for what they find. [A16.] F.A.A. CUTS The Federal Aviation Administration, in a three-pronged approach to cutting its costs, is halting many personnel transfers in its air traffic system, reducing the staffing levels for air traffic controllers and evaluating layoffs of weather forecasters. [A16.] MALARIA FIGHT Wielding a combination of new medicines, better bed nets, old-fashioned pesticides and data analysis, the mining company Billiton and its partners in business and government have made major inroads in the fight against malaria in Mozambique. [A1.] ORTHOPEDIC PRICING For years, makers of artificial hips and other orthopedic devices have benefited from their pricing power. But that may not last much longer. [C4.] MAINE'S STRUGGLING ECONOMY Maine was the only state besides Louisiana to see a decline in economic activity last year, according to a new Federal Reserve study. [A17.] BATTLE FOR GAZPROM SPOT Two outsiders are trying to join Gazprom's board, which has been a tight combination of government ministers and well-heeled businessmen for most of its 15-year existence. [C9.] RUSSIA'S NUCLEAR REVAMPING Russia has unveiled details of a plan to reorganize the country's myriad nuclear power plants, agencies, institutes and departments into a single state company modeled on Gazprom. Underscoring the source of its economic inspiration, the name of the enterprise is likely to be Atomprom, Sergei V. Kiriyenko, above, the director of the Atomic Energy Agency, said. [C9.] ENTER THE AVON MAN The Avon lady isn't what she used to be. For one, she isn't always a woman. [G1.] RADAR IS REVIVED Radar, the pop-culture glossy publication, is being resurrected. ANADARKO PETROLEUM, which agreed last week to buy Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources, plans to sell its Canadian subsidiary and use the proceeds to repay debt. The Critic's Choice column on Tuesday, about new DVD's, misidentified the setting of the 1932 film ''Red Dust,'' which was loosely remade with Clark Gable in 1935 as ''China Seas,'' a film in a new Gable DVD collection. It was Asia, not Africa.

A Federal judge in Miami has orderedthe Miami-Dade Countryschool district not to remove a seriesof children's books from its librariesuntil arguments against the removalcan be heard next month, The AssociatedPress reported. Invoking thestudents' rights to a free press anddue process, the American Civil LibertiesUnion sued last week to preventthe district from clearing theshelves of 25 titles, including oneabout Cuba that depicts smilingyoungsters in uniforms of the country'syouth organization. Judge AlanGold scheduled the next hearing forJuly 21.

A picture caption yesterday with a music review about the Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players, at the JCC in Manhattan, misidentified the violin player. She is Lisa Shihoten, not Anne Akiko Meyers.

THE accouterments for outdoor diversions seem to improve each year. Reproduction items become more durable while preserving their older looks, and modern gear, like portable lounge chairs and beverage coolers, benefit from advances in technology and materials. 1. A new French-style wicker shopping cart can be packed for a picnic and rolls easily. It is $110 from mothology.com, (404) 351-6484. A cotton picnic blanket (in cart) for $185 looks like an old French bed sheet, and a matching tufted cushion, $42, can be used on the ground; both, along with placemats of coated, recycled newspapers for $20 each, are at Ruby Beets, 25 Washington Street, Sag Harbor, N.Y., (631) 899-3275. Rubber dinner plates, for $5.50 each, and bowls, for $4.50 each, come in bright red, green, orange or blue at Pearl River, 477 Broadway (Broome Street), (800) 878-2446. 2. Hand-woven cotton mochila bags, made by Wayuu weavers in Colombia, each in a different pattern, can carry picnic fixings or bathing suit, sunscreen and beach towel. They are $250 at Takashimaya, 693 Fifth Avenue (55th Street), (212) 350-0100, or for stores elsewhere: surevolution.com, (212)255-6928. 3. A picnic trunk packed with utensils and glasses for two, along with salt and pepper shakers and a corkscrew, has a handy fold-out table. In khaki, green or black, $99.98 at Zabar's, 2245 Broadway (80th Street), zabars.com, (212) 496-1234 or, outside New York, (800) 697-6301. 4. An insulated bag holds a portable grill, and has room for charcoal and utensils. It is $29.98 at Zabar's. 5. The lighted planter and beverage tub has a 12-foot-long cord and a 9-watt bulb, and can hold potted palms as well as Diet Cokes. It is $125 from frontgate.com or (888) 263-9850. 6. Cycloc, a compact plastic bike rack from London, attaches to the wall with a few screws; $125 at Moss, 146 Greene Street (Houston Street) or (866) 888-6677. 7. Five-by-eight-foot Veranda mats, woven of synthetic fibers, look like Persian carpets and make good ground covers for beach or lawn picnics; $68 from softsurroundings.com or (800) 240-7076. 8. The Comfort-Lite lounge chair folds compactly and has a shoulder strap for easy carrying. The chair is covered in nylon mesh, and comes in red, yellow, blue or beige; $99 at Brookstone, brookstone.com or (866) 576-7337.

BABAKIAN--Grace.Of Larchmont on June 27, 2006. Wife of George, mother of Glenn, Gerard and Genine. Grandmother of five. Memorial service at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home Bronxville on Wednesday July 5 at 4:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461.

Harry Allen, below, earned a reputation for quirky design with his 2004 cast-resin piggy banks that resemble real piglets, and with his fruit bowls made from actual fruit cast in resin, introduced earlier this year. But his eclectic body of work also includes the sleek interior of the high-end Moss store in SoHo and inexpensive lighting fixtures for Ikea. Now admirers can see the range of his furniture and product design in a new showroom in the East Village. Among the current offerings are the Chuck chair, below left, $5,400, which unfolds into a chaise, and the ash Bedford dresser, bottom left, $6,400. The showroom's summer hours are Tuesday through Friday, from 2 to 7 p.m., at 207 Avenue A (13th Street), (212) 529-7239.

AT some point, all the obsessive labor required to keep a garden from going back to the wild -- weeding, pruning, dividing, mowing -- begins to lose its joy. ''At the Homestead, everywhere you went, you saw something that needed to be done,'' said Dale Booher, 74, an architect who married Lisa Stamm, 62, a garden designer, more than 25 years ago. ''The work never ended.''

GREER--Robert E., of White Plains died June 27, 2006 from ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease). Former Vice President of Finance and Strategic Planning for MBIA Corporation. He is survived by his wife Helen, 2 daughters, Ashley Saber and Alexis Greer and three grandchildren, Billy, Kori and Kristen. A memorial service will be held on July 7, 2006 at KolAmi Temple in White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers make donations to the ALS Division of the MDA. 1-800-344-4863 For further information contact McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home White Plains, NY (914) 949-7777.

McDERMOTT--Kay, Age 67. NY Public library volunteer, Big Apple greeter, senior road runner, and many other selfless endeavors. A caring, generous, loving lady. A friend to all in need, a loss to her community and the many who loved her.
To the Editor: Re ''Buffett to Give Bulk of Fortune to Gates Charity'' (front page, June 26):

Parliament's lower house gave preliminary approval to amendments that would expand the definition of extremism, a measure critics say is so broadly worded that it could allow the authorities to quash political and public protests. The amendments, if adopted in two additional votes, would label as extremist those who ''impede the activities of state bodies'' or organize or take part in public disturbances, according to news reports. It would also apply to ''public slander'' of state officials. The measures would allow the authorities to disqualify political parties or, in extreme cases, prosecute violators. STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

On the strength of a catchy new single, ''Promiscuous'' -- a hit on radio and ubiquitous on television thanks to its use in a Verizon Wireless commercial -- Nelly Furtado reached the top of the Billboard chart this week with her album ''Loose'' (Geffen). It sold 219,000 copies in its first week at stores, according to Nielsen SoundScan, giving Ms. Furtado her first No. 1 album. The No. 2 album in the country, ''Define the Great Line'' (Tooth & Nail) by the Christian hard rock band Underoath, sold 98,000 copies last week with very little commercial airplay; it is the highest-charting Christian album since LeAnn Rimes's ''You Light Up My Life -- Inspirational Songs'' reached No. 1 in 1997, Billboard said. The Dixie Chicks' ''Taking the Long Way'' (Columbia) slipped to No. 3; the British band Keane's new album, ''Under the Iron Sea'' (Interscope), opened at No. 4; and Busta Rhymes's ''Big Bang'' (Aftermath/Interscope), last week's chart topper, fell to No. 5. Music sales overall are down 4 percent from last year at this time, at 261 million units. BEN SISARIO

Gov. Bill Owens called the legislature into special session for next week to talk about immigration. Earlier this month, the State Supreme Court struck down a proposed ballot initiative that would have barred illegal immigrants from receiving non-emergency state and local services, and on Monday the court declined to reconsider. Mr. Owens, a Republican, said the Democratic-controlled legislature should either fashion a new referendum similar to the one invalidated by the court and send it on to the voters, or pass legislation that would address the same issues. KIRK JOHNSON (NYT)

An article in Science Times on Tuesday, profiling Dr. Arata Kochi, the new chief of the World Health Organization's campaign against malaria, referred imprecisely to the pesticide DDT, which can kill the mosquitoes that spread the disease. Its use has been banned in many countries for environmental reasons; it has not been withdrawn entirely.

An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Friday, about a vote by French lawmakers to ease restrictions on a draft copyright law, referred imprecisely to the ability of the Apple iPod to play tunes from online music stores other than Apple's, an issue in the political debate. While Apple's music store makes tunes available in a proprietary format, iPods can play music purchased at certain other stores, usually in MP3 format.

SCRIBNER--DavidJune 28th, 1906 An inspiration to your children, grandchildren and many others. Always remembered with love and pride.
Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about the Italian designer and architect Anna Castelli Ferrieri misspelled the given name of her surviving daughter. She is Maria, not Marial.

The outsiders are on the outside, none more than Uruguay, the only one of the seven nations that have won the World Cup not preparing to play in the quarterfinals of the 2006 tournament. Some would say that order has been restored to soccer's universe as six teams from Europe and two from South America will play for a spot in the final in Berlin on July 9. Only four years ago the quarterfinals were a revelation, but five of those teams are missing: the United States, South Korea and Spain; Senegal and Turkey did not qualify for the 2006 World Cup. By JACK BELL QUARTERFINAL MATCHUPS GERMANY-ARGENTINA Both countries have won the tournament as hosts: Germany in 1974, Argentina in 1978. And this game has the feel of a final - Argentina beat West Germany for the title in Mexico in 1986, and West Germany turned the tables in Italy in 1990. The Germans have looked unbeatable at home; Argentina has simply looked unbeatable. After yielding two goals in the opener, Germany's much-maligned defense has had shutouts the past three games while Miroslav Klose has scored four goals in the tournament. The Argentines have a deep roster that mixes experience and youth. Lionel Messi and Carlos Tevez, starters on nearly any team in the world, are reserves for Argentina. EDGE: Argentina ITALY-UKRAINE Playing in its first World Cup as an independent nation, Ukraine has given its 23 players a shared $8 million bonus for making the quarterfinals. Ukraine is the only team to lose its first game of the tournament and still be playing. It should surprise no one that Italy, with a savvy stalwart defense and goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, has yielded only one goal in four games. It often seems the Italians find an operatic way to tease and then vanquish the opposition. EDGE: Italy ENGLAND-PORTUGAL England's Wayne Rooney said he was ready to play 90 minutes, or more, after bouncing back from a broken foot. David Beckham's lethal free kicks have obscured an offense that is struggling. England has only won the Cup as host in 1966, and it has been 40 years in the wilderness since. Portugal has received a boost from the veteran Lu√≠s Figo, but it will be without the suspended Deco and Costinha. EDGE: Portugal BRAZIL-FRANCE The old men of Europe (France) against the defending champion (Brazil). A rematch of the 1998 final, won by host France, 3-0. That was eight years ago, and while the French team includes the veteran holdovers Zin√©dine Zidane, Patrick Vieira, Lilian Thuram and Fabien Barthiez, the young Brazilian stallions Ronaldinho, Adriano and Kak√° will be hard to stop. EDGE: Brazil

A judge sentenced a businessman, David Mugo Kiragu, to 30 years in prison for drug trafficking but acquitted six other defendants for lack of evidence in one of Africa's biggest drug seizures, 1.1 tons of cocaine. Mr. Kiragu is the brother of the main suspect in the case, George Kiragu, who is awaiting extradition from the Netherlands. The drugs were seized in 2004. Kenyan law enforcement authorities have been criticized for bungling the investigation of the case. MARC LACEY (NYT)

THE voices of protest emanated from everyday folks, including a teacher in a John Starks jersey, a law school student in a loose tie and a Web site techie in a gray T-shirt. Between 20 and 30 of these disenfranchised souls assembled at the Mercury Bar late yesterday afternoon to basically march on James L. Dolan's inheritance: Madison Square Garden.

Police in Bangalore confirmed that they had arrested an employee of the back-office unit of HSBC, the British bank, on charges of stealing customers' confidential data and helping defraud them of about $425,000. The employee, Nadeem Kashmiri, was accused of providing debit card information on about 20 customers to accomplices in Britain who used the data to siphon money from the customers' accounts. SARITHA RAI (NYT)
To the Editor: Re ''It's Goalkeeper vs. Bookkeeper as I.R.S. Discovers Youth Soccer'' (news article, June 25):

An Interior Department official who has been linked to the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff was charged in Federal District Court with filing a false financial disclosure report, a misdemeanor. The official, Roger G. Stillwell, handles the Northern Mariana Islands, a territory that hired Mr. Abramoff as a lobbyist. In interviews with The Washington Post last year, Mr. Stillwell said he had sent Mr. Abramoff copies of e-mail messages to his boss. He also told The Post that he accepted meals and tickets to Washington Redskins games from Mr. Abramoff. He said that was not wrong because at the time he was a contract employee of the Interior Department, not a federal employee.

10 P.M. (FX) IT'S ALWAYS SUNNY IN PHILADELPHIA -- Who knows what kind of cajoling was required to get Danny DeVito to take on his first television series since ''Taxi'' turned off its meter in 1983? (He reportedly filmed a season's worth of appearances in 15 days.) Never mind. He's a welcome addition (and perhaps a needed ratings booster) to the second year of this series about four friends who own an Irish bar together. Mr. DeVito joins the cast as Dennis and Dee's estranged father, who likes his visit to South Philly so much that he stays. 8 P.M. (CBS) GAMESHOW MARATHON -- Next up -- and last -- in this competition series, ''Family Feud,'' in which Kathy Najimy and Brande Roderick team up with their relatives for $100,000 to go to a charity of their choice. 9 P.M. (HBO) BOFFO! TINSELTOWN'S BOMBS AND BLOCKBUSTERS -- Who knows what it takes to create a Hollywood blockbuster, beyond a little backstabbing? No one, really, which is the point of this documentary in which Peter Bogdanovich, Morgan Freeman, Sherry Lansing, Sydney Pollack and others talk about the amalgams of perseverance and good luck that George Clooney (above) calls simply ''a miracle.'' As Brian Grazer explains it, ''The line between success and non-success is very, very razorthin.'' That's pretty thin. 10 P.M. (History Channel) AMERICAN EATS -- If every country has a national food identity, what is ours? One guess, and it's a category that includes hot dogs, hamburgers, fries and, tonight's subject, pizza. 10 P.M. (SportsNet New York) SIMPLY AMAZIN': 86 METS -- It's almost too far back for some of us to remember, but 20 years ago the New York Mets won the World Series. This hourlong special recounts the glory of the 1986 championship season through film clips and interviews with former players and coaches, including Keith Hernandez, Davey Johnson, Ron Darling and Mookie Wilson. Good news for fans still smarting over their team's loss to the Yankees in the 2000 Subway Series: the Mets are currently in first place in the National League. 11 P.M. (SoapNet) I WANNA BE A SOAP STAR -- Really? Then you'd better be something of an exhibitionist. In this episode, the finalists get fired up for a passionate love scene. Melissa Archer and Forbes March, who play the bed-hopping Natalie and Nash on ''One Life to Live,'' offer hot tips. 11:35 P.M. (CBS) LATE SHOW WITH DAVID LETTERMAN -- Johnny Depp (right), back from the Bahamas, where he filmed ''Pirates of the Caribbean,'' Parts 2 and 3, talks about keeping his eye on the Sparrow. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday ordered Russia's secret services to find and kill those who kidnapped and killed four Russian Embassy employees in Iraq, the Kremlin announced in a statement. The bluntness of the statement reflected the deep shock and anger -- much directed at the United States -- that have unfolded in Russia after the kidnapping on June 3 in an attack that killed a fifth Russian.

Montenegro became a member state of the United Nations by acclamation of the General Assembly, less than a month after the end of its 88-year union with Serbia. A short while later, the Montenegrin flag -- a gold double eagle on a red field -- was raised alongside the flags of the 191 other member nations. DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER (NYT)

Then the Red Sox smacked Mart√≠nez around and Mart√≠nez hit Mark Loretta on the wrist and the Red Sox smacked him around some more and the fans who earlier had showered him with love derided him with a chant borrowed from the Bronx.

The ratings race on Tuesday demonstrated the popularity of ''House.'' Two reruns of Fox's grumpy genius doctor series delivered a victory for the network in Nielsen's estimates. From 8 p.m. to 10 p.m. ''House'' (7 million, then 9.8 million) beat two hours of original programming on NBC, ''Fear Factor'' (5.7 million) and ''Last Comic Standing'' (7.1 million). NBC, which also broadcast a repeat of ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' (7.2 million), placed second among adults 18 to 49 and third among total viewers. CBS was No. 2 among viewers. Its lineup benefited from the yanking of ''Tuesday Night Book Club,'' the reality flop, from the schedule; at 10 p.m. a ''48 Hours Mystery'' (7.6 million) ran in its place. Part 1 of AMC's western mini-series, ''Broken Trail,'' drew 9.8 million viewers on Sunday night. It was the most-watched show on both broadcast and cable television on Sunday, and was the most popular program ever telecast on AMC. KATE AURTHUR

Joseph Kony, the leader of a rebel group that has kidnapped thousands of children to reinforce its ranks, told a British journalist that he was finally ready to reach a peace accord with the Ugandan government he has fought for the last two decades. Mr. Kony, who heads the Lord's Resistance Army and is wanted on war crimes charges by the International Criminal Court, denied committing the many atrocities attributed to him and his movement. His followers attribute mystical powers to Mr. Kony, and he told The Times of London in an interview that spirits speak to him. ''They will tell us what is going to happen,'' he said. ''They say, 'You, Mr. Joseph, tell your people that the enemy is planning to come and attack.' '' MARC LACEY (NYT)

Esque, a glassmaking studio based in Portland, Ore., recently introduced Glowdelier, above, a Venetian-inspired chandelier that emits light even when it's off. Andi Kovel and Justin Parker, the company's owners, developed a process that infuses glass with a glow-in-the-dark phosphorescent pigment so that ''wherever it's been most strongly exposed to light is where it will glow the brightest,'' Ms. Kovel said. She and Mr. Parker left some of the chandelier's arms unfinished -- in an amorphous, tentacle-like arrangement, with tool marks intact -- to reveal the process of making them, she said. The chandelier is available through DesignLush, a Manhattan showroom, for $22,500, along with Glonce, a glow-in-the-dark sconce, which is $2,500; (212) 532-5450.

To the Editor: Bob Herbert (''Playing Politics With Iraq,'' column, June 26) is right on the mark when he points out that the Bush administration is blatantly using our troops as political chess pieces.

The North Shore-Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Health System mourns the passing of Herman Merinoff, an esteemed trustee and the chairman of The Feinstein Institute for Medical Research Board of Directors. A leader in business who served as chairman of The Charmer Sunbelt Group, and chairman and CEO of the Renfield Corporation, Mr. Merinoff had also been an attorney with a prominent New York law firm, as well as an assistant US attorney for the Eastern District of New York. Noted as much for his philanthropic endeavors as he was for his business success, he was the recipient of numerous community service awards, including the American Cancer Society's Dr. Louis Berger Memorial Award. We are forever grateful to Mr. Merinoff and his family for the long-time support he has provided to the North Shore-LIJ Health System and The Feinstein Institute. We extend our deep sympathy to his wife, Susan, and their five children. His wisdom and kindness will be greatly missed. On behalf of the board of directors, faculty and staff of The Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, we are profoundly saddened by the sudden loss of our chairman and friend, Herman I. Merinoff. His enthusiasm for patientoriented research - the translation of science into tangible benefits for patients - was remarkable. Herman and his wife, Susan, have been staunch supporters of The Feinstein Institute and the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System for many years, and in 2004 made a generous gift that helped propel The Feinstein into an exciting period of expansion. It is tragic that he is no longer here to witness and enjoy the chain of successes that he forged link by link through his passionate spirit and kind generosity. We miss him dearly, and extend our deep sympathies to Susan and the entire Merinoff family. Kevin J. Tracey, MD Director & CEO Leonard Feinstein Board Member The Feinstein Institute for Medical Research $(6$)MERINOFF -- Herman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Susan; to his children, Linda Merinoff Bogrow, Cathy Ellen Onufrychuk, Charles Merinoff, Spencer Merinoff, and Barbara Albert; to Ruth; & to his entire family. Dead Shark Not Aging Well Has Damien Hirst's famous shark in formaldehyde outlived its youthfulness? Because the work has deteriorated sharply since first seen at the Saatchi Gallery in London in 1992, Mr. Hirst is in discussions with the owner to replace it, The Art Newspaper reported. Not only is the shark's skin showing signs of wear and tear, but the fish has also changed shape, and the solution surrounding it has become murky, the newspaper said. The piece, titled ''The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living, 1991,'' was commissioned by the British collector Charles Saatchi from Mr. Hirst for ¬£50,000 (now about $91,000) and was sold to the American hedge fund manager Steve Cohen in 2004 for a reported $11.85 million. In a statement Mr. Hirst's company, Science Ltd., said, ''Damien will happily help to refurbish as he would with any of his works that are over 10 years old.'' Larry Gagosian, the gallery owner who brokered the 2004 deal, said: ''The shark is a conceptual piece and to substitute a shark of equal size and appearance, in my opinion does not alter the piece. Steve Cohen is very happy with the piece and is not troubled at all with having to substitute it.'' Toronto 'Rings' to Close ''The Lord of the Rings,'' the $24-million musical adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkein's fantasy trilogy, will end its run on Sept. 3 at the Princess of Wales Theater in Toronto, where it began an open-ended engagement on March 23. The producers announced last week that the show would begin performances in May 2007 at the Theater Royal Drury Lane in London. Sleater-Kinney Bows Out The acclaimed rock trio Sleater-Kinney, above, will call it quits after finishing its summer commitments. ''After 11 years as a band, Sleater-Kinney have decided to go on indefinite hiatus,'' said an announcement on the group's Web site, www.sleater-kinney.com. ''The upcoming summer shows will be our last. As of now, there are no plans for future tours or recordings.'' Sleater-Kinney will play at Webster Hall in Manhattan on Aug. 2 and give its final performance at Lollapalooza in Grant Park in Chicago on Aug. 4. BET Winners Mary J. Blige, Kanye West, Jamie Foxx and Chris Brown had their hands full when the Black Entertainment Television Awards were announced on Tuesday in Los Angeles. Each won two awards, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Blige, below, was named top female R&B artist and, in a tie, shared the prize for video of the year with Mr. West and Mr. Foxx. She won for ''Be With You,'' featuring Terrence Howard, who was named best actor. Mr. West and Mr. Foxx took video honors for ''Gold Digger,'' also chosen as best collaboration. Mr. Brown was named best new artist and honored as viewer's choice for ''Excuse Me Miss.'' The BET Award winners are chosen by a panel of executives from entertainment companies, record labels and news media, but the Viewer's Choice award is decided by fans voting online. Wagner in Aix-en-Provence Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle will be heard at the Aix-en-Provence festival for the first time, beginning this year, when the event, in its 58th year, opens on Sunday in southern France, Agence France-Presse reported. The Berlin Philharmonic, conducted by Simon Rattle, right, will usher in the four-year cycle with ''Das Rheingold,'' in a staging by the French director St√©phane Braunschweig to be seen next year in Salzburg. This year's arts festival will pay homage to Mozart, born 250 years ago in Salzburg, and to a native son, C√©zanne, who died 100 years ago. On Wednesday, Sir Simon and the Berlin Philharmonic will be heard in a free performance of Mahler's Fifth Symphony at the foot of Mont Sainte-Victoire, featured in more than 80 C√©zanne paintings. Book Removal Delayed A Federal judge in Miami has ordered the Miami-Dade Country school district not to remove a series of children's books from its libraries until arguments against the removal can be heard next month, The Associated Press reported. Invoking the students' rights to a free press and due process, the American Civil Liberties Union sued last week to prevent the district from clearing the shelves of 25 titles, including one about Cuba that depicts smiling youngsters in uniforms of the country's youth organization. Judge Alan Gold scheduled the next hearing for July 21. Axl Rose, Sober and Fined Axl Rose, the lead singer of Guns N' Roses, was released from a Stockholm jail after 11 hours on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. The police said that when he sobered up, he admitted to assaulting and biting a security guard in the lobby of his hotel and agreed to pay a fine of $5,430 and compensation of $1,360 to the guard. The incident took place after a concert and a night of partying.

To the Editor: The decision by The New York Times to disclose the Terrorist Finance Tracking Program, a robust and classified effort to map terrorist networks through the use of financial data, was irresponsible and harmful to the security of Americans and freedom-loving people worldwide.

Just before 2 p.m. on the last Saturday of each month from April to October, a dozen saber-bearing cavalry officers of the Kremlin Regiment, in tall hats and czarist military uniforms adorned with gold buttons, yellow tassels and epaulets, mount their horses and gallop through the Spassky Gates, past the impossibly colorful onion domes of St. Basil's Cathedral in Moscow. Their destination: the center of Red Square, near the podium where Communist Party bosses once stood and where thousands of tourists from around the world have gathered.

Jade Jagger, the 34-year-old daughter of Mick and Bianca and the creative director of the British jewelry house Garrard, has teamed up with the London-based interior designer Tom Bartlett and Yoo, a residential development company headed by John Hitchcox and the designer Philippe Starck, to adapt her bohemian-meets-rock-and-roll style to new apartments in Chelsea. The renovated building, called ''Jade,'' will be completed by the end of the year and will have 57 apartments with lacquered ''pods'' that contain the closets, bathrooms and kitchens. They come in four colors and are on display in the building's sales office, 16 West 19th Street (Fifth Avenue), (212) 727-1919, jadenyc.com. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

An article in Thursday Styles last week about golf clothing for women misstated the name of a river between New Hampshire and Maine in a reference to a quotation from E. B. White. It is the Piscataqua, not the Pisquata.

An article on Tuesday about a deal secured by Mayor Shirley Franklin of Atlanta to keep the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the city referred incorrectly to the entity set up to buy the papers. A nonprofit organization, the Community Foundation for Greater Atlanta, formed a company to purchase the collection; the city did not create a nonprofit organization.

The National Hockey League may be ready to take its sport outdoors, with Yankee Stadium among several stadiums being considered to play host to a hockey game during the 2006-7 season. Rick Cerrone, the Yankees' senior director of media relations, confirmed that the team had been approached by N.H.L. officials about the possibility of a game being held at the stadium. It is believed that the game, which was reported yesterday by Newsday, would match the Rangers and the Islanders in December or January. The 2006-7 N.H.L schedule will be released next month.

Tamil Tiger boats hiding among fishing vessels off the island's northwest coast attacked two navy craft, killing five sailors in a 45-minute battle, officials said. A navy spokesman said 12 rebels were killed and two of their boats destroyed in retaliatory airstrikes. A Tiger spokesman said just one rebel died. SHIMALI SENANAYAKE (NYT)
