Federal drug regulators issued a strong warning Thursday that Ketek, a controversial antibiotic, could in rare circumstances cause serious liver injury, liver failure and even death. ''We clearly now understand that there is risk of serious liver injury with Ketek,'' said Dr. John Jenkins, director of the Food and Drug Administration's Office of New Drugs.

An article in Business Day last Friday about the sale of the Lord & Taylor department store referred imprecisely to the location of a former rival, Stern's. It had locations on West 23rd Street and West 42nd Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues; Stern's was never on Fifth Avenue itself.

BERK--Irving A. The Community Preservation Corporation mourns , with deep sadness, the passing of Irving Berk. He was a pioneer in the field of trade schools as the founder of the Berk Trade and Business School. His work to create non-degree programs created employment opportunities for thousands of working people. In addition to being a pioneer in education, Irving was also a good and caring friend who will be sorely missed. Michael D. Lappin, President and CEO, The Community Preservation Corporation

The National Labor Relations Board ruled, 4 to 1, that airport screeners who work for a private company have the right to unionize, rejecting the argument that such workers should not be able to unionize because they work in national security. The Transportation Security Administration has barred federally employed screeners from unionizing. The employees in the case work for Firstline Transportation Security and inspect baggage at Kansas City International Airport. The board's majority wrote, ''For 60 years, in times of both war and peace, the board has asserted jurisdiction over employers and employees that have been involved in national security and defense.'' STEVEN GREENHOUSE (NYT)

The J. Paul Getty Trust paid $64,000 in legal fees last year for Barbara Fleischman, who was then a trustee, when she testified in a deposition on behalf of the former Getty curator Marion True. Ms. True, who has been accused by the Italian government of conspiring to deal in looted artifacts, went on trial in Rome in November. The Los Angeles Times reported the payment yesterday, saying that the Getty's board agreed to compensate Ms. Fleischman despite warnings from its lawyers in 2003 that covering such an expense could jeopardize the trust's nonprofit status. In a telephone interview yesterday Ms. Fleischman said she had not asked the board to pay her legal fees and that she ''was also never aware that there were any concerns or questions about any reimbursement.'' Ron Hartwig, a Getty spokesman, said yesterday that ''there was a lively debate, and the board did agree to pay those legal fees,'' and that the Getty reported the expenditure on its tax forms and alerted the California state attorney general's office of the board's decision to pay the legal fees. ''They were considered an expense in connection with Marion True's case,'' Mr. Hartwig said. Ms. Fleischman resigned from the Getty board in January after reports in The Los Angeles Times that she had made a personal loan to Ms. True. The attorney general opened an investigation into the Getty Trust's finances last summer to determine whether it had violated state laws governing its tax-exempt status. CAROL VOGEL

FED MEETS, AND STOCKS RISE The Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the 17th time in a row, but kicked off a celebration in the stock market by lowering its alarms about inflation. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.2 percent -- its biggest one-day gain in almost three years. The other major benchmarks also rose 2 percent or more. [Pages A1 and C1.] QUESTIONS ON APPLE OPTIONS Apple Computer said that it had uncovered irregularities related to stock options awarded from 1997 to 2001, raising questions about whether a large grant made to the chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, was properly disclosed. [C1.] SCRUSHY FOUND GUILTY After twice telling a judge they were deadlocked, a federal jury convicted Donald E. Siegelman, the former Alabama governor, and Richard M. Scrushy, left, the former head of the HealthSouth Corporation, on charges that they conspired in a bribery scheme seven years ago. Lawyers for both men said they would appeal, and both remained free on bond. A year ago, a Birmingham jury acquitted Mr. Scrushy on all charges that he participated in accounting fraud at HealthSouth. [A14.] ANTI-EMISSIONs EXPERIMENT An experiment by Royal Dutch Shell in the Netherlands to limit emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas blamed for climate change, illustrates a fundamental shift in the oil industry that offers glimmers of hope for the future. [C1.] U.S. AUTOMAKERS TRY NEW TACK Detroit auto companies, which have lagged behind their Japanese rivals in selling hybrid vehicles, are taking a new environmental direction, by focusing on flexible-fuel vehicles, which can run on gasoline and another type of fuel like ethanol. [C1.] HOUSE APPROVES OIL DRILLING The House voted to approve oil and gas exploration in coastal waters that have been protected from drilling for 25 years. [A19.] THE GRAYING OF CHINA By 2020 about a third of Shanghai's population, currently 13.6 million, will consist of people over the age of 59, remaking the city's social fabric and placing huge new strains on its economy and finances. Experts say the rapidly graying city is leading one of the greatest demographic changes in history, one with profound implications for all of China. [A1.] CERVICAL CANCER VACCINE A federal advisory panel voted unanimously to recommend that all girls and women ages 11 to 26 receive a new vaccine, made by Merck, that prevents most cases of cervical cancer. [A12.] SHIFT IN KPMG CASE Defendants in the government's mammoth tax-shelter case against 16 former employees of the accounting firm KPMG are quietly embracing separate defense strategies, a shift that could reshape the case. [C3.] BOEING TO TAKE QUARTERLY CHARGE Boeing said that it would take second-quarter charges of up to $1.15 billion as a result of a settlement of ethics investigations with the federal government and delays in surveillance aircraft program for Australia and Turkey. [C3.] WAL-MART STRIKE AVERTED Wal-Mart's British arm narrowly averted a costly strike after reaching an agreement with a union. [C3.] TURKEY, EMERGING AND VOLATILE Turkey has suffered a plunge in its bonds and equities, a sign of how a star of emerging markets can quickly become a pariah as billions head for the door. Market Place. [C1.] JAPAN BOND TRADING HALTS A computer error crippled trading in Japan's government bond market for more than two hours, just months after the Tokyo Stock Exchange suffered a run of similar flaws. [C8.] TENET SETTLEMENT Tenet Healthcare has reached a $900 million settlement with federal officials to end investigations into accusations of overbilling of Medicare. The settlement -- valued at about one-fourth of Tenet's market value -- will be paid over four years and ends all investigations by the Department of Justice and several United States attorneys, the company said. The company also plans to sell about a dozen hospitals to regain its financial footing. [C3.] OLD CHEVY ADS, RENEWED Chevrolet is reviving and updating a popular 1970's advertising campaign featuring the musical theme ''Baseball, hot dogs, apple pie and Chevrolet.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.] ONLINE A SECURE IPOD IPods do not have a security slot, so the Mobile Security Lock for iPod makes use of the docking connector to help secure them. A FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY JUDGE, Allan Gropper, said that Northwest Airlines could throw out its union contract with flight attendants if two more weeks of talks did not produce a deal. (AP) BAXTER INTERNATIONAL, the maker of blood-disease treatments, said federal regulators agreed to consider allowing the company to resume sales of medical pumps tied to two deaths. To the Editor: ''Doctors See Way to Cut Risks of Suffering in Lethal Injection'' (front page, June 23) points to the mounting evidence indicating that at least some prisoners have suffered horribly as they were put to death by lethal injection, awake and racked by pain but unable to move to let anybody know.
To the Editor: Re ''A Renewed Push for the Artistic A B C's'' (Arts pages, June 26):

An obituary on Sunday and in some copies on Saturday about the television producer Aaron Spelling misstated the given name of his brother. He is Daniel, not Randy. The obituary also gave an incorrect title in some copies for a play Mr. Spelling performed in while recovering from a wound sustained in World War II. It was ''O Mistress Mine,'' not ''Old Mistress Mind.'' It also gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of an actress in that play. She was Lynn Fontanne, not Fontaine.

Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about flooding in Binghamton, N.Y., misstated the relative position of Johnson City and Endicott, two neighboring cities that were also flooded. They are downriver, not upriver.

Relax, It's Only a Ghost Friedrich Petzel 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea Through July 14 For her fourth show in the United States since 1991, the well-connected German conceptualist Cosima von Bonin has crowded into the gallery an assortment of bulky two- and three-dimensional objects, most of which resemble contemporary designer products. The effect is puzzling at first, but then a familiar critique of consumerism and mass entertainment becomes glaringly clear.

Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court opinion in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld by Justice John Paul Stevens and a dissent by Justice Clarence Thomas. A full text is at nytimes.com/washington. From the Ruling At a minimum, the government must make a substantial showing that the crime for which it seeks to try a defendant by military commission is acknowledged to be an offense against the law of war. That burden is far from satisfied here. The crime of ''conspiracy'' has rarely if ever been tried as such in this country by any law-of-war military commission not exercising some other form of jurisdiction, and does not appear in either the Geneva Conventions or the Hague Conventions -- the major treaties on the law of war.

STERN--Enid Gardiner. Died on June 29 in her Manhattan residence, succumbing to lung cancer after a year of illness. A native New Yorker, she attended the High School of Music and Art and Hunter College. Upon graduation she became an illustrator for William Douglas McAdams, a pharmaceutical advertising firm. In 1947 she married Leo Stern, Jr., who had begun a career in dentistry, and had a daughter Elizabeth and twin sons Jay and Tony. Enid has been reelected president of her cooperative apartment building, for over 20 consecutive years, and she and her husband have been active members of Sunningdale Country Club for over 50 years. They were active in conservation causes, and in 1972 made a strategic purchase, joined by three partners, of a scenic tract of 330 acres in the upper Beaverkill Valley which they preserved from further development in perpetuity. Loving sister to Robert Gardiner and grandmother to Charles, Joseph, Marguerite, Daniel and Eli. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Sunday, July 16 at 6 P.M. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to The National Resources Defense Council. $(6$)STERN--Enid. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Enid Stern. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, Leo, and to the entire family. Patricia Sumergrade, Pres. Richard J. Bronstein, Sec'y

Rejecting a challenge by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., the State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the validity of a five-year, $33 million agreement that allows Snapple to sell beverages in city-owned buildings in exchange for cash and tourism promotion. Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye, writing for the court, said that once the mayor and corporation counsel certified that ''procedural requirements have been met and legal authority exists,'' the comptroller did not have the power to refuse to register a contract. But the court sided with Mr. Thompson's argument that marketing contracts like the Snapple deal must be submitted to the city's Franchise and Concession Review Committee. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

HANSEN--Stanley .... and the Lord cried out to his flock, ''I need a master framer, who can also cut a lot of mat openings.'' There was a great deal of murmuring ... then two voices were heard, ''Lord, get Stanley Hansen.'' The Lord said, ''who spoke?'' ''I am Sylvan Cole and this is Arthur Brown. Stanley worked for me at Associated American Artists.'' Arthur Brown said, ''Stanley was the best mat cutter Arthur Brown & Bro. ever had. He's been doing his job for sixty years.'' The Lord said, ''Stanley, I need you this week.'' Stanley said, ''Dot, I got to go, I have a big job and they need me.'' Peter A. Brown

Actress Sues Over 'Movin' Out' A dancer and actress who says she was harassed for having large breasts and a serious toe injury while performing in the touring version of the Tony Award-winning musical ''Movin' Out'' has filed a second lawsuit seeking more than $100 million, The Associated Press reported. Alice Alyse, 29, left, filed suit for more than $100 million against the owners and managers of the touring production in March. Now she is suing the Actors' Equity Association for an additional $100 million. In the new suit, filed this week, Ms. Alyse, whose mother is Nicaraguan, contends that the union failed to address her complaints of sexual harassment and sexual and ethnic discrimination, violated union grievance procedures and conspired with the show's owners and managers to damage her financially, emotionally and physically. Franklin Moss, outside counsel for the Actors' Equity Association, said the union had not been served with any papers. Public Knowledge: Kevin Kline in 'Lear' Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public, revealed at a fund-raising gala on Wednesday night that the mysterious Shakespeare play this fall to star Kevin Kline, below, with James Lapine directing, would be ''King Lear.'' The announcement was hardly a surprise; Mr. Lapine and Mr. Kline had held a widely reported ''secret'' workshop of ''Lear,'' and apparently it took. In other Public news Christopher Walken will show up in the second Shakespeare in the Park play this summer, Bertolt Brecht's ''Mother Courage and Her Children.'' Mr. Walken, who will play the Cook, joins an already name-heavy production: George C. Wolfe is directing, Tony Kushner has written a new translation, Jeanine Tesori has written original music and Meryl Streep plays the title role. ''Mother Courage'' begins previews on Aug. 8, and opens on Aug. 21. 'Encores!' to Salute Revues Honoring the 100th anniversary of the first ''Ziegfeld Follies,'' the 2007 season of ''Encores!'' at City Center will pay tribute to the Broadway revue with three shows, including its first original production. The season begins Feb. 8 to Feb. 11 with what is billed as the first full-scale New York presentation of Stephen Sondheim's score for ''Follies'' in more than two decades. From March 29 to April 1, ''Encores!'' will present a full-scale restoration of the 1932 Irving Berlin and Moss Hart musical, ''Face the Music,'' about a desperate New York producer trying to raise money for his latest revue. The season will end with ''Stairway to Paradise,'' May 10 to May 14, a specially created production that is to celebrate a half-century of Broadway revues with numbers and sketches from Ziegfeld shows, as well as from ''The Garrick Gaieties,'' ''The Band Wagon,'' ''As Thousands Cheer,'' ''This Is the Army,'' ''Call Me Mister,'' ''Pins and Needles'' and more. NBC Expands Investigative Unit NBC News has announced an increase in the number of news division producers working in its investigative reporting unit, Reuters reported. In the initial expansion, the number working with Lisa Myers, left, the senior investigative correspondent, will increase to 10 from 4. The unit contributes to ''NBC Nightly News,'' ''Dateline NBC'' and MSNBC and CNBC. ''It's a big commitment,'' said Steve Capus, the president of the news division. ''It's a commitment to the kind of news that I would like to see the news division doing.'' With the first reading of scripts for the final eight episodes of HBO's ''Sopranos'' scheduled for Thursday, four more cast members have signed new contracts or are close to signing, Reuters reported. They are Lorraine Bracco, who plays Tony Soprano's psychiatrist, Jennifer Melfi; Aida Turturro, who plays his sister Janice; and Robert Iler and Jamie-Lynn Sigler, who play his children. Still unsigned are Tony Sirico, Steven Van Zandt and Steven Schirripa. Dave Matthews Band Aids Environment The Dave Matthews Band (below, Mr. Matthews) is lining up on the side of the environment. The band paid $200,000 last year to settle a charge that one of its bus drivers had dumped human waste off a bridge over the Chicago River, is trying to ease global warming by taking part in a program to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and other pollution, Reuters reported. According to the energy company NativeEnergy, the band is buying so-called offsetting credits to eliminate pollution equivalent to 36 million average car miles, roughly what the band and its fans have produced in the last 15 years. NativeEnergy did not say how much the band would pay, but its online calculator put the figure at $216,000. Hootie and the Blowfish will do their part for education when they begin their 10-city Homegrown Concert tour in Nashville on Monday, The Associated Press reported. The band will be collecting school supplies. Ticketholders are encouraged to bring supplies to be donated to the school system in each community, and in each city a business or organization will make a donation to the schools. XM Satellite Radio announced that Willie Nelson would join its lineup to provide creative direction for its traditional music channel, ''Willie's Place,'' formerly known as ''Hank's Place.'' He will also contribute exclusive programming to it and other XM music channels.
To the Editor: Re ''Patriotism and the Press'' (editorial, June 28):

MSNBC announced last night that it would shift its prime-time programming away from talk shows after 10 p.m., going instead with two hours of what it was calling ''documentary programming'' at 10 and 11 p.m. The moves, which were signaled earlier this week in comments by the president of NBC News, Steve Capus, will displace two of the cable news channel's talk-show hosts.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the Irish actress Anna Manahan's return to New York in September in the solo show ''Sisters'' misstated the date of her last appearance in New York. It was 2002, when she was in ''The Matchmaker,'' not 1998, when she won a Tony Award for her performance in ''Beauty Queen of Leenane.''

DRETZIN--David (Duff) died, surrounded by his family, on Monday June 26 at St.Francis hospital, Poughkeepsie, NY as a result of injuries sustained in a car accident. Adored husband of Joanna, cherished father of Rachel and Julie, admired father-inlaw of Barak and Sam, and doting grandfather of Noah, Jesse, Ruby and Ben. With a gentle heart and a luminous intelligence, he fought tirelessly for justice in the law and righteousness in life. We will miss him with all our hearts. Donations in his name may be sent to the Equal Justice Initiative of Alabama, 122 Commerce Street, Montgomery, AL. 36104.

KAPLAN--B. David, a very kind, soft spoken gentleman who we loved is gone from this world but not from our hearts and minds. More than a brother-in-law, you introduced us to food and wine. You inspired our journeys in the world and in our lives. Forever grateful. Beatrice & Michael
To the Editor: Re ''Of All Streets in All the Cities in All the World,'' by Clyde Haberman (NYC column, June 23):

Re-Take of Amrita Sepia International 148 West 24th Street, 11th floor, Chelsea Through July 28 This haunted show by Vivan Sundaram, one of India's most distinguished contemporary artists, is basically an archival family album, a photographic souvenir of the distant past. Thanks to digital technology, however, the pictures are simultaneously old and new. They embody the past the way it survives in the mind: edited, layered, compressed, as if in a dream.

A White House Memo article yesterday about the close relationship between President Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan misspelled the name of a memorial to Japan's war dead that Mr. Koizumi has visited. It is the Yasukuni Shrine, not Yakusuni.

Well, at least one, though there's probably many more out there. Before today's England-Portugal match I asked if we'd hear the word "Falklands" uttered if the English lost a game refereed by an Argentine. I think this qualifies as a winner. On Fox Soccer Channel's "Ticket To Germany" tonight, the second English fan interviewed in Germany explained the outcome this way: "Argentinian ref. -- not that we want to go into politics and stuff, but we've been cheated.... We were never going to win that, we could still be playing now, taking penalties and that referee wouldn't have had it. Robbed, cheated, gutted. The Malvinas is ours and 1982 will be revisited tonight."

The only weak part of the season's new qualifying system is - as has often been pointed out - the first 12 minutes or so of the third and last 20-minute part when the final 10 cars go around in circles doing nothing at all but burn fuel.

Unable to break an impasse on a new budget, Gov. Jon S. Corzine today shut down the state's government for the first time in its history.

England and Portugal first met in the World Cup 40 years ago. Alastair Reid wrote about it a couple of months later in The New Yorker in his roundup of England '66. It's fascinating to read his account of the match, played when blanket TV coverage of sports, celebrity play-by-play commentators and instant replays (or action replays, as they were called in Britain) were all in their infancy, Bobby Charlton and Eusebio were in their prime, and good feeling reigned on the soccer field.
A Manhattan couple were found murdered yesterday, apparently bludgeoned to death in their downtown apartment, where the woman's daughter later discovered them, the police said.
The sale of the St. Louis Blues to a group led by Dave Checketts was completed yesterday, and the new owners immediately named the N.H.L. broadcaster John Davidson as the team president.

Darron Stiles made a 10-foot birdie putt on his final hole to shake free from a crowded pack atop the leader board in the second round of the PGA Tour's Buick Championship in Cromwell, Conn., yesterday.
If Orlando Hernández chose to stay in the clubhouse last night and prolong his deep-tissue massage, the Mets could have hardly blamed him.
Five Yankees pitchers held the Mets to one hit to get a victory in the 63-minute rain-delayed game.

Dontrelle Willis yielded two runs in seven innings, Miguel Cabrera drove in two runs and Hanley Ram√≠rez and Dan Uggla each scored twice to help the Marlins beat the Red Sox, 5-2, ending Boston's 12-game winning streak, which matched the third-longest in franchise history.
The Nets declined the option on power forward Cliff Robinson's contract, but Robinson was hoping to sign a new deal, according to his agent, Bradley Marshall.

Breaking records for self-financing of political campaigns, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent more than $85 million on his 2005 re-election bid, according to final disclosures filed yesterday with the City Campaign Finance Board. The filings show that Mr. Bloomberg spent $85,101,068, or $11,236,685 more than the $73,864,383 he spent on his first campaign, in 2001. The figures are up by almost $1 million from the $84,134,993 the campaign reported in January, with much of it going to settle final bills and fines for improper postering.

A group of people chased and beat the driver of a livery cab and his passenger in Brooklyn yesterday after the driver lost control of his car and swerved into an 8-year-old child on a bike, according to the police and several witnesses. The driver apparently lost control of the car, at 92nd Street and Clarkson Avenue in East Flatbush, at 5 p.m., because his passenger was trying to rob him, the police said. After hitting the child, the car crashed into a wall, and a group of dozens of bystanders confronted the driver and attacked him. When the man explained that his passenger had struck him in the head with a metal bar, the crowd then turned to his passenger, beat him, and tightened a belt around his neck, said one witness, Kevin Beckett, 44. The police arrived and arrested the passenger, Jean Willman, 31, of Newkirk Avenue in Flatbush. He was charged with robbery and assault. The child was taken to Brookdale Hospital Center, where he was in stable condition last night, the police said. The driver, 52, was taken to Kings County Hospital Center in stable condition.

The bodies of two fishermen were pulled from the ocean floor yesterday, the day after their fishing boat was struck by a towboat pulling a barge, officials said. The captain and one crew member on the fishing boat, which sank, were rescued by the crew of a passing boat, the Gambler.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has upheld a lower court's dismissal of a lawsuit brought by former parishioners of St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in the East Village who were trying to stop the Archdiocese of New York from demolishing it. The decision, released on Thursday, clears the way for the demolition. In 2001, Cardinal Edward M. Egan closed the church, which was almost 150 years old, because of structural problems. A group of former parishioners and residents has been fighting to save it. But the appellate division ruled that the justice who issued the decision to dismiss the parishioners' lawsuit had properly decided that it was within the archdiocese's authority to decide what to do with the property.

Police Chief Patrick J. Harnett announced yesterday that he would leave his job on July 13 to do part-time consulting work, possibly for Hartford. Chief Harnett, 63, who retired in 1998 as chief of the narcotics division of the New York City Police Department, was hired in 2004 to institute a community policing plan.

A Brooklyn teenager who was part of a group cavorting on water scooters near the Belt Parkway yesterday was missing and presumed drowned last night after his scooter and another collided, the authorities and witnesses said.
Scott Speed  will give the Americans a rooting interest Sunday when he competes in the United States Grand Prix.

The Ethan Allen, the tour boat that capsized on Lake George last year, killing 20 elderly passengers, was overloaded in part because regulators and operators had failed to consider that the average weight of a person had increased in the 39 years it was sailing, according to papers released yesterday.

A minister's wife charged with killing her husband told the police she shot him after they argued over family finances and then told him "I'm sorry" as he lay dying in their bedroom, according to testimony at a bond hearing. The woman, Mary Winkler, 32, has been jailed without bond since March 23, accused of killing her husband, Matthew Winkler, 31, at their Church of Christ parsonage in Selmer, a small town 80 miles east of Memphis. In court, a Tennessee Bureau of Investigation agent, Brian Booth, read a statement Ms. Winkler gave the authorities in Alabama, where she was arrested. Mr. Booth said that shortly before the killing, Ms. Winkler had shifted money between at least two banks in what he described as a "check kiting" scam.

The 12-year-old boy who died Thursday after riding a Walt Disney World roller coaster had a congenital heart defect, an autopsy found, and an inspection of the ride found no mechanical problems. The boy, Michael Russell, the son of an Iraq war veteran, stopped breathing while riding the Rock 'n' Roller Coaster at Disney-MGM Studios near Orlando. The cause of death was left pending until more tests are conducted, ruled Dr. Sara H. Irrgang, an Orange County associate medical examiner.

A helicopter being used to film scenes for a movie crashed in eastern Iowa, killing one person and critically injuring two others, the authorities said. The crash happened just before 1 p.m., said Jim Saunders, a spokesman for the Iowa Department of Public Safety. Families of six of the seven people swept to their deaths when a century-old earthen dam burst on the island of Kauai in March filed a wrongful death lawsuit Thursday against the property's owners. The suit alleges the area surrounding the reservoir was illegally graded by the landowner, James H. Pflueger, causing the dam failure that unleashed more than 300 million gallons of water that cut a 3-mile path of destruction to the sea. Lawyers for the victims' families said Mr. Pflueger repeatedly refused the state's request to inspect the property, a claim that Mr. Pflueger's lawyer denied. The Kaloko dam, on Kauai's north shore, broke in the early hours of March 14, unleashing a 20-foot-high wave of water that swept away seven people — including a 2-year-old boy — while they slept.

Commercial vessels began using a southwestern Louisiana shipping channel for the first time since a spill of 47,000 barrels of oil forced its closure last week and tapped the nation's oil reserve. The United States Coast Guard allowed a limited number of ships to use the Calcasieu Ship Channel after the wake from a barge carrying gasoline moved through the channel without disturbing cleanup efforts, said spokesman Petty Officer 2nd Class Adam Eggers. Vessels were expected to be allowed to use the channel to head inbound from the Gulf of Mexico toward Lake Charles today.

Paving the way for his son to replace him on the November ballot, the Cook County Board president, John Stroger, dropped his re-election bid and announced he would retire July 31, according to a five-page letter released by his office. Mr. Stroger, 77, has not been seen or heard from publicly since suffering a stroke one week before winning the March primary.

A former Creek County judge Donald D. Thompson was released on $75,000 bond following his conviction Thursday on four felony counts of indecent exposure while presiding over trials in 2002 and 2003. A jury deliberated for five-and-a-half hours Thursday before returning a guilty verdict. The jury recommended one year imprisonment and a $10,000 fine for each count. Special Judge C. Allen McCall set a sentencing hearing for Aug. 14 in Bristow. Mr. Thompson served as a judge for more than 23 years in Creek County. For a few evenings this coming week, people who look up at the right time should be able to glimpse a high-speed space chase: the shuttle Discovery pursuing and finally capturing the International Space Station.
The space shuttle Discovery and its seven astronauts are to roar into orbit on what NASA managers called "a rather pedestrian mission."

Japan, struggling to deal with a falling birth rate and an aging population, said people 65 or older accounted for 21 percent of the total population in 2005, the world's highest elderly ratio, surpassing Italy's 20 percent ratio. The ratio of people 15 or younger in the total population was the world's lowest, at 13.6 percent, surpassing Bulgaria's 13.8 percent, the report said.

The government quit amid infighting over a failed attempt to strip Ayaan Hirsi Ali, the prominent Somali-born critic of Islam, of her Dutch citizenship, setting the stage for elections likely to be dominated by immigration issues. Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende visited Queen Beatrix in the morning to tell her of his government's decision to resign. No date for elections was announced. A small party called D66 pushed Mr. Balkenende's coalition government into a minority when it withdrew on Thursday, saying it refused to work with the immigration minister, Rita Verdonk. Ms. Verdonk had refused to resign, despite being accused of damaging the country's reputation with a bungled attempt to revoke Ms. Hirsi Ali's passport.

A government report ordered by President Bush says that the United States should act fast to support a transitional government in Cuba when President Fidel Castro's rule ends and that it should get advisers on the ground within weeks. It also recommended a

Despite high hopes, none of the 27 women who ran in this week's parliamentary elections, the first in which women could vote and run as candidates, won enough votes to win a seat, according to official results. Analysts had expected one or two women to win. A mix of Islamists, liberals and independents, all favoring electoral reform, swept 36 seats in the 50-seat Parliament, promising to bring about reforms.

Parliament's lower house approved an overhaul of the complex federal system of government. The changes, which would be the broadest ever to the country's 1949 Constitution and which the upper house is expected to approve next week, would give Germany's 16 states more say in issues like schools and civil service. In exchange, the states' veto powers in Parliament would be curbed to speed decision-making. The number of laws that require the approval of the upper house would be cut to less than 40 percent, from about 60 percent now.

The International War Crimes Tribunal sentenced Naser Oric, the wartime commander of the Muslim force at Srebrenica, to two years imprisonment for failing to prevent the cruel treatment and killing of Serbian prisoners during Bosnia's 1992-95 civil war. He was immediately released because he had already spent three years in detention. HUGHES--Charles. Alexander. Of New York City, died quietly on June 21, 2006 after a long illness. We mourn the passing of our witty, cultivated and gentle brother and uncle, who devoted his life to the study of the world's languages. He worked for many years as a spontaneous translator and tour guide, and wrote language learning books which are still in use. Charles never failed to converse with people he met in their native tongue. His humor and equanimity, even in the face of physical adversity, inspired and delighted his family and friends. Born in Altoona, PA., in 1916, and educated first at Princeton University, Charles received undergraduate and graduate degrees from New York University and Columbia respectively. He is lovingly remembered by his surviving sister and brother, Helen Hafner, and William Hughes, of Gaithersburg, MD., by the family of his recently-deceased sister, Janet Stolz, of Chester Springs, PA., and as a loving grand uncle, great grand uncle, neighbor and friend. There will be a graveside service in Altoona at a later date.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8 G.I.'s Investigated In Iraq Rape and Murders The American military is investigating accusations that soldiers raped an Iraqi woman and killed her and three family members, including a child, American officials said. The investigation is the fourth probe of suspected killings of unarmed Iraqis by American troops announced by the military in June. A1 After months of relative calm in Umm Qasr, Iraq's largest and most important Persian Gulf port, the city has become a mix of danger, corruption, modest commercial bustle and a fair amount of intrigue. A6 Congo Faces Challenge in Vote Congo's biggest challenges as it prepares for its first real national elections since 1965 will be getting its competing groups to recognize and respect the results, and managing the outsized expectations of a population exhausted by the world's deadliest conflict since World War II. A1 Pullback Demanded by Hamas Prime Minister Ismail Haniya of the Palestinian Authority said Israel's military operations in the Gaza Strip were part of a larger effort to oust the Hamas government, and he demanded that Israel pull back if it wanted the release of its captured soldier. A8 Vatican Warns Researchers Scientists who engage in stem cell research using human embryos should be subject to excommunication from the Roman Catholic Church, according to Cardinal Alfonso L√≥pez Trujillo, who heads the group that proposes family-related policy for the Vatican. A3 Ex-Leader of Mexico Is Arrested Just two days before a national election, a judge has ordered the arrest of former President Luis Echeverr√≠a on genocide charges in connection with his role during the massacre of student protesters in 1968, overturning a lower court ruling. A3 NATIONAL A9-13 Miami Terror Suspects Shown on Secret Video The seven men who were arrested in Miami on terror charges were shown on undercover videotapes solemnly reciting oaths of loyalty to Al Qaeda, repeating the words that an F.B.I. informant had given them to say. A1 Fire Fears at Hippie Gathering As many as 8,000 campers arrived in Routt National Forest in Colorado for the Rainbow Family gathering, a pilgrimage of the fringe, the flower-empowered and the spiritually engaged. The forest around the camp is tinder-dry and more stressed by disease than at any time in at least 120 years, fire experts say. A9 Senator Doubts Tribunal Plan John W. Warner, a leading Senate Republican, said he was not sure that Congress should pass legislation to create new military tribunals for terror suspects, a stance that raised doubts about prospects for a White House plan to establish an alternative to the commissions struck down this week by the Supreme Court. A10 Federal courts will soon have to grapple with the reach of the Supreme Court's ruling this week on terror suspects, including whether detainees at Guant√°namo Bay and elsewhere may move to assert their rights under the Geneva Conventions, several human rights officials and academics said. A10 Murder Confession Thrown Out The confession of a Florida man charged in the kidnapping, rape and killing of 9-year-old Jessica Lunsford will not be allowed as evidence in his trial because he was denied his right to a lawyer, a judge ruled. A13 SCIENCE/HEALTH Discovery Approved for Liftoff The space shuttle Discovery and its seven astronauts are to roar into orbit on what NASA managers call ''a rather pedestrian mission'' that nevertheless has a great deal riding on it. A12 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Judge Voids Convictions In 'Mafia Cops' Case A federal judge tossed out the convictions of two retired New York City detectives on racketeering charges -- including eight murders for the mob -- because the statute of limitations had run out, even though, he said, there was overwhelming evidence the men had committed ''heinous and violent crimes.'' A1 Kerik Admits Misdemeanors Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor crimes: failing to report a loan and accepting renovations to his apartment worth $165,000. B1 Towns Weigh Flood Damage Riverside communities in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania began to tally the losses from this week's powerful flooding. The governors of the three states asked President Bush for disaster declarations to make their states eligible for federal assistance. B1 Religion Journal B5 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-7 Doping Scandal Snares Stars A doping scandal that may be the most widespread in cycling's history brought havoc to the Tour de France, with several of the top contenders implicated and removed from the field on the eve of the prestigious race. Now the race will go off without the four riders who finished just behind Armstrong last year, including the favorites for this year's race -- Jan Ullrich of Germany, above left, and Ivan Basso of Italy, above right. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Shareholder Presses G.M. General Motors' largest shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian, is pressing the troubled American auto giant to speed up its turnaround effort by forming an alliance with two foreign car companies, Nissan and Renault, which would pay $3 billion for a 20 percent stake in G.M. A1 Although a partnership between General Motors, Nissan and Renault notes the potential for synergy and cost savings, some analysts speculate that the major motivation is to get Carlos Ghosn of Nissan, who is an experienced turnaround artist, to be linked with G.M. An article on Thursday about the decline in Maine's economy referred incorrectly to the fate of one employer, Brunswick Naval Air Station. It was chosen for closure; it was not just briefly on a list of bases to be closed.

Because of an editing error, a Reporter's Notebook article on Sunday about President Bush's visit to Budapest gave an incorrect description of Gellert Hill, where Mr. Bush spoke. It is one of the higher points in the city, not the highest. (Janos Mountain holds that distinction.)

An article on June 20 about a lawsuit by Muslim and Arab-Americans who were erroneously detained at United States border crossings misstated the year of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. It was 1979, not 1978.

GITTELSON--Stanley, M.D. Peacefully on June 29, 2006. Beloved husband to Joan (nee Derris) for 52 years. Loving father to Harry, Glenn and Lori, Anne, Madeline and Gary. Adored grandpa to Joseph, Zachary, Conner, Caroline, Morgan, Paige and Heather. Devoted brother to Dr. Arthur and Genie, the late Dr. Roger and Fern and Dr. David Derris. Loving uncle, great-uncle, cousin and loyal friend to many. Dedicated pediatrician who for 40 years cared for the children of the Merrick-Bellmore communities. Accomplished physician, scientist, patented inventor, musician and golfer with a sense of humor to match. An inspiration to all who knew him, he will be missed and never forgotten. Services Sunday, 10 A.M. at Gutterman's Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

To the Editor: Re ''Justices, 5-3, Broadly Reject Bush Plan to Try Detainees'' (front page, June 30): The Supreme Court decision on Thursday on the Guant√°namo detainees was a victory for Americans who accept the inherent risks of living in a democracy.

A former Goldman Sachs analyst accused of running a $6.7 million insider trading ring involving individuals ranging from a retired Croatian seamstress to an exotic dancer was released on bond yesterday after spending three months in jail. The former analyst, Eugene Plotkin, 27, was arrested on April 11 and pleaded not guilty in the case. Family and friends of Mr. Plotkin provided bail, which was secured by $2 million in real estate. Mr. Plotkin will be under house detention and must wear an electronic ankle bracelet to monitor his movements. A trial date has not been set. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED (NYT)

To the Editor: ''A Loss for Competitive Elections'' (editorial, June 29) points out that the Supreme Court has never set out a test to determine whether an electoral map based on partisan gerrymandering violates the equal protection clause. The court's hesitation to do so is largely a reflection of the historical difficulty in defining electoral fairness.

If Orlando Hern√°ndez chose to stay in the clubhouse last night and prolong his deep-tissue massage, the Mets could have hardly blamed him. They were being no-hit through four innings. They were stiff from a rain delay of 1 hour 3 minutes. And the Yankees' starting pitcher, Mike Mussina, was pulling out of the game.

An article by The Associated Press and a headline in some copies on June 22 about a decades-old underground oil spill in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the status of New York State's negotiations with Exxon Mobil over cleanup of the spill. Although the attorney general's office is considering whether to file a lawsuit, it has not yet decided to do so.

To the Editor: ''Iraq War Ends Silently for One American Soldier'' (front page, June 29) and the accompanying photograph, though veiled in darkness, have shown me the true result of war -- a body bag, the salutes of fellow soldiers, the taking away of a dead human from a war zone.

Gazprom's shareholders re-elected the 11-member board without changes, thwarting the ambitions of hedge funds representing foreign investors to win seats on the board of Gazprom, the world's largest publicly traded emerging market company. Foreign investors had hoped for a larger role in managing Gazprom after trading in the state-owned company's shares was liberalized this year. ANDREW KRAMER (NYT)

DRETZIN--David.The law yers and staff of Kauff McClain & McGuire LLP join his wife Joanna and daughters Rachel and Julie and their families in mourning the untimely death of David (Duff) Dretzin, our former partner, constant friend and dedicated mentor who died on June 26 from injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Duff founded Dretzin & Kauff, our firm's predecessor, with Jerry Kauff in 1972 and helped nurture and build the firm until his retirement in 1988. He remained active after his retirement, representing indigent defendants in death row cases and performing other pro bono work. Duff was a charming, intelligent, righteous and elegant man. He will be sorely missed.

A picture credit on Tuesday with an article about a hearing on New York City's trash-handling plans misspelled the photographer's given name in some copies. He is Cary Conover for The New York Times, not Gary.

RICHARDS--Lloyd. The Board of Directors of The American Theatre Wing mourns the passing of our longtime board member, a ground-breaking, award-winning director, influential educator, and powerful champion of new voices in theatre. He will be missed.
A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about ''The House in Town,'' at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, misstated the closing date. It is July 30, not tomorrow.
''I knew he loved Elvis. I didn't realize how much he loved Elvis.'' PRESIDENT BUSH, on Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan. [A9]

Early Release for Lil' Kim The rapper Lil' Kim will celebrate Independence Day early this year. Sentenced in September to a year and a day in prison for lying about a shootout outside a hip-hop radio station in New York, she is being released on Monday, The Associated Press reported. ''I am thrilled to be coming home,'' Lil' Kim, left, said in a statement issued late Thursday. ''I thank all my fans for all their letters, as well as my family and friends for all their support throughout the past 10 months.'' Lil' Kim, whose real name is Kimberly Jones, was convicted of lying to a federal grand jury and in the subsequent trial. She began serving her time at a federal detention center in Philadelphia on Sept. 19. Her lawyer, L. Londell McMillan, noted then that she could be released early for good behavior. She is to remain under house arrest for 30 days after her release. Theater Notes ''Jay Johnson: The Two and Only!,'' the ventriloquist show that played Off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater Company two years ago, is coming to Broadway. The show will open at the Helen Hayes Theater on West 44th Street on Sept. 28; it was to have opened there this spring, but was postponed because of the success of Sarah Jones's ''Bridge & Tunnel,'' which closes on Aug. 6. ''The Two and Only!'' will have a pre-Broadway run at the American Repertory Theater in Boston from July 12 to Aug. 6. The Roundabout Theater Company has announced the casting for its revival of George Bernard Shaw's ''Heartbreak House,'' which opens at the American Airlines Theater on Broadway on Oct. 11. Joining Philip Bosco will be Swoosie Kurtz, above, Byron Jennings, Lily Rabe and Laila Robins. Theater Communications Group, a New York-based national service organization for nonprofit theaters, named Gigi Bolt its interim executive director yesterday. Ms. Bolt, who has served as the director of theater and musical theater for the National Endowment for the Arts, will run the organization until it finds a replacement for its longtime executive director, Ben Cameron, who left in March for a position at the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. Met Museum Concerts The 2006-7 season of 75 concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York will begin on Sept. 18, when the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra plays Vivaldi and Bach in the Great Hall. Among the highlights of the season are a piano series featuring Andras Schiff, right, Ivo Pogorelich and Ivan Moravec; two concerts starring the early-music pioneer and viola da gamba master Jordi Savall; performances of Bach's Mass in B minor and Handel's ''Acis and Galatea''; and appearances by Steve Ross, Anoushka Shankar, Richie Havens and Patti Smith. Information: metmuseum.org. Big Black Returns Big Black, the influential post-punk group from Chicago that began the career of Steve Albini (producer of albums by the Pixies and Nirvana, among many others), will reunite briefly in September. The band, which also featured the bassist Jeff Pezzati and the guitarist Santiago Durango, broke up in 1987, but is to perform ''a couple songs'' as part of a series of concerts in Chicago celebrating the 25th anniversary of its record label, Touch & Go, the company announced. The concerts, scheduled for Sept. 8 to 10, are to feature Girls Against Boys, the Ex, Killdozer, Man or Astroman?, Pegboy, Quasi and others. Gnarls Barkley, the oddball hip-hop duo of Danger Mouse and Cee-Lo Green, will play a benefit concert at Central Park SummerStage on Aug. 17 as part of its summer tour, the group's label, Atlantic Records, announced. Pop Notes Jeff Buckley, below, the acclaimed singer-songwriter who died in 1997 at 30, will be the subject of a new movie, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The film will be written and directed by Brian Jun, whose ''Steel City'' was a hit at Sundance this year, and produced by Mr. Buckley's mother, Mary Guibert, along with Michelle Sy (''Finding Neverland''). The online music store eMusic, which specializes in independent labels, put 19 previously unreleased tracks from the legendary Sun Records catalog on sale yesterday as part of a collection of 400 songs from the label newly offered for download. The new tracks, by Charlie Rich, Rosco Gordon and Bill Justis, are available only through eMusic, the company said.

Unable to break a bitter impasse with the New Jersey Legislature on a new budget, Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed an executive order today that shut down the states government for the first time in its history. The order began a process that over the next few days will see the state close its parks, beaches and, depending on the outcome of a court decision, possibly the 12 Atlantic City casinos.

(Hallmark) DESOLATION CANYON -- Patrick Duffy and Stacy Keach (near right,with Mr. Duffy) polished up their flintiest gazes to play Sheriff Tomas Lundstromand Samuel Kendrick, a couple of aging gunmen in pursuit of a band of violent outlaws who have kidnapped a young boy. Catch No. 1: one ofthe outlaws is Kendrick's son. Catch No. 2: the kidnapped boy is Kendrick's grandson, and it's his father who is holding him hostage. 7 P.M. Richard Sharpe, the British rifleman played by Sean Bean, takes a break from fighting Napoleon to help an Irishwoman find her father, a prospector lost in the mountains. 8 P.M. (Sundance) BRIGHT YOUNG THINGS -- (2003). In Stephen Fry's adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's ''Vile Bodies,'' the setting is bubbly 1930's London, where an impoverished novelist (Stephen Campbell Moore) starts writing a gossip column to make money to marry his wealthy fianc√©e. Emily Mortimer, who played the conveniently rich -- and oblivious -- wife of Jonathan Rhys Meyers's scheming social climber in Woody Allen's ''Match Point'' last year, stars as the object of his desire. 9 P.M. (CMT) GREATEST SOUTHERN ROCK SONGS -- Let's start with the letter A, as in Alabama. Just in time to ride the wave of momentum from ''Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest,'' this campy horror flick about a group of friends who unwittingly release a demonic pirate (Rhett Giles) from a treasure chest. 9 P.M. (VH1) STORYTELLERS -- Like voices from a distant past, the men of Pearl Jam -- Eddie Vedder (right), Stone Gossard, Mike McCready, Jeff Ament and Matt Cameron -- perform songs from their long-awaited album and talk about the stories that inspired them. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

Ben Wallace became a rebounder-for-hire at 12:01 this morning, and if the event failed to jolt the N.B.A. landscape, then it was only appropriate. Who better than Wallace -- an undrafted, unflashy and not-long-ago-unknown scrapper -- to serve as the face of a generally nondescript free-agent class? There are no franchise players on the market, and aside from Wallace, the Detroit Pistons' 6-foot-9 center, there are no certified All-Stars either. Shoppers will pick through a mildly intriguing cast of B-listers.

SAXE--Rose Chayt, 99, school teacher and librarian, June 27. Loving wife of Harold. Beloved mother of Jon and Linda. Devoted grandmother of Karen, Aleta, Greg, Chris, Stacy, Tom, Aaron, Julia and five great-grandchildren. Services were held Thursday at Mt. Ararat Cemetery.

A caption in The Arts on June 3 about former Tony Award winners who gathered at the Shubert Theater misidentified the woman at the far right of the front row. She was Sheila Bond, not Trazana Beverly.

CBS and Fox were the only two networks in the ratings game on Thursday night, since it was a race to the bottom between NBC and ABC, with UPN and WB barely visible. CBS placed first among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. It led off with the anemic ''Gameshow Marathon'' finals, during which Kathy Najimy won money for charity before an audience of 7.1 million in Nielsen's estimates. CBS's night picked up from there, with repeats of ''CSI'' (10.4 million) and ''Without a Trace'' (10.7 million) pulling up the overall ratings. Fox got a boost from the results show of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (8 million), which drew the night's highest 18-to-49 ratings: the network finished a close second to CBS in that demographic. NBC and ABC's original offerings both tanked. At 8 p.m. ABC's ''Master of Champions'' brought in 4.9 million viewers, and at 10 p.m. NBC's ''Windfall'' attracted 4.8 million. KATE AURTHUR
FRIEDMAN--Fred Dearest Fred, we celebrate your birthday today with the gifts of 2 grandchildren, Nomi and Will. All our love. Linda, Erik, Isabella, Adam and Sara

Youri Djorkaeff, a midfielder for the New York Red Bulls of Major League Soccer, has left the team to return to France to attend to unspecified family issues. Djorkaeff, 38, has started all 13 of the team's games this season and has two goals and three assists for the Red Bulls (2-3-8).

HEILIGMAN--Dr. Sol J. We are profoundly saddened by the passing of our long time resident and friend, Sol. He and his beloved late wife Shirley were staunch supporters of our community for over 30 years. He will be greatly missed. Sedgewood Club Associates China Barrett Association HEILIGMAN--Dr. Sol J. After a life-long friendship of 72 years, I bid a sad farewell to my dear friend, Sol. It was a great ride, but it ended too soon. Fare thee well, Sol. Gene Grant HEILIGMAN--Dr. Sol J. Age 90, on June 24, 2006, at his country home on China Lake, Carmel, NY. Beloved husband of the late Shirley Sperans Heiligman, devoted stepfather of Andrew (Nan), and Tom (Randy), loving uncle of Janet Heiligman, and brother-in-law of Phyllis (Parker). He was born in Fort Wayne, IN. At an early age, his widowed mother brought him and his four siblings to New York. He graduated from CCNY (B.S.) in 1937, and the University of Michigan (Doctor of Dental Surgery) in 1941. In WWII, he served with distinction as a Captain in a Combat Artillery Regiment in Europe. After the war, he volunteered as a Dental Surgeon on the ship ''Project Hope'' in Nicaragua for several seasons. He then embarked on a long and distinguished career in Dental Medicine in New York City, specializing in Periodontia. In recent years, he was a respected volunteer in the Ichthyology Dept. of the American Museum of Natural History. An avid sportsman, he loved tennis, skiing, horseback riding, canoeing and wilderness camping. A bachelor until he was 52, he was married to Shirley Sperans Karsch for 35 years, until her untimely passing in 2003. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue/81st Street, at 4pm, on Thursday, June 29. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Marymount College, East 71st Street, NY, NY in loving memory of Dr. Sol and Shirley Heiligman.

To the Editor: Re '' 'Breathtaking' Waste and Fraud in Hurricane Aid'' (front page, June 27): Up to $2 billion? That doesn't approach the sums we're spending on Iraq. At least the money wasted on Katrina relief went to our own people instead of that bottomless Mideast pit that will never stop draining us of our precious resources. Donella L. Scott Green Valley, Ariz., June 28, 2006
JERABEK--Charles A. Honorary Member, accomplished actor and good friend, he will be missed. The Amateur Comedy Club

Despite high hopes, none of the 27 women who ran in this week's parliamentary elections, the first in which women could vote and run as candidates, won enough votes to win a seat, according to official results. Analysts had expected one or two women to win. A mix of Islamists, liberals and independents, all favoring electoral reform, swept 36 seats in the 50-seat Parliament, promising to bring about reforms. HASSAN M. FATTAH (NYT)

An events entry in the Spare Times for Children listings of Weekend yesterday, about the Top of the Rock Fun Festival on the observation deck at Rockefeller Center, has become outdated. Rockefeller Center said yesterday that the festival would take place on Monday and Tuesday only, from noon to 4 p.m.; it will not begin tomorrow.

A powerful suicide truck bomb ripped through a bustling street market in a Shiite slum here on Saturday, killing at least 62 people and injuring nearly 120 in the deadliest insurgent assault since the new Shiite-led government was installed in May, police officials and witnesses said. The blast took place as a Sunni Arab member of the new Parliament and 8 of her bodyguards were abducted by militiamen while driving into Baghdad, police officials said. Together, the bomb attack and kidnapping pose the greatest challenge yet to the fledgling Iraqi government, which has deployed tens of thousands of Iraqi policemen and troops into the streets of Baghdad in recent weeks to try and secure the besieged capital.

An obituary on Thursday about Herman Merinoff, a liquor wholesaler, incorrectly rendered part of the name of a law firm he worked for in the 1950's. It was then Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside, Wolff & Brophy -- not Wolfe.

An article on Wednesday about President Bush's call for a line-item veto misstated the position on the Senate Appropriations Committee held by Senator Judd Gregg, who is proposing a more restrictive version of the veto. Mr. Gregg, a New Hampshire Republican, is a committee member, not its chairman.

The International War Crimes Tribunal sentenced Naser Oric, the wartime commander of the Muslim force at Srebrenica, to two years imprisonment for failing to prevent the cruel treatment and killing of Serbian prisoners during Bosnia's 1992-95 civil war. He was immediately released because he had already spent three years in detention. Prosecutors had asked for an 18-year sentence, for the looting and burning of Serb villages by the poorly trained volunteer force under his command. But the judges said the ''abysmal conditions'' of the town -- surrounded by Serbian troops and overwhelmed with refugees, many of them starving -- had led to a such breakdown of law and order that Mr. Oric, just 25 when he was appointed commander, could not be held accountable for crimes by his irregular defense force. He left the area two months before the infamous Serbian execution of some 8,000 unarmed men and boys in 1995. MARLISE SIMONS (NYT)

MERINOFF--Herman I. Dear Herman, you were the light that brightened so many lives, especially ours. Sharing important times with you and Sue made them extra special for us. We will miss the glow of your smile, the warmth of your heart, the generosity of your spirit and cherish your memory every day of our lives. Our sincerest sympathy to Sue, the kids, Ruthie and all of their families. Ashley, Becky and Bruce Levine MERINOFF--Herman. You have touched and enriched the lives of each of us, beyond description, teaching by example that integrity, morality and true partnerships arethe cornerstones of all success. A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about an effort by Kathleen Troia McFarland, a Republican candidate for United States Senate, to create her own political line misidentified the ballot on which it would appear. It is the Nov. 7 general election ballot, not the Sept. 12 primary ballot.

Parliament's lower house approved an overhaul of the complex federal system of government. The changes, which would be the broadest ever to the country's 1949 Constitution and which the upper house is expected to approve next week, would give Germany's 16 states more say in issues like schools and civil service. In exchange, the states' veto powers in Parliament would be curbed to speed decision-making. The number of laws that require the approval of the upper house would be cut to less than 40 percent, from about 60 percent now. VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

The most anticipated match of the World Cup recovered from a tedious start to provide a dramatic finish on Friday as Germany defeated Argentina, 4-2, on penalty kicks. Hardly anyone finds a shootout to be a satisfying conclusion, but the tautness served to rescue a quarterfinal that was often uninspiring and fractious. The match had remained tied at 1-1 through 30 minutes of overtime, as neither squad truly measured up to the importance of a confrontation between two World Cup favorites. Afterward, a 90-second scuffle broke out between the teams, bringing a sour end to the afternoon on the field. But outside, hundreds of thousands of German supporters poured into the streets of the capital to celebrate a victory that moved the home team into a semifinal match Tuesday against Italy.

The $52.9 billion budget approved by the New York City Council at 12:40 a.m. yesterday includes a vast pot of money for cultural institutions. The budget documents for the fiscal year that starts today, released Thursday night, suggest that cultural organizations have made out well in this budget cycle, partly because the city enjoyed a huge surplus. The Council restored $14.2 million in operating aid for 34 leading institutions, compared with $11.4 million a year earlier. In an annual ritual, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had cut that money in the full expectation that lawmakers would bring it back. The Council also added $1.9 million to the budget of the Department of Cultural Affairs for its Cultural Development Fund, which awards grants to small arts organizations. Last year the Council gave $2 million to the American Museum of Natural History, the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Lincoln Center for security upgrades; this year it gave $4 million to 21 groups for security projects, including $1.3 million for the Museum of Natural History and $500,000 for the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In addition, at least 263 groups received individual appropriations, up from at least 228 last year. Among the groups that appear to have fared particularly well in the new budget are the Brooklyn Arts Council, the Intrepid Museum Foundation, the Brooklyn Philharmonic (above), the Bronx Council on the Arts and American Ballet Theater. The Council also approved $800,000 to be used for programs at ''various community theaters'' throughout the city. SEWELL CHAN

President Bush on Friday nominated Frederic S. Mishkin, a professor of monetary policy at Columbia, to fill an open seat on the Federal Reserve Board. Professor Mishkin, 55, has been a prolific author of books and articles about central banking and would add weight within the Fed to backers of ''inflation targeting,'' a policy of basing decisions on explicit and publicly disclosed benchmarks for inflation.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has upheld a lower court's dismissal of a lawsuit brought by former parishioners of St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in the East Village who were trying to stop the Archdiocese of New York from demolishing it. The decision, released on Thursday, clears the way for the demolition. In 2001, Cardinal Edward M. Egan closed the church, which was almost 150 years old, because of structural problems. A group of former parishioners and residents has been fighting to save it. But the appellate division ruled that the justice who issued the decision to dismiss the parishioners' lawsuit had properly decided that it was within the archdiocese's authority to decide what to do with the property. MICHAEL LUO (NYT)

The champion Carolina Hurricanes signed center Eric Staal to a three-year, $13.5 million contract. The deal was announced within an hour of Staal's becoming a restricted free agent. Staal, 21, earned $942,400 last season, when he led the team in scoring with 100 regular-season points and led all players in the postseason with 28 points.

Carmelo Anthony agreed to a maximum contract extension with the Denver Nuggets, working out a five-year deal worth approximately $80 million. The 21-year-old Anthony, the third pick in the 2002 draft, averaged 26.5 points last season. The extension will kick in for the 2007-8 season and run through 2012.

The Boston Bruins yesterday signed the 6-foot-9 defenseman Zdeno Chara and center Marc Savard. Chara, 29, received a five-year deal worth $37.5 million. Savard, 28, left Atlanta to sign a four-year deal. Chara, the N.H.L.'s tallest player, had a career-best 43 points last season for Ottawa. Savard had career-highs of 28 goals and 69 assists.

Edmonton re-signed goaltender Dwayne Roloson to a three-year, $11 million deal and forward Fernando Pisani to a four-year contract worth $10 million. Roloson carried the Oilers through the first three rounds of the playoffs before hurting his knee in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals. Pisani, an Edmonton native, scored 37 points in the regular season and 14 goals in the playoffs.

The Cleveland Cavaliers offered LeBron James a five-year maximum contract extension worth about $80 million, a deal that could keep him in Cleveland through the 2012-13 season. The Cavaliers have exclusive negotiating rights with James this summer. If he chooses not to sign this summer, he can become a restricted free agent after the 2006-7 season.

The public has good reason to be wary of the motives of Steve Parrish and the tobacco industry (Joe Nocera, June 18). Even as tobacco companies claim to be fighting the battle against youth smoking, their methods ooze with reverse psychology. By warning adolescents not to smoke until they are older, cigarette corporations are in effect telling young people that smoking is an exclusively adult activity, off limits to children. I'm sure that message isn't intended to tempt teenagers, already craving to assert their independence, into lighting up.

To the Editor: Re ''Endless Meetings: The Black Holes of the Workday'' (The Count, June 18):

Yankees pitcher Mike Mussina was to throw in the bullpen today to test his right groin, which he hurt in the first inning Friday. Mussina remained hopeful of making his scheduled start Wednesday and of pitching in the All-Star Game, if selected. ''I want to get back out there and pitch when it's my turn to pitch, but we have to wait and see how it goes,'' said Mussina, who is 9-3 with a 3.17 earned run average. ''This is nowhere near my worst groin injury.''

I'M neither domestic nor handy. When it comes to dinner, I'm great at making reservations. When the house needs work, I call a contractor. It turns out that a good meal is easier to come by than an honest, reliable, affordable and skilled craftsman. Take the case of my front steps.

THE buds broke on the vines six weeks ago at the 85-acre Castello di Borghese Vineyard and Winery in Cutchogue, on the North Fork of Long Island, and the delicate clusters now forming may be the last crop that the owners, Marco and Ann Marie Borghese, cultivate here. The Borgheses' vineyard is the descendant of Hargrave Vineyard, the region's pioneering winery, established in 1973. The property is now on the market again, along with its wine tasting room, art gallery and a 3,200-square-foot expanded country house with an in-ground swimming pool. The asking price is $9.2 million.

Just days before Cory Booker was to be sworn in as Newark's new mayor, he announced that a former publishing executive and a former city chief code enforcement officer would be among the high-ranking members of his administration. Bo Kemp, co-founder and former executive vice president of the publishing company Vanguarde Media, was named the city's business administrator. Pablo Foneseca, the former chief code enforcement officer for Newark and a marketing director for Mr. Booker's law firm, was appointed his chief of staff.

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Libby P. Levin and Andrew Marcus Finn referred incorrectly to the job of the bride's mother, Adina Levin, at the Hillel Day School of Metropolitan Detroit in Farmington Hills, Mich. She teaches first grade, not third.

IN May, the United States Senate passed the immigration reform bill with a last-minute rider requiring the National Park Service to reopen the Statue of Liberty's crown to visitors. On the surface, that sounds like a good idea. Why not allow tourists fuller access to perhaps the most recognized symbol of the United States? After all, the crown was open to the public for more than 100 years before being closed in reaction to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. But reopening the crown is not a good idea for a variety of reasons. And even talk of amendments proposing as much as $2 million to pay for its reopening simply doesn't make sense.

The Episcopal Diocese of Newark announced last week that it had nominated a gay priest as one of four men to be considered to replace Bishop John P. Croneberger, who is retiring. The move has created controversy within the Episcopal Church in the United States and a possible schism with the global Anglican Communion over the ordination of gay bishops and the blessings of same-sex unions. By naming a gay priest as one of the nominees to be its next leader, the Newark Diocese is testing the church's recent call to avoid backing the election of gay bishops.

A PAIR of ducks sat on the muddy shore of the Neck River in Madison last Tuesday, oblivious to the environmental destruction taking place just under their feet. Vegetation in the salty marshes near Long Island Sound is dying off, putting plants and animals at risk and causing the shore to erode. Scientists call it sudden wetland dieback, but they are not sure how it started and what they can do to end it.

To the Editor: ''When Saving Lives Is More Than Child's Play'' (June 25) is very impressive. As a strong advocate of the idea ''young face, good hands,'' I can appreciate the abilities of these teenage volunteer emergency workers. But I have to question the maturity of the adults who would allow a 16-year-old to be exposed to some of the extraordinarily grisly scenes that these students encounter -- drivers with missing body parts, murdered children.

To the Editor: In her review of Julia Glass's novel ''The Whole World Over'' (June 11), Lorraine Adams mentions the character Saga, who ''is afflicted with . . . a strange gift for visualizing words.'' Adams provides a few examples, like ''Godfather: Red as a ruby, bottomless vibrant purplish red, a big word, impressive but airy, the silk dragon in a Chinese parade.'' Glass has given Saga the relatively rare condition known as synesthesia, a kind of crossing of the senses that is now widely understood to have a neurological basis. As an experimental psychologist at Yale who began studying synesthesia more than 30 years ago, I was struck that Saga lives in Connecticut with her uncle, a professor at Yale. While fictional characters displaying one variety of synesthesia or another crop up sporadically -- a striking example is Jean des Esseintes, the antihero of J. K. Huysmans's ''Against the Grain,'' who hears a musical instrument in each sip of a different liqueur -- so too occasionally do writers themselves. In his autobiography, ''Speak, Memory,'' Vladimir Nabokov famously described his own synesthesia, in which various letters of the alphabet have distinctive colors. Lawrence E. Marks New Haven

At first, Michael Healey's touching play ''The Drawer Boy,'' the Westport Country Playhouse's current production, seems like nothing more than a good-natured comedy about a gullible city boy being played for a fool, in a sweet way, by his country host. To do research for a new play, Miles (Carson Elrod), a fresh-faced young actor from Toronto, moves in with two middle-aged bachelor farmers in central Ontario and asks questions like ''Do the cows mind being milked continually?'' and ''How does the cow feel?'' So his host Morgan (John Bedford Lloyd) can be forgiven for sometimes giving ludicrous answers and for chuckling under his breath as he invents chores for Miles, like washing rocks individually by hand and rotating the eggs in the nests so the hens will not become emotionally attached.

ALBERT--Murray. Passed away on June 27, 2006 in Los Angeles. He was loved as a husband, father, grandfather, son and brother, and by all who knew him as a friend. His rare combination of humility, humor, and charm enriched every person whose life he touched.

The young men and women who challenged segregation as Freedom Riders in the spring and summer of 1961 are now senior citizens. Last year the photographer Eric Etheridge began searching out and making contemporary portraits of the more than 300 Riders who were arrested and served prison time in his home state of Mississippi. Helen Singleton, 73, and her husband, Robert, 70, who married in 1955 and traveled from California to sit in the whites-only waiting room of the Jackson train station, are among his subjects. Their portraits are shown here along with mug shots taken 45 years ago this month.

GROWING up Grucci has its perks and perils, even after the Grucci in question is all grown up. Take 56-year-old Felix J. Grucci Jr., the involuntarily retired Republican politician who served one term in Congress before being ousted in 2002 by Timothy H. Bishop, a neophyte Democrat from the Hamptons, in a vicious campaign characterized by mutual smear-slinging. Is Mr. Grucci nostalgic for Congress, or for the six rollicking years he spent as supervisor of the Town of Brookhaven? Not exactly. ''Getting yourself elected to public office has gotten to be a blood sport,'' he says. ''It's not enough to win. Today the opponent is out to destroy you, and destroy your family name, and I don't want to say it's like what the Mafia does to its enemies, but at the end of the day, it's not exactly not like what the Mafia does.''

Stamford officials have approached the Board of Representatives about passing a law that would allow the public safety department to install security cameras throughout the city, but the proposal has met with resistance. The city has laws restricting where cameras can be placed, said William Callion, the director of the Office of Public Safety, Health and Welfare in Stamford. Mr. Callion said he approached the city's Board of Representatives last month about passing an ordinance that would ease those laws because the city needed the cameras to increase security and to deter crime. He presented the board with different options, from limiting the cameras to areas where terrorists might strike, to placing them anywhere they might have a ''lawful purpose.''

KAPLAN--B. David, a very kind, soft spoken gentleman who we loved is gone from this world but not from our hearts and minds. More than a brother-in-law, you introduced us to food and wine. You inspired our journeys in the world and in our lives. Forever grateful. Beatrice & Michael

To the Editor: ''Spread of Islamic Law in Indonesia Takes Toll on Women'' (news article, June 27) is a cautionary tale for women everywhere. All religious fundamentalism, including our own home-grown varieties, threatens women's rights.

THE past has a nasty way of springing up when it is least expected. It did for Michael Love just as it did for Oedipus and Arthur Dimmesdale. Mr. Love thought he had started afresh. He and his girlfriend had built up an un-Starbucks coffeehouse that is this riverfront village's Rick's Cafe. Cutely named Coffee Labs Roasters, after their Labrador retrievers, the coffee house roasts it own organic beans picked by farmers whose pay has been certified as fair by a watchdog group. The velvet latte was voted the best in Westchester in 2004 by a local magazine. The 36-year-old Mr. Love has been recognized by the Westchester Business Council as one of 40 entrepreneurs under 40 to watch.

To the Sports Editor: I have little interest in watching 22 highly paid grown men run around for 90 minutes waiting for one (or two -- or none) of them to score a goal. But a major shortcoming seems to have escaped the aficionados of this sport.
