One could be forgiven for thinking the little black dress -- so safe, so flattering -- has always been with us, a staple of every woman's closet. But it was radical in its day, replacing the floating chiffons of the early 20th century, as can be seen in ''Art and Fashion: From Marie Antoinette to Jacqueline Kennedy'' at the Nassau County Museum of Art. Intelligently assembled and scrupulously presented, this is one of the best exhibitions here in a long time. It is heartening to see a museum return to form after a string of poorly arranged and presented exhibits. Much of the credit goes to the staff, but also to JoAnne Olian, costume curator emeritus at the Museum of the City of New York, who was co-curator of the exhibition with Franklin Hill Perrell, a house curator. Ms. Olian's handprints are everywhere here, from the astute, elegant integration of displays of art, fashion and furniture to a jaunty, eminently readable essay in the exhibition catalog. Museum officials were smart to draw on her expertise.

SAPINKOPF--Lionel, 80. Devoted husband, father, brother and friend. Renaissance man--soldier, urban planner, athlete, coach, professor, community activist, lover of music, poetry and ideas. A seriously funny guy. We cannot forget you. Your family.

CITIES and states have long fought under-age drinking, easily passing laws that make it illegal in public, but not so easily passing and enforcing laws that make it illegal on private property. The ability of minors to drink in their homes, or in the homes of others, is an old, stubborn behavior, spawning countless teenage house parties that the police have found difficult to combat. But states and municipalities in the region have been chipping away at the problem. A Connecticut law targeting adults who allow drinking by minors was signed into law on June 2. Also last month, Rockland County and the City of Long Beach on Long Island, while taking different approaches, started work on passing laws of their own.

To the Editor: I read with enthusiasm your article about Robert F. Kennedy Jr. By writing the Rolling Stone article, he is expanding past his history as an environmental leader and venturing into some intriguing work. I think it is always beneficial when someone who has a platform to speak from, whether it is because of family name or other means, uses that platform to advance the causes that others may want to speak about but lack the platform to do so. Steven M. Clayton Ocean, N.J.

STUART--Lyle. Died June 24. We mourn the death and celebrate the life of our member Lyle Stuart, courageous and controversial publisher and staunch atheist. Ken Bronstein, President New York City Atheists
To the Editor: Re: ''A Trove of Masterworks, With Masters' Doodles'' [June 25]:

To the Editor: Regarding the random placement of names (''9/11 Memorial Faces Setback Over Names,'' news article, June 27), it is helpful to recall that those on the Vietnam Veterans Memorial are not listed alphabetically but chronologically, and include no other descriptive text; all are equal before mortality's leveling force. We grieve for the dead -- not because they worked for a particular company in a particular location, but because they loved and were loved. This is their eternal legacy.

LUBASCH--Betty. On June 30, 2006, at the age of 96. Be loved and devoted wife of Murray. Loving mother of Arlene and her husband Harry, and of Richard and his wife Lois. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Douglas and Eric and his wife Shari, and great-grandmother of Cori.
To the Editor: Re ''For Riders Below, Fears New, Fears Old,'' by Elizabeth Nunez (New York Observed, June 25):

I'M neither domestic nor handy. When it comes to dinner, I'm great at making reservations. When the house needs work, I call a contractor. It turns out that a good meal is easier to come by than an honest, reliable, affordable and skilled craftsman. Take the case of my front steps.

ALEXANDER--John Winton, 88, died June 22 of congestive heart failure. Born October 6, 1917 in Atlanta, GA to Will and Mabelle Alexander. John attended the George School and Columbia College, class of '39, earning a BA in sociology and an MPH. He served in World War II as a Naval Reserve officer. He returned to academia holding senior positions at Columbia, University of Maryland and SUNY-Albany. He also worked for the American Friends Service Committee on school desegregation projects. After retiring to Chapel Hill, NC he joined the Chapel Hill Friends Meeting and was interim principal of Carolina Friends School, 1988-89. John leaves his wife of 41 years, Miriam, three daughters, three grandchildren, and four greatgrandchildren. A Quaker Memorial Service will be held July 8 at 11am at Carol Woods Retirement Community. Contributions in John's memory may be made to: The United Negro College Fund, PO Box 10444, Fairfax, VA 22031; Interfaith Council, 110 W. Main St., Carrboro, NC 27510 or Carolina Friends School, 4809 Friends School Road, Durham, NC 27705

THE PEABODY SISTERS: Three Women Who Ignited American Romanticism, by Megan Marshall. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Marshall creates a colorful and sympathetic portrait of Eliza and Nathaniel Peabody's remarkable daughters: Elizabeth, the eldest, whose intellect attracted the notice of luminaries like Ralph Waldo Emerson; Mary, a beauty and the author of several children's textbooks; and Sophia, the artist and invalid, who illustrated the books of her husband, Nathaniel Hawthorne. Deftly weaving material from the letters and journals of all three sisters, Marshall places them at the center of the 19th-century spiritual awakening known as Transcendentalism. ''The Peabody Sisters'' was a Pulitzer Prize finalist.

IT is a question that occurs to almost everyone who becomes seriously ill: Should you go to your local hospital or would you do better if you went to a major medical center? It may mean a long trip when you are ill and it will almost certainly mean seeing doctors who are strangers to you. But what if going to a major medical center makes the difference between life and death? Patients reach different conclusions, based often on gut feelings about a doctor or a hospital. And medical researchers, looking for data, say they are not always certain themselves about how to decide. ''There really is very, very little information,'' says Dr. Elliott S. Fisher, a professor at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H., who studies medical outcomes. ''It's the great weakness of all the efforts to foster consumer engagement in health care decision making.''

BARNETT - Philip. 55, of White Plains, on June 29. Beloved son of Helen and the late Frank Barnett, husband for 28 years to Ruth, treasured father to Joseph, Andrew and Karen, and adored brother of Alan. Environmental engineer by trade, chef extraordinaire and golfer by passion. His brilliant mind allowed him, family and friends to enjoy life to its fullest. Donations: Philip Barnett Memorial Scholarship Fund, 1 Franklin Rd., Great Neck, NY 11024.

9 P.M. (13, 49) A PRAIRIE HOME COMPANION AT TANGLEWOOD -- Great American songs and great American stories in honor of the great American holiday. In this ''Great Performances'' special based on Garrison Keillor's public radio variety show, some of the people of Lake Wobegon celebrate Independence Day in Massachusetts. Providing the entertainment: Private Eye Guy Noir, the cowboys Dusty and Lefty, Guy's All-Star Shoe Band and, from the new Robert Altman movie that helped reinforce Mr. Keillor's nostalgic rhapsodizing as a national treasure, Meryl Streep (above, with Mr. Keillor). 3:30 P.M. (Sundance) PLACE VEND√ØOME -- (1998). Catherine Deneuve plays the alcoholic wife of a prominent jeweler (Bernard Fresson, who appeared alongside Ms. Deneuve in 1967 in ''Belle de Jour'') who throws out her Bordeaux to protect five exquisite diamonds he left her before he killed himself. The mood is sober, and so is the lighting in this drama from Nicole Garcia, but Ms. Deneuve sparkles. 8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) CHILDREN OF THE STORM -- Erica lives in a trailer on what was her front lawn but says she feels far from the life she once knew. Clive takes a tour of his old neighborhood and talks about how nothing will ever be the same. In this Nick News special, Linda Ellerbee, who effectively mixes news gathering with nurturing for the tween set, visits New Orleans to see how some of its children are coping one year after Hurricane Katrina ravaged their home sweet home. 9 P.M. (HBO) DEADWOOD -- Who says men are better with money? Tonight, the shrewd Alma (Molly Parker, right) - she's a transplanted New Yorker, after all - opens Deadwood's first bank. 10 P.M. (HGTV) INTERNATIONAL HOME AND HOUSEWARES 2006 -- Even if you don't have a remodeling budget, this special, filmed at the home-design industry's event of the year, has something for every daydreamer. 10 P.M. (BBC America) FOOTBALLERS WIVES -- Amid sagging ratings - something about not enough sports action, but that's hardly the point, now is it? - this show recently got axed in Britain. Still, it has its tasty moments, like this episode, in which the babysnatching Tanya has been sent packing, and Conrad wants to reconcile with Amber, who - their son safely back in her arms - is too busy trying to revive her Bollywood career to care. 10 P.M. (VH1) SUPERGROUP -- All good things must come to an end, and this series, in which five of metal's heaviest converged to try to build the ultimate band, is one of them. Perhaps drawing from his cookbook ''Kill It & Grill It,'' Uncle Ted - that's Mr. Nugent (above) to you - stages a fireside meal to rouse tribal spirit before the final gig. But where is Evan Seinfeld when you need him? KATHRYN SHATTUCK

MY dinner partner to the left was almost completely deaf, and every few minutes opened with the same conversational gambit. ''I was in the Battle of the Bulge, but I can't talk about it,'' he kept shouting. The dinner partner on my right, mercifully, was my father, who spoke in lower tones and was not using the occasion to review his own similarly traumatic memories of World War II. There were, however, many other reminiscences. The event was my dad's 60th college reunion, and I was his date for the weekend. My father and I share an alma mater -- Williams College, a small liberal arts school in New England known for its strong alumni devotion. He was in the class of 1946; I graduated 32 years later, in 1978.

To the Editor: ''When Saving Lives Is More Than Child's Play'' (June 25) is very impressive. As a strong advocate of the idea ''young face, good hands,'' I can appreciate the abilities of these teenage volunteer emergency workers. But I have to question the maturity of the adults who would allow a 16-year-old to be exposed to some of the extraordinarily grisly scenes that these students encounter -- drivers with missing body parts, murdered children. That is not something any 16-year-old, or even any 18-year-old, should ever have to assimilate.

HARMAN--Bettie M. (nee Ettinger). 87 years on June 29. Beloved Mother, Sister, Grandmother and GreatGrandmother. ''To spare family the sad chore,/I pick up my pen yet once more/With hope I have the strength and wit/To compose this, my own obit:/Parents Fran and Dave were the best:/With sisters Pearl and ''Cookie'' blessed/ (Whose Hal and Ralph like brothers mine);/A Hunter B.A. in '39;/'40 Lowell and I married,/With him 57 years tarried;/We roamed the world every chance,/Travel my sole extravagance;/Supported causes I held dear,/Hadassah Woman - of - the - Year./ Even the workplace I enjoyed:/Taught and in banking law employed./Three wonderful daughters I bore,/My world's center forevermore;/ Jane brought Michael Schwartz to the fold--/Forty plus years good as gold./After eight years of being pal,/Linda wed her Solomon, Hal;/ Tom Sansoterra took the vow,/who makes Diane so happy now./Four fine grandchildren stole my heart:/Jennifer and Mitchell to start,/ Next Clover Fields, and Noah last/Whose bride Abigail joined the cast;/These last two have caused me to be/Of babe Leah, Eliana and Dahlia./Millennium saw us dance and rock/At Jennifer's marriage to Jeffrey Stock./In Florida nigh half a year,/To the Bristal in North Woodmere/With two more girls added joy,/Jacey and Juliet./ Chris wed to Clover and Baeden./By family and friend surrounded,/My life was full and well rounded./Loves, don't linger long in sorrow,/I'll live on in your tomorrow.''/ BETTIE M. HARMAN/Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 A.M. Sunday.

STURGES--Alice S. On June 29, 2006. She was the widow of John M. Sturges and is survived by her son, John M. Sturges, Jr., her daughter, Mary S. King, eight grandchildren and seventeen great-grandchildren. A family funeral service will be followed by a memorial service at a later date.

To the Editor: Your cover story can be boiled down to the problem faced by Barbara Molina, the 17-year-old who can't afford tickets to Ozzfest. Who but affluent baby boomers can? Consequently, it's only the tours of baby boomer acts that sell. John Philips Manhattan

To the Editor: Re ''A New Way to Ask, 'How Green Is My Conscience?' '' (June 25), which described consumers' purchase of environmental offsets, to make up for the pollution caused by the events of everyday life: As the article said, the challenge for consumers wishing to reduce their ''carbon footprint'' is to understand how much their dollars help the environment.

CURCI--Robert. Died on June 27. A lifelong Atheist, Bob rejected prayer and asked that no one pray for him. Bob often said ''I'm not afraid of dying,'' and ''My fate is based on medical science and my genes.'' New York City Atheists will miss him. Ken Bronstein, President New York City Atheists

Beloved and cherished husband to Pearl, and to the late Nan. Loving father and father-inlaw to Steven and Bonnie, Robert and Arlene, Roberta and Eric, Elaine and Gerry, Susan and Jeffrey, and Patricia and Misha. Devoted brother and brother-in-law to Bill and his wife Ruth. Adored grandfather to Joshua, Benjamin, Rachel, Daniel, Gabriel, Matthew, Dana, Ali, Rebecca, Michelle, Caleb, Noah, Joanna, and Anton. Burial to take place at the Bayside Cemetery, Queens. Contributions may be made to the HoPe and Cope Fund 514-340-8251.

We at the Department of Homeland Security figured that this Fourth of July holiday weekend --when you New Yorkers are distracted by fireworks, barbecues and gas prices --is as good a time as any to reveal a revised version of our urban area antiterrorism grants for New York City. When you folks complain, we Washington political appointees respond!

A PAIR of ducks sat on the muddy shore of the Neck River in Madison last Tuesday, oblivious to the environmental destruction taking place just under their feet. Vegetation in the salty marshes near Long Island Sound is dying off, putting plants and animals at risk and causing the shore to erode. Scientists call it sudden wetland dieback, but they are not sure how it started and what they can do to end it.

Samantha Simone, the daughter of Linda and Vincent J. Simone of Garden City, N.Y., was married on Friday evening to Hasan Mohammad Ibrahim, a son of Maria and Mohammad H. Ibrahim of North Bergen, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Randall B. Bosch, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony at the Fox Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. Mrs. Ibrahim, 29, is a second-grade teacher at Public School 19 in Manhattan. She graduated from Hofstra University, where she also received a master's degree in education.
To the Editor: Re ''Chinese Medicine for American Schools'' (column, June 27): Nicholas D. Kristof has found the essential reason that this century belongs to China.

Only four matches remain in the World Cup, but the beautiful game won't disappear anytime soon. Levon Biss celebrates it in ''One Love: Soccer for Life,'' a new book whose title is inspired by Bob Marley, who said, ''football is music.''

Vice President Dick Cheney, who has a long history of heart disease and underwent surgery last year to repair aneurysms in arteries behind his knees, was pronounced in stable cardiac health after a routine annual physical examination on Saturday. Tests at George Washington University Hospital found that Mr. Cheney's cardiac pacemaker was working properly and had not been activated due to arrhythmia, or irregular heartbeat, said Mr. Cheney's spokeswoman, Lea Anne McBride.

REESE--Mark Lawrence, 55, in San Rafael, CA on June 23, 2006. World renowned authority and writer on the Feldenkrais Method of Somatic Education, brilliant and cherished teacher and much loved friend, father, brother and husband. Donations to aid publication of Mark's biography of Moshe Feldenkrais can be made to the Feldenkrais Educational Foundation Biography Fund, 800-775-2118.

IN May, the United States Senate passed the immigration reform bill with a last-minute rider requiring the National Park Service to reopen the Statue of Liberty's crown to visitors. On the surface, that sounds like a good idea. Why not allow tourists fuller access to perhaps the most recognized symbol of the United States? After all, the crown was open to the public for more than 100 years before being closed in reaction to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. But reopening the crown is not a good idea for a variety of reasons. And even talk of amendments proposing as much as $2 million to pay for its reopening simply doesn't make sense.

To the Editor: Tom Moore is correct in identifying the real cause of teacher shortages in New York City as failure to retain rather than failure to recruit (''Teacher Dismissed,'' Op-Ed, June 25). But the reason all those Ivy Leaguers recruited by Teach for America and New York City's Teaching Fellows program leave after only a few years is that they were never planning to build long-term careers in the system.

Studying the pastry case at Bruehwiler's bakery, my eyes lock onto what appears to be my favorite French pastry: pain aux raisins, a glazed spiral of sweet, eggy yeast bread studded with raisins, with a fine layer of pastry cream woven throughout. I wonder if I might have wandered into someone else's life and awakened in a Paris boulangerie. I am, it turns out, on Main Street in Old Saybrook. And it is not a pain aux raisins; it is a hazelnut-raisin Danish. And the baker is not French; he is Swiss. But the excellence of the Danish, with its buttery multileaved dough and sweet crusty edges, goes a long way toward assuaging my disappointment.

To the Editor: I was one of the ''girls who went away,'' but my experience was different in some important ways from what was described in Kathryn Harrison's reviewof Ann Fessler's book ''The Girls Who Went Away'' (June 11). In 1955, when I was 19 and still a virgin, I became pregnant by a boy I did not love. His family lived in Sands Point, Long Island, near mine. My parents' dysfunctional marriage was coming apart; my alcoholic mother was having a breakdown, and so was I. A couple of months before that one-time sex, toward the end of my sophomore year in an exclusive women's college, I had become bulimic and anorexic, before these conditions had been widely recognized. So I did the next logical thing: I passively submitted to my ''friend's''desires. Three months later, in Geneva, where I was spending my junior year abroad, a Swiss doctor told me, ''Mademoiselle, vous avez un enfant.'' Believing from the propaganda of the time that all abortions were dangerous and not knowing what else to do, I flew home. My parents and I understood thatmy pregnancywas shameful and had to be kept secret. My father thought I had ruined my life. I thought I was bad. A psychiatrist my mother took me to (a little late) referred me to the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue'sadoption agency, Louise Wise Services. The social worker took me to their Staten Island home for unwed mothers. It turned out to be the first safe and secure environment I had ever experienced andthe beginning of the emotional healing process I so badly needed. The other girls and women in the home were the kinds of people I had never encountered in my narrow life. Some had been in reform school. Some were the victims of rape. Some were professional women. Some were creative artists. Some were just children themselves. I felt deeply for them and felt keenly the victimization of women. Most were giving their babies for adoption; some were not. They elected me president of their little self-governing association. I never put this on my r√©sum√©. Five weeks later, I gave birth to a healthy baby boy who was eligible for immediate adoption because so much was known about me and the father and it was basically all positive. From the beginning, I had not wanted to keep the baby I would bear. I had not loved the father. I did not want the social stigma. I did not want to live with a reminder all my life of such an unhappy experience. I wanted the baby to have a better home than I could possibly have provided at that point in my life. I was told he was going to be adopted by a pediatrician husband and his clinical social worker wife. I knew that I was giving them a great gift. I have never regretted my decision. I went on to get married, have two more healthy children, earn a Ph.D. and have a successful career in academe and nonprofit organization management. Ihave told few people aboutmy first child . . . until now. Dorin Oltarsh Schumacher St. Simons Island, Ga.

An article on June 11 about golf landscapes by the painter Linda Hartough and a correction in this space last week referred incorrectly to the length of the ninth hole at the Winged Foot Golf Club. The entire hole, not the approach, is 510 yards, not feet.

WHEN he was planning his vast estate, Warren E. Buffett apparently wanted to make sure that no one would be watching a legal battle over his inheritance play out on the E! channel someday. As he was signing a set of letters last week to transfer $37.4 billion of his fortune to five different charities, including the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Mr. Buffett deadpanned: ''I wanted to make sure I didn't ever send one that started, 'Dear Anna Nicole Smith.' ''

IT was the prom with strings attached. After some cases of student drinking at a Garden City High School dance in December, the principal, Hank Hardy, canceled two other dances on the calendar. That led many parents and seniors to fear that the prom itself would become a victim. After all, Kellenberg Memorial in Uniondale and Chaminade in Mineola had canceled their proms.

KOCH--Robert Newman Jr. 79, an executive in the fashion jewelry business and beloved husband of Elaine Koch, died Friday, at his East Orleans, Mass., home, of complications of Parkinson's disease. Mr. Koch was president of Coro, Inc., the nation's largest costume jewelry maker, before he founded R.N. Koch, Inc., in 1971, with offices in New York and a factory in Providence, RI. Mr. Koch, who also had homes in New York and Long Boat Key, FL, was born in Buffalo, NY, on September 26, 1926. He later relocated with his parents to New York City. He served in the navy as a radio operator in the Pacific during World War II. After attending Nichols Junior College in Dudley, Mass., he joined Coro and eventually worked his way up to president of the company. ''He loved everything about the jewelry business,'' said his daughter Peggy Palmer. His personality and artistic gifts made him perfectly suited for it. He loved the arts, particularly music and painting, and often shopped at New York and Florida galleries. Mr. Koch was formerly married to Susan Dryfoos and the couple had two daughters. In 1995, he married Elaine Stone on the lawn of his Cape Cod home, and the couple enjoyed traveling, dining and entertaining. His family treasured Bob's love of life, whether it was food, the arts, being with friends and family, or traveling. They will always treasure his goodness of heart. In addition to his wife Elaine and his daughters Peggy Palmer and Katharine Willens, both of California, he is survived by sons-in-law Briggs Palmer and Randall Willens, grandchildren Jordan and Christopher Palmer, and Charlotte and Daniel Willens, his stepdaughters Susan Van Sicklen and Debra Nussbaum, stepsons-in-law Michael Van Sicklen and Paul Nussbaum, and step - grandchildren Barret, Nick and David Van Sicklen, Zachary and Gerry Bissinger, Molly and Mathew Nussbaum, and his devoted caregiver Raymond Bradley. Private graveside service will be held Thursday. A memorial service is being planned for the fall. Donations may be made to the Robert N. Koch Jr. Foundation, established by Mr. Koch to aid Parkinson's Research, in care of Mr. Todd Lang, Esq., Weil Gotshal Manges, 767 5th Ave., New York, NY 10153. $(6$)KOCH--Robert N. Jr. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Robert N. Koch Jr. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Elaine and to the entire family. Patricia Sumergrade, Pres. Richard J. Bronstein, Sec'y

RICHARDS - Lloyd. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund mourn the loss of our beloved colleague and friend. Lloyd Richards was truly one of the greatest voices in the American theatre during the past 50 years. TDF was honored to have had Lloyd guide us as our Board President from 1977-1981. During the intervening years he remained a great supporter and provided counsel to us. He will be greatly missed. Our condolences to his family. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Exec. Dir. Veronica Claypool Managing Director $(6$)RICHARDS--Lloyd. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend and great contributor to the American Theatre, Lloyd Richards. He was a wonderful director, educator and inspiration to his colleagues in the theatre. The Shubert Organization

To the Editor: Robert F. Kennedy's questioning the results of the presidential election in an ''exhaustive, strenuously footnoted article'' is equated with ''wading into a swamp'' and ''venturing into deep waters.'' How strange. Does arguing rationally (and convincingly) that something went wrong in Ohio make you a daredevil? Can we not judge these arguments on their merit, rather than on the style of their messenger? Barbara Eskin Brookline, Mass.

Caroline Barrie Stark, the daughter of Helen L. Stark and Dr. Robert M. Stark of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married today to Joshua Nathaniel Beer, a son of Joan F. Beer and Dr. Dennis J. Beer of Waban, Mass. Rabbi Steven Stark Lowenstein, an uncle of the bride, is to officiate at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y. The bride, 27, is the manager of business development for Amicus Therapeutics, a biotechnology company in Cranbury, N.J. Last month she received an M.B.A. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. She graduated magna cum laude from Duke University.

NIVES--Ernest, 81, on June 25, 2006. Born Vienna, Austria. After seeking refuge in France with his parents in 1939, he and his mother were ultimately deported in 1942 to Auschwitz, where his mother perished. In May 1945, he was reunited with his father and his brother, Fred, then serving in the U.S. Army in France. He met his wife, Fanny, in Paris in 1948, and then immigrated to the U.S. After earning his Bachelor of Business Administration degree at CCNY (Baruch College) in 1958, he established a distinguished CPA practice and specialized in motion picture accounting/auditing and entertainment business management. Throughout his life, he was active in Holocaust education: founding and serving as President of the American Friends of the Anne Frank Center and of the French Children of the Holocaust Foundation; producing traveling exhibits on Anne Frank, anti-Semitism and the history of the French children of the Holocaust. Most recently, he was instrumental in the creation of ''Letters to Sala,'' an exhibit at the New York Public Library, an ongoing project organized by Ann Kirschner. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Fanny, his children, David (Miriam) and Julie (Daniel Schwartzman), granddaughters, Marisa and Zoe, and brother, Fred (Donna). Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

IN four years, Carl Albanese, a 55-year-old freelance video producer, has amassed 50 hours of video recordings showcasing the reinvention of White Plains, from the demolition of vacant buildings to the construction of office and condo towers that dot its downtown. He has also taped countless Common Council meetings, registering the debates that preceded each step of the development for a documentary he plans to show on local cable TV. But some residents started to complain to City Hall about being filmed during the meetings, and Mayor Joseph M. Delfino began to question Mr. Albanese's intentions, said Paul Wood, the city's executive officer, who said he was speaking for Mr. Delfino. The mayor asked city lawyers if there was a way to control Mr. Albanese, and the lawyers found a 63-year-old ordinance limiting anyone from recording council meetings without advance consent.

Negotiations to settle a lawsuit filed by a Latino civil rights group against Mamaroneck over its treatment of immigrant workers collapsed on Tuesday after a federal judge ordered that the case go to trial. The suit, filed in April by the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, accused officials in Mamaroneck of violating the rights of immigrant workers by preventing them from congregating near Columbus Park to look for work. A month later, lawyers for both sides announced with optimism that they had agreed to delay litigation, saying they were in the middle of ''fruitful'' discussions and working toward a settlement.

The scent envelops you as soon as you enter Danielle's Chocolatier in Mount Kisco: sweet with a hint of spice, sultry and absolutely intoxicating. Just try to leave without buying one of the artisanal truffles, made on the premises. It won't be easy. The wizard behind these goodies is the owner, Danielle Rogers, who grew up in Antwerp, Belgium. She began making chocolates in the Belgian tradition after coming to the United States 30 years ago and being disappointed by the American varieties. ''American chocolate is too sweet and filled with preservatives and byproducts,'' she said. ''When chocolate isn't so sweet, the other flavors come through.''

Jay Leno Today Warren Buffett announced he's giving away his multibillion-dollar fortune to charity rather than leaving it to his kids. He said he doesn't believe that somebody's son should inherit his father's ''position in society.'' Today, President Bush immediately put him under surveillance.

The Connecticut A.F.L.-C.I.O. made its endorsements last week in this year's elections, backing the Democratic incumbent, Joseph I. Lieberman, in the Senate race and Mayor John DeStefano of New Haven in the Democratic primary for governor in August. It also endorsed Democrats in all five races for the House of Representatives. The federation of unions represents about 200,000 people and the endorsements allow different unions to coordinate campaign activities.

WILF--Judith. On June 29, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Harry, loving mother of Leonard and his wife Beth, dear sister of Rose Blumenkranz, adoring grandmother and great-grandmother. A true woman of valor, a cherished Holocaust survivor. Service Sunday 12 noon at Jewish Educational Center, 330 Elmora Avenue, Elizabeth, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Hospital, Jewish Educational Center, Elizabeth, NJ, American Society for Yad Vashem. $(6$)WILF--Judith. The world-wide leadership of Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem offers its heartfelt condolences to Leonard and Beth Wilf, Rose Blumenkranz and Amb. Yehoshua Trigor on the loss of their beloved mother, her cherished sister and his faithful companion. An extraordinary matriarch who personified the loftiest values of Jewish tradition and ethics, her very being radiated kindness, dignity, modesty and joy. From the ashes of the Shoah, Judith and her late husband Harry, of blessed memory, built an exceptional legacy of tzedakah and chesed that reflected their stellar commitment and steadfast devotion to Am Yisrael, Torat Yisrael and Medinat Yisrael. The Harry, Judith and Leonard Wilf Woman and Infant Center on ''Charlie's Floor'', where well over 50,000 babies have been born; The Wilf Family Lobby in the Department of Emergency Medicine; and the Wilf Family Pediatric Floor stand as a symbol and testimonial of the family's outstretched hand of kindness, compassion and generosity in building, strengthening, healing and safeguarding the State of srael and its people. May Leonard and Beth, Mrs. Blumenkranz, grandchildren Orin, Halle, Harrison, Jenna and Amb Trigor, together with the entire family, be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Emeritus Jack C. Bendheim, President Prof. Jonathan Halevy, Director-General Paul S. Glasser, Nat'l Director Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division Michael S. Strauss $(6$)WILF--Judith. Yeshiva University mourns the passing of the beloved wife and partner in philanthropy of the late Harry Wilf, who was a Yeshiva University Benefactor, an honorary alumnus, a member of the Board of Directors and founder of YU's Sy Syms School of Business, a Holocaust Studies Fellow, and a Fellow of Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. She, together with her brother-in-law Joseph and sisterin-law Suzie Wilf, established the Harry and Joseph Wilf Scholars Fund at YU's undergraduate schools. Judith was a Woman of Valor, and a generous supporter of many Jewish causes. We extend heartfelt condolences to her son Leonard and the entire Wilf family, all of whom are YU Benefactors. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees $(6$)WILF--Judith. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Judith Wilf, an Aishet Chayil, devoted to her late husband, Harry, loving mother to Leonard (Beth), devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. A woman of strength and dignity whose generosity benefited our Park East Synagogue and day school. To Leonard and Beth, grandchildren Orin (Lisa), religious school students Harrison, Jenna and Halle, and her devoted friend, Ambassador Yehoshua Trigor, we extend our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier $(6$)WILF--Judy. Our collective memories are very clear, when in 1972 we were first together at the Korn's in Washington, D.C. to celebrate law school graduation, along with Harry, Susie and Joe. We were taken by your unmistakable elegance and pride in your son's stellar accomplishment. Throughout the years there continued to be numerous other celebrations where we observed that same gleam and unconditional adoration. A mother, mother-in-law, and grandmother like you does not come along very often. Stephanie & Frank Razzano Debra and Peter Till $(6$)WILF--Judith. We mourn the passing of Judith Wilf, an Ayshet Chayil, Holocaust survivor, philanthropist, and our dear friend. To her son and daughter-in-law, Leonard and Beth, sister, Rose Blumenkranz, sister-in-law and brother - in - law, Elizabeth and Joseph and grandchildren Orin, Halle, Jenna and Harrison, we offer our condolences and sympathies. May the entire Wilf family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Cecile and Edward Mosberg Beatrice Mosberg Louise and Stuart Levine Caroline and Darren Karger and Families $(6$)WILF--Judith. Lenny and Beth, our heartfelt condolences to you and your entire family on the loss of your beloved mother, Judith. Your Friends, Carol and Richard Kalikow

IT was the prom with strings attached. After some cases of student drinking at a Garden City High School dance in December, the principal, Hank Hardy, canceled two other dances on the calendar. That led many parents and seniors to fear that the prom itself would become a victim. After all, Kellenberg Memorial in Uniondale and Chaminade in Mineola had canceled their proms.

KATZ--Robert, M.D. Palm Beach Gardens, Fl April 2, 2006, 83 years old. Born Vienna, Austria. Formerly of Brooklyn and Manhattan. He is survived by his second wife, Inge Gavis Katz; three sons from his first marriage to the late Marie N. Sathmary Katz, M.D., Wesley, Clifford, and Roger Katz; grandchildren, Michael, Noah, Nadine, and Spencer Katz. He was deeply loved by his boys and will be in our hearts forever. May his memory be a blessing. A remembrance service will be scheduled in New York, info: 212-213-2981.

HULL--J. Milfred, Beloved husband and father of wife Helen and daughters Diana Hull-Hopps and Laura Hull, died June 24, 2006. An actor - turned - attorney, he built a successful law practice in Smithtown, New York. He was an elected delegate to the 1967 NYS Constitutional Convention and served on numerous civic and professional organizations. He will be forever loved and missed by his family.
A picture caption on June 11 with the Journeys column on bicycle tours through wine-producing areas misstated the area of New Zealand shown. It was the Marlborough region, not Central Otago.

NASA scrubbed the launching of the shuttle Discovery minutes before its scheduled liftoff Saturday as threatening clouds encroached on the 20-mile boundary around the Kennedy Space Center. The postponement came on the first day of a 19-day launching window, just before the start of a 10-minute span in which the launching pad enters the same orbital plane as the International Space Station.

ED HULIT of Point Pleasant usually grills hot dogs outdoors but serves them indoors. He would prefer to have a regular barbecue, as he did last Fourth of July weekend, when the emergency aid siren 40 yards behind his Hiawatha Avenue home was out of operation. But Mr. Hulit, one of a group of residents who say the three sirens in the borough blare too loudly and too often, says that when that siren is working, he finds himself wondering, ''Is it going to go off?''

DANIELI--Francesa. Mother, sister, daughter, friend, wife, and artist...we all lost a beautiful woman on the the evening of June 27. Francesca has shown remarkable grace, strength & dignity, having first faced cancer 22 years ago when diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma; then with breast cancer eight years ago; followed by metastatic disease diagnosed nearly two years ago. Having lived her life with such grace, dignity and wit, Francesca spent her last weeks in character at a hospice and wanted all of her friends and family to know that she believes that she led a very fortunate life. Having received national recognition for her work as a photographer and videographer, Francesca has published her body of work in Gamma Knife by Nazraeli Press in 2005. Her video project ''One Nice Thing'' was an official selection at 3 film festivals. Her work is held in the collections of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, TX and the Getty Museum. Francesca completed Masters Degrees at both the Columbia Business School and the Maryland Institute College of Art and received her BFA from the Virginia Commonwealth University. Francesca is survived by her three daughters, Anna, Lee and Isabel Gensler; her husband, Gary Gensler, all of Brooklandville, MD; her father, Francesco Costagliola of Alexandria, VA; and her three sisters, Marisa Costagliola of Columbia, MD, Antonia Burns of Cambridge, MD, and Rose Rubin of Falls Church, VA. Funeral services will be held at her home in Brooklandville, MD, Thursday, June 29, at 1:30 pm. Francesca wanted to thank everyone for their expression of support over many years and asked that in lieu of sending flowers or food please send contributions to: Hopewell Cancer Support; PO Box 755; Brooklandville, MD 21022 (410)-832-2719).
To the Editor: Re ''Another Kennedy Living Dangerously'' by Mark Leibovich (June 25):

To the Editor: The author of ''Space Empties, and Time Rushes In'' (June 25) revels in her last child having left the ''nest'' for college. She complains about the ''ridiculously high suburban New York property taxes,'' but at the same time enjoys being ''deliciously self-indulgent'' by continuing to live in a house meant for four. Her ''deep roots'' in the community have convinced her to stay put.

FISCHBARG--Zulema, MD A memorial service for Dr. Fischbarg will be held on Mon July 10th, 6pm at The Faculty House, Columbia Univ, 117th St & Morningside Ave. In lieu of flowers we welcome donations to Hadassah.

GRUBER--Samuel. We mourn the passing of our good friend, Samuel Gruber, a heroic underground fighter during the Holocaust, a leading partisan commander who kept the torch of Jewish resistance in the struggle against the Nazi enemy, and in the effort in saving Jewish lives. He wrote the book ''I Chose Life''. Let his memory remain as a blessing for all who knew and loved him, and will miss him. Our most heartfelt sympathy to the entire bereaved family. Federation of Former Jewish Underground Fighters Against Nazism Frank Blaichman Samuel Bloch

IT was the prom with strings attached. After some cases of student drinking at a Garden City High School dance in December, the principal, Hank Hardy, canceled two other dances on the calendar. That led many parents and seniors to fear that the prom itself would become a victim. After all, Kellenberg Memorial in Uniondale and Chaminade in Mineola had canceled their proms.

KNEELING on a narrow river beach, the four biologists picked deftly through a wriggling, shimmering mound of small fish they had just seined up from the Delaware, and tossed them into small plastic containers to await counting and measuring: white perch, Atlantic croakers, bluefish, silversides, menhaden. Only one variety escaped the rough steerage treatment, the three fish with racing stripes along their flanks and a tinge of dollar-bill green along their backs. They were permitted to swim regally in the first-class temporary accommodations of a brimming five-gallon bucket. ''They're what we're here for, so we try to put them in water right away,'' said Jen Pyle, a fisheries technician for New Jersey's Division of Fish and Wildlife, referring to the three native striped bass that were in the first haul of the season's first sampling trip. The twin suspension spans of the Delaware Memorial Bridge loomed in the distance behind her, and the morning sun glinted off the silty blue river.

To the Editor: We read with interest your story on Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his crusade to draw attention to fraud in the 2004 election in Ohio, having covered that issue in our own pages almost one year ago. We like to think that the ''low-grade rumblings about alleged abuses'' Mr. Kennedy had heard before being fully converted by Mark Crispin Miller's book were, in fact, the cover story of the August 2005 issue of Harper's Magazine, ''None Dare Call It Stolen,'' an article by Mr. Miller that preceded the publication of his book by four months. Giulia Melucci New York, N.Y. The writer is vice president for public relations of Harper's Magazine.
SCHERER--Helen. Beloved wife of the late Jules. Loving mother of Susan and Edward and Cheryl. Dear sister of Minnie, Frances and Sidney. Cherished grandmother of Beth and Peter. Services were held.

The august JACOB'S PILLOW DANCE FESTIVAL in the Berkshires is as beloved for its vivid history and lush green setting as for the eclecticism of its programming, which this week includes modern dance from Israel, performed by EMANUEL GAT DANCE and set to Schubert and Stravinsky, and SUZANNE FARRELL and her ensemble. Ms. Farrell has an eye for unaffected dancers who deliver Balanchine's ballets straight up, here including ''Divertimento No. 15'' and the pas de deux from the rarely seen ''Clarinade.'' Free events include a chat with JOHN ANTHONY GILVEY about his new book, ''Before the Parade Passes By: Gower Champion and the Glorious American Musical,'' which he will sign on Wednesday beginning at 5 p.m., and a discussion on Saturday at 4 p.m. with Ms. Farrell about her Balanchine lineage. Emanuel Gat Dance, Thursday through Sunday, $24, $21.60, students and 65+; Suzanne Farrell Ballet, Wednesday through Sunday, $50, $45, students and 65+; Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, 358 George Carter Road, Becket, Mass. (413) 243-0745 or jacobspillow.org. The AMERICAN BALLET THEATER production of Frederick Ashton's ''SYLVIA,'' a surprise hit last summer, is back at the Metropolitan Opera House for four performances, and it's about time. The ballet is crammed with gods, goddesses, nymphs and shepherds, who skulk and cavort through a complicated plot. But that narrative is set to the most delicious of scores, by Delibes, and it is full of dance that is inventive and tenderly lyrical, just the effervescent treat for hot summer nights. Monday through Thursday at 8 p.m. and Wednesday at 2 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000 or abt.org; $23 to $163. For dancegoers in search of something a little grittier, ROBERT BATTLE'S BATTLEWORKS and GUS SOLOMONS'S PARADIGM will alternate at the Joyce Theater. The program by Mr. Battle, known for his high-energy yet witty modern choreography, includes a world premiere to music by Philip Hamilton. Paradigm will perform new works by Carmen de Lavallade, Wally Cardona, Larry Keigwin, Kay Cummings and Mr. Solomons. Both companies, Wednesday at 8 p.m.; Battleworks, Thursday and Saturday at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m.; Paradigm, Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 p.m. and Sunday at 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea (212) 242-0800 or joyce.org; $30.

To the Editor: ''Bigger, but Not Better,'' by Richard Amper and Richard Johannesen (Op-Ed, June 25), is sadly more than true. I've never understood why most local legislators are indeed more responsive to ''developers than to the public.'' While we're the ones who vote, the developers often don't even live in their districts.

IF the Edith Ort Thomas Elementary School holds its ''Frenchtown Idol'' show again next school year, 9-year-old Olivia Turton hopes to sing ''Awesome God.'' On Monday in Trenton, Judge Stanley R. Chesler of Federal District Court will take up a lawsuit over her right to do so. Olivia was not allowed to sing the song in May 2005, when she was in second grade; school officials said it amounted to Christian proselytizing.

While Mr. Buffett was willing to give away that kind of wisdom last week, more serious and in-depth advice from the man known as the Oracle of Omaha comes at a much steeper price. As he does every year, Mr. Buffett is willing to have lunch with the highest bidder at an auction to benefit the Glide Foundation, a charity for the homeless in San Francisco for which his late wife, Susan, had volunteered.

IN four years, Carl Albanese, a 55-year-old freelance video producer, has amassed 50 hours of video recordings showcasing the reinvention of White Plains, from the demolition of vacant buildings to the construction of office and condo towers that dot its downtown. He has also taped countless Common Council meetings, registering the debates that preceded each step of the development for a documentary he plans to show on local cable TV. But some residents started to complain to City Hall about being filmed during the meetings, and Mayor Joseph M. Delfino began to question Mr. Albanese's intentions, said Paul Wood, the city's executive officer, who said he was speaking for Mr. Delfino. The mayor asked city lawyers if there was a way to control Mr. Albanese, and the lawyers found a 63-year-old ordinance limiting anyone from recording council meetings without advance consent.

Westchester County officials began hearing public comments last week on a proposal to make improvements to Westchester County Airport and told its neighbors that the projects would not lead to an increase in air traffic. The proposal addresses security concerns, environmental issues, and safety and operations, as well as the future use of an 18.8-acre former Air National Guard site on the airport's property. Security improvements proposed by the county include the installation of vehicle checkpoints that could be activated during heightened alerts, creating a permanent baggage screening area and provisions for curbside baggage checking.

CITIES and states have long fought under-age drinking, easily passing laws that make it illegal in public, but not so easily passing and enforcing laws that make it illegal on private property. The ability of minors to drink in their homes, or in the homes of others, is an old, stubborn behavior, spawning countless teenage house parties that the police have found difficult to combat. But states and municipalities in the region have been chipping away at the problem. A Connecticut law targeting adults who allow drinking by minors was signed into law on June 2. Also last month, Rockland County and the City of Long Beach on Long Island, while taking different approaches, started work on passing laws of their own.

GITTELSON--Stanley, M.D. Peacefully on June 29, 2006. Beloved husband to Joan (nee Derris) for 52 years. Loving father to Harry, Glenn and Lori, Anne, Madeline and Gary. Adored grandpa to Joseph, Zachary, Conner, Caroline, Morgan, Paige and Heather. Devoted brother to Dr. Arthur and Genie, the late Dr. Roger and Fern and Dr. David Derris. Loving uncle, great-uncle, cousin and loyal friend to many. Dedicated pediatrician who for 40 years cared for the children of the Merrick-Bellmore communities. Accomplished physician, scientist, patented inventor, musician and golfer with a sense of humor to match. An inspiration to all who knew him, he will be missed and never forgotten. Services Sunday, 10 A.M. at Gutterman's Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

Because of an editing error, a review on Page 10 of the Book Review today, about ''Radical Innocent: Upton Sinclair,'' by Anthony Arthur and ''Upton Sinclair and the Other American Century,'' by Kevin Mattson, misidentified the winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1930. Although Upton Sinclair campaigned for the award, it was won by Sinclair Lewis.

MANNERS--Sydney Howard, MD. Passed away peacefully June 28, 2006 surrounded by his wife, Marie-France and his daughter Robin. Cherished by his family, adored by his friends in NY and France and the patients to whom he dedicated himself for over 45 years in Family Medicine. Proud Royal Air Force Officer. Interment was private.

Jennifer Devereux, 18, of London, who is taking a ''gap year'' before entering the University of Birmingham: ''I had done an overland tour from Cape Town to Nairobi in a converted pickup truck. Along the way I did a sky dive in Namibia that had my mom in fits. She thought that after the sky diving, it was all finished, so I did one more thing to wind her up. Bungee jumping was just like flying, really. Or being about to plummet to your death. My mom and I had an agreement: I couldn't tell her what I was doing until I'd done it. Afterward, I texted her, 'Ooooh, about to do a bungee jump,' left a couple of minutes for her to worry, and then sent a text that said I had done it. She was just relieved I was in one piece. I had a bit of a headache, but that was cured by a beer.'' As told to Seth Kugel

IN May, the United States Senate passed the immigration reform bill with a last-minute rider requiring the National Park Service to reopen the Statue of Liberty's crown to visitors. On the surface, that sounds like a good idea. Why not allow tourists fuller access to perhaps the most recognized symbol of the United States? After all, the crown was open to the public for more than 100 years before being closed in reaction to the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center. But reopening the crown is not a good idea for a variety of reasons. And even talk of amendments proposing as much as $2 million to pay for its reopening simply doesn't make sense.

Even though her great-grandfather may have all but started a war to improve his newspaper's circulation, Amanda Hearst won't bare so much as a shoulder to raise male blood pressure. ''I like pieces that aren't revealing,'' said Ms. Hearst, 22, an art history major at Fordham University, part-time model and a descendant of William Randolph Hearst. ''I dress classically and sometimes conservatively, but with a younger edge,'' she said. Because of her wholesome beauty, the clothing company Lilly Pulitzer, whose preppy prints are synonymous with the Palm Beach cocktail circuit, recently chose Ms. Hearst to represent the label.

To the Editor: The author of ''Space Empties, and Time Rushes In'' (June 25) revels in her last child having left the ''nest'' for college. She complains about the ''ridiculously high suburban New York property taxes,'' but at the same time enjoys being ''deliciously self-indulgent'' by continuing to live in a house meant for four. Her ''deep roots'' in the community have convinced her to stay put.

The Rangers may not have made it far in the playoffs last season, but their newest player did. The Rangers signed Matt Cullen, a forward for the Stanley Cup champion Carolina Hurricanes, to a four-year deal worth $11.2 million yesterday, the opening day of the N.H.L.'s free-agent market.

Caring fatherin-law to Eddie, David, Lou and Michelle. Loving grandfather of Mikele, Ari, Ariella, Augusta, Isabella, Lilly, Gabrielle, Nikki, Jamie, Jacob, Josh, Sammy, Matthew, Jack and Dani. Adored Director and friend to the wonderful caring Robin Hood family. Our summers will not be the same without Uncle Gene. Funeral services at Temple Beth Shalom in Roslyn, NY at 10AM on Sunday, July 2. $(6$)ROBERTS--Eugene. Friendship and love last forever. Our families will always be one. Flo & Dick

Olivia was not allowed to sing the song in May 2005, when she was in second grade; school officials said it amounted to Christian proselytizing.

To the Editor: Emily Nussbaum praises Geoff Nicholson, the author of ''Sex Collectors'' (June 18) for ''puckish asides'' like ''If this is the sort of thing you like, you're going to like this sort of thing a lot.'' Puckish it may be, but Nicholson's it's not. It is a play on a line from Max Beerbohm: ''People who like this sort of thing will find this the sort of thing they like.'' Thomas Swick Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

WUESTENHOEFER -- C., Wm. 82, passed away July 1, in Florida. His wife Patricia predeceased him. Survived by children, Susan, Pamela and William, and a host of other family and friends. Visitation Wednesday, 11 am to 1 pm, at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY. Interment will be private.

BEARD--Margaret (Marion) Cuthbert. Died surrounded by her family on June 18 at Hope Hospice in Cape Coral, FL. She was born February 15, 1927, in Detroit, MI, and married John H. Beard in 1949. Mrs. Beard earned a BA in English literature and an MS in special education from Wayne State University in Detroit. Additional postgraduate work was done at Teachers College at Columbia University. Mrs. Beard was an early champion of mainstreaming children with learning challenges into the same classes as those without. Mrs. Beard worked as a teacher for homebound students, as a substitute teacher for a number of years, and later taught special education at Kean College in New Jersey. Mrs. Beard closed out her career in the Member Education Unit at Fountain House in New York, where her husband, the late John H. Beard, served as Executive Director from 1955 until his untimely death in 1982. Mrs. Beard retired in 1989 and moved to Cape Coral, FL, in 2000, to be near her daughter Margaret. Mrs. Beard is survived by a sister, Mary Louise Glen of Toledo, OH; a brother, Henry Cuthbert of Bloomfield Hills, MI; a daughter, Margaret L. Beard and son-in-law, Rick Eddy of Cape Coral, FL; a son, Jonathan R. Beard and daughter-in-law, Grace Nordhoff of Seattle, WA; and a granddaughter, Josephine Nordhoff-Beard of Seattle. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 9, 2006, at 2 PM, at the Unitarian Universalist Church of Fort Myers, 13411 Shire Lane, Fort Myers, FL 33912. The family will miss her greatly and asks that in lieu of flowers, memorials be directed to Hope Hospice, 9470 Health Park Circle, Fort Myers, FL 33908 or online at www.hopehospice.org

A superintendent from Long Island will take over the top job in the New Rochelle school district starting in August. Richard Organisciak, who leads the Deer Park school system, signed a contract last month for $230,000 a year. His tenure as school superintendent begins on Aug. 15. The Board of Education chose Mr. Organisciak on June 1 after a six-month search to find someone to replace Linda Kelly, who is retiring after 16 years as superintendent and 40 years in the New Rochelle school system. The district hired School Leadership, an educational search company in Port Jefferson, to consult on the hiring process. The firm held a public forum to find out what qualities parents wanted in the new superintendent and also received feedback from the teachers union, administrators, school staff and the leaders of the PTA. Six candidates were invited for interviews.

To the Editor: You claim that Gifford Miller, the former City Council speaker, ''never offered a better idea'' than reopening the East 91st Street marine transfer station (''Time to Move on Solid Waste,'' editorial, June 25).

MORRIS --Cornelia Kellogg On June 20th 2006, in Naples FL. Raised in Morristown, NJ; Attended Brearley School, then Bryn Mawr College. Fiercely loyal wife for 58 years to Grinnell, from a honeymoon on the Miramichi River to shooting woodcock in Maine; Proficient partners in tennis and on the dance floor -always in step. A thoughtful, loving mother, and a wonderful listener. Survived by sons Grinnell, Stephen, Frederic and Daniel, plus seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on August 26th at 1:00pm at Saint John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor. Contributions to Planned Parenthood.

''This biennial will have fewer than 40 artists in it'' has become the curatorial equivalent of ''The check is in the mail.'' But ''STILL POINTS OF A TURNING WORLD,'' the international biennial opening next Sunday at Site Santa Fe in New Mexico, could be the exception. KLAUS OTTMANN, the independent curator and critic who organized this latest incarnation -- the sixth -- has tackled head-on the chronic mega-biennial blights of self-obliterating sprawl and play-it-safe predictability. Not only do most biennials usually represent 50 to 100 artists, they also tend to concentrate on pretty much the same 50 to 100. You can rarely locate a curatorial viewpoint, and by the time you've waded through the show, you're usually too exhausted to care. Mr. Ottmann opted for radical reduction: his biennial has a mere 13 artists and, what's more, most of them are not among the usual suspects. They're from different continents, work in different mediums and range tremendously in age and prominence. Some, like the installation artist WOLFGANG LAIB, are former biennial regulars who haven't been so visible lately. Others, like the Conceptual painter JENNIFER BARTLETT and the post-Minimalist sculptor ROBERT GROSVENOR, are veterans of the American scene who have never been part of the circuit. Several are younger artists on their way up, like the performance-video artist PATTY CHANG, the painting-installation artist WANGECHI MUTU, the painter-videoist STEPHEN DEAN and a three-year-old Norwegian collective called THORNS LTD. Even the best known on the list have not attained white-hot art stardom: MIROSLAW BALKA, PETER DOIG, CRISTINA IGLESIAS, JONATHAN MEESE, CARSTEN NICOLAI and CATHERINE OPIE. Each artist will have plenty of space in Site Santa Fe's cavernous shedlike building. Such art-friendliness could also yield viewer-friendliness. Some people worry that Mr. Ottmann may have gone overboard and that his show actually has too few artists. Even if they are right, he should be commended for having the courage to think bold by simply thinking small. July 9 through Jan. 7, 1606 Paseo de Peralta, Santa Fe, N.M., sitesantafe.org.

An article last Sunday about the 2003 payout of $140 million in pension savings to Richard A. Grasso, then the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, referred incorrectly to Mr. Grasso's second contract with the exchange, signed in 1999. That contract was executed in May of that year by Bernard Marcus, then the chairman of the exchange's compensation committee, not by Kenneth G. Langone, who became the committee's chairman that June.

The longest losing streak of the Mets' season had something to do with their opponents. On consecutive days, they lost to Josh Beckett and Curt Schilling and got one hit against Mike Mussina and his relievers. The specter of Randy Johnson loomed next. Johnson, the Yankees' left-hander, can still inspire fear. He has accomplished more than all the pitchers who contributed to the Mets' four-game losing streak. But as he nears his 43rd birthday, he is not consistently dominant anymore.

An article on June 11 about golf landscapes by the painter Linda Hartough and a correction in this space last week referred incorrectly to the length of the ninth hole at the Winged Foot Golf Club. The entire hole, not the approach, is 510 yards, not feet.

Belly up to the Chocolate Bar in downtown Westfield and get ready for a confectionary buzz: chunky fudge brownies on sticks dunked in dark or milk chocolate ($2.50) share display-case space with hand-dipped almond biscotti ($1.75). Across the cramped but artfully arranged marble counter, strawberries ($2) and bananas ($2.50) drenched in the deep, dark stuff imported from France and Belgium come striped with a contrasting drizzle of white. This time of year, though, it is a subspecialty that has first-time customers wandering back to the three-year-old parlorlike bar for refills. Two dozen flavors of full-bodied gelato -- everything from carapino (caramel with pignoli nuts) to mi amore (strawberry chocolate chip) -- are firm enough to stand up to a crispy waffle cone edged in chocolate, but are just as satisfying scooped into a single-serving cup ($2.80) and savored in small bites.

COHEN--Elias A. Although 54 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun-filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige, his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 88th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President $(6$)COHEN--Elias A. Ever present in our thoughts, we lovingly recall our E.A. Cohen who left us 54 years ago on July 2, 1952. The Cohen Family The Elias A. Cohen Foundation
To the Editor: Re ''Dance Conducting: Good for the Nerves, if Not the Career'' by Roslyn Sulcas [June 25]:

To the Editor: Re ''No Retreat, No Surrender (They Hope)'' (June 18): It's almost sad that the United Automobile Workers is using a song from 1984 as its anthem of defiance, given the sea change that has transpired in organized labor, pensions and health care over the last 22 years.
ROULET--Jean. We miss you, but continue to celebrate your life. Your Sisters

IN four years, Carl Albanese, a 55-year-old freelance video producer, has amassed 50 hours of video recordings showcasing the reinvention of White Plains, from the demolition of vacant buildings to the construction of office and condo towers that dot its downtown. He has also taped countless Common Council meetings, registering the debates that preceded each step of the development for a documentary he plans to show on local cable TV. But some residents started to complain to City Hall about being filmed during the meetings, and Mayor Joseph M. Delfino began to question Mr. Albanese's intentions, said Paul Wood, the city's executive officer, who said he was speaking for Mr. Delfino. The mayor asked city lawyers if there was a way to control Mr. Albanese, and the lawyers found a 63-year-old ordinance limiting anyone from recording council meetings without advance consent.

Alicia Marie Marino, a daughter of Margaret M. Marino and Frederick M. Marino of Bernardsville, N.J., was married last evening to Bobby J. Pittman Jr., a son of Mary Lou Pittman of Clearwater, Fla., and Mr. Pittman Sr. of Naples, Fla. The Rev. John P. Langan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Dahlgren Chapel of Georgetown University in Washington. Mrs. Pittman, 28, received two master's degrees last month from the University of Chicago, one in business administration and the other in public policy. In September, she will join the Boston Consulting Group as a management consultant. She graduated from Princeton.

To the Sports Editor: The last sentence of Charles F. Dolan's touching tribute to his son James is revealing: ''What does startle me, I'll admit, is reading in The New York Times, of all places, such a rancorous column about the dynamics of a family-owned media company'' (In-Box, June 26).

An article on June 11 about golf landscapes by the painter Linda Hartough and a correction in this space last week referred incorrectly to the length of the ninth hole at the Winged Foot Golf Club. The entire hole, not the approach, is 510 yards, not feet.

MY dinner partner to the left was almost completely deaf, and every few minutes opened with the same conversational gambit. ''I was in the Battle of the Bulge, but I can't talk about it,'' he kept shouting. The dinner partner on my right, mercifully, was my father, who spoke in lower tones and was not using the occasion to review his own similarly traumatic memories of World War II. There were, however, many other reminiscences. The event was my dad's 60th college reunion, and I was his date for the weekend. My father and I share an alma mater -- Williams College, a small liberal arts school in New England known for its strong alumni devotion. He was in the class of 1946; I graduated 32 years later, in 1978.

IT is a question that occurs to almost everyone who becomes seriously ill: Should you go to your local hospital or would you do better if you went to a major medical center? It may mean a long trip when you are ill and it will almost certainly mean seeing doctors who are strangers to you. But what if going to a major medical center makes the difference between life and death? Patients reach different conclusions, based often on gut feelings about a doctor or a hospital. And medical researchers, looking for data, say they are not always certain themselves about how to decide. ''There really is very, very little information,'' says Dr. Elliott S. Fisher, a professor at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H., who studies medical outcomes. ''It's the great weakness of all the efforts to foster consumer engagement in health care decision making.''

MERINOFF--Herman. You have touched and enriched the lives of each of us, beyond description, teaching by example that integrity, morality and true partnerships arethe cornerstones of all success. Our gratitude, sorrow and loss are as deep as our commitment to live and work in the spirit of your vision, and we will make you proud. On behalf of The Associates of the Charmer Sunbelt Group $(6$)MERINOFF--Herman, I. It is with deep sorrow that Andrew Crisses, Howard Graff, Deborah Skakel, Malcolm Ross and their colleagues at Dickstein Shapiro Morin & Oshinsky LLP acknowledge the loss of their long time friend and client. Mr. Merinoff's dedication to family, philanthropy and business was an inspiration to all of us. We extend our condolences to his wife Susan, his children Linda, Cathy, Charles, Spencer, and Barbara, his extended family, and his friends. $(6$)MERINOFF--Herman I. The members, officers and staff of Metropolitan Package Store Association extend sincere condolences to the family and business associates of Herman Merinoff. He was a great leader of our industry, a man of distinction and class whose guidance, kindness and help to so many will be greatly missed.

HUGHES--Charles. Alexander. Of New York City, died quietly on June 21, 2006 after a long illness. We mourn the passing of our witty, cultivated and gentle brother and uncle, who devoted his life to the study of the world's languages. He worked for many years as a spontaneous translator and tour guide, and wrote language learning books which are still in use. Charles never failed to converse with people he met in their native tongue. His humor and equanimity, even in the face of physical adversity, inspired and delighted his family and friends. Born in Altoona, PA., in 1916, and educated first at Princeton University, Charles received undergraduate and graduate degrees from New York University and Columbia respectively. He is lovingly remembered by his surviving sister and brother, Helen Hafner, and William Hughes, of Gaithersburg, MD., by the family of his recently-deceased sister, Janet Stolz, of Chester Springs, PA., and as a loving grand uncle, great grand uncle, neighbor and friend. There will be a graveside service in Altoona at a later date.

I'M neither domestic nor handy. When it comes to dinner, I'm great at making reservations. When the house needs work, I call a contractor. It turns out that a good meal is easier to come by than an honest, reliable, affordable and skilled craftsman. Take the case of my front steps.

As the giant Pabst beer bottle looming over the Garden State Parkway in Newark was dismantled last week, nearby residents continued to ask questions about the safety of the demolition at the brewery, which is being razed to make way for more than 100,000 square feet of retail space and 179 affordable housing units. In December 2004, a group of more than 90 residents filed a petition asking the state's Environmental Justice Task Force to investigate whether asbestos or lead would be released into the neighborhood during the demolition process. The task force investigates questions and concerns about environmental hazards that might adversely affect minority communities and poor neighborhoods.

No teacher ever told me that William Shakespeare had a gold hoop earring and a mullet, or that he liked to wear crimson satin coats with slits. He was a real bohemian -- or at least that's the impression you get from several portraits on display at the Yale Center for British Art. They are part of ''Searching for Shakespeare,'' a captivating look at this famous and elusive man of letters. Organized by the National Portrait Gallery in London, where it debuted to rave reviews in March, the show sensibly avoids theories about who wrote Shakespeare's plays and concentrates on how Shakespeare lived his life. Many biographical details have been lost, but we do know that Shakespeare, born in 1564, was the eldest son of a glove maker from Stratford-Upon-Avon, grew up in a prosperous household, attended the local school and, at 18, sought a special dispensation from the Anglican Church to marry Anne Hathaway, 26 and pregnant.

MOSCHEL -- Ann Wasser man, 91, formerly of Indianapolis, IN, and East Brunswick, NJ, died May 4, 2006. Her husband, Irving, predeceased Ann on April 16, 2006. Graduating Mt. Sinai School of Nursing in 1936 and earning a nursing administration certificate from Columbia University, she served in the US Army Air Corps and US Army Nursing Corps in WWII. Mrs. Moschel's nursing career included Mt. Sinai, Lebanon Hospital, Middlesex Hospital (NJ), St. Peter's Hospital (NJ), and Indiana University Medical Center where she retired as Associate Director of Nursing Services for OB/GYN. She was an active leader for Hadassah, Sisterhood, and the Jewish War Veterans including serving on the national ''Women in the Military Committee.'' Born in New York City to Morris and Rebecca Wasserman, and raised in Coaldale, PA, she was preceded in death by brothers Samuel and Robert. Survivors include sister, Ethel Pankove, Boulder, CO; son, Richard Moschel, Sun City West, AZ; daughter, Beverly Hirsekorn, Centennial, CO, and six grandchildren.

I'M neither domestic nor handy. When it comes to dinner, I'm great at making reservations. When the house needs work, I call a contractor. It turns out that a good meal is easier to come by than an honest, reliable, affordable and skilled craftsman. Take the case of my front steps.

George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, stumbled on the stairs while exiting Yankee Stadium after yesterday's game. At the bottom of the stairs, Steinbrenner was prevented from falling over by his driver and by Yankees officials who accompanied him. After he regained his balance, Steinbrenner appeared confused when asked about the pitching performance of Randy Johnson, who gave up eight runs in six innings.

To the Editor: ''Taxes and Broken Promises'' (editorial, June 18) highlights one of the most important problems facing Connecticut. The politicians of our state Legislature refuse to address the problem in any meaningful manner. Rather, they give taxpayers a $500 credit on their income taxes one year and then immediately reduce it the next.

To the Editor: Jonathan Mahler, in his review of ''Just Americans,'' by Robert Asahina (June 18), writes about the executive order allowing ''any and all persons'' to be removed from designated areas: ''Of course, there was never any doubt about who those persons would be.'' He means Americans of Japanese descent. There was actually considerable doubt, both on the West Coast, where Lt. Gen. John L. DeWitt pressed hard from the days just after Pearl Harbor to rid the area of Japanese, German and Italian aliens and ''dangerous'' American citizens of enemy ancestry, and in Washington before political considerations settled the matter. All this was laid out nearly 20 years ago in journals and books, where readers can follow the story. Stephen Fox McKinleyville, Calif. The writer, a historian, is the author of ''UnCivil Liberties: Italian Americans Under Siege During World War II'' and ''Fear Itself.''

It's all about the beef at the American Burger Company in Huntington, where the walls are inscribed with lists of people who have taken the American Burger Challenge: eating the 4X4 Burger (four cheeseburgers piled on one bun) in one sitting. This red, white and blue burger stand honors the 4X4 champion, Jay (One Gallon) Choi, who got his nickname by eating ice cream and earned his American Burger title by downing six 4X4's in a row. His photo smiles down on customers from a poster hung above the griddle. The contest is one of many retro touches at American Burger, with its stainless-steel counter and lipstick-red leather booths. The owner, John J. Tunney III, is planning to open a branch in Hicksville later this month.

STERN--Enid. 1200 Tenant Corp. records with deep sorrow the passing of our leader, Enid Stern. For more than twenty years she guided the affairs of our building with grace and wisdom. Her many grateful friends at 21 East 87th Street/22 East 88th Street extend their heartfelt condolences to Bud and their children.

A PAIR of ducks sat on the muddy shore of the Neck River in Madison last Tuesday, oblivious to the environmental destruction taking place just under their feet. Vegetation in the salty marshes near Long Island Sound is dying off, putting plants and animals at risk and causing the shore to erode. Scientists call it sudden wetland dieback, but they are not sure how it started and what they can do to end it.

''I was in the Battle of the Bulge, but I can't talk about it,'' he kept shouting. The dinner partner on my right, mercifully, was my father, who spoke in lower tones and was not using the occasion to review his own similarly traumatic memories of World War II.
