My father and I share an alma mater -- Williams College, a small liberal arts school in New England known for its strong alumni devotion. He was in the class of 1946; I graduated 32 years later, in 1978.

ADDINGTON--Anne, Ph. D.Age 68, died peacefully at home in Greenwich, CT on June 10th after living with Multiple Sclerosis for 12 years. A native of Lake Forest, IL, she was the daughter of the late James R. Addington and Sarah Wood Armour, who survives her, as does her brother Whitney W. Addington, MD. Her brother Keene H. Addington predeceased her. Her beloved grandparents were General and Mrs. Robert E. Wood. General Wood was Chief Quartermaster during the building of the Panama Canal, later becoming President and Chairman of Sears Roebuck & Co. For a woman who never married nor had children, Dr. Addington had a huge family. She has eleven nieces and nephews and fifteen godchildren, and all their children consider Anne a grandparent. Anne attended Ethel Walker School and Smith College, graduating with a BA in Economics in 1959, and then earned her Ph.D. in Psychology from NYU. She served her patients, primarily children, with empathy and wisdom throughout her life. Anne loved sports, competing ferociously in squash, tennis and golf. She attended four Summer and two Winter Olympiads, but nothing thrilled her more than tennis. She attended each of the four Grand Slams and was a season ticket holder at the US Open. Despite deteriorating health, Anne remained a fixture at the US Open, able to walk and talk her way into any match or front row seat. Music was another passion of Anne's, especially opera. She was a Wagner enthusiast who experienced The Ring Cycle in numerous venues including Bayreuth. Anne studied opera for many years with conductor Robert Bass and frequently invited friends to join her Saturday afternoon excursions to The Met. Anne was a true original, a lover of life with a keen intellect and quick wit. Her homes were full of light, art, books and various pets, primarily large, undisciplined dogs. She approached the world with absolute openness, abundant curiosity and a deep compassion and respect for each of its citizens. Her numerous and varied friends, of all ages and walks of life, will never forget her. A memorial service is planned for Sept. 30th at the NY Historical Society. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society at 733 Third Avenue, NY, NY 10017 are deeply appreciated.

To the Editor: In ''The Heavy Bag Takes Hits, Then Slims Down'' (Practical Traveler, June 18), Charles Passy lets the airlines off too easily. If the weight issue were truly about total weight and the price of fuel, they would charge passengers for every pound over the specified weight limit for luggage.

IT is a question that occurs to almost everyone who becomes seriously ill: Should you go to your local hospital or would you do better if you went to a major medical center? It may mean a long trip when you are ill and it will almost certainly mean seeing doctors who are strangers to you. But what if going to a major medical center makes the difference between life and death? Patients reach different conclusions, based often on gut feelings about a doctor or a hospital. And medical researchers, looking for data, say they are not always certain themselves about how to decide. ''There really is very, very little information,'' says Dr. Elliott S. Fisher, a professor at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H., who studies medical outcomes. ''It's the great weakness of all the efforts to foster consumer engagement in health care decision making.''

STERN--Enid Gardiner. Died on June 29 in her Manhattan residence, succumbing to lung cancer after a year of illness. A native New Yorker, she attended the High School of Music and Art and Hunter College. Upon graduation she became an illustrator for William Douglas McAdams, a pharmaceutical advertising firm. In 1947 she married Leo Stern, Jr., who had begun a career in dentistry, and had a daughter Elizabeth and twin sons Jay and Tony. Enid has been reelected president of her cooperative apartment building, for over 20 consecutive years, and she and her husband have been active members of Sunningdale Country Club for over 50 years. They were active in conservation causes, and in 1972 made a strategic purchase, joined by three partners, of a scenic tract of 330 acres in the upper Beaverkill Valley which they preserved from further development in perpetuity. Loving sister to Robert Gardiner and grandmother to Charles, Joseph, Marguerite, Daniel and Eli. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Sunday, July 16 at 6 P.M. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be made to The National Resources Defense Council.

THE sign outside Nancy Pelosi's office bears the mark of her feminist roots: it identifies her as ''Ms. Pelosi,'' using the honorific created half a century ago to give women an alternative to disclosing their marital status. But mostly Mrs. Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, goes by just that -- Mrs. Pelosi.

Daphne Merkin's byline is always a sign that something special has arrived (June 18). So it was with her touching reminiscence about her father. The hunger she refers to, however, may well be one of the sources that powers her creative drive (which I'm sure has occurred to her), if that is any comfort. Thomas Collins Northport, N.Y. My father died when I was 15 months old. It wasn't until years later that I became aware that the unmet connection and unrequited longing haunting me had something to with a fatal loss and that I would spend the rest of my life trying to read the male animal, as I filled my life with father substitutes. Now 82 (productive, relatively peaceful), I find myself still hanging in there with Daphne -- restless, searching, hopeful, eternally optimistic. Lots of luck to us both. Gloria Vanderbilt New York I, too, was a ''forgotten girl.'' For me, no spontaneous hugs -- just chronic urging to improve my grades. My father was austere, often forbidding. Surely I had been shortchanged. This is what I had: a father who toiled all day at a post-office job for security. A father who, at the end of those insufferable days, took a sullen teenager to the family dentist (my teeth are now straight and beautiful). A father who faithfully picked me up from the innocent high-school dances of which he needlessly disapproved. I see it now: pure love was behind those small colorless tasks, silently expressed. Patricia Conway Wilmette, Ill.

If the cool illicit look of a tattoo beckons, but the fear of pain (and good common sense) stands in the way, you can still wear the classic designs of Norman (Sailor Jerry) Collins, a legendary American tattoo artist, in more removable ways. At www.sailorjerry.com, devotees of tattoo iconography can choose T-shirts, Converse sneakers, bags and even baby clothes emblazoned with patriotic eagles, anchors, leggy pinup girls and the skull and crossbones.

LARKIN--Rev. John P. On June 29, 2006. Son of the late William and Delia Larkin. Brother of the late William. Ordained March 25, 1944. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 pm, Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial Sacred Heart Church, Mt. Vernon, on Monday, July 3, at 10 am. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

To the Sports Editor: I enjoyed Dave Anderson's column on nicknames (''Where Have You Gone, Yankee Clipper?'' June 30). I was a little disappointed, though, that he didn't mention my favorite, George Selkirk, known as Twinkle Toes, which symbolized the fun rather than the brutish and dynastic aspects of the game, like Bronx Bombers, Sultan of Swat or even Iron Horse.

WILF--Judith. The Board and staff of the Israel Cancer Research Fund mourn the loss of the beloved mother of our dedicated friend, Leonard Wilf. Our deepest condolences to Mr. Wilf, his wife Beth, her sister Rose Blumenkranz, and the entire Wilf family. Service at 12 noon on Sunday, July 2nd, at the Jewish Educational Center in Elizabeth, NJ, 908-355-4850. Dr. Theodore Miller, President Dr. Yashar Hirshaut,Chair Simon Kaminetsky, Exec Dir $(6$)WILF--Judith. Sutton Place Synagogue extends our deepest sympathies to dedicated members and benefactors Leonard and Beth Wilf on the passing of Lenny's beloved mother. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire bereaved family.Allan Schranz, Rabbi Mark Wiener, President

Mets pitcher Steve Trachsel left yesterday's game against the Yankees with tightness in his right groin, but afterward he seemed much more concerned about the waning seconds of a World Cup match. ''Just let me see the television,'' Trachsel said, craning his neck as a crowd of reporters gathered in front of his locker.

FRANK SINATRA -- the undertaker, not the singer -- has been known as a serene presence here, where his unremarkable funeral home is wedged between a restaurant and an organic food store. But his soothing air, almost as much a trapping of his trade as sprays of lilies, went out the door when he tried to move his business to a new location. Now Mr. Sinatra and residents are sniping at each other in the local newspaper. Mr. Sinatra's initial aim seemed innocuous enough. Parking at his Hastings Funeral Home site on Spring Street, where he has been in business for a generation, is limited, and the access for the handicapped is poor. So he paid $1.6 million last year for a former State Farm Insurance office , at the busy corner of Jackson Avenue and Route 9A. The site -- opposite Mount Hope Cemetery and near a pair of headstone shops -- had everything, except for the correct zoning. It is zoned for office use, not funeral homes.

Even as Hector V. Barreto prepares to step down as the chief of the Small Business Administration, his most persistent critic continues to take shots at him. Mr. Barreto ''is a liar,'' said Lloyd Chapman, who runs the American Small Business League of Petaluma, Calif., criticizing the S.B.A.'s announcement that small businesses were awarded $79.6 billion in federal contracts in fiscal 2005.

CONNECTICUT children are healthier, and making healthier decisions, than their counterparts in most of the rest of the country, according to a report released last week. Teenagers in Connecticut die at a lower rate than anywhere else in the country, and the state also had the lowest percentage of children living in poverty, according to the most recent statistics released by the Annie E. Casey Foundation of Baltimore in its annual Kids Count survey. Over all, the state ranked third in the nation in the survey, trailing just New Hampshire and Vermont. Each year, the foundation tracks statistics on childhood health nationwide, though there is a time lag between when the statistics are collected and when they are released. The numbers in this year's report were compiled by the United States Census Bureau and the National Center for Health and were from 2003 and 2004, the most recent statistics available. The Census Bureau collected answers from surveys of parents and the National Center for Health got its numbers from birth and death certificates, said William O'Hare, a senior fellow with the Kids Count project.

IN case you watched the first two debates for the United States Senate seat this past week, the answer is: No, the two guys standing up there were not actors reprising the roles of George W. Bush and Al Gore, circa 2000. But at times, it seemed as if Senator Robert Menendez, in the role of Mr. Gore, Democrat, and State Senator Thomas H. Kean Jr., in the role of Mr. Bush, Republican, were doing their best imitations.

LOBIANCO--Anna. True partner of Bolivar Chiq Avila. Mother of Ruby and Dario. Sister of Yummy and Nina. Daughter of Dora and Tony. Ferocious mother, ferocious friend, compelling and powerful teacher and leader. Bravest of the brave young women. Her bright star shines on us all. Family and friends will be remembering her on Thursday, July 6th at the New York Historical Society, 2 W. 77th St entrance at 6pm. Donations can be made directly to Anna's family: Bolivar Avila, 14 Lockwood Road, South Salem, NY 10590.
A picture caption with an article on May 21 about Biloxi, Miss., misidentified the location of a street shown in an aerial view. It was Long Beach, Miss., not Biloxi, which is 19 miles away.
To the Editor: Re ''Iron Man Slows, and So Does the Industry'' by Jeff Leeds [June 25]:

County officials began hearing public comments last week on a proposal to make improvements to Westchester County Airport. The officials told the airport's neighbors that the projects would not lead to an increase in air traffic. The proposal addresses security concerns, environmental issues, safety and operations, as well as the future use of an 18.8-acre former Air National Guard site on the airport's property.

To the Editor: David Laskin's ''St. Petersburg: History Is Perennial in the Gardens of the Great Czars'' (Cultured Traveler, June 18) recalled our 2004 visit while river-cruising from Moscow to St. Petersburg. Parents might note that although these are long walks for little legs, the Peterhof gardens include several interactive ''trick'' fountains (they squirt water at innocent passersby) that children will enjoy. In pleasant weather, there's a happy bustle of local families spending the day outdoors.

IN four years, Carl Albanese, a 55-year-old freelance video producer, has amassed 50 hours of video recordings showcasing the reinvention of White Plains, from the demolition of vacant buildings to the construction of office and condo towers that dot its downtown. He has also taped countless Common Council meetings, registering the debates that preceded each step of the development for a documentary he plans to show on local cable TV. But some residents started to complain to City Hall about being filmed during the meetings, and Mayor Joseph M. Delfino began to question Mr. Albanese's intentions, said Paul Wood, the city's executive officer, who said he was speaking for Mr. Delfino. The mayor asked city lawyers if there was a way to control Mr. Albanese, and the lawyers found a 63-year-old ordinance limiting anyone from recording council meetings without advance consent.

SANCHEZ--Fernando. On June 28, 2006. Born in Belgium in 1935, educated in Paris and worked side by side with Yves Saint Laurent at Dior. He came to New York in the 1960s and went on to achieve international acclaim as a fashion designer. Survived by his beloved cousin and business partner, Jano Herbosch and her daughter Alessa Herbosch. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

To the Editor: ''Corzine Takes Lawmakers' Pay Off the Table'' (June 18) quotes State Senator Stephen M. Sweeney and Assemblymen Paul Moriarty and Gerald B. Green as supporting pay and benefits cuts for state workers. They claim that this would bring New Jersey ''back into the real world.'' According to the 2005 actuarial report for the Public Employees' Retirement System of New Jersey, in 2004 the average pension among the 37,430 retired state workers (not including police officers and firefighters or public college and university faculty whose pensions are on a separate national system) is $17,343, while 79,933 local government retirees collect on average $10,952.

Stefani Topol Orland, the daughter of Carole and Burton I. Orland of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Mark Lloyd Silverstein, a son of Lynne and Robert Silverstein of Great Falls, Va. Rabbi Seth L. Bernstein officiated at Essex House in New York. The bride, 23, and the bridegroom, 24, met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which they graduated, she cum laude and he magna cum laude. He finished his second year of law school at Penn in May, and she is to begin studying there in August for an M.B.A. degree.

The Q&A column last Sunday about finding low airline fares on the Internet gave an incorrect address for SkyLow, a fare-search and booking service. It is www.skylow.com.

When Sally Hershberger Face Place came out with its Supreme Lip Kit this season, no one expected the stir it would create as consumers rushed to polish their pouts. The product sold out at Barneys New York and on the Sally Hershberger Face Place Web site, and the demand generated lengthy waiting lists.

DRETZIN--David.The law yers and staff of Kauff McClain & McGuire LLP join his wife Joanna and daughters Rachel and Julie and their families in mourning the untimely death of David (Duff) Dretzin, our former partner, constant friend and dedicated mentor who died on June 26 from injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Duff founded Dretzin & Kauff, our firm's predecessor, with Jerry Kauff in 1972 and helped nurture and build the firm until his retirement in 1988. He remained active after his retirement, representing indigent defendants in death row cases and performing other pro bono work. Duff was a charming, intelligent, righteous and elegant man. He will be sorely missed.

The public has good reason to be wary of the motives of Steve Parrish and the tobacco industry (Joe Nocera, June 18). Even as tobacco companies claim to be fighting the battle against youth smoking, their methods ooze with reverse psychology. By warning adolescents not to smoke until they are older, cigarette corporations are in effect telling young people that smoking is an exclusively adult activity, off limits to children. I'm sure that message isn't intended to tempt teenagers, already craving to assert their independence, into lighting up. Jason Liebowitz Rockville, Md. If a cigarette manufacturer acknowledges the harm of its product, stops targeting the teenage demographic and spends money trying to help people to quit, is it fair to blame the company? There's nothing wrong with being suspicious of Altria's and Steve Parrish's motives, but at least this devil that we do know is trying, as opposed to those reckless new companies that would leap at the chance to usurp Philip Morris USA. A.C. Riccio New York Steve Parrish is probably correct when he says that ''if Philip Morris USA were to shut down tomorrow, it would not reduce the consumption of cigarettes at all.'' It's also correct that young kids can purchase dangerous narcotics on the street, whether I sell them to them or not. Still, I'm not going to do it. Robert Carlton Upland, Calif.

The long, layered dowager necklaces of last fall are still holding strong, but taking on new incarnations. The latest look is the lucky necklace: a chain or lanyard littered with charms and tokens meant to usher in good fortune. Nicole Schumann's delicate creations are made from 12-karat gold-filled chains that have intricate Victorian-style wood hearts, gold Buddhas, looping infinity signs and horseshoes ($258 to $695 at Searle stores). Pamela Fink's Good Charma line is moving from its rustic Balinese roots to a more luxurious feminine feel with intricate 22-karat gold vermeil and sterling silver chains that have 17 diminutive good-luck charms jingling in a row ($400 for gold, $225 for silver) and lacy oval-link chains with dangling turquoise stones, engraved Tibetan medallions and slender wishbones ($350 for gold, $195 for silver, all at Bloomingdale's stores). And Chan Luu's multicharm necklace for Henri Bendel showcases artfully random clusters of agates, tusks, carved disks and other mementos on the end of leather cords ($228 at Henri Bendel in New York) .

Brazil and England Toppled at the World Cup Members of the French national team, at right, celebrating their 1-0 win over Brazil, the defending champion and pretournament favorite, in the quarterfinals of the World Cup. Joining France in the semifinals was Portugal, which scored an upset by beating England on penalty kicks. SPORTSSUNDAY Mexico's Pivotal Middle Class Mexico's presidential race has been cast as one between a defender of the rich and a champion of the poor, but the deciding votes will most likely be cast by the middle class, many of whom were only recently lifted out of poverty. PAGE 8 Episcopalians Shaken by Rift Episcopalian parishioners are expressing concern about the future of their church after several dioceses announced plans to break away and the archbishop of Canterbury offered a plan that could limit regional churches' autonomy. PAGE 10 Shuttle Launching Postponed NASA scrubbed the launching of the Discovery minutes before liftoff because of threatening clouds. Liftoff is now set for 3:26 p.m. today. PAGE 14

LEWIT--Robert, 79. Died unexpectedly on June 20. Devoted husband to Mickey for almost 60 years. Cherished Dad to Wendy, Guy & Leslie. Father-in-law to Peggy and Dr. Lawrence Milner. Loving grandfather of Geoffrey, Randi and Jacob. Caring companion to Sandy for 14 years. Retired NYC newspaper and magazine distributor; dabbled in real estate. Witty, and wise. Loved by all.

Jeffrey Toback, a Nassau County legislator, has decided that he may have better luck getting Google to change its ways if he talks to it instead of suing it. Mr. Toback dropped a federal lawsuit last month that accused Google of profiting from child pornography. He filed the suit in early May, but now he says he hopes he can negotiate with Google to get it to improve its filtering system to keep child pornography links off its site.

To the Editor: It was refreshing to read ''C√©zanne's Provence'' (June 11) by Barbara Ireland. I am a student who just studied in Aix-en-Provence for four months. When I walked down the Cours Mirabeau every day, the pictures of Paul C√©zanne on the lampposts were constant reminders to me of the artist. I also remember several dinner talks where my French host would ask, ''Tu connais Paul?'' as if he wanted us to know the artist personally.

IT was the prom with strings attached. After some cases of student drinking at a Garden City High School dance in December, the principal, Hank Hardy, canceled two other dances on the calendar. That led many parents and seniors to fear that the prom itself would become a victim. After all, Kellenberg Memorial in Uniondale and Chaminade in Mineola had canceled their proms.

MY dinner partner to the left was almost completely deaf, and every few minutes opened with the same conversational gambit. ''I was in the Battle of the Bulge, but I can't talk about it,'' he kept shouting. The dinner partner on my right, mercifully, was my father, who spoke in lower tones and was not using the occasion to review his own similarly traumatic memories of World War II. There were, however, many other reminiscences. The event was my dad's 60th college reunion, and I was his date for the weekend. My father and I share an alma mater -- Williams College, a small liberal arts school in New England known for its strong alumni devotion. He was in the class of 1946; I graduated 32 years later, in 1978.

SWETZ--Elizabeth (Betty), died June 19th, 2006. Born September 11th, 1923 in Byesville, OH, she received her RN from the Cadet Nursing Corps and her BSN from Capital University, OH. In 1960 she moved to NYC, began working at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center until retirement in 1999. A longtime member of the Association of Operating Room Nurses (AORN), she served as President, Vice-President and member of the Board of Directors of AORN of NYC Chapter 3004, served on many committees, praised for her fundraising activities for the Chapter. She was a longtime member of Marble Collegiate Church, NYC. Memorial service at Marble Collegiate Church, 29th St. at 5th Ave., NYC (date to be announced).

If you have your traveling shoes on, like opera and want to get out of a hot city to enjoy a little of it, the LAKE GEORGE OPERA is offering what is being called the ''professional world premiere'' of NED ROREM'S ''OUR TOWN.'' (The opera had its first performances at Indiana University in late February.) This two-act setting of Thornton Wilder's famous play represents almost as much a legal as a musical victory. Wilder said he didn't want ''Our Town'' to be an opera and in the process thwarted aspiring eminences like Aaron Copland and Leonard Bernstein, who were both eager to get their hands on it. The estate, however, has relented, largely at the persuading of Mr. Rorem's librettist, J. D. McCLATCHY. Wednesday and next Sunday at 1 p.m., Saratoga Performing Arts Center, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., (518) 587-3330; $48 to $70; $5 off for students and 60+. If a subway ride is the most you are up for in the coming week, the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC is happy to refrigerate and relax you with a series of musical happy hours. Sunday at 3 p.m. at Avery Fisher Hall, the amiable BRAMWELL TOVEY conducts Borodin, Tchaikovsky and Prokofiev favorites, with the pianist ALEXANDER KOBRIN as soloist. The series continues on Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. with Mr. Tovey, but now offering Bernstein, Gershwin (with MARCUS ROBERTS as pianist) and F. MURRAY ABRAHAM narrating Copland's ''Lincoln Portrait.'' The same program repeats on Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Favorites by Rossini, Saint-Sa√´ns, Rimsky-Korsakov and Ravel take up Mr. Tovey's programs with the Philharmonic on Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. Sit back, feel the cool breezes of Avery Fisher Hall's admirable air-conditioning system and enjoy just about every old favorite you can think of. Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $19 to $49.

WHEN it comes to garage sales, everyone has a strategy. Shop early for selection. Shop late for bargains. Bring a list or let serendipity prevail. I'm from the undisciplined serendipity school, which means I have wasted a lot of money over the years. I once bought a huge wooden toboggan, only to find that it turned up regularly on the local garage sale circuit. Buyers would ride it downhill once, realize they could not pull it back uphill and sell it the next summer. We did the same. But the garage-sale fates have also bestowed upon me some of my favorite possessions: a footstool with bull's-eye trim, a stately pair of salt-and-pepper shakers, an eerie print of a century-old indoor swimming pool. None of them are treasures of an ''Antiques Roadshow'' sort; all of them make me smile.

IT is a question that occurs to almost everyone who becomes seriously ill: Should you go to your local hospital or would you do better if you went to a major medical center? It may mean a long trip when you are ill and it will almost certainly mean seeing doctors who are strangers to you. But what if going to a major medical center makes the difference between life and death? Patients reach different conclusions, based often on gut feelings about a doctor or a hospital. And medical researchers, looking for data, say they are not always certain themselves about how to decide. ''There really is very, very little information,'' says Dr. Elliott S. Fisher, a professor at Dartmouth Medical School in Hanover, N.H., who studies medical outcomes. ''It's the great weakness of all the efforts to foster consumer engagement in health care decision making.''

deadliest insurgent assault since the new Shiite-led government was installed in May, police officials and witnesses said. 1 Mexico's Middle-Class Vote Although Mexico's presidential race has been broadly cast as a fight between the rich and the poor, its outcome will almost certainly be decided by the country's middle-class voters, who have grown in number for the first time since 1995. 8 towns across the country are increasingly putting lobbyists on retainer to leverage their local tax dollars into federal tax dollars. Private lobbying firms have succeeded in acquiring federal appropriations, known as earmarks, for smaller cities. 1 A Split Among Episcopalians Six traditionalist dioceses and some individual parishes have announced plans to break from the Episcopal Church because they could not live with a church that permits an openly gay bishop and ceremonies for same-sex unions. 10 Vermont Dairy Farm Crisis Record rainfall, combined with dismally low milk prices and rising fuel prices, has Vermont's dairy farming industry in a crisis. The federal Department of Agriculture declared the entire state a disaster zone. 10 Shuttle Launch Delayed NASA scrubbed the launching of the shuttle Discovery minutes before its scheduled liftoff as threatening clouds encroached on the 20-mile boundary around the Kennedy Space Center. 14 NEW YORK/REGION 25-29 New Jersey Shutdown Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey signed an executive order shutting down the state's government for the first time in its history. The order resulted from an impasse over the budget for the new fiscal year. 1 Bloomberg's Next Step Mayor Bloomberg, taking the first concrete steps toward his post-mayoral life, has all but completed the purchase of a $45 million Beaux-Arts building to house the philanthropic foundation he plans to create, according to a person with knowledge of the transaction. 25 OBITUARIES 30-31 Jaap Penraat An architect and industrial designer who saved 406 Jews in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands, he was 88. 30 Chess 29 Weather 20

BULLOUGH--Vern. Vern Bullough a life long champion of civil liberties recently died. He worked for justice through his research and writing and with his associations with groups like the American Civil Liberties Union and the NAACP. He spent many years working to improve housing equal opportunities for all people. He was a strong believer in the separation of church and state and was an active humanist. SUNY Distinguished Professor emeritus and former dean of the Faculty of Natural and Social Sciences at Buffalo State, Vern L. Bullough, R.N., Ph.D., was a pioneer in many fields from the study of the cultural and biological aspects of human sexuality to the effectiveness of military deterrence. Vern Bullough has received numerous awards for his activism and scholarship, including the 1995 Alfred Kinsey Award, of which he was co-recipient with his late wife, Dr. Bonnie Bullough, former dean of the School of Nursing at the University at Buffalo. He has served as co-president of the International Humanist and Ethical Union, and is a past president of the Society for the Scientific Study of Sexuality and a founder of the American Association for the History of Nursing. Vern Bullough was a distinguished scholar in many fields. Using G.I. Bill benefits after being in the army, he received his Bachelor's degree from the University of Utah. He then went on to receive his Ph.D. from the University of Chicago. As a professor he taught at University of Youngstown; California State University Northridge; and the State University of New York at Buffalo. The author, coauthor, or editor of more than 50 books, Vern Bullough has also contributed chapters to more than 100 publications and has written hundreds of refereed and popular articles. As a middle aged student he studied Nursing at California State University Long Beach. He received many prestigious awards, grants and fellowships. Vern has lectured in most of the 50 states and more than 25 countries, including Australia, China, Egypt, Ghana, Greece, Mexico, and Russia. Vern's death was preceded by his brother Bert Bullough; his son David Bullough; his sister-in-law Janice Neumann Bullough; and his partner of over 50 years Bonnie Bullough. He is survived by his brothers and sister: Darwin Bullough, Duane Bullough, Karen Hyde and their families; his sons Jim Bullough-Latsch, Michel Hayworth, Steve Bullough, his daughter Sue Bullough; his partner since 1998 Gwen Whitehead Brewer; and most importantly his granddaughter Jamie Bullough-Latsch. Vern is also the contributor to several scholarship funds and encouraged the support of libraries, lectureships and the preservation of liberties. His web site www.vernbullough.com lists some of the organizations he recently donated to. His papers and the Vern and Bonnie Bullough Special Collection are housed at California State University Northridge Oviatt Library www.csun.edu . Vern Bullough felt that a citizen had the duty to vote and had the duty to contribute time and efforts to improve the overall quality of life for all beings without regard to race, gender, religion, handicaps, ethnic origins, or sexuality orientation. He dedicated his life to these beliefs.

MERINOFF - Herman. Our dear friend Herman who modeled life for us in such a wonderful unconventional way--you will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to our dearest Sue & the entire Merinoff family. We love you. Hazel & Marvin Shanken

''HEADING SOUTH,'' the third film by the French director LAURENT CANTET, pushes as many buttons -- political, racial and sexual -- as a movie could hope without straining to be all things to all people. The film, which opens on Friday in New York, was the strongest entry in this year's Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series at Lincoln Center. Earlier it was shown at the Toronto Film Festival, where critics, nervous about its subject matter, greeted it with guarded approval. CHARLOTTE RAMPLING, in one of her most fearless performances, plays a 55-year-old college teacher of French literature taking her annual vacation at an out-of-the-way Haitian resort in the late 1970's. She is the queen bee among a gaggle of unattached middle-aged women from Europe and North America who flock there to enjoy the sexual company of handsome, impoverished black beach boys. The visitors lavish gifts and cash on them in exchange for love. Without judgment, the film, adapted from three stories by DANY LAFERRI√àRE, explores the intersections of cultural imperialism, sexual tourism and women's liberation in a repressive dictatorship. Much as the proud Haitian hotel workers loathe the rich visitors who exploit them, they desperately welcome their needed dollars. These relationships may be commercial, but they are also tender. Weighing the value of erotic pleasure and the emotional risks involved in its pursuit, the women address questions of sex, love, aging, loneliness and desire in blunt personal monologues. The movie is a powerful reminder that indeed the personal is political. Lincoln Plaza Cinemas, Broadway at 63rd Street, (212) 757-2280, and Angelika Film Center, Mercer and Houston Streets, Greenwich Village, (212) 995-2000. (The film also opens July 21 at the Laemmle Royal Theater in Los Angeles.)

P. T. BARNUM, this city's most famous resident and for a time its mayor, once wrote, ''The bigger the humbug, the better people will like it.'' For those who find that remark inscrutably concise, a sign in the Barnum Museum here explains: ''He knew that the public enjoyed being fooled provided they were also educated and entertained at the same time.'' Well, the people of Bridgeport have certainly been educated and entertained in recent years -- all while being fooled. Just three years ago, the mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, was sent to prison for nine years for taking kickbacks of $500,000 in cash, meals and Oriental rugs. Contractors would park on the roof of the City Hall Annex and scramble down a private staircase into the mayor's opulent office, without his secretary even noticing, just to be shaken down.

''If we didn't have foundations to run, Howie would farm. I would be sewing, knitting and quilting.'' SUSIE BUFFETT, who with her brothers, Howard and Peter, helps oversee the philanthropy of their father, Warren Buffett. [14]

Avian flu tends to kill younger people, much as the 1918 Spanish flu epidemic did, the World Health Organization said Friday as it released an analysis of more than 200 cases. Deaths from the disease surged in the winter for the last three years, the report said, so a rise in fatal cases can be expected late this year even if the virus does not mutate into a form more easily transmitted.

BRADY--John X. Sr., ''Jack'', born 1929 in Queens NY, died June 28, 2006 in Orlando FL. Resident of Smithtown, NY, La Canada, CA, S Natick, MA & Heathrow, FL. Predeceased by parents Edward and Grace, brothers Rev Fr Justin CP and Thomas. Survived by wife of 47 yrs Theresa, 5 children & 8 grandchildren. Summa Cum Laude St John's University & Beta Gamma Sigma Columbia University Graduate School of Business. Former executive MW Kellog & JC Penny; former executive director Cravath, Swaine & Moore and Latham & Watkins. Combat-decorated veteran officer Korea. CARITAS medal & Knight Commander of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. Through all he sought simplicity, quiet & peace, avoided pretense and always tried to find and speak the truth; dearly loved God and family & friends; truly a servant, always gave from an unselfish nature. May he rest in the bosom of the Lord he served on faith alone.

COHEN--Dr. Jay Alpert. We are profoundly saddened by the passing, on June 29, of our lifelong friend Jay. A warm, witty, cultivated man. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. The Gaba Family

To the Editor: Harold Bloom ends his review of Rebecca Goldstein's ''Betraying Spinoza'' (June 18) with the exhortation: ''Read his 'Ethics.' It will illuminate you.'' Let me warn your readers not to take Bloom's advice. Spinoza's ''Ethica more geometrico demonstrata'' is a crushing bore, utterly unreadable as it moves pedantically from one ''theorem'' to the next, and of course it does not demonstrate anything, either geometrically or otherwise. P. G. Kafka Bellevue, Wash.

Maybe it's not as big a shock for music fans as the day Bob Dylan went electric at the 1965 Newport Folk Festival, but Bruce Springsteen going folkie is certainly unexpected. In ''BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN -- THE SEEGER SESSIONS LIVE,'' a ''Great Performances'' special on PBS stations Wednesday night (check local listings), Mr. Springsteen pays tribute to PETE SEEGER, 87, with a program of songs Mr. Seeger made popular, including ''John Henry,'' ''Jacob's Ladder'' and the civil rights anthem ''We Shall Overcome.'' It's basically an hourlong plug for his new album and tour, but we'll take Springsteen any way we can get him. STEVE BRIDGES, the Bush impersonator, was a hit working side by side with the president at the White House Correspondents' Association dinner in April. He'll perform for the first family again on ABC's holiday gala ''AN AMERICAN CELEBRATION AT FORD'S THEATER: THE JULY 4TH SPECIAL'' (Tuesday night at 10). Heaven knows shows like these need laughs, so it's good to learn that in addition to the musical acts (including HEATHER HEADLEY and the country group LONESTAR), KEVIN NEALON will perform, and that TOM SELLECK, who can be funny under the right circumstances, is the host. NBC's special ''MACY'S 4TH OF JULY FIREWORKS SPECTACULAR'' is conveniently scheduled for 9 p.m., so viewers can watch both. The new version of ''Doctor Who,'' the British adventure series about a time traveler who faces aliens and other annoyances, had its premiere on the Sci Fi Channel in March. And on Tuesday ''DOCTOR WHO -- THE COMPLETE FIRST SEASON'' will be released on DVD. The stars are CHRISTOPHER ECCLESTON (he did only one season before his character regenerated into DAVID TENNANT) and BILLIE PIPER (who is leaving the series after the second season). And if you happen to be in London on Saturday, you can catch the second-season finale.

CITIES and states have long fought under-age drinking, easily passing laws that make it illegal in public, but not so easily passing and enforcing laws that make it illegal on private property. The ability of minors to drink in their homes, or in the homes of others, is an old, stubborn behavior, spawning countless teenage house parties that the police have found difficult to combat. But states and municipalities in the region have been chipping away at the problem. A Connecticut law targeting adults who allow drinking by minors was signed into law on June 2. Also last month, Rockland County and the City of Long Beach on Long Island, while taking different approaches, started work on passing laws of their own.

SUMMER music festivals have gone the way of the nation's food supply: much is produced to satisfy the masses, with a determined subset of finicky listeners holding out for a more homegrown sound. In New Jersey, where a sprinkling of major festivals coexist alongside a shower of minor ones, Clinton's annual Black Potatoe Music Festival may be to the high-minded indie music movement what food co-ops are to organic gourmands -- an inspiration and a source of hope.
.. Because of an editing error, an article on June 18 about ceramic materials in brakes misstated the price of the Bentley Continental GT Diamond Series. It is $189,900, not $210,000.

Dr. Deborah Lisa Hillman, a gastroenterologist, and Dr. Neal David Goldberg, a plastic surgeon, are to be married this evening by Rabbi Hillel Friedman at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The bride, who graduated from Princeton, and the bridegroom, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, received their medical degrees from New York University, where they met.

Maybe it was somebody's idea of a very inside joke. But for some time now New York State officials have referred to a huge pool of hidden money appropriated by lawmakers each year as the ''007 accounts.'' These accounts amount to $200 million each year to finance a long list of pork-barrel projects across the state. The funds are controlled by state leaders and appear in the budget in anonymous chunks, listed under health care, economic development or some other broad category. This is camouflage for hundreds of so-called member items -- small and medium-size public projects in each legislator's home district. The clandestine way that 007 money is parceled out would make Q himself proud.

The invitation said to wear white, and most of the 600 guests at a party celebrating the 100th anniversary of the Payne Whitney mansion at 972 Fifth Avenue complied. The building, designed by Stanford White, now houses the cultural services of the French Embassy and the many French guests took the dress code particularly seriously, jewelry, bags, shoes, hats and all. Men often took the easy road, wearing white shirts and white jeans. The theme extended to the white cosmopolitans, canap√©s, chocolates and calla lilies. Many of the guests moved outside to linger in the mansion's garden among the trees -- birches, of course.

To the Editor: Re ''When the Librarians Come Marching In,'' by Bob Greene (Op-Ed, June 29): As one of the thousands of librarians who spent several days attending the American Library Association conference in New Orleans, I was struck by the almost zealous cleanliness of my hotel room and the convention center, and the very real gratitude of everyone I encountered.

SOLOWIEJCZYK - Anita. Cherished wife of Henry. Loving mother to Joseph, Jack, David and Alan. Devoted grandmother to Arielle, Joshua, Gabrielle, Joelle and Dylan. Loved mother-in-law of Mara and Ivy. A beautiful woman who was known for her smile and warmth. Always put other people's needs ahead of her own. She was truly an eishess chayil characterized by her sensitivity and compassion for all she knew and touched by her big heart. Her large presence will be missed, but will always be with us. She was a woman with style and grace and lived life to its fullest. Services to be held at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76th St, Monday, July 3, 11:45 am.

RECTOR--Milton G.,The former President and Chief Executive Officer of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, died Saturday June 24th, at age 88. Milton Rector was widely recognized as a leader in the field of Criminal Justice. Prior to joining NCCD, Milton began his career as a Deputy Probation Officer and director of a Forestry Camp for delinquent juveniles in Los Angeles County. He served in the Navy during WWII, and later in the Naval Reserves, retiring with the rank of Commander, U.S.N. He completed his undergraduate work with a BA from the University of Southern California and began his graduate work at the University of California, receiving a MSW from Columbia University. As a member of the NCCD technical staff, he participated in and directed numerous studies assessing correctional, court and community services, which dealt with crime prevention, control and treatment of offenders. In his position as President of the NCCD, Milton seized upon opportunities to develop an international perspective of criminal justice and to serve on many federal, state and local commissions as well as private sector positions. Through appointments by Presidents Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon he represented the United Nations in the Social Defense (now the Criminal Justice) Section of the U.N. After retiring, he served as a visiting professor for study of Criminal Justice at the Graduate School of Social Work, University of Utah from 1982-1984. For 65 years, Milton was the beloved husband of the late Harriet Rector. He was the devoted father of Dianne Funke and Bruce Rector, grandfather of Michael and Sharon Funke and great-grandfather of Julia and Christian Funke. A private family memorial service will be held.

Diane Wenbi Lai, a daughter of Yung Yung Lok and Dr. Eugene C. Lai of Houston, is to be married today at the Codman Carriage House in Lincoln, Mass., to Keigo Hirakawa, a son of Michiko and Hiroshi Hirakawa of Hudson, Ohio. Adithya Raghunathan, a friend of the bridegroom, was authorized by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate. The bride, 28, is known as Wenbi. She is an engineer in the quality assurance group at Draper Laboratory, a company in Cambridge, Mass., specializing in military, space and biomedical research and development. She is also a violinist with the Longwood Symphony Orchestra, which is mostly made up of medical professionals in Boston. She graduated from Cornell, where she also received a master's degree in engineering management.

IN PHILANTHROPY The News -- Warren E. Buffett, one of the world's wealthiest men, said he would give most of his billions to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Behind the News -- Mr. Buffett, 75, had said in the past that he wouldn't give away his money until after his death, but apparently his close relationship with Mr. Gates made him change his mind. The donation, which will amount to about $31 billion, doubles the size of the Gates organization, making it by far the largest grant-making foundation in the United States. Experts in philanthropy said that what made Mr. Buffett's decision even more remarkable was the apparent lack of ego involved: most people who donate an enormous sum of money would create an institution in their own name. IN DIPLOMACY The News -- Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan and President Bush presented a united front against North Korea. Behind the News -- After talks with Mr. Bush at the White House, Mr. Koizumi said Japan would ''apply various pressures'' on North Korea if that country tested a long-range missile. But the security discussions were far from the highlight of the two-day visit by the Japanese leader, one of Mr. Bush's closest foreign partners. The president took Mr. Koizumi, a huge Elvis fan, to Memphis for a visit to Graceland, treating everyone to fried peanut butter and banana sandwiches, the King's favorite, on the way. Mr. Koizumi paid tribute to his hero by singing ''Love Me Tender'' in the Jungle Room. IN DEATH The News -- Nathaniel Hawthorne was reunited with his wife, Sophia, at a cemetery in Concord, Mass., after nearly a century and a half. Behind the News -- The author was buried in the cemetery in 1864, but Sophia, by all accounts one of his major sources of inspiration, was buried seven years later in London, where she had resettled. A Roman Catholic order of nuns founded by Hawthorne's daughter Rose financed the reinterment of Sophia and another daughter, Una, by saving $15,000 out of living expenses. The nuns, based in Hawthorne, N.Y., care for terminally ill cancer patients. ''Taking care of the deceased is an act of mercy,'' one of them said, ''and it's an act of our faith.'' IN THEATERS The News -- Superman and Lois Lane were together again in ''Superman Returns.'' Behind the News -- The film, the latest repackaging of the Superman saga, got middling reviews but did boffo box office, earning $21 million in its first day as it headed into the long holiday weekend. As for the Man of Steel (played by Brandon Routh) and Lois (Kate Bosworth), their on-again, off-again romance of previous films is now mostly off. In this incarnation, Lois has both a child (of uncertain lineage) and a fianc√© who -- great Caesar's ghost! -- is the son of Perry White, Clark Kent's old boss at The Daily Planet.

HEILIGMAN--Dr. Sol J. After a life-long friendship of 72 years, I bid a sad farewell to my dear friend, Sol. It was a great ride, but it ended too soon. Fare thee well, Sol. Gene Grant $(6$)HEILIGMAN--Dr. Sol J. Age 90, on June 24, 2006, at his country home on China Lake, Carmel, NY. Beloved husband of the late Shirley Sperans Heiligman, devoted stepfather of Andrew (Nan), and Tom (Randy), loving uncle of Janet Heiligman, and brother-in-law of Phyllis (Parker). He was born in Fort Wayne, IN. At an early age, his widowed mother brought him and his four siblings to New York. He graduated from CCNY (B.S.) in 1937, and the University of Michigan (Doctor of Dental Surgery) in 1941. In WWII, he served with distinction as a Captain in a Combat Artillery Regiment in Europe. After the war, he volunteered as a Dental Surgeon on the ship ''Project Hope'' in Nicaragua for several seasons. He then embarked on a long and distinguished career in Dental Medicine in New York City, specializing in Periodontia. In recent years, he was a respected volunteer in the Ichthyology Dept. of the American Museum of Natural History. An avid sportsman, he loved tennis, skiing, horseback riding, canoeing and wilderness camping. A bachelor until he was 52, he was married to Shirley Sperans Karsch for 35 years, until her untimely passing in 2003. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue/81st Street, at 4pm, on Thursday, June 29. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Marymount College, East 71st Street, NY, NY in loving memory of Dr. Sol and Shirley Heiligman.

The thoroughly original Japanese rockers known as BOREDOMS were scheduled to set up an exhibition-concert called ''77 Drum'' for several days at Deitch Projects in SoHo. It was to open on Friday, and there were to be 77 drum kits of various sizes arranged around a circular stage, where the band would play. Anyway, no such luck. ''77 Drum'' was canceled for logistical reasons; the band says it may be rescheduled. Instead, Boredoms will play a single New York show. Reports from other cities on the tour suggest it will be like the show here last year. In that one the singer YAMATAKA EYE began with a gestural dance in the dark holding a pair of amplified lights: the faster he swung them and the louder he sang, the brighter they glowed. Then the band, which now consists of three drummers besides Mr. Eye and his spaghetti of electronic instruments, started in with long, overlapping, slowly building grooves. The band Lightning Bolt will open. Tonight at 7, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (866) 468-7619; $25. SIX ORGANS OF ADMITTANCE boils down to one person, BEN CHASNY, who makes his music flicker between folk textures and torching guitar distortion. He's into meditative music, basically, with lots of repetition, whether it's light or heavy. But he's not a flower child or a bore, and you get the sense that he has thought hard about what he wants to do before he does it. Thursday at 10 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, East Village, (212) 260-4700; $12.

From 1929 until his death in 1972, Joseph Cornell spent much of his time at home in Queens, caring for his sick mother and invalid brother. He had no life to speak of, no friends and very little in the way of physical relationships. What he did have was his art, box assemblages made at night in the basement. The thrust of his life is in these artworks, almost 50 of which are on display at the Katonah Museum of Art in an intimate, elegantly installed exhibition put together by Therese Lichtenstein, an independent curator.

Upper West Side One-Bedroom $719,000 MANHATTAN: 410 Central Park West (between 100th and 101st Streets), #4D A one-bedroom, one-bath co-op. Lew Schneider, Bellmarc Realty (212) 688-8530, ext. 269; www.bellmarc.com MAINTENANCE: $657 a month PROS: This clean, 630-square-foot apartment across the street from Central Park is nicely laid out, with bathroom access from both bedroom and living room and an eat-in kitchen far from the bedroom. There are beamed ceilings and crown moldings as well as remote-controlled air-conditioners. The galley kitchen has granite countertops and plenty of cabinet space. The building has full-time doormen, laundry facilities and bicycle storage. Pets are allowed. CONS: Some of the windows face a wall. Two-Bedroom Co-op $1,295,000 MANHATTAN: 50 West 67th Street (between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West), #8C A two-bedroom, one-bath co-op. Arabella Greene, Brown Harris Stevens (212) 588-5614; www.brownharrisstevens.com MAINTENANCE: $1,215 a month PROS: This 900-square-foot apartment in the Musicians Building on the Upper West Side has acoustically lined walls high ceilings, delicate prewar details, a wood-burning fireplace, a Juliet balcony and arched windows with views of 67th Street. A foyer opens into the living space (which is large enough to include a dining area), and there are windows in both the kitchen and the bathroom. The building has laundry facilities, bicycle storage and full-time elevator operators. Pets are allowed. CONS: The apartment lacks closet space. CONS: The four flights of stairs might be daunting for some. GERST--Hilde W. A prominent art dealer and gallery owner in New York City, died on June 30, 2006, at the age of 98. Born in Central Europe and educated at French boarding schools, she traveled widely after World War II, which provided her the opportunity to collect works of art and antiques from various parts of the world. In 1953, she opened her art gallery on Madison Avenue, which she continued to operate personally until her recent illness. Her gallery became known for the high quality of its collection. She was renowned for her expertise in the area of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist artists and their works. She had a devoted following and was held in high esteem by clients and art dealers worldwide, many of whom became personal friends and frequent visitors to her home, and her gallery at the Carlyle Hotel. She was a member of the Foreign Policy Association and was involved in local and national political affairs. An extraordinary woman, a captivating hostess and a friend and confident of many, she is survived by her son, Paul, a surgeon, of Tenafly, NJ; her daughter, Ruth Silberstein and husband Ronald Silberstein, of Newton Centre, MA; six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Her husband, Dr. David Gerst, died in 1972. Services at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, on Wednesday, July 5, at 1:30 PM. Interment at Linwood Memorial Park, Randolph, MA. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, DC 20024-2126.

The Streetscapes column last Sunday about the Commandant's House at the Brooklyn Navy Yard misstated the completion date for Gracie Mansion, another important house built in the same era. It was finished in 1799. (An addition to the mansion was completed in 1804.)

ROSENBLATT--Hortense, (nee Weinstock), died on May 31, 2006 in San Franciso at the age of 85. Pre-decaesed by husband William, she is survived by her daughters Nan and Jane, son-in-law Jeffrey, brother Louis, and grandchildren Zachary and Lauren. Her fun loving spirit will be greatly missed.

When JOS√â RIVERA first imagined himself into the mind of Che Guevara for the 2004 film ''The Motorcycle Diaries,'' Guevara was a 23-year-old medical student named Ernesto heading off on a 7,500-mile trek with a friend to see South America and pick up girls. Mr. Rivera finished writing the movie, but he wasn't finished with his subject. He was intrigued enough to write a play about the famed revolutionary, not at a time of fresh-faced enthusiasm but on the night before his execution in Bolivia in 1967, after the failure of his guerrilla campaign. ''SCHOOL OF THE AMERICAS,'' now in previews, is based on Guevara's encounter with a village schoolteacher who wangled her way into the tiny schoolhouse where he was kept before his death. Mr. Rivera found out about the episode while doing research for the movie. Guevara was a prolific writer, so if you're interested in going to the source, consider reading ''THE BOLIVIAN DIARY,'' compiled from notebooks found in his knapsack after his death, or ''THE MOTORCYCLE DIARIES: NOTES ON A LATIN AMERICAN JOURNEY,'' his own account of his youthful excursion. For an outsider's look at his life, try Jon Lee Anderson's 1997 biography, ''CHE GUEVARA: A REVOLUTIONARY LIFE.'' Or to see how another artist mixes fact and fantasy, get Jay Cantor's beautiful first novel, ''THE DEATH OF CHE GUEVARA.'' Sartre once called Che ''part of the great myths of this century -- our era's most perfect man.'' And now Mr. Rivera has contributed to the myth-making myth by imagining not only a beginning in Che's brief life, but also an end. Opens Thursday and runs through July 23, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, (212) 239-6200 or (800) 432-7250; $25 to $50.

THE iambic pentameter of William Shakespeare will again be heard in the amphitheater at Pettoranello Gardens in Princeton this summer, thanks to an agreement between the Princeton Rep Shakespeare Festival and the Joint Recreation Board of Princeton Borough and Princeton Township. Princeton Rep canceled its summer season last year when the board would not award the theater troupe a multiyear contract. ''The Princeton Recreation Board compromised, and we compromised, and that's why we're back,'' said Victoria Liberatori, Princeton Rep's co-producing artistic director.

Debora Tamar Cahn and Michael Adam Heller were married on Thursday by Blanca Martinez, a community associate, at the New York City Municipal Building. Jeffrey Cahn, a member of the Kehilat Romemu congregation and the brother of the bride, is to lead a Jewish ceremony today at the Faculty House at Columbia. Ms. Cahn, 35 is keeping her name. In April, she became a supervising producer and writer in Los Angeles for ''Grey's Anatomy,'' the Touchstone television program on ABC. From 2002 until April, she was a producer and writer for Warner Brothers on ''The West Wing,'' the NBC program, for which she won a 2005 Writers Guild Award. She graduated from Barnard College and received a master's degree in acting from the American Repertory Theater's Institute for Advanced Theater Training at Harvard.

Are Detroit's chronic problems to be blamed on the American executives who run the car companies? Toyota must not think so. It just promoted two General Motors alumni to top manufacturing jobs. Gary L. Convis, who once worked at Ford and spent 15 years as a G.M. employee before joining Toyota in 2000, was named chairman of Toyota Motor Manufacturing Kentucky, one of five Toyota factories in the United States. Steven St. Angelo, who spent three decades at G.M., succeeded Mr. Convis as president.

Many people who are not interested in car races think that people who are interested in them like to watch them in order to see the accidents. But I don't know any race fans who would rather see a really great accident than a really great race without accidents. Maybe sometimes if you don't want a particular driver to win, you don't mind if they go off with a broken car on the first corner.
After being laid low by a cold, the Frugal Traveler recovers and explores Kefalonia, the largest Greek island in the Ionian Sea, by scooter.
In Sunday's column about China, I had a reference to why China was reluctant to devalue the yuan -- of course, that should have been "revalue" rather than "devalue." We'll have a correction soon.

I had planned to leave Saturday for the Chad/Darfur border, but then had to delay my travel plans. Maybe it's just as well. My base was going to be the border town of Ade, and today the Janjaweed and its associated Chadian rebels attacked Ade. There apparently was fierce fighting, and both sides say they won.

As some of you have no doubt noticed, we've been not just blogging but also moblogging the World Cup, by posting images and video here of fans in New York watching the matches in Germany. Even a quick look at these images shows that fans here have been living and dying with each touch of the ball, just as hundreds of thousands or millions of their fellow countrymen and countrywomen have been doing back home and in other parts of the world in the temporary enclaves that form around television sets in bars, restaurants and social clubs whenever matches are played. Below is a slide-show collection of those images, taken on and transmitted back here via camera-phone while the games were in progress, presented through the miracle of Flickr.com.

In the United States, TV coverage of the World Cup in English and Spanish might be setting such benchmarks as drawing more viewers than Nascar and the U.S. Open golf tournament, attracting close to the audience that watched the NBA finals, and getting the highest rating on ESPN2 this year -- but that's just child's play compared with the TV ratings in Europe.

Independent bank holding company Cullen/Frost Bankers, which runs the nation's largest Texas-based national bank, on Monday said it has agreed to acquire Summit Bancshares, the holding company for Summit Bank, for about $363.5 million.

Russian steel maker Severstal will consider placing shares in London after a proposed merger with Arcelor was rejected by the European steel giant, industry analysts said on Monday. News reports speculated that the float could reach 12 billion euro ($15.3 billion).

The board of Nissan Motor, the Japanese carmaker, has voted to explore a proposal to create a new global auto giant by forming a three-way alliance with General Motors and with Nissan's controlling shareholder, Renault of France. Renault's board was scheduled to meet Monday in Paris to discuss the same proposal, put forward by a group of dissident G.M. shareholders led by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian.

Shares of Millicom International Cellular fell 24 percent on Monday after the company said it had decided to "terminate all discussions concerning a potential sale." The announcement signalled the end, at least for now, of Millicom's widely reported talks with China Mobile about a takeover said to be valued at more than $5 billion. The deal, had it occured, would have been the largest overseas acquisition to date by a Chinese company.

Michaels Stores, the nation's largest arts and crafts retailer, agreed to be sold Friday to a consortium of private equity firms for more than $6 billion. A group that includes Bain Capital and the Blackstone Group beat Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group as bidders for the 900-store chain. (Blackstone has been busy lately: Also on Friday, Cendant announced it would sell its travel services unit, Travelport, to an affiliate of Blackstone for $4.3 billion.)

Which New York political figure faced the worst news over the holiday weekend?

Construction has begun on a rail line to link the Meadowlands sports complex with Pennsylvania Station in New York, as well as with New Jersey Transit lines around New Jersey. The rail line, about 2.5 miles long, will be capable of transporting 7,000 people per hour to an event. For New Jersey riders, the line will start in Hoboken, stop at the Secaucus Junction station and continue to a station about 100 feet from a new $1 billion stadium in the Meadowlands, which is scheduled to open in 2010. Fans coming from Pennsylvania Station in New York would transfer at Secaucus. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is financing the $150 million rail line expansion, which is scheduled to open in 2008.

A catamaran race from New Jersey to the Statue of Liberty was interrupted yesterday morning when several vessels capsized in the rough waters near Staten Island. The Statue of Liberty Marathon, held by the Sandy Hook Bay Catamaran Club, was midway through its eight-hour course when the boats capsized near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge shortly before noon, said Petty Officer Angelia Rorison, a Coast Guard spokeswoman. Officers on several Coast Guard vessels pulled the racers from the water. There were no injuries. An official with the club, Jacques Pierret, said at least five boats capsized, the largest a three-person vessel.

A teenager was shot in the leg Saturday night by an undercover police officer working as part of a narcotics investigation, the police said. The teenager, Christopher Grajales, 16, was in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center yesterday, the police said. The officer fired at the teenager after he spotted him with a knife, the police said.

A Holbrook man was arrested Saturday evening and charged with criminal possession of a weapon after an officer said he spotted an assault rifle in his pickup truck during a routine traffic stop, the Suffolk County police reported. The man, Thomas Lynagh, 42, was arrested after Officer Anthony Dieguez stopped his pickup truck for making an illegal U-turn, then spotted a Bushmaster AR-15 assault rifle in the back, the police said. The weapon was loaded, the police said.

A man was killed yesterday when his motorcycle crashed into a guardrail on Laurelton Parkway, the police said. The driver, Jason Brown, 27, lost control of his 2001 Suzuki motorcycle about 2:10 a.m. near Francis Lewis Boulevard, in Cambria Heights, the police said. Mr. Brown was pronounced dead at the scene of the crash, the police said.

Rescue workers searched last night for an 18-year-old Brooklyn man who had been swimming at Jacob Riis Park in the Gateway National Recreation Area when lifeguards saw him go underwater, the police said. When the lifeguards could not find the man, Trevon Gidding , police divers were sent down around 5 p.m. Searchers also used water scooters and helicopters.

Most comparisons between David Wright and Jos√© Reyes and a well-known pair of Yankees infielders are based on geography and position. Wright and Reyes cannot yet boast the accomplishments of the Yankees' Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez, but yesterday all four shared the honor of being selected as starters for the All-Star Game on July 11 at PNC Park in Pittsburgh. Wright and Reyes, both first-time All-Stars, headlined a Mets contingent that will turn the All-Star Game into Shea Stadium West. Vern Leroy Bullough, a historian of medicine and sexuality noted for chronicling the development of American nursing, died on June 21 at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 77. The cause was cancer, his family said. Dr. Bullough wrote prolifically about prostitution, medieval medicine and modern sexual practices but found his largest audience in writing about nursing.

GERST--Hilde W. A prominent art dealer and gallery owner in New York City, died on June 30, 2006, at the age of 98. Born in Central Europe and educated at French boarding schools, she traveled widely after World War II, which provided her the opportunity to collect works of art and antiques from various parts of the world. In 1953, she opened her art gallery on Madison Avenue, which she continued to operate personally until her recent illness. Her gallery became known for the high quality of its collection. She was renowned for her expertise in the area of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist artists and their works. She had a devoted following and was held in high esteem by clients and art dealers worldwide, many of whom became personal friends and frequent visitors to her home, and her gallery at the Carlyle Hotel. She was a member of the Foreign Policy Association and was involved in local and national political affairs. An extraordinary woman, a captivating hostess and a friend and confident of many, she is survived by her son, Paul, a surgeon, of Tenafly, NJ; her daughter, Ruth Silberstein and husband Ronald Silberstein, of Newton Centre, MA; six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Her husband, Dr. David Gerst, died in 1972. Services at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, on Wednesday, July 5, at 1:30 PM. Interment at Linwood Memorial Park, Randolph, MA. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, DC 20024-2126.

The Mets will wake up today in a place where pitchers bat and No. 8 hitters do not bat .280. No more Yankees or Red Sox, bleacher creatures or Green Monsters. Their world, the National League, has teams like the Pirates and the Cubs, and the Mets are thankful to be playing them soon. Their disappointing road trip against the class of the American League East ended last night, with a 16-7 drubbing by the Yankees in the Bronx.

''It's nothing bad, because he's been playing with it.'' TYLER KEPNER (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''The Wreckage in the China Shop,'' by Bob Herbert (column, June 29): Bullies in or out of china shops are not smart, and self-interest is their only criterion. Until we replace them with knowledgeable individuals who have no monetary stake in the outcome, nothing will change.

KOCH--Robert Newman Jr. 79, an executive in the fashion jewelry business and beloved husband of Elaine Koch, died Friday, at his East Orleans, Mass., home, of complications of Parkinson's disease. Mr. Koch was president of Coro, Inc., the nation's largest costume jewelry maker, before he founded R.N. Koch, Inc., in 1971, with offices in New York and a factory in Providence, RI. Mr. Koch, who also had homes in New York and Long Boat Key, FL, was born in Buffalo, NY, on September 26, 1926. He later relocated with his parents to New York City. He served in the navy as a radio operator in the Pacific during World War II. After attending Nichols Junior College in Dudley, Mass., he joined Coro and eventually worked his way up to president of the company. ''He loved everything about the jewelry business,'' said his daughter Peggy Palmer. His personality and artistic gifts made him perfectly suited for it. He loved the arts, particularly music and painting, and often shopped at New York and Florida galleries. Mr. Koch was formerly married to Susan Dryfoos and the couple had two daughters. In 1995, he married Elaine Stone on the lawn of his Cape Cod home, and the couple enjoyed traveling, dining and entertaining. His family treasured Bob's love of life, whether it was food, the arts, being with friends and family, or traveling. They will always treasure his goodness of heart. In addition to his wife Elaine and his daughters Peggy Palmer and Katharine Willens, both of California, he is survived by sons-in-law Briggs Palmer and Randall Willens, grandchildren Jordan and Christopher Palmer, and Charlotte and Daniel Willens, his stepdaughters Susan Van Sicklen and Debra Nussbaum, stepsons-in-law Michael Van Sicklen and Paul Nussbaum, and step - grandchildren Barret, Nick and David Van Sicklen, Zachary and Gerry Bissinger, Molly and Mathew Nussbaum, and his devoted caregiver Raymond Bradley. Private graveside service will be held Thursday. A memorial service is being planned for the fall. Donations may be made to the Robert N. Koch Jr. Foundation, established by Mr. Koch to aid Parkinson's Research, in care of Mr. Todd Lang, Esq., Weil Gotshal Manges, 767 5th Ave., New York, NY 10153. $(6$)KOCH--Robert Newman Jr. To our wonderful, devoted friend and business partner. Gerrie and Roger Joann and Todd

An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about the Midtown Manhattan office market gave an incorrect address for a building whose owner declined to renew a lease in order to seek higher-paying tenants. The building is at 1350 Avenue of the Americas, not 1340.

Rise Against The Sufferer & the Witness (Geffen) The last Rise Against album, ''Siren Song for the Counter Culture,'' began with a raw-throated rant called ''State of the Union.'' It was by no means this Chicago punk band's best song, but it did make two points at once. One was about the war. (The singer, Tim McIlrath, croaked his furious verdict: ''We did nothing to stop the murder of a people just like us.'') And the other point was about the band's new deal with Geffen Records: ''State of the Union'' let nervous fans know they could expect more of the same.

RICHARDS--Lloyd. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of Yale School of Drama and Yale Repertory Theatre mourn the loss of our esteemed Professor Emeritus and former Dean and Artistic Director. Lloyd was a distinguished teacher, ground breaking director, producer and champion of playwrights. He will be remembered for his extraordinary dedication to supporting emerging voices, and leaves the theatre an unparalled legacy. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Barbara and sons, Scott and Thomas. James Bundy, Dean and Artistic Director Victoria Nolan, Deputy Dean and Managing Director

Michael Drexler, president at Optimedia U.S., New York, part of the ZenithOptimedia division of the Publicis Groupe, is retiring after 40 years in advertising. Antony Brown, chief executive at the ZenithOptimedia U.K. Group, London, will succeed Mr. Drexler, 67, after moving to New York during the summer.

Every year Edgar sounded off on the irony of all these Americans celebrating Independence Day in the exact same way, on the exact same highway, going to the exact same place at the exact same time. ''Where is the revolutionary spirit?'' he would shout. ''Where is the independence?'' And every year Violet silently vowed to divorce him before next year.

The Yankees announced that they had sold more than four million tickets for this season, putting them on pace to break last year's A.L. attendance record of 4,090,692. The Yankees said that they had sold 258,902 more tickets this season than they had by the same date last year. The Yankees lead the major leagues in attendance, averaging more than 51,000 fans a game. TYLER KEPNER (NYT)

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. The closes tomorrow for Independence Day. At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.98 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5.23 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.46 percent.

Leo Burnett, Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, won the $100,000 Grand Prize Kelly Award for outstanding magazine advertising for the humorous ''Burn through'' campaign for Altoids cinnamon gum, sold by Kraft Foods. The honor was among nine presented by the Magazine Publishers of America as part of the 25th annual Kelly Awards.

PayPal, San Jose, Calif., part of eBay, named Zimmerman Advertising, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., owned by the Omnicom Group, to help introduce the PayPal Mobile ''text to buy'' service. Zimmerman will work with marketers to encourage them to include PayPal Mobile in their advertising campaigns. Spending has not been determined. THERE are as many no-hitters in the front office of the Los Angeles Angels as there have been in the major leagues for more than four seasons. Bill Stoneman, the general manager of the Angels, pitched two no-hitters for Montreal, one in 1969 and the other in 1972. Ken Forsch, the team's assistant general manager, pitched a no-hitter for Houston in 1979.

O'CONNOR--George E. Died at his home in Manhattan on June 24th, 2006 after a long illness. He was 89 years of age. After enlisting in the army during World War II he served in Belgium, France, Holland and Germany and advanced to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He was awarded the Silver Star, the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart, the Croix de Guerre and the Combat Infantry Mans Badge. His career was spent at New York Life Insurance Company from which he retired in 1982 as Executive Vice President. During his tenure he completed the AMP at Harvard University. From 1982 until 1989 he acted as consultant for NYLIC in Washington, DC. He also served on the Board of Aqua Chem. He is survived by his wife of 60 years Dorothy; three children Gail Bushey of Brookville, NY, Jane and Christopher of Manhattan; son-in-Law and daughter-in-law, three grand children, and three greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held July 18th at 10AM at St. Vincent Ferrer at 66th Street and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The Lenox Hill Hospital Auxiliary, 100 East 77th Street, New York, NY 10021.

To the Editor: It is truly fitting that a sign of the revival of New Orleans was marked by thousands of librarians attending their annual convention (''When the Librarians Come Marching In,'' by Bob Greene, Op-Ed, June 29).

Sailors and Shipowners Fear Piracy Off Somalia After 19 hijackings of ships off the coast of Somalia in 15 months, and 45 attempted hijackings, many ships are keeping their distance from the country. Heavily armed pirates routinely demand ransom from shipowners. PAGE A4 Shuttle Launching Delayed Again NASA scrubbed the launching of the space shuttle Discovery for the second day in a row as thunderstorms and clouds cloaked the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The next attempt will be tomorrow afternoon, when weather conditions are expected to improve. PAGE A11 Manhattan Jail Un-Named Bernard B. Kerik's name came off the jail complex in Lower Manhattan after Mr. Kerik, the former police and correction commissioner, pleaded guilty to accepting free work from a contractor. PAGE B1 Push for Spending Database A plan to create a public database, searchable over the Internet, that would list most government contracts and grants has drawn liberal and conservative support.
