A1 North Korea Defiant on Missiles North Korea declared it would continue to test-fire missiles and vowed to use force if other nations tried to stop it, even as it acknowledged for the first time that it had launched seven missiles. A12 Video Shows London Bomber On the day before the anniversary of the London bombings, Al Jazeera broadcast a video that appeared to show one of the attackers warning, ''What you have witnessed now is only the beginning.'' A3 One year after the bombings, a survey has turned up surprisingly positive attitudes among European Muslims toward Europe and European society toward Muslims. A3 Moldova Bus Bomb Kills 7 A powerful explosion killed at least 7 people and wounded at least 26 others on a minibus in the separatist region of Moldova, the region's interior minister said. A6 NATIONAL A13-15 Border Cities' Ties Tested By Long Fight Over Water The ties that bind Calexico, Calif., and Mexicali, south of the border, are being tested as a 20-year dispute over the rights to water leaking into Mexico from a canal on the American side is growing. A1 Medicaid Rule Is Eased The Bush administration said it would exempt millions of the most vulnerable Medicaid recipients from a new law that requires them to prove they are United States citizens by showing birth certificates, passports or other documents. A15 Ex-Officials Are Convicted A jury convicted four former city officials on corruption charges in Chicago, sending a message that the city's longtime practice of awarding jobs and promotions to politically connected candidates and campaign workers was indeed a crime. A14 Hate Groups and the Army Recruiting shortfalls have allowed ''large numbers of neo-Nazis and skinhead extremists'' to infiltrate the military, according to a watchdog organization. A14 Same-Sex Marriage Ban Upheld In a unanimous reversal of a lower-court decision, six justices of the Georgia Supreme Court ruled that the state's 2004 ban against same-sex marriage is constitutional. A14 Columbine Papers Released Documents seized from the teenage Columbine killers were released by a sheriff as a result of an order by the Colorado Supreme Court. A14 Tom DeLay Still on Ballot Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, has to stay on the Texas ballot in November, despite his efforts to move out of state so Republicans can pick a stronger candidate, a federal judge ruled. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Court Rejects Gay Marriage Under Current State Law New York's highest court rejected a broad attempt by gay and lesbian couples across the state to win the right to marry under state law, saying that denying marriage to same-sex couples does not violate the State Constitution. A1 New Jersey Shutdown to End Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the New Jersey Legislature reached agreement on a new budget that would bring an end to a six-day government shutdown that left nearly 100,000 workers idled and cost the state millions of dollars in lost revenue. A1 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-6 Record Number of Yellow Cards One of the lasting legacies of this World Cup tournament will be the unprecedented number of yellow cards that have been handed out. With 2 of 64 matches remaining, a record 336 yellow cards have been given. Some people have interpreted the high number as evidence that FIFA's campaign for fair play has backfired. It is a question for directors of General Motors, who are scheduled to meet Friday to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance between G.M. and the two companies that Mr. Ghosn runs, Renault and Nissan. ALLISON--Harry A. The Horace Mann School deeply mourns the passing of Harry Allison 1940, a respected student, helpful colleague, beloved friend and esteemed administrator at HM for over 45 years. His unwavering loyalty and support of the school and his unparalleled commitment to doing the right thing at all times made him an invaluable member of the community. Horace Mann students were the beneficiary of his wisdom, kindness, intellect, and exacting academic and moral standards. His efficient pragmatic style of leadership made it easy for those who worked alongside him and with him. It was a privilege to have such an accomplished and principled individual in our midst. Predeceased by the death of his beloved wife Eleanor, and his devoted son David, our heartfelt condolences are extended to his daughters Nancy, former HM Faculty member, and Anne, his son Paul and to the entire Allison family. His remarkable presence will be remembered. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly Head of School Steven M. Friedman 1972 Chair, Board of Trustees

From cathedrals on Fifth Avenue to messages of millennial hope and doom scrawled on ghetto walls, New York is shot through with signs and symbols of religious belief. Larry Racioppo, who is in his day job the official photographer for the New York Department of Housing Preservation and Development, has been assiduously cataloging vernacular displays of Roman Catholic devotion since 1989. The approximately 80 examples of his work at the Museum of Biblical Art offer a fascinating window onto this easily overlooked dimension of metropolitan life. Among the most striking are color pictures of elaborate, spray-painted memorial murals. One dedicated to someone named Mike, above, has a pair of B.M.W.'s parked in front of a glowing vision of the archangel Michael slaying the Devil. Mixtures of the sacred and the profane run through out, as in the rear view of a woman with a bejeweled gold cross hanging from a chain over tattooed flaming letters that spell ''Hot and Sexy'' across her back . Other photographs depict the God Bless Deli in Brooklyn; an early-20th-century family chapel built of stone in the Bronx; the Biblical verse John 3:16 printed on a T-shirt; a beautiful Staten Island grotto; and a simple wooden cross bearing the words ''In Memory of Pablo'' affixed to a bridge support in Queens. Mr. Racioppo studies his subjects with sympathetic interest, neither satirizing nor proselytizing. You don't have to be devout yourself to be touched by the human yearning for supernatural meaning that his photographs evoke. (Museum of Biblical Art, 1865 Broadway, at 61st Street, 212-408-1500. Through Aug. 20.) KEN JOHNSON

ZIZZAMIA--Alba I. On June 30, 2006. Born in Hartford, CT in 1910 and was a graduate of Trinity College in Washington, DC. She held a Doctorate in literature from the University of Rome. She translated several Italian works on Catholic social thought as well as the widely admired ''Life of Christ'' by Giuseppi Riocciotti. From 1948 to 1972 she was associate director of the US Catholic Conference Office for United Nations Affairs and was later director of the NY Archdiocese Office of Justice and Peace. Alba was a prominent member of the United Nations non-governmental organization community for nearly 50 years. She is survived by a nephew Mark Hill Zizzamia of Johns Island, SC. A memorial mass will be held on Monday, July 10, 11 AM at Epiphany Church, 22nd St and 2nd Ave., NYC.

Prime Minister Vlado Buckovski conceded defeat in elections that ousted the center-left government. According to early results, the winner, a conservative opposition party, claimed 55 of 120 seats in Parliament, requiring it to form a coalition government. The election, held Wednesday, was marred by irregularities but still met international standards, foreign monitors said, meaning Macedonia's goal of membership in the European Union remained on track. NICHOLAS WOOD (NYT)

To the Editor: Re ''Naming Names at Ground Zero'' (editorial, July 5):

Connecticut's state government announced that it had set aside $200,000 in its recently approved budget for the National Theater of the Deaf in West Hartford, which has been struggling to stay open after its federal financing was eliminated. The theater, which blends American Sign Language and spoken English, learned in 2004 that it was one of several arts groups sharing this specialty whose longtime federal financing was not being reauthorized by Congress. Without the money, it has been unable to resume its adult productions or restart its summer training academy for deaf and hearing-impaired actors. Lt. Gov. Kevin B. Sullivan said the state's Commission on Culture and Tourism would provide $200,000 to the group over the next 12 months. ''This is one show that simply must go on,'' he said. The group has gotten $15,000 at most from the state in recent years, according to Paul L. Winters, its executive director. The new state money ''will certainly keep us going for at least another year, possibly another two years,'' he said. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

WHO -- Doug Steimle, 62, retired chief officer of California Pools, a pool construction company, from Glendora, Calif., shown seated as Dallas Nielson, a neighbor, swims WHAT -- 4-bedroom house WHERE -- Sandy, Utah The summers in the mountains are terrific, and the swimming season is pretty close to that of California. When April comes along people are eager to shed the snow and hit the golf course and the pool. This house is used as a gathering place for my family year round, and of course, the grandkids love the pool. Generally, we can use the pool until the end of September. Sullivan & Cromwell remains atop the hill of mergers and acquisitions legal advisers so far this year. Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom has moved up to No. 2 from No. 4 in the first quarter, thanks to its work for Arcelor and Kinder Morgan, according to Bloomberg News.

An article last Friday about weekend homes in St. Michaels, Md., of Bush administration figures, including Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, misstated the relationship between the abolitionist orator Frederick Douglass and Mount Misery, a former plantation home now owned by Mr. Rumsfeld. As a young slave, Douglass fought there with a landholder who had abused him, but did not escape. (It was in Baltimore that he escaped slavery.) Also, a picture caption misidentified the waterfront scene that was shown. It was the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, not the St. Michaels marina.

Keith de Lellis 47 East 68th Street, Manhattan Through Sept. 23 Although these two photographers used very different approaches, they both could be considered social documentarians, focusing on the poor in rural regions. As an investigator and photographer for the National Child Labor Committee, Mr. Hine (1874-1940) made pictures of exploited children in factories, mills and mines, producing telling images that were instrumental in the passage of child labor laws.

The New York City metropolitan area will receive $53.8 million in federal antiterrorism grants to protect its rail, bus and ferry systems, a 25 percent increase over last year, the Department of Homeland Security announced yesterday. The additional money may curtail some of the criticism of a 40 percent cut announced on May 31 in a separate, larger antiterrorism grant program. The new grant money -- $47 million for rail, $5.5 million for bus systems and $1.3 million for ferry security -- means the New York area will get nearly 44 percent of the total transit grants distributed this year. ''The Department of Homeland Security is finally putting some of its money where its mouth is and seems to have realized that New York City's subways and buses remain under constant threat,'' Senator Charles E. Schumer said. ERIC LIPTON (NYT)

To the Editor: Thomas L. Friedman struck a chord of guilt in me when he suggested that attention is a victim of our electronics-filled digital age (''The Age of Interruption,'' column, July 5). I offer myself as an example.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Anna Lee Aldred, the first woman in the United States to receive a jockey's license, misstated the location of the Agua Caliente racetrack, from which she received the license. It is in Mexico, not California.

To the Editor: Re: ''Weekends With the President's Men'' (June 30), if our enemies were wondering just where our country's vice president and secretary of defense spend weekends with their families, all they have to do is check out Peter Kilborn's article where he gives up not only where the Cheneys and Rumsfelds stay, but where they shop and dine, and the location of a security camera! Theodore Kobran Union, N.J. To the Editor: Re: ''Weekends With the President's Men'' (June 30), I am shocked that you would again expose another national security secret. Why, anyone could stand outside these men's houses and protest, picket, harass and generally disrupt their quiet peaceful existence. What's next, holding them accountable? Lithgow Osborne Kent Cliffs, N.Y.

WIN FOR TOBACCO COMPANIES -- United States tobacco companies won a major legal victory when the Florida Supreme Court upheld a decision to toss out a $145 billion judgment against them. [Page C1.] MICROSOFT MUSIC PLAYER -- Microsoft's interest in making its own hand-held music and video player indicates that its old way of doing things is not working in its battle against Apple's iPod. [C1.] PETROBRAS SHIFTS FOCUS -- New offshore drilling techniques and an aggressive plan to diversify have enabled Petrobras of Brazil to shift its focus from production at home toward becoming a player on the global energy market and a major foreign investor. [C1.] NEW AOL STRATEGY -- AOL, a unit of Time Warner, is putting the final touches on a plan that would stop marketing its subscription service, which for more than a decade has been the most popular way that Americans connect to the Internet, according to an AOL executive. Instead, it will redouble its efforts to build a free, advertising-supported business on the Web, offering members access to the most popular features of its paid service -- including e-mail addresses at AOL.com, free virus protection, and use of AOL's software program. [C3.] BUDGET DEAL IN NEW JERSEY -- Gov. Jon S. Corzine and the New Jersey Legislature reached agreement on a budget that would bring an end to a six-day government shutdown that left nearly 100,000 workers idled and cost the state millions of dollars in lost revenue. [A1.] ASSESSING GHOSN'S IMPACT -- What would Carlos Ghosn bring to the table? It is a top-of-mind question for the directors of General Motors, who are scheduled to meet today to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance between G.M. and the two companies that Mr. Ghosn runs, Renault and Nissan. [C1.] RATE SIGNAL IN EUROPE -- Worried about inflation amid strong economic growth, the European Central Bank signaled that it would raise interest rates in early August, stepping up its pace of tightening credit. [C5.] DEMAND FOR BANK DISCLOSURE -- The European Parliament demanded that European institutions in Brussels and European governments disclose how much they knew about a American program to tap into international banking data. [A10.] RETAIL SALES RELEASED -- For the second consecutive month, sales at department stores like Kohl's and J. C. Penney far outstripped those of specialty apparel chains like Gap and the Limited, according to June sales data released by dozens of chains. [C3.] STOCKS RISE -- The Dow Jones industrial average rose 73.48 points, to finish at 11,225.30. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 3.17 points, to end at 1,274.08. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 1.75 points, to close at 2,155.09. [C7.] CONCERN ON BOEING SETTLEMENT -- Three prominent Republican senators have written to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to express concern that Boeing may be allowed to take a tax deduction for a $615 million settlement reached last week with the government. [C3.] HEALTH INSURANCE EXEMPTION -- The Bush administration said that it would exempt millions of the most vulnerable Medicaid recipients from a new law that requires them to prove they are United States citizens by showing birth certificates, passports or other documents. [A15.] NEW SUIT IN HOLLINGER CASE -- Hollinger Inc. said that it was countersuing the newspaper publisher Hollinger International in Chicago, claiming fraud related to the transfer of two newspapers to the publisher in the late 1990's. Hollinger also sued Ravelston once controlled by Conrad M. Black, left, to seek the equivalent of more than $650 million for damages ranging from breach of contract to unjust enrichment. United States prosecutors have accused Lord Black, the former press baron, and others of looting Hollinger International. [C7.] MANISCHEWITZ GOES MAINSTREAM -- The leading marketer of kosher foods, Manischewitz, is expanding efforts to reach mainstream shoppers with what the company is calling its first campaign aimed at the general market as well as at consumers who traditionally buy kosher products for religious reasons. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.] SERVICE GROWTH SLOWED -- The United States service sector grew more slowly than expected in June, but the labor market showed strength as jobless claims dipped unexpectedly last week. [C4.] ONLINE A SPECIAL REPORT: STOLEN LIVES -- An interview with Shiva Brent Sharma, who was drawn into the world of identity theft as a teenager, can be found at nytimes.com/video. SCREENS -- In her new blog on Web video, Virginia Heffernan, the TV critic of The Times, discusses a viral video from, of all places, Iran. Her report is at nytimes.com/screens. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.

An Associated Press obituary on Monday about Irving Green, who co-founded Mercury Records in 1945, referred incorrectly to part of the company's history. It was sold to Philips Electronics in 1960, not to Polygram Records in the mid-1970's. The obituary also misidentified the label that recorded Louis Armstrong's first No. 1 hit, ''Hello Dolly.'' It was Kapp Records, not Mercury.

Candice Dupree had 20 points and 6 rebounds to help the host Chicago Sky beat the Liberty, 78-73, last night. The Sky went on a 12-4 run to open the fourth quarter, taking a 66-56 lead with 4 minutes 58 seconds remaining, then made 10 of 12 free throws in the final minute. Becky Hammon scored 18 points for the Liberty (4-13), which lost its fourth in a row.

The woman who was allegedly assaulted by Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Santonio Holmes has asked that charges against him be dropped, his attorney said yesterday. Holmes was arrested June 19 and charged with misdemeanor domestic violence and simple assault. The woman accused Holmes of choking her, throwing her to the ground, grabbing her arms and slamming her into a door, according to a statement to the police in Columbus, Ohio.

Jamaica's Asafa Powell taunted Justin Gatlin, his sprint rival, yesterday by claiming that Gatlin was trying to avoid racing against him. Powell and Gatlin hold the 100-meter world record time of 9.77 seconds, and the pair were scheduled to race at Monday's I.A.A.F. Super Grand Prix in Athens. But Gatlin withdrew with a leg injury.

A judge disqualified Kentucky's attorney general from any involvement in prosecuting Gov. Ernie Fletcher in a state hiring scandal. The special judge, David Melcher, ruled that the office of the attorney general, Gregory D. Stumbo, left, still has jurisdiction; its prosecutors can remain on the case, but without Mr. Stumbo. Mr. Fletcher, a Republican, was indicted in May, accused of rewarding political supporters with protected state jobs. Mr. Fletcher's lawyers had argued that Mr. Stumbo should be disqualified because he may be a political rival in the 2007 governor's race. Judge Melcher said he was "exercising caution" in disallowing Mr. Stumbo's participation.

Tom DeLay suggested that he might not be ready for retirement just yet, a day after a federal judge ruled that his name must remain on the November ballot even though he resigned from Congress. Mr. DeLay, in Sugar Land for a tribute, also criticized the ruling by Judge Sam Sparks of Federal District Court.

A surge in wildfires in the mountains of the West since the 1980's, particularly in the northern Rockies, appears to have been caused mainly by the warming climate, a new study says. Researchers from several universities, writing in the online journal Scienceexpress.org, sifted records on forest fires and climate conditions and found that human activities like timber cutting were less important than factors like a shortening snow season and rising summer temperatures, particularly in forests more than a mile high. The scientists said further warming from the buildup of heat-trapping gases was likely to lengthen the Western fire season.

Ralph Deeds, Birmingham, Mich.: It appears to me that the politics of global warming is more difficult than the science. For example, existing automobile technology could produce a huge savings in oil if our Congress would stop debating flag burning and pass legislation to encourage more fuel-efficient motor vehicles. This could easily be done by gradually increasing the gasoline tax to bring pump prices up to European levels. Phasing in the tax increase over several years would give drivers and car companies time to adjust to the production and sale of smaller, more fuel efficient cars. The downside of a big gas tax increase is that it would be regressive, bearing most heavily on those least able to afford it. An alternative would be a vehicle weight and or horsepower tax. Likewise, technology exists for cleaner power production if there were the political will to require the power companies to use it.

8 P.M. (UPN) CARRIE -- (1976) Stephen King's 1974 novel about a high school misfit, Carrie White, who discovers her telekinetic powers and uses them to exact violent revenge on her teenage tormentors at the senior prom hit the big screen two years later with Brian De Palma at the helm. Sissy Spacek (right) is the young avenger, Piper Laurie her overbearing and super-religious mother and John Travolta, in his first major movie role, is the sadistic Billy Nolan - but boy does he get his. The film may be 30 years old, but the desire to get back at the meanies is timeless. 7 P.M. (Animal Planet) EUKANUBA TOURNAMENT OF CHAMPIONS 2006 -- Spaniels and boxers and pugs, oh my. Dogs from around the country compete in Harrisburg, Penn., for the title of Best in Show. 9 P.M. (13) THE MIRACLE WORKER -- (1962) Patty Duke (left) is Helen Keller, blind, deaf and mute since infancy, and Anne Bancroft is her devoted teacher, Annie Sullivan. Both actresses were reprising their roles from the successful Broadway play by William Gibson, and both won Academy Awards for their efforts in the film: Ms. Bancroft for best actress and Ms. Duke, at age 16, for best supporting actress. 9 P.M. (FOOD) PAULA√ïS EUROPEAN VACATION -- Southern cookin' charmer Paula Deen and her husband, Michael, head off to enjoy their first overseas vacation and sample the culinary delights of London and Paris. Will she find time to bake and perhaps win over those forbidding Parisians with her charm and a slice of Old South Jelly Roll Cake? 9 P.M. (Hallmark) WILD HEARTS -- (2006) Richard Thomas is Bob Hart, a widowed Los Angeles officer and single parent who learns that his estranged father, a mustang rancher and sheriff of a small Montana town, deputized him before he passed away. Bob packs up and heads to a town called Hope, attempting to rescue the family ranch in danger of being sold to the highest bidder. 10 P.M. (History) COMIC BOOK SUPERHEROES UNMASKED -- Comic book heroes often seem timeless, but they also reflect their own times. From the 1930's through today, a variety of do-gooders with all kinds of unusual powers (and costumes) have been role models for generations of children. This two-hour special looks at some representative characters and the industry that created them. 10 P.M. (MAX) WEDDING CRASHERS -- (2005) It√ïs a crazy weekend for two divorce mediators (Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn) who crash the wedding reception of an eccentric politician's daughter. Crude hilarity ensues. STEVEN McELROY

Two astronauts from the shuttle Discovery ended a spacewalk of more than seven and a half hours after doing a bit of on-orbit repair to a malfunctioning part of the International Space Station and testing a new use for the shuttle's robot arm and sensor boom as a work platform. Astronauts two Piers J. Sellers and Michael E. Fossum returned to the space station's Quest airlock just after 4:30 Eastern.

An article in Business Day on June 29 about the impending federal approval of the drug Lucentis, which treats macular degeneration in the elderly, omitted attribution for a statement about the motives of the drug's maker, Genentech. Several doctors raised the issue, including Dr. Raj K. Maturi and Dr. Philip J. Rosenfeld, who noted that Genentech was not seeking approval for another of its drugs, Avastin, to treat the condition because that would undermine Lucentis sales. The article also gave an outdated title for Dr. Rosenfeld. He is a professor of ophthalmology at the University of Miami, not an associate professor. And the article misstated the source material for Lucentis. The drug is derived from the same mouse antibody from which Avastin was developed; it was not derived directly from Avastin. (The error on the source material appeared in articles on May 24 and Sept. 27, 2005; on Aug. 26, 2004; and on Nov. 16, 2003.)

A front-page article on Monday about the partnership between President Bush and Senator John McCain of Arizona referred incorrectly to the role of Mark D. Wallace in Mr. McCain's political planning. Although Mr. Wallace had been advising Mr. McCain, he stopped doing so in March when he became United States ambassador to the United Nations for management and reform.

An obituary on Sunday about Japp Penraat, who saved more than 400 Jews from the Nazis in the Netherlands, omitted several countries that historians say lost a higher percentage of their Jewish population in the Holocaust than the Netherlands. In addition to Poland, Lithuania, Yugoslavia, Greece, Latvia and Slovakia lost a larger proportion.

Services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck this Sunday, July 9 at 9:30AM. Interment will follow at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

When Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, pulled back recently from a plan to donate $115 million to Harvard, Richard L. Sprott was reminded again of the tenuous nature of his livelihood. Mr. Sprott is the executive director of the Ellison Medical Foundation, a philanthropy that has received $175 million from Mr. Ellison mostly to aid research on the science of aging. Although the Harvard situation was unrelated to the foundation -- Mr. Ellison reportedly changed his mind about donating after the resignation in February of Lawrence H. Summers, the president of Harvard, amid a storm of controversy -- the events reinforced for Mr. Sprott his awareness that his organization also depended on a single billionaire.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sidestepped the controversy over gay marriage in New York yesterday, reiterating her support for gay civil unions and calling for ''full equality for people in committed relationships'' after the state's highest court rejected marriage rights for same-sex couples. Mrs. Clinton's remarks, which made no specific mention of gay marriage, disappointed and even angered some gay rights advocates, who are now recruiting political leaders to push a gay marriage bill through the State Legislature.

INSURER DISCUSSES BID FOR AMERUS -- Aviva, the largest insurance company in Britain, said it was in talks to buy the AmerUs Group, an insurance company based in Iowa, in a deal that would increase its presence in the American market. AmerUs, of Des Moines, confirmed the talks but said there was no assurance a transaction would result. The company provides life insurance and annuity products and has a market capitalization of $2.4 billion.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed an executive order early Saturday ending an eight-day government shutdown and resolving an acidic standoff with the Legislature that paralyzed New Jersey, frayed nerves and cost the state millions of dollars. The order meant that nearly 100,000 workers including 45,000 state employees could begin returning to their jobs. Although government offices like the Motor Vehicle Commission were not expected to reopen until Monday, the 12 Atlantic City casinos the most high-profile casualties of the shutdown re-opened Saturday morning.

On a day devoted to moving thousands of pounds of supplies from the space shuttle Discovery to the International Space Station, engineers and analysts on the ground scrutinized images of the shuttle on Friday for damage that might cause problems in the brutal heat of re-entry. Officials said that the shuttle came through the rigors of ascent in a remarkably clean state and that they had narrowed their analysis to a few unresolved issues.

Data on Jobs and Wages Leaves Uncertainty Disparate economic data on job growth, unemployment and wages underscored the uncertain situation facing the Federal Reserve as it ponders whether to continue raising interest rates over the summer to cool the economy further or whether it is time to pause. DEUTSCHER -- Samuel P. (Uncle Sam), at 92. Devoted companion of Annette Feder. Loving patriarch of the extended Deutscher family. Masonic Funeral Service Sunday, 10:30AM, immediately followed by traditional service at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

An article on Wednesday about the case of a former American soldier accused of involvement in the rape and killing of an Iraqi woman, and in the killing of members of her family, misstated the date of the arrest. The suspect, Steven D. Green, was arrested on June 30; Monday was the day that prosecutors announced the arrest. (The error was repeated yesterday in an article about the case.)

An article in Business Day on June 29 about the impending federal approval of the drug Lucentis, which treats macular degeneration in the elderly, omitted attribution for a statement about the motives of the drug's maker, Genentech. Several doctors raised the issue, including Dr. Raj K. Maturi and Dr. Philip J. Rosenfeld, who noted that Genentech was not seeking approval for another of its drugs, Avastin, to treat the condition because that would undermine Lucentis sales. The article also gave an outdated title for Dr. Rosenfeld. He is a professor of ophthalmology at the University of Miami, not an associate professor. And the article misstated the source material for Lucentis. The drug is derived from the same mouse antibody from which Avastin was developed; it was not derived directly from Avastin. (The error on the source material appeared in articles on May 24 and Sept. 27, 2005; on Aug. 26, 2004; and on Nov. 16, 2003.)

FOSTER--Zelda. A valued member of the Beth Israel Medical Center Institutional Review Board, Ms. Foster was well known for her work in the hospice movement and social work. She was the Chief of Social Work Services for the VA Medical Center in Brooklyn and held faculty positions at New York University, Smith College and Columbia University Schools of Social Work. Arnold Winston, MD, Chair, BIMC Institutional Review Board, Martha Alvarado, MPH, Director, Human Subjects Protection Office, Keith King, IRB Manager and members of the IRB Board express their condolences to Zelda's family.

An article yesterday about the persistence of Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey, a trait that legislators and aides say led to his success in resolving the state's budget stalemate, misstated the percentage by which the state sales tax will increase when it is raised to 7 percent from 6. It is 16.7 percent, not 1 percent.

GUTTAG--Marjorie. Of Delray Beach, FL, widow of Irwin Guttag, passed away Friday, July 7, 2006. Born Marjorie Vogel, she grew up in Long Beach, NY, and attended Syracuse University. She was an accomplished artist and had a longstanding interest in community service. She served as President of the Mid-Westchester YMHA, a member of the Board of the Jewish Communal Fund, and a member of the Distribution Committee of UJA-Federation of NY. She is survived by her daughter Addie of NYC, her son John and daughterin-law Olga of Lexington, MA, and her grandchildren David, Andrea, Michael and Mark. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM on Sunday, July 9, at the 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Ave. Friends are invited to visit with the family at 575 Park Ave. immediately following the service and on Monday from 2 to 7 PM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the charity of your choice.
BLUESTONE--Harold E. Beloved husband of Edith. Father of Mimi & Susie, grandfather of Joey, Rosa & Lila. Memorial Sun, Jul 9, 2pm, Sinai Free Synagogue, 550 N.Columbus Av., Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

GOLODNER--Syril Kirson, 82. On July 5, 2006. Born and raised in Manhattan, resided in Park Slope, and was a resident of Boca Raton, FL since 2000. A homemaker, business manager and children's clothing buyer, Syril was an elegant, graceful and caring woman who was deeply loved by her family and friends. Syril had a keen sense of humor, which stayed with her, and pleased those around her, throughout her life. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry Golodner. Devoted mother of Dr. Ellen Golodner, Adam Golodner & Meg Quiat and mother-in-law of Eileen McMahon and Daniel Quiat. Adored grandmother of Caitlin and Sarah Quiat. Services Sunday, July 9th, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to HospiceCare of Boulder County, 2594 Trailridge Dr. Lafayette, CO 80026.

Authorities overseas have arrested one man and have taken two others into custody on suspicion of planning suicide bombings in train tunnels beneath the Hudson River between Manhattan and New Jersey, officials said yesterday. It is a joyous scene of country life. Two men, shirts undone, celebrate the harvest, dancing a jig to a fiddler's tune. Soft afternoon light floods the barn siding where a boy keeps time with crude drumsticks. Farm workers look on, clapping, from the back of the barn; a dog eyes a cat under the floorboards. William Sidney Mount painted ''Dance of the Haymakers'' on a farm near present-day Stony Brook in 1845, and the image resonates with the optimism and pioneering spirit of post-Revolutionary War American life. The painting takes pride of place in the main room of ''Painters for a New America: Works by William Sidney Mount and Shepard Alonzo Mount,'' a new exhibition at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages.

The commentators who have done live play-by-play of the soccer matches on the World Cup blog of The New York Times -- Jeff Z. Klein, Rob Mackey, Victor Mather, Duncan Irving and Austin Kelley -- have heard from fans around the world. Here, based on what they have seen, read and experienced, are the 10 top moments from the elimination rounds. 1. Zidane and the Old Guard ''YOU'LL SEE -- I'M SUPERCONFIDENT we'll be in Berlin on July 9,'' said Zin√©dine Zidane on the eve of the tournament. Nobody really believed him. But in the swan song of his illustrious career, Zidane, 34, has been a master of unparalleled grace in leading France to the final. He isn't the only member of the ancien r√©gime who has enjoyed a renaissance; so have France's Lilian Thuram, 34, Claude Makelele, 33, and Patrick Vieira, 30; Italy's defender Fabio Cannavaro, 32; and Germany's goalkeeper Jens Lehmann, 36. After this tournament, where Gillette sponsors an award for young players not yet able to shave, perhaps FIFA can ask Geritol to create an award for next time around. 2. Fat Ronaldo's Stepover CRITICIZED BY EVERYONE, including the president of Brazil, for being overweight and slow and weird on the field, Brazil's striker Ronaldo managed a stepover feint so deft he actually faked Ghana goalkeeper Richard Kingson to the ground as he scored a record 15th World Cup goal. We should all be so slow and so weird. But when Brazil lost to France, 1-0, Ronaldo and his teammates went home to cries of national shame -- all the 3-0 victories forgotten, all the Nike ads of Brazilian magic stored away in mothballs. 3. Like Any Other Country THE UNITED STATES CRASHED out of the tournament against Ghana after a dismal performance and some strange refereeing decisions. Hundreds of readers on the Times blog went ballistic. Fire Bruce Arena! Get rid of all the players! The ref robbed us of what little chance we had! In the hysteria of their response, American soccer fans sounded, marvelously, just like everyone else in the world. 4. Graham Poll's Gaffe THANKS TO JOSEPH S. BLATTER's incomprehensible instructions to crack down on fouls, this has been a tough World Cup for referees, who for a couple of weeks were handing out bookings in record numbers. The Englishman Graham Poll had the worst of it, issuing a second yellow card to Croatia's Josip Simunic, forgetting to send him off, remembering a few minutes later, showing a third yellow and a red, and waving off a late Australia insurance goal in the process. Poll retired from the international game afterward -- but Blatter, FIFA's president, remains. 5. Three Characters In Search of a Farce A MOMENT OF SUBLIME COMEDY toward the end of the fractious, absurdly refereed match between Portugal and the Netherlands: the three players sent off in the second half, Portugal's Deco and the Netherlands' Khalid Boulahrouz and Giovanni van Bronckhorst, sat together on a step watching the end of the game. Deco and van Bronckhorst, teammates at Barcelona, chatted amicably enough, but Boulahrouz, sent off because the ref had been conned by a bit of play-acting from Deco's teammate Lu√≠s Figo, sat stunned and glaring at Deco through the game's last farcical moments. 6. How to Beat Germany IN THE QUARTERFINAL against Germany, Argentina's coach, Jos√© Pekerman, tried to protect a 1-0 lead and left swift attackers like Javier Saviola and Lionel Messi on the bench. But when the Germans equalized late, Argentina had no offense to reply and lost on penalties. In the Germany-Italy semifinal, Italy's Coach Marcello Lippi knew better. He inserted attacker after attacker and went for broke with four forwards -- and when Fabio Grosso scored in the 119th minute, it was a triumph not only for Italy, but also for positive, adventurous soccer. 7. Too Much Emotion? AT THE BOHEMIAN BEER GARDEN in Astoria, Queens, the Germany-Italy semifinal was the World Cup in microcosm. As the beer flowed and the scent of grilling sausages filled the air, hundreds of fans of both teams cheered and chanted relentlessly while the game played on five outdoor screens. Suddenly, after more than two hours of unendurable tension and with penalties looming, a lightning goal for Italy -- and then another. Fans of Germany wept openly; right next to them, fans of Italy exulted in boundless joy. For a neutral, the depth of emotion was almost unbearable. Just maybe the World Cup should be abolished, for the sake of everyone's sanity. 8. From Heartthrob To Villain PORTUGAL'S BACK-HEELING, bicicleta-pedaling Cristiano Ronaldo was acclaimed for his skills and good looks. But in the quarterfinals he incensed English fans by appealing to the referee to have Wayne Rooney (justly) sent off and winking when the red card was shown. In the semifinal against France, he was booed constantly and vilified for diving whenever challenged. Defiant to the end, Ronaldo left the France game saying, ''I was pleased about being booed.'' Then he complained about the referee. 9. No Hablan F√∫tbol SOME TOURNAMENT GAMES have been the United States' most-watched sports event of the day. But the great untold story of the World Cup in the United States may well be the level of viewer dissatisfaction with ABC/ESPN's coverage. The Times blog has received hundreds of complaints about the gaps in knowledge and the penchant for rambling, off-the-point discussions during play by the lead announcing team, Dave O'Brien and Marcelo Balboa. The complaints come from longtime soccer fans and first-time viewers equally -- and at least half say they have switched off ABC/ESPN and are watching in Spanish, a language many of them do not understand. According to Crain's Television Week, as many as 30 percent of Univision's World Cup viewers do not speak Spanish. Since Univision's audience for the tournament is almost as large, it suggests that ABC/ESPN has actually chased away a large portion of its viewers. 10. The Perfect Hosts GERMANY 2006 has been one enormous, good-natured, monthlong party. Whether at fan fests across the country, where millions have eaten, drunk, celebrated and made friends, or in the superb, atmospheric stadiums, the German people have been generous and laid-back hosts, fans and even contributors to the Times blog, unfailingly gracious in victory or defeat. For visiting fans from around the world, there has never been a better World Cup.

FOR years, opponents of sprawl have argued that the growth of suburbs and exurbs saps the vitality of central cities. They claim that the result has been homogenous, affluent, white bedroom communities at the urban periphery, and at the core an increasing number of poor and minority neighborhoods. They also blame sprawl for longer commuting times, more traffic congestion and increased pollution. Many of these observers hailed recent news from the Census Bureau that New York City is expected to grow by more than a million people by 2025. Some have even suggested that this might mark the end of suburban growth in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York as people move back toward the center to take advantage of shorter commuting times, more demographic diversity and all the other benefits that higher-density living can bring.

THE ball fields at Commack Park were filled with Little League baseball teams practicing for the tournament season one day in late June. The parents were getting ready, too. ''I love this game,'' Valerie Monroy said as she watched her 10-year-old son, William, go through infield drills with his teammates. ''I think it's so cute.'' Donna Pesci, the mother of Joseph, also 10, said her favorite part of the game was when the catcher went out to the mound for a chat with the pitcher. ''What can they be talking about?'' she said.
To the Editor ''Points of Interest'' (June 25), about the increasing number of homes with turrets, made me think of Euripides's words: ''Whom the gods seek to destroy, they first make mad.''
MY older son, Gabriel, is in his room, propped up on elbows over a copy of ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' ''Hey Mom, want to see a picture of the man with fireproof skin?''

To the Sports Editor: I'm not a Knicks fan, but I almost fell out of my chair laughing when I read Nate Robinson's quotation about Coach Larry Brown taking away his joy (''Thomas Sets a New Goal for the Knicks: the Playoffs,'' July 7).

To get more consumers to test their products, technology companies like Sony and Fuji are making deals with hotels to give guests the use of digital cameras and portable game consoles during their stays. Rosewood Hotels and Resorts recently teamed with Fujifilm U.S.A. to offer guests free use of some of Fuji's newest digital cameras. The FinePix V10, right, for example, a new pocketsize camera with four video games built into it, will be available at the Carlyle in New York, the CordeValle in San Martin, Calif., and the Inn of the Anasazi in Santa Fe, N.M., by mid-July. Members of the hotel staffs will download pictures onto a CD so guests can take them home. At four Fairmont Hotels and Resorts, guests can try out Sony's PlayStation Portable. The hand-held game console is available on a first-come-first-served basis at the Fairmont Scottsdale Princess in Arizona, the Fairmont Empress in Victoria, British Columbia, and two hotels in Bermuda. In conjunction with Hewlett-Packard, Fairmont also offers free use of HP digital cameras to guests in Washington; San Jose, Calif.; and Aventura, Fla.

WHEN the popular superintendent of schools here put out the word in January that he would be leaving at the end of the year, the search for a new educator in chief began at once. In this intimate district in Westchester County, at once arty and high-achieving, the hunt for a new leader propelled the Board of Education -- and the community -- on a journey that was far more complex and heady than anyone had imagined.

SANACORE--Joseph A., MD. The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary notes with sorrow the passing of a longtime member of the Medical Staff, graduate of the Ophthalmology program, and teacher in the operating room and clinics. Our sincerest condolences to the Sanacore family. Joseph B. Walsh, MD Chairman, Ophthalmology Department Douglas F. Buxton, MD President, Alumni Assoc.

To the Editor: ''Looking for Answers When Choosing Care'' (July 2) struck a personal chord with me. When my wife learned she had breast cancer, we decided that the highest quality of care would be provided at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. We were impressed with the understanding and sensitivity of the staff, and the support services provided. But most important, the collective knowledge exhibited by the staff and the exemplary quality of medical services met our best expectations.
To the Editor: Re ''Paris Breaks a Nail and You Are There'' (July 2):

For much of last week, New Jersey's churches of chance were silent. No horses thundered down the stretch at The Meadowlands. Atlantic City glittered a little less brightly by the shore. And at the Leprechaun II Newsstand in Rutherford, considered lucky by some since a local couple won a $258 million jackpot last year, the ''green machines'' sat cold and still, shut down, like every other government-regulated sweepstake in the state, by the impasse in Trenton.

To The Editor: Re ''They're Only in It for Frank's Legacy'' by Jesse Fox Mayshark [June 11]:

FOR years, opponents of sprawl have argued that the growth of suburbs and exurbs saps the vitality of central cities. They claim that the result has been homogenous, affluent, white bedroom communities at the urban periphery, and at the core an increasing number of poor and minority neighborhoods. They also blame sprawl for longer commuting times, more traffic congestion and increased pollution. Many of these observers hailed recent news from the Census Bureau that New York City is expected to grow by more than a million people by 2025. Some have even suggested that this might mark the end of suburban growth in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York as people move back toward the center to take advantage of shorter commuting times, more demographic diversity and all the other benefits that higher-density living can bring.

Chamnan Lim, a daughter of Lone Srey of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Lim Ho, was married at her mother's house on Friday evening to Sophal Ear, a son of Cam Youk Lim of Fremont, Calif., and the late Ear Muy Cuong. The Rev. Elaine S. Banks, an American Baptist minister, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony. Yesterday, Ponlork Le, a member of the board of the Cambodian Buddhist Society in Maryland, led a traditional Cambodian wedding ceremony, also at the home of the bride's mother. Mrs. Ear, 31, is a policy adviser to the United Nations Development Program on aid coordination for Cambodia; she works in Phnom Penh. She graduated from Frostburg State University in Maryland, and received an M.B.A. from Johns Hopkins University. Her mother retired as a seamstress and a housekeeper at the J W Marriott Hotel in Washington. The bride's father was a medical paraprofessional in Neak Ta, Cambodia.

To the Sports Editor: Martin B. Schmidt seems effusive in his praise for Nike's Joga Bonito (play beautifully) ad campaign, in which Nike implores soccer players to stop ''flopping,'' or pretending to be hurt to draw a yellow card on an opponent (Keeping Score, July 2). Schmidt calls these ads ''a noble attempt'' to introduce an honor code into the game.

While there is no shortage of chief executives who have taken extraordinary compensation while running their companies into the ground, there are also plenty who have been paid modestly in comparison to how much their companies have prospered. The Corporate Library, a watchdog group in Portland, Me., recently cited 10 of them. Together, these executives were paid $190 million in salary, bonus and stock over the last five years while their companies posted total gains -- dividends and rising stock prices -- of $82.7 billion. Some were particular bargains. The new chief of AutoZone, William C. Rhodes, for example, was paid only 24 percent of the median salary-bonus-and-options package of other chiefs in the auto products industry. Over the last five years, AutoZone has had a total return to shareholders of 255 percent.

INTERNATIONAL 3-9 U.S. Announces Russia Talks The White House said it would open formal negotiations that would allow Russia to become one of the world's largest repositories of spent nuclear fuel. According to the press materials, ''Uncertain States of America'' at the Center for Curatorial Studies Gallery at Bard College is a rollicking selection of contemporary artworks promising a frank assessment of the current state of American art, culture and society. But the bulk of these works are oblique and often annoyingly perverse, having less to say about life in the United States than they do about the confused state of the contemporary art world. That said, there is some fine work here. Three European curators, Daniel Birnbaum, Hans Ulrich Obrist and Gunnar Kvaran, made the selections. It apparently took them two years of research and more than 500 studio visits to come up with the 40-something artists in the show, many of whom are young, though already seasoned exhibitors.

Last month the Supreme Court offered self-indulgent state legislatures the judicial equivalent of a hot fudge sundae when it mostly approved the wildly partisan Texas redistricting plan engineered by former Representative Tom DeLay. It was a depressing outcome and one that made it even more critical that local elected officials be mobilized to adopt more equitable methods of drawing political boundaries. That is very much the case in New York, which suffers from a different form of compulsive gerrymandering than Texas. Instead of manipulating geography to give one party the political edge, the New York State Legislature -- divided for so long between a Republican Senate and Democratic Assembly -- tends to stick to protecting incumbents.

OVER the last few years, as its residents fought a battle against the city to keep their homes, the Fort Trumbull neighborhood of New London looked more and more like a war-torn village, with acres of vacant lots interrupted intermittently by debris and a few scattered houses. Fort Trumbull was at the center of a national debate over eminent domain last year after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the city could take residents' homes and transfer them to a private developer to put up new housing, offices and a hotel. Of the seven property owners who sued the city, the final two agreed on June 30 to settle, ending the battle.

FRANKEL--Howard J. D.D.S. 83, July 1St, formerly of New Rochelle, NY, devoted husband and best friend of 56 years to Janice. Survived by son Jeffrey, daughter-in-law Gwen, granddaughter Holli and adored daughter Heidi Shore. In addition to a private practice in New York City, he held the rank of Assistant Professor of Crown and Bridge at NYU School of Dentistry. Donations to: Alzheimer's Society.

To the Editor: In ''The Ultimate Road Trip'' (June 18), Mark Sundeen describes his visit to the coastal town of Vik while traveling Iceland's Ring Road. In the winter of 1943, I was stationed at the Air Force Direction Finding Station in Vik. Mr. Sundeen mentioned its abandoned building and radio tower in his piece. The winds were incredible when I was there, sometimes reaching 100 miles per hour. Our main base was at Keflavik, which is now the Reykjavik Airport.

To the Editor: As Queens has become a haven for immigrants, Bob Brody's schoolyard basketball experience has become increasingly multicultural (''World Court,'' July 2). He refers to Jacques Barzun's quote that ''Whoever wants to know the heart and mind of America had better learn baseball,'' but says that, for the more recent immigrants, basketball has become the route to assimilation.

Tiny as it is, Ol√© Mol√©, a taqueria in a small strip mall in Stamford, packs a big wallop -- largely because of its salsas. There are seven made daily on the premises (as are the chips); the mildest is the salsa verde (a blend of tomatillos, chiles, cilantro, onion and garlic); the most incendiary is the chile de arbol (roasted tomato, onion, garlic and chile de arbol). The five other gradations fall in between. All the salsas add extra punch, though every dish I tried was well seasoned in and of itself, from the four types of quesadillas, to burritos, tacos, tortas and platillos, or main entrees. Ol√© Mol√© has been in the same location for more than 10 years and still turns out fresh and appealing Mexican food, prepared quickly and served by a friendly, smiling staff. The takeout business looks to be thriving, but I enjoy eating in. The cheerful, crowded quarters consist of four brightly painted concrete tables along a short wall, and a counter with stools facing the street. There are two tables outside, for those intrepid enough to endure the noise and fumes of a main thoroughfare.
SCHNEIDER--Bob, 83, Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Your impact on us is everlasting. We will miss you. Ashkenazis and Habers

Gasoline prices in the state rose by a few cents last week because of an increase in the gross receipt tax levied on oil companies. Starting July 1, the tax rose to 6.72 percent, from 6.16 percent, on each gallon sold. Michael J. Fox, the executive director of the Gasoline and Automotive Service Dealers of America in Stamford, which represents gas retailers in the state, said the tax was passed on to consumers. He said prices at the pump rose to 5 cents a gallon from 2 cents a gallon.

JACQUELINE NEWMAN got her first Chinese cookbook as a wedding gift more than 50 years ago. She bought another, and another, and soon, she recalled, collecting Chinese cookbooks became ''a love, an obsession, a sickness.'' She has collected scores of new Chinese cookbooks every year for several decades now, often traveling the globe to get them.

THIS is determination: ordering legislators to report to Trenton and delivering the same message to them at 9 o'clock, morning after morning. Gov. Jon S. Corzine probably had ways of dealing with the legislators privately, and even making them miserable, but in the past week's budget battle, his stoic face on television sent a wider signal about which side would be more immovable. When Mr. Corzine did prevail, as fellow Democrats in the General Assembly finally agreed to vote for his budget, he surprised some of those who had sized him up six months ago. That was when he arrived at the State House, keeping mostly to himself, wearing a sweater vest and tending to mumble.

Lt. Gov. Winthrop Paul Rockefeller returned to his home here on Saturday after months of treatment at a Seattle cancer clinic, including two bone marrow transplants that failed to cure a blood disease that can lead to leukemia, a spokesman for his family said. Mr. Rockefeller, 57, announced last year that he had received a diagnosis of myeloproliferative blood disorder and would obtain care from the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, a consortium of research and treatment facilities.

Q: Your new book, ''The End of Iraq: How American Incompetence Created a War Without End,'' argues that the Bush administration should stop insisting that Iraq can ever be a unified nation. Iraq still exists on a map, but it no longer functions as a single country. We're trying to build national institutions right now -- like the army and the police -- when there is no nation.

FOR years, opponents of sprawl have argued that the growth of suburbs and exurbs saps the vitality of central cities. They claim that the result has been homogenous, affluent, white bedroom communities at the urban periphery, and at the core an increasing number of poor and minority neighborhoods. They also blame sprawl for longer commuting times, more traffic congestion and increased pollution. Many of these observers hailed recent news from the Census Bureau that New York City is expected to grow by more than a million people by 2025. Some have even suggested that this might mark the end of suburban growth in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York as people move back toward the center to take advantage of shorter commuting times, more demographic diversity and all the other benefits that higher-density living can bring.

If you want a fictional character to do something stupid or reckless, just kill off one of his relatives. Being crazed with grief is a tried-and-true dramatic excuse for unlikely behavior. That's probably why Gino DiIorio and Nancy Bleemer open their affable new comedy, ''Centennial Casting,'' now at the Penguin Repertory Company, with several mentions of the recent death of Vincent DiDonato's mother. Mom ran the family business of the play's title, and now Vincent (Lou Martini Jr.) can't find anything on her desk or in the files -- except an 8-by-10 photograph of an actress name Edie Keaton, with whom he immediately falls in love.

To the Editor: ''Measuring Risk at Indian Point,'' by Herschel Specter (Op-Ed, June 25), focuses on the least important indicator of risk: early injury. The true danger of terrorism at Indian Point is the long-term effects.

A picture caption on June 25 with an article about the architect John Portman referred incorrectly to a hotel he designed. The J. W. Marriott Tomorrow Square in Shanghai opened in 2003; it is not in the planning stages.

OFFICIALS at the Masters School, a day and boarding school on a manicured 90-acre campus here, were worried about an increase in vandalism on the school's grounds, which are often used as a public shortcut through town. Over the last few years, empty beer bottles and drug paraphernalia had been found in the woods on the campus's western side; cars have been damaged as well, and one was stolen.

Mozart: 'Die Zauberfl√∂te' Vocal soloists; Arnold Schoenberg Choir; Mahler Chamber Orchestra, conducted by Claudio Abbado. Deutsche Grammophon 00289 477 5789; two CD's. FOR all its familiarity Mozart's ''Zauberfl√∂te'' remains an elusive opera. On the one hand it is just a charming fairy tale, a singspiel with spoken dialogue written for what was essentially a people's theater offering lowbrow musical comedies complete with stage effects and magic tricks. Yet ''Die Zauberfl√∂te'' is also a musically sophisticated and deeply spiritual work about a truth-seeking young prince swept into a confusing battle between forces of enlightenment and evil.

THOMAS EDISON was a 39-year-old widower with three children when he married for a second time, in 1886. As a wedding present, he gave his new bride, Mina Miller, a 29-room Queen Anne-style home in the exclusive Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, about a mile from his famous laboratories. Known as Glenmont, the estate, which sits on about 15 acres, was reopened to the public last month after a three-year, $1 million restoration by the National Park Service, which administers the property. The work on the house mainly involved the installation of a sprinkler system and a geothermal heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system.

SINCE the big things in suburbia are often taken care of -- an ample house, a stuffed Sub-Zero, a college fund -- the matters that unsettle daily equilibrium often come down to the small things. In the hamlet of Edgemont, to name one trouble spot, the smooth unfolding of everyday life is being ruffled by a battle over sidewalks. New York City denizens take them for granted; a song about the city's sidewalks was composed in the 1890's and was virtually the city's anthem until Frank Sinatra sang a better one.

Lindsey Tina Brooks, the daughter of Eleanor Brooks and Louis Brooks of Martinsville, N.J., was married in Jersey City on Monday evening to Michael Andrew Sag, the son of Marna Sag of Lansdale, Pa., and Dr. Jerome Sag of North Wales, Pa. Cantor Gabrielle Clissold officiated at Liberty House Restaurant in Liberty State Park. Mrs. Sag, 27, is the associate general manager at the Manhattan Theater Club, negotiating artist contracts and assisting the general manager. She graduated from the University of Miami. Her father is the chief financial officer of Active Concepts, a maker of ingredients for hair and skin care in Piscataway, N.J. Her mother teaches high school history at Solomon Schechter Day School of Essex and Union in West Orange.

You can buy incense in red or yellow, and they burn about three weeks. Your eyes are tearing. I had just come from New Zealand, where I led a trip for a month. I said bye-bye to my group and made a stopover in Hong Kong, where I was joined by my husband, Herman Wouters, who took this photograph. I'm hooked on traveling. But a real vacation for me? TWO proposals for converting a building that takes up a city block in the heart of Hempstead Village into a commercial and residential development have revealed markedly different visions for revitalizing the downtown. The building, at 100 Main Street, is a former bus terminal and, possibly, a future anchor for downtown. But it is unclear who will develop the site or what it will eventually contain.

To the Editor: ''Paradise Bought'' erroneously states that before its creation 16 years ago, North Beverly Park was ''a 250-acre swath of flat, empty scrub.'' Nothing is more untrue. Rather, it was beautiful mixed oak woodland, home to many indigenous California birds, like the endangered oak titmouse, that crucially depend on the coast live oak and other native flora.

CAPE CANAVERAL The News -- The space shuttle Discovery safely lifted off and later docked with the International Space Station. Behind the News -- The flight was the shuttle system's first in a year, and only the second since the Columbia disintegrated on re-entry in 2003, killing the seven-member crew. In this launching there appeared to be no major damage from foam insulation falling off the shuttle's external fuel tank, a problem that had doomed Columbia and that had cropped up again on the flight a year ago. But if NASA seemed to have taken care of one headache, it faced longer-term ones: how to re-establish a presence in space with a diminished shuttle fleet that is expected to be retired in 2010, and how to fight a perception that its programs, particularly the space station, lack purpose. NORH KOREA The News -- North Korea went on a rocket-launching spree, firing at least seven missiles over the Sea of Japan, including one that is designed to be able to reach Alaska. Behind the News -- The long-range missile, the Taepodong 2, failed or was aborted shortly after launching and fell into the Sea of Japan. But some United States officials said even a failure would provide some valuable information for the North Koreans, who seem intent on developing a long-range missile capability. The White House, which had long ignored Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, has more recently tried to engage him in diplomacy, urging international support for strong measures, including sanctions, to get the country to drop its weapons program. But China and Russia resisted the move. THE MIDDLE EAST The News -- Hamas militants fired a small rocket deeper into Israel, prompting the Israeli military to move farther into Gaza. Behind the News -- The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Olmert, called the Qassam rocket fired from Gaza that landed in Ashkelon, a city of 115,000 six miles from the Gaza border, an ''escalation without precedent.'' It and the other launchings were also evidence that the Israeli strategy of positioning troops just inside Gaza was ineffective. So the military moved farther into the territory, taking up positions near abandoned Israeli settlements. Prime Minister Olmert faced a delicate balancing act: pushing militarily against Hamas while trying to get the organization, and its military wing, to release a captured Israeli soldier. WASHINGTON The News -- Central Intelligence Agency officials said the agency had closed a unit that had hunted for Osama bin Laden. Behind the News -- The disbanding of the unit, which had been in operation since long before the Sept. 11 attacks, is a sign of increased concern that other groups have begun carrying out attacks independent of Mr. bin Laden, and that Al Qaeda is a more decentralized organization than it once was. Agency officials said that while efforts to capture Mr. bin Laden were as strong as ever, the better plan was to focus on regional trends rather than specific individuals or groups. But one former senior C.I.A. official said the closing would hurt the search for the Qaeda leader. ATLANTA The News -- Federal agents in Atlanta foiled a plot to sell Coca-Cola Company secrets to PepsiCo. Behind the News -- A Coca-Cola employee and two other people were arrested and charged with stealing the information and trying to sell it for $1.5 million to PepsiCo, which alerted Coca-Cola officials to the plot. The authorities said they had videotaped one of those arrested, an executive administrative assistant at the company, stuffing documents into bags and holding a small vial containing a product sample. It appeared that the purloined information concerned a beverage under development; a Coca-Cola spokesman said the most jealously guarded secret, the recipe for Coca-Cola Classic, was safe and sound. The company said it would tighten security.

GRUBER--Robert A. On July 6 at 86 years. Devoted husband of Harriet and the late Marilyn, beloved and loving father of Gary, adored brother of the late Pearl and surviving sister Martha. Also survived by nieces Lise, Maya and Shelley, grandnephews Joshua and Charles, by Rod and Cheryl, Amy and Greg, Kristin and Chad Brayman and by Karen, Dick, Courtney and Lindsay Turner. Bob served in WWII as a US Army Air Corps Warrant Officer and was a CPA for 40 years. He was a partner in the accounting firm of Bookbinder, Stein, Tunick & Platkin. He will be remembered for his keen intelligence and social graces and will be missed by his family and many friends. Services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck this Sunday, July 9 at 9:30AM. Interment will follow at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

PURCELL--James T. Age 79, of North Fort Meyers, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died June 30 at Cape Coral Hospital. A veteran of WW II, he lived much of his life in Norwalk, CT and Willsboro, NY. He was employed by the New York Times for 35 years and retired as production manager in 1983. He is preceded in death by his wife, Margery Purcell. Survived by his daughter, Jean Walter, sons Thomas, James M. and Dennis, and nine grandchildren. Memorial service on August 2 at St. John's Episcopal Church, Essex, NY. Memorials can be sent to St. John's.
To the Editor: In ''Live Kiosk Free, or Die'' (Op-Ed, July 2), Jeff Colt bemoans the presence of food concessions in city parks, but these park amenities have a rich and storied history.

Stamford has established free wireless Internet access downtown, in Columbus Park. Now, anyone with a Connecticut library card can relax in the park, pop open a laptop and answer e-mail. This is a smart move. It is a selling point for the city. Stamford is thinking of expanding Wi-Fi to other parks, showing that it has been paying attention to visionaries in places like New York, where Bryant Park has a wireless network; Washington; Fresno, Calif.; Cincinnati; and Singapore.

SCHOOL superintendents in the metropolitan area are among the best paid public servants anywhere. In Westchester, the median base salary among the county's superintendents was $210,000 in 2005-6, which is more than the governor or the vice president makes, and many bring in much more than $300,000 in pay and benefits. Their defenders say that they make less than chief executives in the private sector who have companies with similar budgets. But critics say their salaries are inflated by cozy relationships with their boards.
To the Editor: Re ''Keeping Tabs on Teenage Drinking'' (July 2):

DEL TORO--Vincent, 82, Electrical Engineer and Emeritus Professor of City College of New York died on Wednesday, July 5, in New Jersey. He was a devoted teacher and prolific author. His teaching honors included three Educator of the Year awards and he authored 10 books on electrical engineering including the best selling textbooks, ''Principles of Electrical Engineering'' and ''Electrical Engineering Fundamentals.'' He graduated from CCNY and Brooklyn Polytechnic University. Survivors include his wife of 41 years, Franca, and two sons, Marc and Peter. Memorial donations may be made in his name to the City College 21st Century Foundation, Attn:Rosemary Weiss, City College of New York, 160 Convent Avenue, S-154, New York, NY 10031.

BARRETT--Arthur L. 88, on July 7, 2006, in Goshen, NY. Devoted husband of Mary B. Barrett, loving father of David and Didi, and proud grandfather of Alec and Annabel Barrett. Raised in Shanghai, China, educated at Grinnell College and Harvard, he was a dedicated teacher and retired chairman of the Middletown (NY) High School English Department.
