To the Editor: Re ''Paradise Bought'' (July 2) :

TULLY -- Kathryn (Kay). Passed away peacefully at home surrounded by her family on July 8th. She is survived by her loving husband, William J. Tully, her nine cherished children, her 17 adoring grandchildren and her new great-grandchild. Reposing at Pelham Funeral Home, Monday, July 10, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Tuesday, 10 AM.

The Cultured Traveler column on June 25, about contemporary art in Mexico City, referred incorrectly to Z√≥calo, the city's main square, which is home to many of the city's cultural treasures. The square is treeless, not ''leafy.''

ALL is not well in my Garden of Eden. I first discovered that I had a problem last summer as I was leaving with my family on a vacation to Canada. Just before I pulled out of the driveway, I grabbed a can of fish food and hustled over to my pond, which is the centerpiece of my front lawn in New Jersey and a major source of domestic pride.
NEARY--Laurence J. Beloved husband of Joan, father of Scott and Jeffrey, brother of Robert and grandfather of Noah Collier, on July 6 2006 after a long illness.

Last month the Supreme Court offered self-indulgent state legislatures the judicial equivalent of a hot fudge sundae when it mostly approved the wildly partisan Texas redistricting plan engineered by former Representative Tom DeLay. It was a depressing outcome and one that made it even more critical that local elected officials be mobilized to adopt more equitable methods of drawing political boundaries. That is very much the case in New York, which suffers from a different form of compulsive gerrymandering than Texas. Instead of manipulating geography to give one party the political edge, the New York State Legislature -- divided for so long between a Republican Senate and Democratic Assembly -- tends to stick to protecting incumbents.

FOR years, opponents of sprawl have argued that the growth of suburbs and exurbs saps the vitality of central cities. They claim that the result has been homogenous, affluent, white bedroom communities at the urban periphery, and at the core an increasing number of poor and minority neighborhoods. They also blame sprawl for longer commuting times, more traffic congestion and increased pollution. Many of these observers hailed recent news from the Census Bureau that New York City is expected to grow by more than a million people by 2025. Some have even suggested that this might mark the end of suburban growth in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York as people move back toward the center to take advantage of shorter commuting times, more demographic diversity and all the other benefits that higher-density living can bring.

To the Editor: Perhaps there is a connection between treating husbands like trainable seals and the fact that, by some estimates, as many as 40 percent of American males are sexually dysfunctional. But, of course, Amy Sutherland is entitled to a perfect husband, having apparently reached perfection in herself. Still, it may not have occurred to her that in most of the world's cultures, her words and behavior in regard to her husband would be considered not only insulting but aberrant. One can only hope that the hapless male who has the misfortune of being married to her will eventually find the mental and emotional strength to find his freedom. Vito Stagliano Chicago

As an entrepreneur, a merchandiser and a civic-minded citizen, Leslie H. Wexner, the founder, chairman and chief executive of Limited Brands, has long been near the top of many lists. Now Mr. Wexner, along with his wife, Abigail S. Wexner, has joined the list of the world's top 10 art collectors, published in the latest issue of ArtNews. Long a supporter of the arts, Mr. Wexner founded the Wexner Center for the Arts (named for his father, Harry L. Wexner) at Ohio State University and sponsors the annual $50,000 Wexner Prize. He joins Charles Saatchi, the advertising executive; Stephen A. Wynn, the casino developer; and Fran√ßois Pinault, the luxury goods retailer, on the ArtNews list of art buyers.

LANDES--Evelyn. At home in New Rochelle, July 2nd, 2006. Loving mother and inspiration to Alan, Vikki, Llyana, wife to Edward. She surrounded herself with beauty, books, a wonderful circle of friends/family who will miss her terribly and treasure her memory.

To the Editor: ''In Ramadi, Fetid Quarters and Unrelenting Battles'' (front page, July 5) describes a poster hanging inside an American-held building that says, ''Be polite, be professional and have a plan to kill everyone you meet.''
To the Editor: Re ''Keeping Tabs on Teenage Drinking'' (July 2):

Michelle Terese Musorofiti, a daughter of Jeanne Musorofiti and Robert Musorofiti of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., was married Tuesday to Peter James Sellers, the son of Christine Sellers and Walter Sellers of Edmonds, Wash. Msgr. John A. Alesandro performed the ceremony at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Chapel in Oyster Bay. Mrs. Sellers, 28, is a mathematics teacher at Roslyn High School in Roslyn, N.Y. She graduated from Cornell and received a master's degree in secondary education from Adelphi University.

Jere Longman breaks down a few matchups in today's World Cup final between Italy and France. Gennaro Gattuso ITALY MIDFIELDER VS. Zin.dine Zidane FRANCE PLAYMAKER Gattuso is a relentless irritant on defense, clogging the middle, tackling fiercely, disrupting the flow of an opponent's offense. Zidane is the French playmaker, clever with the ball and always a threat to score. At 34, he is playing in his final match before retirement, which should provide him with even more incentive to win a second World Cup in eight years. Fabio Cannavaro ITALY DEFENDER VS. Thierry Henry FRANCE FORWARD Stocky and muscular in central defense, Cannavaro, Italy's captain, has anchored a defense that has allowed only one goal in six matches -- a ball Italy kicked into its own net against the United States. Marcello Lippi, Italy's coach, calls him the best defender in the world. Henry is fast, elegant and possesses a great finishing touch. His volley defeated Brazil in the quarterfinals, and his run into the box drew a penalty kick that defeated Portugal in the semifinals. First goal wins The 2006 World Cup is on course to produce the lowest scoring total since the 1990 World Cup in Italy. Heading into yesterday's third-place match, this tournament had averaged only 2.27 goals, the lowest since 1990, when 2.21 goals a game were scored. The losing team in a World Cup final has not scored a goal since 1986, which means the first one to put the ball into the net today would seem to have a huge advantage.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Face It: U.S. No Longer Reigns Supreme'' (Selena Roberts, July 4): Thomas J. Watson's slogan ''world peace through world trade'' might be extended to ''world peace through world play.''
The Going To column on June 25 about Lake Como misidentified a tavern in Cernobbio, a town in the region. It is Barry's Bar, not Harry's Bar.

A collection of historic but fading murals that adorn the walls of Yonkers City Hall will be restored early next year in time for the hall's centennial in 2008. The 11 murals hang from the walls of the City Council chambers and tell the story of Yonkers since it was first settled by Lenape Indians hundreds of years ago. They were painted by the muralists Vincent Aderente and A. E. Foringer when City Hall was built a century ago and are among the building's most recognizable features.

To the Editor: Amy Sutherland shares the information that she and her husband had tried marriage counseling. I would suggest she resume individual therapy as soon as possible to try to understand why she is attracted to males who are emotionally 12 years old. Therapy may also help her to learn that the vast majority of American husbands do not require training, cajoling or even a reminder to pick up their dirty laundry. Robert L. Caulfield San Francisco

The Going To column on April 9 about Brussels misstated the dates of the Brussels Flower Carpet, a biennial event that covers Grand Place with begonias. It is Aug. 12 to 15 this year, not 15 to 18. A reader pointed out the error by e-mail on June 20.

JACQUELINE NEWMAN got her first Chinese cookbook as a wedding gift more than 50 years ago. She bought another, and another, and soon, she recalled, collecting Chinese cookbooks became ''a love, an obsession, a sickness.'' She has collected scores of new Chinese cookbooks every year for several decades now, often traveling the globe to get them.

A new show every Tuesday for 10 crazy weeks: that was summer stock on the straw-hat circuit, so named for its informality compared with the fancy-dress season in town. What ISAIAH SHEFFER remembers most fondly about his own time in those trenches 40 years ago is the ''intimacy and unpretentiousness'' of the offerings. More recently Mr. Sheffer, who is now 70, sought to revive the tradition, not in lakeside vacation communities but in Manhattan, where he is artistic director of Symphony Space. For the last four years off-season renovations to the three-theater complex interfered, but finally this month he's inaugurating SUMMER STOCK ON BROADWAY, which he hopes will be an annual event. First up: a ''newly discovered lost musical'' by RODGERS AND HART. If you've heard Mr. Sheffer play host to Symphony Space's ''Selected Shorts'' series, you know his impish humor, so it's no surprise that despite his claim to have found the score in the same Secaucus warehouse ''where they find all the old musicals,'' ''MANHATTAN MADCAPS OF 1924'' is a fake. Having secured the patchwork of rights to perform 22 Rodgers and Hart songs -- from familiar classics (''He Was Too Good to Me'') to extreme obscurities (''Stonewall Moskowitz March'') to some that are both (three early versions of ''Blue Moon'') -- Mr. Sheffer hired one Jerzy Turnpike (who oddly resembles his boss) to fashion a libretto at least as inane as the shows and movies from which the songs were extracted. The result, which is now in previews and opens Thursday in the 99-seat Leonard Nimoy Thalia, certainly replicates the intimacy and unpretentiousness of summer stock that Mr. Sheffer treasured, and even the low prices. All he needs now are the feral mosquitoes. Through July 23, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400; $19.

NEW YORKERS dodged a bullet last month when the State Senate rejected a bill, which the Assembly had earlier passed, that would have increased the number of bottles and cans that can be returned for a 5-cent deposit at your local grocery store. Why am I pleased with the decision? Because the state has had a bottle bill on the books since 1982 and besides being a disaster for me as a supermarket owner, it's had little overall effect on recycling. If recycling is important -- and I believe it is -- we need something more than bottle bills.

To judge from the outside, Tom the Greengrocer is the floral centerpiece of Scotch Plains, with its maze of blooming plants and flowers, hanging baskets and quirky garden art. Inside, the produce is edible. Bins are filled with gorgeous Jersey corn and tomatoes and premium fruits like colossal red and white Mt. Rainier cherries averaging $5.95 a pound, along with extra-virgin olive oils and an array of artisan breads.

Ayesha Khan, the daughter of Yasmin Nighat Khan of New York and the late Raja Karam Dad Khan, was married at the Yale Club of New York yesterday to Dr. Ali Omer Farooqi, a son of Dr. Shabnam O. Farooqi and Dr. M. Sultan Farooqi of Karachi, Pakistan. Imam Ghazi Y. Khankan, a Muslim cleric, officiated. Mrs. Farooqi, 32, was until last month an associate in the New York office of Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, the Los Angeles law firm, for which she specialized in corporate finance matters. She is to become a corporate finance associate next month in the New York offices of the Los Angeles law firm of Latham & Watkins. She graduated from Queens College and received a law degree from St. John's University.

GORDUN -- Douglas Wolfe. Died from cancer on June 26, 2006. Doug was a courageous and intrepid liberal, who dedicated his life as a professional consultant to elect Democratic candidates to local, state and national offices. He was an avid rock climber, raconteur, cyclist and Trekker. Doug served as the President of New York Young Democrats and Vice-President of Young Democrats of America. Doug's parents, Jack Gordun and Winifred Wolfe are both deceased. He is survived by his cousin, Mark Wolfe of Thousand Oaks, CA. Service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street Monday, July 10, 2006 at 7 P.M. Doug's friends request that you contribute in his memory to the Democratic candidate of your choice, or to the Winifred Wolfe Scholarship Fund, c/o Curtis Arluck, Treasurer, 545 West 111th Street, Apt. 8B, New York, NY 10025.

THE historian David Oshinsky, who reviews two books about Hurricane Katrina on this week's cover, taught at Rutgers for more than 30 years but moved to the University of Texas in 2002. The reaction in George W. Bush's home state to the administration's handling of Katrina, Oshinsky said in an e-mail message, was ''one of shock and embarrassment.'' The president ''is popular here and remembered by most as having been an effective state leader. Texans expected a whole lot more from him.'' In contrast, he added, ''Gov. Rick Perry, a conservative Republican, led a heroic effort to welcome more than 250,000 Katrina refugees. Houston became the epicenter, but every town pitched in. Here in Austin, 5,000 evacuees were provided housing, clothing, health care, counseling, even library cards. Kids at the Sanchez Elementary School, in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, raised $2,200 for the relief effort. It brought tears to your eyes.''

OFFICIALS at the Masters School, a day and boarding school on a manicured 90-acre campus here, were worried about an increase in vandalism on the school's grounds, which are often used as a public shortcut through town. Over the last few years, empty beer bottles and drug paraphernalia had been found in the woods on the campus's western side; cars have been damaged as well, and one was stolen.

The developers of a $1.6 billion proposal to rebuild the Nassau Coliseum and turn the sea of parking that surrounds it into a ''town square'' -- a bustling destination spot that currently doesn't exist on Long Island -- signed an agreement on June 29 with Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive. But the project may face its biggest hurdle yet as it goes before the Town of Hempstead for zoning approval, a process that will most likely take several years to complete.

THE ball fields at Commack Park were filled with Little League baseball teams practicing for the tournament season one day in late June. The parents were getting ready, too. ''I love this game,'' Valerie Monroy said as she watched her 10-year-old son, William, go through infield drills with his teammates. ''I think it's so cute.'' Donna Pesci, the mother of Joseph, also 10, said her favorite part of the game was when the catcher went out to the mound for a chat with the pitcher. ''What can they be talking about?'' she said.

To the Editor: In response to Walter Kirn's review of my collection ''The Din in the Head'' (July 2), I offer ''How to Write a Literary Essay, by Walter Kirn'': No words too big, no brow too high. Haunch lacks raunch, so just say thigh. Stuck-up prose gets up your nose. Edge is what the wise guy knows. What's new is true, the rest is quaint. What Trilling was is what you ain't. If you don't agree with the dogma I bring You are left behind (and surely right-wing). So take my advice, and din it in your head: The best is right now, because Trilling is dead. Cynthia Ozick New Rochelle, N.Y.

''I take the path of least resistance. This summer, I looked for the four easiest courses I could take that would let me graduate in August.'' RICK KOHN, a student at the University of North Carolina, Greensboro. [1]

Like some gleefully malevolent highway engineer, the playwright Rupert Holmes packed his 1989 whodunit ''Accomplice'' full of pretzel turns, stops and starts and slam-on-the-brakes denouements. Currently being presented by the Two River Theater Company here as a summer offering, a kind of Two River Lite, this slick and witty spoof is receiving a marvelously acted and directed production that celebrates the victory of style over substance. And with no apologies necessary, thank you.

Jody Ruth Jakob, a school psychologist, was married last evening to Dean Jerry Schlanger, a high school principal. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz officiated at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, N.Y. The bride, 35, works at the Sawmill Intermediate School in Commack, N.Y. She graduated from Hofstra University, where she also received a doctoral degree in school and community psychology. In addition, she has a master's degree in school psychology from St. John's University. She is a daughter of Laura Jakob of Fresh Meadows, Queens, and Howard Jakob of Park Ridge, N.J., and is a stepdaughter of Eva Jakob and of Sheldon Flatow.

When the Museum of Modern Art organized a Lee Friedlander retrospective last year, it included almost 500 photographs, making it one of the most sprawling shows of its kind. Now imagine an exhibition with 100,000 photos, and that's just for starters. The show -- ''Self-Portraitr: An Interactive Exhibition Curating the Flickr Community'' -- at the Pace/MacGill Gallery in Midtown, is a marriage of the gallery world, the Internet and that most democratic of media, photography. Conceived with the help of the graduate photography department at the School of Visual Arts, the show allows anyone who is a member of the wildly popular photo-sharing Web site Flickr to join in as artist or curator or both. Any photo posted to the site and given the tag ''self-portrait'' automatically becomes part of the show, which can be perused either at the gallery -- computer screens and monitors have been installed for viewing -- or on the gallery's Web site, www.pacemacgill.com. By Aug. 25, when the show closes, tens of thousands more photos, most by amateurs, some by professionals, will probably be added, and members of the site will help choose the best pictures by voting for their favorites. 32 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7999. What does the most expensive painting in the world look like? You can see for yourself on Thursday, when ''Adele Bloch-Bauer I,'' the gold-flecked 1907 portrait by Gustav Klimt, goes on display at the Neue Galerie, whose founder, the cosmetics magnate RONALD S. LAUDER, paid a record $135 million for the work last month. The portrait, depicting the hostess of a prominent Vienna salon, was the focus of a highly publicized restitution battle between the Austrian government and a niece of Mrs. Bloch-Bauer, who argued that it had been seized along with four other Klimt paintings by the Nazis. In January an Austrian tribunal awarded her and her fellow heirs the paintings. All will be included in the show, ''GUSTAV KLIMT: FIVE PAINTING FROM THE COLLECTION OF FERDINAND AND ADELE BLOCH-BAUER,'' which runs through Sept. 18. 1048 Fifth Avenue at 86th Street; (212) 628-6200.

A recipe with the Food column on June 25 misstated an ingredient in the instructions for rhubarb pie. In the first step, the crust ingredients should stop being mixed when the sheen of the shortening, not the butter, disappears.

THEY look like the houses just down the street, and like dwellings from another world. Two structures on the grounds of the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, at 258 Main Street, are faithful copies of Victorian homes in Ridgefield, except for a couple of details: They are about a third the size of the originals, and they are inflatable, with bulging walls and squishy-looking roofs. The works of the artist John Giglio, the houses seem so puffy and playful, they bring to mind the Moonbounce at a summer carnival. But Mr. Giglio's objective wasn't all fun and games.

OVER the last few years, as its residents fought a battle against the city to keep their homes, the Fort Trumbull neighborhood of New London looked more and more like a war-torn village, with acres of vacant lots interrupted intermittently by debris and a few scattered houses. Fort Trumbull was at the center of a national debate over eminent domain last year after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the city could take residents' homes and transfer them to a private developer to put up new housing, offices and a hotel. Of the seven property owners who sued the city, the final two agreed on June 30 to settle, ending the battle.

BRODERICK--Most Reverend Edwin B. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick notes with deep sadness the passing of a most distinguished, honorary member, the Most Reverend Edwin B. Broderick and extends its deepest sympathy and condolences to his surviving nieces and nephews. Alfred E. Smith IV, President Henry F. White, Jr. Historian

9 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO -- He's one of Hollywood's most talented -- and most troubled. Tonight, Robert Downey Jr. (left) talks about drug addiction, prison and staying clean while continuing to demonstrate his acting gift in films like ''Kiss Kiss Bang Bang'' and ''Good Night, and Good Luck.'' 5:30 P.M. (A&E) BIG SPENDER -- The people at A&E are calling it a cross between Dr. Phil and Suze Orman, but it's Larry Winget, a personal money manager, who is doing the hard work here. In this new half-hour series, a few of the 40 percent of Americans who live beyond their financial means are filmed in the midst of their spending frenzies, then taught how to rein in their lifestyles. 8 P.M. (Food Network) EMERIL LIVE -- Mr. Lagasse whips up classic dishes from New Orleans -- fried shrimp po'boys, duck and sausage gumbo, shrimp and mirliton casserole, and bread pudding -- to the sounds of Bourbon Street from the jazz trumpeter Wynton Marsalis (above). 8 P.M. (History Channel) TRUE CARIBBEAN PIRATES -- Capt. Jack Sparrow, the Johnny Depp creation in ''Pirates of the Caribbean,'' is nothing compared with these terrorists of the high seas. This special chronicles the golden years of piracy in the late-15th and 16th centuries as Spain mined the New World for treasures and men with names like Capt. Henry Morgan, Blackbeard, Calico Jack and Black Bart tried to claim them as their own, using whatever force was necessary. 9 P.M. (Comedy Central) CHAPPELLE'S SHOW -- They're being plugged as ''the lost episodes,'' but these skits are really just the ones Dave Chappelle did before his aversion to fame sent him packing. In this season premiere, Mr. Chappelle seeks revenge on all those who have wronged him. 9 P.M. (13, 49) MISS MARPLE, SERIES II: THE MOVING FINGER -- When is the pen mightier than the sword? When the letters being written with it are of the poisonous variety. In this new ''Mystery!'' production, Jerry Burton (James D'Arcy) travels to the sleepy village of Lymstock to recuperate from a motorcycle accident, only to discover that a round of hate mail has wreaked havoc on residents' lives. Thank God Miss Marple (Geraldine McEwan, above, with Mr. D'Arcy) is in town. 10 P.M. (Showtime) BROTHERHOOD -- Two brothers from a blue-collar neighborhood in Providence, R.I., veer in opposite directions -- one into local government, the other into organized crime -- in pursuit of the American dream. In this series premiere, Tommy Caffee finds his political ambitions jeopardized when his brother Michael reappears to make amends with his estranged family and claim his place as the city's underworld kingpin. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

To the Editor: Duh! What took them so long? But now that we have their attention with ''Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont,'' ''Ladies in Lavender'' and the rest, they proceed to muck it all up with Ms. Seidelman's ''Boynton Beach Club.'' In case they didn't notice, none of the previous films featured aged Gidgets frolicking by the pool in unseemly beach attire. Actually they may want to leave the whole thing to the British. Our local art house is filled with elderly audiences (mostly women) starved for intelligent, literate movie fare of all kinds, preferably featuring excellent older actors and actresses. A. Jacobucci Centerville, Mass.

THEY look like the houses just down the street, and like dwellings from another world. Two structures on the grounds of the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, at 258 Main Street, are faithful copies of Victorian homes in Ridgefield, except for a couple of details: They are about a third the size of the originals, and they are inflatable, with bulging walls and squishy-looking roofs. The works of the artist John Giglio, the houses seem so puffy and playful, they bring to mind the Moonbounce at a summer carnival. But Mr. Giglio's object wasn't all fun and games.

GUTTAG--Marjorie. Of Delray Beach, FL, widow of Irwin Guttag, passed away Friday, July 7, 2006. Born Marjorie Vogel, she grew up in Long Beach, NY, and attended Syracuse University. She was an accomplished artist and had a longstanding interest in community service. She served as President of the Mid-Westchester YMHA, a member of the Board of the Jewish Communal Fund, and a member of the Distribution Committee of UJA-Federation of NY. She is survived by her daughter Addie of NYC, her son John and daughterin-law Olga of Lexington, MA, and her grandchildren David, Andrea, Michael and Mark. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM on Sunday, July 9, at the 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Ave. Friends are invited to visit with the family at 575 Park Ave. immediately following the service and on Monday from 2 to 7 PM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the charity of your choice.
To the Editor: Re ''Beatles in Vegas Against the Odds'' by Allan Kozinn [June 25]:

FORTY years of service to Nassau and Suffolk Counties, a forced retirement and not a gold watch in sight: Lee Koppelman, 79, a man with a master plan, is officially finished fighting the demon sprawl that is gobbling up Long Island. But unofficially, he's still on duty; he's a thousand pages into drafting the third regional plan, a 1,200-page document that is his last hurrah. Or lasting legacy. If the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, who authorized delivery of the pink slip to Mr. Koppelman in May, does not want his continued input on open space and groundwater preservation, on a prudent plan for energy, plus a manifesto against mushrooming malls, too bad. He's getting it anyway.

To the Editor: With the American divorce rate where it is, ''What Shamu Taught Me About a Happy Marriage,'' by Amy Sutherland (''Modern Love,'' June 25), could certainly be considered one of the most important, if not most useful, articles you have published all year. Thank you, I'm indebted! Sophie Sutton New York

MITHERZ--Beatrice. On July 2, 2006 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Leon Mitherz. Loving mother of Steve Mitherz and his wife Ellen Kirouac and Mara Lehmann. Grandmother of Joshua and Julie. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice

The formula for terror is simple (Christopher Caldwell, June 25). A few disaffected teenagers, a crowded urban setting and a messianic leader promising martyrdom in the service of Allah are all that is needed to channel angst into suicidal rage. Among the law-abiding citizens of London's Muslim community, there is no way to tell just by looking who is carrying hate in his heart or a bomb in his backpack. That's what terror is -- the uncertainty, the not knowing. Carol Haskill San Francisco

An article last Sunday about ''Boynton Beach Club'' contained an incomplete reference to the companies distributing the film. In addition to Roadside Attractions, Samuel Goldwyn Films is releasing it.

WHEN the popular superintendent of schools here put out the word in January that he would be leaving at the end of the year, the search for a new educator in chief began at once. In this intimate district in Westchester County, at once arty and high-achieving, the hunt for a new leader propelled the Board of Education -- and the community -- on a journey that was far more complex and heady than anyone had imagined.

Andrea Michelle Zucker and Dr. Nicolas David Muzin were married on Monday evening at the North Charleston Convention Center in South Carolina. Rabbi Yehoshua Weber officiated, with Rabbi Ari Sytner taking part. Mrs. Muzin, 24, is a business consultant in Washington for nonprofit organizations and for family businesses, including Tristan Restaurant, Sunfire Grill & Bistro and the Carolina Palace ice skating rink, all in Charleston. She graduated summa cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania. Next month she is to begin studying for an M.B.A. at George Washington.

PLAIN speaking can be a rare commodity in the debate over corporate governance, but Charles T. Munger dished out plenty of it at this year's two-day ''director's college'' at the Stanford Law School. Mr. Munger, the vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway in Omaha, said that many corporate governance problems stem from one thing: executive greed. ''We expect guys to be generals and Supreme Court justices and all kinds of things where they do a lot of good and retire to obscurity and never get rich,'' he said. ''It isn't asking too much of a C.E.O. that he not have some wretched excess of compensation hit the headlines at the same time he's laying off 50,000 workers.''

An article on Page 13 of The Times Magazine today about the recent Supreme Court decision that blocked the Bush administration's plan to try detainees at Guant√°namo Bay by military commission misattributes a passage from a Supreme Court opinion 60 years ago that dealt with many of the same issues in the case of a Japanese war criminal. The dissenting opinion, about ''the immutable rights of the individual,'' was written by Justice Frank Murphy, not another of the dissenters, Justice Wiley B. Rutledge.

BENSON--J. Goffe, 93, died in his home in Waccabuc, NY on June 30, 2006. His career at Union Carbide (now part of Dow Chemical), included serving as the president of the Linde division, and as a vice president of the corporation. Mr. Benson was an avid golfer, and traveled extensively. His first wife Margaret Oehler, died in 1973. He is survived by his wife of 30 years Marie Tiesler Goldfinger, and his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

OSTROVE--Tanya. On July 6, 2006. Beloved aunt of Barbara Gross, Deborah Verlen and Susan Matthews. Dearest great aunt of Jerry Gross, Jason Verlen, Ira Gross and Zachary Haines. Loving great-great aunt of Wyatt and Danielle Verlen and Roisin Gross. Graveside service Monday, July 10, 1pm, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Contributions to Sarah Neuman Center for Healthcare and Rehabilitation, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER ends its Met season on a high note this week with six wonderful sets of Romeos and Juliets in Kenneth MacMillan's tried and trusted version of this ballet. First choice must go to the delightful JULIE KENT-MARCELO GOMES pairing on Friday night, which will celebrate Ms. Kent's 20th anniversary with the company. But ballet lovers shouldn't miss ALESSANDRA FERRI, partnered by JOSE MANUEL CARRE√ëO, in one of her signature dramatic roles, on Tuesday and Saturday, or the gloriously expressive DIANA VISHNEVA with ANGEL CORELLA on Monday. And devotees will also want to catch the young DAVID HALLBERG, the company's newest principal: he is making his New York debut as Romeo opposite PALOMA HERRERA on Wednesday night and Saturday afternoon. ''Romeo and Juliet,'' Monday through Saturday at 8 p.m., and Wednesday and Saturday at 2 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000 or abt.org; $23 to $100. CHUNKY MOVE, a group based in Melbourne, Australia, has made a name for itself as an adept practitioner of an intensely physical, muscular movement style. GIDEON OBARZANEK's nicely titled ''I Want to Dance Better at Parties'' takes the stories of five men and their relationships to dance as a starting point, offering an interpretation of their experiences -- seen on film -- by the company dancers. The piece won several awards at the 2005 Melbourne Festival; it sounds intriguing. Tuesday through Saturday at 8 p.m., and Saturday at 2 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or www.joyce.org; $36. Audiences had a brief glimpse of TANIA P√âREZ-SALAS's lush, visually compelling work at last year's Fall for Dance. This Mexican choreographer brings her company to the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival this week, presenting two American premieres that sound somewhat in the Pina Bausch mode of major stage mess: ''Waters of Forgetfulness'' features 500 gallons of water and sheets of sand pouring down. Also on the program is ''The Hours'' which puts three women inside a huge ball gown and promises a score by Lully, Vivaldi and the Slavic rock musician Goran Bregovic. Wednesday through Saturday at 8 p.m., and Saturday and next Sunday at 2 p.m., 358 George Carter Road, Becket, Mass., (413) 243-0745 or jacobspillow.org.; $45, $40.50 for students and 65+.

ROSENBLATT--Hortense, (nee Weinstock), died on May 31, 2006 in San Francisco at the age of 85. Predeceased by husband William, she is survived by her daughters Nan and Jane, son-in-law Jeffrey, brother Louis, and grandchildren Zachary and Lauren. Her fun loving spirit will be greatly missed.

GOLODNER--Syril Kirson, 82. On July 5, 2006. Born and raised in Manhattan, resided in Park Slope, and was a resident of Boca Raton, FL since 2000. A homemaker, business manager and children's clothing buyer, Syril was an elegant, graceful and caring woman who was deeply loved by her family and friends. Syril had a keen sense of humor, which stayed with her, and pleased those around her, throughout her life. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harry Golodner. Devoted mother of Dr. Ellen Golodner, Adam Golodner & Meg Quiat and mother-in-law of Eileen McMahon and Daniel Quiat. Adored grandmother of Caitlin and Sarah Quiat. Services Sunday, July 9th, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to HospiceCare of Boulder County, 2594 Trailridge Dr. Lafayette, CO 80026.

The Practical Traveler column on June 25 about getting the best currency exchange rates abroad misstated three examples of exchange rates for converting United States dollars to British pounds. Thomas Cook recently offered an exchange rate of $2.03 converted to ¬£1, not 2.03 percent; Natwest quoted a rate of $1.9551 to ¬£1, not 1.9551 percent; and HSBC quoted a rate of $1.9766, not 1.9766 percent.

SCHOOL superintendents in the metropolitan area are among the best paid public servants anywhere. In Westchester, the median base salary among the county's superintendents was $210,000 in 2005-6, which is more than the governor or the vice president makes, and many bring in much more than $300,000 in pay and benefits. Their defenders say that they make less than chief executives in the private sector who have companies with similar budgets. But critics say their salaries are inflated by cozy relationships with their boards.

Benoit Denizet-Lewis (June 25) carefully lays out the evolving scientific approach to treating addiction, and it is promising. The treatment field is at a crossroads. We should find ways to integrate pharmacology with psychological and behavioral interventions so that we can comprehensively heal the pain and emptiness of addiction. Peter Provet President, Odyssey House New York As William C. Moyers aptly stated, ''Recovery is also about the spirit, about dealing with that hole in the soul.'' But it was disturbing that there was no mention of our soulless drug policy, which routinely punishes drug users who are poor, through cycles of incarceration -- imitating the psychologist Bruce Alexander's description of putting rats in small cages. Carol Shapiro Founder and Executive Director Family Justice New York

WATROUS - Philip. The Board of Directors and staff of Jericho Project mourn the passing of our friend and mentor Phil Watrous, a Founding Director of Jericho since 1983. Phil always showed compassion for those less fortunate, modestly likening himself to a leaky pail watering the plants along the road. His guidance helped Jericho Project navigate safely through difficult times in the early days. Phil will forever remain an inspiration for his continued service to others and good humor throughout his 12 - year struggle with ALS. Our love goes out to his wife, Linda, and his family

If you're a gambler, you can always find a silver lining -- even when the casinos shut down, as they were forced to do last week in Atlantic City. Just ask George Cann, 53, of New Milford. He was in Atlantic City early Wednesday morning, playing roulette at Caesars. And he would have continued playing had the casino not been forced to close at 8 a.m. because of the government shutdown prompted by the impasse over the state budget. (State inspectors are required for the casino to operate.)

ALL is not well in my Garden of Eden. I first discovered that I had a problem last summer as I was leaving with my family on a vacation to Canada. Just before I pulled out of the driveway, I grabbed a can of fish food and hustled over to my pond, which is the centerpiece of my front lawn in New Jersey and a major source of domestic pride.

In this intimate district in Westchester County, at once arty and high-achieving, the hunt for a new leader propelled the Board of Education -- and the community -- on a journey that was far more complex and heady than anyone had imagined.

USDAN--Morton. Beloved friend and owner. We will miss you very much. Supreme Corporation Usdan Kolmes Industries/UKI Hickory Dickory Dock $(6$)USDAN--Morton. Partner and friend for over 40 years, relative forever. You will be missed by the Kolmes family. Nat, Keely, and Matthew $(6$)USDAN--Morton. Age 70, passed away on July 6, 2006. Beloved husband of Pamela. Devoted father of Lynn and Rick Shapiro, Steven, and Lisa Usdan and Mark Podgainy. Cherished grandpa and poppy of Scott and Tessa Shapiro and Lila and Georgia Podgainy. Dear Morty: You were always there for me and the boys. I will miss our long phone calls, commiserating about the kids and boasting about the grandchildren. You were not only my brother but my best friend. I love you and will miss you. Iris $(6$)USDAN--Morton. Dear Morty: Your devotion to family was as endless as the goodness in your heart. We can't imagine our world without you in it. We will miss you. Love, Aunt Naomi, Nina, Lenny, Michael and Jenny $(6$)USDAN--Morty. Beloved brother of Allen and Marion, uncle of Amanda, Aron, Kristine and Maggie. We'll miss your shining smile, quick wit and wonderful love and commitment to family. We'll miss you more than words can ever describe. Allen and Marion

Early this summer, after a little sampling, I settled on two house wines to see me through Labor Day. I wanted picnic wines that could play well with others, that could get along with deviled eggs, potato salads, ham sandwiches and mosquitoes. The best summer wines don't ask you to think too hard about what is in the bottle; they have a nice acidity, forward fruit and a clean finish. They like being chilled. Toward the end of both cases, I have tired of neither, perhaps the highest compliment for hot-weather wines. The first is the 2005 Mulderbosch Cabernet Sauvignon Ros√©, from the sweeping Stellenbosch region of South Africa. Uncomplicated, with a light acidity, the Mulderbosch is a little bolder than the grenache-based ros√©s of southern France. Watermelon pink, with notes of grapefruit and strawberries, it's a good match with potato chips. The label lore suggests pairing it with crab cakes, fruit-glazed pork chops, ratatouille and strawberries and cream -- the makings of a pretty fine picnic right there.

JACQUELINE NEWMAN got her first Chinese cookbook as a wedding gift more than 50 years ago. She bought another, and another, and soon, she recalled, collecting Chinese cookbooks became ''a love, an obsession, a sickness.'' She has collected scores of new Chinese cookbooks every year for several decades now, often traveling the globe to get them.

CANADE--Vincent, born July 9, 1916, to the late artist Vincent Canade and Josephine Canade, died January 26 of this year. Born in New York, Canade proudly served in the US Air Force during World War II in the 22nd Bomb Squadron and the 341st Bomb Group. A printer by trade, Canade spent most of his life in Brooklyn. Canade was predeceased by his parents, brothers, George and Eugene, and sisters, Laura, Celia and Florence. He passed away surrounded by his loving nieces, Bianca Bakalar, Melanie Micale, Francesca Sautman, Georgie Taylor, their spouses, and godson, Robert Arcaro.

RICHARDS--Lloyd. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, artists and staff of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, we extend our sincere condolences to the family of Lloyd Richards who served as Artistic Director of the O'Neill's National Playwrights Conference for more than three decades. One of the most important influences in the American Theater, guiding a generation of America's most prominent playwrights, Lloyd Richards will be greatly missed. The O'Neill is honored to continue his legacy. Amy Sullivan, Exec. Dir.

Avner Dorman: Piano Sonatas Nos. 1-3, Piano Works Eliran Avni, pianist. Naxos 8.579001; CD. THE most common complaint of listeners who dislike new music is that its language, whether atonal, avant-garde or Minimalist, stands apart from the syntax and harmonic vocabulary that developed over earlier centuries. But composers can't win; those who try to reconnect with that lost thread are often dismissed as throwbacks.

OFFICIALS at the Masters School, a day and boarding school on a manicured 90-acre campus here, were worried about an increase in vandalism on the school's grounds, which are often used as a public shortcut through town. Over the last few years, empty beer bottles and drug paraphernalia had been found in the woods on the campus's western side; cars have been damaged as well, and one was stolen.

Yes, there are problems with congestion and divided communities, but trashing the Interstate Highway System is not the way to solve them (Robert Sullivan, June 25). Interstate roads are often called arteries. Their purpose is to move traffic expeditiously. Most of the roads that interact with communities could be called capillaries. It makes sense to narrow capillaries, to place bike lanes and greenery on them. It doesn't make sense to slow down arteries. In fact, if there are insufficient arteries, some capillary roads become de facto arterials. Such would suggest the need for more arterials, not fewer. Robert L. Debiase Staten Island

The World Cup final today between France and Italy may be Zin√©dine Zidane's last game. Then again, it may not be. Zidane, a 34-year-old midfielder for France, has had a renaissance of sorts during the monthlong tournament in Germany. He had long said he would retire after the World Cup.
BERLIN--Naomi. Of Teaneck, NJ peacefully June 27, 2006 in Washington, DC. Graveside memorial service 1 PM Sunday, July 16, 2006, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, Westchester County, NY.

AMBER PLAUNTY, a 24-year-old from San Diego, figures she has stayed with about 20 complete strangers while traveling around Europe since last August. Mark Galbraith, a 34-year-old manager with a finance company in London, has played host to more than 200 people he met online. But that's still shy of the number of travelers 66-year-old Helga Smith has welcomed into her apartment in Manhattan: ''I stopped counting after 300 -- and that was three years ago,'' she said.

Hoping to ensure a place on the November ballot, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said on Monday that he would gather petition signatures to run as what he called ''an individual Democratic candidate'' if he does not win the Democratic primary on Aug. 8. Mr. Lieberman, in his third term, faces a strong challenge from a political newcomer, Ned Lamont, a wealthy businessman from Greenwich who has used Mr. Lieberman's support for the war in Iraq to make a broader argument that the senator has been disloyal to the Democratic Party and too supportive of President Bush.

GINZBURG--Ralph. We, classmates, colleagues, and lifelong friends, mourn his death. We will remember his continuing battle for freedom of expression. We extend our condolences to his widow, son, daughters and grandchildren. Aaron Shapiro, Sanford Socolow, Carl Spielvogel

STERN--Enid Gardiner died on June 29 in New York City. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Sunday, July 16 at 6 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Natural Resource Defense Council.

Alex Witchel's article about Jeff Garlin was great (June 25). He is my favorite character on ''Curb Your Enthusiasm.'' Here's hoping he gets all his health problems under control so he can continue his career for manymore years. Jodi Bornstein Boca Raton, Fla.

Allison Elizabeth Quaglino and Michael Daniel Guttentag were married last evening at their home in Santa Monica, Calif. The Rev. Elizabeth Oakes, a Universalist minister, officiated. The bride, 31, is completing her Ph.D in neuroscience at the University of Southern California, where she is studying the brain cells in birds that allow them to learn and produce songs. She graduated from the University of California, Davis, from which she also received a master's degree in avian sciences. She is a daughter of Ingeborg Quaglino and Richard Quaglino of West Los Angeles.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a budget for New Jersey Saturday evening, after a seven-day government shutdown and an acidic standoff with the Legislature that paralyzed state operations, frayed nerves and cost the state millions of dollars. Mr. Corzine, in a crowded public ceremony, approved the $30.9 billion budget but also cut $51 million in proposed new spending, much of it inserted by legislators before they approved the budget.
MY older son, Gabriel, is in his room, propped up on elbows over a copy of ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' ''Hey Mom, want to see a picture of the man with fireproof skin?''

BOLGER--Francis J, 78, actor, director, teacher, and activist, died on June 5, 2006. Mr. Bolger appeared in television, film, and New York theater, receiving great critical acclaim for his performance in the Broadway revival of The Hasty Heart. In Los Angeles, he founded the Group Theater West and served as Associate Professor of Advanced Acting at the Pasadena Playhouse. Mr. Bolger became a leading AIDS activist in Los Angeles, receiving awards from the City of West Hollywood and from AIDS Project Los Angeles for his work. Mr. Bolger was also an active volunteer for the Actors' Fund of America. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 2pm, Saturday July 15th.
To the Editor: Re: ''An Amazing Race to Opening Night'' by Sarah Lyall [June 25]:

Even after his recent conviction in a state bribery case, HealthSouth's former chief executive, Richard M. Scrushy, faces many more days in court. Mr. Scrushy, who was acquitted last year of participating in a $2.7 billion accounting fraud at HealthSouth, was convicted last month of arranging a payment of $500,000 to Donald E. Siegelman, the former Alabama governor, in exchange for a seat on the board of a state hospital regulator.

Next weekend a couple of overstuffed concerts take over the city. One is a New York tradition. And the other definitely isn't. The New York tradition is the SIREN MUSIC FESTIVAL, presented by The Village Voice, which will swamp Coney Island for the sixth year on Saturday. The festival, as always, is free and packed full of indie rock acts. One of the oddest things about Siren is that it scarcely seems to reflect the musical or demographic diversity of the city's music scene, even the city's downtown music scene. And compared with the three major indie-rock festivals that will hit Chicago this summer (the recent Intonation, along with the forthcoming Pitchfork and Lollapalooza), this one seems slightly lacking in big names. Then again, Siren is free, and surely the pink-skinned, glassy-eyed fans staggering down the boardwalk won't be in a mood to complain. This year's headliners include the petulant Canadian indie-pop act STARS, the blithe and absurd British band ART BRUT, the exuberant neo-glam band SCISSOR SISTERS and SHE WANTS REVENGE, the shameless Los Angeles gloom-pop band. (You'd think a self-respecting New York audience would boo those guys off the stage.) The full schedule is at villagevoice.com/siren. The other, distinctly nontraditional New York concert is KENNY CHESNEY's current tour, which is to touch down at Madison Square Garden on Friday. Mr. Chesney is a laid-back country singer whose obvious influences include Jimmy Buffett and James Taylor; his radio-ready hits (he recently topped the country charts with a sweet, straightforward song called ''Summertime'') and exuberant arena shows have made him one of the country's most popular singers, though he rarely plays Manhattan. On Friday he is to be joined by DIERKS BENTLEY (whose hits include the shrugging break-up song, ''Settle for a Slowdown'') and the ''American Idol'' winner CARRIE UNDERWOOD, who established herself as a country-pop star with the smash ''Jesus, Take the Wheel.'' The concert is sold out, but resourceful New Yorkers should be able to figure out a way in.

THOMAS EDISON was a 39-year-old widower with three children when he married for a second time, in 1886. As a wedding present, he gave his new bride, Mina Miller, a 29-room Queen Anne-style home in the exclusive Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, about a mile from his famous laboratories. Known as Glenmont, the estate, which sits on about 15 acres, was reopened to the public last month after a three-year, $1 million restoration by the National Park Service, which administers the property. The work on the house mainly involved the installation of a sprinkler system and a geothermal heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system.

Vivaldi: 'Dixit Dominus'; Galuppi: Sacred Choral Works Vocal soloists; K√∂rnerscher Singverein Dresden; Dresdner Instrumental-Concert, conducted by Peter Kopp. Deutsche Grammophon Archiv 00289 477 6145; CD. A STICKER on the cellophane wrapper describes the ''Dixit Dominus'' (RV 807) as ''the work scholars are calling 'the most important Vivaldi discovery in 75 years.' '' But hold on. Just a couple of months ago Archiv issued a recording of Vivaldi's rediscovered opera ''Motezuma,'' which at least one expert, Kees Vlaardingerbroek of the Netherlands, had proclaimed ''the most important Vivaldi discovery in 75 years.'' Evidently you pay your money, and you choose your scholar.

GORDON -- Margaret Jane. 67, on July 7, 2006, after a long illness. A brilliant and devoted graduate of Cornell University, Peggy was a systems analyst for more than 40 years. Donations to Hospice of Orange and Sullivan Counties, Inc, 800 Stony Brook Ct, Newburgh, NY 12550.

To the Editor: In ''The End of Authorship'' (June 25), John Updike misses the very real, very financial impact the Internet is having on writers. For example, according to Publishers Weekly, Updike's latest book, ''Terrorist,'' has an announced first printing of 150,000 copies. It lists for $25, but Amazon sells it for $15, and new and used copies are available for $12. I can buy one of those $12 copies, pay about $3 in postage, and sell it again on Amazon a few weeks later for just about what I paid for it. Total cost for enjoying Updike's insights and exquisite prose: about $3. The publisher and author are paid for one copy that is read by many individuals for the price of the postage. Thus, as my wife and frequent co-author, Emily, suggests, in the future only 10,000 or fewer copies of most books will ever be printed. The first print run will be the only print run. And thanks to Amazon and the Internet, those copies will endlessly circulate through cyberspace like some sparkling cloud -- a veritable Van Allen belt of books! It's always been difficult to make a living as a writer. The Internet makes it impossible, at least if you insist on sticking to the conventional print paradigm. Alfred Glossbrenner Yardley, Pa. The writer is the author or co-author of approximately 60 books. To the Editor: John Updike's fond remembrance of bookstores throughout his life closely parallels my own. But an alarming, and increasing, number of people do not have any access to bookstores. Nor, for that matter, do they have access to libraries. In these circumstances, how are we to foster a love of reading? How are we to promote literacy? Digital books powered by reliable networks allow us partially to mitigate such circumstances. Digital books offer us a means to reach many people, including children, who would not otherwise have such access. By marrying simple, well understood lessons about networks, search and computer user experiences, we are today providing exemplary kids' literature to places as distant as the rural communities of Mongolia. And our books retain their edges. Tim Browne Manchester by the Sea, Mass. The writer is executive director of the International Children's Digital Library Foundation (www.childrenslibrary.org). To the Editor: The digital book will never replace the printed text as long as there are those who can appreciate the sensual experience of holding a book in their hands, as their eyes, sometimes guided by their fingers, work their way down the page -- pausing when they encounter a particularly complex passage that must be parsed and underscoring each line with a slow-moving finger until all the words coalesce into a thought. My lifelong commitment to books began when I discovered that beyond the circulation desk of the Scranton Public Library lay the stacks, which to me were the equivalent of the Emerald City. It was there that I learned how to hold, sometimes cradle, a book in my hands and lose myself in my discovery. I still wander through the stacks of the library at my university, always learning -- but never learned -- from whatever I take from the shelf, even if I only have time to read a chapter or two. I'm still making contact with something that I can touch, feel and reread without scrolling. Advice to all teachers: Play the Pied Piper and lead your students through the library stacks before they turn virtual. Bernard F. Dick Teaneck, N.J. The writer is a professor of communications at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

SCHOOL superintendents in the metropolitan area are among the best paid public servants anywhere. In Westchester, the median base salary among the county's superintendents was $210,000 in 2005-6, which is more than the governor or the vice president makes, and many bring in much more than $300,000 in pay and benefits. Their defenders say that they make less than chief executives in the private sector who have companies with similar budgets. But critics say their salaries are inflated by cozy relationships with their boards.

I read ''Things Fall Apart,'' Chinua Achebe's allegorical novel of Nigerian independence, when I was a schoolboy growing up in Australia. It was dazzling and heartbreaking. And when I had finished it, I flicked back through, marveling at the illustrations of African spirits and animals that divided the chapters. Many years later, when much of the book had faded from my memory, I was astonished to see the creator of those illustrations featured in a current exhibition at the Newark Museum. He is Uche Okeke, who is now 73 and one of Nigeria's foremost modern artists.

NORWALK, Conn.IF their children repeatedly play hooky from school, residents of Norwalk's public housing complexes could be evicted under regulations proposed by the Norwalk Housing Authority. The authority, saying that it wants to improve school attendance and the academic performance of children who live in public housing, made the proposal at a meeting in April and discussed it again last month. Under the plan, families would be evicted after a child had 10 unexcused absences.

ROSEN--Irene. On July 3, 2006. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Melinda, Alan and son-in-law Howard and daughter-in-law Meri. Devoted sister of Edith Duberstein and brother Seymour Schneider. Loving grandmother of Jaclyn, Rebecca, Marisa and Jack. A true woman of valor.

Stephanie Cooperman, the daughter of Ilene Cooperman of Mount Laurel, N.J., was married on Monday evening to Brian Corey Abrahams, the son of Sheila and Lewis Abrahams of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Raphael Adler officiated at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y. The bride, 28, will continue to use her name professionally. She received a master's degree in journalism in May from Columbia and works in Manhattan as an assistant editor at ForbesLife magazine. She is also the author of three books for young people, including ''Wakeboarding'' (Rosen Publishing Group, 2003). She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania.

An article today on Page 4 of Arts & Leisure about a documentary on actresses who have appeared in the musical ''Annie'' omits one of the directors. Gil Cates Jr., who was a co-producer with Julie Stevens, also directed the film with her.

TACKLER--Barry. He was loved, admired and respected by all who were lucky enough to know him. His strength belied his gentleness. For 60 years his smile dazzled me. There is no end to the seas he loved and no end to the wonderful times Paula, Barry and I shared. It all went too fast. Ri & The Compain Family

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended June 24, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest CROSS COUNTRY, by Robert Sullivan. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) Part memoir, part rumination on the great American road trip, by a veteran of some 30 drives across the United States. THE DIN IN THE HEAD: Essays, by Cynthia Ozick. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) Ozick's latest collection focuses on the state of the novel. RADICAL INNOCENT: Upton Sinclair, by Anthony Arthur. (Random House, $27.95.) A biography of the socialist author of ''The Jungle,'' who also ran a strong race for California governor in 1934. BY A SLOW RIVER, by Philippe Claudel. Translated by Hoyt Rogers. (Knopf, $23.) This novel's hero is a French policeman troubled by memories of World War I and a child's murder. LOST HEARTS IN ITALY, by Andrea Lee. (Random House, $23.95.) Lee's first novel in more than 20 years follows a young American woman to Rome, and into a destructive affair. ENGLISH, AUGUST: An Indian Story, by Upamanyu Chatterjee. (New York Review, paper, $14.95.) A civil servant tries to find himself in this ''slacker novel,'' first published in India in 1988. THE WHISTLING SEASON, by Ivan Doig. (Harcourt, $25.) In 1909, a Montana widower and his family are startled when the city woman he hires as a housekeeper brings her brother along. NEW AND COLLECTED POEMS, 1964-2006, by Ishmael Reed. (Carroll & Graf, $25.95.) Poetry of politics and diversity, suffused with humor. VOYAGE OF THE TURTLE: In Pursuit of the Earth's Last Dinosaur, by Carl Safina. (John Macrae/Henry Holt, $27.50.) A conservationist's account of the endangered leatherback turtle and some of the people trying to save it. VIRGINITY OR DEATH! And Other Social and Political Issues of Our Time, by Katha Pollitt. (Random House, paper, $13.95.) Essays culled from Pollitt's columns for The Nation. PIECE OF MY HEART, by Peter Robinson. (Morrow/HarperCollins, $24.95.) Two crimes, decades apart, are linked by rock music in this mystery, set in Yorkshire. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

The NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC tossed off 11 concerts in 12 days during a tour of Italy and Slovenia last month. Now it takes on the boroughs and a 'burb. The season of park concerts has arrived. On Tuesday the orchestra plays Prospect Park in Brooklyn; on Wednesday, the Great Lawn in Central Park; on Thursday, Cunningham Park in Queens; on Friday, the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island; on Saturday, Heckscher State Park in East Islip, N.Y. The program will be Tchaikovsky's ''Festival Coronation March'' and Violin Concerto, and Dvorak's Symphony No. 8, conducted by XIAN ZHANG, the orchestra's dynamic associate conductor. All concerts start at 8 p.m. (212) 875-5709; free. With summer firmly settled in, the concert buffet is spare. But there are options. Ever-dependable BARGEMUSIC has performances on Sunday, and Thursday through Saturday this week. 7:30 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083; Sunday, $25 to $40; Thursday through Saturday, $20 to $35. On Sunday the MUSEUM OF MODERN ART is presenting a concert in its sculpture garden called ''New Music for New York,'' including chamber works by Agust√≠n Fern√°ndez, Eric Tanguy and Patrick Zimmerli. 8 p.m., 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9491; free. WHEN the popular superintendent of schools here put out the word in January that he would be leaving at the end of the year, the search for a new educator in chief began at once. In this intimate district in Westchester County, at once arty and high-achieving, the hunt for a new leader propelled the Board of Education -- and the community -- on a journey that was far more complex and heady than anyone had imagined.

BLOOMFIELD--Frederick A. Died peacefully on July 8, 2006, after a long and full life. He resided at the Whitney Center in Hamden, CT. Formerly of Cliffside Park, NJ, and New Hyde Park, NY. Predeceased by his beloved wife Theophilia (nee Novak). He was born September 4, 1913, son of the late Samuel and Hortense Blumenfeld and was raised in Brooklyn, NY. Executive with Phillip Weschler & Son Coffee Importers for 35 years. Survived by children David Peter Bloomfield, of Santa Fe, NM, and Judith Talbot, of New Haven, CT, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by seven siblings. His generosity, wisdom and warmth will be greatly missed. Graveside funeral service at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ, Monday; please call for time, 203-624-6912, Weller Funeral Home, New Haven, CT.

THOMAS EDISON was a 39-year-old widower with three children when he married for a second time, in 1886. As a wedding present, he gave his new bride, Mina Miller, a 29-room Queen Anne-style home in the exclusive Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, about a mile from his famous laboratories. Known as Glenmont, the estate, which sits on about 15 acres, was reopened to the public last month after a three-year, $1 million restoration by the National Park Service, which administers the property. The work on the house mainly involved the installation of a sprinkler system and a geothermal heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system.

The government of Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, announced yesterday that it had signed a memorandum of understanding with the Guggenheim Foundation to build a 300,000-square-foot museum in Abu Dhabi to be designed by Frank Gehry. The museum, to be called the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, would house Modern and contemporary art and serve as the linchpin of a sprawling development in a new cultural district of Saadiyat (Arabic for ''isle of happiness''), a 10-square-mile natural island just off Abu Dhabi.

PAPIER--Dr. David, 89 years old, died on July 7, 2006. Loving husband to Sarah Nevins Papier for 56 years. A great father to Lewis, Edward and Arthur Papier; devoted brother to Harold; father-in-law to Susan Voci and grandfather to Ariana and Chloe Papier. He was a gentle, kind-hearted man who was a source of inspiration to all his family and friends. A graduate of New York University and NYU Medical School, he served in World War II as a Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps. A physician who practiced in Forest Hills for over 40 years, he was beloved by all his patients. Funeral services Monday July 10, 10 A.M. Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.
