''Yi,'' the Chinese word for ''one,'' is the simplest of all characters, graphed by a single horizontal line. Writing ''Yi Yi'' looks like this -- -- and translates literally as ''one one,'' though its common usage signifies ''individuality.'' It also suggests a pun: stack ''one'' on top of ''one,'' and you get, naturally enough, the Chinese word for ''two.'' This neat bundle of multiple meanings provides the title for EDWARD YANG's masterly study of contemporary Taipei as experienced by three generations of the middle class. In America ''YI YI'' was subtitled ''A One and a Two'' (not that anyone ever called it that), a clever indication of the picture's essential qualities: how it swings with the verve and confidence of a great jazz tune, proceeds with mathematical precision, develops from an accumulation of minute observations and is characterized by calm, clearheadedness and serenity. Plotted from a wedding to a funeral, featuring dozens of characters and hundreds of incidents, ''Yi Yi'' commands the largest of stages while favoring the smallest of gestures. Despite its sprawl, it has the intimacy of a chamber piece, and is well suited to home viewing. Until now this has only been possible on a DVD of wretched image quality. A superb new packaging by the Criterion Collection, to be released on Tuesday, clarifies the wondrous things Mr. Yang can do with the reflection in a window or a roomful of bubblegum-pink balloons. ''Yi Yi'' is that rare subtitled masterwork bridging (semi-) popular enthusiasm with cinephile fervor, a movie for both the New Yorker set and subscribers to CINEMA SCOPE. Edited by Mark Peranson with contributions by an international roster of writers, this bimonthly Canadian magazine advocates for a passionate, political and purist engagement with the movies. The cover of Issue 27 displays a T-shirt reading ''Vote for Pedro,'' not in reference to the cult of ''Napoleon Dynamite,'' but to the Portuguese cineaste Pedro Costa, whose ''Colossal Youth'' was much abused at the recent Cannes Film Festival but vigorously championed in the magazine's pages. This Cannes-heavy edition also goes to bat for Richard Kelly's reviled ''Southland Tales,'' and spills happy ink on the latest by Richard Linklater among much else. A generous sample is available at cinema-scope.com, but you'll definitely want to nab a hard copy to read what Rob Nelson has to say about ''Marie Antoinette.''

MATUTINOVIC--Zeljka (Suncica) Died Sunday July 2nd, on Martha's Vineyard. She was 41. While vacationing in Martha's Vineyard, she was in a traffic accident, and was reported dead at the Martha's Vineyard Hospital, shortly after. She is survived by her parents, Zeljko and Katarina Matutinovic, off of Zagreb, Croatia. Zeljka, a native of Croatia, was a beloved friend to many, and a highly accomplished professional. She earned a PHD degree in electrical engineering, from Princeton University, and had started her career at McKinsey and Company. Zeljka established a career in investment banking, working at Credit Suisse First Boston, International Real Returns LLC, and most recently, Jerusalem Venture Partners. Since 2005 she had been working to build her own investment firm. Zajka will be remembered for her sharp mind, generous heart, and the vibrant love of life. Her interests extended far beyond the business world, and included skiing, sailing, and biking. She also took pleasure in opera, and art. Zajka's bright smile was matched by her warmth, and infectious enthusiasm. She will be sorely missed by her family and friends. The funeral service will be held in Zagrev, Croatia, on July 12th. The memorial mass will be held on Tuesday July 18th, 7pm, at St. Cyril Catholic Church, at 502 W. 41st St., in NYC.

To the Editor: In the same issue of the Book Review in which Robert Stone argues for ''generosity and tolerance'' and against the ''vocabulary of dismissal'' in reviewing, I was disappointed to encounter Anthony Swofford's harsh appraisal of my book ''2012: The Return of Quetzalcoatl'' (June 18). From Swofford's swipes, the reader would have no idea that ''2012'' weaves together ideas from such thinkers as Carl Jung, Martin Heidegger, Walter Benjamin, Jean Gebser and Fritjof Capra, among others. I do not propose that ''near the end of 2012 the world as we know it will end,'' as Swofford misstates. Instead, I develop the hypothesis that we are already in a process of accelerated transformation, compelling an evolution in human consciousness, and I explore what this could mean for our world. While use of psychedelic substances in indigenous shamanic ritual is a strand of the book, it is only one of many elements, although Swofford does not bother to mention this. How sad that even today, 40 years after the social and cultural watershed of the 1960's, our media seem incapable of holding a serious -- or, apparently, even a civil -- discussion about the validity of non-ordinary states of consciousness. Our capacity for avoiding inconvenient truths appears to be matched by our inability to entertain transformative possibilities. Daniel Pinchbeck New York
PART 12

OVER the last few years, as its residents fought a battle against the city to keep their homes, the Fort Trumbull neighborhood of New London looked more and more like a war-torn village, with acres of vacant lots interrupted intermittently by debris and a few scattered houses. Fort Trumbull was at the center of a national debate over eminent domain last year after the United States Supreme Court ruled that the city could take residents' homes and transfer them to a private developer to put up new housing, offices and a hotel. Of the seven property owners who sued the city, the final two agreed on June 30 to settle, ending the battle.

AFTER the death of Jackie McLean, jazz saxophonist and educator, on March 31, the jazz world turned its attention to Hartford. The globe-trotting musician was the most visible figure in the city's arts and education arena, helping to create and oversee two of its better-known institutions: the Artists Collective, a nationally recognized community education center on the North End that he founded with his wife, Dollie McLean, and the jazz program at the University of Hartford's Hartt School of Music, known since 2001 as the Jackie McLean Institute of Jazz. Both programs have nurtured thousands of young musicians since their start in the early 1970's, and along with other schools in the area, they have given Hartford credibility in wider jazz circles. The city has produced nationally recognized musicians like the pianist Brad Mehldau, who combines jazz with classical music and rock; Jimmy Greene, a rising young saxophonist with a busy international career; and Nat Reeves, a bass player who teaches at the McLean Institute. In addition, Hartford's location, midway between New York and Boston, allows it to attract some of the finest players in the Northeast.

To the Editor: The conclusion to be drawn from Amy Sutherland's essay is important, but can easily be missed. Ms. Sutherland did not change her husband's behavior. She changed her own behavior. Her husband then chose his responses to her new behaviors. The old adage is true: the only person you can change is yourself. Kristin A. M. Scott Peyton, Colo.

MAGEE--Kathrine Sarles Durstine Griswold. March 2, 1921--June 23, 2006. Born in White Plains, NY to Roy S. and Harriet Hutchins Durstine. In 1942 she married James Robert Griswold of Lookout Mountain, TN, a Naval officer killed in WWII. In 1946 she married Edward Jennings Magee of Pittsburgh, PA, and they enjoyed 46 years together. Kathrine made her homes in Ligonier, PA, Marathon, FL and Nevada City, CA. Remembered for her wit, loyalty, generosity and love of family, she is survived by sons James R. Griswold, Jr, of Easton, MD and Edward J. Magee, Jr., of Portland, OR, and by daughters Harriet Magee Henderson of Challis, ID, and Elizabeth Magee Ely of Nevada City, CA. Many dear grandchildren and great-grandchildren are also saddened by her death. Family and friends are invited to attend memorial services at Allegheny Cemetery in Pittsburgh, PA, at 2:00 P.M, Saturday, July 22. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to your local Hospice.

GLUCKSMAN--Lewis L. Passed away peacefully in Ireland on July 5, 2006. He was a passionate participant in all aspects of life, a wonderful friend, a loyal partner, a stalwart ally in good times and bad. Our heartfelt and most profound sympathy goes out to his wife Loretta, the source of so much of his strength, and to his children, her children, and all of their grandchildren. Marty and Bob Rubin $(6$)GLUCKSMAN--Lewis L. Died in Ireland on July 5, 2006. He was a treasured friend and mentor who influenced our lives in ways that cannot be measured. We loved him very, very much and he will remain in our hearts forever. Barbara and Jim Boshart $(6$)GLUCKSMAN--Lewis L. Lehman Brothers and its employees mourn the loss of Lewis L. Glucksman. In his 21 years with the Firm, Mr. Glucksman served as our chief operating officer, president, co-chairman and co-chief executive officer, chairman & chief executive officer and acted as a dedicated mentor to many of our current management. He will be remembered on Wall Street as a giant in our industry and will be remembered at Lehman Brothers for his strong leadership, his invaluable guidance and his outstanding dedication to the Firm and, above all, as a friend. Richard S. Fuld, Jr. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Lehman Brothers $(6$)GLUCKSMAN--Lewis L. The members of the NYU Leonard N. Stern School of Business community mourn the passing of their dear friend, Lewis L. Glucksman. A Stern Emeritus Overseer and NYU trustee, Lewis was a treasured alumnus and dedicated supporter of the School. The Glucksman Institute for Research in Securities Markets at NYU Stern, established with a generous gift from Lewis in 1982, is a lasting tribute to this remarkable man. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Loretta, and his entire family.

CONWAY--Margaret A. ''Peggy'' On July 6th, 2006. Long time realtor on the west side of NYC. Dear sister of Edward & Kevin. Loving aunt of six. Peggy was much loved and will be missed by her many friends. Reposing at John J. Barrett & Son Funeral Home. 424 West 51st Street, NYC 2-5 and 7-9 pm Sunday. Funeral mass 10 am Monday. St. Paul the Apostle RC Church. Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Franciscan Sisters of the Atonement, care of Sister Clair Murphy, 41 Old Highland Turnpike, Garrison, NY 10524 would be appreciated.

What if Tony Soprano were Irish, lived in Rhode Island and had a clean-cut brother in local politics? SHOWTIME is surely thinking forward to life after ''The Sopranos,'' and as a replacement proposes ''BROTHERHOOD,'' which has its premiere Sunday night at 10. JASON CLARKE stars as the Providence politician and family man, trying to avoid the rampant corruption around him. JASON ISAACS is his gangster brother, who has just come back to town after years on the run. There are suitcases full of money, suspicious construction sites and casual violence (including a severed ear in the first hour). The last few STEPHEN KING television projects haven't exactly been masterpieces. But the latest, ''NIGHTMARES & DREAMSCAPES: FROM THE STORIES OF STEPHEN KING,'' is at least highly ambitious. It's a four-week extravaganza of eight stories, beginning on Wednesday (TNT, 9 p.m.) with a commercial-free hour and a star turn by WILLIAM HURT. He plays a San Francisco hit man who kills a toy manufacturer, then finds himself under siege by an army of tiny plastic soldiers with surprisingly real weapons. That will be followed by CLAIRE FORLANI and EION BAILEY as newlyweds honeymooning in another dimension. The first season of the Showtime series ''WEEDS'' comes out on DVD on Tuesday (Lionsgate, $39.98). MARY-LOUISE PARKER, who beat out the ''Desperate Housewives'' stars for a Golden Globe, plays a tasteful suburban widow, soccer mom and marijuana dealer. Hey, how else is she going to keep her fabulous house? ELIZABETH PERKINS is her best friend (in a way), the most deliciously detestable role of her career. And now that Bruce Springsteen has gone folkie again, the latest ''AMERICAN MASTERS'' documentary, ''WOODY GUTHRIE: AIN'T GOT NO HOME'' (PBS, Wednesday, check local listings), seems timely. As the film puts it, Guthrie, who gave the world ''This Land Is Your Land,'' wasn't actually a hick, he just played one on radio.

WENDY CHAMBERLIN, a landscape designer, first pitched her idea for a photography book on the farming families of the East End to the publisher Paul Gottlieb not long before he died in 2002. Mr. Gottlieb, then president of Harry N. Abrams Books, was the emperor of coffee-table books. It might have been a perfect match, but the Abrams sales staff rebelled, Ms. Chamberlin recalls Mr. Gottlieb saying; the niche was too small to justify the expense. Ms. Chamberlin, a novice photographer and author, had already spent more than a year trailing the Halsey, Foster, Corwith and Zaluski families as they sowed and harvested their crops. Undeterred, she eventually shot 7,000 photos, assigned a season to each wall of a guest room in her house in Bridgehampton, and started tacking up her favorites.

MARIA APOSPOROS is from Sparta -- so you know she's tough. For 25 years the revivifying City of Stamford has coveted the site of her plainspoken anachronism of a diner, with its Grecian blue banquettes, the obligatory boxes of miniature Frosted Flakes atop a glass case containing the obligatory rice pudding, and a rooftop sign that promises: ''CURLEY'S WELCOME 24 HRS OPEN.''

"Albania kaput!" announced the lunatic on the streets of Tirana. I looked at my new friends, a pair of Serbian filmmakers and a Dutch backpacker I'd met in a cafe, and we tried to walk away. But his insanity was unavoidable, and soon we were a captive audience to his crackpot ramblings about Bill Clinton, Sept. 11 and the future of Albania. I'd been in Tirana less than four hours and, already, moments like these had ceased to faze me. I had arrived in Albania hoping to discover an untrammeled paradise hidden in the Balkans. What I found instead was a deeply weird place: a majority-Muslim country where the mosques are mute but the miniskirts are loud, where horse carts share highways with Hummers, and where people shake their heads to mean yes except that sometimes they shake their heads to mean no.

THE CLOSED CIRCLE, by Jonathan Coe. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.) This sequel to ''The Rotters' Club'' (2002) is both a satirical state-of-England saga and a close-up of one Benjamin Trotter. In ''The Rotters' Club,'' a novel of the 1970's set in Birmingham, Benjamin is a dreamy adolescent; ''The Closed Circle'' opens 20 years later, on Dec. 31, 1999, and Benjamin -- accountant, failing husband and would-be novelist -- is mired in the past. Coe follows the midlife surprises and disappointments of Benjamin; his brother Paul, a rising star in Tony Blair's New Labor government; and their old high school friends. In the Book Review, Jenny Turner described the novel's ''free-form, improvised'' quality: ''The effect is odd but also charming: sometimes bathetic, sometimes sublime.''

ELLISON McCALL bought his brown-shingled Dutch colonial 29 years ago, and for almost 28 of them, the Delaware River was a gentle neighbor down at the other end of Laclede Avenue. He would walk up to the grassy, tree-lined bank and fish for striped bass with herring, or maybe chicken livers. The river had risen mightily back in 1955, but everybody said that was a biblical aberration, the storm of the century, and Mr. McCall was just a boy then in north Trenton, well beyond its reach. It didn't chase him out of his own home until September 2004, when it filled his basement with muddy water. Once every 50 years -- that seemed a reasonable price for the almost-country sweetness of life in the neighborhood called the Island, a stable, peaceful enclave cut off from the rest of the city by Route 29.

To the Editor: Re ''Crisis Postponed at the U.N.'' (editorial, July 3): The European Union concurs with your view on the importance and necessity of United Nations reform. The share of the member states of the European Union in the United Nations budget is 37 percent and more than 40 percent of the financing of United Nations peacekeeping.

To the Editor: Re ''In Pt. Pleasant, Anger Grows Over Sound of Sirens'' (July 2): As the mother of a volunteer firefighter, I know that the firefighters and first aid members many times rely on the town's sirens to alert them. Pagers fail to work or are left somewhere in the house where they can't be heard.
WEINSTEIN--Henry A. Devoted husband of Frances. Loving, fabulous father of Bette Zimmerman, Susan Gooden, Wendy Delisle, and grandfather to Joshua, Eric, Heather, Arlene and Steven.

FREED--Ethan. With a profound sense of grief the Camp Winadu family mourns the loss of Ethan Freed. Ethan was a model son, brother, grandson, camper, student, athlete and friend. Everyone who knew him loved and respected his ability to find peaceful solutions to all situations. Ethan truly made a difference during his life. We extend our deepest sympathy to his parents Susan and Jeffrey, his brothers Adam and Alex, his grandparents and extended family. Shelley and Arleen Weiner and the entire Camp Winadu family, campers and staff

In a Milestone, One Pill, Once a Day, for AIDS The first complete treatment for AIDS that is taken once a day as a single pill is expected to be available soon. The pill combines drugs made by two companies and would be a milestone in improving the simplicity of AIDS treatment, which a decade ago involved dozens of pills each day. BAER--Richard A. Retired food service executive active in International Food Service Executive Association, Veterans of the Ninth Regiment and The Old Guard Of New York City. Long time volunteer, loving uncle and good friend. Memorial July 14, 2006, 11:00AM, Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue.

To the Editor: O.K., I've fallen into the trap that Amy Gunderson's ''Pets at Hotels: What's the Thread Count on My Dog's Bed?'' (Journeys, June 25) has laid. How can a reader who doesn't own a private jet read such an article without feeling the decadence of a society ripe for extinction? Clearly, the writer meant to rankle her readers by describing the excesses of patrons who will spend an extra $75 for their pets to have ''in-room bowls and a nightly carob 'truffle' '' as well as extra-charge options for aromatherapy massages or bones from the hotel's restaurant.

LANGLEY--Robert C. Of North Port, FL, formerly of Millington, NJ, on July 3, 2006. Husband of the late Julie L., father of June Langley and brother of Margaret Ravin. Graveside service at Somerset Hills Memorial Park, Basking Ridge, on Monday, July 10, at 11 A.M. For more info: Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home, 101 S. Finley Avenue, Basking Ridge, NJ.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell has directed the State Department of Transportation to inspect 34 train stations for structural damage, cleanliness, a lack of signs and bad lighting. In response to Mrs. Rell's announcement, a commuter watchdog group announced a campaign last week urging passengers to take pictures of damage at their stations and send them to the Transportation Department. Mrs. Rell said in a press release that she wanted two transportation department employees to inspect all the stations owned by the state, starting with the parking garage at the Stamford station, where commuters have complained about holes in the concrete and a lack of stop signs. Mrs. Rell said she had told the department to fix the outdoor lighting at the Darien station, where commuters have also complained.

SHUB--Anatole, On Sunday, July 2nd in Washington, DC. Journalist, author and expert on Russian Affairs. Born May 19th, 1928. Editor at the New Leader, Commentary, Sunday Writer at the New York Times, ICWA fellow, News Director of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and award winning Foreign Correspondent for the Washington Post. Cherished father to Rachel and Adam, loving grandfather to Carla and Alexander and doting fatherin-law to Maria del Carmen. Family can be contacted at: rachelshub@hotmail.com

CHAZEN--Hartley James, the founding partner of Chazen & Fox, a specialist in securities, tax and transactional law, passed away Friday, June 30, in Greenwich, CT. He was a graduate of Harvard Law School where he was a Staff Member of the Harvard Law Record and the Harvard Legislative Bureau. In 1959 he received a Master's of Law with distinction from New York University School of Law, where he also taught. He practiced in the State of New York and Federal Courts for over four decades. During this time he was a member of the NYC, New York State and American Bar Associations, and Harvard Club. He was also active at the the Appleseed Foundation. Earlier, he was a Captain in the US Army Reserves, stationed in Germany. A memorial service will be held September 9, at 1 PM, in NYC, at the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

While people up and down the Delaware River shoveled muck and put out ruined refrigerators and other debris, the recent flooding renewed a call in Trenton for action on proposals that might have prevented some of the damage in the first place. A crucial measure, environmentalists say, is restricting construction in floodplains and development that increases runoff into streams. Stricter limits were recommended in a recent report from a task force appointed by Richard J. Codey when he was governor after floods in April 2005, and the Department of Environmental Protection has spent months writing regulations to slow development in vulnerable areas.

Italy had its final practice yesterday in Duisburg, Germany, in front of a selected audience of about 100 before flying to Berlin for the World Cup final today. More than a billion people worldwide are expected to watch today when Italy plays the championship game against France. ''Tomorrow we are going to sit down at a lavishly prepared table and see who is hungry,'' Italy Coach Marcello Lippi said after the session. ''We have our forks in hand. Let's see what happens.''

SCHOOL superintendents in the metropolitan area are among the best paid public servants anywhere. In Westchester, the median base salary among the county's superintendents was $210,000 in 2005-6, which is more than the governor or the vice president makes, and many bring in much more than $300,000 in pay and benefits. Their defenders say that they make less than chief executives in the private sector who have companies with similar budgets. But critics say their salaries are inflated by cozy relationships with their boards.

THE ball fields at Commack Park were filled with Little League baseball teams practicing for the tournament season one day in late June. The parents were getting ready, too. ''I love this game,'' Valerie Monroy said as she watched her 10-year-old son, William, go through infield drills with his teammates. ''I think it's so cute.'' Donna Pesci, the mother of Joseph, also 10, said her favorite part of the game was when the catcher went out to the mound for a chat with the pitcher. ''What can they be talking about?'' she said.

He will be dearly missed by his wife of 53 years, Gloria; children Tony, Peter and Jennifer; daughter - in - law Lynne; grandchildren Melanie & Daniel and their mother Elsie; sister Pauline Schwartz and his niece Judith SchwartzEprile and nephew Frederick Schwartz and their families. Born in New York City on June 15, 1929, Weil attended the Fieldston School and received a BA from the University of Chicago. Deborah Solomon's interview of Jack Carter was fascinating (June 25). Jack says he doesn't have to be ''the best candidate in the world'' and that ''whenever you are going to be the best at something, then you give up an awful lot of stuff.'' For someone whose father's autobiography was titled ''Why Not the Best?'' I'm surprised Jack would have that point of view. Terence Kane Long Beach, N.Y.

OFFICIALS at the Masters School, a day and boarding school on a manicured 90-acre campus here, were worried about an increase in vandalism on the school's grounds, which are often used as a public shortcut through town. Over the last few years, empty beer bottles and drug paraphernalia had been found in the woods on the campus's western side; cars have been damaged as well, and one was stolen.

THOMAS EDISON was a 39-year-old widower with three children when he married for a second time, in 1886. As a wedding present, he gave his new bride, Mina Miller, a 29-room Queen Anne-style home in the exclusive Llewellyn Park section of West Orange, about a mile from his famous laboratories. Known as Glenmont, the estate, which sits on about 15 acres, was reopened to the public last month after a three-year, $1 million restoration by the National Park Service, which administers the property. The work on the house mainly involved the installation of a sprinkler system and a geothermal heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system.
To the Editor: ''Looking for Answers When Choosing Care'' (July 2) struck a personal chord with me.

To the Editor: Re ''How to Educate Young Scientists'' (editorial, July 3): I am fortunate that as a scientist I work with bright people from around the world. The problem with science in the United States is not a failure to educate and inspire, but a failure to retain. I have seen many young scientists come to this country for training and stay because of the opportunities, while many of my young American colleagues have left science to pursue more lucrative careers.

To the Editor: Re ''Keeping Tabs on Teenage Drinking'' (July 2): Dining at the Paris home of a friend some time ago, I was shocked as she poured a little wine for her 7-year-old son. I said that was never done in our country. We thought it would lead to alcoholism.

WEISS--Paul D., 98, of Boca Raton, Florida, passed away on June 30, 2006. With grace and warmth, he challenged and inspired the lives of all those who knew him. Devoted husband to Dorothy for 69 years; loving father of Larry, Judith and daughter-in-law Suzanne; cherished brother to Etta Young; beloved grandfather of Robert, Elizabeth and Jennifer and proud great-grandfather of Ethan, Anna, Devin, Alexis, Robbie and Catarina. Growing up on NYCs lower east side, Paul was truly a selfmade man, having earned his engineering degree after attending City College for 10 years at night. He rose to head one of the City's leading steel construction firms and over a 40 year career was responsible for the building of hundreds of office towers, apartment buildings, schools, hospitals and arenas, including Shea Stadium. A recognized industry leader, in 1967 he received the distinguished service award from the United Jewish Appeal. A memorial service was held in Florida on July 2, 2006. Donations in his memory may be sent to the UJA.

So is Al Qaeda moving into Darfur? There have been some hints of that, including Osama Bin Laden's extraordinary call for jihadis to go to Sudan to defend the faith against U.N. crusaders. But the clearest warning comes in a new item by Douglas Farah at: http://www.douglasfarah.com/ . It begins:
Rod Ben Zeev traveled from Amsterdam to Berlin in search of soccer atmosphere and bratwursts.
Science reporter Anahad O'Connor tours the American Museum of Natural History's new exhibit of snakes and lizards.

On the homepage of Zin√©dine Zidane's official Web site today, right beside the latest news about the man -- like, for instance, that French President Jacques Chirac told him this afternoon in Paris that "France loves you and admires you" and that journalists decided last night to award him the Golden Ball as player of the tournament he both graced and disgraced -- there is a trailer for the high-tech, fine-art film made about him by the Scottish Turner Prize winner Douglas Gordon and the French conceptual artist Philippe Parreno called "Zidane: un Portrait du 21√®me Si√®cle" which can be translated as either "Zidane: A 21st Century Portrait" or "Zidane: A Portrait of the 21st Century".
Rod Ben Zeev traveled from Amsterdam to Berlin in search of soccer atmosphere and bratwursts.

The ancient Greeks had an explanation for strange episodes when men and mythological heroes lost their minds: a deity called Ate. This daughter of Zeus was banished by her father to Earth where she inspired inexplicable, irrational movements of the soul, causing those known for prudence, wisdom or knowledge to suddenly act in incomprehensible, aggressive, mad, even suicidal ways.
Business Travel columnist Joe Sharkey says airport chapels are good places to find peace and solitude in busy airports.  (Produced by: Emily B. Hager)
Mark Landler says that the World Cup has made Germany a different place.
Did Zidane's actions upstage Italy's victory? Roger Cohen and George Vecsey examine the end of the tournament.
His lawyer just dropped off 40,000 signatures, or triple the number required to qualify for the Sept. 12 primary ballot against Eliot Spitzer for the Democratic nomination for governor.
A gas explosion leveled an entire building on New York City's Upper East Side Monday morning. (Produced by: Erik Olsen and Emily B. Hager)
Shamil Basayev claimed responsibility for some of Russia's worst terror attacks, including the Beslan school siege.

New York attorney general Eliot Spitzer is among the first to point out when financial firms face unseemly conflicts of interest (often while brandishing a lawsuit). In that spirit, The New York Daily News is pointing out a potentially interesting convergence related to Mr. Spitzer: Several donors to his gubernatorial campaign also received millions of dollars in investments from a charity run by Mr. Spitzer and other members of his family.

Apropos of exactly nothing, Rep. Anthony Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn and Queens, gave a speech this morning to the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce proposing a 10 percent federal income tax cut for couples making up to $150,000, plus assorted other tax goodies for the middle and working classes.
Did Zidane's actions upstage Italy's victory? Roger Cohen and George Vecsey examine the end of the tournament.
Mark Landler says that the World Cup has made Germany a different place.

Why did Zinedine Zidane blow up the way he did before a television audience of hundreds of millions, with the world championship on the line? Nearly a day after Zidane's battering-ram head butt to the sternum of Marco Materazzi, we still don't know why. Speculation is flying, but it's all merely that. The French newspaper Nouvel Observateur and Reuters do a nice roundup of theories, all unproven, including "whispers" that Materazzi said something to Zidane about the steroid scandal that surfaced at Juventus in the days when Zidane was playing there (The Independent), that there are "suggestions" floating around that Materazzi called Zidane a "terrorist" (The Guardian), that whatever Materazzi said to Zidane must have been "something grave, surely about his mother" (Bernard Tapie on TF1), that "one imagines that there was some provocation" and that Zidane "was in a state of nerves" (Minster of Sports Jean-Fancois Lamour on LCI).

As Chicago prepares to sell its Midway airport, The Financial Times is taking note of the possibility -- or, rather, the high probability -- that firms outside the United States will be the strongest bidders in the precedent-setting auction. The privatization of Midway would be "by far the largest for a U.S. airport," the newspaper notes. As such, it could inspire other cash-strapped cities to try similar moves.
Shares of Foot Locker sprinted to a new 52-week high on Monday after a trade publication said that buyout behemoth Kohlberg Kravis Roberts was the lead contender to acquire it.

Vernon Robinson, a conservative black candidate for Congress from North Carolina, has stirred Internet chatter for taking political incorrectness to a new level with his "Twilight Zone" campaign commercials.
The Dutch specialist marketmaker Van der Moolen Holding said on Monday it had agreed to pay a fine to settle with the New York Stock Exchange over an investigation into its stock loan department.
Former U.S. Senator Tom Daschle has resigned as a director of Apollo Investment Corporation less than three months after joining the board.
Premier Foods of Britain said on Monday it was in non-exclusive talks to acquire The Campbell Soup Company's businesses in Britain and and Ireland.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

Francis Leung appears to have outmaneuvered United States-based Texas Pacific Group and Australia's Macquarie Bank in the bidding war for the assets of PCCW, Hong Kong's largest telecommunications company.

Opinionland is showing more and more interest in Ned Lamont's Democratic primary challenge to Senator Joe Lieberman in Connecticut. Suzanne Nossel of the group blog Democracy Arsenal tries to explain why Lieberman is having so much trouble fending off Lamont: "The crux of Lieberman's problem is his unwillingness to acknowledge the severity of what's happened in Iraq, and to demand accountability for it. Iraq has now replaced 9/11 as America's 'prism of pain' - the trauma-tinged lens through which everything else is viewed." Nossel writes:
Yet another Brooklyn lawmaker is in trouble with the law.
Readers respond to Bob Herbert's July 10 column, "A Vietnam Lesson, Unlearned"
Readers respond to David Brooks's July 9 column, "The Liberal Inquisition"
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his July 10 column, "The New York Paradox"

Daily Candy, the shopping and culture e-mail newsletter and Web site put up for sale early this year, has yanked itself off the auction block, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing "people familiar with the matter."
It's too delicious a headline to pass up: Faso beats Spitzer!
Cash America International said on Monday it had agreed to buy an online lender, CashNetUSA, for around $35 million.

For years Spain has been considered a paradise for athletes open to doping. A 500-page investigative report describes the network surrounding Madrid sports doctor Eufemiano Fuentes. In addition to German cyclist Jan Ullrich, T-Mobile's J√∂rg Jaksche has also been implicated in a scandal that threatens to make a farce of the Tour de France.

The CB Richard Ellis Group, the biggest commercial real estate broker in the United States, said on Monday it had acquired Holley Blake, an industrial real estate services specialist in Britain, for about $22 million.
The Swiss investment bank UBS ranked first globally in the first half of 2006 on advice for mergers and acquisitions smaller than $500 million, according to Thomson Financial.

The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation said on Monday it would sell its Bear Head LNG Corporation subsidiary which is developing a liquefied natural gas receiving terminal at Point Tupper, Nova Scotia, to U.S. Venture Energy, a private equity firm, for $125 million.

Kimco Realty said early Monday it would buy Pan Pacific Retail Properties, an owner of shopping malls, for $70 per share, or about $2.9 billion. Including $1.1 billion in debt, the transaction is valued at about $4 billion. Though the offer is in the form of cash, Kimco said it may choose to fund as much as $10 per share of the purchase price with its own stock.
Federated Department Stores said on Monday it would sell its downtown Boston Filene's department store to Vornado Realty Trust for about $100 million.

WPS Resources said Monday it hjad reached a definitive agreement to buy Peoples Energy in a $1.5 billion all-stock transaction that would unite two Midwestern electric and gas utilities. Combined, the companies will serve about 1.6 million natural gas customers and 477,000 electric customers, according to a joint press release.

United States bosses could be scurrying to lock file cabinets and recover printouts from their waste baskets after federal prosecutors this week charged three people with stealing information from the Coca-Cola Company and trying to sell it to its rival, PepsiCo.

A French shareholder association has filed a lawsuit over the recent share price collapse of EADS. The suit, filed in the Netherlands, where the Airbus parent group is registered, seeks class-action status.
RadioShack's stock price soared 23 percent Friday as investors bet the newly named chairman and chief executive, Julian Day, would fix the struggling consumer electronics chain or ready it for sale.

H.J. Heinz is likely to fend off a proxy fight led by the billionaire Nelson Peltz at its annual meeting next month, but if history is any guide, the ketchup king may find itself with something of a Pyrrhic victory.

A federal district judge in Washington is considering the imposition of major modifications to the two largest telephone mergers in history: SBC Communication's acquisition of AT&T and Verizon's purchase of MCI.

A Milan judge ruled that former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi should be tried for tax fraud, false accounting and embezzlement in relation to the purchase of movie rights by his media company Mediaset.
The boardroom titans of Silicon Valley and Wall Street have met their match in a Norwegian-born finance lecturer from a hitherto obscure business school in America's Corn Belt.
Tony Blair will personally lobby Russian president Vladimir Putin at the G8 summit urging him to lift restrictions on a hedge fund manager who has been denied entry to Russia.
The 7.6 billion pound ($14 billion) fund just raised by private equity firm Permira may be a European record, but the real interest is in what it says about the state of the industry globally.

The Texas Pacific Group is expected to announce later this month it is buying Field Container, a maker of folding cartons and specialty paper packaging based in Elk Grove, Ill. TPG will likely combine Field Container with its portfolio company, Altivity Packaging.

A biotechnology startup, Alder BioPharmaceuticals, has raised $16 million in a second round of venture financing amid hopes that success for the startup could mean its technologies could halve prices for some of today's most expensive drugs.

CoreOptics, a German designer and manufacturer of optical networking chips and subsystems, closed a $28 million Series D financing as it contemplates going public in 2007 with the help of a new lead investor, GIMV.

Texas-based Growth Capital Partners has raised $65 million for its second mezzanine fund, which will look to make $2 million to $5 million subordinated-debt investments in capital-hungry companies planning to grow or make acquisitions.

Three of the nation's biggest movie theater chains plan to raise as much as $1 billion to convert about one-third of all theater screens in the United States to electronic projection from film projection.
Pop quiz: What do venture capitalists, Bill Gates and major investment banks have in common? They are all making large bets on ethanol.

In a move that could bring in $224 million, Cowen will move to spin itself off from its French parent, Soci√©t√© G√©n√©rale. An initial public offering, which should come this week, is the latest in a chain of attempts by boutique investment banks to grab Wall Street's attention.
A property developer, Greentown China Holdings, has raised $344 million after healthy demand by institutional investors.
Kraft Foods said on Monday it would buy the Spanish and Portuguese operations of the British cookie maker United Biscuits, moving into faster-growing cookie markets in a deal valued at $522 million.

Arsenal Holdings is preparing for a bond market victory. Arsenal, the owner of the Arsenal soccer club in Highbury, London, plans to raise $478 million this month in the first public sale of asset-backed debt by a European team.

Shares of the Hong Kong fixed-line telecom company PCCW and its Sunday Communications cellular services unit were suspended from trading Monday, following reports a new group led by Francis Leung Pak has stepped forward with an offer to buy a stake held by the chairman, Richard Li.

The Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich has placed a bid for a stake in Rosneft - possibly for several hundred million dollars - giving a lift to the Russian oil group's planned initial public offering.
Shares in Standard Life, an Edinburgh, Scotland-based life insurance and pensions provider, rose 5.1 percent in the first day of trading after the company's $3.9 billion initial public offering.

Dubai Ports World, which stirred up controversy with its takeover of the British ports operator P&O, is drawing up plans for a float on the London Stock Exchange that could value the business at as much as 6 billion pounds ($11.1 billion), though the Telegraph says that the company will put up only about a 20 percent stake, or 1 billion pounds.
Morgan Stanley has teamed up with Guy Hands's private equity firm, Terra Firma, to make a potential bid of 7 billion pounds ($12.9 billion) for the water giant Thames Water.

Speculation is increasing that Goldman Sachs is moving closer to raising a new giant private equity fund after it confirmed that Richard Sharp, the current head of its European principal investment division, is resigning at the end of the year.

Radiologix of Dallas will be acquired by a California radiology company to form the nation's largest chain of outpatient medical imaging offices. Primedex Health Systems, based in Los Angeles, agreed to pay $208 million in cash and stock for Radiologix, including net debt.

A 20-year-old man was fatally shot in Queens Village yesterday morning after a fight outside a nightclub, the police said. The man, identified as Carl Waldron, was shot shortly after 4:20 a.m. in the area of Murdock Avenue and Springfield Boulevard, the police said. Mr. Waldron was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was declared dead on arrival, according to the police. Neighbors said that there had been a party at the Rapture Cocktail Lounge and Cafe, and that several men had been arguing before gunshots were fired. A second man, who was not identified by the police, was shot in the ankle and treated at Mary Immaculate Hospital. No immediate arrests were made, the police said.

Councilman David I. Weprin of Queens, the chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, said yesterday that he will introduce a bill next week to triple the penalties for abusive practices by debt-collection agencies and to enhance the city's authority to suspend or revoke their licenses. The current penalty is $700 to $1,000 per violation. The city Department of Consumer Affairs recently reported that complaints against collectors have more than doubled in three years.

Two Brooklyn youths, ages 18 and 12, were arrested yesterday for their role in a hate crime on June 26, when two black teenagers were assaulted at Gerritsen Beach, the police said. The 18-year-old was identified as Joseph Jirovec. Previously, three 17-year-old boys from Brooklyn were arrested and charged.

New tests have indicated that E. coli bacteria found in Fire Island water samples might have been caused by contamination of earlier test samples and not by bacteria in the water supply, said Michael Stevenson, deputy chief executive of the Suffolk County Water Authority.
Major R. Owens, who has represented central Brooklyn for 24 years, is campaigning for his son Chris, who faces stiff competition in the Democratic primary.
New York is undoubtedly more liberal than many other places. But even in New York City, only 35 percent of those surveyed in a poll favored gay marriage.

After nearly two months on the run, a former East Orange police officer has surrendered, prosecutors said. The former officer, Natasha McRae, and her husband, Norman Price, a former East Orange police detective, were convicted on May 19 of stealing more than $106,429 intended for department improvements. On the day the verdict was read, the couple failed to appear in court. Ms. McRae surrendered in Newark on Wednesday and is being held in the Essex County jail, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutor's office. Mr. Price was arrested last month in Mesa, Ariz., and is being held pending extradition.

Mayor John M. Fabrizi, who tearfully confessed last month to occasional cocaine use while in office, passed a random drug test after being challenged last week by a local newspaper editor. The Connecticut Post reported yesterday that after being challenged, Mayor Fabrizi canceled his afternoon appointments and accompanied the paper's managing editor to a testing center in Milford. The mayor said he had been drug free for 18 months and offered to take a random test

The University of Connecticut has delayed construction of its $90 million School of Fine Arts building, citing financial problems. The Hartford Courant reported that university officials said they had decided to put off the project for a year and increase their fund-raising efforts. To pay for the project, the university set aside $20 million from its construction program known as UConn 2000. However, it has only raised about $43,000 of the remaining $70 million.
The Yankees are four games better than they were at the break last season but they have not  been this far out of a playoff spot at the break in the past 11 years.

The David Carr column in Business Day last Monday about cost cuts at Gawker Media, a blogging company, erroneously included a Web site on a list of sites where editors were moved to new jobs or replaced on June 30. The changes occurred at Gawker.com, Gizmodo.com, and Gridskipper.com; no editors were moved or replaced at Wonkette.

Ravens linebacker Roderick Green was stabbed early yesterday during a fight at a bowling alley, Baltimore County police said. A Ravens spokesman said Green's injury did not appear to be serious. The police said a fight broke out when Green, 24, bumped into another bowler. Green tried to break it off and left the alley, but the man came after him and stabbed him in the parking lot.

The jazz saxophonist and composer Ornette Coleman, below, will release ''Sound Grammar,'' his first new album in more than a decade, on Sept. 12 on his own label, also called Sound Grammar. Recorded live in Germany late last year, it will have eight Coleman compositions, including two remakes. The album features his new band, with his son Denardo Coleman on drums, and Tony Falanga and Greg Cohen on acoustic basses. BEN SISARIO

World Cup, Schmorld Cup. Baseball is clearly America's game. Books about the sport and its players dominate the top 10 titles in the sports and adventure category at Barnes & Noble online. There are biographies of revered players like Babe Ruth and Roberto Clemente (above), investigations of cheating and the sport as just another multimillion-dollar industry, and dense statistical bibles. No soccer titles are listed in the top 50, but ''Pit Road Pets: Nascar Stars and Their Pets'' comes in at No. 34. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Jorge Posada was among the last Yankees to arrive in the clubhouse on Sunday, showing up about 90 minutes before the game against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. Manager Joe Torre understood. One look at Posada persuaded Torre to leave him out of the lineup.

Cheyenne Kimball ''The Day Has Come'' (Daylight/Epic) Cheyenne Kimball's MTV reality show, ''Cheyenne,'' portrays an earnest young singer-songwriter trying to make the transition from child prodigy to pop star. (In 2003 she was named America's Most Talented Kid on a television show of the same name.) There are few tantrums, rants, ill-advised hookups, blithely ignorant pronouncements or plainly delusional boasts; instead, you see a more than competent singer with an impressive work ethic and an upbeat attitude. No wonder it's not much fun to watch.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about Britain's observation of the one-year anniversary of the terrorist bombings in London contained an incorrect given name for London's mayor, who was shown taking part in the commemoration. He is Ken Livingstone, not Kevin.

Barry Bonds passed Babe Ruth in home runs, although it seemed as if it took forever. Roger Clemens's return to the Astros for a third season seemed as if it took forever as well. Federal investigators said Jason Grimsley used steroids, human growth hormone and amphetamines, a development that will probably hover over baseball forever. The Tigers have been terrific, which hardly anyone expected. The Royals have been terrible, which nearly everyone expected. The Mets have been better than every National League team, and better than the Yankees. George Steinbrenner did not expect that.

DVC Worldwide in Morristown, N.J., which works for clients like Georgia-Pacific, JVC and Kraft Foods, is being acquired by Aspen Marketing Services in West Chicago, Ill. Financial terms were not disclosed. Aspen is acquiring DVC, which was founded in 1985 as Dugan Valva Contessa, from the Frontenac Company and Lake Capital. About 40 of the 50 employees in Morristown, who work on assignments in areas like advertising, promotions and event marketing, will join Aspen.

India Reports Nuclear Missile Test; Success in Doubt India test-fired its longest-range nuclear-capable missile for the first time, government officials said. But it was unclear whether the entire test was successful. At least one report said that the missile had failed. PAGE A6 122 Dead in Russian Air Crash The death toll reaches at least 122 in the crash of an airliner in Siberia, and one survivor said that the plane accelerated after it landed, went off the runway and struck a concrete wall. The cause of the crash was unclear. PAGE A6 Brotherly Politics in Poland President Lech Kaczynski of Poland announced that he would appoint his twin brother and longtime political partner, Jaroslaw, to succeed Prime Minister Kazimierz Marcinkiewicz, who resigned over the weekend. PAGE A3 Bush's Rhetorical Shift The president has recently urged patience when dealing with the standoffs in Iran and North Korea, a change from his earlier, muscular statements. 5:30 P.M. (TLC) DINNER TAKES ALL -- Five strangers with a passion for entertaining engage in a competitive dinner cook-off in this new series showing Monday through Friday nights through Aug. 4. They don't have to impress judges but instead will cook for one another. Each evening, one contestant invites the four others over for dinner, and the guests will vote on food and presentation. Some episodes have the added obstacle of cramped, New York City living quarters. (Is that a bathtub in your kitchen?) Tonight, Valerie Grubb (above left, with the other contestants Joshua Warr, Cindi Avila, Nikki Thompson and Martin Szymanski) opens her 400-squarefoot apartment to the others for a dinner party themed ''Late Night Nibbles.'' 8 P.M. (COURT) BEACH PATROL: MIAMI BEACH -- Drunken brawls on the beach, dangerous ocean rescues and other unpredictable situations face the Miami Beach Ocean Rescue team in this new series. 8 P.M. (Family) KYLE XY -- The Trager family still hasn't figured out where their new boarder came from, and he seems unable to offer any help. Tonight, police discover a skeleton in the woods near the spot where Kyle (Matt Dallas) originally appeared. 8 P.M. (Military) BEST RANGER 2006 -- Think you're tough, do you? Army Rangers are active duty military personnel who might be called into service at any time, so they're tough and they're ready. This competition pits the best of the best against one another to determine the top twoman Ranger team in the country. The battle, though, is so grueling that only 15 of the 26 teams competing at Fort Benning, Ga., were able to finish. 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) CAUGHT IN THE MOMENT -- In this series premiere, Tristan Bayer and Vanessa Garnick, childhood sweethearts turned best friends, travel the globe in search of rare glimpses at unusual moments in the lives of animals; or just unusual animals. (Have you ever seen a spirit bear?) 10 P.M. (HGTV) HOUSE HUNTERS -- Star Jones Reynolds has left ''The View,'' but you can get your fix as she takes on hosting duties for a weeklong look at the intimidating and expensive New York City housing market. Real estate agents and buyers will give a crash course in the buying process and the real deal on some of the city's hottest neighborhoods. 10 P.M. (13) HOW ART MADE THE WORLD -- In ''The Art of Persuasion,'' the third episode of this five-part series, the host Dr. Nigel Spivey (left) shows us how historical figures have used images to persuade, influence and manipulate others. STEVEN McELROY

The Red Brick Road in London, the agency opened in December by Sir Frank Lowe, has landed its second big client. Heineken named Red Brick Road as its lead worldwide creative agency for the Heineken brand, replacing Strawberry Frog in Amsterdam, which was awarded the assignment last August. Spending estimates for the Heineken worldwide brand campaigns range from $50 million to $100 million; they include ads promoting sponsorships of a European soccer league, the coming James Bond film ''Casino Royale'' and the 2007 Rugby World Cup.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Rampages and Bombs Kill Dozens in Baghdad A mob of gunmen went on a daytime rampage through a predominantly Sunni Arab district of western Baghdad, pulling people from their cars and homes and killing them in what officials and residents called revenge by Shiite militias for the bombing of a Shiite mosque. Reports of the death toll ranged from less than a dozen to more than 40. Later a bomb in a Shiite mosque in another Baghdad neighborhood killed at least 19 people and wounded 59. A1 U.S. Stresses Talks with Korea The top American negotiator with North Korea, Christopher R. Hill, left, said his priority was to get back to the negotiating table, signaling that the United States was seeking a diplomatic solution instead of punitive economic sanctions against North Korea for test-launching seven missiles. A6 India Tests Long-Range Missile India test-fired its longest range nuclear-capable missile for the first time, government officials said. But it was unclear whether the test was successful, with at least one report saying that the missile failed at some point during its flight. A6 Israel Vows Ongoing Action Israel will continue its military offensive in the Gaza Strip at its own pace until Palestinian militants release a captured Israeli soldier and halt their rocket attacks, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, above, told his cabinet. Mr. Olmert also ruled out negotiations with Hamas, saying that would only support another kidnapping. A10 Polish Leader Elevates Twin President Lech Kaczynski of Poland announced that he would appoint his twin brother and longtime political partner, Jaroslaw, to succeed Prime Minister Kazimierz Marcinkiewicz, according to a Polish news agency. A3 Russian Plane Crash Kills 122 A Russian passenger plane crashed after landing, claiming 122 lives. The reason for the crash was unclear. The official Russian Information Agency cited an investigator who said the airplane's hydraulic braking system had failed. A6 Wolfowitz Urges Trade Talks Paul D. Wolfowitz, left, president of the World Bank, has called on President Bush and other world leaders to make further compromises to revive the faltering global trade talks that are at an impasse over the issue of farm subsidies. Mr. Wolfowitz said the failure to reach an agreement on trade would be a blow to the world's poorest countries. A9 NATIONAL A11-15 Republican Gives Details Of Intelligence Withheld Peter Hoekstra, left, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said the Bush administration briefed the panel on a ''significant'' intelligence program only after a government whistle-blower alerted him to its existence and he pressed Mr. Bush for details. A11 Court's Decision Divides G.O.P. The Supreme Court decision striking down the use of military commissions to bring terrorism detainees to trial has set off sharp differences among Republicans in Congress over what kind of rights detainees should be granted and how much deference should be shown the president in deciding the issue. A1 Tough Race for Republican Rick Santorum, the third-ranking Republican leader in the Senate, is fighting for his political life, trying to convince his Pennsylvania constituents that he has not gone ''Washington.'' A former symbol of the conservative movement, he is now trying to show his kinder, gentler side. A1 Florida Mayor Pushes Fines The mayor of Avon Park, Fla., is pushing a proposal to root out and punish landlords who rent to illegal immigrants, fining them $1,000 for every such tenant. The plan has supporters across the country, but civil rights organizations and the town's immigrant community and farmers want to strike it down. A11 Football Lures Male Students Some small American colleges, eager to attract men to increasingly female campuses, have taken notice of how many students can be lured to attend by adding a football team. Officials say football can bring in more tuition-paying students than any other course or activity -- and not just players themselves. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Small Towns Resist High-Voltage Towers Private power companies looking to supply the New York City area with electric power from upstate sources are facing opposition from residents in small hamlets where high-voltage transmission towers would be built. They have become the first battleground over a law that expanded federal powers to meet energy needs. B1 Gap in Campaign Money Republican candidates in New York are struggling to raise money this year, and in some cases are competing against one another, while Democrats, particularly Eliot Spitzer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, have turned their popular support into large war chests. B1 Five Killed in Car Crash Five people were killed and two others critically injured when their car jumped a barrier into oncoming traffic on the Bronx River Parkway and was crushed by another vehicle, the police said. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Italy Wins World Cup Title Italy won its fourth World Cup title, defeating France, 5-3, in a penalty-kick shootout after overtime ended with the score tied at 1-1. France went into the shootout without its captain and star midfielder, Zin√©dine Zidane, who had been ejected after he head-butted the Italian defender Marco Materazzi in the chest after the two exchanged words. A1 ARTS E1-8 Harvard Divided Over a Room A renovation of a Harvard University poetry reading room designed by the Finnish architect Alvar Aalto has drawn heated objections from architects and preservationists who say the room should be maintained exactly as Aalto created it. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Data on Defibrillators Federal health officials are expected to release records showing that patients with severe heart disease suffered complications, including infections and deaths, when they underwent surgery to have heart devices implanted in their chests. C1 Executive Turmoil at EBay After a trying week in which one of the company's top executives resigned, eBay is facing new concerns over executive turnover and management succession, adding to what may be an even bigger challenge: an invasion of its turf by Google. C1 AOL's Strategy Shift In two weeks, the board of Time Warner Inc., which owns AOL, will hear a proposal from AOL's chief executive calling for a near halt in marketing for AOL's Internet access service, price cuts for existing customers and thousands of layoffs. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: The U.N. sideshow on Korea; drafting the future of the parks; lobbyists yes, the people maybe; Lawrence Downes on day laborers. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E6 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 Obituaries B7 TV Listings E8 Weather B8
To the Editor: Re ''Surgery With a Side of Fries,'' by Dr. Andrew Weil (Op-Ed, July 6):

To the Editor: As a public school teacher, I appreciated ''Teachers Matter,'' your July 4 editorial drawing attention to the importance of highly trained teachers and the difference they can make in students' learning.
To the Editor: The school where I teach does not parallel ''What Boy Crisis?,'' by Judith Warner (column, July 3).

DATA ON DEFIBRILLATORS -- Federal health officials are set to release records about tens of thousands of recent heart defibrillator implant operations, including data showing that about 4 percent of those patients had at least one complication during an implant procedure. But the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services has decided to withhold information identifying the doctors involved in those procedures [Page C1.] NEW DIRECTION FOR AOL -- In two weeks, the board of Time Warner, which owns AOL, will hear a proposal from Jonathan Miller, AOL's chief executive, calling for a near halt in marketing for AOL's 17-year-old Internet access service, price cuts for existing customers and thousands of layoffs. [C1.] EBAY'S CHALLENGES -- After a trying week in which one of its top executives resigned, eBay is facing new concerns over executive turnover and management succession. [C1.] BASEBALL BOOKS REIGN -- Books about baseball and its players dominate the top-selling titles in the sports and adventure category at Barnes & Noble online. For the year, the No. 1 title in the category is ''Game of Shadows'' about the baseball steroids scandal, followed by ''Clemente: The Passion and Grace of Baseball's Last Hero,'' about Roberto Clemente, above. [C8.] RECORD-BREAKING 'PIRATES' -- ''Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest'' pulverized several records at the box office over the weekend, becoming the most-successful movie opening in Hollywood history. [E2.] FUTURE OF ONLINE MOVIE TICKETS -- Because of user fees and a confusing tangle of theater alliances, online ticket sellers like MovieTickets.com and Fandango.com, whose purpose is to save people from long waits at the ticket counter, have yet to win the hearts of mainstream theatergoers. But surging revenue from advertising and a possible shift in business philosophy could change that, perhaps in time for ''Pirates of the Caribbean 3.'' Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C8.] DELL'S DAMAGED IMAGE -- A Dell notebook computer that burst into flames last month in Japan has damaged more than just the conference table where it sat smoldering. The incident, publicized in photos on the Internet, has also hurt Dell's recent attempts to improve its image. [C6.] MOBILE MARKETING -- Lucky, a Cond√© Nast magazine, will offer readers of its September issue a chance to send text messages from their mobile phones to buy merchandise from 18 marketers and retailers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.] HOLLYWOOD IN IDAHO -- The small town of Preston, Idaho, is working to capitalize on the success of the 2004 cult movie ''Napoleon Dynamite,'' which was filmed there. [C1.] WORLD CUP AD WINNERS -- In the marketing arena, it created many opportunities for glory -- as well as a few disappointments. [C7.] FROM GAELIC TO GLOBAL -- Setanta Sports, which started out delivering broadcasts of Irish sports like Gaelic football as well as mainstream fare like soccer to expat-friendly bars in Britain and the United States, has grown into a major international sports broadcaster. [C5.]

A six-month stretch of political fund-raising will end tomorrow for New York candidates, and the results, by all accounts, will be stark: Republicans are struggling, and in some cases competing with one another for cash. The race for governor should yield a particularly sharp contrast, according to advisers to the two leading candidates. The Democrat, Eliot Spitzer, has about $15 million on hand, his allies say, and that is after spending $10 million on advertising already. The Republican, John Faso, is expected to report having $2 million to $3 million, and he has not advertised since an introductory television spot in February.

Guster ''Ganging Up on the Sun'' (Reprise) ''We're not sentimental, we're just oil-filled machines,'' Ryan Miller sings near the end of Guster's fifth album. He sounds as if he wants to believe it himself. But the rest of the album suggests that Mr. Miller is obsessed with his sentiments, including a nagging sense of disaffection. He's horrified by the war, frustrated by the ruling class; he wants to know where we go from here. Back to high school, perhaps, or some imaginary Eden. Anywhere, really, just to escape ''the trenches of the new underground.''

Because of an editing error, an article on July 3 about a decision by NASA to postpone the launching of the space shuttle Discovery until July 4 misstated a factor in the timing of the current mission. The space agency needed to launch the shuttle by July 19, or wait until late August, because of the amount of daylight required to photograph both the liftoff in Florida and the jettisoning of the external fuel tank over the Indian Ocean; the date was not dictated by the orbital plane of the International Space Station.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about new research on men's attitudes toward prostate cancer referred imprecisely to the course of the disease. While it tends to advance slowly, it is not invariably slow-growing.

The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: Allied World Assurance Holdings, an initial public offering of 8.8 million shares. Goldman Sachs. Ares Capital Corporation, 9.4 million shares. Merrill Lynch. Cowen Group, an initial public offering of 11.2 million shares. SG Cowen, Credit Suisse and Merrill Lynch. Gordon Biersch Brewery Restaurant Group, an initial public offering of 4.5 million shares. Thomas Weisel. (Source by MCM EquityWatch)

Rhymefest ''Blue Collar'' (J/Allido) Rhymefest is honest enough to admit on his first major-label album that he owes a good part of his career to a fellow Chicagoan, Kanye West. Mr. West produced Rhymefest's first album, the little-noticed, independently released ''Raw Dawg,'' in 2001. A few years later Mr. West and Rhymefest, whose real name is Che Smith, shared a Grammy Award for the hit they wrote together, ''Jesus Walks.''

An entry in the Addenda listing with the Advertising column last Monday gave the incorrect surname of the executive who is becoming president at the Optimedia U.S. media agency in New York. He is Antony Young, not Brown.

The top American negotiator with North Korea said Sunday that his first priority was to get that country back to the negotiating table, signaling that the United States was seeking a diplomatic solution instead of punitive economic sanctions against it for launching seven missiles last week. The negotiator, Christopher R. Hill, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said his talks with South Korean officials here over the weekend focused on kick-starting the six-nation talks over the North's nuclear program. The talks have been deadlocked since last September.

Centro Properties Group, an Australian real estate investment trust, is planning to announce today that it has agreed to acquire Heritage Property Investment Trust for about $1.8 billion. The acquisition of Heritage, which is based in Boston and owns 157 shopping malls in 27 states, is Centro's largest purchase in the United States as it continues an aggressive overseas acquisition strategy.
To the Editor: Re ''About Breast-Feeding '' (editorial, July 2):

Cult of Luna ''Somewhere Along the Highway'' (Earache) The new album by Cult of Luna is good, but maybe not good enough to suggest where this kind of occluded, slow, intricately built and theatrically morose metal is going to go.

An article in Business Day on Friday about plans by AOL to stop marketing its subscription service and build a free, advertising-supported business on the Web misidentified the magazine that earlier this year put AOL's software at the top of its list of the 25 worst technology products. It was PC World, not PC Magazine.

Two Brooklyn youths, ages 18 and 12, were arrested yesterday for their role in a hate crime on June 26, when two black teenagers were assaulted at Gerritsen Beach, the police said. The 18-year-old was identified as Joseph Jirovec. Previously, three 17-year-old boys from Brooklyn were arrested and charged. JENNIFER 8. LEE (NYT)

CSS ''Cansei de Ser Sexy'' (Sub Pop) Smart, insubordinate fun reigns on ''Cansei de Ser Sexy,'' the debut album by CSS, a Brazilian band from S√£o Paulo that sings in English and declares things like ''Music Is My Hot Hot Sex.''

The Liberty will enter the W.N.B.A.'s All-Star Game break with its worst record in franchise history at the midway point. The Liberty (4-14) lost its fifth game in a row yesterday, falling to the Phoenix Mercury, 94-88, in overtime at Madison Square Garden. With four minutes left in overtime, the Liberty's leading scorer, Becky Hammon, twisted her ankle and left the game. From that point, the Liberty was unable to keep up with the Mercury's offense, which was led by Diana Taurasi, who scored a career-high 36 points. The Phoenix rookie guard Cappie Pondexter, who was the 2006 Big East player of the year, had 22 points. Hammon, the Liberty's only All-Star, is not sure if her ankle injury will keep her from playing in Wednesday's All-Star Game at the Garden. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT (NYT)

THAT'S MR. SECRETARY TO YOU -- Henry M. Paulson Jr., below, the former chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, will be sworn in as Treasury secretary. (Monday.) MICROSOFT FINES -- The European Commission will make a final decision on how much to fine Microsoft for failing to comply with an antitrust order to supply Windows documentation to competitors. The commission has threatened to impose fines of up to 2 million euros ($2.6 million) a day, backdated to Dec. 15, which would amount to more than $500 million. (Wednesday.) KEN LAY MEMORIAL -- A memorial service will be held at First United Methodist Church in Houston for Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy in the company's collapse. (Wednesday.) TRADE GAP The Commerce Department will release the trade deficit figures for May. Economists are expecting that the deficit will remain steady at about $63.4 billion. (Wednesday.) ADELPHIA SALE -- The Federal Communications Commission will vote on the sale of Adelphia Communications to Comcast and Time Warner. (Thursday.) JAPAN RATES -- The Bank of Japan is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter-point, the first such increase in six years. (Friday.) ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- Reports are due on wholesale inventories for May and consumer credit for May (Wednesday). Other reports due this week are business inventories for May, retail sales and import prices for June and the University of Michigan consumer confidence index for July. (Friday.) EARNINGS ROUNDUP -- Earnings season kicks off with second-quarter results coming from Alcoa (Monday)PepsiCo (Thursday) and General Electric (Friday). Others reports include Standard Microsystems (Monday); Genentech, AMB Property and Pepsi Bottling (Tuesday); Commerce Bancshares, Gannett, Infosys Technologies and M&T Bank (Wednesday); and Cintas, Marriott, McClatchy, Media General and Tribune. (Thursday.)

When the Yankees led by five runs early on Sunday against the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, Alex Rodriguez sensed that the first half of the season would end happily. ''We thought it had the potential to be a blowout,'' Rodriguez said. ''We just couldn't add more runs to the board.''

Hedge fund manager Pirate Capital is scanning the horizon for potential acquisition candidates -- and its list of preferred targets includes other hedge funds. (If Pirate's name sounds familiar, that may be because in recent weeks it has been loudly and repeatedly urging power producer Mirant to consider various options including a sale of the company.)

Before we sign off, I just want to mention that should you somehow manage to get me elected president of FIFA soon, I promise that no World Cup trophy will ever again be awarded after a penalty shootout. The 90-minute final will simply be replayed three days later in the event of a draw, and then replayed again and again if necessary until someone actually manages to win it. If we can have seven games and two weeks to decide the winner of national baseball or basketball titles in this country, why not play as many games as it takes to get a winner in international football? Failing that, we will just not award the trophy to either team and hand out second-place medals to everyone. That's a just reward for playing not to lose rather than to win. Till then, thanks so much for reading and writing along with us! Rob Mackey

Money manager Mario Gabelli is nothing if not dogged. Just a few weeks ago, Mr. Gabelli settled with the Justice Department over charges that he used deceptive methods in a Federal Communications Commission auction of wireless spectrum licenses. On Tuesday -- before the settlement had even been approved by a judge -- his company declared its intention to bid in another such auction.

As we mentioned earlier, we were fortunate enough to get to both blog and moblog this entire World Cup from a city that happens to be home to someone from almost every corner of the planet. Moblogging allowed us to post nearly live images and video on this site of fans in New York watching the matches in Germany. Even a quick look at the photographs we managed to grab from various points around the city reveals how passionately New Yorkers followed the tournament and makes it clear that fans of all nations here lived and died with each touch of the ball, just as hundreds of thousands or millions of their fellow countrymen and countrywomen did back home and in other parts of the world, in those temporary national enclaves that formed day after day around television sets in bars, restaurants and social clubs whenever matches were played.

Topps, the venerable purveyor of trading cards and Bazooka chewing gum, remains in a sticky proxy fight with an activist hedge fund shareholder that wants wholesale change at the company.
Two days after Juan Pablo Montoya announced that he would go to Nascar next season, his McLaren-Mercedes team in Formula One announced today that he would take the rest of the season off.
The power company Mirant Corporation said on Tuesday it would repurchase $1.25 billion in stock and announced plans to sell its Philippines and Caribbean businesses.

The road to the public markets in Milan has been littered with casualties lately, with Pirelli Tyre recently becoming the latest Italian company to withdraw its planned initial public offering. No such fate befell Piaggio, however. Shares of Italian company, which makes the Vespa scooter, staged strong gains on Tuesday after it raised about $400 million in an I.P.O.
