Germany's Linde on Tuesday reassured investors that its 8.2 billion pound ($15.1 billion) merger with the British industrial gases group BOC was on track to close this year following news that a $960 million lawsuit had been lodged against BOC, the Financial Times reported Tuesday.

The National City Corporation, a bank holding comany based in Cleveland, said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy Harbor Florida Bancshares for about $1.1 billion in stock. National City said it had agreed to pay $45 a share for Harbor Florida, which is based in Fort Pierce, Fla., and has 40 branches in the state.

A French distributor of electric supplies, the Rexel Group, said Tuesday it would buy the electric supply business of General Electric in a deal worth $725 million. In a press release, GE said the divestiture was part of a "repositioning of its industrial business."

The Swiss-based miner Xstrata said on Tuesday it was raising its hostile bid for the 80 percent of theCanadian miner Falconbridge it does not own to 59 Canadian dollars a share from 52.50 Canadian dollars.

HSBC has appointed Spencer Lake as its new global head of debt capital markets a mere month after he had been introduced as Merrill Lynch's head of Pacific-Rim debt capital markets. He was due to arrive in Asia this month to start his new role.
Venali has filed suit against J2 Global Communications and Catch Curve, alleging violations of Federal antitrust, trademark competitiveness and patent laws.

A federal judge is deciding whether to throw out a suit filed by a Washington, D.C.-based law and lobbying boutique, Butera & Andrews alleging that I.B.M. and an unidentified employee in its Durham, N.C., facility tried to hack into its e-mail system.
The top privacy officer at the Department of Homeland Security will join the Washington, D.C., office of the law firm Hunton & Williams in September.

Saudi Arabia plans to block a $3.5 billion pipeline backed by Occidental Petroleum, Total and a partner that would carry Qatari natural gas to the United Arab Emirates, the Middle East's second-largest Arab economy.

The European Commission is scheduled to announce measures to help break down barriers to stock and derivatives trading in Europe, a move it says should significantly reduce transaction costs across the bloc.
An activist investor in the H.J. Heinz Company asked fellow shareholders to reject the company's slate of candidates for the board.
Wal-Mart Stores would have to abandon its bid to operate a bank under the provisions of a bill introduced in Congress on Monday.
The Man Group, the British hedge fund company, won investor approval for a 6-for-1 stock split on Tuesday after earlier announcing a rise in assets under management to $54 billion at the end of June.
Two companies implicated in the widening stock-options backdating morass said that they face further troubles over the controversial practice.

Three former British bankers wanted in the United States on Enron-related fraud charges will be extradited Thursday over protests from business leaders such as the billionaire Philip Green and the chairman of British Airways, Martin Broughton.
Europe's competition watchdog plans to fine Microsoft up to 3 million euros ($3.8 million) a day if the company continues to defy an antitrust decision, Reuters reported.

As Ajit Jain was departing McKinsey & Company two decades ago, he told a colleague he'd be helping to oversee insurance at Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. He said he knew little about the business, yet was unconcerned.
Warburg Pincus has purchased Brandywine Senior Care, a Mount Laurel, N.J.-based operator of long-term care facilities, in a secondary buyout for about $150 million.

Evergreen Pacific Partners is luxuriating in its purchase of Gene Juarez Salons & Spas, a 35-year old company that has pampered the likes of Jennifer Lopez, Angelina Jolie and former president Bill Clinton, for an undisclosed amount.

VeriFone Holdings' largest shareholder continued to lighten its load of the company's shares last month as it sold off nearly $80 million, or 13 percent, of its stake in the San Jose, Calif., company.

After pressing for the sale of both Carreker and Sunterra last month, an activist hedge fund manager, Robert Chapman, has turned his sights on a third company, calling for troubled Vitesse Semiconductor to put itself on the auction block.

Swiss Re will cut 2,000 jobs by 2007, or 17.5 percent of its global workforce, through layoffs and attrition in the wake of its $7.4-billion takeover of GE Insurance Solutions, the company said on Tuesday.

Osage Ventures said Monday it has led a first-round $2.3 million private equity financing of Moda Technology Partners, which sells environment-testing systems. Moda, which is based in Wayne, Penn., will use the money to accelerate the development of its products, market presence and management team.

Internet traffic management vendor CacheLogic has raised $20 million in its third round of funding and plans to expand its product portfolio to help Internet service providers deal with the anticipated ramp in networked video.

The Carbon Trust is to launch a listed venture-capital arm to invest in green technologies. The government-funded organization, which helps companies to assess and reduce their impact on the environment, is planning to raise 75 million pounds ($138 million) from institutional investors to back the fund, which will be created from its own in-house investment unit and listed on the Alternative Investment Market.

SecondSpace, a Bellevue, Wash. startup now in stealth mode, said it had received $6.5 million jointly from Ignition Partners of Bellevue and an unnamed commercial partner in its initial round of funding.

Owens & Minor said on Tuesday it had agreed to acquire certain assets of the acute-care medical and surgical supply distribution business of McKesson Medical-Surgical, a unit of the McKesson Corporation, for about $170 million.

ConSentry Networks has raised $20 million in an oversubscribed round of funding. The company, which is based in Milpitas, Calif., provides secure products for local area networks. It said the fourth funding round included existing investors Accel Partners and Invesco Private Capital, both of which have offices in Palo Alto, and Sequoia Capital, which has an office in Menlo Park. Also participating was a new investor, Duff Ackerman & Goodrich Ventures of Palo Alto.

Craft College, which makes instructional videos, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise between $250,000 and $750,000 by selling 1 million to 3 million shares at 25 cents apiece in Colorado and five other states.
Protalex, a New Hope, Penn., biotechnology company, said that it had raised $15.2 million in a private placement of 6.1 million shares of common stock at $2.50 a share.

Shares in VNU, the world's largest market research company, were delisted on Tuesday, exactly one year after the company announced plans to buy a data firm in the United States, IMS Health, a move that sparked an investor revolt and made VNU takeover prey.
GeoMet, which extracts natural gas from coal, plans to raise nearly $228 million in an initial public offering and a separate sale.
Commerzbank of Germany has appointed J.P. Morgan Cazenove alongside Goldman Sachs to advise it on listing Jupiter, its U.K. asset management arm, in London.

A decision by the Indian government to halt all sales of stakes in state-owned companies could crush investors' interest as it raises fear that a larger program of economic change will be bogged down in politics.

Federal prosecutors investigating Deutsche Bank over its role in questionable tax shelters have been focusing on a lesser-known shelter sold through a Silicon Valley firm founded by a dot-com billionaire, court documents show.
Citigroup, the world's biggest bank, is pulling out of retail banking in France and will close its last branch, on the Champs-Elys√©es in Paris, by next spring.

DigiMedical Solutions has finalized its acquisition of Harrington's Pharmacies and Apothecary Pharmacies. Terms were not disclosed, but the acquisition secured $15 million in annual revenue from six locations, including two in Dallas, three in Naples, Fla., and one in Fort Myers, Fla.
Marathon Oil announced it was entering into a joint venture to build and operate ethanol plants, a testament to the growing importance of the corn-based fuel for the refining industry.
Hamleys, owner of the famous toy store in Regent Street, London, is stepping up its expansion overseas with a new franchise operation in the Middle East.
Earlier this year, Cascade Natural Gas announced it had hired an investment banking company to investigate "all available options to maximize shareholder value."
Royal Dutch Shell will sell its downstream sales and marketing operations in some Pacific island nations to focus its regional portfolio on fewer, larger scale businesses.
Generali pushed ahead with its plans to expand outside Italy, announcing it had entered the Bulgarian insurance market with the acquisition of a 51 per cent stake in Orel-G.

Two groups are vying to buy Bouwfonds, the property subsidiary of ABN Amro that the Dutch bank put on the market late last year for about 1.5 billion euros ($1.9 billion).
The United Auto Workers president, Ron Gettelfinger, said he doubts that a proposal for General Motors Corporation to link up with Nissan Motor Company and Renault will go anywhere.

Klausner Technologies said Monday it had filed a patent infringement suit against Vonage in federal court in the eastern district of Texas. Klausner is seeking damages and royalties worth about $180 million.

The British orthopedics company Smith & Nephew said Tuesday its endoscopy unit is buying privately held, San Antonio-based OsteoBiologics, which sells bioabsorbable bone graft substitutes in Europe, for $72.3 million.
Mittal Steel said Monday that it does not plan to purchase the outstanding minority stakes of Arcelor's two Brazilian subsidiaries as part of its $31.9 billion takeover of Arcelor.

The newspaper estimated the value of the deal at about $100 million and said the acquisition would be announced later on Tuesday. This would be CA's seventh acquisition in Israel.

The U.S. television ratings for the World Cup final are in, and not surprisingly, they were quite high. As Richard Sandomir reports in Tuesday's Times, the Italy-France finalissima drew 16.9 million viewers -- 11.9 million on ABC and 5 million on Univision. It is unclear whether those figures count the large groups, sometimes numbering to several hundreds of people, that gathered in public places to watch. Even so, the numbers are triple those of 2002 and 31 percent higher than 1998. And, as Sandomir points out, the viewership for Sunday's match was greater than that for the NBA finals and about even with the NCAA men's basketball final and the World Series. (Interestingly, though, viewership numbers for this year's World Cup final are merely even with those for the 1994 final, when the tournament was held in the United States.)

An obituary and headline on Friday about Theodore Levitt, a marketing scholar at the Harvard Business School, referred incorrectly to the origin of the word globalization. While Mr. Levitt‚Äôs work was closely associated with the idea of globalization in economics, and while he published a respected paper in 1983 popularizing the term, he did not coin the word. (It was in use at least as early as 1944 in other senses and was used by others in discussing economics at least as early as 1981.).
Diane M. Gordon, a state assemblywoman from Brooklyn, was accused of having sought a $500,000 home in return for city land.

Wallace Potts was a film archivist for the Rudolf Nureyev Foundation.

The four-story Upper East Side town house that was destroyed in a gas explosion yesterday once served as a clandestine meeting place for a circle of prominent New Yorkers who informally gathered intelligence for President Franklin D. Roosevelt before and during World War II, according to several published histories.
Take-Two Interactive, maker of the Grand Theft Auto video game, said it was the focus of an informal inquiry into its stock options.
Jack Smith was a singer and recording artist who was host of the popular ‚ÄúYou Asked for It‚Äù television show.
Wayne Terwilliger, who is 81 and has been in professional baseball 57 years, longer than anyone else, is now sporting bling.
Hugh Stubbins Jr. was an architect best known for the angular tower of the Citicorp Center in Manhattan.
In the year since he accosted two camera operators, Detroit pitcher Kenny Rogers has turned his career around and will start for the American League tonight in Pittsburgh.
June Allyson's perky wholesomeness made her the perfect girlfriend in a series of MGM musicals during the 1940‚Äôs and the perfect screen wife in the 1950‚Äôs.

The aid group Oxfam closed two of its six offices in the north of the Darfur region because of the abduction of a Sudanese staff member who has been missing for two months. Efforts to track him have been fruitless. Oxfam‚Äôs regional director, Paul Smith-Lomas, said it would continue providing aid in the rest of Darfur, but he said lack of security was complicating efforts to reach three million people dependent on aid in the region.

AFRICANIGERIA: DELTA KIDNAPPERS FREE DUTCHMAN A Dutchman abducted last week while working on an unfinished Shell gas plant in the violent oil-producing Niger Delta has been freed, said his employer Royal Boskalis Westminster. Gunmen seized the hostage, Michael Los, on July 6 from a houseboat after disarming policemen on guard. It was the latest in a series of attacks on the oil and gas industry that have shut down a quarter of Nigeria‚Äôs crude output since February.

In his inaugural address, Prime Minister Jos√© Ramos-Horta said he would invite foreign investors and rebuild the shattered army and police force. Mr. Ramos-Horta, 56, a Nobel Peace prize laureate, said the development of the country, one of the poorest in the world, had been crippled by ‚Äúthe inefficiency, the incompetence, the laziness‚Äù of the government and private sector. He takes over from Mari Alkatiri, who was forced to resign two weeks ago when East Timor spiraled into violence.

India‚Äôs attempt to launch a communications satellite failed when the rocket carrying the satellite exploded. Television images showed the rocket lifting off from Sriharikota Space Center, in eastern Andhra Pradesh, and bursting into flames seconds later, destroying the Insat 4C satellite. ‚ÄúThere seems to be a mishap in the first stage of the launch,‚Äù the director of the Indian Space Research Organization, G. Madhavan Nair, told reporters. Insat 4C was the first satellite launched from India and was expected to increase capacity for direct-to-home satellite television services, weather imaging and satellite imagery. The launching failure came just a day after the test-firing of India‚Äôs longest-range nuclear-capable ballistic missile also ended in failure. Space scientists said that work had already begun on another communications satellite in the Insat 4 series, and that it would be launched within a year from Kourou, in French Guyana.

The Spanish police said they had arrested a former Colombian drug lord, Leonidas Vargas, on Saturday. Mr. Vargas once led the drug cartel in Caquet√° Province, in southwest Colombia. Mr. Vargas was an ally of Pablo Escobar, the cocaine kingpin who was killed by the police in 1993.

Three Russian passenger planes made emergency landings after suffering malfunctions one day after a jet burst into flames in Siberia after crashing during a landing. No one died in the new incidents, but three people were injured when their Tu-134, carrying the navy chief of staff, Vladimir Masorin, caught fire after it overran the runway at a military base in the Crimea region of Ukraine. An Airbus A-310 operated by S7 Airlines made an emergency landing in Ukraine after an engine malfunctioned, and a Urals Airlines Tu-154 flight from Yekaterinburg landed in Irkutsk after one of its engines broke down. On Sunday, an S7 A-310 crashed in Irkutsk; 124 people died and 4 were missing.

Breaking official secrecy, Britain will publicly announce its assessment of terrorism threat levels as of Aug. 1. John Reid, the home secretary, said the estimates were ‚Äúnot an exact science‚Äù but would follow a five-point scale replacing the current seven grades in secret assessments. In the United States, the five levels of terror risk go from green (low) to red (severe). Last year Britain lowered its secret threat-level assessment only weeks before the London bombings.
Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee at a field hearing in Miami on immigrants in the military.
Commuters may be subjected to tests involving radar, infrared sensors or handheld devices that look like cameras.
Officials who objected to the administration‚Äôs plan for military commissions will now testify before Congress.
A leading public interest group says the Deficit Reduction Act, which would cut $39 billion in spending over the next five years, is unconstitutional because of a clerical error.
Family members said they believed the Italian defender Marco Materazzi had called Zidane, the son of Algerian immigrants, a ‚Äúterrorist.‚Äù

A man who pleaded guilty to shaking his 3-month-old son, breaking several of his bones, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 11 years in prison, prosecutors said. The man, Jerome Wiza, 26, of Elmhurst, pleaded guilty last month to first-degree assault for violently shaking his son, Nikkolas, in February because he would not stop crying, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The boy suffered brain hemorrhages and a fractured leg and ribs. As part of his sentence, Mr. Wiza must participate in making an instructional video warning parents of the dangers of shaking children.

Part of Princeton University was closed briefly yesterday after a director of a summer program found an envelope containing a white powdery substance. University officials say they believe that the powder was a bleach cleaner or similar substance. A hazardous-materials team spent about half an hour on campus after the powder was discovered in a dorm room about 11 a.m.

A 46-year-old Washington Township man shot and killed his two sons in their beds yesterday before killing himself, the Bergen County prosecutor said. The police found the body of the man, Thomas J. Frazza, in the basement of his home shortly after noon, said the prosecutor, John L. Molinelli. They found two handguns, a 9-millimeter and a .357-caliber Magnum, near his body. The prosecutor said the police believed that Mr. Frazza shot his sons ‚Äî John, 20, and Kevin, 14 ‚Äî while they were asleep. Both had gunshot wounds. Mr. Frazza‚Äôs wife and 19-year-old daughter were in South Jersey at the time of the shootings, the prosecutor‚Äôs office said.
Major League Baseball and Fox Sports will announce Tuesday a seven-year renewal of their contract.

The Suffolk County police are collecting information on the race of people detained for routine traffic violations as part of a study into the possibility that drivers are being profiled on the basis of race, officials said yesterday. County Executive Steve Levy said the goal was to determine if the practice occurred, and to counter the accusations of profiling if it did not. The review, which began about two months ago, is expected to continue for 6 to 12 months.

Residents of several Fire Island communities were given permission yesterday to resume using tap water after an advisory over the weekend to boil water because of concerns about E. coli bacteria, said Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive. Tests from late last week showed the presence of the bacteria, which can be of particular concern for people with weakened immune systems, but officials said it was more likely a problem with the samples that were tested rather than with the water system. County officials distributed 27,000 bottles of water and 100,000 pounds of ice to residents in about 3,000 homes and businesses on the island over the weekend.

A Queens councilman wants the City Council to disclose which members are responsible for the ‚Äúmember items‚Äù added to the city budget each year during negotiations with the mayor. The councilman, Hiram Monserrate, said yesterday that he would introduce a bill to require the disclosure. By tradition, the hundreds of appropriations inserted in the final days of the budget talks are listed on a document with minimal explanation of the purpose of each item and no totals or year-by-year comparisons. ‚ÄúWe cannot in good conscience pursue an agenda of reform that does not address the most significant responsibility the Council holds: allocating funds in the annual budget process,‚Äù said Mr. Monserrate, a Democrat who is challenging a fellow Democrat, State Senator John D. Sabini, for his seat.

A homeless man has been charged with five counts of burglary in connection with repeated break-ins at Sts. Cyril and Methodious Roman Catholic Church, the police said yesterday. The man, Daniel LaValle, 37, was arrested on Sunday, the police said. The break-ins took place between May 23 and June 29, said Detective Lt. James Maher of the Suffolk police. In most cases, money was stolen from the poor boxes, Lieutenant Maher said.

Nassau and Suffolk Counties are seeking proposals from companies interested in creating a wireless broadband system that would be accessible anywhere on Long Island, officials said yesterday. The request, a preliminary step in contracting for a wireless system, says the counties will accept proposals until Aug. 30, then decide whether to make a formal request for bids.

The New London police sought a search warrant yesterday for a car that plowed into a crowd at the city‚Äôs annual Sailfest on Saturday, injuring 27 people. The police want an expert to determine whether mechanical failure led to the accident or if criminal charges should be filed, said Capt. William Dittman. The driver, Robert Laine, 85, said his gas pedal jammed, causing the car to lurch into the crowd. Mr. Laine has a clean driving record, a Department of Motor Vehicles spokesman said.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman filed paperwork with the Connecticut secretary of state yesterday that would allow him to run on a new party line if he loses the state‚Äôs Democratic primary next month. The 25 people who signed petitions to create the party, called Connecticut for Lieberman, will run the drive to collect the 7,500 signatures needed to allow the senator‚Äôs presence on the ballot, said Marion Steinfels, a spokeswoman for the campaign. By running with the party rather than individually, Mr. Lieberman could receive a higher place on the ballot, officials said.
David A. Bright, an authority on the sinking of the Andrea Doria, was helping lead preparations to commemorate the disaster‚Äôs 50th anniversary.

Technology stocks fell after Merrill Lynch cut its rating on the sector and after an earnings warning from the data storage equipment maker EMC.

Federal prosecutors investigating Deutsche Bank are focusing on a lesser-known tax shelter sold through a firm founded by a dot-com billionaire.

The Department of Defense has identified 2,534 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.

Mayor Cory A. Booker outlined goals that included improving access to city services and replacing old police stations.

The trial began a process that may finally render a verdict on the sweep of Serbia‚Äôs actions during the war in Kosovo.

Inmates are not subject to federal minimum wage laws, and the absence of compensation for prison jobs does not violate the Constitution, a federal appeals court ruled.

The Army surpassed its recruiting goal for June, the Pentagon said, the 13th consecutive month the service has met or exceeded its target. The Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps also met or exceeded their goals, Defense Department statistics showed. The active-duty Army, which offered a wider array of financial incentives for potential recruits and put more recruiters on the street, found 8,756 recruits in June, compared with its target of 8,600, the Pentagon said.

A boy convicted of stabbing a playmate to death when he was 12 was sentenced to the maximum 26 years in prison. A jury convicted the boy, Evan Savoie, now 15, of first-degree murder for the stabbing death in 2003 of Craig Sorger, 13, who was developmentally disabled. Prosecutors tried Mr. Savoie as an adult. His lawyers have said they will appeal the verdict.

Secretary of State Roger Williams ruled that the musician Kinky Friedman could be listed on the ballot in the November election for governor as Richard ‚ÄúKinky‚Äù Friedman. Mr. Friedman has used the nickname in publishing and on stage. Mr. Williams rejected a request by State Comptroller Carole Keeton Strayhorn to be called ‚ÄúGrandma‚Äù on the same ballot. Whether that qualified as a nickname was a minor consideration, said a spokesman, Scott Haywood. More important was that it tied in with Ms. Strayhorn‚Äôs campaign slogan, ‚ÄúOne Tough Grandma.‚Äù Sloganeering is prohibited on Texas ballots.
If current trends hold, tobacco will kill a billion people this century, 10 times the toll it took in the 20th century, public health officials said.
A county official has collected enough signatures to get on the November ballot opposite the prosecutor of the rape case against Duke University lacrosse players, election officials said.
On the first of two Mondays off, most Tour de France riders rested in preparation for tough climbs ahead in the Pyrenees.
There is not much to crow about in the White House midsession budget review.  But President Bush is likely to gloat, anyway.
Credit card and other types of revolving debt jumped in May by the most since October 2004.

Kraft Foods said it would buy the Spanish and Portuguese units of the United Biscuits Group and regain its Nabisco trademarks in Europe in a transaction valued at $1.07 billion. Kraft is exchanging a 25 percent stake in United Biscuit and assuming $548 million in debt for the divisions and the rights to brands like Ritz and Oreo in the European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, Kraft said. United Biscuits, based in Edinburgh, is selling some of Southern Europe‚Äôs biggest cookie brands, including Fontaneda and Filipinos, as well as Fruco fruit juices.

The Tata Group, one of India‚Äôs largest industrial conglomerates, said it was suspending its proposed $3 billion investment in Bangladesh because of government delays. The group had planned to build steel, coal, fertilizer and power plants in Bangladesh, but wanted government approval by the end of June. Upcoming elections, however, have delayed any decisions on the plants. The company had offered the government a 10 percent stake in each of the projects if the proposals were approved by June.

Three former bankers are set to be extradited from Britain to the United States on Thursday to face fraud charges related to the collapsed energy company Enron after the failure of appeals for them to be tried in Britain. The three, David Bermingham, Gary Mulgrew and Giles Darby, will fly to Houston in the custody of United States marshals, their lawyer, Mark Spragg, said. They will ask to be released on bail so that they can return to Britain to prepare their cases, Mr. Spragg said. The bankers, who worked for NatWest bank, now part of Royal Bank of Scotland, are charged with having conspired with Enron executives over the sale of a stake in an Enron entity in 2000 for less than it was worth, which made them $7.3 million.

The British markets regulator told a financial court that Philippe Jabre, the former director of the hedge fund GLG Partners, should be banned from trading on Britain‚Äôs financial markets because of allegations of insider trading. The Financial Services Authority sought the additional penalty from the Financial Services and Markets Tribunal at a hearing. Mr. Jabre, 46, is already contesting a record fine of ¬£750,000 ($1.4 million) levied by the authority in March. The agency says Mr. Jabre traded on a 2003 Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group securities sale using confidential information provided to him by a Goldman Sachs Group salesman. Mr. Jabre denies wrongdoing; Goldman Sachs is not accused of wrongdoing in the case.
The summer of 2006 may go a long way in the film industry to undo the damage of the summer of 2005, which was nearly devoid of entertainment and profit.
A top government spokesman said Japan should consider whether its Constitution would allow pre-emptive military strikes.
The city's health commissioner said he did not anticipate the need to quarantine vast numbers of flu victims, but isolation measures were included in the plan.
WHEN I travel, I‚Äôm always on the lookout for undiscovered musical talent. But often the talent ‚Äî and I use that term loosely ‚Äî is also on the lookout for me.
Twenty retired military officers say they have ‚Äúdeep concern‚Äù about William J. Haynes II because he approved coercive techniques to interrogate terror suspects.

Nur Barud Gurhan, a hard-line sheik in Mogadishu, has declared Coke an un-Islamic beverage in Somalia.
Bad-check writers might reasonably be excluded from working in banks. But this offense should not be disqualifying for port laborers who have gone on to live crime-free lives.
Several international carriers recently began sharing nutritional information for their menu items and offering lighter alternatives.
Tools developed since the Columbia disaster help NASA to identify endless new problems to worry about.
In the shuttle mission's second spacewalk, Michael E. Fossum and Piers J. Sellers prepared a pump for installation and repaired an equipment transporter.
Hewlett-Packard's $16 billion consulting and services business, HP Services, has been one of its few laggards.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert forcefully rejected dealing with Hamas, despite hints of behind-the-scenes deals.
A former Chilean intelligence chief implicated the disgraced dictator in a cocaine manufacturing and smuggling scheme.
If you think baseball hosiery isn‚Äôt important, think again.
Talks continue about the other two objects sought by the Greek government, with a goal of reaching an accord by late August, officials said.
A slimmer Deborah Voigt at the Royal Opera, Dan Rather's new job, judge orders takeover of Death Row Records and more culture news.
A new study suggests that the amount of weight ex-smokers gain is greater than many experts believed.

Bill Minutaglio portrays Alberto R. Gonzales, who helped draw up the legal framework for the administration‚Äôs war on terror, as a discreet and loyal man.
The film version of "A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints" not only got made against tall odds, it also picked up significant notice and awards at the Sundance Film Festival.
It is clear that success or failure in Iraq lies in the hands of the American officers and sergeants embedded as combat advisers in the new Iraqi security forces.
This P.O.V. documentary should be a treat for avid Tintin fans, who come to it with a thorough appreciation of the character and his adventures.
Adam Szymkowicz's new comedy, which he says is loosely inspired by Chekhov‚Äôs "Three Sisters," is fabulously weird and weirdly fabulous.

Smart paper from cellulose, a starshade for detecting planets, the vulnerable basking shark and an extinct rhino.

Chocolate and greasy foods will not cause acne, but can other foods?

A new book provides sharp insights into Francis Crick's  scientific work and the nature of his remarkable creativity.

Though domestic hotels, in general, provide excellent service, readers had some pet peeves.

For same-sex couples who may wonder what they are missing, New York‚Äôs marriage license bureau is the most romantic setting this side of the motor vehicles bureau.
The W.N.B.A.‚Äôs attendance fell to a league-worst average of 8,174 per game in 2005 (from a high of 10,864 in 1998), and some teams routinely draw under 5,000.

To the Editor: Re ''Long Live Harry,'' by Judith Warner (column, July 7): Well, perhaps it's silly to care about whether Harry Potter lives or dies, given the daunting challenges facing this world. That's probably why it's so appealing to think about this young wizard's fate.

SIEGAL--Molly. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved mother of Michael Siegal and cherished wife of Sol Siegal. Michael Siegal is the distinguished Vice Chairman of Israel Bonds' National Board. We extend our sincere condolences to Michael, his father, and the other members of the Siegal family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joshua Matza President and CEO Burton P. Resnick Chairman of the Board David Halpern National Chairman Bobbie Goldstein,Chairman National Campaign Cabinet

To the Editor: Re ''Prostate Cancer Decisions Often Based on Fallacies'' (July 4): Although many patients make educated decisions, a huge number have minimal recall and comprehension of the details of their problems, their treatment options and the risks and benefits of their choices. The story that takes the cake came from a friendly neurosurgeon. The patient had a brain tumor but wanted the surgeon to know that he (the patient) had an urgent flight to South America the next day for an important conference.

10 P.M. (National Geographic) TOOLS OF THE TRADE: DEMOLITION -- Ever wonder how to tear down a 50,000-seat ballpark? At the old Busch Stadium in St. Louis last year, it was a simple matter of a 10,000-pound wrecking ball above home plate and a 100,000-pound track-hoe with jaws to bite through concrete. 6 P.M. (FMC) THE EFFECT OF GAMMA RAYS ON MAN-IN-THE-MOON MARIGOLDS (1972) -- Paul Newman produced and directed this adaptation of the Pulitzer prize-winning play by Paul Zindel about a widow (Joanne Woodward) and her two daughters. Despite her mother's pessimism, the younger daughter is not to be deterred from a positive attitude. Through a school science project she learns that while radiation often kills growing marigolds, it sometimes makes them more beautiful. 8 P.M. (NBC) FEAR FACTOR -- Aw, Mom, do I have to?! In tonight's 90-minute episode, parents and children work together. In one stunt, parents jump out of a helicopter flying at 200 feet, and in another, a parent must drive through an obstacle course with a child on top of the van. And you were questioning Britney Spears' mommy skills? 9 P.M. (NBC) LAST COMIC STANDING -- The contestants participate in a Friars Club roast. Phyllis Diller, Gilbert Gottfried and the previous winner of ''Last Comic Standing,'' Alonzo Bodden (left), are judges. Later, something is amiss on board the Queen Mary, and the field narrows to five. 9 P.M. (Bravo) KATHY GRIFFIN: MY LIFE ON THE D-LIST -- The misadventures continue for a bottom-shelf celebrity who can't get any respect. Kathy has problems with her new puppy, and she is hired by the Learning Annex to teach a class. So perhaps her students will appreciate her gifts - assuming anyone actually shows up. 10 P.M. (Food) ROAD TASTED -- Paula Deen isn't the only foodophile in the family. Her two sons, Bobby and Jamie, head off on a cross-country road trip in search of unique local culinary treats. For example, Henrietta's Key West coconut strips... yum. 11 P.M. (Bravo) QUEER EYE FOR THE STRAIGHT GUY -- A New York City firefighter, Steve Halliday (right), gets some help from the team as he prepares for a ''thank you party'' where he will attempt to thank the people who have helped him through recent hard times. STEVEN McELROY
To the Editor: Re ''The Liberal Inquisition'' (column, July 9): David Brooks writes that a ''liberal inquisition'' against Senator Joseph I. Lieberman ''has been reduced to one issue, the war.''

In his inaugural address, Prime Minister Jos√© Ramos-Horta said he would invite foreign investors and rebuild the shattered army and police force. Mr. Ramos-Horta, 56, a Nobel Peace prize laureate, said the development of the country, one of the poorest in the world, had been crippled by ''the inefficiency, the incompetence, the laziness'' of the government and private sector. He takes over from Mari Alkatiri, who was forced to resign two weeks ago when East Timor spiraled into violence. JANE PERLEZ (NYT)

To the Editor: ''Anglican Plan Threatens Split on Gay Issues'' (front page, June 28) summarizes the response of the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Rowan Williams, to the General Convention of the Episcopal Church reaction to the Windsor Report, which was issued in 2004 by a committee commissioned by the archbishop. The article is drawn from his ''Reflections,'' which clearly offer thoughts on a way forward.

Henry M. Paulson Jr. took over on Monday as Treasury secretary and as President Bush's top economic adviser, filling out a new economic team with a more pragmatic cast for the final two and a half years of this administration. Mr. Bush, who wooed Mr. Paulson from his post as chairman of Goldman Sachs, said on Monday that the former executive would have a central role in setting the agenda and implied that the Treasury Department would regain some of the power it lost to White House advisers during Mr. Bush's first term.
LOBIANCO--Vera M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vera Lobiano, associated with The Times since October, 1967 until retiring in November 1987.

To the Editor: ''Physics Awaits New Options as Standard Model Idles'' (Essay, July 4) nicely captures the nervous state of particle physics. But one remark -- that physicists have no experimental clues as to what that more overarching theory might be -- is misleading. In fact, there are at least four consistent ones, and they imply that the theory is supersymmetry. Direct confirmation of that (if true) should come soon from the Large Hadron Collider at CERN, and it could emerge even before from Fermilab.

To the Editor: In ''Maine Struggling to Revive Ailing Economy'' (news article, June 29), you report that a senior policy adviser to Gov. John Baldacci views a promising trend: ''middle-age professionals moving to Maine for the scenic setting and low cost of living, while commuting or telecommuting to jobs in other states.'' But Maine may not be able to count on interstate telecommuting to boost economic activity at home. New York and some other states to which Maine residents may telecommute have a tax rule (the ''convenience of the employer'' rule) that penalizes nonresidents who telecommute to in-state employers.

With summer in full swing and clothing at a yearly minimum, concern about weight is naturally at an annual maximum. You may wonder why we just keep becoming fatter despite all the diets millions of Americans have latched onto in recent decades. Don't any of them work? And, if not, why not? Hasn't all the research into the causes and treatment of weight problems yielded clues to help most people achieve and maintain normal body weight?

Japan and South Korea Divided on Missile Tests North Korea's missile tests last Wednesday moved Japanese television to cancel regular programming to broadcast the news and Tokyo's response. In South Korea, World Cup soccer coverage continued. The difference showed a rift between allies of the United States. PAGE A6 F.B.I. Gen. Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, testified on Monday before the Senate Armed Services Committee at a field hearing here on immigrants in the military. General Pace paused several times and his voice became emotional as he spoke about his father, an Italian immigrant, who he said often worked three jobs to help his children. He said immigrants had earned 200 awards or medals in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Becky Hammon, the Liberty's only All-Star, will not play in tomorrow's All-Star Game at Madison Square Garden because of a sprained ankle incurred in Sunday's loss to the Phoenix Mercury. Indiana's Tamika Catchings, the top vote-getter, will also not play; she has Achilles' tendinitis in her left heel. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT (NYT)

An article and picture caption yesterday about the decision of President Lech Kaczynski of Poland to appoint his twin brother as the country's prime minister misspelled the given name of the brother in some copies. It is Jaroslaw, not Jaroslav. (The error was repeated in some copies in a front-page contents entry and in the News Summary.)

GINSBERG--Mildred K. of Rockaway, N.J. on Friday July 7, 2006. Wife of the late Max Ginsberg, mother of Toni Ann Gartner and Martin Ginsberg. Grandmother of Rochelle Topper, Julie LaFranco, David Ginsberg, Elizabeth Graham and David Gartner. Great grandmother of Devon, Reilly, Sarah, Jack, Samara, Jayden and Sydney. Services and interment were held on Monday.

To the Editor: While I appreciate Greg Grandin's arguments about the wisdom of supporting a recount in the Mexican election (''How to Be a Good Neighbor,'' Op-Ed, July 8), it is hilarious even to ask the Bush administration to support one -- since Bush officials relied on the quashing of a recount and United States Supreme Court intervention to get themselves into power.

To the Editor: Re ''A Star Falters, France Fades, Italy Rejoices'' (front page, July 10): I never watch sports. When the newspaper featured odds for the World Cup teams, I thought that it was a good opportunity to teach math to my 7-year-old daughter.

NATHANS--Barbara Lange. Died on June 19, 2006 at her home in Coronado, California. She was 74 years old and died of Melanoma. A weaver and bead artist, she was the wife of Robert Nathans, sister of Judy Lange Topkis, and mother of Mark, Leah, Jessie, Sam, and Amy. She was also the grandmother of nine grandchildren. Barbara was born on April 26, 1932 in Wilmington, DE. She received her BA from The University of Delaware. Barbara was an accomplished textile and bead artist. She lived in Bellport, NY, and later moved to Coronado, CA. A Memorial Service is planned for the fall. Donations may be made to The San Diego Creative Weavers Guild, or The Skin Cancer Foundation.

OVERSPENDING AT THE PENTAGON -- Lawmakers from both parties worry that runaway costs and delays threaten to weaken the military. Congress has promised to clamp down on the inefficiencies and wasteful practices, which critics and government oversight agencies say have worsened with the flood of money into military spending. [Page C1.] CHINA'S EXTRAORDINARY SURPLUS -- China reported a large trade surplus with the rest of the world, the greatest monthly trade surplus any country has ever recorded and one that is likely to heighten trade tensions, particularly with the United States and Europe. The surplus for June reached $14.5 billion. [C1.] TURNING POINT IN JAPAN -- Japan's central bank is expected to take a momentous step by raising interest rates for the first time in many years, signaling an end to stagnant growth and falling prices. almost two decades. But economists wonder if Japanese consumers will keep up their spending. [C1.] PAULSON JOINS TREASURY -- Henry M. Paulson Jr., formerly of Goldman Sachs, took over as Treasury secretary and as President Bush's top economic adviser, filling out a new economic team with a more pragmatic cast for the remainder of the administration. [C1.] INDIA HALTS PRIVATIZATION -- A decision by the Indian government to halt all sales of stakes in state-owned companies could crush investor interest because of fear that a program of economic change is becoming bogged down in politics. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, above, has said in a statement that privatization plans would be stopped, pending further review, after a coalition party threatened to withdraw crucial support. [C6.] PLAYING THE ANTI-FOX CARD -- Keith Olbermann, the host of ''Countdown With Keith Olbermann'' on MSNBC, has enjoyed an increase in ratings as he aims barbs at the competition on Fox News Channel, and particularly at Bill O'Reilly. [E1.] STOCK OPTIONS UNDER SCRUTINY -- Take-Two Interactive, maker of the Grand Theft Auto video games, said that it was the focus of an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its stock options. The company's shares fell 76 cents to close at $9.34. Separately, the Manhattan district attorney is seeking information from the company about hidden sex scenes in some video games. [C9.] THAT WORLD CUP GLOW -- Germany's public image underwent a remarkable makeover during the jubilant and well-managed World Cup. Germans, by giving a rollicking party and shedding their dour image, could help make this country a more attractive destination for tourists and for foreign investment, according to experts. [C6.] DEALING IN NOSTALGIA -- Brand-name mascots from the world of advertising, like the Sun-Maid Raisin Girl, are being made over and updated. This summer, consumers will be asked to vote on a change of attire for Mr. Peanut, from Kraft Foods. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.] TROUBLED WATERS -- Skeptical oceanographers have long doubted the existence of rogue waves, but scientists are now finding that these giants of the sea are far more common and destructive than once imagined, prompting new studies and research projects that could have implications for oil drilling. [F1.] MEDICARE HELP LINE FAULTED -- Investigators said Medicare's new prescription drug plans generally provided incomplete and inaccurate information to callers who asked questions about the drug benefit. The findings are significant because the program is supposed to help consumers make informed choices among competing plans. [A15.] ONLINE MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT -- Investors who hitched their wagons to the speculative frenzy in the first quarter were hit with reality in the second, as mutual funds took a U-turn. A report is at nytimes.com/business. POPCORN AT 30,000 FEET -- Joe Sharkey, who writes about business travel, surveys the growing movie-viewing options offered by airlines at nytimes.com/video. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE COSMETICS MAKER -- Revlon forecast a wider loss for the second quarter, hurt in part by a $40 million shortfall in a line of makeup aimed at women 50 and older. But Revlon maintained its 2006 outlook. (AP) A PRIVATE INVESTMENT FIRM said that it had taken a 5.64 percent stake in RadioShack. The firm, Hall Financial Group, said that it had amassed 7.63 million RadioShack shares, worth nearly $134 million based on Monday's closing price. Craig Hall, the founder and chief executive of Hall Financial, said that his firm intended to ''actively review and monitor RadioShack's financial and strategic direction.'' It could buy more shares or seek representation on RadioShack's board. (REUTERS) AN ELECTRIC AND GAS UTILITY, the WPS Resources Corporation, said it had agreed to buy the Peoples Energy Corporation for about $1.52 billion in a move to expand in gas distribution in the Midwest. (AP) THE EMC CORPORATION, the maker of data storage equipment, said it would fall short of its profit and revenue goals for the second quarter. (AP)

IF nine consecutive winless games and 15 of 18 aren't bad enough, the National League should be concerned about All-Star Games in the near future if Francisco Liriano, Jered Weaver, Zach Miner, Jon Lester and Justin Verlander replicate their rookie seasons. Those five pitchers have reached the All-Star Game break with a combined record of 36-6, and the American League initially had not called on any of them to be here for tonight's game. Yesterday, the league added Liriano (10-1) to its staff in place of Jos√© Contreras, who pitched Sunday and, like Tom Glavine of the N.L., would have been unavailable tonight.

DAVIDOFF--Charlotte. On July 10, with great sadness and love, the family of Charlotte Davidoff mourns her passing. Her husband Ed, daughters Andy and Carol Fassler and her beloved family and friends will love, cherish and miss her forever. Graveside services, Wednesday, 1PM at Beth-El Cemetery, Westwood, N.J.

An obituary on Friday about Ralph Ginzburg, whose obscenity and defamation cases as the publisher of Eros and Fact magazines went to the Supreme Court, referred incompletely to the damages awarded to Barry Goldwater in a defamation suit over a Fact article during his 1964 presidential campaign. Besides receiving $1 in compensatory damages, he also was awarded $75,000 in punitive damages. The obituary also misstated the name of the City College newspaper on which Mr. Ginzburg worked. It was The Ticker, not The Daily Ticker.
An Internet video posted by insurgents shows the mutilated bodies of two American soldiers abducted and killed in Iraq in June. Page A10.

An article in The Arts yesterday about a dispute over the renovation of a reading room at Harvard designed by the architect Alvar Aalto misidentified the site of another of his projects in the United States, the Mount Angel Library. It is in St. Benedict, Ore., not Salem.

Senator Joseph I. Lieberman filed paperwork with the Connecticut secretary of state yesterday that would allow him to run on a new party line if he loses the state's Democratic primary next month. The 25 people who signed petitions to create the party, called Connecticut for Lieberman, will run the drive to collect the 7,500 signatures needed to allow the senator's presence on the ballot, said Marion Steinfels, a spokeswoman for the campaign. By running with the party rather than individually, Mr. Lieberman could receive a higher place on the ballot, officials said. JENNIFER MEDINA (NYT)

MATUTINOVIC--Zeljka (Suncica). Died Sunday July 2nd, on Martha's Vineyard. She was 41. While vacationing in Martha's Vineyard, she was in a traffic accident, and was reported dead at the Martha's Vineyard Hospital shortly after. She is survived by her parents, Zeljko and Katarina Matutinovic, of Zagreb, Croatia. Zeljka, a native of Croatia, was a beloved friend to many and a highly accomplished professional. She earned a PhD degree in electrical engineering from Princeton University and had started her career at McKinsey & Co. Zeljka established a career in investment banking working at Credit Suisse First Boston, International Real Returns LLC, and most recently, Jerusalem Venture Partners. Since 2005 she had been working to build her own investment firm. Zeljka will be remembered for her sharp mind, generous heart, and the vibrant love of life. Her interests extended far beyond the business world, and included skiing, sailing and biking. She also took pleasure in opera and art. Zeljka's bright smile was matched by her warmth and infectious enthusiasm. She will be sorely missed by her family and friends. The funeral service will be held in Zagreb, Croatia on July 12th. The memorial mass will be held on Tuesday July 18th, 7pm at St. Cyril Catholic Church, at 502 West 41st Street in NYC.

FLIGHTS ARE PACKED -- If you haven't made summer travel plans yet, you could be out of luck. The summer travel season has started with airlines reporting record load factors, or the percentage of seats filled with paying customers. Here are the figures for June from the top six airlines: The load factor at United Airlines was 88.3 percent, the highest ever. The load factor at Delta Air Lines was 84.6 percent, largely driven by a 30.6 percent increase in international passengers over June 2005; on June 30, Delta's flights were 94.4 percent full -- the highest daily load factor ever, the airline said. The June load factor at US Airways was 84.3 percent, and at Northwest Airlines, it was 89.7 percent, also the highest ever. At Continental Airlines, the June figure was 84.8 percent. But at Southwest Airlines, by comparison, the load factor was a relatively roomy 73.8 percent. Meanwhile, flight delays are mounting. The 20 top domestic carriers achieved an overall on-time arrival rate of 78.3 percent in May, compared with 83.7 percent in May 2005, according to the Bureau of Transportation Statistics of the Transportation Department. At the same time, airlines have fewer employees to handle increased business. In April, domestic airlines employed 4.8 percent fewer workers than in April 2005; that means April 2006 was the 16th consecutive month that the work force was lower than in the year-ago month, the bureau said. LESS ROOM, MORE MONEY AT THE INN -- Hotel rooms are going to be harder to find and they are going to cost more this summer than last, according to PKF Hospitality Research, which says domestic hotel occupancy rates are likely to average nearly 74.1 percent, the highest level since 1997. Room rates are forecast to be up 6 percent over last summer. And forget about just dropping in unexpectedly. ''It will be tough to find a hotel room during the summer of 2006 without booking in advance,'' said R. Mark Woodworth, president of PKF Hospitality Research. TRANS-ATLANTIC BOOM -- With June load factors at 72 percent, the all-business-class carrier Eos Airlines said it was beginning a second daily flight in September from Kennedy International Airport to Stansted Airport in London. Eos, which began service last October, flies Boeing 757-200 aircraft, which typically hold 220 seats, configured with 48 premium lie-flat seats. Eos round-trip fares range from $2,950 for advance purchase to $6,500 walk-up (compared with more than $9,000 walk-up on major competitors). Reflecting the growing demand for New York-to-London service, British Airways said it was adding an eighth daily flight from Kennedy to Heathrow International Airport in December. British Air also has three daily flights serving Newark and Heathrow. BUSINESS WITH PLEASURE -- Many corporations are evidently returning to a policy that was sharply curtailed in the years after 9/11 -- allowing their traveling employees to tack a little time onto business trips for personal pleasure. According to the latest National Business Travel Monitor, 44 percent of business travelers now agree that they ''extend business trips for pleasure purposes'' whenever possible. That's up from 40 percent this time last year, according to YPB&R/Yankelovich, which publishes the monitor. NORTHWEST ELITE LANES -- Northwest has now joined several competitors and set aside special boarding lanes at departure gates for elite-status members of its WorldPerks frequent-flier program. The first-to-board lanes are also available to nonelite passengers with first class or World Business Class tickets, and to elite-status members of frequent flier programs of other airlines in the SkyTeam Alliance. COMPANION FLIERS -- Flying with a pet is, of course, infinitely more convenient on a private jet. Noting that many of its customers do take a pet along, NetJets, the leading fractional-share business jet company, has added a service giving domestic customers 24-hour telephone access for emergency or even general consultations with experts at the Matthew J. Ryan Veterinary Hospital at the University of Pennsylvania. NetJets said it flew nearly 10,000 pets on about 6,500 flights last year. Dogs and cats predominate, of course, but the pets have included a falcon, a wolf and a 250-pound kangaroo, said Maryann Aarseth, a NetJets spokeswoman. ONLINE HITS -- According to the online travel-data company Hitwise.com, these were the top 10 travel sites in May, ranked by the number of visits: MapQuest; Yahoo Maps; Expedia; Orbitz; Travelocity; Southwest Airlines; Cheap Tickets; Google Maps; Priceline; and Yahoo Travel. ET CETERA -- The most preferred hotel loyalty program in the world is Hilton HHonors, according to a survey of domestic and international travelers by Phoenix Marketing. But in the United States, Hilton HHonors shared the top-rated status with Marriott Rewards JetBlue just started more new routes: Burbank-Orlando, Fla.; Burbank-Las Vegas; and Boston-Buffalo, as well as routes from Pittsburgh to Kennedy International Airport and Pittsburgh to Boston. In September, JetBlue plans to start three new daily nonstops from Kennedy to Hobby Airport in Houston, with introductory one-way fares of $99. JOE SHARKEY

An obituary yesterday about Jack Sameth, an early director of television news, referred incorrectly to his work on the Kennedy-Nixon presidential debates in 1960. He directed ABC's coverage of one debate, not all four. The obituary also referred imprecisely to a space flight whose coverage he directed. It was the first manned space flight from Cape Canaveral, on May 5, 1961, not the first manned spaceflight, which was made by Yuri Gagarin on April 12, 1961.

The aid group Oxfam closed two of its six offices in the north of the Darfur region because of the abduction of a Sudanese staff member who has been missing for two months. Efforts to track him have been fruitless. Oxfam's regional director, Paul Smith-Lomas, said it would continue providing aid in the rest of Darfur, but he said lack of security was complicating efforts to reach three million people dependent on aid in the region. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

Dan Rather, who said on the eve of his rocky departure from CBS News last month that he was leaning toward joining a high-definition television channel called HDNet, has formally agreed to do just that, the channel's co-founder Mark Cuban said in a telephone interview yesterday. Mr. Rather, 74, will serve as host of a one-hour weekly news program, ''Dan Rather Presents,'' beginning in October, said Mr. Cuban, who is perhaps best known as owner of the Dallas Mavericks. Initially, the program will be mostly interviews, but Mr. Cuban said he hoped Mr. Rather would eventually pursue investigative reports in the vein of ''60 Minutes.'' Mr. Cuban said he was eager to draw on Mr. Rather's 44 years of experience at CBS News, and was confident that he could contribute much to HDNet, a premium service to which, he said, nearly four million viewers subscribe. ''The part I like the best is he's got something to prove,'' Mr. Cuban said. ''There's no better person to have on your side than someone with experience, access and on a mission to prove certain people wrong.'' JACQUES STEINBERG

''Sensenbrenner is a pit bull. And the Senate negotiators he's up against are wearing Milk Bone underwear.'' REPRESENTATIVE RIC KELLER on the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, who is in talks with the Senate on an immigration bill. [A16]

Breaking official secrecy, Britain will publicly announce its assessment of terrorism threat levels as of Aug. 1. John Reid, the home secretary, said the estimates were ''not an exact science'' but would follow a five-point scale replacing the current seven grades in secret assessments. In the United States, the five levels of terror risk go from green (low) to red (severe). Last year Britain lowered its secret threat-level assessment only weeks before the London bombings. ALAN COWELL (NYT)

Terrors of the Deep Q. Are submariners given any coaching on how to cope with claustrophobia? A. The United States Navy relies on careful psychological screening of submarine officers and enlisted men while they are still in training rather than on coaching. The goal is to identify those most at risk of problems and remove them from the pipeline before they face life on a sub.

Picture captions in The Arts on Thursday with an article about performances in Paris by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater misspelled the photographer's surname in the credits. He is S√©bastien Math√©, not Mah√©.

David Wright was such an underdog in the All-Star Game home run derby Monday night that his Mets teammate Cliff Floyd had teasingly predicted he would manage two homers. Wright did much better than Floyd guessed -- he almost won the event. But Ryan Howard hit a prodigious homer off the ''Hit It Here'' sign in the right-center-field bleachers for the clinching homer in the final at PNC Park. Howard, the powerful first baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, edged Wright, 5-4. Because Howard drilled the sign, a fan won 500 round-trip airline flights.
FRANCO--Herzl J. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to his family. Peter Neustadter, Parnas

Beyond the Rocks Rudolph Valentino has the bad luck to be remembered for his worst performance. Clips from ''The Sheik,'' directed by George Melford in 1921, seem to turn up in every documentary on silent filmmaking. When Valentino, playing an Arab chieftain, approaches the helpless British socialite (Agnes Ayres) he has stolen away to his desert caravan, his eyeballs-bulging, nostrils-flaring pantomime confirms what most people have come to think of silent cinema: that it was crude, wildly melodramatic and hopelessly na√Øve.

A front-page article on Friday about a decision by the New York State Court of Appeals that rejected any right to same-sex marriage misstated the number of years Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye has served on the court. It is 23, not 13. (She has been chief judge for 13 years.)

To the Editor: ''Jump-Start a Heart: The Simplified Approach'' (Personal Health, July 4) is somewhat misleading about the impact of resuscitation on outcome and survival. Even under the best of circumstances, survival rates are still quoted (generously) as being less than 15 percent.

BASEBALL FOX AND M.L.B. RENEW CONTRACT -- Major League Baseball and Fox Sports will announce today a seven-year renewal of their contract, which would have Fox retain the Saturday game of the week, the All-Star Game and the World Series. But Fox is likely to keep the rights to only one League Championship Series, according to executives who are familiar with the terms of the negotiations but were granted anonymity because the contracts had not been signed.

A picture caption on Sunday about a Roman Catholic priest in Darien, Conn., who is under federal investigation in connection with allegations that he misused church funds, misspelled his surname at one point in some copies. He is the Rev. Michael Jude Fay, not Faye.

A sports article on Sunday about the progress Greg Biffle has made as a Nascar driver misidentified the winner of the 2005 Nextel Cup. It was Tony Stewart, not Jimmie Johnson. (Biffle placed second; Johnson was fifth.)
LODISPOTO--William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Vera Lobiano, associated with The Times since June, 1958 until retiring in December 1984.

Three Russian passenger planes made emergency landings after suffering malfunctions one day after a jet burst into flames in Siberia after crashing during a landing. No one died in the new incidents, but three people were injured when their Tu-134, carrying the navy chief of staff, Vladimir Masorin, caught fire after it overran the runway at a military base in the Crimea region of Ukraine. An Airbus A-310 operated by S7 Airlines made an emergency landing in Ukraine after an engine malfunctioned, and a Urals Airlines Tu-154 flight from Yekaterinburg landed in Irkutsk after one of its engines broke down. On Sunday, an S7 A-310 crashed in Irkutsk; 124 people died and 4 were missing. C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

GOLDSMITH--Jim. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jim Goldsmith, beloved son of Carol and Philip Goldsmith, cherished friends of the New York Jewish community whose commitment and support strengthens our ability to serve those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to Carol and Phil, and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

The newest technology in Lasik surgery, commonly called custom Lasik, provides additional accuracy and personalization to the eye correction procedure. Wavescan technology creates a ''fingerprint'' of the patient's vision, precise enough to capture subtle anomalies in each eye. A guided laser can cut a thinner, more uniform flap, while a corrective laser with variable size beams can reshape the cornea with increased accuracy, keeping on target even as the eye moves. But as with all corrective surgeries, complications can arise. GRAHAM ROBERTS

On a recent Saturday afternoon in Harlem, a bus stopped at 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, dropping off dozens of tourists at what is perhaps the world's most famous asphalt arena. Gregory Marius, the chief executive of the Entertainers Basketball Classic, was soon holding court at Rucker Park, regaling visitors with stories of the great games and colorful names that have filled his summer tournament the past 25 years.

The Spiegeltent is coming! (All together now: ''The what?'') A Spiegeltent is a huge, elaborately decorated tent made of mirrors, cut glass, velvet and brocade, and is essentially a transportable 320-seat concert hall. Ross Mollison, who produced ''Slava's Snowshow'' off Broadway, and Vallejo Gantner, the artistic director of Performance Space 122, are bringing one of the tents to New York. This tent, built in Belgium in 1926, is one of the original Spiegeltents. (A modern Spiegeltent is on display at the SummerScape Festival at Bard College.) It will be assembled at the site of the former Fulton Fish Market and will open on Aug. 3 as the site of a series of concerts until Oct. 1. Performers will range from Absinthe, a combination vaudeville, cabaret and circus sideshow, to the satirist Reverend Billy to musicians, including Duncan Sheik, Menlo Park and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band. Next door will be a well-stocked beer garden. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

A report in the Around the Majors column in Sports on Sunday, about concerts the singer Bob Dylan plans to give at minor league baseball stadiums this summer, misidentified the location of Fifth Third Ballpark, the site of his Aug. 12 concert. It is in Comstock Park, Mich., not Comstock.

BOGEN--Irving, 90, of Manhattan died Thursday July 6th, 2006 after a long illness. A free lance commercial artist and master calligrapher, his art work for Random House, Delacorte, Knopf, and many others graced the covers of many first editions, including Truman Capote's ''In Cold Blood''. He is survived by his wife, Evelyn; his sister and brother-in-law Pearl and Sol Parnell; three nephews, Peter Parnell, Bobby Sandler and John Sandler and his grandniece Lucy Sandler.

The Tata Group, one of India's largest industrial conglomerates, said it was suspending its proposed $3 billion investment in Bangladesh because of government delays. The group had planned to build steel, coal, fertilizer and power plants in Bangladesh, but wanted government approval by the end of June. Upcoming elections, however, have delayed any decisions on the plants. The company had offered the government a 10 percent stake in each of the projects if the proposals were approved by June. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

HOMAN--Valerie Ross. The Psychoanalytic Association of the Westchester Center mourns the loss of our friend and colleague, Valerie Ross Homan. Valerie was a life long learner and ready volunteer. She and her husband, William Homan, M.D., who died with her, founded the White Plains Bariatric Surgery Program, performing the first weight loss surgery at White Plains Hospital in 1999. Valerie was Clinical Coordinator and emphasized the centrality of psychoanalytic theory to understanding morbid obesity. She was also Assistant Professor of Social Work and Field Education Coordinator at Mercy College. Valerie graduated the Psychoanalytic Program of WCSPP in 1999. She held Master's Degrees in Psychology from LIU and in Clinical Social Work from Columbia. Formerly, she was Program Supervisor in the Child Sexual Abuse Treatment Center of WJCS and a Psychiatric Social Worker at NY Hospital. We will miss deeply her generous contributions. The Psychanalytic Association of the Westchester Center, Inc. $(6$)HOMAN--Valerie Ross. The faculty, graduates, candidates and staff of the Westchester Center for the Study of Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy mourn the untimely death of our esteemed colleague and friend. She will be deeply missed. Diane Girdwoyn Caspe, Director

An obituary and headline on Friday about Theodore Levitt, a marketing scholar at the Harvard Business School, referred incorrectly to the origin of the word globalization. While Mr. Levitt's work was closely associated with the idea of globalization in economics, and while he published a respected paper in 1983 popularizing the term, he did not coin the word. (It was in use at least as early as 1944 in other senses and was used by others in discussing economics at least as early as 1981.)
NUTKIS--Pearl July 8th, 2006. Wife of the late Martin Nutkis, Beloved mother, mother in-law, grandmother, sister and friend.

Royal Opera Welcomes A Slimmer Deborah Voigt Deborah Voigt and the Royal Opera House have kissed and made up, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Voigt, right, was dismissed in 2004 when the London opera house decided that given the director's choice of a black evening dress as a costume, someone slimmer would be more suitable in her signature role, Ariadne in Richard Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos.'' Subsequently Ms. Voigt, a soprano, underwent gastric bypass surgery and lost 135 pounds. Yesterday a Royal Opera spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity because the house does not officially announce casts so far in advance, said Ms. Voigt had a contract to return in the 2007-8 season. Her spokesman, Albert Imperato, said, ''She's very, very excited.'' Judge Orders Takeover Of Death Row Records A federal bankruptcy judge has ordered a takeover of Death Row Records in the latest round of legal proceedings surrounding the rap impresario Marion (Suge) Knight, below, The Associated Press reported. Saying that the label had suffered gross mismanagement, Judge Ellen Carroll ordered a bankruptcy trustee to step in. ''It seems apparent there is no one at the helm,'' she said. Mr. Knight was not present at the hearing in Los Angeles, and a message left for his lawyer was not immediately returned. In April, Mr. Knight filed for bankruptcy protection for himself and Death Row. He has claimed debts of more than $100 million. His bankruptcy petition was an outgrowth of the $107 million civil court judgment won last year by Lydia Harris, who said she had been cheated out of a 50 percent stake in the label, which represented Snoop Dogg and Tupac Shakur. Chris Daughtry Signs Recording Deal Chris Daughtry, below, a fan favorite though a fourth-place finisher this year in the fifth season of ''American Idol'' on Fox, has signed with 19 Recordings/RCA Records. An announcement said Mr. Daughtry had formed a band and begun to work with collaborators to record songs written by him and others. Release of his album is expected later this year. The same label recently signed Katharine McPhee, who lost out to Taylor Hicks in the ''American Idol'' finale. First McCartney Guitar To Be Sold at Auction A Rex acoustic guitar on which Paul McCartney learned his first chords is expected to fetch more than $185,000 when it is auctioned at Abbey Road Studios in London on July 28, the BBC reported. The instrument was owned by Sir Paul's Liverpool friend and schoolmate Ian James, now 64, who is selling it to help finance his retirement. The guitar, to be sold at a Cooper Owen's Music Legends auction, is accompanied by a letter of authenticity from Sir Paul saying, ''The above guitar belonging to my old school pal Ian James was the first guitar I ever held.'' In ''The Beatles,'' a biography by Hunter Davies, Sir Paul describes playing the guitar when he persuaded John Lennon, who was 16 and appearing with the Quarrymen at an event at a church in Liverpool, to let him join the band. The lot includes a photograph of Sir Paul playing it in his office this year. Appeal Is Planned In 'Da Vinci Code' Case Court officials say two historians who lost a plagiarism case against the British publishers of Dan Brown's best seller ''The Da Vinci Code'' plan to appeal the verdict, Reuters reported. The officials said the appeal could take place later this year, but no specific date has been set. Random House U.K., which won the copyright case earlier this year at the High Court in London, expressed disappointment at the decision by Michael Baigent and Richard Leigh, two of the three authors of ''Holy Blood, Holy Grail,'' to appeal. ''We have the utmost respect for the British legal system and acknowledge Baigent and Leigh's right to appeal the ruling,'' a Random House spokesman said. ''We regret, however, that more time and money is being spent trying to establish a case that was so comprehensively defeated in the High Court.'' No 'Pirates' Treasure In China Movie Theaters At least for now, not much gold (or yuan) will be spilling out of ''Dead Man's Chest'' in China. State news media said yesterday that scenes of cannibalism in the latest installment of ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' have prompted China's censors to keep the hit film out of theaters, Agence France-Presse reported. The Shanghai Daily reported that the censors reached their decision after watching frames showing people eating human flesh. ''The movie didn't get the approval from the state authority,'' the newspaper was told by an official of Shanghai United Cinema Lines, a theater chain. China does not have a movie-rating system, but the government will often suggest cutting scenes of violence or sex before permitting distribution. Ancient Greek Find Greek archaeologists have reported finding the ''intact and richly adorned'' torso of a statue of the goddess Artemis, right, that dates to the first century B.C., Agence France-Presse reported. ''It is a very important find and the most beautiful feminine statue found in Thessalia,'' said Athanassios Tzafalias, leader of the search team. He said the 31-inch torso was part of a statue measuring more than five feet and held out hope of finding other parts

SCOTT--Harold Joseph. Of Scarsdale, NY, passed away on July 8, 2006, at 79 years old. Mr. Scott was born on December 19, 1927, in New York, New York to the late Harold Bertram and Mary Cornella Scott. Harry served in the U.S. Army and was a graduate of St. John's University. In the late sixties he joined the Reader's Digest in marketing where he played a key role in developing fiscal year forecasting and long range planning models. He had developed a forecast book for marketing analyses, an innovation which spread to all divisions and then to the Digest international companies. He represented the company in the early days of the Audit Bureau of circulatiion magazine advisory committee. In 1985 Mr. Scott became vice president of Administrative Services, a position he held until he retired in 1992. He was responsible for all new building, expansions, renovations, security and food services in the main Pleasantville location and all New York City offices. Mr. Scott is survived by his loving wife of 49 years Margaret (Peggy) Horan. He is also the brother of Jack and Mary Ellen Bennett. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11 A.M. Immaculate Heart of Mary Church Scarsdale. Interment Holy Mount Cemetery Eastchester. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Reposing at Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY 10583, 914-725-1137.

India's attempt to launch a communications satellite failed when the rocket carrying the satellite exploded. Television images showed the rocket lifting off from Sriharikota Space Center, in eastern Andhra Pradesh, and bursting into flames seconds later, destroying the Insat 4C satellite. ''There seems to be a mishap in the first stage of the launch,'' the director of the Indian Space Research Organization, G. Madhavan Nair, told reporters. Insat 4C was the first satellite launched from India and was expected to increase capacity for direct-to-home satellite television services, weather imaging and satellite imagery. The launching failure came just a day after the test-firing of India's longest-range nuclear-capable ballistic missile also ended in failure. Space scientists said that work had already begun on another communications satellite in the Insat 4 series, and that it would be launched within a year from Kourou, in French Guyana. SARITHA RAI (NYT)
