To the Editor: Re ''When Genocide Worsens'' (column, July 9): We just returned from Darfur and can attest that Nicholas D. Kristof's assessment of the situation as becoming more volatile and unstable since the signing of the May peace agreement is true.

A decade or so ago, when the revolution in genetics was getting under way, the air was heady with promises. Gene tests, scientists predicted, would become an integral part of drug prescribing. No longer would patients find out too late that a drug did not work for them. No longer would they have to wait to see if they had side effects to one drug before switching to another.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Explosion Kills Leader Of Chechen Terror Group Shamil Basayev, the Chechen rebel who organized the deadliest terrorist attacks against Russia, was killed in a special operation that began by tracking shipments of weapons and explosives from abroad, Russian officials said. A1 Iraqi Governs Despite Threats Mamoon Sami Rashid, who has survived 29 assassination attempts since joining the provincial government in January 2005, stands as the measure of both the tenacity and the weakness of the American-backed government in Anbar Province, the tumultuous area west of Baghdad. A1 Two bombings in a Shiite enclave killed at least 10 people and wounded dozens, and gunmen executed seven civilians in a bus in a Sunni Arab neighborhood. A10 Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said proceeds from the rampant narcotics trade in Central Asia were fueling the insurgency in Afghanistan. Mr. Rumsfeld arrived in Kabul, the Afghan capital, for talks with President Hamid Karzai. A10 Missiles Divide Seoul and Tokyo North Korea's recent missile tests have underscored how much the issue has set South Korea and Japan heading in opposite directions, making it harder for Washington to achieve foreign policy goals like United Nations sanctions against the North. A6 Milosevic Aides' Trial Begins Four months after the death of Slobodan Milosevic, the trial of six of his top aides has opened, beginning a process that may finally render a verdict on Serbia's actions during the 1999 war in Kosovo. A3 NATIONAL A12-16 Identity Theft Increase Linked to Meth Epidemic Law enforcement officials in Denver find methamphetamine users have become the face of identity theft. The rise of meth has been accompanied by a specific set of crimes and skills shared among users. A1 Seizure of Records Upheld A federal judge ruled that the seizure of records by the F.B.I. from the office of Representative William J. Jefferson was legal. A12 Debate Over Guant√°namo The military's senior lawyers found their objections brushed aside when the Bush administration formulated plans for military commissions at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba. This week, their concerns will get a public hearing as Congress takes up the question of resurrecting the tribunals. A14 Gay Marriage Challenge Massachusetts, the only state in which same-sex marriage is legal, is bracing for a battle. Legislators will consider a proposed amendment to define marriage as solely between a man and a woman. A12 Medicare Plan Faulted Federal investigators said Medicare's prescription drug plans provided incomplete and inaccurate information. The findings are significant because the premise of the new program is that consumers will make informed choices. A15 Legality of Law Challenged Lawyers for the government and a leading public interest group squared off in a court case hinging on how a bill becomes a law. The case stems from a federal lawsuit which seeks to challenge the legality of the Deficit Reduction Act. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Gas Explosion Levels East Side Town House A thunderous blast destroyed a four-story town house on the Upper East Side, and law enforcement officials said they were investigating whether it was a bizarre last chapter in a divorce battle over who would end up owning the building. Four people walking along the street outside and 10 firefighters were injured. A1 Dr. Nicholas Bartha, ashen, burned and barely conscious, was pulled from the ruins of his home after it was obliterated. But even before the fires were extinguished, the police began focusing on him as the person who most likely sparked the blast. A1 Triborough Bridge Turns 70 The Triborough opened 70 years ago today, and the anniversary is prompting a reappraisal of Robert Moses, who, although he never learned to drive, rolled out a concrete carpet to the suburbs that changed the face of New York. B6 Assemblywoman Is Indicted Diane M. Gordon, a Democrat from Brooklyn, was charged with conspiracy and receiving bribes, accused of having sought a $500,000 home from a developer in return for helping the builder acquire city land. B1 ARTS E1-10 Getty to Return Two Antiquities After months of international scrutiny of its collection of Greek and Roman antiquities, the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles announced that it had agreed to relinquish ownership of two of four rare ancient works that the government of Greece says were illegally removed from within its borders. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 New Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. took over as Treasury secretary and as President Bush's top economic adviser, filling out a new economic team with a more pragmatic cast for the final two and a half years of the administration. C1 Cost Overruns in the Military Members of Congress from both parties are concerned that runaway costs at the Pentagon threaten to weaken the armed forces as higher price tags mean that fewer weapons can be built. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A18-19 Editorials: Another mission ''accomplished''; death of a terrorist; ex-prisoners and port security; hawking Sparrow. Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof. THE CLAIM -- Your diet can bring on an acne outbreak. THE FACTS -- Despite what parents everywhere have long insisted, most people know by now that chocolate and greasy foods will not cause acne. But can other foods? According to dermatologists, what largely determines whether a person develops acne are genetics and hormonal fluctuations, hence the tendency for it to occur during puberty, pregnancy and menopause.

The coming French Grand Prix weekend is very special. The circuit and teams are all making a thing out of the fact that it is the centennial of the first ever Grand Prix race, which took place in France, and which I mentioned in a little more detail in an earlier post. I will make note of the unusual things that happen on this very special weekend as they happen, but I also wanted to do my part toward celebrating the importance of the homeland of Grand Prix racing.

Publishing and trade-show outfit Penton Media has put itself on the block, calling on investment banks Allen & Company and Credit Suisse Securities to advise it on "strategic alternatives" including a possible sale, the company said.

Have Bush administration critics finally won the war on torture? Andrew Sullivan calls the Pentagon memo ordering that detainees be treated in compliance with the Geneva Conventions "a great moment in a war we can now fight as honorably as the United States has fought every other war since the Geneva protocols were instituted." Sullivan adds, "As far as the military is concerned, America is America again. And this president's brutality has been reined in."
Skype is offering free calls from your Mac or PC to traditional landlines and cellphones in the U.K., Mexico or Japan.
Deutsche Bank said on Wednesday it had agreed to acquire MortgageIT Holdings for $429 million, to expand in home loans and packaging them into bonds for investors.

A company that brings television shows to mobile phones and other portable gadgets said Wednesday that it has scored a $70 million investment from venture firms led Oak Investment Partners. PaidContent calls MobiTV's third-round financing "possibly the biggest mobile content funding to date" and quoted MobiTV's interim chief financial officer as saying the money was for expansion.
Anyone who is following Eliot Spitzer's campaign for governor knows that he says his top priorities in office would be:

Private equity giant Carlyle Group said Wednesday it has raised 216 billion yen ($1.9 billion) -- more than double the amount originally expected -- for its latest Japan buyout fund, a result that underlines the resurgence of investor interest in the nation's economy.

The British publisher Daily Mail & General Trust said on Wednesday it had acquired three online businesses that specialize in autos and job searches for an initial consideration of 12.3 million pounds ($22.71 million).

Robert Novak breaks his semi-silence on the Plame Affair in his Chicago Sun-Times column. National Review's Byron York notes that Novak could be more forthcoming. "The cut-to-the-chase question in the new Robert Novak column on his reporting in the C.I.A. leak matter: Does Novak reveal the name of his original source? And the answer is no."
The Entergy Corporation, the nuclear power operator, said on Wednesday it had agreed to buy a 798-megawatt nuclear plant from a subsidiary of the CMS Energy Corporation for $380 million.

The London Stock Exchange reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter revenue driven by record trading volumes on the exchange's electronic order book and growth in the number of terminals taking exchange data.

Repsol, the Spanish oil company, agreed to buy a stake in a Gulf of Mexico oil field from BP for 1.7 billion euros ($2.2 billion) to diversify away from Latin America, where it faces growing resource nationalism.
New tissue-paper-thin nylon tops that can wad into the palm of a hand or fit in a pocket or fanny pack.

Deutsche Asset Management has hired Clayton Coplestone as head of distribution for Greater China and Hong Kong country head. He will be responsible for expanding the distribution of DeAM's global and regional products to both retail and institutional investors, as well as building and managing the Hong Kong operation.
Eurotunnel, the British-French tunnel operator, said that it sought protection in a French court as it pursued talks to avert bankruptcy because of $11.5 billion in debts.
Executives at Google have reaped eye-popping sums from selling some stock holdings. But they're not bailing out-just getting rich.

Alan Lacy will step down as Sears Holdings' vice chairman on July 29, 10 months after he was replaced as chief executive officer of the nation's third-largest retailer. Lacy also is resigning from the boards of directors of Sears Holdings and Sears Canada.

Legal filings related to former Enron Chairman Ken Lay have come to a standstill since his death last week, but the paperwork regarding former C.E.O. Jeff Skilling and others continues to fly.

In one of the biggest Texas-based venture capital deals of the year so far, on-demand software testing and virtualization company Surgient has raised a $20 million Series C round of funding to expand its sales and marketing both in the U.S. and Europe.

Intersouth Partners has continued its financial support of Florida software firm CallMiner by joining a handful of other investors in a $10 million series B venture capital round. The Durham, N.C.-based venture capital firm also took part in CallMiner's $2.8 million series A round two years ago.
Yodlee, once a high-flying Internet company during the dot-com boom days, has added $6 million in Series AA recapitalization financing as it broadens its online financial services business.

The amount of money raised by companies floating on the London Stock Exchange soared by 64 percent in the first six months of this year to 10.4 billion pounds ($19.1 billion) as equity markets boomed.

Andrx shareholders may have voted to allow Watson Pharmaceuticals to buy the company for about $1.9 billion. But the closing for the $25-a-share cash deal has been postponed, in part because regulators are taking a detailed look at the combination of the two drug makers.

State spending under the budget deal agreed to by Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature last month will grow by about 10 percent, roughly three times the rate of inflation, the state comptroller, Alan Hevesi, reported yesterday. Mr. Hevesi said his review of the final budget deal, based on preliminary figures, indicated that state spending would grow twice as fast as revenue. “This is not sustainable for the long term,” he said.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, working with Citigroup and MasterCard, began a six-month experiment yesterday that will allow subway riders to use specialized bank cards or payment tags instead of MetroCards. The test, paid for by the two financial service companies, is taking place in 30 stations on the Lexington Avenue line between 138th Street in the Bronx and Borough Hall in Brooklyn. At the stations, customers can tap or wave their Citi credit cards, MasterCard debit cards or bank-issued payment tags to gain entry through specially equipped turnstiles. The test is intended to “evaluate the potential of contactless payments to simplify fare payment for customers,” said Peter S. Kalikow, the authority’s chairman.

A leader of a heroin ring that federal prosecutors said was linked to the Taliban pleaded guilty yesterday to drug charges in Federal District Court. The defendant, Baz Mohammad, was the first heroin kingpin extradited from Afghanistan to the United States, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. According to the indictment, Mr. Mohammad, who lived in Karachi, Pakistan, led the organization since 1990. The group provided financial support to the Taliban from 1994 to 2000, Mr. Garcia said, adding that Mr. Mohammad had told followers that smuggling heroin to the United States was a form of jihad.
New ratings from Nielsen will show how many people are actually watching commercials, not just programs.

A Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 20 years in prison for repeatedly stabbing his aunt and setting her house on fire in December, prosecutors said. The man, Anthony Copeland, 37, pleaded guilty to attempted murder and arson last month, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Copeland, who was on parole at the time, attacked his aunt, Betty Pressley Bethel, after he learned that she was planning to sell her house on Sanders Place in Jamaica.

The Bergen County prosecutor said yesterday that a failing business venture and financial concerns might have led a man to shoot and kill his two sons early Monday before turning the gun on himself. The man, Thomas J. Frazza, 46, of Washington Township, was found in the basement of his house by relatives. His two sons, John, 20, and Kevin, 14, were each found dead in their beds, said John L. Molinelli, the county prosecutor. Mr. Molinelli said that Mr. Frazza might have been under the influence of drugs or medication and that toxicology tests were being conducted. Mr. Frazza’s wife and 19-year-old daughter were in Brigantine.
The Pataki administration moved to make up for some of the millions of dollars New York City and Buffalo lost in federal antiterror money.

A man who spent 18 years in prison on a rape charge walked out of court yesterday a free man, exonerated by DNA evidence. The man, James Calvin Tillman, 44, of Hartford, had been imprisoned since his arrest in 1988. He was sentenced a year later to 45 years in prison. Judge Thomas Miano of State Superior Court dismissed charges against Mr. Tillman, left, and said the case demonstrated the need for the police and prosecutors to take steps to avoid wrongful convictions. Mr. Tillman maintained his innocence and rejected a plea bargain that would have resulted in an eight-year sentence. Recent DNA tests proved that his genetic profile did not match a sample taken after the attack.
A proposal, approved 68 to 32, would create a loophole, applying only to drugs from Canada, in a ban on importing prescription medicine.

Japanese leaders raised what Seoul considers a chilling scenario: a pre-emptive strike on North Korea that would violate Japan‚Äôs Constitution.

A federal judge in Charleston approved a $1.6 million class-action settlement to compensate students who were searched in a 2003 drug raid at a high school. The judge, Patrick Michael Duffy of Federal District Court, approved the settlement Monday in a lawsuit filed against the Berkeley County School District and the Goose Creek Police Department by students‚Äô families. Surveillance videotapes captured the raid at the school, Stratford High, in which officers drew their guns, ordered students to lie on the floor and used a dog to search them for drugs. No drugs were found, and no arrests were made.
Women who smoke cigarettes run twice the risk of lung cancer as men who smoke but are far less likely to die from the disease than men, according to a study.

Flood damage at the headquarters of the Internal Revenue Service will take six months to repair completely, the agency said. The lower level of the headquarters building was flooded during heavy rains last month, which ruined the building‚Äôs heating, air-conditioning and electrical systems. Taxpayers should notice no change in operations, the agency said, because its computers and employees work at sites around the country.

A judge on Monday struck down part of an Alaska law criminalizing possession of small amounts of marijuana, saying it conflicted with past decisions by the Alaska Supreme Court. Under the ruling, people can possess less than an ounce of marijuana in their homes. The judge, Patricia A. Collins of Superior Court, granted a summary judgment to the American Civil Liberties Union of Alaska, which sued when the law took effect in June.

A Chinese filmmaker detained while making a documentary on underground Christians was freed after more than five months in police custody, his sister said in an Internet posting. Wu Hao was taken away by the authorities on Feb. 22, and the police refused to give details of the charges or let his family see him. Before his release, the police had informed the filmmaker he was under ‚Äúsupervised residence,‚Äù according to a Web diary kept by his sister, Wu Na. Wu Hao lived in New York, Massachusetts and California for 12 years before returning to China in 2004 to make documentaries.

Interpol, the international police network, issued a worldwide alert to security agencies requesting help in tracking down seven fugitives who escaped from a Saudi prison on Saturday. The fugitives, six Saudis and one Yemeni, escaped from Malaz prison, near the capital, Riyadh. The incident, which follows an escape by 13 members of Al Qaeda from a prison in Yemen in February, raised concerns that Saudi security authorities had not alerted international security agencies, Interpol said.

Parliament passed a law that is intended to give Aceh Province greater autonomy under the terms of a peace accord with former separatists there. But the Free Aceh Movement, which fought for independence for nearly three decades and signed the peace accord last year, said the new law fell short of its demands, and of the provisions in the accord. ‚ÄúThe authority for the government in Aceh is not clear ‚Äî it says in the bill that the law in Aceh has to follow Indonesian law,‚Äù said Bakhtiar Abdullah, above, a spokesman for the movement. ‚ÄúIf everything has to be in with the Indonesian standard, where‚Äôs the new law?‚Äù A key to the settlement, negotiated between the sides by Martti Ahtisaari, a former president of Finland, was an understanding by the rebels that a new provincial government in Aceh would have far wider authority than in the past. The passage of the law, four months later than stipulated in the peace accord, paves the way for elections later in the year.

Foreshadowing a major environmental debate, the British government said nuclear power would make a ‚Äúsignificant contribution‚Äù to future energy needs. Nuclear power currently accounts for one-fifth of Britain‚Äôs energy, scheduled to fall by 6 percent by 2020. Alistair Darling, the trade and industry minister, told Parliament that a new generation of nuclear power stations could help reduce carbon emissions and dependence on imported energy.

Joaqu√≠n Navarro-Valls, a doctor who served for more than two decades as an aide and spokesman to Pope John Paul II, retired from the Vatican at age 69. He will be replaced by Federico Lombardi, 63, a Jesuit priest who runs the Vatican‚Äôs radio and television divisions. Mr. Navarro-Valls, a Spaniard who speaks five languages, achieved a public prominence rare for a Vatican spokesman, partly because of his suave and unflappable manner, and partly because of his closeness to a media-savvy pope.

Swastikas spray-painted in Rome‚Äôs Jewish quarter and racial comments about French athletes by a former aide sullied celebrations of Italy‚Äôs World Cup victory. Interior Minister Giuliano Amato said swastikas had been daubed on walls of the ghetto during postgame festivities. Roberto Calderoli, the former minister of reform and a member of the right-wing National Alliance Party, was criticized after saying Italy had vanquished a French team made up of ‚ÄúNegroes, Communists and Muslims.‚Äù The comments received a strong rebuke from Italian politicians and the French ambassador to Italy.
A young man was shot to death hours after the security chief for the mayor was believed to have been kidnapped, adding to a month of violent events linked to drug trafficking in Acapulco.

A Croatian journalist went on trial on charges of publishing the name and the testimony of a protected witness more than five years ago. The war crimes tribunal in The Hague is holding the journalist, Josip Jovic, in contempt because as editor of Slobodna Dalmacija, a Croatian newspaper, he published the secret testimony of a witness despite orders from the court telling him to stop. Mr. Jovic argued that the United Nations tribunal had no jurisdiction in the matter and continued publication. If found guilty, he could face a fine or prison sentence.

The Financial Times plans to merge its newspaper and Web desks, a move that could lead to the layoffs of about 50 staff members.
Beacon Capital Partners has acquired a billion-dollar Manhattan office tower and the tallest office building in White Plains.
The Veterans Affairs analyst who lost information on 26.5 million veterans showed poor judgment, but his supervisors are also to blame, investigators said.
By Bloomberg News.
By The Associated Press.
A study found that in the highest income groups, young men of all races were slightly more likely than women to be in college.

ATLANTA, July 11 (AP) ‚Äî A federal grand jury indicted three people on Tuesday on a charge that they conspired to try to sell Coca-Cola trade secrets to PepsiCo and were willing to give the information to the ‚Äúhighest bidder.‚Äù.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts yesterday about a decision by the J. Paul Getty Museum to return two rare ancient works to Greece, including a grave marker that was bought from the Safani Gallery in Manhattan, carried an outdated reference to the owner Alan Safani, who was asked to comment on his gallery‚Äôs role in buying the marker in Europe in the late 1980‚Äôs. Although Mr. Safani did not return calls before the section went to press, he did respond later Monday evening, telling a reporter that his father, who ran the gallery at the time of the sale in 1993, had followed proper procedures in buying and importing the marker. He said his father had no information at the time he sold the stele to Getty that it might have been illegally removed from Greece. A version of the article on The Times‚Äôs Web site was updated early Monday evening to include his comments.
The protests against Vladimir Putin's rule and Kremlin attempts to suppress them were ignored by Russian media.
The Delphi Corporation, the auto parts supplier now in bankruptcy protection, reported an $828 million net loss for its fourth quarter.
Old Navy is working to regain its reputation for trendy and inexpensive clothes after customers complained the store was offering too many basics.
By Reuters.
The winner for the second time in this 93rd Tour de France was Oscar Freire, a Spaniard with Rabobank, who finished ahead of Robbie McEwen, an Australian with Davitamon, who has won three stages.
Catherine Leroy's stark images of battle helped tell the story of Vietnam in Life magazine and other publications.

CLEVELAND, July 11 (AP) ‚Äî The National City Corporation, a Midwestern bank holding company, said Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire Harbor Florida Bancshares for $1.1 billion in stock to establish its first retail presence in Florida.
With parliamentary debate in Ukraine reduced to insults and fistfights, supporters called for President Viktor A. Yushchenko to dissolve Parliament.
President Bush is coming to the seaside town where German Chancellor Angela Merkel began her political career, and locals' feelings are mixed.
The investment banking arm of Giuliani Partners is expected to announce an alliance with French and German firms.
The federal Liberty Bonds program, which critics say has benefited developers and high-profile corporations, is almost depleted.
Dorothy Uhnak, once famous as a 125-pound New York City Transit Authority policewoman, was the author of best-selling crime novels.
Dr. Fred J. Epstein was a pioneer in using new ways to remove tumors once thought to be incurable.
The subpoena was an attempt to force the president of the College Board to disclose a report on scoring errors involving more than 5,000 SAT exams last October.

Apple Computer said its vice president for marketing in Japan, Yoshiaki Sakito, one of the company’s top executives in Japan, had stepped down. Mr. Sakito resigned Monday after he and Apple reached an agreement, the company said, but declined to give details. Mr. Sakito has been credited with leading a successful marketing push for Apple’s iPod portable digital music player in Japan. Phil Schiller, above, the senior vice president overseeing worldwide marketing at Apple, will be the interim successor to Mr. Sakito .
The Swiss mining conglomerate Xstrata intensified the fight for Falconbridge, Canada‚Äôs second-largest nickel-mining company.

General Electric said it had agreed to sell its electrical products distributor, GE Supply, to a French electrical supplies distributor, Rexel, for $725 million. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter, and is part of G.E.’s strategy to focus on higher-return business segments. G.E. plans to use proceeds from the sale to reinvest in core operations and pay for restructuring. G.E. Supply will continue to distribute G.E. products. GE Supply, based in Shelton, Conn., had about 2,500 employees and $2.4 billion in revenue in 2005. Rexel plans to operate GE Supply as a stand-alone company reporting to a newly created holding company.

The Swiss Reinsurance Company, the largest reinsurer in the world, will cut as many as 2,000 jobs, or 17 percent of its work force, after the purchase of the reinsurance unit of General Electric. Swiss Re, which is based in Zurich, said the reductions would affect employees in Zurich; London; Munich; Armonk, N.Y.; and Kansas City, Mo. In January, the company said the purchase of GE Insurance Solutions, based in Kansas City, would result in the loss of as many as 1,700 jobs. Swiss Re surpassed Munich Re as the largest reinsurer last month after completing the $7.4 billion purchase of the G.E. unit.

The Marks & Spencer Group, the largest clothing retailer in Britain, said sales at stores open at least a year rose for a fourth consecutive quarter as the company won back shoppers with new fashion designs, brighter stores and increased advertising. Sales rose 8.2 percent in the first quarter, which ended July 1, including gains of 11 percent for clothing and home products and 5.8 percent for food, the company said.

The LG.Philips LCD Company, one of the world’s biggest makers of liquid-crystal displays, reported that it swung to a loss in the second quarter as high inventories drove average selling prices lower. The company, based in Seoul, South Korea, said it lost 322 billion won ($340 million) in the three months ended June 30, compared with a profit of 41 billion won a year earlier. The result was slightly worse than expectations. Sales rose 0.3 percent, to 2.32 trillion won ($2.49 billion), compared with analysts’ forecast of 2.31 trillion won. The company, which makes thin-film transistor liquid-crystal displays used in flat-screen televisions and computers, is a joint venture of LG Electronics of South Korea and Philips Electronics of the Netherlands. LG.Philips, like other flat-panel display makers in Asia, suffered from sharp price declines as sales of TV’s using the technology during the World Cup soccer tournament failed to meet expectations.

Coca-Cola promoted Dan Sayre to president of its Japan unit to succeed Masahiko Uotani after first-quarter sales in the country fell 2 percent. Mr. Uotani was named to the newly created position of chairman of the Japanese division and will no longer oversee daily operations, the company said. Coca-Cola is struggling to turn around sales in Japan, where it gets 20 percent of its profits, after an advertising campaign for its Georgia brand canned coffee failed to attract younger drinkers.

Eurotunnel, the British-French tunnel operator, said that it sought protection in a French court as it pursued talks to avert bankruptcy because of £6.2 billion ($11.5 billion) in debts. Eurotunnel announced the move after hours of meetings with major creditors aimed at securing a debt restructuring plan that the Channel Tunnel operator says is essential to its survival. A spokeswoman, Mady Chabrier, said that the filing could be withdrawn if a debt restructuring agreement was reached. The chairman of Eurotunnel, Jacques Gounon, wants a deal with creditors that he can put before shareholders at a meeting in Calais on July 27. If not, he has said he plans to file for bankruptcy.
Janet Hill has an imprint at Doubleday; it‚Äôs called Harlem Moon. When she started it, people asked if she worried about being marginalized.
Disappointments from Alcoa and Lucent dragged the major indexes sharply lower before they rebounded late in the session.
Colombia wants to further cement the special relationship with a free trade agreement. It can begin by treating workers‚Äô rights as human rights.

An anguished night has fallen over Mumbai, but when the city eventually sleeps it will do so secure in the knowledge that its spirit is unbroken.

Mariano Rivera to appear at Thursday's opening of Mo's New York Grill,  Ralf Kuettel's Trestle on Tenth brings a taste of Switzerland to Chelsea and the Sullivan Street Bakery changes its name to the Grandaisy Bakery.
The 52nd Fancy Food Show was characterized more by the quality of artisanal products, both domestic and imported, than by their gimmickry.

In a few weeks, New York shops are expected to start selling the special, costly meat from the black-footed Ib√©rico pigs of Spain, including the Ib√©rico de bellota, the ones that are fattened on acorns.
Mr. Carpenter proved to be a player with extraordinarily glib fingers and Astaire-like footwork in his program of Bach and Shostakovich.
Diana Vishneva, with arms flung back like wings, legs that were even more eloquent, was the embodiment of rapture as a wonderfully willful Juliet.

Marshall Karp‚Äôs novel about someone out to bring down a Disney-like entertainment empire brings to mind Robert B. Parker, Janet Evanovich, Dean Koontz, Stuart Woods and a lot of other fast-paced authors.
In this eight-part, four-week TNT series, Mr. King serves up nightmares and grand subjects for horror.
Argentines, feeling the effects of external forces like globalization, are re-evaluating the country‚Äôs long-shunned culinary roots.
Don‚Äôt want to spend $200 and two and a half hours for dinner you reserved a month in advance? Get an affordable snapshot of what top chefs can do at these six  restaurant lounges.

An article last Wednesday about the chef Anne Quatrano of Atlanta misstated the year of the Summer Olympics there, which drew her to the city. It was 1996, not 1992.
One of Anne Quatrano's favorite childhood dishes is pan-fried pole beans, for which she uses her grandmother‚Äôs technique to excellent effect.
A recipe for Tomato Soup With Bread (Pappa al Pomodoro).

We'd call it tomato soup with bread, but in some impoverished regions of Italy, where bread was daily fare and tomatoes not always available, it was pappa al pomodoro ‚Äî ‚Äúpap,‚Äô‚Äô or mush, with tomatoes.

Five weeks after the world's major powers offered Iran economic and political rewards if it agreed to freeze important nuclear activities, Iran has neither accepted nor rejected the offer, nor even set a date for when it would respond. And it has argued that the United States and its allies have set unrealistic preconditions for talks. Indeed, when the two sides met in Brussels on Tuesday, they simply talked past each other, again dashing expectations that the incentives proposal would reinvigorate negotiations. Instead, the talks have stalled, ensuring that nothing will be accomplished before the summit meeting of industrial countries that opens this weekend in St. Petersburg, Russia.

ROGOFF--Mifa August 15, 1915 -July 9, 2006. Family and friends mourn the passing of Sulamith (Mifa) Rogoff, legendary hostess, fluent speaker of five languages, superb cook, world traveler, and champion AIDS walker. She is survived by her two daughters, Ilana and Tamar, her four grandchildren, Dawne, Heidi, Joshua, and Ariel, and two greatgrandchildren, Arlo and Lois. Her family is extended by inlaws: Richard, Bob, Claudia, Ben and Pablo. Memorial services will be held at Gramercy Park, Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave. NY, NY. Thursday, July 13th 11:30 am.

Skewers infused with herbs and spices might seem a bit gimmicky, but tasting is believing. These come in six flavors, some delivering more punch than others. Chicken seemed to benefit most from the flavorings, especially the assertive Mexican Fiesta and Indian Mango Curry. Other flavors are citrus rosemary, honey bourbon, garlic herb and a subtle Thai coconut lime. Food should be left on the skewers 15 minutes before cooking.

An obituary on July 3 about Vern Leroy Bullough, a historian of medicine and sexuality, referred imprecisely to the California and New York State universities with which he was associated. He taught at California State University in Northridge, a specific part of the state university system, not at the system in general. He was also the dean of the faculty of natural and social sciences at Buffalo State College, not at SUNY Buffalo.

FAMILANT--Aaron (Arcky). On July 10, 2006, age 85. With sadness and love, the family of Aaron Familant marks his passing. Devoted husband of the late Rosalind for over 60 years, father of Linda Meisel (Arthur) and Robert Familant (Ray Anne), proud grandfather of Seth (Anna), Micah (Rachel) & Rachel (Morgan) and Max Familant. Greatgrandfather of Zachary Meisel. Aaron Familant was a leader of the Credit Union movement for nearly 50 years as Treasurer and Board Member of Progressive Credit Union, he took the credit union from a local Bronx institution to national prominence. He also served on the Boards of Excelsior, Central, Greater New York and Empire Corporate Federal Credit Unions. He was President of the NY State Credit Union League and served as a Director to the Credit Union National Association. He was the first Credit Union professional to serve on the NY State Banking Board, having been appointed by former governor, Mario Cuomo. A life long member and officer of the Bessarabian Young Men's Benevolent Association, he never forgot and honored his heritage. He was admired by all for his integrity, loyalty and generosity. We will miss you, Poppy. Service Wednesday, July 12, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions to Rosalind ''Mimi'' Familant Fund Jewish Community Foundation of Princeton Mercer Bucks 4 Princess Road, Suite 206 Lawrenceville, NJ, 04648.

DUNSEITH--James J. of Upper Brookville on July 10, 2006. Retired Commander USNR. Retired Lt. Detective NYPD. Retired President/ Chairman Shields Asset Management Company. Beloved husband of Joan. Loving father of Leslye Diener (George), S. Michael (Trish), James (Karen), Richard (Eileen), Jerome (Ann), Maureen Hunt (John) and Jeneen Zimmermann. Cherished grandfather of 25 and great grandfather of five. Friends may call Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the family's home. Mass Friday 10AM St. Paul the Apostle RC Church, Brookville. Interment LI National Cemetery, Pinelawn. Funeral entrusted to the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Homes, Hicksville Chapel.
A theater review yesterday about ''Chekhov & Maria'' misidentified the theater where it is playing. It is the Barrow Group Theater, on West 36th Street, not the Barrow Street Theater.

An article on July 5 about an apartment building for homeless alcoholics in Seattle referred incompletely to its financing. Private sector investors, who receive federal tax credits, contributed to the cost of the building; it was not solely financed with government funds.

GANDELMAN--Beatrice. Beloved sister of Charles, Robert (Sandy), and the late Frances. Loving aunt of Richard, Jaime, Mitchell and Jeffrey. Adored great-aunt of three. Services today, 10 AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

To the Editor: Re ''At Colleges, Women Are Leaving Men in the Dust'' (''The New Gender Divide'' series, front page, July 9): Only a few decades after the women's movement, we are simply witnessing what traditionally happens when doors are opened for once-oppressed groups: they take full advantage of it. Even with young women outnumbering (and performing better than) young men in college, women continue to receive lower wages than men for the same jobs and put their careers on hold while raising families, only to suffer the consequences for doing so years later when attempting to re-enter the work force.

In 1970, Marv Levy joined George Allen's coaching staff with the Los Angeles Rams. Allen had assistants for the offensive and defensive lines, the backfield, the receivers, the linebackers and the secondary. His idea, to hire Levy to handle only the special teams, was new in the N.F.L. ''We had a burgeoning staff of seven,'' Levy, the 80-year-old former coach of the Buffalo Bills, said in a recent telephone interview. ''Now I'm saying, 'Wait, what's going on here?' ''

ZACKMAN--Dorothy. Be loved wife of the late Aaron, loving mother of Myron and Ronnie, Carol and Stan. Bubby/Bubs of Alan and Viktoria, Odin, Mitchell and Gabra. Thrilled great grandmother of Sam Aaron. Much loved by many. Service Wednesday 10:30am Gutterman's RVC.

FERBER--Arnold. Wow, what a life. A life of generosity, of adventure and exploration, of challenge and triumph and steadfast determination. Arnold was born in New York on October 29, 1920, the only child of Beatrice and Irving Feinberg. He graduated CCNY at 19, then joined the Army to serve his country in World War II. A shy young man, Arnold's magnetic personality and charisma began to emerge in his late 20's. First, an entrepreneur, then a world traveler, he circled the globe with Zelda, his wife of 57 years. And, late in life, Arnold found another love in Jackie, with whom he shared a deep sense that we are all here to nurture one another. Arnold died on July 11, 2006, leaving behind a rich legacy of love, and dedication to the principle that life is to be lived, to the fullest. Services will be held Friday, July 14, at 11:30 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St.

DRAPOS--Alex, The American Farm School mourns the untimely passing of its beloved trustee , former chairman of the Board. Alex was a devoted friend, who gave generously to the School. He will be deeply missed. A tree is being planted in his memory in the campus Olive Grove.

China and Russia introduced a draft resolution on North Korea today and asked Security Council members to consider it in place of a tougher Japanese-sponsored resolution they both object to. In offering the new measure, the Chinese ambassador, Wang Guangya, said that he had instructions from his government to veto the Japanese resolution if it were put to a vote.

Sardinia has its own assertively rustic cuisine, like the crisp shepherd's bread called pane carasau, made in big crackerlike disks. Try brushing the bread with oil and lightly toasting it, or layering it with tomato sauce and cheese to make a quick lasagnalike dish. A two-pound box from Gourmet Sardinia (gourmetsardinia.com) is $15.99, plus shipping.

Interpol, the international police network, issued a worldwide alert to security agencies requesting help in tracking down seven fugitives who escaped from a Saudi prison on Saturday. The fugitives, six Saudis and one Yemeni, escaped from Malaz prison, near the capital, Riyadh. The incident, which follows an escape by 13 members of Al Qaeda from a prison in Yemen in February, raised concerns that Saudi security authorities had not alerted international security agencies, Interpol said. HASSAN M. FATTAH (NYT)

A chart in Science Times yesterday with an article about slight shifts in the location of the misidentified the pole at one point. As noted in the article and elsewhere in the chart, it is the traditional, or rotational, North Pole -- not the magnetic pole.

Magenta-red radishes selling for $1 a bunch at the Union Square Greenmarket are easily the size of limes. Super Bunny might want to munch on them raw, but why not cook them? I cut each of 12 radishes in eighths vertically, heated two tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet and saut√©ed the pieces, turning them frequently, until they became slightly translucent and crisp-tender. Then I added four tablespoons of cr√®me fra√Æche and some salt and pepper and let them cook a few minutes longer.

9 P.M. (TNT) NIGHTMARES AND DREAMSCAPES: FROM THE STORIES OF STEPHEN KING Stephen King means to keep you up at night. This four-week event starts off with a double-header. At 9 p.m., there's William Hurt (above) in ''Battleground,'' presented commercial free: after murdering the owner of a toy company, a professional assassin receives a package of very unusual toy soldiers in the mail. Then, at 10 p.m., a couple honeymooning in Londonencounters the creepy world of ''Crouch End.'' No sweet dreams for you. 7 P.M. (Sundance) SUPER SIZE ME Morgan Spurlock gorged himself on the delectable fare available at McDonald's. This documentary, winner of the director's award at the Sundance Film Festival in 2004, might forever change the way you see fast food. Fries with that? 8 P.M. (TCM) A WOMAN OF PARIS (1923). Charlie Chaplin's foray into the world of serious filmmaking wowed some critics, but was a flop at the box office, perhaps because he didn't star in it himself. He does make a quick appearance as an unbilled extra, though: he's a porter in a railroad station. 8 P.M. (13) JEANMICHEL COUSTEAU: OCEAN ADVENTURES The first in a two-part series that looks at the current decline in the number of sharks, and how this might affect other species in the food chain. Mr. Cousteau (left) suggests that sharks might have more to fear from us than we from them. 9 P.M. (FOX) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE The six remaining couples dance tonight. But first, at 8 p.m., a rebroadcast of last Thursday's results show, when two hopefuls bit the dust. 9 P.M. (National Geographic) EXPLORER: KILLER CANE TOADS Those froggies may look innocent, but their venom can harm humans and is lethal to some animals. An army of them has spread across Australia and has wiped out much of the native wildlife. If it were France, locals would be reaching for the garlic butter. 10 P.M. (Bravo) PROJECT RUNWAY As the third season begins, a new crop of designers are vying for the chance to show their work in Bryant Park during New York City's Fashion Week. Heidi Klum (right) again heads a panel of industry luminaries and Tim Gunn will guide the contestants through their challenges. At 9 p.m. you can catch a pre-show special for a glimpse into the casting process. This season's winner will walk away with $100,000 to start a clothing line er, make that drive away Saturn is throwing in a 2007 Sky Roadster for the winner as well. STEVEN McELROY

Joaqu√≠n Navarro-Valls, a doctor who served for more than two decades as an aide and spokesman to Pope John Paul II, retired from the Vatican at age 69. He will be replaced by Federico Lombardi, 63, a Jesuit priest who runs the Vatican's radio and television divisions. Mr. Navarro-Valls, a Spaniard who speaks five languages, achieved a public prominence rare for a Vatican spokesman, partly because of his suave and unflappable manner, and partly because of his closeness to a media-savvy pope. IAN FISHER (NYT)

Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld promised Afghan officials Tuesday that the Bush administration would not lose interest in stabilizing Afghanistan, even as the United States transfers a larger combat role to NATO in coming months. At a news conference in Kabul with President Hamid Karzai at his side, Mr. Rumsfeld said the answer to questions about whether the United States would disengage from Afghanistan as NATO assumes responsibility for more missions was ''an emphatic no.''

Parliament passed a law that is intended to give Aceh Province greater autonomy under the terms of a peace accord with former separatists there. But the Free Aceh Movement, which fought for independence for nearly three decades and signed the peace accord last year, said the new law fell short of its demands, and of the provisions in the accord. ''The authority for the government in Aceh is not clear -- it says in the bill that the law in Aceh has to follow Indonesian law,'' said Bakhtiar Abdullah, above, a spokesman for the movement. ''If everything has to be in with the Indonesian standard, where's the new law?'' A key to the settlement, negotiated between the sides by Martti Ahtisaari, a former president of Finland, was an understanding by the rebels that a new provincial government in Aceh would have far wider authority than in the past. The passage of the law, four months later than stipulated in the peace accord, paves the way for elections later in the year. JANE PERLEZ (NYT)

A Classical Music entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstated the address of the Frick Collection, where the Vienna Piano Trio is to give a performance tomorrow. It is 1 East 70th Street, not 79th Street.

SEEKING TRADE DEAL FOR RUSSIA -- Russia and the United States are racing to reach a deal this week that would allow Russia into the World Trade Organization, officials from both countries said. [Page C1.] CLINTON'S HEALTH CARE CONNECTION -- As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, below, runs for re-election this year and lays the groundwork for a possible presidential bid in 2008, she is receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions from doctors, hospitals, drug manufacturers and insurers. Some of the same interests that tried to derail Mrs. Clinton's health care overhaul in the 1990's are supporting her Senate re-election bid more than a decade later. [A1.] BIOTECH COMPANIES MOVE TO U.S. -- Biotechnology companies from countries including Denmark, France, Germany, Australia and New Zealand have been moving to the United States, in name at least, for greater access to the largest investment pool for life sciences. [C1.] GLOBAL CAR -- Nanjing Automobile Group, which bought the assets of the bankrupt M.G. Rover Group last year, aims to be the first Chinese carmaker to open a factory in the United States. It plans to build a newly designed M.G. TF coupe in Oklahoma that will compete with cars like the Mazda Miata. [C1.] INTERNET GAMBLING LIMITS -- The House approved a crackdown on Internet wagering that would ban not only sports bets but also online poker and other games that have become increasingly popular. [A18.] REDUCED U.S. DEFICIT -- The Bush administration said that a big jump in tax revenues would reduce the budget deficit for this year to $296 billion, down from $318 billion in 2005. But budget analysts warned that the long-term fiscal outlook remains almost as bleak as before. [A21.] BUSH PROMOTES FISCAL MOVES -- Pointing to signs like the lower-than-expected deficit, President Bush has been working to make the case that his tax cuts have brought jobs and prosperity to Americans. [A21.] ALLIANCE FOR GIULIANI CAPITAL -- The investment banking arm of Giuliani Partners, a firm founded by former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is expected to announce that it has joined forces with two counterparts in Europe in an effort to advise on more cross-border mergers and acquisitions. [C3.] STOCKS RISE -- The Dow rose 31.22 points, to 11,134.77, after tumbling as much as 75 points earlier. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 5.18 points, to 1,272.52, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 11.93 points, to 2,128.86. [C8.] PLAN TO CUT AUDIT COSTS -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said that it expected to propose a rule aimed at curbing costs of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. [C3.] DEALS FOR BOSTON DEVELOPER -- Beacon Capital Partners, a Boston real estate company, has made two major acquisitions in the New York region: a Manhattan office tower and the tallest office building in White Plains. Square Feet. [C7.] THE POWER OF FADED DENIM -- Sales of jeans with the used, worn or beat-up look are booming on both sides of the Atlantic, making battered jeans a case study of the push and pull of global competition, and wrapping Europeans and Americans in more jeans than ever before. [C1.] NEW BID FOR MINING COMPANY -- In a move that intensifies the fight for Falconbridge, the Canadian nickel-mining company, a Swiss mining conglomerate, Xstrata, increased its cash offer to 59 Canadian dollars a share, 12 percent above its offer two months ago. The bid also puts pressure on Inco, the leading Canadian nickel producer, which has agreed in principle to buy Falconbridge in a cash-and-stock offer worth 58.36 Canadian dollars a share. [C4.] FIGHT OVER PIPELINE -- Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are clashing over a $3.5 billion pipeline project intended to deliver natural gas to the emirates from Qatar. [C8.] FINING MICROSOFT -- The European Commission is expected to fine Microsoft hundreds of millions of euros for failing to provide information to its competitors. And if Microsoft continues to withhold the information, even higher fines will be imposed, a person with knowledge of the commission's plans said. [C3.] LOUNGE LIFE -- In the lounges of many fine New York restaurants, a visitor can get a snapshot of what a chef can do and what a restaurant can be without having to pledge fidelity to the tune of two and a half hours and $200. [F1.] ONLINE INTERNET MARKETING -- The Internet has provided theater producers a new and, some say, improved set of tools to generate word of mouth. A report is at nytimes.com/theater. TALK TO THE NEWSROOM -- Michele McNally, the chief editor for photography at The Times, is taking reader questions at nytimes.com/business. A SLIDE SHOW -- Motorcycle makers are pushing scooters in a big way, with a range of sophisticated cycle-size mega-scooters that are quiet, stylish and fast. A report is at nytimes.com/autos.

The Republican chairwoman of a House subcommittee said Tuesday that the Bush administration had failed to inform Congress adequately that it was sifting through a vast international banking network in an effort to track terrorists' finances. The lawmaker, Representative Sue Kelly of New York, chairwoman of the House Financial Services subcommittee on oversight, was joined by members of both parties in accusing the administration of being too secretive and unaccountable to Congress about the program. Its existence was disclosed last month by The New York Times and other newspapers.

The Foreign Ministry confirmed that it had expelled two American diplomats for what it termed inappropriate contact with nongovernmental organizations, the first expulsion of American diplomats in a region where the United States increasingly has been struggling to maintain influence. The American Embassy said in a statement that the expulsions ''are clearly in the interest of those who would wish to harm relations between the Kyrgyz Republic and the United States.'' Relations between Kyrgyzstan and the United States have worsened since Kyrgyzstan's revolution in 2005. Since then, Kyrgyzstan's president, Kurmanbek Bakiyev, has proposed a tenfold increase to $200 million in annual payments from the American military to maintain a base in the country. ILAN GREENBERG

BRENNAN--Bernard P., Ph.D. born on April 30, 1918 of Brooklyn Heights passed away on July 11th at the age of 88. Beloved son of Margaret and Michael Brennan form County Longford in Ireland. He attended St. Teresa of Avila Grade School in Brooklyn, class of 1932 and graduated from Cathedral Seminary High School in 1936. He earned BA, Master's and Doctor of Philosophy degrees from Fordham University. Dr. Brennan was Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Pace University where he taught for over 50 years. He was a nationally recognized authority on American philosopher William James, having authored two books on the subject, William James and The Ethics of William James during his tenure at Pace. Affectionately known as 'Bernie' and'Buzz' to his many friends and large extended family, he is survived by his sisters Helen Marr (husband Luke), Frances Hurley, (husband Bob) Joan Shannon (husband Joseph) and by brother Peter Brennan (wife Anne). He was predeceased by loving brother William Brennan (wife Mildred) and sister Margaret O'Brien (husband Joe). Survived by many cousins living here and in Ireland. Buzz was a loving uncle and friend to 24 nieces and nephews and 33 grand nieces and nephews. He was a loyal neighbor and devoted friend to all who knew him in Brooklyn Heights, especially his crew at the Heights Cafe. Dr. Brennan was a supporter of many civic, community and charitable organizations throughout his life, including The Society of Old Brooklynites, The Brooklyn Bird Club, St. Teresa of Avila Alumni Association, The Brooklyn Museum, The Brooklyn Botanic Gardens and the National Audubon Society. One of his nieces said every time she hears or sees a bird she will think of Uncle Buzz. Bernie loved to spend time with family and friends, whether in Brooklyn, Califon, NJ, Roxbury, NY or on Long Island. He loved to talk, laughand eat! He was, without a doubt, everyone's favorite uncle. His generous soul and supportive spirit will be missed by all of those who were fortunate enough to have had him in their lives. Truly, may be rest in peace. Reposing at Macken Funeral Home, 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, NY. Visiting hours are 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 Wednesday and Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Agnes Cathedral, 20 Quealy Place, Rockville Centre, NY on Friday, July 14th 10 am. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens, 1000 Washington Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11225 or the Monastery of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, 361 Highland Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11207.

To the Editor: Re ''The State of New Orleans: An Update,'' by Matt Fellowes, Bruce Katz, Amy Liu and Nigel Holmes (Op-Chart, July 5): The good news is that 53 percent of the public libraries in Jefferson Parish are open, although in need of repairs and carpeting. But elsewhere in suburban New Orleans, two of Plaquemines Parish's three libraries and both of St. Bernard's libraries were destroyed. Seven of the 13 libraries in New Orleans itself are still closed.

''The Pajama Game'' will not be coming back to Broadway after all. After a sold-out run at the Roundabout's American Airlines Theater this spring -- and before winning the Tony Award for best musical revival -- several of the show's producers said that ''The Pajama Game'' would move to another Broadway theater in the fall. But Jeffrey Richards, one of the producers, said yesterday that ''there are no theater availabilities.'' Specifically, there are no open theaters next season with 1,200 or more seats, which is what the producers were seeking. Asked if there were concerns about replacing the popular leads, Kelli O'Hara and Harry Connick Jr., above, Mr. Richards said that other performers who had the producers' confidence were under consideration for both lead roles, though he declined to name them. A national tour of the show is still planned for the 2007-8 season. CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

Water, Poured An exhibition of medieval vessels called aquamanilia, for pouring water at church services and at home, will be on display through Oct. 15 at the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture, 18 West 86th Street. Called ''Lions, Dragons and Other Beasts,'' the exhibition shows the first hollow-cast vessels made in Western Europe, each with an opening for filling and another for pouring. The center is open from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. On Thursday it is open from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. It is closed on Mondays. Admission is $3 for adults, $2 for students and those 65 or older, and free on Thursdays from 5 to 8 p.m. Information: www.bgc.bard.edu/exhibit/. WORGAN--David S., Esq. Age 94 of Little Compton, RI formerly of New York City, NY died Monday, July 3, 2006 at his residence. He was the husband of the late Judge Florence M. Kelley. Born in New York City son of the late Emmanuel Worgan and the late Rose (Wein) Worgan. He was a 1929 graduate of Morris High School, a 1933 graduate of City College of CCNY with a Bachelor Degree of Science, a 1936 graduate of Columbia Law School with an L.L.B. Degree. In 1938 he began his career in the District Attorney's office in New York County, as an assistant district attorney, launching a 43 year career. For the first 17 years he moved through a succession of Bureau's, including serving as Chief of the Indictment Bureau. He conducted a wide variety of investigations and trials, including several involving Maritime crimes, naval matters being one of his great interests. In fact, he is an Associate member of the U.S. Naval Institute. In 1955 Mr. Worgan became Executive Assistant District Attorney, a position he would hold until his retirement in 1981. In that position, he controlled the machinery of the office, was the nerve center for the transmission of the District Attorney's orders and responsible for seeing to it that they were carried out. In addition, he represented the District Attorney's office in the critical area of budget hearings and in sensitive labor negotiations. He also served as acting District Attorney on a number of occasions. Throughout his career Mr. Worgan was active in the NYC Bar Association, serving on numerous committees and in particular, working in those areas dealing with the Administration of Criminal Justice. He served as well on the Appellate Division Special Committee on the Jury System. He was appointed by the Governor to the Juvenile Justice Advisory Board, to succeed District Attorney Morgenthau. Generous in sharing his experience, he appeared as a guest lecturer at the Practicing Law Institute, John Jay College and the Police Department. He was a member of the American Bar Association and was an active member of the New York City Bar Association serving as Chairman of the Admissions Committee. He was a member of the Executive Committee, Admissions Committee, Criminal Courts Committee, Nominating Committee and Special Committee to survey problems and needs of the Administration of Criminal Justice. He was also a member of the Sakonnet Yacht Club and Golf Club in Rhode Island, a member of the Board of Directors for the Friends of Sakonnet Light House. He was a former member of the Board of Directors of New York Society for the deaf, and a former member of the board of councilors for Girls Town. Surviving are one brother Seymour Barry Worgan of Deerfield Beach, FL; three nieces Susan Kelley of West Virginia, Deborah Kelley of Providence, RI, Martha Weisman of Levittown, NY; two nephews Andrew Worgan of Kings Park, NY, Nicholas M. Kelley of Brookline, MA and a sister-in-law the late Margaret Kelley and brother-inlaw the late Nicholas Kelley of Little Compton, RI. When history remembers with approval the New York County District Attorney's Office, a large measure of credit must be given to David Worgan, a fine lawyer, a loyal colleague, an outstanding public servant and a splendid gentleman. His Funeral was held on Friday, July 7, 2006 at 10:00 AM at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY. Burial was in the Mount Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, NY. For information: Waring - Sullivan Home of Memorial Tribute at Cherry Place, 178 Winter St, Fall River, MA

FOX--Professor Seymour, 77, died July 10th, in Jerusalem, Israel. Beloved husband of Sue, father of David, Eytan, Danny and family. A cherished leader in outstanding educational initiatives in the United States, Israel, and worldwide. Including his positions as: Director of camps Ramah, Dean of the Teachers Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary, Head of the Hebrew University School of Education, Director of the Melton Center for Jewish Education, founder of the Jerusalem Fellows and President of the Mandel Institute Worldwide. A dear friend, outstanding human being and great educator. He will be sorely missed. Donna and Stanley Batkin

Commissioner Bud Selig wanted to talk about the increased attendance in Major League Baseball, the boost in revenues and the marquee players who were playing in the All-Star Game on Tuesday night at PNC Park. But Selig, who is typically optimistic, was realistic enough to know he had to address other topics, too. Selig discussed those subjects, ranging from Barry Bonds to performance-enhancing substances to the next labor contract. ''There are always going to be problems,'' Selig said.

ANNE QUATRANO is one of those unpretentious chefs who don't romanticize the family tables of their childhoods. One of her grandmothers, the one who fell in love with an Italian, was a great cook. The other, the one from Ohio who fell in love with a Georgia boy, wasn't.

BEER and pizza are a natural pairing, but less so, perhaps, when the beers in question are American wheat beers made in the German hefeweizen style. Then you might say sausages or even sausage pizza. That was not the direction in which I headed. There is a small buffet at our tastings and this time among the items was a good hunk of Stilton. I was surprised at how well the salty, acidic and assertive cheese complemented the beers, with their hints of toasty spice and banana.

To the Editor: ''Gay Marriage Setback'' (editorial, July 7) called for those who support marriage fairness to move past the decision by the New York Court of Appeals and ''get energized.'' We could not agree more.

To the Editor: Bravo to Andrew Weil (''Surgery With a Side of Fries,'' Op-Ed, July 6). At a hospital I work at, Burger King was removed but was replaced by items like hash browns, ham and cheese omelets, chili cheese dogs and fried chicken.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Train Bombings in India Leave Nearly 200 Dead A string of powerful bombs ripped through a vital spine of Mumbai's commuter train system during the evening rush hour, killing 190, bringing India's financial capital to a standstill and resurrecting memories of previous bombing attacks in India and the London bombings of a year ago. A1 The explosions in Mumbai prompted heightened security in transit systems in the United States. A6 Baghdad Rocked by Violence More than 50 people were killed in Baghdad in violence that included a double suicide bombing near busy entrances to the fortified Green Zone, shootings, mortar attacks, a series of car bombs and the ambush of a bus with Shiite mourners returning from a burial. A1 Israeli Army Advances in Gaza Israeli troops moved in force into central Gaza, expanding a two-week-old Israeli offensive intended to release a captured soldier and stop rocket fire into Israel. A12 Talks With Iran Stalled Negotiations in Brussels have stalled between the world's major powers and Iran, weeks after Iran was offered economic and political rewards if it halted its nuclear program. Iran has yet to accept or reject the offer or give a timetable for any response. A12 NATIONAL A16-21 U.S. to Grant Detainees Geneva Convention Rights The White House conceded for the first time that terror suspects held by the United States had a right under international law to basic human and legal protections under the Geneva Conventions. A1 Terror Target List Criticized The inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security found that the National Asset Database, which is used to help allocate the hundreds of millions of dollars in antiterrorism grants each year, is flawed. A1 Big Dig Accident Kills Woman Huge slabs of concrete, each weighing at least three tons, fell from the ceiling of one of the Big Dig tunnels in Boston, crushing a woman to death in a car. A16 Crackdown on Online Gambling The House approved a crackdown on Internet wagering that would ban not only sports bets but also online poker and other games. A18 Immigration Deal in Colorado Colorado legislators have struck a compromise over illegal immigration law, forging a deal that Democrats and Republicans said could be the most far-reaching state overhaul in the country. A18 Leak Case Revelation Robert D. Novak, the journalist who first identified the intelligence officer at the center of the C.I.A. leak case, says in his syndicated column that six months later he voluntarily identified three sources to the prosecutor in the case, who, he says, had already learned of his conversations with each of them. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Preparing for Final Space Walk Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Discovery continued to move supplies into the International Space Station as they prepare for their third and final space walk. A18 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 Health Care Industry Contributing to Clinton Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is running for re-election to the Senate from New York and is laying the groundwork for a possible presidential bid in 2008, is receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions from the health care industry, including some of the same interests that tried to derail her health care overhaul as first lady. A1 New York's Violent Divorces The epic East 62nd Street divorce battle that apparently culminated in the explosion of a town house was bad by any standard. But in New York, divorce lawyers say they have seen comparable acts. Some say such spiraling levels of anger, rage and eventually violence are a function of New York's cumbersome divorce laws. B1 Officers Said to Aid Dealers Five police officers and one retired county sheriff's officer from several towns in Passaic County, New Jersey, were indicted on charges that they conspired to help twin brothers avoid arrest on drug charges and hide their close social relationships with the two men. The brothers were later arrested and charged with illegally selling drugs and prescription medications. B3 OBITUARIES C11-12 Syd Barrett The songwriter and singer who created the psychedelic rock of Pink Floyd but suffered a mental breakdown and left the band in 1968, he was 60. C12 Barnard Hughes A Tony and Emmy award winning character actor who was well known for playing warm-hearted if not always serious-minded father figures, he was 90. C11 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 China's U.S. Car Factory Nanjing Automobile Group, which purchased the assets of the bankrupt M.G. Rover Group, aims to be the first Chinese carmaker to open a U.S. factory. It plans to build a newly designed M.G. TF coupe in Oklahoma. C1 Biotech's Move to U.S. Increasingly, European biotechnology companies have been migrating to the United States because of a greater access to investment money. The exodus suggests that money, not molecules, could become the United States' main competitive advantage in biotechnology. C1 Strength in Faded Denim Sales of jeans with the worn or beat-up look are booming on both sides of the Atlantic, making battered jeans a case study of the push and pull of global competition. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Recognizing the power of the courts; limits of Congressional rights; a dangerous job in Colombia; Francis X. Clines on scenes from New York. Columns: Maureen Dowd, Judith Warner. Crossword: E2 TV Listings: E8 Weather: D8

To the Editor: Re ''The Age of Interruption'' (column, July 5): Thomas L. Friedman finds the recent violence between Israelis and Palestinians to be ''utterly without purpose.'' I agree. But Mr. Friedman doesn't discuss the conditions that led to the recent escalation.

WE'D call it tomato soup with bread, but in some impoverished regions of Italy, where bread was daily fare and tomatoes not always available, it was pappa al pomodoro -- ''pap,'' or mush, with tomatoes. At its most meager, it would have been stale bread, soaked in water, with whatever tomatoes and seasonings could be gathered to augment it. It's still not exactly a luxury dish, but it's become the kind of thing Italian restaurants trot out when they want to show off their authenticity. It's something you can trot out to take advantage of the beginning of tomato-and-basil season. Looked at carefully, it's quite familiar -- fresh tomato sauce over bread instead of pasta -- but the eating experience is completely different. (It's good at room temperature, which is how it is sometimes served in Italy, and it's not even bad cold, like a thick gazpacho.)

YOU don't buy a car without taking it for a spin, a pair of pants without testing the fit. But when it comes to a meal in a fancy restaurant, which can cost a lot more than slacks, you have to commit to many bites, minutes and dollars without any advance taste of how well it will suit you. Except, that is, when you don't.

Because of a production error, a front-page article on Monday about an escalation of violence in Baghdad omitted part of a sentence just before the continuation of the article in some copies. It should have read: The death toll from the shootings alone ranged from fewer than a dozen, according to the American military, to more than 40 reported by some news services.

Nate Robinson broke his nose Monday night in a summer-league game in Las Vegas but planned to play in the Knicks' final two games. Robinson was fitted with a plastic mask yesterday but started the game last night against the Detroit Pistons without it. The injury occurred late in the third quarter of the Knicks' 79-78 victory over the Sacramento Kings. A team spokesman characterized the fracture as minor. Robinson will not need surgery, and he should be fully recovered by the time the Knicks open training camp in early October.

Asbury Park, N.J., will honor the former world-record-breaking sprinter Frank Budd with a track meet named in his honor Saturday. The meet will be at Asbury Park High School, where Budd first attracted attention a half-century ago as a runner and football player. In 1962, Budd set a world record of 9.2 seconds for the 100-yard dash. He later played wide receiver and returned kickoffs for the Philadelphia Eagles and the Washington Redskins. FRANK LITSKY (NYT)

Kemal Gorgun took the shiny young branch of an apple tree in his thick hand and tried to show me what to do with it. He bent it down, then released it, explaining how I would know whether to let the shoot grow skyward or to tether it horizontally to one of the metal cords that ran the length of the green orchard. His instructions were perfectly clear except that he was speaking Turkish, and I couldnt understand a thing he was saying. No matter. My 55-year-old host just fixed me with his gentle brown eyes, grinned and spoke one of the few English words he knew: Wow!

The $25 and Under column last Wednesday, about Cafe Condesa in the West Village, misstated an ingredient in the goat cheese galette. It is flour, not potatoes. And a reference to appliances in the cafe incorrectly included a panini press. The cafe does not have one.

AS the American palate has grown more worldly, food lovers have become thrill seekers, always looking for the next big flavor. First came the excitement of chilies, as diners learned to love fiery red Sichuan dishes and the green heat of poblano and jalape√±o peppers. Now the flavor fashionsetters have moved on, to the piercing thrill of supersour. Adults sip puckery green apple martinis, and even children chew sour candy, marketed as ''extreme,'' until their eyes tear. Restaurants produce house-made pickles and ceviches with tangy, irresistible notes of lime and vinegar, and experiment with new sour flavors like Japanese yuzu, Indian green mango powder and Middle Eastern sumac.
SPRINGER--Betty B. , 70, died peacefully in her home on July 8th. Retired Executive Director of Day Care Council, New York.

The journalist who first identified the intelligence officer at the center of the C.I.A. leak case says he later voluntarily identified three sources to the prosecutor in the case, who, he says, had already learned of his conversations with each of the three. In his syndicated column being published Wednesday, the journalist, Robert D. Novak, confirms that two of his sources were Karl Rove, the senior White House adviser, and Bill Harlow, then a spokesman for the Central Intelligence Agency, both of whose roles in the case are already widely known. Mr. Novak does not disclose his primary source, saying this official has not come forward publicly.

I ducked under the rolled-up doorway of the Arghand women's area, screened from the rest of the compound with woven rush mats. It was the third week in May. Ten miles outside Kandahar, open battle was raging between the resurgent Taliban and government and coalition forces - an unthinkable development just months earlier.

It appears as though some of Joe Lieberman's supporters have had enough of all the rough treatment the Connecticut senator has been getting from left-of-center bloggers during the state's Democratic primary campaign: They've launched their own blog, LieberDem, as a counterweight. Among the contributors is Dan Gerstein, a former senior aide to Lieberman and now a New York-based consultant. His first outing is a long and combative response to several of Lieberman's critics. This is what people in the political business like to call a frank exchange of views. Stay tuned.

The N.H.L. players union elected a five-member interim executive committee yesterday but decided against picking a replacement for Trevor Linden, its outgoing president.
Just about everything but the smell has changed since the Fulton Fish Market‚Äôs move from Lower Manhattan to the South Bronx.

Concerns about infections in Barbaro‚Äôs repaired right hind leg and the previously healthy left one have added to feelings of unease.
