Tracy L. Boyland, a former city councilwoman, filed papers with the State Board of Elections yesterday to challenge State Senator Velmanette Montgomery, a Brooklyn Democrat who has been in office since 1985. Ms. Boyland, left, who was barred by term limits from running for re-election in 2005, is the sister of Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr., and her father is a former assemblyman who ran unsuccessfully last year for her Council seat. Ms. Montgomery has not had a serious challenger in years. Ms. Boyland said she began collecting signatures after “a lot of people urged me to run because they were dissatisfied with the senator’s lack of productivity.” Ms. Montgomery’s staff members said she was in meetings yesterday and unavailable to be interviewed.

A busboy at Caf√© Boulud was charged yesterday with strangling a woman and dumping her body beside a house in Elmhurst, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Miguel Martinez, 21, of Case Street, was charged with murder and evidence tampering in the killing of Alicia Figueroa, 33, of Manhattan, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Martinez strangled Ms. Figueroa on the morning of July 9, stuffed her body in plastic garbage bags and threw it into a small yard beside his home. Neighbors found the body and called the police.

A Manhattan lawyer has been indicted on charges of stealing more than $1.6 million from seven clients, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, in an announcement yesterday. The lawyer, Campbell Holder, 58, who lives in Brooklyn, pleaded not guilty to grand larceny and forgery yesterday in State Supreme Court. Mr. Morgenthau said Mr. Holder represented clients in matters including personal injuries, divorces and estates. He said Mr. Holder transferred his clients‚Äô money to his general business account and used it to pay for trips to Barbados, a BMW and clothing. Mr. Morgenthau said Mr. Holder avoided his clients‚Äô demands for their money by blaming administrative delays. When one client confronted him, prosecutors said, Mr. Holder asked him to wait in his office and then left.

A man arrested after a high-speed chase through Essex County pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to murder charges unrelated to the car chase, as well as to charges stemming from the chase. The man, Jarrell Murphy, 20, of Newark was arrested Friday after a chase in which his car slammed into a medical transport van carrying five people, said Cheryl Cucinello, an Essex County assistant prosecutor. All five people suffered injuries, including broken bones. She said he had been fleeing detectives seeking to arrest him in connection with the murder of Johnny Collier in Newark on June 4. Mr. Murphy is charged with murder, aggravated assault and using his car as a weapon she said.

A former Suffolk County smoke shop operator pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court yesterday to charges that he conspired in the 2003 murder of a Brooklyn tobacco vendor. The suspect, Rodney Morrison, 39, was charged with racketeering and conspiracy in an 11-count indictment that accuses him of arranging the murder of the vendor, Sherwin Henry, 23, who once worked for Mr. Morrison selling tax-free tobacco on the Poospatuck Reservation in Mastic, said Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York. The indictment supersedes an earlier one that accused him of ordering the firebombing of a car belonging to another former employee. He was arrested in that case in August 2004.

In an attempt to curb thefts, Connecticut plans to issue vehicle registration stickers to be displayed inside windshields rather than on license plates. Gov. M. Jodi Rell and officials from the State Department of Motor Vehicles said yesterday that the change would be reflected in about 100,000 renewal notices being mailed July 21 for registrations that expire Sept. 1. Police officers have told state officials that the current stickers are often stolen by thieves and resold for illegal use.

A former Seton Hall University professor pleaded guilty in State Superior Court yesterday to stealing more than $575,000 from the school‚Äôs radio station, where he was faculty adviser, prosecutors said. The former professor, Michael A. Collazo, who was arrested on June 1, was fired from the university in 2004 after an audit found that over 19 years he had funneled station funds into his personal account. Mr. Collazo‚Äôs lawyer, Nicholas Bergamotto, said his client had pleaded guilty because he wanted to take responsibility for his actions, serve his prison time and move on. Mr. Collazo, 58, is being held in the Essex County jail on $250,000 bail and could face five years in prison at his sentencing on Aug. 18.

A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing from immigrants by posing as a federal immigration worker and promising to help them obtain green cards, prosecutors said. The defendant, John Nevarez, 53, of Manhattan, was indicted on Monday on charges of grand larceny and criminal impersonation. Prosecutors say he accepted money from immigrants and then, unknown to them, used fraudulent documents to apply for green cards on their behalf. Mr. Nevarez is charged with stealing more than $200,000 from 40 immigrants, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. None of the immigrants obtained green cards, Mr. Morgenthau said.

A 42-year-old Queens man was fatally shot in front of his Jackson Heights apartment building just after midnight yesterday, the police said. Adames Valerio of 35-19 100th Street, was shot once and taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead at 12:43 a.m., according to the police. They said that they had not found any witnesses to the shooting.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that its plan to remove or reassign subway conductors was postponed, pending its stalled labor negotiations with the Transport Workers Union. The authority, which first proposed what it called “one-person train operations” in 1996, was overruled last year, when an arbitrator said it must obtain union approval first. The Daily News reported yesterday that Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the arm of the authority that runs the subways, considered the plan to be on hold. Timothy O’Brien, a spokesman for the authority, said yesterday that it was proposing new contract rules that would keep conductors on trains, but have them circulation among passengers, giving them an “eyes and ears function.”.
The party‚Äôs  campaign to raise the minimum wage and focus attention on income inequality is playing a role in states where Republicans are vulnerable.

Officials in Transnistria, a separatist region that broke from Moldova in a 1992 civil war, announced plans to hold a referendum this summer on independence and possible union with Russia. Voters will be asked whether they support independence and ‚Äúsubsequent free union‚Äù with Russia or reject independence and wish to rejoin Moldova. Russia has maintained 1,200 peacekeepers in the region since the 1992 war. A dispute over customs with its two neighbors, Moldova and Ukraine, has all but sealed the region‚Äôs borders to trade. The region‚Äôs government is not internationally recognized.

A government official said Iran would use diplomacy and cultural channels to regain ancient clay tablets that a United States court ruled last week could be sold to pay compensation to victims of a 1997 Jerusalem bombing. The tablets date to between 553 B.C. and 330 B.C. and are the oldest Persian tablets with alphabetical inscriptions. They have been under study at the University of Chicago‚Äôs Oriental Institute since the 1930‚Äôs. The University of Chicago has opposed the court ruling and called the tablets an ‚Äúirreplaceable scholarly data set‚Äù that should not be subject to political battles. Iran‚Äôs Foreign Ministry also denounced the court ruling.
In a rare display of limited permissiveness, Wal-Mart is letting thieves off the hook in cases involving $25 or less.

A pipeline, one of the world‚Äôs longest, to carry Caspian basin oil to Western markets from Baku in Azerbaijan through Georgia will officially open today with a ceremony at Ceyhan, its Turkish Mediterranean terminal. The project, backed by the United States and built by an international consortium led by the British oil company BP, is expected to provide up to 7 percent of the global oil supply. Presidents Ilham Aliyev of Azerbaijan, Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia and Ahmet Necdet Sezer of Turkey will attend the ceremony.

The far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen is headed to court for injudicious comments he made last year about the Nazis‚Äô wartime activities in France. The trial will decide whether he is guilty of ‚Äúcomplicity in contesting crimes against humanity and complicity in justifying war crimes‚Äù by telling a right-wing weekly magazine last year that ‚Äúin France, at least, the German occupation was not particularly inhumane, although there were some blunders, inevitable in a country of 550,000 square kilometers.‚Äù Mr. Le Pen has been fined twice for dismissing the Holocaust as a ‚Äúdetail‚Äù of history. Denying the Holocaust is a crime in France, punishable by fines or prison.
The Galeras volcano in southwest Colombia sent out rocks, gas and ash prompting the government to evacuate about 10,000 nearby residents.

The family of a 14-year-old boy who died a day after entering a Panama City boot camp, filed a wrongful-death lawsuit for more than $40 million against the Bay County Sheriff‚Äôs Department and the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice. The boy, Martin Lee Anderson, was admitted to the boot camp Jan. 5 for a probation violation. After he collapsed while exercising, camp guards struck him and forced him to inhale ammonia in an effort to revive him. An initial autopsy concluded that the boy died of sickle cell trait, but a second autopsy concluded that he died of suffocation.
A Bosnian man was convicted on charges that he failed to admit on immigration documents that he was a member of a military unit involved in the killings of Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger asked the federal government to prohibit roads on 4.4 million acres of national forest land in California, with limited exceptions for thinning trees to reduce fire danger, according to a press release on his Web site. Mr. Schwarzenegger acted under a regulation adopted last year by the Bush administration. That regulation replaced a Clinton-era rule prohibiting road-building on nearly a third of national forest land. The Bush administration rule opened 58.5 million acres of the previously protected land to potential road building, unless governors petitioned the federal government to preserve the areas.
The public defender representing Steven D. Green, the former Army private accused of rape and murder in Iraq, is seeking an order prohibiting parties from speaking publicly about the case.

National Transportation Safety Board officials began an investigation into the cause of a Chicago subway derailment on Tuesday that caused a smoky fire and sent 152 passengers to the hospital. City officials said foul play was not suspected and praised a quick and smooth response by emergency personnel after the last car on an eight-car train leaving downtown for O‚ÄôHare International Airport derailed during rush hour, officials said. At least four passengers remained in two hospitals, but most were released Tuesday night. Trains resumed normal schedules on Wednesday. At least three passengers have filed lawsuits seeking more than $50,000 in damages, claiming the Chicago Transit Authority was negligent.

Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez urged Congress to pass legislation that would put illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship and create a temporary worker program to ensure that American companies could meet their labor needs. Mr. Gutierrez, testifying before the Senate Judiciary Committee, said that 500 of the nation‚Äôs top economists recently sent a letter to the Bush administration stating that immigration had been a net gain for Americans. Meanwhile, House Republicans announced plans for seven more hearings this month to highlight their concerns about the Senate immigration bill, which would legalize most of the nation‚Äôs illegal immigrants.

WASHINGTON, July 12 — The stories of waste, fraud and mismanagement that occasioned the doling out of billions of dollars in federal disaster assistance after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, are well documented.

The sport of caving, formally known as spelunking, combines a broad set of disciplines ranging from mud wrestling to demolition, with a bit of rock climbing and the occasional claustrophobic swimming thrown in.

HOUSTON, July 12 (AP) — The Houston Astros acquired third baseman Aubrey Huff from the Tampa Bay Devil Rays for two minor league prospects on Wednesday with the hope that Huff can help revive the Astros’ offense.

TRENTON, July 12 — Senator Robert Menendez continues to outpace his opponent in raising money in the race for his United States Senate seat, and he now has a better than 3-to-1 advantage in overall resources, according to campaign data released on Wednesday.

Premier Foods is buying the British and Irish businesses of the Campbell Soup Company for about $845 million, strengthening its stable of branded goods. Premier already owns brand names like Ambrosia, Branston and Quorn, and the Campbell deal will add Homepride sauces, OXO dry stocks and Batchelors dry soup and meals. The businesses Premier is adding have annual sales of about $480 million. The company said the combination should produce cost savings and increase revenue by ¬£28 million ($51.7 million) within three years. The sale includes three manufacturing plants in Britain and one in Ireland, Campbell said.

India‚Äôs industrial production slowed to 10 percent in May from 10.8 percent in May 2005 as the mining and power sectors slowed sharply, a government report said. Industrial production, however, was higher than the 9.5 percent growth recorded in April this year. According to the government‚Äôs Central Statistical Organization, manufacturing grew 11.3 percent compared with 10.9 percent last year. Growth in mining fell to 3 percent from 5.2 percent while electricity slid to a 4.7 percent pace from 10.5 percent last year.

The Burberry Group, the British luxury goods maker, said quarterly sales rose 18 percent as the company added stores around the world and took over retail operations in Spain and Taiwan. Revenue in the period, which ended June 30, climbed to ¬£135 million ($249 million) from ¬£114 million ($210 million) a year earlier, the company said. The company, which is based in London, said it increased its net retail selling space by 10 percent in the quarter and is on schedule to keep expanding at that pace over the full year. Retail sales rose 34 percent from a year earlier, to ¬£82 million ($150 million), and represented 61 percent of total revenue.

Eurotunnel, operator of the Channel Tunnel, said it would activate a legal procedure to protect it from creditors after talks aimed at restructuring the company‚Äôs huge debts ended without agreement. The company had set a debt a deadline of midnight on Wednesday to reach a deal. On Thursday morning, a group representing most of the company‚Äôs debt holders said in a statement: ‚ÄúWe believe that considerable progress has been made. However, agreement could not be reached within the deadlines imposed by Eurotunnel.‚Äù The group added that it was still interested in reaching a negotiated settlement. Creditors are owed some ¬£6.2 billion ($11.4 billion). Eurotunnel processed an initial filing for protection on Tuesday.

Deutsche Bank said it was buying MortgageIT Holdings in a $429 million deal that is its latest expansion in the mortgage-lending business in the United States. Deutsche Bank is paying $14.75 in cash for each MortgageIT share, representing a premium of about 19 percent over the Tuesday closing price of $12.40 a share. MortgageIT, based in New York, is a real estate investment trust that writes and resells residential mortgages.

Infosys Technologies, India‚Äôs second-largest outsourcing firm after Tata Consultancy Services, said its net profit for the quarter ended in June rose 50 percent, to 8 billion rupees ($174 million) from 5.32 billion rupees, exceeding expectations. Infosys hired 8,097 workers in the quarter, including a record 2,000 employees on a single day, and its work force now totals 58,409 workers. Its stock rose 7.5 percent, helping to keep the Sensex index of Indian stocks in positive territory on the day after a series of bombs ripped through commuter trains at rush hour in Mumbai.

MADRID, July 12 (Reuters) — The Spanish oil company Repsol YPF said Wednesday that it had agreed to buy 28 percent of an oil field in the Gulf of Mexico from BP for $2.15 billion.

The Department of Defense has identified 2,536 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.

Alfred Dreyfus, a French Jewish army officer, of high treason, misstated the year and setting in which Dreyfus was wounded in an assassination attempt. A government official said Iran would use diplomacy and cultural channels to regain ancient clay tablets that a United States court ruled last week could be sold to pay compensation to victims of a 1997 Jerusalem bombing. The tablets date to between 553 B.C. and 330 B.C. and are the oldest Persian tablets with alphabetical inscriptions. For a single day, 22 private gardens on the North Side of Chicago will be open to the public for the 48th annual Dearborn Garden Walk. The tour this Sunday includes small gardens, right, and larger landscapes. Architecture tours of the neighborhood -- once home to the likes of Aaron Montgomery Ward -- will also be offered. ''Most people who come are garden geeks,'' said Carol Truesdell, a tour committee member, ''but they get hooked on the architecture.'' The tour, from noon to 5 p.m., includes gardens and architecture and costs $30 in advance or $35 at the door. Information: dearborngardenwalk.com or (312) 632-1241. LISA CREGAN

Thanks to a light release schedule last week, a Johnny Cash album has reached the top of the Billboard album chart for the first time in 37 years. ''American V: A Hundred Highways'' (American Recordings/Lost Highway), shown at right, was drawn from Mr. Cash's last recording sessions before he died at 71 in 2003; it sold only 88,000 copies in its first week in stores, making it the lowest-selling No. 1 debut since Nielsen SoundScan began tracking music sales in 1991. But in a particularly slow week at record stores, and with very few other new albums in competition, that was enough. The last time Mr. Cash had a No. 1 album was in 1969, when ''At San Quentin'' held that spot for four weeks. Nelly Furtado's ''Loose'' (Geffen) is No. 2 this week, with sales of 81,000; India.Arie's ''Testimony: Vol. 1, Life & Relationship'' (Universal Motown), last week's best-seller, fell to No. 3; the Dixie Chicks' ''Taking the Long Way'' (Sony) held at No. 4. Gnarls Barkley's ''St. Elsewhere'' (Atlantic) continued its crawl up the charts, rising one spot to No. 5. BEN SISARIO

During the Hotel Valley Ho's heyday in the late 1950's, Bing Crosby smoked a corncob pipe by the pool and Natalie Wood and Robert Wagner held a wedding reception there. The hotel, a Scottsdale, Ariz., landmark, is one of the country's best preserved midcentury hotels; after a nearly two-year restoration, the 194-room resort, above, reopened in December. Now 37 units are being sold as furnished condominiums, below, designed by Cathy Hayes of Hayes Architecture/Interiors in Phoenix. Decorated with furniture and fabrics reminiscent of the 1950's, the first 14 residences will be completed in mid-August, and are priced between $800,000 and $2 million. Information: (480) 248-2025 or hotelvalleyho.com. LEIGH FLAYTON

An obituary yesterday about Harold Olmo, a grape breeder and geneticist, misstated the location where he found what he considered to be the original wine grape vines growing wild. It was in mountains on the border of Iran and Afghanistan, not Iraq and Afghanistan.
LEVENE--Ricky. So dearly loved, so deeeply missed, so much too soon. Our constant love, Mom and your family

LeBron James has never taken a traditional path in his basketball career. Instead of choosing to accept the most money now, James, the Cleveland Cavaliers' superstar, opted to stay in his hometown area for a shorter contract and the promise of a more lucrative payday in the future. James yesterday agreed to a three-year contract extension with a player option for a fourth year, worth about $60 million. The extension will take effect for the 2007-8 season; in 2006-7, James will make $5.8 million.

GAIR--Harriet E. 100, died at home on July 11, 2006. Harriet E. Gair had been an important figure in New York's legal structure for six decades. Her road to success was paved by performance and character. Harriet's trek to her leadership in the legal profession began at the age of fifteen, when she went to work for her late husband, the noted trial lawyer Harry A. Gair, in order to sustain herself and her family, and, at the same time attended high school in the evenings. She earned her high school diploma from the George Washington Evening High School. She continued her education at Washington Square College, at night, earning her Bachelors Degree in 1938. Harriet went on to New York University School of Law, after her marriage to Harry A. Gair, dean of the negligence bar. She received her LLB from the law school in 1940 and was thereafter admitted to the Bar of the State of New York. In 1945 she became a partner in the law firm of Harry A. Gair, which was thereafter known as Gair and Gair. Harriet was in full charge of the management of the firm while her husband continued to achieve eminence in the field of trial practice. The firm continues to the present as Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf. Even with the burdens of major law office partnership, Harriet was a worthy President of the New York Womens Bar Association; President of the Putnam Valley Free Library Board of Trustees; President of the Mid-Hudson Library System; a member of the Town Board of Putnam Valley, and a Town Justice of the Town of Putnam Valley from 1976 to 1981, having been elected to that post by popular acclaim. Her guidance, wisdom and compassion will be missed by her family and all who knew her. Wife of the late Harry A. Gair, Harriet is survived by sons Anthony and Roger, stepsons Donald and Ellwood, and stepdaughter Barbara Schieber. She is also survived by 30 grandchildren and great grandchildren, including Daniel A. Gair, a New York lawyer at Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf.The funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, telephone number (212) 362-6600, on Thursday, July 13, 2006 at 1:15 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New York University School of Law would be appreciated. $(6$)GAIR--Harriet E. The partners, associates, and entire staff deeply mourn the loss of the beloved co-founder of our firm, Harriet E. Gair. For all of her 100 years, she embodied the best of everything. She began working at the firm at the age of 15, and when she received her law degree from NYU 66 years ago, she was one of the first women to do so. For most of her life, she was our managing partner, but more importantly, she touched and inspired each of our personal lives. The legal profession has lost one of its pioneers and giants, but we have lost our leader and our friend. We extend our profound sympathies to her entire family and especially to her son and our partner, Anthony Gair, and to her grandson and our associate, Daniel Gair. Gair, Gair, Conason, Steigman & Mackauf

A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing from immigrants by posing as a federal immigration worker and promising to help them obtain green cards, prosecutors said. The defendant, John Nevarez, 53, of Manhattan, was indicted on Monday on charges of grand larceny and criminal impersonation. Prosecutors say he accepted money from immigrants and then, unknown to them, used fraudulent documents to apply for green cards on their behalf. Mr. Nevarez is charged with stealing more than $200,000 from 40 immigrants, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. None of the immigrants obtained green cards, Mr. Morgenthau said. MICK MEENAN (NYT)

8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) BUTTERFIELD 8 -- (1960). Oh, the things she makes men do. TCM devotes a night to Elizabeth Taylor -- who else? -- starting with her Academy Award-winning turn as a high-end call-girl who thinks she has finally found the man to make her life right. And the list goes on, as she plays Tennessee Williams's girl-gone-mad in ''Suddenly, Last Summer'' (1959), at 10; his long-suffering Maggie (above, with Paul Newman as Brick) in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' (1958), at midnight; and Theodore Dreiser's tragic heiress in ''A Place in the Sun'' (1951), at 2 a.m. before getting all virginal in ''Father of the Bride'' (1950) at 4:15. Even then, she's somehow convincing. 7:30 P.M. (BET) THE BLACK CARPET -- ''BET Style'' gets an image makeover with this new series intended to cover, its producers say, the black experience from the Detroit Hair Show to the N.B.A. All-Star Game to the Oakland Players Ball. Tour√© and Danella, the channel's one-name wonders, report from the front lines. 8 P.M. (VH1) I LOVE THE '70'S, VOLUME II -- Name that year: Nadia Comaneci (left) got a gold for her perfect 10, Sally Field got an Emmy for her perfect 16 (personalities, that is), and hits like ''Silly Love Songs'' and ''Afternoon Delight'' rocked the charts in a summer that had the entire nation seeing fireworks. Tonight, this weeklong special looks at a few of the highlights from 1976 before moving on, at 9 p.m., to the Year of the Disco, 1977. 8 P.M. (ABC) MASTER OF CHAMPIONS -- Oksana Baiul finds new uses for her goldmedal skills when she joins two other ice skaters as they compete to see who can spin the most toilet paper around their bodies inrecord time. 9 P.M. (BBC America) WATERLOO ROAD -- His fling with her closest friend puts an end to their impending nuptials. Only now, Tom Clarkson, the English teacher everybody loves to love, discovers that he still loves Lorna Dickey. Isn't that just like a man? 10 P.M. (Food Network) THROWDOWN WITH BOBBY FLAY --That Mr. Flay is one crafty chef. In this new series, he helps convince masters of their domains -- barbecuers, bakers, pizza makers -- that Food Network is filming a profile of them. Then he goes in for the kill: a surprise visit and an unexpected cook-off. But can Mr. Flay (above) hold his own and keep his cool? Tune in as the temperature in the kitchen rises. 11:30 P.M. (Biography) HOLLYWOOD'S 10 BEST -- Call it learning on the job. Jodie Foster, Ashley Judd, Rene Russo and other screen beauties discuss their roles as female detectives and why they think they're so darn good at them. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

The cost of setting up a dorm room can rise quickly -- especially with the expense of the storage units that make it possible to live efficiently in a small space with roommates. In recognition of this perennial challenge, the Container Store, a national 37-store chain, is sponsoring a series of ''private college nights.'' Everything will be sold at a 20 percent discount to anyone with college or high-school identification, and dorm-room experts will be present to demystify the process of organizing a very small living space. Dates can be found at containerstore.com/collegenight or (888) 266-8246. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

China and Russia introduced a draft resolution on North Korea in the Security Council on Wednesday and asked the Council's members to consider it in place of a Japanese-sponsored resolution, to which they both have objected, that would have allowed for military enforcement and sanctions. In offering the new measure, Wang Guangya, the Chinese ambassador, said he had instructions from his government to veto the Japanese resolution if it were put to a vote.

The list of aging stars the Rangers have brought to New York in recent decades is long. Most of them -- from Boom Boom Geoffrion in the 60's to Phil Esposito in the 70's to Marcel Dionne and Guy Lafleur in the 80's to Wayne Gretzky and Jari Kurri in the 90's -- were clearly past their prime. Brendan Shanahan, the Rangers' most significant addition this summer, does not plan to add his name to those whose best years were behind them when they finally reached Broadway.

FOX--Seymour. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion community mourns the passing of a great Jewish leader whose love for the Jewish people and vision played a singular role in advancing Jewish education and leadership. He will be sorely missed. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Burton Lehman, Chair $(6$)FOX--Seymour. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family and the Jewish people in mourning the loss of Professor Seymour Fox, of Jerusalem, the premier Jewish educator of his generation. A seminal force in bringing the best thinking in general education to new frontiers in Jewish education, he turned theory into practice at JTS and later at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Professor Fox instituted innovative initiatives which invigorated Jewish education around the globe. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor-elect Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

It may be a fallacy, this notion that the Yankees have a mandate to win a championship every season. For five years, they have not done it. And what has changed? Joe Torre is still the manager. Brian Cashman is still the general manager. The background static has been dialed down, not up. With the principal owner George Steinbrenner, 76, all but gone from public view, there is a sense of calm, not foreboding, around the team that calls itself the most famous sports franchise in the world.

Infosys Technologies, India's second-largest outsourcing firm after Tata Consultancy Services, said its net profit for the quarter ended in June rose 50 percent, to 8 billion rupees ($174 million) from 5.32 billion rupees, exceeding expectations. Infosys hired 8,097 workers in the quarter, including a record 2,000 employees on a single day, and its work force now totals 58,409 workers. Its stock rose 7.5 percent, helping to keep the Sensex index of Indian stocks in positive territory on the day after a series of bombs ripped through commuter trains at rush hour in Mumbai. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

KIRMSER--Earl died July 11th from a stroke. Born August 21st, 1916, in St. Paul, Minnesota, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Minnesota. He was a writer and editor at newspapers in Minnesota, Columbus, Ohio, and at The Washington Post. He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II and the Korean War. A career in public relations included service at the firms, Carl Byoir and T. J. Ross. He founded Earl Kirmser, Inc., in 1971. He was an arbitrator at the New York Stock Exchange, and in the 1960's, a proprietor -manger of the Port Washington Flyers, a Queens Alliance baseball team. An accomplished violinist, he played for the New Amsterdam Symphony Orchestra. He is survived by Helen-claire Kirmser, his wife of 64 years, sons Earl and Ralph, and their wives, Cheryl and Sally, respectively, seven grandchildren and four great grandchildren, brother Philip of Manhattan, Kansas, and sister Helen Anderson of Forest Lake, Minnesota. A memorial Mass at Holy Family Church, on 47th Street between First and Second Avenue, is scheduled for July 14th at 10:30AM. Contributtions can be made to the charity of the donor's choice.

When Ilan Dei, below, an Israeli-born interior designer, created his new collection of outdoor furniture, he was inspired by two things: light and technology. ''The quality of light is key,'' he said, referring to the way the translucent acrylic he used for the surfaces of the table and chairs casts an amber glow when the furniture sits in direct sunlight. The computer-driven milling process used to cut the acrylic and the weather-resistant plywood frames is what made the design possible -- and the final product less expensive than if it had been handmade. The Aquarium collection includes a chaise ($780) and a side table ($290), bottom, as well as a lounge chair ($450). Ilan Dei Studio, ilandeistudio.com or (310) 302-9222. KIMBERLY STEVENS
To the Editor: Re ''Small Colleges, Short of Men, Embrace Football'' (''The New Gender Divide'' series, front page, July 10):

A pipeline, one of the world's longest, to carry Caspian basin oil to Western markets from Baku in Azerbaijan through Georgia will officially open today with a ceremony at Ceyhan, its Turkish Mediterranean terminal. The project, backed by the United States and built by an international consortium led by the British oil company BP, is expected to provide up to 7 percent of the global oil supply. Presidents Ilham Aliyev of Azerbaijan, Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia and Ahmet Necdet Sezer of Turkey will attend the ceremony. SEBNEM ARSU (NYT)
ROLLER--Mildred. To my mother on her 81st birthday; always on my mind and in my heart. Love, Cheryl

News from the development drawer at Disney Theatricals: a new musical based on ''The Man in the Ceiling,'' the 1993 children's book by Jules Feiffer, right, about a boy who wants to grow up to be a cartoonist. Andrew Lippa, who wrote the book, music and lyrics for ''The Wild Party,'' is writing the music and lyrics, and Mr. Feiffer is writing the libretto. The musical would be the first for Mr. Feiffer, who wrote the plays ''Little Murders,'' ''Knock Knock'' and ''Grown-Ups.'' CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the Georgia law requiring voters to present government-issued ID cards violated the United States Constitution by discriminating against minorities, the poor and the elderly. If the preliminary injunction imposed by Judge Harold L. Murphy of the United States District Court in Rome, Ga., is not overturned on appeal, it may keep the law from being enforced until this case is settled.

Grants From Payola Fund A fund set up by the New York State Attorney General's office from settlements with major recording companies investigated for violating laws against payola has issued its first grants. Intended to make contemporary music of all types more available and accessible to diverse audiences, the awards, ranging from $15,000 to $750,000, were distributed to 153 recipients from every part of the state and totaled $13 million, according to Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors, which manages donation programs. Hip-hop, indie rock, fusion and reggae programs accounted for more than a third of the grants, while 30 percent went to new classical music and roughly 13 percent went to jazz initiatives. The City Parks Foundation received $230,000 to expand its free concerts in low-income neighborhoods in all five boroughs of New York, and the Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture received $90,000 for Bomplenazo 2006, two festivals celebrating the African and Latin musical roots of the South Bronx. 'South Park' to Rerun Scientology Episode Comedy Central has changed its mind and will rerun ''Trapped in the Closet,'' an episode of ''South Park'' that satirized the Church of Scientology and its famous follower Tom Cruise, Variety reported. ''If they hadn't put this episode back on the air, we'd have had serious issues, and we wouldn't be doing anything else with them,'' Matt Stone, one of the animated show's two creators, said. Comedy Central pulled a rerun of the episode in March after speculation that Mr. Cruise was displeased. At the time, Paramount, which like Comedy Central is owned by Viacom, was about to release Mr. Cruise's movie ''Mission: Impossible III.'' Last week, ''Trapped in the Closet'' captured an Emmy Award nomination. Comedy Central scheduled the rerun for Wednesday. For Metropolitan Opera, A New Art Gallery A contemporary visual arts gallery at the Metropolitan Opera is to open on Sept. 22, a result of a $1 million donation by Marie Schwartz, an advisory director on the Met's board. Named for Mrs. Schwartz and her late husband, the Arnold and Marie Schwartz Gallery Met will be in the south side of the opera house lobby; admission will be free. Inspired by the heroines of six new productions next season, six artists have already produced works for the inaugural exhibition: Cecily Brown, who took as her subject Suor Angelica in ''Il Trittico''; John Currin, who chose Helena in ''Die √Ñgyptische Helena,'' above; Barnaby Furnas, who selected Euridice in ''Orfeo ed Euridice''; Makiko Kudo, who took Princess Yue-yang in ''The First Emperor''; Richard Prince, who chose Cio-Cio-San in ''Madama Butterfly''; and Sophie von Hellermann, who selected Rosina in ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia.'' Developing New Artists Three nonprofit Jewish arts organizations have announced an artist development program financed by $1 million from the Commission on Jewish Identity and Renewal of UJA-Federation. The grant, described as the largest ever by UJA to an arts organization, will give each of 12 New York-based artists up to $45,000 for living expenses and project-related support for two years. Established by the National Foundation for Jewish Culture, JDub Records and Avoda Arts, the development program, called the Six Points Fellowship, is focused on the visual arts, music and the performing arts. The organizers said applications would be accepted through Aug. 31 from artists from 22 to 39 living in greater New York. Information: www.sixpointsfellowship.org. Stones Roll in Milan The Rolling Stones rocked for two hours as they opened the delayed European leg of their ''Bigger Bang'' tour at a packed San Siro soccer stadium in Milan on Tuesday night, Reuters reported. During their hiatus, Keith Richards, above on guitar, underwent cranial surgery in New Zealand after a fall from a tree, and Ron Wood entered a rehabilitation clinic in London for treatment of alcohol abuse. At the concert, Mick Jagger, also above, congratulated Italy on its victory in the World Cup soccer championship, and invited Marco Materazzi and Alessandro Del Piero, two members of the winning team, onstage. Referring to the head butt Mr. Materazzi took from Zin√©dine Zidane of France, Mr. Jagger, speaking in Italian, said, ''Materazzi and Richards have something in common tonight: they both recently had head-related problems.'' So Bad It's Good Jim Giugli, a retired mechanical designer from Carmichael, Calif., was pronounced the best of the bad when judges awarded the annual Bulwer-Lytton literary parody prize, Reuters reported. Founded in 1982 by the English department at San Jose State University, the contest, which takes its name from Edward George Bulwer-Lytton, the novelist who began ''Paul Clifford'' in 1830 with the words ''It was a dark and stormy night,'' seeks the worst opening sentence of an imaginary novel. Mr. Giugli's winning entry, chosen from thousands from around the world, read, ''Detective Bart Lasiter was in his office studying the light from his one small window falling on his super burrito when the door swung open to reveal a woman whose body said you've had your last burrito for a while, whose face said angels did exist, and whose eyes said she could make you dig your own grave and lick the shovel clean.'' Footnotes The Public Theater's free performance of ''Stuff Happens'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park will take place on Wednesday, Sept. 6, not on Tuesday, Sept. 5, as the theater previously announced. Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie will be at it again next season. The fifth installment of their reality-style show, ''The Simple Life,'' will be presented by E! Entertainment Television, The Associated Press reported.

SEELIG--Alma (nee Amerikaner). Beloved wife of the late Julius, honored mother of Evelyn Feiner and Kent and Susan Seelig, cherished Oma of Rod, Laura, Jeffrey & Jennifer Feiner, Joshua, Lee and Laine Seelig, revered great grandmother of Abigail, Grace, Jason and Noah Feiner. We will miss her.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Israelis Enter Lebanon After Guerilla Attacks Two Israeli soldiers were captured and at least eight killed as the Lebanese guerilla group Hezbollah launched a surprise daytime assault across the border of Israel, while the Israeli army was staging a military offensive in the Gaza Strip. Israel responded by sending armored forces into southern Lebanon for the first time in six years, and by bombing the airport in Beirut. A1 Bombs Aimed at India's Well-Off Though the bombers responsible for the explosions on Mumbai's suburban commuter line remain unknown, authorities believe they were focusing on the city's upper classes, as the victims were overwhelmingly male and working age, and each of the bombs exploded in the trains' first-class men's compartments. A12 Russia and China Back Plan Russia and China joined the United States and Europe by agreeing to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution ordering Iran to freeze its nuclear activities or face sanctions. A10 China and Russia introduced a resolution on North Korea in the Security Council and asked the Council's members to consider it in place of a Japanese-sponsored resolution. A10 Army to End Halliburton Deal The Army said it plans to terminate and restructure a lucrative and contentious logistics contract that has paid a single company, Halliburton, more than $15 billion to do jobs like deliver food and fuel and construct housing for American troops around the world. A6 NATIONAL A16-21 U.S. Seeks to Limit Rights For Terrorism Suspects A day after saying that terror suspects had a right to protections under the Geneva Conventions, the Bush administration said it wanted Congress to pass legislation that would limit those rights. A1 More Flaws Found in Tunnel Massachusetts officials ordered every road and tunnel in the city highway system examined after inspectors found at least 60 more trouble spots in a Big Dig tunnel where a woman was killed. A18 Vote on Amendment Postponed The Massachusetts Legislature postponed until after Election Day what promises to be an impassioned debate and vote on a constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage. A16 EDUCATION Similarities in Textbooks A high school history textbook by the Pulitzer-Prize winning historian Daniel J. Boorstin and Brooks Mather Kelley, is virtually identical to another textbook by different authors. It is a tale of how the largely obscure world of high school textbook publishing often works. A1 SCIENCE/HEALTH Brain Controls Computer A paralyzed man with a small sensor implanted in his brain was able to control a computer, television and robot using only his thoughts, scientists reported. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Fiery Van Crash in Queens Kills Five From Adult Home Five residents of one of the state's most troubled adult homes for the mentally ill burned to death when a van carrying them back to the home slammed into a tree and exploded in flames in a remote corner of Queens, the police said. A1 Adult Dorms Return As a homegrown response to the soaring rents bedeviling desirable cities like New York, Karen Falcon, an agent for the owner of a a 60-unit building in Harlem, has placed young professionals in the building to share big apartments with strangers as a way to keep housing costs down, calling it a dorm for adults. A1 Bouncer Charged in Murders A bouncer who was charged with shooting patrons outside a Chelsea nightclub in May -- killing one -- has also been charged with three killings in Brooklyn, court and law enforcement officials said. B1 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-6 Friend Says Bonds Used Drugs The former best friend and business partner of Barry Bonds has told federal investigators that Bonds was a heavy steroids user and flew into ''roid rages,'' the friend's lawyer said. D1 ARTS E1-12 The Met Raises Price The Metropolitan Museum of Art is raising its recommended admission price for adults to $20 from $15. E1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Europeans Fine Microsoft The European Commission hit Microsoft with a $357 million fine for failing to share technical information about its hugely profitable Windows operating system as it was ordered to do in a 2004 ruling. C1 New Wal-Mart Theft Policy According to internal documents, Wal-Mart will no longer prosecute first-time shoplifters unless they take merchandise worth at least $25 and are between the ages of 18 and 65, putting the company in line with many other retailers. C1 Higher U.S. Trade Deficit The nation's trade deficit edged slightly higher in May, pushed up by soaring oil prices. C2 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Israel's two-front battle; earning that Congressional raise; the politics of exploding houses; save the earth and find a hair gel. Columns: David Brooks, Bob Herbert. Bridge E10 Crossword E2 Obituaries B7 TV Listings E7 Weather D7

HABBERSTAD--Howard L., Sr. 71, auto dealer, founder & retired President of Habberstad BMW and Habberstad Nissan of Huntington Station, NY, passed away peacefully in Hospice care on July 11, 2006 after a courageous battle with Lymphoma. Howard was a lifelong resident of Huntington & upon retiring in 1997, he & his wife Dorothy spent winters in Jupiter, FL. Howard's son Erik states, ''Dad had a lifelong love affair with cars.''his passion for cars fueled his desire to own and operate a car dealership. In 1971, he purchased a BMW franchise. By 1981, due to his success, he expanded his business to a larger facility and purchased the Nissan franchise as well. Today, his two sons, Howard Jr. and Erik continue to carry on his vision and legacy with Habberstad BMW, MINI, Nissan and Kia, all in Huntington Station, NY. Visiting hours will be on Friday, July 14, 2-4:30PM, then again from 7-9PM. Religious services will follow at 8:30PM at the M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, NY 11746. Survived by his wife Dorothy, two sons, Howard Jr. and his wife Susan of St. James and Erik of Centerport. Also, five grandchildren, Courtney, Christian, Brielle, Andrew, and Brooke. The far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen is headed to court for injudicious comments he made last year about the Nazis' wartime activities in France. The trial will decide whether he is guilty of ''complicity in contesting crimes against humanity and complicity in justifying war crimes'' by telling a right-wing weekly magazine last year that ''in France, at least, the German occupation was not particularly inhumane, although there were some blunders, inevitable in a country of 550,000 square kilometers.'' Mr. Le Pen has been fined twice for dismissing the Holocaust as a ''detail'' of history. Denying the Holocaust is a crime in France, punishable by fines or prison. CRAIG S. SMITH (NYT)

To the Editor: I enjoyed ''The Devil Wears Teflon,'' by David Carr (Business Day column, July 10). I would let Anna Wintour throw coats and handbags at me, bark orders for coffee and not take it personally, provided that she give me new shoes.

GUTTAG--Marjorie. The staff and Board of Trustees of the Jewish Communal Fund mourn with sorrow the passing of Marjorie Guttag, Trustee Emeritus of the Jewish Communal Fund. Marjorie, together with her busband Irwin, served as examples of communal responsbility. Marjorie's dedication to making the world a better place and her devotion to her family has created a legacy for generations to come. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Guttagfamily. Harold R. Handler, President Susan F. Dickman Executive Vice President
ROSENBERG--William. Beloved husband of the late Mollie, loving father of Steven, Norman and Marian. Cherished grandfather. Graveside services were held on July 12th at Beth David Cemetery.

Train Bombers in India Focused on the Elite Indian commuters dashed through the Churchgate train station in Mumbai's financial district yesterday after service on the commuter line resumed. Whoever set off eight bombs on the line on Tuesday systematically chose first-class men's compartments, making a target of the city's business class. PAGE A18 Leeway for Shoplifters Wal-Mart is easing its policy on first-time shoplifters who are under 18 or over 65 and who take goods worth less than $25, company documents say. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Democrats Push Wage Rise Seeking to energize voters over economic issues, Democrats have begun a broad campaign to raise the minimum wage and focus attention on income inequality. DRAPOS--Alex. The American Farm School mourns the untimely passing of its beloved trustee, former chairman of the Board. Alex was a devoted friend, who gave generously to the School. He will be deeply missed. A tree is being planted in his memory in the campus olive grove.

MICROSOFT IS FINED -- The European Commission slapped Microsoft with a $357 million fine for failing to comply with an antitrust order. European authorities have also raised concerns about Windows Vista, the next version of the company's operating system. The most recent letter from the commission came on July 4, requesting answers to an additional 79 questions, according to Bradford L. Smith, Microsoft's general counsel, above. [Page C1.] NEW SHOPLIFTING POLICY -- According to internal documents, Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer and leading destination for shoplifting, will no longer prosecute suspected thieves unless they are between 18 and 65 and steal merchandise worth at least $25, putting the chain in line with many other retailers. [C1.] WEINSTEIN DEAL MAY BE NEAR -- The Weinstein Company, the film studio started by the founders of Miramax, is near a deal to form a joint venture with Robert L. Johnson, founder of Black Entertainment Television, to create an entertainment company, according to people involved in the negotiations. [C1.] BIG JOB AT BP -- Robert A. Malone, tapped to run BP America Inc., faces the challenge of restoring BP's credibility not just with the public but also with regulators from the Justice Department and the Labor Department. [C1.] PHONE COMPANIES MAKE CASE -- Lawyers for the nation's two largest telephone companies and the Justice Department urged a federal judge to swiftly approve the antitrust settlements that permitted SBC Communications to acquire AT&T and Verizon to buy MCI. [C9.] REPORT ON NEW YORK -- New York City's economy bounced back after Sept. 11 with surprising speed and is much healthier now than its slowing job market indicates, according to a report released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. [C14.] DEMOCRATS AND ECONOMY -- Democrats, seeking to energize voters over economic issues in much the way that Republicans rallied conservatives with efforts to ban gay marriage, have begun a broad campaign to raise the minimum wage and focus attention on income inequality. [A18.] INDIA'S ECONOMY AFTER ATTACK -- A day after terrorist bombs ripped through the commuter train system of India's financial capital here, business executives said the attack would have little effect on India's buoyant economy. [C10.] BLOW TO TOYOTA'S IMAGE -- An investigation by the local Japanese police into an accident involving a Toyota sport utility vehicle is threatening to turn into a scandal for the carmaker, which has built its success on a reputation for reliability. [C10.] RUSSIA'S ENERGY STANCE -- Despite calls from European and American leaders for open Russia's energy market, allowing greater foreign investment and unfettered access to its network of oil and gas pipelines, President Vladimir V. Putin has made it clear that he will not bend on the energy issue. [A10.] ANSWER TO HIGH RENTS -- In full-service ''dorms for adults,'' overeducated and underpaid strangers share big apartments to keep housing costs down as soaring rents bedevil desirable cities like New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles. [A1.] STOCKS FALL -- The Nasdaq composite index sank 38.62 points, to close at 2,090.24. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 121.59 points, to end at 11,013.18. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 13.92 points, to finish at 1,258.60. [C12.] HALLIBURTON CONTRACT MAY END -- The Army plans to terminate and restructure a lucrative and enormously contentious logistics contract that has paid a single company, Halliburton, more than $15 billion to do jobs like deliver food and fuel and construct housing for American troops since late 2001. [A6.] SOYBEANS AS FUEL -- Biodiesel produced from soybeans produces more usable energy and reduces greenhouse gases more than corn-based ethanol, making it more deserving of subsidies, according to a study. [C4.] PERFUME AND PROFITS -- The highest court in France has ruled that making perfume is not an artistic creation, but the work of artisan. At stake are potential royalties for perfume makers, and profits and protection for manufacturers. [G1.] ONLINE THE PROMISE OF GENETIC TESTING -- With the exception of a few tests, the genetics revolution has not yet happened. Now maybe, just maybe, it is imminent. A report is at nytimes.com/science. VIDEO: VISION -- Chester Higgins Jr. of The Times introduces a series of portraits of significant New Yorkers at nytimes.com/nyregion. ONLINE: DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. THE BOOKSELLER -- Barnes & Noble said that a shareholder had filed a complaint in a New York court contending improprieties in the company's issuing of stock options. (REUTERS) A FEDERAL JUDGE HAS SENTENCED a former FBI agent, Lynn Wingate, to three years' probation for obstruction of justice related to the insider-trading prosecution of a stock picker, Anthony Elgindy. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE LIONS GATE ENTERTAINMENT Corporation has bought Debmar-Mercury to move into TV syndication. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

To the Editor: Re ''White House Says Terror Detainees Hold Basic Rights'' (front page, July 12):

Because of an editing error, the David Carr column in Business Day on Monday, about Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, misstated the title of a recent memoir by another prominent editor, Bonnie Fuller of Star magazine, whose public persona was compared with Ms. Wintour's. It is ''The Joys of Much Too Much: Go for the Big Life -- the Great Career, the Perfect Guy and Everything Else You've Ever Wanted.'' The working title was ''From Geek to Oh My Goddess: How to Get the Big Career and the Big Love Life and the Big Family -- Even if You Have a Big Loser Complex Inside.''

The Metropolitan Museum of Art is raising its recommended admission price for adults to $20 from $15, making it one of the most expensive museums to visit in the world. Harold Holzer, a museum spokesman, said the increase, which is to take effect on Aug. 1, was intended to remedy an annual operating deficit that had averaged $3 million in recent years.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on June 30 about a new labor agreement between Wal-Mart's British unit, Asda, and employees at its distribution centers referred incorrectly to the status of union representation at Wal-Mart stores in North America. While unions have been certified in at least four locations in Canada, no store in the United States has a labor agreement. The article also misstated the scope of the agreement reached in Britain. Unions representing employees at the distribution centers will continue to negotiate individually or in existing partnerships with Asda on issues like pay; the agreement does not establish nationwide collective bargaining. (A national joint council has been set up in Britain to negotiate issues like employee training and technological advances.)

An article and a picture caption in Thursday Styles last week, about former high school and college athletes who have stopped exercising, misspelled the surname of a former baseball player who has since resumed workouts. He is John Deodato, not Diadato.
To the Editor: Re ''A Vietnam Lesson, Unlearned'' (column, July 10):

India's industrial production slowed to 10 percent in May from 10.8 percent in May 2005 as the mining and power sectors slowed sharply, a government report said. Industrial production, however, was higher than the 9.5 percent growth recorded in April this year. According to the government's Central Statistical Organization, manufacturing grew 11.3 percent compared with 10.9 percent last year. Growth in mining fell to 3 percent from 5.2 percent while electricity slid to a 4.7 percent pace from 10.5 percent last year. SARITHA RAI (NYT)

An article on Friday about anti-Semitism in France in the 100 years since its supreme court absolved Capt. Alfred Dreyfus, a French Jewish army officer, of high treason, misstated the year and setting in which Dreyfus was wounded in an assassination attempt. It was in 1908, when the ashes of √âmile Zola, who had denounced Dreyfus's accusers, were transferred to the Pantheon.

HEISLER--Toni. The Board and Staff of United Hospital Fund mourn the loss of a dear friend and long-time employee. For more than 25 years, Toni was the ''go to'' person for important information on health and health care in New York City. She was also a beloved member of the Fund family whose great sense of justice and humor, vast range of interests, ever-questioning mind and enormous courage earned her lasting friendships and many admirers. We extend our deepest sympathies to her companion Jerry Fritz and the Heisler family. J. Barclay Collins, II, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. , Pres. $(6$)HEISLER--Toni. On July 11,2006. Beloved daughter of the late Irving and Vivienne Heisler. Dear sister of Jeffrey and adored aunt of Rebecca. Loving companion of Gerald Fritz. Memorial services to be announced.

An article on July 2 about the New York Police Department's aviation unit referred imprecisely in some copies to the Coast Guard station in Atlantic City. While it is the closest station with an aviation unit, it is not the closest Coast Guard station to the metropolitan region; Staten Island's is closer. The article also misstated the name of the manufacturer of one of the two types of helicopters the department uses. It is AgustaWestland, not Augusta. The article also reversed the identifications for a helicopter patrolling the West Side Highway and one carrying a scuba team over Jamaica Bay. An AgustaWestland A119 Koala flew over the highway, and a Bell 412 was over the bay.

Russia and China, crossing a diplomatic threshold in the effort to curb Tehran's nuclear ambitions, joined the United States and Europe by agreeing to seek a United Nations Security Council resolution ordering Iran to freeze some nuclear activities, or face sanctions. Article, Page A10.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that its plan to remove or reassign subway conductors was postponed, pending its stalled labor negotiations with the Transport Workers Union. The authority, which first proposed what it called ''one-person train operations'' in 1996, was overruled last year, when an arbitrator said it must obtain union approval first. The Daily News reported yesterday that Lawrence G. Reuter, the president of New York City Transit, the arm of the authority that runs the subways, considered the plan to be on hold. Timothy O'Brien, a spokesman for the authority, said yesterday that it was proposing new contract rules that would keep conductors on trains, but have them circulation among passengers, giving them an ''eyes and ears function.'' THOMAS J. LUECK (NYT)
A theater review on Tuesday about ''Food for Fish,'' at the Kraine Theater in the East Village, misstated the given name of the director. She is Alexis Poledouris, not Alex.
HEMINWAY--Nan. The Litchfield Historical Society mourns the loss of friend and board member Nan Heminway. Nan was a leader in the preservation of historic Litchfield. Her guidance will be missed.

Music lovers and fans of Gothic Revival architecture have a new reason to visit Buffalo, the hometown of the punk folksinger Ani DiFranco. Ms. DiFranco, above, recently raised $10 million to buy and restore a Victorian church, which has been converted to house a performance hall, offices for her recording company, Righteous Babe Records, and an arts center. Built for Methodists in 1876, the church, above right, changed congregations several times in the 1980's and 90's. By the mid-1990's, its facade was crumbling, and the city had plans to demolish it. Ms. DiFranco had long admired the building; in 2003, her company arranged to buy it and recruited two local architecture firms, Flynn Battaglia Architects and Architectural Resources, to devise reuse plans.

FLESCHNER--Janice(nee Hubshman) died on June 24, 2006 at JFK Hospital in Lake Worth, FL. She was 85. Mrs. Fleschner grew up in New York and Milford, CT. She graduated from the Ethical Fieldston School. She also studied at The Arts Students League of New York and attended Temple University's Tyler School of Art. She was married to Malcolm King Fleschner who died in 1999. They lived in Westport, CT, New York City, Palm Beach and often summered in France. Together they were avid collectors of 20th Century American Art and donated many pieces to the Norton Museum in West Palm Beach, Florida. She is survived by her son and daughter, six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Expressions of sympathy may take the form of donations to the National Audubon Society.

THE 17th-century English wing chair, with a high back and wings on either side to protect the occupant from drafts, has never gone out of style and is constantly being updated. Some new versions use modern upholstery materials like water hyacinth fibers rather than cut velvet or damask. And one model has a large hood to screen out not just breezes but noisy relatives or roommates. 1. The Winged Chair by Brueton can be upholstered in either fabric or leather ($2,900 to $5,300); to the trade at Brueton, 200 Lexington Avenue (31st Street), (212) 838-1630; for showrooms elsewhere, brueton.com or (800) 221-6783. 2. A classic wing chair with a loose seat cushion and a movable back pillow is upholstered in water hyacinth fibers. It is $3,000 from centuryfurniture.com; (800) 852-5552 for showroom addresses. 3. The Caribou Club Arm Chair from Century Furniture's Sun Valley Collection was inspired by the rustic-elegant style of its namesake club in Aspen, Colo. Made of alder wood and leather, the chair is $1,770. (Contact information is given in No. 2, above.) 4. The Lapel Chair, designed in Sweden by the firm of Claesson Koivisto Rune, has what the designers call ''avant-garde wings that fit the sitter like a glove.'' It is $790 at Dune, 88 Franklin Street (Church Street), or through either (212) 925-6171 or dune-ny.com. 5. Peekaboo, a molded felt-covered lounge chair designed by Stefan Borselius in Stockholm, has an optional hood with a transparent plastic front that can be attached to provide privacy. The chair is $2,715, and the hood is $855. They are at ICF Group, 920 Broadway (22nd Street), (212) 388-1000; other locations are available at icfsource.com. 6. The Circa Chair, an upholstered side chair, is $649 from Room and Board, roomandboard.com or (800) 301-9720. 7. Free Chair, a lounge chair that swivels on a chrome base, is suitable for home or office. It can be upholstered in leather ($3,910) or fabric ($3,350). At Dune. (Contact information is in No. 4, above.) 8. The wings on some chairs are subtle, like those on the Denby Modern Wing Chair by Martha Stewart from the Opal Point Collection. It is $1,150. For retailers, marthastewart.com or (888) 562-7842.

An obituary on Monday about Paul Nelson, a pioneering rock critic, misstated the cause of death in some copies. While his friend Steven Feltes initially said he had apparently died of starvation, he said later that a cause had not been determined. The New York City medical examiner's office said yesterday that the cause was heart disease. The obituary also misstated the date of Mr. Nelson's collaboration with Lester Bangs on a biography of Rod Stewart. The book was published in 1981, not 1988.

An article yesterday about the indictments of six current or former law enforcement officers in Passaic County, N.J., on charges of conspiring to help drug suspects avoid arrests, misidentified the employer of one officer, Paul Kleiber, in some copies. It is the Ringwood Police Department, not the West Milford Police Department.

Officials in Transnistria, a separatist region that broke from Moldova in a 1992 civil war, announced plans to hold a referendum this summer on independence and possible union with Russia. Voters will be asked whether they support independence and ''subsequent free union'' with Russia or reject independence and wish to rejoin Moldova. Russia has maintained 1,200 peacekeepers in the region since the 1992 war. A dispute over customs with its two neighbors, Moldova and Ukraine, has all but sealed the region's borders to trade. The region's government is not internationally recognized. JAMES K. PHILIPS (NYT)

Michael Eisner, the former chief executive of Walt Disney Corp., interviewed Rupert Murdoch of News Corp., Sir Howard Stringer of Sony and Barry Diller of InterActiveCorp on Friday morning. The presentation was perhaps the best attended of the conference with nearly every executive packed into the room. (That is, except Eric Schmidt of Google, who was spotted back at the lodge.) Here are the highlights, according to an unscientific poll of the mogul audience:

Hertz, the auto-rental giant, has streaked from buyout target to I.P.O. hopeful in slightly more than six months, suggesting remarkable confidence -- or impatience -- on the part of its owners. The company filed with securities regulators late Friday to raise as much as $1 billion in an initial public offering, with the proceeds earmarked to repay a $1 billion loan. Hertz incurred the loan to pay a special dividend of nearly that same amount to its private equity sponsors late last month.

Tom Suozzi may be far behind in the polls, but he is apparently showing some strength on the fund raising front. We're told Mr. Suozzi will report that he has $2.8 million on hand. The Republican candidate for Governor, John Faso, has just half that, and is expecting to report that he has $1.4 million.

Come Saturday, foes of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 will be able to commiserate on an international scale. Starting July 15, the law's corporate governance regulations will start applying to foreign firms, Forbes.com's Hannah Clark notes.

I have not lodged on the Nevers side of the circuit for many years. Lately I have been staying in Moulins, and for several years I stayed "chez l'habitant," in homes right next to the circuit. This year, however, I am staying in a gite in La Charit√©-sur-Loire, a beautiful town classified in Unesco's World Heritage list. I was mesmerized by the antiquarian bookshops this morning on my way to my car, and learned later that the town is known in part for these bookshops.

Attendees made their way, alone and in small groups, to the Allen & Company conference's morning sessions on Friday. Michael Eisner and Barry Diller, pictured separately below, make up half of the four-person panel of media-industry power brokers scheduled for later that day; the others were Sony chief Howard Stringer and News Corporation chairman Rupert Murdoch. Mr. Eisner was down to play the role of interviewer.
The Clinton campaign has just released its new fund-raising numbers, and it shows that she has roughly 100 times the cash on hand as her two would-be Republican rivals, KT McFarland and John Spencer:

Oneida, a marketer of flatware, glasses and other tabletop items, said Friday it has tentatively agreed to be acquired by two hedge funds for "at least $222.5 million." The deal appears to be a strategy for resolving a clash between Oneida, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March, and a group of shareholders who claimed they were being short-changed by its reorganization plan.

Mergers and acquisitions are at a six-year high thanks in part to the bulging cash accounts of both corporations and private equity firms, according to a recent report from PriceWaterhouseCoopers. Easy financing and low levels of troubled debt are also helping to keep deals flowing. Among the sectors considered likely to see more M&A activity for the rest of the year: energy, manufacturing, utilities, retail and technology.

Recently we reported on how the proposed Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn has sent noticable ripples through the borough's political scene. Among other things, it had helped Bill Batson, an underdog candidate for the 57th Assembly district who has taken a hard line against the project, attract money and volunteers. (His opponent, lawyer Hakeem Jeffries, has walked more of a middle road on the issue.)

This blog began on the 10th of January--just a little over six months ago--and now's the time to bring it to an end. The reasons are purely personal--the garden needs weeding more than the blog needs writing. I'll continue to write Rural Life pieces for the editorial page of the New York Times, of course. In a sense, ending the blog is just a way of re-entering the privacy of the garden. I'm deeply grateful to all the readers who've read what I've written here, especially to those who have added their own comments. I'm also grateful to the bloggers who've linked to these pages over the past 6 months. My only real regret is bringing to an end the daily journal kept by Gilbert White in Selborne in 1784. It has been a joy to run it and a pleasure to watch other people discover how interesting and moving the daily record of a man who lived so quietly and so long ago can really be. So let me close with the entry for this day, 14 July 1784:29 9/10 1/4; 60 1/2; W, NW. Sun, dark, sun, sweet even: Wheat turns colour. Papilio Machaon [swallowtail butterfly] in Mrs. Etty's garden. They are very rare in these parts.

FIFTY years ago this summer, on Aug. 11, 1956, Jackson Pollock drank himself into a rage and crashed his Oldsmobile on a curving road in Springs, a bucolic bayside hamlet in East Hampton, N.Y. His lover, Ruth Kligman, survived the accident, but Pollock, who was 44, and another passenger did not. When Pollock died, he was light years from the focused state in which he had created his most acclaimed work and thousands of miles from his wife, Lee Krasner (like him, a pioneering Abstract Expressionist painter), who had fled to Europe to escape his abusive rants and blatant infidelity. But he was only about a mile from his modest wood-shingled house overlooking the tranquil salt marshes of Accabonac Creek, a site now open to the public as the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center.

WHO -- Susan Burrows, 69, a retired teacher, and her husband, Jack Burrows, 74, a retired Navy commander, who live in Virginia Beach. WHAT -- 2-bedroom cabin WHERE -- Roxbury, N.Y. This cabin was built in 1941 on property that has been in my family since 1893. When my grandfather built it, he rolled my grandmother's grand piano inside before the fourth wall went up. It's still here. After my grandfather died in 1922, my father hired a family to live on the dairy farm that was part of the property. For my whole life, the day after school closed we'd come up from the suburbs of Philadelphia and share the farmhouse with the family who lived there. At the time, this cabin was one room. We'd use it on weekends as a getaway from the farmhouse. We've added on to it since then.

Reggae Concert Canceled Protests have led to the cancellation of a reggae concert scheduled for Tuesday at Webster Hall. The event, intended to raise awareness of H.I.V. and AIDS, was to have featured Beenie Man, right, and the group T.O.K., who, protesters complained, are antigay, The Associated Press reported. The protesters flooded the organizer, LIFEbeat, a nonprofit group, with calls demanding that the acts be dropped from the lineup or that they publicly denounce antigay lyrics. A LIFEbeat board member, Tom Rosta, said the depth of feeling on the subject had been misjudged, and John Canelli, the organization's executive director, said some calls had been so threatening that safety at the concert became an issue. Shelley Poem Found A 172-line poem written by Percy Bysshe Shelley in 1811 has been rediscovered, the BBC reported. The poem, carrying an antiwar message, was printed in an 18-page pamphlet, ''Poetical Essay on the Existing State of Things,'' and attributed only to ''a Gentleman of the University of Oxford.'' The so-called poetical essay was published to raise money for the radical Irish journalist Peter Finnerty, who was in prison for libel. It was never republished, and some experts had doubted its existence. But Richard Linenthal, a director of the antiquarian bookseller Bernard Quaritch Ltd. of London, said the book had been brought by another bookseller for verification, and the poem's existence was discovered in an Internet search. Mr. Linenthal characterized the find as ''a discovery one dreams of making,'' and said the poem would be offered for sale. ''We cannot comment on its commercial value,'' he said. First Folio Fetches Millions A copy of Shakespeare's First Folio in mint condition was sold yesterday for $5.2 million at auction at Sotheby's in London, Reuters reported. The volume, published in 1623, seven years after Shakespeare's death, includes 36 plays, 18 of them not previously printed. The sale price was below the top estimate, $6.4 million. The volume had been in the Dr. Williams Library, a research institution for English Protestant dissent, since about 1716. Sotheby's said the buyer was a ''London book dealer,'' Agence France-Presse reported. Prison Sentences Sought In Croesus Theft A prosecutor in Turkey yesterday demanded prison sentences for the director of a state museum and nine others suspected in the theft of at least two objects from the treasure of King Croesus, The Associated Press reported. The prosecutor, Mustafa Celebi, asked that Kazim Akbiyikoglu, the director of the Archaeological Museum in Usak, in western Turkey, and seven other suspects receive as much as 25 years in prison in connection with the theft of a coin and a gold brooch in the shape of a winged sea horse, above. They were taken from the museum and replaced with fakes. Two other suspects, including a police officer, face sentences as long as four years for failing to investigate the theft, the indictment said. The collection was returned to Turkey by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1993 after a prolonged legal battle. Surgery for Gandolfini Delays 'Sopranos' Finale Fans of ''The Sopranos'' are going to have to wait even longer for the final eight episodes, Reuters reported. Chris Albrecht, the chairman and chief executive of HBO, said surgery to correct an old injury to the knee of James Gandolfini, above, who stars as the gangland boss Tony Soprano, led to a delay in production that would push the premiere from the previously announced Jan. 7 to as late as March. Angelina Jolie Is to Star As Journalist's Widow In a movie to be produced by her companion, Brad Pitt, Angelina Jolie, right, will star as Mariane Pearl, the wife of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was kidnapped in Pakistan in 2002 and beheaded, The Associated Press reported. The film, to be directed by Michael Winterbottom, will be adapted from Mrs. Pearl's book, ''A Mighty Heart: The Brave Life and Death of My Husband Danny Pearl.'' The film will be a production of Revolution Films and Plan B, founded and owned by Mr. Pitt and Jennifer Aniston. After a seven-year relationship, including five years of marriage, they were divorced last year, after he and Ms. Jolie made ''Mr. & Mrs. Smith'' together. Dates for the start and release were not announced. Footnotes Bruce Springsteen and his Seeger Sessions band will tour Europe in the fall to promote their album, ''We Shall Overcome'' (Columbia). The tour is to begin on Oct. 1 in Bologna, Italy, and end on Nov. 21 in Belfast, Northern Ireland, Billboard reported. The Brave New World Repertory Theater, which staged ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' on the front porches of Ditmas Park Street in Brooklyn last summer, will present a concert production of the Pulitzer Prize-winning Howard Sackler play ''The Great White Hope'' at 8 p.m. on Thursday at the Prospect Park Bandshell. The multimedia production will include live music by the ragtime pianist Roy Eaton as it tells the story of the heavyweight boxing champion Jack Johnson. The Public Theater announced that Kevin Kline would be taking the place of Christopher Walken in the Shakespeare in the Park production of ''Mother Courage and Her Children,'' which starts performances on Aug. 8.

Jeanine F. Pirro, the Republican candidate for state attorney general, said yesterday that her campaign had raised about $2.7 million in the last six months, one of the highest amounts raised by a candidate for attorney general in the current election cycle. Ms. Pirro, the former Westchester County district attorney, entered the race for attorney general in December, after abandoning her candidacy for United States Senate as a challenger to Hillary Rodham Clinton. She had raised no significant amount of money for the attorney general campaign before January.
